site_title: UK will not appoint new Bank of England chief before Dec 12 election: official
summary: The UK government will not name a new Bank of England chief before the December 12 national election, following a convention not to make major appointments in the run-up to elections. Governor Mark Carney's departure on January 31 is also the deadline for the UK to leave the European Union. The finance ministry prefers candidates such as former deputy governors Minouche Shafik or Paul Tucker, but has declined to comment on speculation. Finance Minister Sajid Javid is looking for an independent-minded new BoE governor.

images.alt_text: Britain's government will not name a successor to Bank of England Governor Mark Carney before a national election due on December 12, a finance ministry official said.

site_title: Billionaire families reshaping Silicon Valley's venture terrain
summary: Billionaire families are significantly increasing their venture capital investments in Silicon Valley, reshaping the landscape of venture investing. These family offices, which include prominent examples such as Tony James and Azim Premji, are pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into individual companies and are even independently institutionalizing their investments. The trend is driven by the availability of capital in the private market and the growing disruption in traditional industries. As a result, family offices are becoming increasingly powerful players in the venture ecosystem, with some allocating 60-70% of their balance sheet to venture investments.

site_title: China's Oct factory activity expands at fastest pace in over 2 years: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity expanded at its fastest pace in over 2 years in October, according to a private business survey, with the Caixin/Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.7 from 51.4 in September. New export orders rebounded into expansionary territory, driven by the US exempting more Chinese products from tariffs in September. The better-than-expected results contrast with an official survey showing China's factory activity shrinking for the sixth straight month.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity unexpectedly expanded at the fastest pace in well over two years in October as new export orders rose and plants ramped up production, a private business survey showed on Friday.

site_title: Ascendas Reit plans to buy 30 business park properties in US, Singapore for S$1.66b
summary: Ascendas Reit plans to acquire 30 business park properties in the US and Singapore for S$1.66 billion. The proposed transactions, conditional on approval, are expected to be completed in the fourth quarter this year. The acquisitions will boost Ascendas Reit's investment in the business and science park segment by 46% and increase its overseas investment to 28% of total asset value. The US properties will provide geographical diversification and fit with the manager's mandate of investing in developed markets, while the Singapore properties will deepen Ascendas Reit's presence in business parks and strengthen its portfolio.

site_title: Government officials around the globe targeted for hacking through WhatsApp: sources
summary: Government officials in at least 20 countries, including US allies, were targeted with hacking software that used WhatsApp to take over users' phones, according to a WhatsApp investigation. The hacking affected at least 1,400 users between April 29 and May 10, 2019, and included high-profile government and military officials. WhatsApp filed a lawsuit against Israeli hacking tool developer NSO Group, alleging it built a platform to exploit a flaw in WhatsApp's servers to hack into users' cellphones.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on fresh US-China tensions
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to fresh US-China trade tensions and a stronger yen, with the Nikkei 225 index easing 0.33% to 22,850.77. Investors took profits amid concerns over the ongoing trade dispute.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on a downward trend, falling 0.29% as China-US trade worries and recession data weighed on the market. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,829.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The recession data, which showed Hong Kong's economy had plunged into recession, added to the market's concerns.

site_title: China Sunsine warns of 'material decrease' in Q3 profit
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings expects a "material decrease" in Q3 net profit due to a decrease in product average selling prices. The company attributes this to China's slowing economic growth and lower raw material prices. Revenue is expected to be lower compared to last year's Q3. The company will release its Q3 results on November 7.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.84% to 22,734.32. Investors took profits on recent gains amid US-China trade tensions and a stronger yen. The broader Topix index also declined 0.74%.

site_title: 'From the internet up': Toronto plans futuristic bayfront
summary: Toronto authorities have given a provisional green light to Sidewalk Labs' plans to build a futuristic neighbourhood on a 5-hectare lakefront site. The carbon-neutral community, called "from the internet up," will feature robots for delivering mail and collecting garbage, heated sidewalks, and underground waste management. The project, valued at an estimated $1 billion, has faced criticism over data protection concerns but has been revised to include Canadian privacy laws and reduced in size. A final evaluation is pending before a formal decision in March 2020.

site_title: Indonesia's Oct inflation rate cools to 6-month low
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate slowed to 3.13% in October, the lowest level in six months, according to the statistics bureau. This rate is within Bank Indonesia's target range of 2.5-4.5% for the year. The slower inflation rate may provide relief to policymakers.

site_title: US Interior Department grounds Chinese-made drones
summary: The US Department of the Interior has grounded its fleet of 810 Chinese-made drones, pending a review of the programme. The decision comes amid US security concerns over Chinese electronics. Exceptions will be made for emergency purposes such as wildfires, search and rescue, and natural disasters. The review was ordered by Interior Secretary David Bernhardt, amid warnings from the US Department of Homeland Security about the security risks posed by Chinese-made drones.

site_title: Qantas finds cracks in three of its Boeing 737NG planes
summary: Qantas found hairline cracks in three of its Boeing 737NG planes, prompting removal from service for repair. This comes as airlines worldwide inspect their fleets of the troubled aircraft. The cracks were discovered in the pickle fork structure, a part that helps bind the wing to the fuselage. Boeing reported fewer than 5% of 1,000 planes with cracks were grounded, and other airlines, including Korean Air and Southwest, have also taken some 737NGs out of service. Qantas CEO Andrew David assured travellers the issue is not an immediate risk.

site_title: North Korea conducts new test of 'super-large' rocket launcher: KCNA
summary: North Korea has conducted a successful test of its "super-large multiple rocket launcher" system, launching two projectiles approximately 370km from South Pyongan province. The test, aimed at verifying the security of the launcher's continuous fire system, was overseen by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The launch is the latest in a series of provocations by Pyongyang, and if confirmed, would grant the North a submarine-based missile capability, potentially altering the military balance on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back amid unease over growth, trade
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday amid concerns over global growth and the US-China trade war, despite strong earnings reports from Apple and Facebook. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.3% and 0.1% respectively, while the Dow Jones shed 0.5%. Analysts attributed the pullback to the Federal Reserve's decision to hold off on further interest rate cuts and skepticism over a long-term trade deal between the US and China. Large industrial companies, such as Boeing and Caterpillar, also suffered losses.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished lower on Thursday as worries over global growth and the US-China trade war offset strong earnings reports from Apple and Facebook.

site_title: SembMarine bags Shell's floating production unit contract
summary: SembCorp Marine won a contract from Shell Offshore to build and integrate a floating production unit (FPU) for Shell's Whale field development in the Gulf of Mexico. The FPU, valued at 25,000 tonnes, is expected to be completed in 2022 and operate in the Alaminos Canyon Block 772. The contract does not significantly impact SembCorp Marine's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the year ending December 31, 2019.

site_title: Macau gaming revenue slips on weak Chinese economy, geopolitics
summary: Macau's gaming revenue declined 3.2% in October to 26.4 billion patacas, the lowest level in a year, due to a weakening Chinese economy and pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The mass segment failed to offset the decline in high rollers, who are staying away. The October results were pressured by factors such as the trade war, yuan weakening, social unrest, and regulatory uncertainty. The Bloomberg Intelligence index of Macau casino operators rose 9.9% in October, but remains down 17% from its high in April.

site_title: Watchdog sues FBI over facial recognition secrecy
summary: A civil liberties watchdog sued the FBI and other federal agencies over the government's secrecy on how it uses a facial recognition database of millions of Americans. The American Civil Liberties Union claims the public has a right to know how law enforcement agencies use face recognition technology and what safeguards are in place to protect rights. The lawsuit seeks information on the FBI's surveillance activities and the safeguards in place to prevent misuse of the technology.

site_title: Ascendas Reit raises Q2 DPU by 2.3% after UK acquisitions; calls for trading halt
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 2.3% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.978 Singapore cents, driven by overseas acquisitions in the UK. Gross revenue rose 5.3% to S$229.6 million, while net property income climbed 12% to S$177.9 million. The Reit also announced plans for a trading halt. The company's half-year DPU was 1.2% higher, and total income available for distribution grew 7% to S$248.5 million.

site_title: Australian shares edge higher, but suffer first weekly loss in three
summary: Australian shares rose on Friday, but ended the week with their first loss in three after a sell-off in banks. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to close at 6,669.1, despite a 1% drop over the week. Financials, led by the 'Big Four' banks, fell every day this week, dragging the index down.

images.alt_text: Australian shares ended higher on Friday, but a sell-off in banks this week dragged the benchmark to its first weekly loss in three.

site_title: Olam completes 120b naira acquisition of Nigeria flour and pasta maker
summary: Olam International has completed its acquisition of Dangote Flour Mills in Nigeria for 120 billion naira (S$450.4 million). The acquisition sees Crown Flour Mills, an Olam subsidiary, acquire all of Dangote's shares. Trading in Dangote shares has been suspended, and the company will be delisted from the Nigerian stock exchange's main board. The deal was adjusted from 130 billion naira following adjustments for Dangote's net working capital and net debt.

site_title: Nico Steel extends property lease for 20 years, to invest S$460,000 in machinery, equipment
summary: Nico Steel has extended its 20-year property lease at 51 Loyang Way, committing to develop the property and investing S$460,000 in machinery and equipment. The lease extension, starting January 1, 2023, will expire on December 31, 2042, with the company required to develop the property to a minimum gross floor area of 0.65 to 2.50. This move aims to enhance the company's operations and competitiveness in the industry.

site_title: Game Changer
summary: Hugo Boss CEO Mark Langer is shifting the brand's focus towards inclusivity and sustainability, particularly in China, where consumers have become a key driver in the luxury market. The company is showcasing its Pre-Fall 2020 collection in Shanghai, featuring soft and unfussy silhouettes, and has made a commitment to source sustainable cotton and create natural-leather alternatives. Langer aims to grow the business with a focus on sustainability, as evident in the brand's inclusion in the Dow Jones sustainability index for three years in a row.

site_title: PhillipCapital, Maybank Kim Eng among brokerages hit by recent DDoS attacks
summary: Several brokerages in Singapore, including PhillipCapital and Maybank Kim Eng, were hit by distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks on their online systems on October 24, causing disruptions to trading platforms. The attacks, which targeted up to five brokerages, resulted in varying levels of disruption, from 30 minutes to the entire early session of the Singapore market. Despite the disruptions, both PhillipCapital and Maybank Kim Eng confirmed that their clients' information and security were not compromised. The Monetary Authority of Singapore issued an advisory to alert financial institutions of a heightened risk of DDoS activities.

site_title: China airlines hit by slides in demand on routes to Hong Kong, Taiwan
summary: China's three largest airlines, China Eastern, China Southern, and Air China, experienced double-digit declines in demand on regional routes to Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Macau in September due to ongoing protests in Hong Kong and travel restrictions to Taiwan. Demand fell 21.1% for China Southern and 15.7% for Air China, with passenger yields potentially dropping 10% next year. The airlines offset this decline with increased profits, driven by the abolishment of a civil aviation airport development fee, with China Eastern and China Southern reporting a 9.8% and 17.2% increase in profits, respectively.

site_title: Filipino Food Trail
summary: A new illustrated book, "Kain Na! (Let's Eat): An Illustrated Guide to Philippine Food," provides a culinary tour of the Philippines, written by food historian Felice Prudente Santa Maria and food and travel writer Bryan Koh. The book showcases 12 chapters of Filipino dishes, from breakfast to street food, with a glossary of must-have ingredients. The book features watercolor and oil paintings of each dish, but no recipes, aiming to introduce readers to the rich and diverse Philippine cuisine. The authors hope to encourage readers to explore Filipino food further through cookbooks.

site_title: Fed rate cut and dovish signals a chance to let economy play out
summary: The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time in 2019, but also signaled a pause on additional cuts, citing the need to assess the economy's response. The move came as strong consumer data offset a slowdown in factory activity related to the trade war. The Fed characterized the rate cuts as insurance policies against global economic weakness. Investors are cautiously optimistic, with stocks rising slightly, but safe-haven Treasury bonds also rose, suggesting some investor nerves. The central bank's statement reduced expectations for near-term rate policy moves, shifting market focus away from the Fed.

site_title: Hong Kong banking giants defy dire predictions amid protests
summary: Hong Kong's banking giants, HSBC and Standard Chartered, have posted quarterly results showing business in the city is holding up despite civil unrest and protests. The city's former secretary for financial services, KC Chan, believes Hong Kong's financial markets will not lose their position as a global center due to the unrest. Despite predictions of a technical recession and potential capital outflow, the banks' results suggest the city's unique regulatory framework and laws remain a key draw for international investors, supporting the city's continued economic resilience.

site_title: Nintendo shares jump almost 7% after strong Switch Lite launch
summary: Nintendo shares surged almost 7% after the company reported strong demand for its Switch Lite console, with over 2 million units sold in 10 days following its September launch. The company's operating profit doubled in the second quarter. Nintendo also announced plans to test a multiplayer option for its Mario Kart Tour mobile game in December, a move aimed at boosting the title's revenues.

site_title: Keeping spirits up - and an eye on the job market - amid the current slowdown
summary: Singapore's industrial output unexpectedly grew 0.1% in September, beating forecasts of contraction, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. This positive reading is a glimmer of hope in the economic slowdown, but global uncertainty persists. The MAS notes that domestic confidence and labor conditions will be key to containing the weakness, with Tier 3 industries showing a marginally higher 2.1% decline compared to Tier 2 industries. The MAS expects modest growth to improve in 2020, but warns of continued headwinds and month-to-month fluctuations in data.

site_title: HK home prices down for 4th consecutive month in September
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.8% in September, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, amid ongoing US-China trade dispute and anti-government protests. Despite this, home prices have still increased 5.9% so far in 2019. Analysts expect prices to continue falling next year, but a low interest rate environment may provide support. The decline is attributed to the city's financial turmoil, but property prices remain resilient compared to tourism and retail sectors.

site_title: Return Of The Crooner
summary: Engelbert Humperdinck, a renowned British crooner, is set to perform in Singapore as part of his The Angel On My Shoulder World Tour. The concert will take place at the University Cultural Centre at National University of Singapore on November 5. Tickets range from S$78 to S$168. This will be Humperdinck's return to Singapore, where he has entertained fans for over half a decade.

images.alt_text: Engelbert Humperdinck plays University Cultural Centre at National University of Singapore on Nov 5 at 8pm.

site_title: Australia: Shares lead lower by banking sector; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, led by a decline in banking sector shares after ANZ reported disappointing financial results and reduced franking credits. Westpac, Commonwealth Bank, and National Australia Bank also fell. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,642.5. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.3%. The decline was partly attributed to concerns about a potential Sino-US trade deal and uncertainty in global markets.

images.alt_text: Australian shares slipped on Friday, pulled lower by heavweight banking shares after disappointing financial results from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group.

site_title: Singapore, Shandong to boost business collaboration
summary: Singapore and Shandong province have launched a platform to boost business collaboration, with Singapore firms offering financing, listing, and legal advice to Shandong companies seeking to internationalize. The platform, set to be launched by mid-2024, will be supported by Enterprise Singapore and the Qingdao Bureau of Commerce, with participating firms including OCBC, UOB, and the Singapore Exchange. This initiative aims to increase trade and investment between the two regions.

site_title: Going under the hammer
summary: Singapore properties are being put up for auction at a record high, indicating a surge in bank foreclosures in the residential and retail sectors. Online travel booking giant Expedia is expanding its services, and a new article discusses the company's growth and its CEO's vision. In other news, a new bubble tea cocktail trend has emerged, and a BMW car model has been redesigned to improve its quality and uniqueness. Additionally, articles cover topics such as corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainable living, highlighting various aspects of the business and lifestyle world.

site_title: Demand soars for basic semi-automated driving features
summary: Aptiv Plc, an auto supplier, is experiencing soaring demand for semi-automated driving features due to the high cost and complexity of fully self-driving technology. The company has contracts with seven automakers to provide basic driver assistance packages, including automated emergency braking and lane keeping assist, at a cost of $700-$1,000 per vehicle. This demand is expected to generate $500 million in revenue for Aptiv by 2025, as part of its goal to develop fully self-driving car technology by 2022.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,228.29, down 0.05% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,228.29, down 0.05% on Friday, with 505.9 million securities worth S$468.4 million changing hands. Losers beat gainers 147 to 141. Notable movers included Rex International, TEE International, and Sasseur Reit, while UOB and DBS traded down despite reporting stronger quarterly results. Asian markets were mixed due to US-China trade war concerns, with Hong Kong, Seoul, and Sydney rising, while Tokyo and Jakarta fell.

site_title: Monday Meal Deals
summary: Indigo Blue Kitchen, a Peranakan restaurant by the Les Amis group, offers a one-for-one set lunch at $36 and 15% off menu items until Nov 18. The restaurant has added new dishes, including babi pongteh, udang masak nanas, and lobster gulai. To celebrate the start of the work week, customers can also enjoy steamed glutinous rice topped with durian, kaya, or inti. The promotion is available at #03-09/10/11, Shaw Centre.

images.alt_text: Indigo Blue Kitchen is at #03-09/10/11, Shaw Centre

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.69 points to 1,595.29. The market saw 113.14 million lots traded at RM18.68 million, with 88 gainers beating 83 losers.

site_title: Cages, pods and containers: 8 homes highlighting cities' housing strains
summary: A global housing shortage forces people to live in unconventional dwellings such as shipping containers, concrete pipes, and plywood bunk beds. At least 150 million people, or 2% of the global population, are homeless, with many living in cities. Unconventional housing solutions include sleep pods in cities like London and New York, and tiny wooden houses in Paris backyards. In the US, homeowners are converting basements and garages into small living units, while in Hong Kong, micro homes are being built in concrete water pipes to ease the housing crisis.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hug hefty weekly gains despite trade jitters
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw significant weekly gains despite trade jitters. A Chinese manufacturing report showed factory activity expanded at its fastest pace in over two years, offsetting concerns over Sino-US trade talks. The Aussie edged up to US$0.6905, 1.2% higher for the week, and is now above the week's low of US$0.6811.

site_title: Switch Lite sales help Nintendo beat profit estimates
summary: Nintendo reported a fiscal second-quarter profit of 66.8 billion yen ($840 million), beating analyst estimates, driven by strong Switch Lite sales and software sales. The company sold 4.8 million Switch units, a 50% gain, and 35.9 million software titles, a 48% increase. Nintendo's full-year profit and revenue outlooks remain unchanged, with the company expecting 260 billion yen in operating profit and 1.25 trillion yen in revenue for the year ending March 2020.

site_title: US immigration system needs fixing, but Trump's hostile approach is not the solution
summary: The US immigration system is in need of reform, but President Donald Trump's approach is not the solution. The current system is broken, with concerns including inhumane treatment of migrants, a shortage of qualified immigration judges, and long delays for green-card holders. Trump's claims of an immigration emergency are not credible, as immigrants have been coming to the US since its inception. In fact, the majority of foreign-born residents in the US are documented, and undocumented workers contribute disproportionately to productivity growth. The administration's focus on a border wall is misguided, as it will not curb illegal immigration or address the root causes of migration.

site_title: JTC to build new semiconductor facility in Tampines, refurbish 4 wafer fab parks
summary: JTC Corporation is building a new semiconductor facility in Tampines, with the first phase set to be completed by 2021. The company is also refurbishing its four wafer fabrication parks, adding greenery and connecting them to the islandwide Park Connector Network. This move aims to boost the electronics sector in Singapore, despite global uncertainties, and capitalize on emerging opportunities in areas like artificial intelligence and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Now you too can experience Hong Kong Protest violence, virtually
summary: A new virtual reality game, "Liberate Hong Kong," simulates the experience of a pro-democracy protester in Hong Kong's protests. The game, developed by a group of students and office workers, allows players to navigate the city's streets, avoiding police tear gas and live ammunition. The game aims to educate players about the protests, which began in the summer, and has been released in both PC and virtual reality versions. The developers plan to donate all profits to a fundraiser for protesters and have submitted the game to Steam for approval.

site_title: Resources Prima CFO quits less than 1 year into job
summary: Resources Prima Group, a Catalist-listed Indonesian coal miner, announced that CFO Thng Tien Lung will leave the company on Dec 7, citing other career opportunities. Lam is serving a two-month notice period and will cease to be a director for three subsidiaries. The company is searching for a replacement and will make an announcement when a suitable candidate is appointed, following a period of restructuring since its trading suspension in 2017.

site_title: Tesco vows to remove 1b pieces of plastic packaging by end-2020
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, has pledged to remove one billion pieces of plastic packaging from its UK stores by the end of 2020. The move aims to reduce its environmental impact and meet growing consumer demand for less waste. Tesco plans to eliminate hard-to-recycle materials from its own brand products, replace small plastic bags with paper ones, and remove plastic trays, lids, and straws from products. The company is also working with suppliers to reduce packaging and will inform suppliers that products with excessive or hard-to-recycle materials will no longer be stocked.

site_title: China to use import fair to highlight trade credentials
summary: China is hosting the China International Import Expo (CIIE) in Shanghai, a week-long event aimed at showcasing its free trade credentials and deepening its global economic influence amid the China-US trade war. The event, which features over 3,000 companies and foreign leaders, comes as the US has expressed skepticism about China's trade policies. Despite criticisms that the expo is mostly symbolic, China sees it as a key tool to cast its economy in a new light and bolster its global role, with Chinese President Xi Jinping set to deliver opening remarks.

site_title: Ford reaches deal with UAW on new pact, averting a strike
summary: Ford Motor Co. reached a tentative agreement with the United Auto Workers (UAW) union, averting a potential strike. The new labor contract includes $6 billion in US product investment and the creation of over 8,500 jobs. This deal is seen as a significant relief for Ford, as a strike would have cost the company billions of dollars, unlike its rival General Motors Co. which faced a costly strike earlier.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: iFast Corporation, a digital bank, reported a 5.5% drop in net profit to S$2.5 million for its third quarter ended Sept 30, due to increased investments in platform capabilities. Revenue rose 7.6% to S$33.8 million, driven by higher contributions from two main business divisions. Earnings per share decreased 6% to 0.92 Singapore cent.

site_title: Crypto firm Luno plans Singapore reboot after bank accounts opened
summary: Crypto firm Luno plans to restart digital wallet and trading services in Singapore using Singapore dollars within a month after two local banks opened corporate accounts for the firm. Luno had halted Singapore activities two years ago due to bank account closures. The company's existing bank accounts don't allow it to hold client money, a major hurdle for crypto-exchange operators. Luno's expansion in Singapore is seen as a positive sign for the industry, with the company welcoming new legislation that regulates cryptocurrency transactions.

site_title: 154.6m new Mapletree Logistics Trust units to start trading on Nov 1
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) will issue 154.6 million new units on Nov 1, priced at S$1.617 apiece, to fund acquisitions of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China. The new units will increase the total MLT units in issue to 3.8 billion. Holders of the private placement units will not receive the full cumulative distribution, and MLT units closed at S$1.68 on Thursday, down 0.6%.

site_title: Sygnum gets MAS go-ahead for asset-management ops
summary: Sygnum, a Singapore- and Switzerland-based tokenisation startup, has obtained a capital markets services licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). With the licence, Sygnum will conduct asset-management activities in Singapore, focusing on digital-asset investment strategies for accredited and institutional investors. The firm's first product offering, a multi-manager fund, is planned for launch. Sygnum's regulatory compliance and oversight in Singapore and Switzerland form the foundation of its business, with a board of directors and advisory council consisting of notable figures from Singapore and Switzerland.

site_title: WeWork, former CEO Adam Neumann accused of pregnancy discrimination
summary: WeWork's former CEO Adam Neumann has been accused of pregnancy discrimination by his former chief of staff, Medina Bardhi. Bardhi claims she faced discrimination after announcing her pregnancy in 2016, including being replaced by a man with a higher salary after taking maternity leave. She also alleged that Neumann's marijuana use on chartered planes posed a risk to her unborn baby's health. Bardhi filed a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, alleging a hostile work environment and unequal treatment.

site_title: JPMorgan stock pickers bet on Thai tourism in 'ignored' South-east Asia
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management sees investment opportunities in South-east Asia, particularly in Thailand's tourism sector. The region's stock markets have "selective investment opportunities" despite Wall Street's ignoring them. Thailand's tourism has seen an increase in visitors from Indian and other nations, benefiting from the growth. JPMorgan has invested in airports and medical tourism, citing these sectors as promising areas, with shares in Airports of Thailand Pcl rising 23% this year. The region's growth is slowing, but tourism remains a "bright spot".

images.alt_text: South-east Asian stock markets still have "selective investment opportunities" even though Wall Street is ignoring them, according to JPMorgan Asset Management.

site_title: HSBC cuts HK prime rate for first time in 11 years
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc cut its Hong Kong prime lending rate by 12.5 basis points to 5% for the first time in 11 years, amid economic challenges in the financial hub. The move comes as the city's government is expected to release data showing a technical recession in the third quarter. The retail and tourism sectors have been heavily impacted by almost five months of anti-government protests.

site_title: Oil prices decline on weak Chinese data, US pipeline problems
summary: Oil prices declined on Thursday due to weak Chinese factory activity and US pipeline disruptions. Brent futures fell 0.6% to $60.23, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.6% to $54.18. The disruptions, combined with a bearish outlook from US President Trump's tariff policies, led to the price drop. The front-month Brent contract expired on Thursday, settling at $59.62 for January delivery.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Thursday after data showed weak factory activity in China, with US crude facing extra pressure after flows out of the Cushing, Oklahoma storage hub were disrupted because of reduced flows on a pipeline.

site_title: Lawsuit accuses Facebook ad targeting of abetting bias
summary: A lawsuit has been filed in San Francisco federal court accusing Facebook of allowing ad targeting tools to exclude women and older people from financial services ads. Two law firms are representing a 54-year-old woman in a potential class-action suit, arguing that women and older individuals should have equal access to financial services advertised on the platform. The lawsuit claims Facebook's ad targeting tools have been used to discriminate against these groups, violating their rights to full and equal services.

images.alt_text: A lawsuit filed on Thursday accuses Facebook of letting ad targeting tools be used to exclude women and older people from offers regarding loans, investments and other financial services.

site_title: Uptick in sentiment for factories: govt survey
summary: Singapore businesses show mixed sentiment for the next six months, with a 5% net weighted balance of manufacturers expecting business to worsen, a 1% increase from the previous quarter. The biomedical manufacturing cluster boosted factories, while the electronics cluster saw a 7% net weighted balance, an improvement from 24% previously. Services outlook remains positive, with a 1% increase in expected business improvement, despite a slip in the previous quarter. Economists anticipate a potential recovery, citing factors like tourism-related service activity and Asian Currency Unit loans.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed but trade standoff back in spotlight
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, with the China-US trade talks back in focus after Beijing officials raised doubts about a long-term deal. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's speech, calling China "truly hostile," led to accusations from Beijing. Despite this, top-level phone talks are set to take place later Friday, with investors watching the developments closely. The US stock market, however, edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed on Friday but about the China-US trade talks returned to the fore after a report said Beijing officials had raised doubts about the chances of a long-term deal.

site_title: SIA could be flying higher for Q2 if not for its woeful associates
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) may show improved operating profits in Q2, driven by stronger passenger loads, despite a weak cargo market. The airline's flagship carrier, Singapore Airlines, and budget carrier Scoot saw passenger load factors rise, with SilkAir expected to continue losses due to the grounding of its Boeing 737 Max 8 planes. However, risks remain from associates, including Virgin Australia and Vistara, which may impact the group's bottom line, analysts warn.

site_title: White Truffle Affair
summary: The World Alba White Truffle Auction will be held on November 10 at Aura, National Gallery Singapore, with a charity dinner auction featuring a specially curated menu by chef-owner Beppe De Vito. Proceeds will be donated to a Singapore charity, with a portion also going to a charity in Moscow. The auction dinner is priced at S$420++ per person, including wine, and reservations are available at 68661977.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.46% to 3,215.13
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.46% to 3,215.13 at Friday's open, tracking weaker Asian markets amid US-China trade worries. Losers outnumbered gainers 66 to 51, with notable declines in Rex International Holding and P5 Capital Holdings. Despite this, Sembcorp Marine rose 1.5% after winning a contract from Shell Offshore. Other active index stocks included Mapletree Commercial Trust and Singtel, which declined 0.6% and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: Europe: Autos, miners keep shares in the red as trade jitters resurface
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Thursday, despite a second straight monthly gain, due to losses for miners and automakers amid trade uncertainty between the US and China. The Stoxx 600 index ended the session lower, with oil and gas producers, including Royal Dutch Shell, down 1.7% after the company warned of slower share buyback plans. Tariff-exposed miners and automakers also fell, while some sectors, such as healthcare and utilities, saw gains. The US Federal Reserve's decision to lower borrowing costs earlier in the week failed to lift markets.

site_title: UK Brexit accord rules out trade deal with US: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit divorce deal, stating it makes a future trade deal between the two countries impossible. Trump contradicts his previous pledge to work on a "magnificent trade deal" with Johnson. Johnson's deal has been met with deadlock in parliament, and he hopes a general election will help him secure a majority to pass enabling legislation. Trump suggested forming an electoral pact with Johnson to avoid splitting the pro-Brexit vote, but only if Johnson drops the deal.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Thursday criticised British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit divorce deal, saying it made it impossible to strike a future commercial agreement with the United States.

site_title: Keppel Land invests US$25m in India-based coworking operator
summary: Keppel Land, a Singapore-based property arm, has invested US$25 million in India-based coworking operator Smartworks Coworking Space. This investment allows Keppel Land to enter India's growing flexible office market, where leasing activity rose 52% year on year in the first half of 2019. Smartworks provides flexible spaces for enterprise companies and plans to grow its footprint to 20 million sq ft over the next five years. The investment opens opportunities for collaboration between Smartworks and Keppel Land's smart serviced co-office platform KLOUD.

site_title: African Development Bank announces record capital increase to US$208b
summary: The African Development Bank (AfDB) announced a record capital increase of US$208 billion, a 125% jump from its previous capital of US$93 billion. This historic increase, approved by the bank's board of governors, will provide the institution with significant resources to further develop the African continent. AfDB President Akinwumi Adesina hailed the move as "a day of joy for Africa." The increased capital will enable the bank to support the continent's economic growth and development.

images.alt_text: The African Development Bank on Thursday announced the largest capital increase in its history, with an almost 125 per cent jump from US$93 billion to US$208 billion.

site_title: Consumer spending up slightly in Sept
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in September, driven by increased purchases of motor vehicles and healthcare, while wages remained unchanged. This slight increase in spending, accounting for over two-thirds of the US economy, suggests consumers are still supporting the economy despite a deepening slump in business investment. The economy grew at a 1.9% rate in the third quarter, with inflation remaining tame, and the Federal Reserve signaled a pause in its interest rate-cutting cycle.

site_title: IndoAgri sinks into the red with 125.68b rupiah loss for Q3
summary: IndoAgri, a Singapore-based agribusiness, reported a net loss of 125.68 billion rupiah (S$12.2 million) for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2019, due to weak commodity prices. Revenue fell 3.1% to 3.59 trillion rupiah, with losses from associate companies and joint ventures. The company attributed the losses to ongoing US-China trade tensions and volatile commodity prices, particularly for crude palm oil. No dividend was declared for the current period, and the company will review this at the end of the year.

site_title: CAO profit up 26% for Q3 on lower expenses
summary: CAO (China Aviation Oil) reported a 26% rise in net profit to US$23.9 million for its Q3, driven by higher gross profit and lower operating expenses. Revenue fell 12.2% to US$5.56 billion due to lower oil prices. Gross profit rose 47.1% to US$16.3 million, while total expenses halved to US$3.8 million. The company declared no dividend for the quarter. CEO Wang Yanjun emphasized the group's focus on driving long-term profitability and investing in synergetic assets for sustainable growth.

site_title: South Korea Oct factory activity shrinks for 6th month as new export orders return to contraction
summary: South Korea's factory activity contracted for the sixth consecutive month in October, according to a private business survey, with the Nikkei/Markit PMI inching up to 48.4 from 48.0 in September. New export orders slipped back into contraction after expanding the previous month, with weaker sales reported to Japan, China, Taiwan, and Europe. The contraction was at a slightly slower pace than the previous month, but the economy remains vulnerable to cooling global demand and trade tensions.

site_title: 1 HDB flat for 2 condos? Such sales tack plays down risks
summary: Singapore property agents are promoting a "sell one, buy two" strategy, where homeowners sell their HDB flats to invest in two condominiums. However, market watchers caution against this approach due to potential risks, including changes in the economic environment, property value depreciation, and the impact on mortgage servicing if one spouse loses their job. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warns that households should be aware of these risks and consider their financial stability before making such a move.

site_title: A VUE to a grill
summary: VUE, a penthouse restaurant in Singapore, has revamped its concept and menu after rebranding from Me@OUE. The restaurant offers a strong emphasis on grill-cooking, with a menu that showcases dishes such as oysters, wagyu beef, and grilled lamb chops. The USP is that VUE buys the whole cow, allowing for a more transparent and flavorful dining experience. The restaurant's focus on beautiful surroundings and a curated menu has earned it a 7/10 rating, with reviewers praising its grounded approach and attention to detail.

site_title: Trump hotel sale is tied to claims of conflict
summary: The Trump Organization is exploring the sale of its Washington hotel due to concerns over potential conflicts of interest with international guests. According to Donald Trump Jr., the decision is related to "all international business." This move comes amid claims of conflicts of interest.

site_title: New Wave Korean Cuisine
summary: Seoul is gaining recognition as a dining destination, with fine dining chefs modernizing classic Korean cuisine. Chefs such as Cho Hee-Suk and Shin Chang Ho are taking risks to express their originality, resulting in a new wave of "mod-Korean" cuisine. Modern palace dining, deconstructed Korean cuisine, and high-end Korean barbecue are among the trends. Restaurants like Hansikgonggan, Joo Ok, and Born & Bred are showcasing traditional Korean techniques and ingredients in innovative ways, attracting both local and international guests.

site_title: Up to 50 737NG planes grounded globally over cracks, says Boeing
summary: Boeing announced that up to 50 of its 737NG planes have been grounded globally due to cracks detected in the "pickle fork" part, which helps bind the wing to the fuselage. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) initially ordered checks on planes that had flown over 30,000 times. Airlines such as Qantas and Southwest have pulled planes from service for repairs, with Qantas stating that passengers have nothing to fear. Boeing is working with customers to develop a repair plan and provide technical support.

site_title: Taste Of Opera
summary: A 90-minute Beijing opera performance, Operatic Identities, combines immersive singing with a Chinese mixology experience. The event, led by Tian Ping, transforms opera into a contemporary, interactive experience where audience members participate. Award-winning mixologist Paul Zhang creates cocktails inspired by famous opera characters. A music showcase is also available for those who prefer to focus on the singing. Operatic Identities runs on Nov 9-10 at the China Culture Centre.

site_title: New York bans foie gras on animal cruelty grounds
summary: New York City has voted to ban foie gras in October 2022, citing animal cruelty grounds. The ban prohibits the sale, serving, or possession of the French delicacy, which is made by force-feeding ducks and geese. The move follows a similar ban in California and comes after the US Supreme Court upheld a ban in California in January. Foie gras farmers claim that force-feeding is not cruel, but animal rights activists have long supported the ban. The law is expected to affect the state's two major producers and may lead to a shift towards alternative methods of replicating foie gras.

site_title: Tough As Steel
summary: Casio's G-Shock has released the New Generation Origins GM-5600, a metallic makeover of its iconic square model. The collection features three watches with metal bezels and resin bands, omitting solar power, Bluetooth, and Multi Band 6 capabilities, resulting in a significantly lower retail price. The steel bezel and black band combo is the most classic, while the camo dial, black ion-plated bezel, and khaki band combo is designed for the urban jungle. The GM-5600 collection is a more affordable alternative to the GMW-B5000, priced around S$259.

site_title: BOJ keeps current policy unchanged, but hints at rate cuts in the future
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its current monetary policy unchanged but hinted at possible interest rate cuts in the future, citing fears of global risks weighing on Japan's fragile recovery. The BOJ lowered its inflation forecasts, expecting 0.7% growth in 2020, and cut its economic growth forecasts to 0.6% for 2020 and 0.7% for the following year. The central bank warned that a pick-up in the global economy is likely to be delayed due to US-China trade friction and slowdowns in emerging economies.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) held fire on monetary policy on Thursday but hinted at possible interest rate cuts in the future, reflecting its fears that global risks could weigh on the country's fragile recovery.

site_title: China's state telcos to launch 5G services on Friday
summary: China's three state telcos, China Mobile, China Unicom, and China Telecom, announced the launch of 5G mobile phone services nationwide, starting from Friday, October 31, 2019. The services, priced from 128 yuan (S$25) a month, will support new features like autonomous driving and will have a significant impact on the global supply chain. Authorities plan to install over 50,000 5G base stations across 50 Chinese cities by the end of the year, with big cities already covered.

site_title: Ex-Apple executive joins startup aimed at banishing smartphone cables
summary: Ex-Apple executive Rubén Caballero joins Silicon Valley startup Keyssa Inc to develop a chip that can transfer data wirelessly, potentially eliminating smartphone cables. Keyssa's chip uses high frequencies to transmit data without interference, and the company has raised over $100 million from prominent investors. Caballero aims to apply his experience overseeing Apple's wireless engineering team to commercialize the technology, which has already been tested with LG Electronics and other companies.

site_title: India should take the RCEP route to trade integration
summary: India is considering joining the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free-trade agreement, despite concerns over trade deficits with several member countries. The agreement, which involves 15 countries, aims to create a $2.8 trillion trading area. India's demands to shift the base year for tariff cuts and introduce a tariff differential mechanism to prevent cheap imports from China have been met with resistance from other RCEP member states. The Indian government believes joining the RCEP is crucial for India's economic growth and competitiveness in the global market, while domestic producers worry about the impact of tariff cuts on their industries.

site_title: Fiat and PSA tie-up will pool resources to face expensive future
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and PSA Group have agreed to combine resources to face the challenges of trade tariffs, emissions rules, and electrification. The deal, which will create the fourth-largest automaker, will pool resources and reduce costs by 3.7 billion euros. Shareholders will own 50% of the combined entity, listed in Paris, Milan, and New York, with cost savings projected to be significant. The tie-up aims to create a regional powerhouse to challenge Volkswagen AG and help automakers finance major transformation in the industry.

site_title: Fire engulfs World Heritage castle on Japan's Okinawa island
summary: A major fire engulfed the 500-year-old Shuri Castle on Japan's Okinawa island, destroying large parts of the World Heritage site. The blaze started before 3am and spread quickly to nearby buildings, with all three main buildings burning down. The cause of the fire is unknown, and no reports of injuries have been made. The complex was largely destroyed during World War II, but was extensively restored and reopened as a national park in 1992.

site_title: Bombardier sells Belfast, Casablanca, Dallas operations for US$1.2b
summary: Bombardier sold its aerostructures business to Spirit AeroSystems for $1.2 billion, involving operations in Belfast, Casablanca, and Dallas. The Canadian manufacturing group announced the sale last May as part of a restructuring to focus on trains and business aircraft. The deal includes the assembly of Airbus A220 wings in Belfast and will see Spirit AeroSystems take over operations in Casablanca and Dallas.

site_title: UK lawmakers want bank payments 'speed bump' to stop scammers
summary: UK lawmakers recommend a 24-hour delay on all first-time payments from one bank account to another to cut mounting finance fraud, which cost consumers over 600 million pounds in the first half of 2019. The delay would allow customers or their banks to verify transactions, preventing scammers from quickly diverting funds. The proposal, which aims to prevent instant money transfers, could be implemented by March 2020, with regulators facing sanctions if banks fail to comply.

site_title: GIC-backed travel app Traveloka eyes dual listing, bets on fintech
summary: Traveloka, Southeast Asia's largest online travel startup, is considering a dual listing in Indonesia and another center, such as the US, to boost profits. The company, backed by Expedia, JD.Com, and Singapore's GIC, has 35 million active users and plans to expand into financial services, targeting "under-banked" Indonesian customers. Traveloka aims to raise $500 million and is valued at $4.5 billion, with its financial services business expected to reach $1 billion next year.

site_title: Energy giants face 35% output cut to hit Paris climate goals: watchdog
summary: Energy giants must reduce oil and gas output by 35% by 2040 to meet Paris climate goals, according to a Britain-based think tank. Current emissions rates would see the world's carbon budget surpassed within decades, and major oil and gas companies must cut production to limit temperature rises to "well below" 2°C and a safer cap of 1.5°C. Companies such as ConocoPhillips and Shell face significant production cuts, with ExxonMobil needing a 55% reduction, while others like ENI and Chevron face 40% and 35% cuts respectively.

site_title: For many widows, the hardest part is meal time
summary: Michele Zawadzki, a 68-year-old widow, struggles to cope with mealtime after her 47-year marriage ended. She faces triggers everywhere, including shopping for food her late husband loved. Support groups like Culinary Grief Therapy, founded by Heather Nickrand, aim to help widows adjust to cooking and eating alone. The program uses demonstrations and group discussions to teach participants how to cook, eat, and shop for one. Many widows face challenges such as weight gain or loss, and difficulties adjusting to new routines, including eating alone or at restaurants.

images.alt_text: Widows learning to prepare a straightforward meal that would be easy to make at home. The class was run recently at Culinary Grief Therapy in a Chicago suburb. For a spouse accustomed to sharing every meal with a partner, the grieving can go on and on.

site_title: Trump to move permanent residence to Florida
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he will move his permanent residence from New York to Palm Beach, Florida, citing being "treated very badly" by city and state leaders despite paying millions in taxes. Trump expressed his appreciation for New York, but stated he had been "disrespected" by local politicians. The decision was made through a tweet, with no further details provided.

site_title: LVMH-backed private equity firm closes US$1.45 billion Asia fund
summary: L Catterton, a US$15 billion private equity firm backed by LVMH, has closed its third Asia fund, L Catterton Asia 3, at US$1.45 billion, exceeding its target. The fund will focus on retail and healthcare companies in first-tier cities across Asia, with an average deal size of US$100 million. Managing partner Chinta Bhagat believes that cities, not countries, drive business growth in the region, citing 50-60% of GDP in these cities. The fund will run for 10 years and aims to offset challenges from trade wars and economic slowdowns in China.

site_title: Gojek, Grab waging a price war on everyday groceries in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing apps Gojek and Grab are waging a price war on everyday groceries, offering discounts of up to 50% on purchases made online or with e-wallets. This competition has helped keep inflation low, easing to 3.1% in October, allowing the central bank to cut interest rates four times this year. The move is expected to keep prices down, supporting the economy amid a global slowdown.

site_title: Slowing growth, tighter emission standards likely to shrink China's auto market by about 8% in 2019
summary: China's auto market is expected to contract by about 8% in 2019, with sales forecast to reach 26 million units, according to a senior industry executive. The prediction is due to slowing economic growth and tighter vehicle emissions standards. This marks a second consecutive year of contraction for the market. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) had previously forecast a 5% drop. The contraction is expected to be caused by a combination of these factors.

site_title: South Korea searches for survivors of helicopter crash off disputed islands
summary: South Korea is searching for seven missing passengers of a helicopter that crashed into the sea off the disputed Dokdo islets. The Airbus Helicopters H225 aircraft, carrying a patient to a hospital, crashed shortly after takeoff from Dokdo on Thursday. South Korea's Defence Ministry has sent vessels, planes, and divers to scour the ocean for survivors. The crash occurred on a long-range and all-weather search and rescue aircraft, which entered service with the fire department in 2016.

site_title: Court dismisses appeal against Australia's New Hope's Acland coal project
summary: Australia's New Hope Corp's Acland coal project has won a court dismissal of an appeal against the granting of licenses for the New Acland Coal Stage 3 project. The activist group Oakey Coal Action Alliance had appealed the decision in favor of the project. New Hope welcomed the ruling, stating there is no further barrier to the Queensland Government granting final approvals. The project is expected to create A$7 billion in economic activity over 15 years and will provide certainty for the current workforce, following the layoff of 150 workers due to delays.

site_title: URA launches tender for housing site at Irwell Bank Road
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 99-year leasehold site at Irwell Bank Road for sale by public tender. The site, spanning 12,789 sq m, can yield approximately 445 residential units with a maximum building height of 36 storeys. The tender, part of the government land sales (GLS) programme, closes on January 9, 2020. Experts predict a cautious bidding process, with four to six bids, and a top bid in the S$650-680 million range, translating to S$1,700-1,770 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: The rise of innovative edu-districts
summary: Education districts are emerging as innovative hubs, reflecting the shift from industrial to knowledge-based digital economies. These "edu-districts" have been present for centuries, but their proliferation is a recent phenomenon. Education-oriented urban environments can be socio-economic lifeblood of a city, supporting growth and prosperity. Historically, centers of learning attracted scholars, creating catalysts for neighborhood and community growth, which in turn enhanced industry and trade. Today, edu-districts are driving progress and offering opportunities for individuals to find meaning and understanding in the world.

site_title: UOB extends S$140m in green loans to real estate SMEs
summary: UOB has provided its first green loans under its new real estate sustainable finance framework, extending S$140 million to two companies, Lucrum Capital and Teambuild Engineering & Construction, to finance the construction and operation of their green buildings in Singapore. The framework aims to support sustainability-related projects for the property sector, making it easier for small- and medium-sized enterprises to access green financing. This move aligns with Singapore's target for 80% of buildings to be certified green by 2030.

site_title: Kellyanne Conway: Trump's fierce media pugilist
summary: Kellyanne Conway, a senior White House official and presidential counselor, is known for her sharp tongue and loyalty to President Donald Trump. She has been a key defender of the president, often clashing with journalists during press conferences and maintaining a strong public presence on Trump's favored TV network, Fox News. Despite her own husband's criticisms of Trump's mental fitness, Conway remains steadfast in her support, frequently countering criticism with her own attacks on the media and journalists.

site_title: HK plunges into first recession since the global financial crisis
summary: Hong Kong has officially entered its first recession since the global financial crisis, with the city's gross domestic product shrinking 3.2% in the third quarter compared to the previous period. The recession is attributed to months of pro-democracy protests and the US-China trade war, which have significantly impacted the city's tourist and entertainment industries. Year-on-year GDP also shrank 2.9%, its sharpest drop in a decade, with retail figures falling 23% in August and expected to drop further in September.

images.alt_text: Overseas visitors have fallen by as much as 40 per cent, especially from mainland China which accounts for 80 per cent of the city's tourists.

site_title: US House lawmakers secure enough votes to pass Trump impeachment rules
summary: US House lawmakers have secured enough votes to pass legislation setting up next steps in the impeachment process involving President Donald Trump. The impeachment inquiry focuses on whether Trump pressured Ukraine into helping him in his 2020 re-election campaign. The eventual articles of impeachment would be drafted by the Judiciary Committee for a final floor vote to impeach the president, which would then be decided by the Republican-led Senate.

site_title: Mazda braces for 30% FY profit drop on falling car sales in US, China: Nikkei
summary: Mazda Motor Corp expects a 30% drop in annual profit to 60 billion yen (S$754.6 million) due to falling sales in the US and China, its largest markets. This would be a seven-year low, with operating profit forecasted to be half of its previous estimate. Demand for Mazda vehicles has slumped since record sales in 2018, amid a global sales slowdown caused by a trade war and slowing growth in China.

images.alt_text: Mazda Motor Corp is facing a drop in annual profit of about 30 per cent as the Japanese automaker struggles with falling sales in the United States and China, its biggest markets, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Friday.

site_title: Euro rises as US dollar weakens on rate cuts
summary: The euro rose 0.1% to $1.1161 against the US dollar, following the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates for the third time this year, which weakened the dollar. The US dollar index fell to 97.29, its lowest in a week, while the Chinese offshore yuan rose to an 11-week high against the dollar. Despite the euro's gains, data expected to show the eurozone's GDP growth slowed and inflation rate fell in the third quarter may weigh on the euro later.

site_title: Old Is Gold
summary: A Singaporean couple, Chin Sing Ping and Sharon Tay, purchased a dilapidated pre-war shophouse in the Joo Chiat Conservation Area with the intention of restoring it to their own preferences. Keith Khoo of EZRA Architects oversaw the conservation work, adhering to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's guidelines. The facade was retained, and original features such as windows, terracotta floor tiles, and timber rafters were preserved. The restoration also included the addition of a loft, double volume dining room, and rooftop garden. The project earned a Special Mention at the URA Architectural Heritage Awards.

site_title: Asian reserve managers navigate increasingly complex risks
summary: Asian reserve managers face increasingly complex risks as global economic uncertainty deepens due to trade tensions and rising geopolitical tensions. To diversify and achieve returns, they are investing in "riskier" asset classes such as equities, commodities, and corporate credits, with gold regaining popularity as a reserve asset. With growing reserves, reserve managers must balance liquidity, concentration, and return considerations, and assess adequacy against various objectives, while navigating emerging risks and new challenges like cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Rex unit completes deal for 30% stake in 2 Norwegian Sea drilling licences
summary: REX International's unit Lime Petroleum AS has completed a 30% stake in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences from DEA Norge. The deal, effective January 1, 2019, includes PL838 and PL838B licences, with operator PGNiG Upstream Norway AS holding 40% and AkerBP holding 30%. The licences contain the Shrek prospect with potential for 19-38 million barrels of oil. This marks the second oil and gas discovery from PL838, with recoverable oil equivalents estimated at 3-6 million standard cubic metres.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q3 DPU rises 1.9% to 3.3 Singapore cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 1.9% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.3 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, driven by higher rent from its Singapore properties and appreciation of the Japanese yen. Gross revenue climbed 5.4% to S$29.9 million, exceeding expectations. The positive results are attributed to the growth of its Singapore properties.

site_title: Shell warns of weak economic outlook despite bumper profit
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc reported a strong third-quarter trading performance with adjusted net income of $4.77 billion, beating analyst estimates. However, shares dropped due to CEO Ben van Beurden's warning of uncertain economic conditions, which may slow returns to shareholders. Shell's gearing ratio and share buyback program are also under scrutiny. The company's cash flow from operations remained relatively stable, but its outlook is clouded by weak macroeconomic conditions and oversupply in natural gas markets.

site_title: Trick or treat: Is your doorstep fair game for zombies at Halloween?
summary: A growing number of Britons are seeking ways to deter trick-or-treaters from visiting their homes on Halloween, citing concerns over safety and nuisance. Despite having no legal right to refuse, residents can use tactics such as disabling doorbells, displaying "no trick-or-treat" posters, and leaving treats in a bowl by the door. Police advise respecting residents' wishes, but note that knocking on doors is not trespassing unless there's a restraining order or injunction in place.

site_title: EHT says no requirement to disclose sponsor's links to its largest investor
summary: EHT, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), confirmed that its largest shareholder, Frank Yuan, sold six hotels to the sponsor, Urban Commons, ahead of the IPO. However, there is no legal requirement to disclose this relationship. Yuan's firm, ASAP Holdings, also advised EHT on five other hotel acquisitions. EHT clarified that a recent bill to repair the Queen Mary floating hotel does not affect its capital expenditure projections, as the property is only responsible for 17 hotels. The Queen Mary's carrying value has been revalued to $159.4 million, and it is forecast to contribute 15.9% to EHT's net property income in 2020.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore Government Bond quotation as of Oct 31, 2019, is available. In business news, OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring and will be succeeded by Tan Teck Long. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices. Chinese banks stumbled due to Beijing's consumer lending push, and Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Countering the effects of climate change: High altitudes, old grapes
summary: A vineyard in Tremp, Spain, at an altitude of 3,000 feet above sea level is producing rare grapes, countering the effects of climate change. The Sant Miquel vineyard, covering over 200 acres, features unusual grapes that did not exist a few years ago. Researchers are studying these high-altitude grapes to understand how they can thrive in challenging conditions, potentially providing insights for climate-resilient crops. The findings aim to help mitigate the impacts of climate change on global food production.

site_title: China's financial regulator moves to shut down P2P lending
summary: China's financial regulator ordered over 40 peer-to-peer lenders in Shanghai to exit the business, citing concerns over fraud and defaults. The move comes after the sector, which once had over $150 billion in loans, has shrunk by half this year. The regulator verbally communicated with platforms, but did not give a deadline. This crackdown is part of China's efforts to overhaul the industry, which was plagued by problems and has caused financial woes for thousands of individual investors.

site_title: Foodie Folklore
summary: HBO's new anthology series "Food Lore" premieres on November 3, featuring eight hour-long stories set in various Asian countries, including India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. Each episode is directed by a prominent Asian filmmaker, with award-winning Singaporean director Eric Khoo at the helm. The series showcases a mix of stories and cuisines, highlighting the cultural significance of food in Asian cultures. "Food Lore" will be available on HBO GO and HBO.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Ascott Reit, Keppel Corp, MLT, Olam, Yangzijiang
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Key developments in Singapore stocks on Friday include United Overseas Bank's 8% rise in 3Q net profit, Ascott Reit's share price falling 1.43% after divesting a subsidiary, and Keppel Corp investing $25 million in an Indian coworking operator. Olam International acquired a Nigerian flour and pasta manufacturer for $450.4 million, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding won new order contracts for six bulk carriers. SembMarine won a contract from Shell Offshore to build a floating production unit in the Gulf of Mexico. Meanwhile, Chip Eng Seng's shares fell after former transport minister Lui Tuck Yew resigned from the board.

site_title: Trump blasts Fed after rate cut, says hurting US competitiveness
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve, saying its policies are hurting US competitiveness. Trump tweeted that interest rates in the US should be lower than those in Germany and Japan. The Fed lowered interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.5-1.75% to keep the US economy strong amid global developments. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated the move aimed to provide insurance against ongoing risks. Trump's comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Chile's Apec cancellation raises new hurdle for US-China trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping face a new hurdle in their trade talks after the APEC summit in Chile was cancelled due to violent protests. The summit, where they were set to sign an interim trade deal, was postponed to focus on restoring law and order. Despite the setback, the US still expects to sign a trade agreement with China next month, with potential alternatives in Alaska and Hawaii being considered. Trade experts say pulling together a replacement summit at short notice is challenging, but both leaders have incentives to keep talks on track and avoid further escalation.

site_title: DBS to boost Asean focus and hunt for region's next unicorns
summary: DBS Bank is focusing on boosting its coverage of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and connecting regional supply chains with global multinational corporations and emerging startups. The bank's head of institutional banking, Tan Su Shan, aims to link startups with big companies in industries such as logistics and healthcare, and will launch a business toolkit for startups, including cash-management services and mentorship. DBS also plans to expand its venture debt team to support more startups, leveraging recommendations from venture capital funds. The bank's goal is to help startups access the ecosystem and secure contracts by bringing fresh digital solutions to the market.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q3 profit plunges 52%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 52% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to 6.29 trillion won (S$7.3 billion), mainly due to falling memory chip prices. The company attributed the decline to a global downturn in the chip market. Despite this, Samsung's mobile division saw profits boosted by strong sales of the Galaxy Note 10 and A series devices, as well as 5G product offerings. Analysts expect Samsung to benefit from restrictions on Chinese competitor Huawei and the increasing availability of 5G services in the US, Japan, and China.

site_title: Starbucks beats sales estimates on digital push
summary: Starbucks reported beating quarterly sales estimates with a 7% increase in total net revenue to $6.75 billion, driven by its loyalty program and new delivery options. The company's active US membership in its "Rewards" program jumped 15% to 17.6 million, and sales at locations open for at least 13 months rose 5%. Starbucks forecast 2020 comparable restaurant sales to rise 3-4%, beating analyst estimates of 3.3%. The company's shares rose 3% in extended trading following the announcement.

site_title: Mekong levels at lowest on record as drought and dams strangle river
summary: The Mekong River has reached record lows due to drought and a newly completed dam in Laos, straining fish flow and water levels. The US$4.47 billion Xayaburi hydro-electric power plant, owned by a Thai company, began operations this week, despite warnings over its impact. Water levels have dropped significantly, restricting fishing grounds and causing concern for the upcoming dry season. Experts say the dam-building frenzy has compounded the drought, threatening the livelihoods of millions of people who depend on the river for fishing and agriculture.

site_title: Malaysia okays rail link with Singapore, but proposes tweaks
summary: Malaysia has agreed to proceed with a cross-border MRT link project with Singapore, with proposed changes aiming to reduce costs by 36% to RM3.16 billion. The 4km rail project, initially valued at RM4.93 billion, will connect Woodlands North station in Singapore to Bukit Chagar in Johor Baru. Malaysia's Transport Minister Anthony Loke had previously mentioned roping in the private sector to reduce costs. The project's completion target has been pushed back to after Dec 31, 2024.

site_title: Optimism that the worst is behind lifts October's stock market
summary: Singapore's stock market reversed three months of losses in October, with a total market cap increase of S$25.5 billion (3%) to S$885.5 billion. The Straits Times Index rose 3.5% to 3229.88, driven by blue-chip gains. The month saw 290 gainers for every 239 losers, with the STI market cap increasing by S$21.6 billion (4%).

site_title: DBS to boost Asean focus and hunt for region's next unicorns Continued from Page 1
summary: DBS Bank is shifting its focus to supporting Southeast Asian startups, aiming to spot the next unicorns in the region. The bank has established a business toolkit for startups, providing cash-management services, mentorship, and access to co-working space. DBS also connects startups with private-banking clients who may invest as angel investors, subject to thorough evaluation. The bank plans to expand its venture debt team to support more startups, leveraging recommendations from venture capital funds. DBS believes that the current market conditions, including the rise of "sensible" venture capital firms, will lead to more sustainable investments.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore's 'Sandwich Generation': Personal financial habits & retirement plans
summary: A recent podcast discussion on Money FM 89.3 explored Singapore's "Sandwich Generation," individuals caught between caring for their aging parents and saving for their own retirement. The phenomenon was highlighted through a viral short film, sparking a conversation about personal financial habits and retirement plans. Experts discussed the need for Singaporeans to reassess their financial priorities and make informed decisions to ensure a secure future for themselves and their loved ones. The discussion aims to encourage more open conversations about financial planning and retirement strategies.

site_title: Trump says US, China to announce new venue to ink trade deal soon
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the US and China will soon reveal a new site to sign the "Phase One" trade deal, after Chile canceled a planned summit. The deal, which includes a timetable of Chinese purchases of US farm products, is expected to be finalized within the same time frame as the original plan. Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will sign the agreement, with potential locations including Alaska, Hawaii, and Macau. Negotiations continue, with both sides working towards a deal despite ongoing discussions over US demands.

site_title: China factory activity shrinks for 6th month in Oct; PMI at 49.3
summary: China's factory activity shrank for the sixth consecutive month in October, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.3, down from 49.8 in September. This marks the weakest economic growth in nearly 30 years, attributed to cooling domestic demand, sluggish investment, and the ongoing Sino-US trade war. Economists expect Beijing to roll out more stimulus measures to avoid a sharper slowdown and bigger job losses, with GDP growth expected to slow to 6.2% in 2019 and 5.9% in 2020.

images.alt_text: China's manufacturing sector will remain under pressure in the coming months as the nearly 16-month long Sino-US trade war remains unresolved.

site_title: European stocks mixed at open after Fed cut
summary: European stocks opened mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index retreating 0.4% and the Paris CAC 40 receding 0.1%. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.2%. Investors are awaiting a potential interest rate reduction from the US Federal Reserve, which could impact the eurozone markets.

site_title: Wall St edges higher at open
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, driven by strong quarterly reports from Apple and Facebook, but gains were capped by uncertainty around a potential trade deal between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.01%, the S&P 500 gained 0.00%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.13%. Despite tariff uncertainty, the STI (Singapore stock index) rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors remaining positive.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.68 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 27,188.37.

site_title: Ascott Reit divests Vietnam subsidiary for US$10m
summary: Ascott Reit has divested its entire shareholding interest in its Vietnamese subsidiary, The Ascott (Vietnam) Investments, for US$10 million. The subsidiary owned 70% of the Vietnamese project company West Lake Development Company, which owns a serviced residence called Somerset West Lake Hanoi. The sale is part of Ascott Reit's ordinary business activities and is expected to have no material effect on the Reit's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Customer satisfaction: Business dealmaker or deal breaker?
summary: A business roundtable in the US has emphasized the importance of prioritizing customer satisfaction and employee well-being over shareholder interests. The move is seen as a shift from the traditional focus on maximizing profit for shareholders. Research suggests that companies in Singapore and the Asia Pacific region can follow suit, with technology startups gaining ground on incumbent brands. Customer satisfaction is key to success, with companies like Apple and United Airlines using metrics to track and reward customer satisfaction.
