The emphasis on customer satisfaction also highlights the importance of trust and loyalty in business, with customers willing to switch banks and telecom providers if they don't receive a good experience.

images.alt_text: Apple CEO Tim Cook and his predecessor Steve Jobs both said that customer satisfaction and experience are paramount to Apple's success.

site_title: Chris Christie is among lawyers reaping US$15m in 1MDB deal
summary: Former US Governor Chris Christie's law firm, Christie Law Firm LLC, is set to receive $15 million from the 1MDB settlement for advising fugitive financier Jho Low. The funds come from Low's $415 million stake in EMI Music Publishing, which grew after Low invested $100 million in stolen 1MDB assets. The Justice Department allowed the payment to cover Low's lawyers' fees, including those from Christie's firm. The settlement still needs federal judge approval and must be used only for Low's legal fees and costs.

site_title: World record in negative rates has bankers testing no-man's land
summary: Denmark's largest banks, Sydbank A/S and Jyske Bank A/S, are facing extreme negative interest rates for over seven years, forcing them to pass on the pain to retail depositors. Banks are cutting costs and adjusting revenue streams, with mortgage units being the exception. The policy is seen as a "market standard" in Denmark, where the central bank defends the krone's peg to the euro. The banks' shares have slumped, and some experts predict the policy may last another eight years, with the Riksbank in Sweden eager to exit.

site_title: Singapore shares continue to post gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,229.88, a 0.7% gain, after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time this year, boosting market confidence. Despite global growth concerns and China's weak factory data, the STI gained 3.5% in October, its second-best performance in Asia ex-Japan. Market strategist Stephen Innes said the US-China trade relationship appears to be improving, with both parties expressing confidence in ongoing negotiations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.98 points to 1,597.98 on Thursday, with 2.9 billion lots traded worth RM2.7 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 540 to 308.

site_title: Furniture Finds
summary: The Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts's annual after2 exhibition showcases 3D design prototypes by second and third-year students. The event features original furniture pieces, including the Timeless Stool and double-duty Kustool, for sale until November 3 at Lim Hak Tai Gallery. Admission is free, offering a unique opportunity for visitors to discover up-and-coming designers and unique, handmade furniture.

images.alt_text: after2 - A collection of 3-Dimensional Prototypes is on till Nov 3, at Lim Hak Tai Gallery

site_title: Lufthansa ready to invest up to 200m euros in Alitalia: source
summary: Lufthansa is ready to invest up to 200 million euros in struggling Italian airline Alitalia, according to a source. The investment, which could be between 150-200 million euros, would be twice as much as Delta's contribution to the Alitalia rescue. The move comes as Italy's industry ministry has extended a deadline for binding bids on Alitalia until November 21. This development may help rescue the loss-making airline, which has been struggling to secure a rescue package.

site_title: Hues Of Time
summary: Recent watch releases feature dominant colors, with notable models including Panerai's dark grey Luminor Luna Rossa Regatta, Ulysse Nardin's Hourstriker Phantom with acoustic performance, and Hublot's emerald green SAXEM Big Bang MP-11. Other limited-edition watches include Glashutte Original's green and grey Seventies Chronograph Panorama Date and Longines' Heritage Classic with a blue steel hands apaline disk. These watches showcase innovative materials and designs, reflecting the luxury watch industry's focus on color and craftsmanship.

site_title: Five shortlisted designs for Founders' Memorial unveiled for viewing
summary: The Founders' Memorial in Singapore, honoring the country's pioneer leaders, has unveiled five shortlisted designs for public viewing. The designs, created by local and international firms, will be on display from November 4 to December 29. Singaporeans can vote for their favorite design online until the end of December, with a jury evaluating the submissions based on functionality, technical feasibility, and public feedback. The winning design will be announced in the first quarter of 2027, with construction expected to start in 2021.

site_title: US consumer spending rises moderately, wages flat
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in September, driven by purchases of motor vehicles and healthcare, while wages remained flat. This moderate growth in consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of the US economy, could cast doubts on consumers' ability to drive the economy amid a deepening slump in business investment. The economy grew at a 1.9% rate in the third quarter, with inflation remaining tame, and the Federal Reserve signaled a pause in interest rate cuts, citing solid household spending and supportive financial conditions.

site_title: Lange's New Family
summary: A Lange & Sohne has released its sixth watch collection, the Odysseus, named after the Greek hero in Homer's epic poem The Odyssey. The 40.5mm stainless steel watch features an integrated bracelet, screw-down crown, and large day-of-the-week display, making it a "sporty elegant" timepiece. The Odysseus is not a diver's or pilot's watch, but designed for everyday wear. After eight years, CEO Wilhelm Schmid finally has a collection he can be personally associated with, marking the brand's first series-produced stainless steel watch and its first with a water-resistant case and screw-down crown.

site_title: Beijing ends key conclave with promise to protect Hong Kong
summary: China's Communist Party concluded its Fourth Plenum meeting with a promise to protect Hong Kong's stability amid months of pro-democracy protests. The government vowed to uphold and improve the "one country, two systems" framework, which grants Hong Kong greater autonomy than mainland China. The meeting also emphasized the need for peaceful reunification with Taiwan and did not address the US-China trade conflict, sparking criticism that it fell short of expectations. The statement's silence on the trade conflict may indicate increased division among party members.

site_title: Homes destroyed, hundreds more evacuated as Los Angeles wildfires spread
summary: Wildfires near Los Angeles have destroyed homes and forced evacuations, with the Hillside Fire growing to 80 hectares and at least six homes damaged or destroyed. The fires, fueled by strong desert winds, have displaced over 1,300 people, while the Getty Fire and Easy Fire have charred the region since the start of the week. The region's Santa Ana winds have been exacerbated by dry conditions, leading to an "extreme red flag warning" through Thursday evening. No injuries have been reported, but at least a dozen homes in Los Angeles have burned down.

site_title: ESR Cayman to raise HK$4.4 billion with HK listing
summary: ESR Cayman plans to raise approximately HK$4.4 billion (S$770.4 million) through a Hong Kong Stock Exchange listing with an offer price of HK$16.80 per share. The funds will be used to reduce debt, complete existing projects, and expand through mergers and acquisitions. The offering is expected to commence on November 1 if the deal becomes unconditional by November 1, 9am. ESR Cayman is the largest Asia-Pacific focused logistics real estate platform and sponsor of Singapore Exchange-listed ESR-Reit.

site_title: India fiscal deficit nears 93% of full-year target in 6 months, limiting scope for tax cuts
summary: India's fiscal deficit in the first six months of the year reached 92.6% of the target, or $125 billion, due to slower economic growth and declining tax revenue. The country's economic growth slowed to a six-year-low of 5% in the April-June quarter, and the government faces a challenging task to meet its deficit target of 3.3% of GDP. To meet the target, India needs 42% growth in tax collections in the second half of the year. The government has already implemented a corporate tax cut and is considering further measures to boost economic growth and consumer demand.

site_title: Lui Tuck Yew resigns from Chip Eng Seng board
summary: Former Singapore Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew has resigned from Chip Eng Seng's board to pursue other work commitments. He was appointed Singapore's new ambassador-designate to the People's Republic of China, replacing Stanley Loh. Chip Eng Seng shares declined 0.5 Singapore cent or 0.81% to S$0.615 following the announcement.

site_title: UOB extends S$140m in green loans to real estate SMEs under new framework
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has provided its first green loans under its new real estate sustainable finance framework, totaling S$140 million to SMEs Lucrum Capital and Teambuild Engineering & Construction. The loans will finance green buildings in Singapore, meeting criteria such as sustainability strategy and performance targets. This framework aims to support sustainability-related projects in the property sector, particularly for SMEs with limited resources, and aligns with BCA's target of 80% green-certified buildings by 2030.

site_title: Property investor Madison earmarks US$1b for central London despite Brexit
summary: Property investor Madison International Realty has earmarked US$1 billion for central London investments, despite Brexit uncertainty. Madison's president, Ronald Dickerman, believes a Brexit deal will attract investors back to the city, with the firm looking to buy industrial and residential properties. Madison has a 3.1% stake in Capital & Counties Properties, which owns the Covent Garden retail area and a development in west London. A sale of Earls Court is preferred over a demerger, and the firm is also investing in properties outside Britain.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several financial news articles were published on July 11, 2025. CGSI downgraded Grab's rating to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in the second half. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. Chinese banks are struggling due to a consumer lending push by Beijing.

site_title: Eurozone faces stagnation, as inflation falls again
summary: The eurozone's economic growth remains stagnant at 0.2% in the third quarter, with inflation falling to 0.7% in October, below the European Central Bank's target rate of 2%. This marks the lowest inflation rate since November 2016. Analysts predict further growth slowdown in the fourth quarter due to ongoing trade disputes and Brexit uncertainty, with some warning of stagnation in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong crashes into recession as protests hit economy
summary: Hong Kong's economy has contracted 3.2% in the third quarter, entering a recession, with two consecutive periods of negative growth since 2009. The economic downturn is attributed to nearly five months of protests, with economists warning it's unlikely to be a mild dip. Financial Secretary Paul Chan predicts a full-year economic contraction, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has cut its benchmark interest rate to stabilize the local currency. The city's tourism industry remains a key factor in determining recovery, with mainland Chinese tourists still a significant contributor to arrivals.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore businesses are mixed on near-term prospects, with 5% of manufacturers expecting worse growth in the six months to March 2020. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The UK economy shrank for the second month, while South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and a meeting between Rubio and China's Wang is set to occur at Asean talks.

site_title: Yangzijiang secures new orders for 6 vessels
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured new orders for six 31,800 dwt Great Lakes bulk carriers from Bulgarian shipping company Navibulgar. The vessels are expected to be delivered between 2021 and 2022, with Navibulgar having the option to exercise the orders for two of the ships. The order marks a significant addition to Yangzijiang's dry bulker portfolio, following its research and development efforts. The company's CEO, Ren Letian, praised Navibulgar's positive feedback on their previous vessel and expressed commitment to building high-quality vessels.

site_title: Keppel Land invests US$25m in India-based coworking operator
summary: Keppel Land, the property arm of Keppel Corporation, has invested US$25 million in India-based coworking operator Smartworks Coworking Space. Smartworks, which counts Amazon among its clients, aims to expand its footprint to 20 million square feet over the next five years. The investment will allow Keppel Land to enter India's growing flexible office market and collaborate with Smartworks on its smart serviced co-office platform KLOUD. Smartworks is cash-flow positive and profitable, and the investment is expected to enable further growth in India's Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities.

site_title: Bombardier in advanced talks to sell 3 plants to Spirit AeroSystems for over US$1b: sources
summary: Bombardier is in advanced talks to sell three facilities, including its Belfast wing-making plant, to Spirit AeroSystems for over $1 billion in cash and assumed liabilities. The deal, which could be announced as early as Thursday, would shed Bombardier's commercial aviation business and focus on its business jets and rail divisions. The Belfast plant, which produces wings for Airbus's A220 jet, is considered politically sensitive due to its workforce and location. Spirit would assume liabilities, including pension obligations, in the deal.

site_title: South Korean stocks end flat
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Thursday, despite early gains, due to uncertainty about Samsung Electronics' recovery in chip sales. The KOSPI rose 1% for the month, while Samsung Electronics rose nearly 2% but ended flat. Foreigners invested US$30.43 million in the main board, and investors were cautious amid Apple's positive iPhone sales outlook and Trump's new threats to stocks.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares gave up most of early gains to end steady on Thursday as investors were uncertain about Samsung Electronics' recovery in chip sales.

site_title: Banks, led by ANZ, pull Australian shares lower
summary: ANZ, Australia's fourth-largest lender, reported a near 3% drop in second-half cash profit due to record low interest rates and competition for home loans. This led to a 3.3% fall in ANZ shares, with other Big Four banks also declining. Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.4% to 6,663.4, despite gains in Asian markets after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates.

images.alt_text: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.4 per cent lower, hurt by the slide in financials - the largest component of the benchmark.

site_title: The double edges of growing exports to China
summary: Growing exports to China have benefited emerging economies in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam, but also make them vulnerable to Chinese economic coercion. From 2013 to 2018, exports to China outpaced imports from China in these four economies, distinct from wealthier, more globally integrated Asean economies. This reliance on China trade may compromise their economic sovereignty and create future vulnerabilities.

site_title: Malaysia to proceed with JB-S'pore RTS rail project, says Mahathir
summary: Malaysia has decided to proceed with the Johor-Bangkok-Singapore (JB-S'pore) RTS rail project, reducing costs by 36% to RM3.16 billion ($1.03 billion). The Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the decision during a press conference on October 31, 2019. The project aims to create a cross-border MRT link between Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.90% to 26,906.72, driven by interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. However, the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes fell 0.35% and 0.76%, respectively.

site_title: Pollux Properties, PACC Offshore call for trading halts
summary: Pollux Properties and PACC Offshore Services Holdings have called for trading halts, pending announcements. Pollux Properties shares more than doubled to 7 Singapore cents, while PACC Offshore shares rose 19.2% to 13 Singapore cents. The trading halts follow Pollux Properties' release of its first-quarter results, which showed a net loss of S$531,000 due to a delay in obtaining strata title for a project. PACC Offshore announced the winding up of its joint venture company, which it has a 50% stake in.

site_title: Lui Tuck Yew to be Singapore's next ambassador to China
summary: Singapore has appointed Lui Tuck Yew as its next ambassador-designate to China, replacing Stanley Loh who held the post since 2012. Lui previously served as transport minister and held various other government roles. President Halimah Yacob expressed confidence in his ability to carry out his duties.

site_title: UK election campaign hots up on Brexit day that never was
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson blamed Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn for his failure to deliver Brexit on Brexit day, despite having secured a new deal with the EU. The UK had been set to leave the EU on October 31, but was given a delay until January 31 due to opposition in the House of Commons. Johnson is riding high in opinion polls ahead of the December 12 election, but risks backlash over failing to keep his pledge to deliver Brexit. Labour is shifting the debate to domestic issues, while business leaders criticize its renationalisation plans.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson sought Thursday to blame the opposition Labour leader for his failure to deliver Brexit, as both men stepped up campaigning on the day Britain had been due to leave the EU.

site_title: Thailand's internet economy 'healthy' but lags in digital adoption
summary: Thailand's internet economy is growing at a healthy clip, increasing from $6 billion in 2015 to $16 billion in 2019. The online travel sector is the largest component, followed by e-commerce, online media, and ride-hailing. Despite this growth, the country lags behind regional peers in digital adoption and digitalization, with e-commerce penetration rate at only 2% of total retail sales. The government's digital economy vision, "Thailand 4.0," aims to revolutionize industries through digitalization, but challenges remain, including low digital readiness, a lack of human capital, and a laborious tax system.

site_title: North Korea launches two possible 'ballistic missiles' into sea
summary: North Korea launched two projectiles, identified as ballistic missiles, into the sea between the Korean Peninsula and Japan on Thursday, with Japan's EEZ being the target. The launch occurred in the afternoon, a departure from the usual morning timing, and came amid heightened tensions. The move has raised concerns about North Korea's intentions, with South Korea's military maintaining a readiness posture and expressing concern over "short-range projectiles." The launches follow a string of tests by North Korea this year, which have raised questions about the country's denuclearization talks with the US.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.7% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,229.88, up 21.96 points or 0.7% for the month of October, despite global growth concerns. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut had little impact, with markets already pricing in the move. Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea posted gains, while Australia and China were lower. The US-China trade tensions continue to ease, with US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaling a pause to interest rate cuts for the rest of the year.

site_title: SP Group launches tradable international green energy certs for companies
summary: SP Group, a Singapore utility firm, has launched tradable international green energy certificates (I-RECs) on its digital marketplace, allowing companies to buy and sell certificates to achieve their green targets. The certificates prove electricity generated by renewable sources, similar to carbon emissions trading. SP Group's accreditation as an I-REC local issuer ensures the integrity of REC transactions. The company's digital REC trading platform has been enhanced to automate the process, and its 2019 Smart Grid Index found significant improvements in Asia-Pacific utility firms' integration of distributed energy resources.

site_title: China says to proceed with trade negotiations with US as planned
summary: China's commerce ministry stated that trade negotiations with the US will proceed as planned, despite the cancellation of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit where a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping was expected to take place. The two sides remain in close communication and will hold a telephone call on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on Fed rate cut
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.37% on Thursday following the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 22,927.04. US shares also increased overnight. The benchmark Topix index rose 0.07% to 1,667.01. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: ANZ bottom-line profits down after 'challenging' year
summary: ANZ, Australia's second-largest bank, reported a 7% decline in statutory profit after tax to A$5.95 billion in the full year to September 30, due to a "challenging" year marked by slow economic growth, regulatory change, and global uncertainty. The bank attributed lower interest rates and the costs of misconduct charges to its lower profit. Despite this, ANZ maintained a steady cash profit of A$6.47 billion and invested in simplifying operations to confront challenges. The bank announced a full year dividend of 80c per share.

site_title: 6.5 magnitude quake hits South Philippines: USGS
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck the southern Philippines on October 31, 2019, in the same area where a 6.8-magnitude quake occurred on Tuesday, killing at least six people. The USGS reported no tsunami threat.

site_title: Experience vs expertise: How technology is changing who gets hired
summary: ASEAN businesses are shifting from experience-based hiring to expertise-driven talent acquisition as technology advances. With 85% of new jobs yet to be invented, companies must identify potential leaders by assessing skills and capabilities. Employers are adopting new performance measurement methods, such as predicting potential rather than past performance. Technology, including predictive psychometrics, video-based interviewing, and augmented analytics, is being used to support talent management decisions. Companies like Great Eastern are prioritizing talent development and embracing digital transformation to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: "We didn't do anything wrong, but somehow, we lost." These marked Stephen Elop's final words as the CEO of Nokia, when he announced the sale of the ubiquitous Finnish mobile giant to Microsoft.

site_title: Startup Helpling raises 20m euros in funding; eyes expansion in Europe, Asia-Pacific
summary: Helpling, an online marketplace for household services, has secured 20 million euros in funding led by European media group ProSiebenSat.1, bringing its total funding to 87 million euros since its 2014 launch. The company plans to expand in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region, including Singapore, where it has achieved profitability. Helpling aims to drive significant growth and expansion across additional verticals, with a focus on customer experience, and plans to reach a turnover of three-digit million euros in Singapore by 2021.

site_title: Nets partners ComfortDelGro to offer in-app payments for rides
summary: Nets has partnered with ComfortDelGro to offer in-app payments for ComfortDelGro cab rides through Nets bank cards, introducing "Nets Click" for commuters with DBS, OCBC, and UOB cards. This allows cardholders to authenticate their identity with a one-time password and pay for mobile bookings and street hail trips without additional steps. The new initiative aims to provide a convenient payment option for students and others without credit cards, with a promotion offering S$3 off fares from Friday to end-April next year.

site_title: Indonesia Q3 foreign direct investment rises 17.8% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) rose 17.8% in the July-September quarter, reaching 105 trillion rupiah (US$7 billion). The transport, warehousing, and communication sectors were the largest recipients. Singapore, Netherlands, and China are the top sources of FDI. This marks the second consecutive quarter of growth, indicating a positive trend in the country's investment climate.

site_title: Alibaba to resume Hong Kong listing plans as soon as November: sources
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd plans to resume its Hong Kong listing plans as early as November, aiming to raise up to $15 billion. The move would boost Hong Kong's status as a major capital markets hub and potentially impact liquidity in the city's financial system. The company's online retail frenzy Singles Day on November 11 is seen as a key trigger for the listing, with shares potentially listing in early December.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Fed cuts rates, suggests no more are likely
summary: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time this year, signaling no further reductions are likely. This move boosted Asian markets, with the S&P 500 rallying to a record close. However, gains were tempered by concerns over global developments, including the US-China trade row and Brexit uncertainty. The Fed indicated it would only cut rates if developments warranted a reassessment of its outlook. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore rose, while Shanghai eased. The move also supported higher-yielding, riskier currencies.

site_title: Singapore bank lending down 0.06% in September: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending decreased 0.06% in September from the previous month, driven by a 0.2% decline in business loans and a 0.04% drop in housing loans. Consumer loans, however, rose 0.1% to S$262.5 billion, marking its first increase since December 2018. Total lending still rose 2.2% year-over-year, unchanged from August. The decline in business loans is attributed to cooling measures in the local property market.

site_title: Qantas grounds Boeing 737 plane with crack, inspects others
summary: Qantas has grounded one Boeing 737NG due to a structural crack and is urgently inspecting 32 others for the flaw. This comes amid concerns over the 737 Max, following two crashes that killed 346 people. The US aviation authority has ordered checks of Boeing 737NG planes that have flown over 30,000 times. The incident highlights ongoing safety issues with Boeing's planes.

images.alt_text: Australian flag carrier Qantas said Thursday it had grounded one Boeing 737NG due to a structural crack, and was urgently inspecting 32 others for the flaw.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,231.41, up 0.73% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.73% to 3,231.41, driven by a mixed performance in Asian markets following the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut. The index saw gains from stocks like Singtel, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank, while ComfortDelGro Corp fell 2.1%. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.68%, with Hong Kong and Seoul also up, while Japan's Nikkei stock index rose 0.2%.

site_title: HSBC cuts Hong Kong best lending rate, first since financial crisis
summary: HSBC Holdings has cut its best lending rate in Hong Kong for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis, lowering it by 12.5 basis points to 5% to support the city's economy. The move comes amid concerns over the local economy, which is expected to have entered a technical recession in the third quarter due to the ongoing anti-government protests. The cut is seen as a positive step for the Hong Kong economy and companies, with the reduction likely to be the last this year.

site_title: Singtel-backed fintech Sygnum gets capital markets services licence
summary: Sygnum, a Singapore and Switzerland-based fintech backed by Singtel Innov8, has obtained a capital markets services licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The licence allows Sygnum to conduct asset management activities, primarily focusing on digital asset investment strategies for accredited and institutional investors. The firm plans to launch its first product, a multi-manager fund, on November 1. Sygnum's regulatory compliance and oversight in both Singapore and Switzerland form the foundation of its business, with a board of directors and advisory council consisting of notable figures from the financial industry.

site_title: China's financial hub moves to shut down P2P lending
summary: China's financial hub, Shanghai, has ordered over 40 peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders to exit the business, following a crackdown on the industry by President Xi Jinping. The move, aimed at addressing fraud and defaults, affects major platforms like Lufax and Dianrong.com, which have seen loans outstanding decline by 48% this year. The regulator has given no deadline for the platforms to wind down their services, but some local governments have directed a complete shutdown. The sector, which once had $150 billion in loans and 50 million investors, is expected to shrink further.

images.alt_text: The regulator in China's financial centre has ordered Shanghai's more than 40 peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders to exit the business, people familiar with the matter said, the latest blow to an online industry that's shrunk by half this year.

site_title: SoftBank wires US$1.5b to WeWork before cash runs out
summary: WeWork received a US$1.5 billion investment from SoftBank Group Corp, averting a cash run-out just weeks before it was expected to happen. As part of the deal, governance changes took effect, including the replacement of Adam Neumann as chairman and the assignment of five board seats to SoftBank, which now holds a majority stake. WeWork's new executive chairman, Marcelo Claure, stated that the financing package enables the company to accelerate profitability. The investment was accelerated as part of a SoftBank bailout package to rescue WeWork after a failed IPO.

site_title: France's Engie looks to set up renewables fund in Australia
summary: France's Engie plans to establish a renewable energy investment fund in Australia, aiming to develop 2,000 megawatts of wind and solar farms over the next decade. The fund will be partnered by Japan's Mitsui & Co, and Engie has already installed 165 MW of wind power in Australia. The company's Australian head, Augustin Honorat, sees strong interest from foreign and local funds for the project, which is expected to take a few months to set up. Engie aims to speed up investment in renewables despite Australia's uncertain energy policy.

site_title: China's October factory activity shrinks for sixth month: official PMI
summary: China's factory activity shrank for the sixth consecutive month in October, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.3, down from 49.8 in September. This marks the weakest economic growth in nearly 30 years. Analysts had forecast the PMI to remain flat at 49.8. The contraction points to further pressure on China's manufacturers and raises concerns about the country's economic growth.

site_title: Bank of Japan sends clearer signal of rate cut chance; keeps policy steady
summary: The Bank of Japan kept monetary policy steady, maintaining its short-term rate target at -0.1% and 10-year government bond yield at around 0%. The decision signals a possible rate cut in the future, as the BOJ is concerned about overseas risks potentially disrupting Japan's fragile economic recovery, following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut decision.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank urges prudence amid global headwinds, cuts rates after Fed move
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) lowered its policy rate by 25 basis points to 2% amid global economic headwinds, following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut. The move aims to manage financial risks prudently, as the city faces its first recession in a decade due to the US-China trade war and anti-government protests. HKMA chief Eddie Yue noted that interbank rates may not track the fall, and the US rate cut reflects the downward pressure on the global economy.

site_title: Airbus A220 engines pass engine checks after recent failures
summary: Airlines have completed engine checks on the Airbus A220 after recent failures, with no faults found. The checks were ordered after an engine failure on a Swiss-operated aircraft. A software issue is being investigated, with a new version expected in the first quarter. The incident has led to a re-inspection of over half of the fleet in service, with no signs of stress found. Airlines remain confident in the aircraft's safety.

images.alt_text: Airlines have completed one round of checks triggered by engine failures on the Airbus A220 and have found no faults, an executive at engine maker Pratt & Whitney said on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong mask ban challenged in court ahead of Halloween rally
summary: Hong Kong democracy activists challenged an emergency law banning protesters from wearing masks in court on October 31, 2019. The law, invoked by the city's pro-Beijing leader, restricts face coverings at rallies. The move comes as protesters plan to defy the restrictions at Halloween parties. The international finance hub has been embroiled in nearly five months of pro-democracy protests, with participants often wearing masks to hide their identities. The outcome of the court challenge is uncertain, but the protesters vow to continue defying the restrictions.

site_title: Singapore businesses mixed on near-term prospects amid uneven growth: polls
summary: Singapore businesses are mixed on their near-term prospects, with manufacturers showing a slight improvement in their outlook. According to a quarterly survey, a net weighted balance of 5% of manufacturers expect business to worsen in the next six months, down from 11% in the previous quarter. The overall services sector sentiment has slipped slightly but remains positive. This marks a slight easing of negativity from recent months, but the outlook is still poorer than in October 2018.

images.alt_text: Singapore businesses are mixed on their near-term prospects, but the depth of manufacturers' negativity is easing from recent months, official quarterly surveys show.

site_title: SingPost to introduce new rates for small packages, end doorstep deliveries
summary: SingPost will introduce new rates for small packages and end doorstep deliveries starting December 2. The postal service provider will replace ordinary mail with two new categories: basic package and tracked package, with prices ranging from 90 cents to S$4.80. Doorstep deliveries will cease, and the domestic registered article service will be renamed to accept only letters and printed papers up to 500g. International airmail rates will also increase by 20 cents for deliveries to Malaysia and Brunei.

site_title: Pompeo says US must confront China's Communist Party
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has urged the US to confront China's Communist Party, citing its focus on international domination and human rights abuses. Pompeo said the US has long cherished its friendship with the Chinese people but must address the fundamental differences between the two systems. He announced plans to deliver a series of speeches on competing ideologies and values, including on China's economic practices and military build-up. Pompeo emphasized that the US is not seeking confrontation but wants a transparent, competitive market-driven system in China.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as ANZ, energy stocks drag; New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,673.70, dragged down by ANZ Banking Group's weak results and lower oil prices, despite the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut. ANZ's stock dropped 3.5% after missing market expectations, while Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and National Australia Bank also fell. Oil prices and energy stocks also declined, but gold stocks rose due to safe-haven buying. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% to 10,768.14, with ANZ being the second-biggest loser.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Federal Reserve cut rates
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on October 31, 2019, following the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.51% or 115.93 points to 22,959.05. This move was seen as a positive signal for global markets, despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Neonatal tech startup Child Health Imprints raises US$2.3m in pre-Series A round
summary: Singapore-based startup Child Health Imprints (CHIL) has raised US$2.3 million in pre-Series A funding to improve clinical outcomes in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs) by aggregating vital data and analyzing it in real-time. The funds will be used to expand services in the Asia-Pacific, seek international regulatory approvals, and deploy managed services for networked hospitals. CHIL's proprietary solutions aim to reduce medical errors and improve early diagnosis of critical diseases, with a goal of improving neonatal safety across countries with high neonatal mortality rates.

site_title: US agrees US$1b 1MDB forfeiture deal with Malaysia's Jho Low
summary: The US Justice Department has agreed to a $1 billion civil forfeiture deal with Malaysian financier Jho Low, who is accused of misappropriating funds from the Malaysian state fund 1MDB. The deal includes the forfeiture of $700 million in assets, including a private jet and real estate, and marks the largest civil forfeiture in US history. Low, who faces charges in the US and Malaysia, has denied wrongdoing and says he is willing to address remaining issues if conditions are right. The settlement does not include an admission of guilt and is separate from criminal charges against Low.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says SingPost changes are 'steps in right direction'
summary: SingPost, a Singapore postal service provider, is implementing changes to its products and services, effective December 2, to reduce costs and adapt to the e-commerce boom. The changes include new rates for small packages, an end to doorstep deliveries for certain types of mail, and revised domestic and international airmail rates. Analysts from DBS Equity Research say the measures are a step in the right direction, reducing costs and leveraging SingPost's strengths in letterbox delivery. However, the company still faces headwinds, including higher terminal dues and operating costs, which may take two to three years to overcome.

site_title: China's service sector activity grows at slower pace in October: official PMI
summary: China's services sector activity grew at its slowest pace since February 2016 in October, with the official PMI dropping to 52.8 from 53.7 in September. This slowdown in services activity, along with a stagnant manufacturing sector, points to further weakening in domestic demand and pressure on China's economy. The country's economic growth has slowed to near 30-year lows, and policymakers face mounting pressure to address the issue.

site_title: How long will it take Hong Kong to bounce back from recession?
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to contract for a third consecutive quarter, with GDP growth forecast to decline 0.6% in the third quarter. This would mark the first recession since the global financial crisis a decade ago. Financial Secretary Paul Chan stated that a full-year economic contraction is "very likely." The recession is attributed to the ongoing US-China trade war and the demonstrations, with financial experts debating the duration of the downturn and potential long-term damage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Thursday, driven by the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut for the third time this year. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.15% to 26,708.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. Investors await the release of economic growth data for Hong Kong's third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares climb at Thursday's open after Fed rate cut; STI up 0.33% to 3,218.47
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.33% to 3,218.47 on Thursday, tracking a positive US market after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. The S&P 500 finished at a record, while the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB rose, while Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and ST Engineering also advanced. The Fed signaled it will hold off on further rate changes for now, citing a resilient US economy despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Impeachment investigators ask Bolton to testify: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump's former national security advisor John Bolton has been asked to testify in the impeachment probe, with a scheduled hearing behind closed doors on November 7. Bolton resigned in September and reportedly expressed alarm over secret administration efforts, including pressure on Ukraine to investigate Democrats, including Joe Biden. The White House seeks to limit cooperation with the probe.

site_title: New battery design can charge an electric car in 10 minutes
summary: Scientists at The Pennsylvania State University claim a breakthrough in battery technology that can charge an electric car in 10 minutes, adding 200 miles of driving range. The breakthrough requires a battery to rapidly take in 400 kilowatts of energy, a feat currently not possible for current generation vehicles due to the risk of lithium plating, which severely deteriorates battery life. This innovation could resolve one of the key concerns surrounding all-electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Ten minutes charging time to add 200 miles of driving range: scientists in the US have claimed a technological breakthrough that could resolve one of the key concerns surrounding all-electric vehicles.

site_title: Trading strength boosts Credit Suisse Q3 results, bringing relief to CEO
summary: Credit Suisse's third-quarter results showed a pre-tax profit of 269 million francs at its global markets trading unit, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's CEO, Tidjane Thiam, has faced a spying scandal but received backing from shareholders and the board. Despite a downbeat outlook for the remainder of the year due to the US-China trade dispute, the bank's trading unit saw revenue soar. Thiam is seeking to boost private banking services and retain top talent after the scandal, but faces challenges from a global slump in trading and low interest rates.

site_title: Twitter to ban political ads worldwide on its platform
summary: Twitter has announced it will ban all political ads globally on its platform, citing concerns over misinformation and the potential for ads to influence votes. The move, set to take effect on November 22, will ban ads on political issues as well as from candidates. This decision comes as Facebook faces pressure to apply fact-checking to politicians running ads with debunked claims. Twitter's CEO, Jack Dorsey, stated the move is aimed at preventing "machine learning-based optimisation of messaging and micro-targeting, unchecked misleading information, and deep fakes."

site_title: How the trade war and a changing China are roiling world shipping
summary: Global shipping volumes grew 2.7% to 11 billion tonnes in 2018, slower than the 4.1% expansion the previous year, due to the trade war and China's economic shift. The US-China trade war has reshaped global shipping flows, with a 15% decline in merchandise trade between the two economies projected. China's economic transformation away from manufacturing toward consumer-led expansion has led to declines in imports of iron ore and coal. The UN Conference on Trade and Development forecasts 3.5% growth in global shipping volumes from 2019 to 2024, but notes that uncertainty remains a major theme.

site_title: Tillerson denies that ExxonMobil defrauded investors
summary: Former US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson testified in court that ExxonMobil did not intentionally mislead investors about the financial costs of mitigating climate change. Tillerson acknowledged that ExxonMobil used two different projections of greenhouse gas costs, but claimed they were "different levels" intended to inform long-term planning, not deceive investors. The case, brought by the New York attorney general, alleges ExxonMobil defrauded shareholders by underestimating climate change risks, potentially costing them $416 million to $1.16 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 0.31 points to 1,580.31, driven by a 114-53 gainers-to-losers ratio. Volume reached 58.15 million lots worth RM21.97 million.

site_title: Stop inflating the inflation threat
summary: The US economy's current low unemployment rate, below 6%, is not expected to lead to rapidly accelerating inflation, contrary to the Phillips curve theory. Since 1988, the slope of the curve has been effectively zero, with an estimated regression coefficient of minus 0.03, indicating that inflation has not accelerated even at low unemployment. The author argues that monetary policymakers should focus on other problems rather than the risk of inflation, as the current economic conditions do not justify a rapid normalisation of monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices ease for 4th straight month in September
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.8% in September, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline. The price drop was faster than the revised 1.4% decrease in August. Analysts expect prices to continue falling, with some predicting a 5% drop by the end of the year. Despite the economic downturn, property prices have remained relatively resilient, with a 5.9% rise in the first half of the year.

site_title: Japan justice minister quits, second Cabinet exit in a week
summary: Japan's justice minister, Katsuyuki Kawai, has quit the Cabinet after allegations his wife broke election law while running for a Parliament seat. The allegations stated that his wife, Anri Kawai, paid staff members a daily allowance exceeding the law. This is the second Cabinet exit in a week, following another minister's resignation. Kawai submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe early on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Katsuyuki Kawai told reporters he had submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe early on Thursday.

site_title: IndoAgri sinks into the red with 125.68b rupiah loss for Q3
summary: IndoAgri, a major Indonesian agribusiness, reported a net loss of 125.68 billion rupiah (S$12.2 million) for its third quarter, down from a net profit of S$8.74 billion a year ago. The company's revenue fell 3.1% to 3.59 trillion rupiah, mainly due to weak commodity prices. The plantation division's revenue was flat, despite a higher sales volume, due to lower selling prices of palm products and sugar. The company will review its dividend policy at the end of the year and focuses on cost control and innovation to increase productivity.

site_title: Brazil cuts interest rates to new record low
summary: Brazil's central bank cut its interest rates to a new historic low of 5.0% for the third consecutive month, citing the slowing global economy and pro-market reforms. The rate cut was unanimously adopted and predicts an "additional adjustment" in December. The move is aimed at stimulating the economy, which has yet to respond to previous rate cuts. The decision follows a pension reform approved by Congress, which will allow Brazil to save 800 billion reais over the next decade.

site_title: URA launches tender for Irwell Bank Road residential site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 99-year leasehold residential site at Irwell Bank Road for sale by public tender. The 12,789 sq m site can yield approximately 445 residential units with a maximum building height of 36 storeys. The site is located in a well-established residential area near Orchard Road and River Valley Primary School, with nearby freehold condo The Cosmopolitan selling for S$2,341 per square foot in June. The tender closes on January 9, 2020, with predicted top bids ranging from S$650 million to S$680 million.

images.alt_text: The Irwell Bank Road site (marked in red) is located within a well-established residential area surrounded by existing condos such as The Cosmopolitan and OUE Twin Peak, and is within walking distance to the future Great World City MRT Station.

site_title: Boeing CEO grilled again amid calls for resignation
summary: US lawmakers grilled Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg for not holding top leaders accountable after two deadly crashes, with at least two lawmakers calling for his resignation. Muilenburg apologized for the accidents and acknowledged mistakes in the development of the 737 Max, but lawmakers criticized him for not taking a pay cut despite his $23.4 million compensation package. The company has already stripped him of his chairman title and ousted commercial plane chief Kevin McAllister, and analysts predict his eventual departure after the Max returns to service.

site_title: New York bans foie gras on animal cruelty grounds
summary: New York City has banned the sale of foie gras, a French delicacy made from the liver of force-fed ducks and geese, due to concerns over animal cruelty. The city council voted 42-6 to implement the ban, set to take effect in October 2022. The law prohibits selling, serving, or possessing foie gras, with fines ranging from $500 to $2,000 per offense. The move follows a similar ban in California and is expected to impact Hudson Valley Foie Gras and La Belle Farms, two major producers.

site_title: US interest rate cut was 'insurance,' policy now in 'good place': Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the recent interest rate cut of 25 basis points was designed to "keep the US economy strong" and provide "insurance" against ongoing risks. The rate is now set at 1.5-1.75% and Powell indicated that the central bank is unlikely to move again unless the situation deteriorates. This move was seen as a precautionary measure to support the US economy amidst global developments.

site_title: PSA Peugeot board approves merger with Fiat Chrysler: source
summary: The board of Groupe PSA, the parent company of Peugeot, approved a merger with Fiat Chrysler, creating a new global auto giant. The merged company would have 11 members, with 6 from PSA and 5 from FCA. The deal still needs FCA's board approval. This union aims to create a more competitive player in the global automotive market, combining PSA's Citroen and Opel brands with FCA's brands. The merger is expected to create significant synergies and improve the companies' market presence.

site_title: iFast Q3 profit falls 5.5% amid surge in expenses for platform upgrades
summary: iFast Corporation, a digital bank hopeful, reported a 5.5% decline in net profit to S$2.5 million for its third quarter ended Sept 30, mainly due to increased investments in platform upgrades. Revenue rose 7.6% to S$33.8 million, driven by a 17.5% year-on-year increase in the B2C segment. Assets under administration reached a record high of S$9.44 billion, despite volatile financial market conditions. The company expects operating expenses to increase at a "moderate" pace over the next 12 months, with a planned digital banking licence in Singapore potentially affecting expenses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Parkway Life Reit, Sheng Siong, Hi-P, IndoAgri, Creative, iFast
summary: Singapore stocks saw varied developments on Thursday. SIA proposed a partnership with Malaysia Airlines, resulting in a 0.44% gain. Parkway Life Reit posted a 1.9% rise in DPU, while Sheng Siong Group's revenue and net profit rose 11.4% and 16.4%, respectively. Hi-P's net profit dropped 2.7%, and IndoAgri suffered a net loss of S$12.2 million. Creative Technology reported a US$5.7 million loss, but expects revenue growth in the second quarter. iFast Corporation's net profit fell 5.5%, and MindChamps PreSchool opened a new flagship center in Australia.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q3 net profit slumps 52%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 52% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profits to 6.29 trillion won, citing a significant slump in memory chip earnings due to downward price trends. The company is battling challenges from the US-China trade war and supply restrictions. A retrial began for Samsung's vice-chairman Lee Jae Yong over a corruption scandal, which could see him return to prison. The decline in memory chip prices is attributed to global supply increases.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics, the world's largest smartphone and memory chip maker, saw net profits slump by more than half in the third quarter, it said on Thursday, amid a continued downturn in the global chip market.

site_title: UK's culture minister Morgan joins exodus from parliament
summary: UK culture minister Nicky Morgan will not run for re-election, citing a toxic political atmosphere and the toll on her family. Her resignation is the latest in a wave of departures from parliament, including former interior minister Amber Rudd and education minister Justine Greening. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to hold an election has triggered a surge of resignations, with centrist politicians citing the need to move on. Morgan will continue to support the Conservative Party and Johnson, but her departure raises concerns about the party's direction.

site_title: Australian dollar scales 3-month peak, New Zealand dollar follows as rate risk shifts
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged to three-month highs, with the Aussie reaching a peak of US$0.6928 and the kiwi dollar reaching US$0.6424, as investors scaled back bets on interest rate cuts after the US Federal Reserve signaled a pause in its easing campaign. Solid domestic data on housing and trade offset disappointing Chinese manufacturing and services activity. Westpac economists revised their interest rate expectations, now predicting no cut at the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's policy meeting on November 13, and the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to maintain a cash rate of 0.75% in the near term.

site_title: Private market for startups getting frothy; correction expected 'soon'
summary: The private market for startups in Singapore and Southeast Asia is becoming increasingly frothy, with valuations rising rapidly. Experts warn of a correction "fairly soon" due to the unsustainable nature of current valuations. Venture capitalists attribute this to investors' need to deploy capital, pushing startups to expand prematurely, and the fundraising cycle of funds. Despite this, opportunities remain at the seed stage, and angel investors are still investing in early-stage startups.

site_title: Inflation expectations shaped by rise of premium goods: study
summary: A study by academics at the National University of Singapore and Singapore Management University found that households tend to overestimate inflation due to rising living standards and the variety of consumer goods available. Respondents who were shown prices of premium ice cream brands and mass-market brands later reported significantly higher inflation estimates. The researchers suggest that policymakers can counter this bias by informing consumers about cheaper alternatives and changing consumption habits. This bias may contribute to higher inflation expectations in Singapore, which are currently above the Monetary Authority of Singapore's estimate.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts Q3 loss of 832m euros on restructuring costs
summary: Deutsche Bank posted a 832 million euro loss in Q3 due to major restructuring costs and a sharp decline in income from its bond trading division. The bank's revenue fell 15% to 5.3 billion euros, exceeding analyst estimates. Despite posting a pre-tax profit in its four core divisions, the bank faces ongoing challenges, including a decline in its investment bank's performance. This marks the second consecutive quarterly loss for the German lender, which has been restructuring its business to reshape its operations and cut costs.

site_title: Facebook profit climbs along with user base
summary: Facebook reported a 28% increase in revenue to $17.4 billion in its latest quarter, with a profit of over $6 billion. The number of active monthly users grew 8% to 2.45 billion. This growth comes despite concerns over the platform's use, including political ads and cryptocurrency. The company's user base growth suggests continued popularity, but the report also highlights the challenges Facebook faces in maintaining its position in the rapidly evolving tech landscape.

site_title: Honda and Hitachi to merge 4 car parts makers, says report
summary: Honda Motor Co. and Hitachi Ltd. agreed to merge four car parts businesses to create a components supplier with nearly $17 billion in sales. The combined entity, with Hitachi owning two-thirds and Honda the rest, aims to address industry shifts towards electric vehicles and autonomous driving. The move follows partnerships between Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and PSA Group, and Toyota's stake in Subaru Corp. The four suppliers will merge in two steps, with Hitachi owning 67% and Honda 33%.

site_title: Apple beats profit forecasts amid growth in services, wearables
summary: Apple reported strong profits for the past quarter, driven by growth in digital services and wearables. The company's profit declined 4% to $13.7 billion, while revenues increased 2% to $64 billion. Apple's services segment, including music, payments, and software, saw significant revenue gains, as did its wearables and accessories segment, which includes the Home Pod, Apple Watch, and earbuds. The company's new streaming television service is set to launch this week.

site_title: Reinventing energy sector through innovation
summary: Global energy experts gather at the Singapore International Energy Week, emphasizing the need for innovative technology to reshape the energy landscape and combat climate change. Countries in the Asia-Pacific region, such as India and China, have made significant advancements in renewable energy, with solar panels becoming 80% cheaper and wind turbines 40% cheaper. The region is also pioneering industrial micro-grids, floating solar power installations, and solar forecasting. Singapore has established itself as an innovation hub, investing heavily in solar research and development. This innovation is crucial for supporting growth and averting climate change.

site_title: Oil falls on hike in US crude stockpiles, trade deal concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after a US crude inventory build and concerns over a possible delay in resolving the US-China trade war, which has hurt global oil demand. US crude futures settled at $55.06 a barrel, down 48 cents, while Brent crude futures fell 98 cents to $60.61. The US crude oil stockpiles soared last week amid higher imports and a release from national reserves, despite refiners ramping up production. The delay in a trade deal between the US and China has added to market uncertainty, with the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates to support US growth.

site_title: Europe: Shares nudge higher as L'Oreal outweighs bank earnings upset
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by L'Oreal's 7.6% jump in quarterly revenue, beating forecasts. Despite weak earnings from Deutsche Bank and Santander, the personal & household goods sector led gains. Most companies modestly beat earnings expectations, with a 1.5% rise in the sector. Banks declined 1.9%, with Deutsche Bank falling 8% and Santander 4.1%, due to restructuring costs and one-off charges. A positive tone around US-China trade relations also supported gains.

images.alt_text: European shares eked out gains on Wednesday, buoyed by upbeat results from L'Oreal which defied Chinese slowdown fears, although weak earnings from some of the bloc's biggest lenders such as Deutsche Bank and Santander kept a lid on gains.

site_title: Raffles Place sale lifts Ascott Reit's DPU by 5%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust's (Ascott Reit) third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) rose 5% to 1.91 Singapore cents, driven by the sale of Ascott Raffles Place Singapore. Net income before changes in fair value increased to S$46.2 million, while revenue slipped 2% to S$132.4 million. The trust's proposed combination with Ascendas Hospitality Trust is expected to complete by the end of 2019, with stapled units trading on the Singapore Exchange on January 2, 2020.

site_title: Woolworths underpaid staff by up to A$300m; under govt probe
summary: Woolworths Group Ltd has admitted to underpaying thousands of its supermarket workers by up to A$300 million, with the underpayments potentially dating back to 2010. The company will repay the amount, estimated between A$200 million and A$300 million, and has contacted staff who have left. The Fair Work Ombudsman will investigate the breach, and a parliamentary inquiry has been called by Labor to address the issue of "wage theft" in Australia.

images.alt_text: A routine internal review found the salaries that Woolworths paid to 5,700 permanent employees failed to take into account an allowance for overtime which they should have received under industrial laws.

site_title: Dollar steady as markets hunker down for Fed rate cut
summary: The US dollar remained steady against major currencies as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's rate cut decision. A 1.6% growth rate in the third quarter is expected, which could influence the rate outlook. Sterling was firmer due to Britain's snap election in December, while the dollar was steady against the euro and marginally lower against a basket of six currencies. Investors are watching for indications of further rate cuts, with futures pricing suggesting more easing in 2020.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record as Federal Reserve cuts interest rates again
summary: The S&P 500 closed at a record high of 3,046.77, up 0.3%, after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third consecutive time. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached new highs. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell cited trade wars and Brexit uncertainty as reasons for the rate cut, but expressed confidence in the US economy's resilience. The move was largely seen as a relief by investors, who were expecting a rate cut and were already optimistic about the market.

site_title: Huawei tightens grip on China's smartphone market
summary: Huawei has tightened its grip on China's smartphone market, cornering 42% market share in the third quarter. Despite US sanctions, Huawei's smartphone sales in China rose by two-thirds, driven by domestic consumers and promotions. The company's global shipments also grew, despite a slump in other regions, and its profits remained resilient. Huawei's dominance has put pressure on rivals Oppo, Vivo, and Xiaomi, with Apple also experiencing a decline in Chinese sales.

site_title: Japan's September retail sales rise most in 51/2 years
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 9.1% in September, the strongest pace in 5½ years, driven by consumers buying big-ticket items before a sales tax hike. The increase is seen as a temporary boost, with some analysts warning that spending could pull back sharply in the coming months, potentially tipping the economy into recession. The Bank of Japan may hold off on loosening policy as stable markets and robust domestic demand give it room to save its limited ammunition.

site_title: Boeing CEO knew about pilot's warnings before 2nd crash
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg testified before Congress, acknowledging he knew of a top pilot's concerns about the 737 Max jet before the second fatal crash. Muilenburg said he would have grounded the plane sooner if he knew then what he knows now. The admission comes after the company faced criticism for its handling of the crisis. The two crashes killed 346 people and led to a crisis for Boeing and the global aviation industry. Muilenburg apologized to the families of victims and will face further questioning from the House transportation committee.

site_title: Key figures in Britain's Dec 12 general election
summary: Britain's December 12 general election could reshape parliament after years of Brexit gridlock. Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson seeks a ruling majority, while smaller parties, including Labour's Jeremy Corbyn, Liberal Democrats' Jo Swinson, and Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon, aim to soften or reverse Brexit. Johnson, a 55-year-old Oxford University graduate, has navigated scandals to become prime minister, while Corbyn, 70, has a proven track record in party politics. The election campaign will unfold across British town halls and debate stages, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q3 DPU rises 1.9% to 3.3 S cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 1.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.30 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by higher rent from Singapore properties and appreciation of the Japanese yen. Gross revenue rose 5.4% to S$29.9 million, with net property income increasing 3.9% to S$27.6 million. The Reit's stable results, despite a global economic slowdown, are seen as a positive sign for the industry's long-term outlook.

site_title: SE Asia's digital financial services revenue set to soar
summary: South-east Asia's digital financial services revenue is projected to reach $60 billion by 2025, with a base-case revenue of $38 billion, driven by digital lending activities. However, to achieve this potential, financial players must solve the multiple needs of underserved small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through digital means. A report by Google, Temasek, and Bain & Company found that SMEs are at an inflection point for digital adoption, with 76% expecting to use both cash and digital payment methods by 2022. To succeed, fintech players and incumbent banks must form partnerships to access each other's strengths.

site_title: Watchers expect Budget fillip, with output gap set to worsen in 2020
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to perform below its potential in 2020, prompting policymakers to consider an expansionary stance in the upcoming Budget. Despite initial expectations of a boost from public spending, data suggests this may not be the case. However, with the economy expected to worsen, watchers anticipate policymakers to loosen the purse-strings to stimulate growth.

site_title: Great potential to grow S'pore's adoption of AI
summary: Singapore is poised to grow its adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) with the government's supportive policies. The country has already seen a significant increase in AI adoption rate, with world spending on AI systems projected to reach $79.2 billion in 2022. However, challenges remain, including adopting a capability and value-centric mindset, creating effective policies and governance, and addressing the limited availability of skills and experience. To overcome these hurdles, businesses and the AI community must engage in open dialogue, develop career development frameworks, and create collaborative industry-focused programmes for AI competency development. With the right approach, Singapore has great potential to become an AI leader in the region.

site_title: Pending US home sales post biggest annual increase since 2015
summary: Pending US home sales increased 6.3% in September from a year earlier, the largest annual increase since 2015, according to the National Association of Realtors. This surge in pending sales signals a revival in interest from buyers due to lower mortgage rates. The increase is a positive sign for the housing market, suggesting that buyers are taking advantage of lower interest rates to purchase homes.

site_title: CDLHT Q3 DPS falls 4.1% on lower income
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 4.1% fall in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.09 cents for Q3, driven by lower net property income (NPI) and higher interest expense. NPI declined 1.5% due to weaker currencies affecting overseas properties, while Singapore hotels recorded higher earnings. Despite lower NPI from overseas properties, the trust's Singapore hotels saw a 4.9% increase in revenue per available room (RevPAR).

site_title: AT&T surprises with HBO Max price in battle against Disney and Netflix
summary: AT&T's HBO Max streaming service will launch in May with a price of $15 a month, a surprise move to compete with Netflix, Disney, and Apple. The service aims to reach 75-90 million subscribers by 2025, generating $5 billion in US revenue. AT&T has committed to invest up to $4 billion in additional content by 2025, targeting younger audiences and expanding its reach beyond its core HBO audience. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to merge content with distribution, playing catch-up in the streaming era dominated by Netflix.

site_title: The worst isn't over for Chinese bonds as supply surge looms
summary: China's sovereign bond market faces strain as a record $2 trillion of local government notes mature in 2020, adding to pressure from a global selloff and rising inflation. The 10-year yield rose 3 basis points to 3.33%, while the cost on 12-month interest rate swaps jumped 5 basis points. A flood of new supply is expected to exacerbate weakness, and analysts warn that the "snowball of Chinese local government debt" will continue to grow, potentially affecting the market's stability.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust posts 4.1% drop in Q4 DPS
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 4.1% drop in quarterly distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.1655 Singapore cents for Q4 2019, due to decreased gross operating revenue and profit in its Australia portfolio. Gross revenue rose 2.1% to S$39.5 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 2.3% to S$30 million. The trust's DPS for the full year fell 7.3% to 4.4129 Singapore cents, citing a challenging trade environment and foreign exchange impact.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler-PSA talks point to car industry consolidation push
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and French carmaker PSA Group are in talks for a potential merger, creating a regional powerhouse to rival Volkswagen AG. The deal would have a market value of approximately $49 billion and bring together two vehicle-making dynasties. The merger is seen as a push for global consolidation in the industry, which is struggling with a downturn and expensive shift to electric cars. Analysts believe the combination of FCA and PSA has more logic than previous deals and could lead to significant cost savings.

site_title: China's electric carmakers battle for survival after subsidies scaled back
summary: China's top electric carmakers, including BYD Co and BAIC BluePark New Energy Technology Co, are struggling after subsidies were scaled back. BYD reported an 89% slump in third-quarter earnings and warned of a potential 43% profit fall this year. The company's biggest rival, BAIC, also forecast a 2019 loss. The decline in demand has left these companies battling for survival, as the Chinese government reduces support for the industry.

site_title: PM Johnson needs majority win in December polls
summary: Prime Minister Boris Johnson needs a majority win in December's UK polls to get his Brexit deal approved, a crucial step for the economy and investors. A Conservative majority is considered the best outcome, while a hard-left Labour-Scottish Nationalist alliance would be a major disadvantage. Johnson has promised to improve public services, while Labour seeks to reduce poverty and nationalise key industries. The Brexit Party's involvement is key to a Tory victory, but its tactics could split the Conservative vote. Economists warn that Johnson's deal will leave the UK £70 billion worse off, with sterling at risk.

site_title: Far East H-Trust's Q3 DPS down 1% due to enlarged base
summary: Far East H-Trust's distribution per stapled security for Q3 2019 fell 1% to 1.04 Singapore cents due to an enlarged base resulting from the distribution reinvestment plan. Income available for distribution rose 1.5% to S$20.4 million and net property income grew 1.3% to S$28.1 million. Despite softer corporate demand, the hospitality sector is expected to benefit from government plans to develop tourist attractions and moderate hotel room supply growth.

site_title: Soho China considers selling stake in commercial property holdings
summary: Soho China is considering selling a majority stake in its commercial property holdings, valued at up to $8 billion, in deals including at least eight office towers in Beijing and Shanghai. The planned sales are part of the developer's shift away from China's office market, which has seen declining rents and high vacancy rates. The transactions are being shopped to sovereign wealth funds and private equity groups, and would be China's largest commercial property deal if completed.

site_title: Maxi-Cash to buy four shops for S$23.7m from chairman's firm
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Services Corporation has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire four investment properties in Singapore for S$23.7 million. The acquisition will enable the group to own the properties instead of renewing leases, reducing operational costs. The estimated net profit from the properties is S$69,000, based on the existing rental yield and property tax. The deal, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, is expected to be completed by March 31, 2020.

site_title: Money FM podcast: From homeless to entrepreneur
summary: Lianna Dhamirah, author of "Homeless: The Untold Story of a Mother's Struggle in Crazy Rich Singapore," shares her journey from homelessness to becoming a successful entrepreneur on Money FM podcast. She discusses budget planning and financial strategies, inspiring listeners to overcome adversity and achieve financial stability.

site_title: This rainforest trills, burbles and booms
summary: The Museum of Modern Art in New York has installed an interactive sound installation, "Rainforest V (variation 1)," created by David Tudor. The installation features 20 mundane objects suspended in the air, each emitting a unique sound that changes according to proximity. The soundscape, inspired by Tudor's first music for choreographer Merce Cunningham's dance company, is an aural collage of electronic sounds evoking a rainforest environment. The installation is part of a series of Tudor's work, including the 1973 "Rainforest IV" and the upcoming "Forest Speech" performances.

site_title: It's not just about creating jobs, but creating good jobs
summary: The US labor market has created over 20 million private-sector jobs during the record-length expansion, but the quality of jobs is a concern. A Gallup survey found that 40% of Americans have good jobs, while 44% have mediocre jobs and 16% have bad jobs. The survey highlights the importance of non-wage factors such as job stability, control over hours, and sense of purpose in determining job quality. Low-income workers, African Americans, and black women are disproportionately represented in bad jobs. Employers can improve job quality by engaging workers, offering benefits, and providing opportunities for development and career advancement.

site_title: Gender neutral emojis hit screens in new Apple update
summary: Apple has released a new update to its mobile operating system, iOS 13.2, featuring gender-neutral emojis of people icons, including punks, clowns, and zombies. The update includes a range of inclusive designs, including wheelchair, guide dog, and flexing prosthetic arm emojis. However, some users have expressed concerns that the new emojis may not accurately represent the diversity of the LGBTQ+ community, with some suggesting they may perpetuate stereotypes. Apple's attempt at inclusivity has sparked debate, with some calling for more neutral designs from the start.

images.alt_text: The Emojipedia website says in some emojis, a "gender neutral facial structure" is used, and in others haircuts are different.

site_title: Why snap UK election may not banish 'Brexit blues'
summary: The UK is set to hold a general election in December, which may not resolve the Brexit impasse, as many voters remain divided on the issue. A second successive parliament with no party majority could deepen the political impasse and fuel voter frustration. The election may not provide a clear pathway forward on Brexit, with some voters supporting a referendum and others advocating for a hardline Brexit stance. The outcome may not bring a national consensus, and the divisions within the electorate on Brexit issues are significant, making it challenging for politicians to forge a consensus.

site_title: Temasek's proactive moves on S'pore assets sweeten SGX's prospects
summary: Temasek Holdings has made a partial bid for control of Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, with a S$4.1 billion offer to gain 51% ownership. This move is seen as a shot in the arm for the Singapore bourse, which has struggled since the 2008 global financial crisis. Temasek's bid aims to revamp Keppel's businesses and extract more value, signaling a shift away from complacency and towards sustainability. The move may also prompt Keppel to undergo a comprehensive strategic review to create sustainable shareholder value.

site_title: Samsung Electronics shows off new design for square-folding phone
summary: Samsung Electronics unveiled a new design for a square-folding phone, racing ahead in the folding device market. The device can fold in half horizontally and is expected to be compact, making it easy to fit in a pocket. Samsung did not provide a launch date, but the company is committed to pioneering the foldable category. This move comes as Samsung battles rivals Apple and Huawei in a saturated market, and follows the launch of its first foldable phone in September.

site_title: Singapore Airlines, Malaysia Airlines plan tie-up to share revenue, expand routes
