Prologis plans to increase its US footprint, while Blackstone has dubbed logistics its "highest conviction" theme, with a focus on buying warehouses to meet this growing demand. The deals are seen as a silver lining for bankers, boosting M&A deal value despite a 28% decline over summer months.

site_title: HSBC posts sharp fall in Q3 earnings
summary: HSBC reported a sharp fall in Q3 earnings, with pre-tax profit of $4.8 billion, missing analysts' forecasts. The bank dropped its 2020 profit target and warned of a costly restructuring, citing sluggish performance in Europe and the US. Interim CEO Noel Quinn said investors may have to wait until early 2020 to hear his full plans to "remodel" the bank. Quinn attributed the slowdown to a "more challenging" revenue outlook, and vowed to shift capital away from low-return businesses and cut costs.

site_title: UBS 'obsessed' with costs as new targets loom amid scrutiny: CEO
summary: UBS Group CEO Sergio Ermotti has vowed to cut costs across the bank as he prepares to unveil new targets, amid scrutiny from investors. Ermotti said all units will be assessed for potential cost cuts and resource allocation before January 2020. He also discussed succession planning and the Hong Kong protests, stating that the investment bank's performance this year was not pleasing and that the bank needs to be at the forefront of changing investment banking. Ermotti is seeking to maintain an edge as competition for wealthy clients and negative interest rates weigh on earnings.

site_title: EU agrees Brexit delay until Jan 31 as Johnson seeks election
summary: The European Union has agreed to a three-month flexible delay to Britain's departure from the bloc, pushing the deadline to January 31, 2020. This decision comes as British Prime Minister Boris Johnson seeks to call an election after his opponents forced him to request an extension. Johnson will review the EU's "flextension" offer before responding. The Brexit deadline was previously set for October 31, but the delay gives Johnson more time to negotiate a deal or face the consequences of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Oil falls on weak Chinese data, forecasts for US crude stocks build
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as US crude stockpiles were forecast to rise and worries about weak Chinese industrial data outweighed hopes for increased oil demand from a potential Sino-American trade deal. Brent futures fell 0.7% to $61.57 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell 1.5% to $55.81. Despite optimism over trade talks, negative Chinese economic data and a slowdown in US energy company spending on new drilling tempered growth in US crude output, which has reached records above 12 million barrels per day this year.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Monday after four days of gains as expectations US crude stockpiles will rise and worries about weak Chinese industrial data offset hopes oil demand will increase if talks progress on a Sino-American trade deal.

site_title: Money FM podcast: OCBC - NTUC First Campus Bridging
summary: The OCBC - NTUC First Campus Bridging, a bridging loan product, was discussed on the Money FM podcast. The product aims to provide financial assistance to students pursuing higher education at the NTUC First Campus. The loan offers flexible repayment terms and competitive interest rates, making it an attractive option for students. The product is designed to support students' financial needs during their studies, and OCBC is the first bank to offer such a bridging loan.

site_title: UK lawmakers call for action on banks, big tech to avoid IT failures
summary: UK lawmakers recommend higher levies on banks and cloud service providers to prevent IT failures, citing the 2018 TSB glitch that left thousands of customers locked out of their accounts. The review calls for increased resources, swift customer complaints resolution, and accountability for firms' roles in IT failures. Regulators must also regulate cloud service providers like Microsoft, Google, and Amazon to mitigate significant consequences of major operational incidents.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical, Eagle Hospitality Trust, KIT, KORE, Mermaid
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 16.9% decline in net profit to S$13.6 million for the third quarter, while revenue rose 7.8% to S$130.5 million. Eagle Hospitality Trust's stapled securities fell 10 US cents after a clarification on repairs to its Queen Mary floating hotel. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink unit faces "adverse consequences" due to a new directive from Hydro Tasmania. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit listed 104.3 million new units at US$0.725 per unit, raising S$75.6 million. Mermaid Maritime secured a contract extension worth around US$162 million.

images.alt_text: Raffles Medical Group: Raffles Medical's net profit for the third quarter was 16.9 per cent lower at S$13.6 million versus S$16.4 million a year ago as it continues to absorb the startup costs for its Chongqing hospital.

site_title: ABB buys majority stake in Chinese electric vehicle charging company
summary: ABB acquired a 67% majority stake in Shanghai Chargedot New Energy Technology Co Ltd, a Chinese electric vehicle charging company, for an undisclosed price. Chargedot, which employs 185 people, develops charging stations and software platforms. The acquisition aims to boost ABB's presence in China's growing electric vehicle market and strengthen its relations with electric vehicle manufacturers. China's electric vehicle fleet of two million vehicles, supported by a government incentive scheme, has driven 52% growth in sales during the first half of 2019.

site_title: British PM loses election bid after EU backs Brexit delay
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's bid to force an early election was defeated by MPs on Monday, just hours after the European Union agreed to a Brexit delay until January 31, 2020. Johnson had initially sought an early election but was forced to agree to a delay due to opposition from MPs. He then proposed a snap poll for December 12, which was also defeated. The EU has proposed that Britain could leave earlier if the deal is ratified, and Johnson has vowed to legislate for a poll on December 12 despite opposition from Labour.

site_title: Hedge funds fight for Asia talent by boosting bonuses, training
summary: Hedge funds in Asia are intensifying their recruitment efforts to attract top talent, offering higher bonuses and training programs to lure graduates and experienced portfolio managers. The region's assets under management have grown 20% since 2016, outpacing the US and UK, and platforms like Point72 and Balyasny are investing in extensive training programs to develop their own bench of managers. Top portfolio managers in Asia can earn up to $20 million per year, while junior managers can command $2-3 million. The competition for talent is driving up compensation packages, with bonuses ranging from 25% of profits.

site_title: US: Stocks up on China talks optimism, S&P hits new record
summary: US stocks surged on renewed optimism about US-China trade talks, with the S&P 500 hitting a new record. The Federal Reserve is expected to proceed with another interest rate cut on Wednesday. President Trump expressed confidence in a partial "phase one" trade deal, which he expects to sign in mid-November. The EU backed an extension on Brexit, helping the pound firm against the dollar. Despite tariff uncertainty, 80% of S&P 500 companies reported better-than-expected earnings.

images.alt_text: Wall Street surged on Monday on renewed optmism about US-China trade talks, with the S&P 500 hitting a new record, while the pound firmed against the dollar after the EU backed an extension on Brexit.

site_title: Europe: US-China trade deal hopes drive shares to 21-month high
summary: European shares reached a 21-month high, driven by carmakers and miners on hopes of a US-China trade deal. The S&P 500 index hit a record high, while the Stoxx 600 index gained 0.3%. European automakers jumped 1.8% and commodity-linked stocks rose 1.5%. However, banks, including HSBC, dropped 3.7% after lowering profit targets. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's meeting for more clarity on the economy.

images.alt_text: European shares touched their highest level since January 2018 on Monday, boosted by carmakers and miners on hopes that the United States and China were closer to getting a trade deal, while a drop in banks led by HSBC capped gains.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet profits slip amid bigger investments
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a 23% drop in profits to $7.1 billion in the latest quarter, despite a 20% increase in revenue to $40.5 billion. The company's digital advertising revenue remained strong at $34 billion, but investments in cloud computing and research and development costs rose 25% and 20%, respectively. Alphabet aims to diversify its business with new hardware and services, but losses on "other bets" such as delivering internet services from balloons increased to $941 million.

site_title: Investing in tourist hotspots amid uncertainty
summary: Investors are turning to tourist hotspots in emerging economies despite uncertain external environments, such as trade tensions and Brexit. Cities like Bali and Penang in South-east Asia offer growth potential, with Bali ranking 14th globally in international overnight visitors and Penang generating significant revenue from medical tourism. To mitigate risks, investors should select populous cities with strong growth, tourist hotspots with a planned exit strategy, and conduct due diligence on regulations and operators. This approach can balance potential yields with reduced portfolio risks.

site_title: Communist Party elite open key meeting on China's roadmap
summary: China's Communist Party elite convened a key meeting in Beijing, known as the Fourth Plenum, to discuss the country's roadmap and future direction. President Xi Jinping delivered a work report, outlining plans to strengthen the party's control and modernize China's governance system. The meeting is seen as a move to solidify Xi's power and authority, with possible outcomes including a document criticizing past policies to elevate his status. The meeting follows pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong and a slowing economy, with analysts predicting the CCP will emerge more firmly entrenched in power.

site_title: The Met's Herculean task: 4 operas in 48 hours
summary: The Metropolitan Opera is performing four operas over a 48-hour period, starting Friday evening and ending Sunday evening. This is a unique and complex task, requiring four casts, 718 costumes, 201 wigs, and a massive stage crew of 178. The production includes Madama Butterfly, Turandot, Manon, and Orfeo ed Euridice, with sets measuring up to 40-foot truck containers. The production involves a tight schedule, with multiple set changes, deaths, and dramatic scenes, all taking place within a short timeframe. Despite the logistical challenges, the Met's technical director, David Feheley, describes the process as "like playing a sliding tile game" but notes the lack of empty space backstage.

site_title: Xi's blockchain talk triggers frenzy in China tech shares
summary: Chinese investors surged into blockchain-related stocks after President Xi Jinping announced Beijing's plan to speed up the development of the technology. Over 60 tech shares rose by the daily 10% limit in Shanghai and Shenzhen, with stocks like Zhejiang Huamei Holding Co Ltd and Julong Co Ltd seeing significant gains. The excitement also boosted stocks with indirect connections to blockchain, such as Beingmate Co and Meitu Inc, with Bitcoin rallying 30% in tandem. The market reaction highlights the significant impact of a high-level endorsement in China.

site_title: Dubai faces a 'disaster' from overbuilding, says top developer
summary: Dubai's top developer, Damac Properties, warns that the city faces an economic disaster due to overbuilding, with around 30,000 new homes to be built this year. Chairman Hussain Sajwani calls for a halt in new construction for one to two years to curb supply and prevent a decline in property prices. The warning comes as Dubai's house prices have fallen by 30% and the city's banks risk growing bad loans. A committee has been created to limit supply and ensure fair development practices.

site_title: Utilising, optimising and reaping the full benefits of proptech
summary: Property technology (proptech) is transforming the way buildings are managed in Singapore, aiming to enhance performance, reduce risks, and lower costs. A recent survey found that property owners prioritize smart and sustainable proptech solutions, particularly chatbots and real-time occupancy portals, to improve the quality of the workplace experience. However, high costs and implementation risks deter some owners from investing in proptech. To overcome these challenges, it's essential to choose the right proptech partners, invest in skills training, and foster a digital culture across all levels of facilities management professionals.

site_title: China and Japan make progress on cordiality track
summary: China and Japan have made progress on improving their cordial relationship, with key events including Vice President Wang Qishan's attendance at Japan's emperor enthronement and a Chinese guided missile destroyer's participation in Japan's fleet review. However, deep-seated differences remain, particularly over the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands and history issues. Despite this, both countries are working to sustain their improved relations, with China seeking to drive a wedge between Japan and the US and Japan aiming to act more independently in international affairs. The outcome of President Xi Jinping's upcoming visit will be crucial in determining the trajectory of their relationship.

site_title: Indonesian students use puppets to banish 'big ghost' of plastic waste
summary: Indonesian students are using puppets made from plastic waste to educate their community about the dangers of littering and the importance of responsible waste management. The puppets, created by students aged 7-16, are part of a program initiated by Abdul Latief, who established a puppet school on the island of Lombok in 2015. The program aims to teach children to care for the environment and reduce plastic waste, which can harm marine life. The puppets have been performed in Jakarta, the capital city, as part of the show's tour from Lombok.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary:

Several key events occurred on July 11, 2025. Companies announced changes: CGSI downgraded Grab to a 'hold' rating, while Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long taking over. Analysts are optimistic on SGX earnings, raising target prices. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Tesla marked its formal entry into India, and Citigroup set a target for the MSCI global equity index to reach 1,150 by mid-2026. Chinese banks faced challenges due to Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Weak Chinese industrial data pushes oil down
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday after China's industrial data showed profits at Chinese industrial companies fell for the second straight month in September, reinforcing signs of a slowing economy. Brent crude and WTI crude futures declined 0.4% and 0.5% respectively, following last week's gains. Progress in China-US trade talks and reduced oil rigs operating in the US supported prices, despite weak China data.

site_title: Aussie bank returns to shrink on extra low rates, competition
summary: Australia's Big Four banks are expected to report their lowest returns in over two decades, with full-year cash earnings heading towards single digits. Record low interest rates and increased competition from smaller lenders and foreign players are driving the decline. The banks face one-off customer remediation charges and rising costs, which are eating into margins. Analysts expect Commonwealth Bank to report flat cash earnings, National Australia Bank to fall 25%, and Westpac to target a 14% return, but may lower its target to 11-12%.

site_title: Entrenching Sias is not the solution
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (Sias) has proposed making it mandatory for listed companies to engage with the organization when restructuring, with Sias to act as the representative of retail investors. However, critics argue that this would give Sias a monopoly and stifle the growth of other investors' advocacy groups, potentially leading to administrative bottlenecks and liability issues. Instead, the solution lies in updating the legal system to allow for class action lawsuits and better empower minority shareholders.

site_title: Softbank's Vision Fund pumps extra US$655m into Greensill
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund has invested an additional $655 million in Greensill Capital, bolstering the financing group's global expansion. The investment follows an initial $800 million in May and comes as SoftBank faces challenges after the collapse of plans to list The We Company. Greensill provides financing to over eight million customers across 60 countries, offering innovative working capital solutions. The deal brings total funding to over $1.7 billion from leading investors, with the new investment in the form of convertible loan notes.

site_title: Swiss franc extends fall as markets eye US-China deal
summary: The Swiss franc weakened against its rivals, extending a week-long losing streak, as markets await a US-China trade deal. The Canadian dollar rose to a three-month high, while the euro and pound were firmer against the dollar and yen. Speculators cut long-held dollar positions, and investors await the US Federal Reserve meeting on Wednesday, where interest rate cuts are expected. The improving risk appetite suggests easing trade tensions, with a high probability of a trade deal being signed next month.

site_title: A united front against climate change
summary: Singapore has taken steps to combat climate change, including a carbon tax and the Zero Waste Masterplan. The government aims to limit global temperature rises to well below 2 degrees Celsius, in line with the Paris agreement. Businesses, including large corporations and SMEs, are also encouraged to reduce their carbon footprint and adopt sustainable practices. The government has partnered with companies to implement climate action strategies and mobilize consumers to adopt energy-conscious behavior. With the Open Electricity Market, consumers can now choose their electricity retailer, and businesses can help educate and incentivize them to reduce their carbon footprint.

site_title: Red Bull's Thai rivals top global peers on overseas ambition
summary: Thai energy drink makers Osotspa pcl and Carabao Group pcl have outperformed global peers, with Osotspa delivering a 45% total return in the past six months and Carabao generating a 39% return. Analysts attribute their success to domestic sales growth and expansion into neighboring countries. The companies' shares are trading at over 33 times their earnings estimates, raising concerns about a possible correction in the short term. Osotspa and Carabao dominate Thailand's energy drink market, with a combined 80% share, surpassing Red Bull's local version.

site_title: Even eagles have data roaming limits, researchers find
summary: Researchers tracking 13 endangered steppe eagles found that even eagles have data roaming limits. One eagle, Min, sent hundreds of text messages at once, draining the researchers' phone credit while flying from Kazakhstan to Iran, where rates are more expensive. This unexpected event highlighted the limitations of even these powerful birds.

site_title: Discontent with CDU leader Kramp-Karrenbauer grows louder after poll defeat
summary: German conservative leader Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer faces growing discontent within her party after a humiliating election defeat in eastern Thuringia, where the Christian Democrats (CDU) lost voters to the far-left Linke party. The CDU's fourth setback under Kramp-Karrenbauer's leadership has led to calls for a reversal of its policy towards the Linke, which conservative leaders deem the reincarnation of the communist party. A poll shows over 70% of CDU voters in Thuringia want their party to join a Linke-led coalition, further eroding Kramp-Karrenbauer's authority.

site_title: Making learning fun, mobile and effective
summary: A Singapore-based startup, Gnowbe, aims to revolutionize corporate training with a mobile microlearning approach, making learning engaging and effective for working professionals. The platform is based on the science of adult learning and utilizes smartphones to deliver bite-sized training sessions. Gnowbe's head of strategic partnerships, Loh Chi Ming, is determined to change the traditional classroom-based learning model, which is often time-consuming and ineffective. The startup seeks to make mobile learning the new norm for company training, offering a more efficient and enjoyable way to acquire new skills.

site_title: Travel times getting longer in congested Metro Manila
summary: Travel times in Metro Manila have increased by 1.1 minutes per kilometer, reaching 4.9 minutes in September, according to Waze data. The Philippine capital region is expected to top Waze's 2019 ranking of the world's worst cities to drive in, with traffic congestion worsening over the All Souls' Day long weekend and before Christmas. Waze anticipates a 16% jump in kilometers driven and a 10% increase in active users during the peak November and December period.

site_title: US lawmakers to press Boeing CEO for answers on 737 crashes
summary: US lawmakers will press Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg for answers on the 737 crashes during hearings starting Tuesday, with panel chief Senator Roger Wicker stating the plane won't return to US skies until 99.9% of the public and policymakers are convinced it's safe. Reports have found Boeing failed to adequately consider pilot responses to cockpit emergencies during the 737 MAX's design. The FAA is reviewing software upgrades and other changes, with a possible return to service in December. Wicker plans to investigate the relationship between regulators and manufacturers and reform the FAA's certification process.

site_title: Fernandez wins in Argentina as voters rebuff Macri's austerity
summary: Argentina's left-wing populist Alberto Fernandez won the presidential election with 48% of the vote, defeating Mauricio Macri's pro-market policies. Fernandez's victory signals the return of Peronism, an anti-elite movement that traditionally favors workers. However, the economy is fragile, with inflation above 50% and unemployment over 10%, and investors expect a default. Fernandez will face challenges in balancing competing demands from far-left factions and the IMF, which agreed to a $56 billion bailout last year. His vice president, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, will also play a key role in the new administration.

images.alt_text: Mr Fernandez, Argentina's president elect, greeting supporters at the party's headquarters in Buenos Aires on Sunday. He will take office on Dec 10.

site_title: Geena Davis receives honorary Oscar for work against gender bias
summary: Geena Davis received an honorary Oscar for her work promoting more women on screen, addressing the ongoing gender imbalance in media. She emphasized that the issue is worse in fiction than in real life, urging filmmakers to take action. Davis suggested changing the script by adding more female characters, stating that it can be done "absolutely overnight." Other honorees included Wes Studi, David Lynch, and Italian writer-director Lina Wertmuller, who also called out Hollywood for favoring men. Davis hopes to change the name of the Oscar to "Anna" to honor women's contributions.

site_title: Economic, political interests luring key nations to Africa
summary: Key nations, including Russia and China, are increasingly interested in Africa due to the continent's growing economic weight and potential for growth. Russia and China have signed billions of dollars in economic agreements, while China has invested heavily in infrastructure projects across the continent. The US, however, has been criticized for lacking a coherent Africa policy, with President Trump's administration exploring ways to boost bilateral trade. Other great powers, such as the UK, India, and the Gulf states, are also showing interest in Africa, giving countries more diplomatic options. The continent's economic potential is expected to continue growing, with Africa's overall growth prospects among the best in the world in the next five years.

site_title: Trump is bad? Warren will be worse
summary: US corporate leaders are experiencing high anxiety under the potential presidency of Elizabeth Warren, who has a better-than-even chance to emerge as the Democratic frontrunner. Unlike Donald Trump, Warren's plans target the concentration of power and wealth in the hands of a few multi-billionaires and large companies, with proposals to restrict lobbying, break up big companies, ban shale fracking, and nationalize healthcare. Warren's industrial policy would also help fund Made-in-America exports and condition new trade deals. In contrast, Warren's "fair market" approach differs from Trump's "disrupter" rhetoric, with a focus on reforming the free market to benefit the forgotten Americans.

site_title: Streaming TV gears up for ad targeting
summary: Streaming TV is shifting towards targeted advertising, with platforms like Hulu and WarnerMedia incorporating addressable ads that use data on viewing habits, location, and other factors to deliver relevant ads. This shift is expected to grow the US addressable TV ad revenue from $1.5 billion in 2018 to $3.5 billion in 2021. Streaming services are making it easier for smaller companies to advertise, and the rise of streaming may raise concerns over data privacy. Advertisers will pay more for targeted ads, and platforms will aim for fewer, more relevant ads.

site_title: Powering Singapore for the future
summary: Singapore is set to transition to a smart grid system powered by digital technologies, including smart meters and renewable energy. The country aims to reduce its carbon footprint while meeting growing energy demands. With fossil fuels still dominating the global energy mix, renewables are expected to play a key role in the shift to green growth. By 2050, energy demand is projected to double, with electrification and renewable energy sources expected to drive this growth, making electric vehicles and solar cells more viable options.

site_title: Will Trump win the battle for public opinion?
summary: The US presidency of Donald Trump may be decided by public opinion, with Democrats having enough votes in the House of Representatives to impeach him, but falling short in the Senate. Despite this, Trump's core supporters remain stable, with an average approval rating of 39% since 2017. Public opinion is notoriously hard to predict, with people often resistant to changing their minds, especially emotionally. The battle between Trump's supporters and Democrats may lead to a significant shift in public opinion, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: Tata Motors shares surge as China revival narrows loss
summary: Tata Motors shares surged 16.8% to ₹148.10 in the Diwali trading session, after reporting a narrower loss of ₹2.17 billion in the second quarter, compared to a loss of ₹10.5 billion in the same period last year. The company's Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) pre-tax profit for the quarter was £156 million. Demand for JLR vehicles in China is stabilizing, and the company has completed a £2.5 billion savings drive, including cutting thousands of jobs worldwide. Analysts expect JLR's performance to improve in the coming quarters.

site_title: Small oil-and-gas companies get cold shoulder from large banks
summary: Major banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, have cut their estimated values for oil-and-gas companies' reserves, which could put further financial stress on struggling producers. This move is part of regular biannual reviews and is expected to affect loans to the oil and gas sector. The cut in reserve values is a sign of banks' growing caution in the sector, with oil prices expected to remain low due to bearish market outlooks. The move may lead to increased financial difficulties for oil and gas companies relying on reserve-based loans.

site_title: Brazil wooing airlines to fly domestic; will hold talks with three carriers
summary: Brazil is holding talks with three airlines - Jet Blue, Volaris, and Sky Airline - to operate domestic flights in the country's largest aviation market. The meetings aim to introduce Brazil to these carriers and explore potential partnerships. Brazil's government has opened its aviation market, allowing foreign carriers to set up domestic airlines, and has offered incentives to attract new players. However, some industry watchers are skeptical about the feasibility of new low-cost airlines entering the domestic market due to high costs, including value-added taxes on fuel.

site_title: Dry spell Down Under: aid for farmers may create a moral hazard
summary: Australia is experiencing a prolonged drought, prompting the government to offer a support package of A$100 million and a planned A$5 billion future drought fund. Economists warn that providing aid to farmers constitutes a moral hazard, encouraging them to farm unsuitable crops or animals in marginal lands. This could exacerbate future droughts. Experts argue that teaching farmers to manage risk is a more effective approach, and that current farm practices are unsustainable, contributing to ecological disasters such as the toxic blue-green algae outbreak in the Murray-Darling Basin.

site_title: HK enters recession, unlikely to grow in 2019 amid protracted protests
summary: Hong Kong has entered recession due to five months of anti-government protests, which are unlikely to end this year. Financial Secretary John Lee stated that the city is unlikely to achieve any growth in 2019. The protests, marked by violence and property damage, have continued despite police efforts to restore order. The economic downturn is attributed to the prolonged unrest, which has deterred investors and disrupted business operations.

site_title: The Joker gets the last laugh on a scary weekend
summary: Joker reclaims the top spot in North American theaters, selling an estimated US$18.9 million in tickets, beating Maleficent: Mistress of Evil. The film, starring Joaquin Phoenix, has now taken in US$849.1 million globally, becoming the most successful R-rated movie in history. Other scary movies, such as The Addams Family and Zombieland: Double Tap, also performed well, with Halloween just around the corner.

site_title: Dollar supported before Fed meeting, Brexit delay in focus
summary: The US dollar traded near its highest in over two months versus the yen ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, where policymakers are expected to cut interest rates for a third time this year. The Fed's reluctance to ease policy further is expected to be signaled, potentially boosting the dollar. Meanwhile, a Brexit delay is expected, with Britain's divorce from the European Union now set for January 31. The dollar index and euro strengthened, while sterling edged lower.

site_title: HSBC unveils mandate for radical shakeup
summary: HSBC's interim CEO Noel Quinn has unveiled a mandate for a radical shakeup of the bank, aiming to accelerate remodelling plans despite lousy third-quarter figures. Quinn, who took over in August, has abandoned an important return target for 2020 and pointed to businesses that performed well in a challenging environment. Quinn and Chairman Mark Tucker will need to ensure their plans are bold enough to address the bank's challenges.

site_title: KIT's Basslink says it will comply with 'unnecessary' pricing directive
summary: Basslink, a Singapore-based undersea power cable company, has agreed to comply with a directive from Hydro Tasmania, an Australian state enterprise, which restricts Basslink's operating capacity. The directive, set to take effect on Nov 1, limits Basslink's capacity to 445 MW until May 31, citing concerns about operating above design limits. Basslink's CEO, Malcolm Eccles, described the directive as "unnecessary" and "based on multiple assumptions." Despite this, Basslink has no choice but to comply under the Basslink Services Agreement.

site_title: Incumbent Macri the underdog as Argentina heads to the polls
summary: Argentina's President Mauricio Macri faces a tough election as the country votes on a new leader, with Peronist rival Alberto Fernandez trailing in opinion polls by 20 points. Macri's austerity policies are pitted against the left-leaning opposition's "social contract," which has gained popularity amid a severe economic crisis, including recession, high inflation, and poverty. The election outcome could have far-reaching implications for Argentina's economy and its debt restructuring talks with creditors.

site_title: Sponsor will pay for Queen Mary repairs: Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a Singapore-based sponsor, has clarified that it will cover the repair costs for the Queen Mary floating hotel, estimated at up to $7 million, not the trust itself. A 2017 marine survey had previously estimated $235-289 million in repairs, but the actual costs were much lower. The trust's manager, Urban Commons, has been working with the City of Long Beach since 2016 to address needed repairs. The repairs are expected to be completed within two years and will not have a material adverse impact on the hotel's operations.

images.alt_text: Urban Commons, the sponsor of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), is responsible for all the repair work that EHT's Queen Mary floating hotel requires, and these expenses will not come out of EHT's own pocket, the trust clarified on Monday.

site_title: Taylor Swift headlines Alibaba Singles' Day concert
summary: Taylor Swift will headline Alibaba's Singles' Day concert in Shanghai, marking her highest-profile appearance since its inception. The event, set for November 11, is expected to draw over 500 million participants and feature more than 200,000 brands offering a million new products. Swift's involvement underscores Alibaba's effort to take the signature event global, following her successful Prime Day concerts for Amazon. The concert will be televised and livestreamed, with Swift promoting Alibaba's online shopping spree amidst a backdrop of US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Harnessing technology for modern security problems
summary: FormTeam Consultancy, a security solutions provider, has revolutionized the industry by harnessing technology to offer innovative and future-proof solutions. Founded in 2008 by Tom Ho and Frankie Pang, the company has expanded to include five affiliate companies and has won the Enterprise 50 award. FormTeam uses cutting-edge technology, such as unmanned solutions and smart workforce management, to enhance security operations. The company's general manager, Derek Chew, believes that technology improves productivity and reduces manpower needs, but not completely eliminates the need for ground officers. FormTeam aims to continually improve and expand globally, with strategic partnerships across 11 countries.

site_title: UK lawmakers call for action on banks, big tech to avoid IT failures
summary: UK lawmakers are calling for action to prevent IT failures at banks and big tech companies. A review after the TSB IT meltdown last year recommends higher levies on banks if needed resources are required, and regulating cloud service providers like Google. Lawmakers also suggest increasing accountability for senior officials at financial firms, with the goal of ensuring quicker resolution of customer complaints and compensation for IT failures.

site_title: Sponsor will pay for Queen Mary repairs, says Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has clarified that Urban Commons, its sponsor, will cover all repair expenses for the Queen Mary floating hotel, not EHT itself. A 2017 marine survey found the repairs to be "grossly overstated" and more than two-and-a-half years old, contradicting a recent article. The Queen Mary, a retired British ocean liner, is docked in Long Beach, California, and features EHT's 347-room hotel.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on hopes for China trade deal
summary: Tokyo's stocks opened higher on Monday, following upbeat US trade comments and rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.28% to 22,862.59, driven by a tailwind from US share rallies. Analysts expect China's manufacturing PMI data this week and the US Federal Reserve's policy decision on Wednesday to impact markets. Shares in Canon and Fanuc rose ahead of their earnings reports, while dollar-yen traded at 108.73 yen.

site_title: Mermaid bags US$162m contract extension for Middle East subsea services
summary: Mermaid Maritime has secured a contract extension with a Middle East oil major for offshore inspection, repair, and maintenance services. The three-year extension, valued at approximately US$162 million, will commence in the fourth quarter of 2019. The company will continue to provide diving services using its DP2 saturation dive support vessel, along with remotely-operated vehicles and specialized equipment. This contract extension represents a stream of stable revenue for Mermaid and maintains its presence in the region, supporting further growth and expansion.

site_title: HSBC Q3 pre-tax profit falls 18%, flags challenging revenue outlook
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc reported an 18% drop in quarterly pre-tax profit to $4.8 billion, missing analyst forecasts, due to a challenging revenue growth outlook amid a gloomy business environment. The bank cited a trade war, easing monetary policy, unrest in Hong Kong, and Brexit as factors. HSBC said it would rebalance capital and adjust its cost base, potentially leading to significant charges. The results are under interim CEO Noel Quinn, who faces the task of showing progress on key priorities, including cost reduction and turning around its underperforming US business.

site_title: Lazada doubling down on logistics
summary: Lazada, the Alibaba-owned e-commerce platform, is expanding its logistics network in South-east Asia, aiming to reach 70% of the region's population with its in-house last-mile deliveries. The company has over 30 fulfilment centres across 17 cities, with over 75% of parcels sorted in-house in July 2019. Lazada's CEO, Pierre Poignant, emphasizes the importance of building an "open logistics network" that includes third-party providers, as the company seeks to deliver a consistent experience for consumers and sellers.

site_title: Microsoft's Pentagon contract changes cloud computing game, but likely to stir protests
summary: Microsoft has secured a $10 billion Pentagon contract for cloud computing services, known as the Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure, despite objections from some employees who claim it will increase the lethality of the US Department of Defense. Amazon Web Services, the market leader in cloud services, is considering a challenge to the award, citing President Trump's interference in the bidding process. The contract is seen as a major win for Microsoft, cementing its reputation as a serious contender in the cloud computing market and potentially altering the competitive landscape.

images.alt_text: Microsoft was awarded the US Defense Department's 10-year project over Amazon, which was considered the front-runner.

site_title: China's bid for commodity price clout extends to natural gas
summary: China, the world's largest natural gas buyer, is seeking to establish its own price for imported gas, influenced by domestic supply and demand rather than global market fluctuations. This move aims to break the current pricing system, where importers pay rates tied to European weather, Middle East conflicts, and other factors unrelated to China's fundamentals. Producers, distributors, and financial exchanges are pushing for prices in the yuan, rather than US dollars, to better reflect Chinese market dynamics.

site_title: Gold steady as investors wait for Fed's take on rate cut
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,504.44 per ounce on Monday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's rate decision later in the week, while progress in US-China trade talks limited upside. The Fed is expected to reduce its benchmark interest rate for the third consecutive time this year. Despite weak US economic data and rising hopes of a rate cut, gains in gold prices may be limited due to reduced trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore banks may see margin squeeze in Q3
summary: Singapore banks are expected to see a margin squeeze in Q3 due to the weaker global economic environment, particularly with the US Fed's interest rate cuts. Net interest margins for the three major banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - are likely to see limited growth, with DBS's margins expected to be affected more due to its larger, slow-to-reprice current and savings account funding base. Analysts are also monitoring non-performing loan (NPL) ratios, which are expected to increase due to the protracted trade war and exposure to Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: UOB will open the results season for the three banks, announcing its results on Nov 1. This will be followed by OCBC on Nov 5. DBS will cap off the earnings season for banks on Nov 11.

site_title: As Charles Schwab exits Singapore, others take its place
summary: US discount broker Charles Schwab has announced its exit from Singapore, with plans to cease operations in the city-state by year-end. Interactive Brokers, a US-based electronic trading platform, has received an approval-in-principle for a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Capital Markets Service licence and plans to commence operations in Singapore from January 2020. Meanwhile, Australian electronic trading platform Yieldbroker has also set up operations in Singapore, targeting institutional investors and focusing on fixed income securities. Both platforms aim to capitalize on Singapore's status as a global financial centre.

images.alt_text: Singapore remains an attractive destination for new brokerage entrants, with two such outfits setting up here even as US-focused discount broker Charles Schwab announced that it would cease operations in the city-state by year-end.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge up to 3-month high, dollar marks time before Fed
summary: Asian shares reached a three-month high on Monday, driven by optimism over a potential US-China trade deal and the US Federal Reserve's upcoming interest rate decision. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.3% to 518.29, with Chinese, Hong Kong, and Australian shares also gaining ground. US stocks surpassed their July 26 closing record, and the S&P 500's total return index hit an all-time high. Investors await the Fed's rate decision, expected to lower interest rates, and earnings from major companies.

site_title: Money Hacks podcast: What's the difference between credit card fraud and disputes? (Ep 57)
summary: In a recent episode of the Money Hacks podcast, host Chris Lim and his team discuss the difference between credit card fraud and disputes. Natalia Goh, head of credit cards and personal loans at Standard Chartered Bank Singapore, explains that credit card fraud involves unauthorized transactions, while disputes are related to errors or inaccuracies on a customer's account. She advises keeping receipts for at least 6 months to protect against fraud and recommends being cautious of unfamiliar transactions and regularly checking account activity. The episode aims to provide actionable financial tips for listeners.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Tuesday. The news is unrelated to the provided articles, which discuss various market developments, including a mandatory offer for PSC shares, the impact of US trade tensions, and a Dutch firm's plan to privatize Grand Venture Technology.

site_title: KIT's Basslink says will comply with 'unnecessary' pricing directive
summary: Basslink, an undersea power cable company, will comply with a pricing directive from Hydro Tasmania that restricts its operation to full capacity only during critical periods. The directive, set to take effect on Nov 1, limits the cable's capacity to 445 MW, which Basslink believes will result in "adverse consequences" for its operations and Tasmania's energy security. Basslink's CEO, Malcolm Eccles, stated that the directive is "unnecessary" and based on "multiple assumptions" and disputed information.

site_title: Hong Kong enters recession as protests show no sign of relenting
summary: Hong Kong has entered recession due to ongoing anti-government protests, which show no signs of relenting. The city's Financial Secretary, Paul Chan, stated that a preliminary estimate for third-quarter GDP will show two successive quarters of contraction, meeting the technical definition of a recession. The protests, now in their 21st week, have led to widespread destruction, including store fronts, businesses, and the metro system. Tourist numbers have plummeted, with a 50% decline in October, and retail operators have been forced to shut for multiple days. Economic growth is unlikely to be achieved this year.

site_title: LVMH explores potential takeover of Tiffany
summary: LVMH, the French luxury conglomerate, is exploring a potential takeover of Tiffany & Co, valuing the US jeweler at $12 billion. This would be LVMH's largest acquisition ever, following its $7 billion purchase of Christian Dior in 2017. The deal would further diversify the company, which has been expanding in the US market and seeking to broaden its presence in the jewelry segment. LVMH's chairman Bernard Arnault is seeking to sharpen the company's focus on the US market, and a successful deal could help maintain his position as Europe's richest man.

site_title: Red Bull's Thai rivals outperform most global beverage stocks
summary: Red Bull's Thai rivals, Osotspa and Carabao Group, have outperformed most global beverage stocks with Osotspa delivering a 45% total return and Carabao Group a 39% return in the past six months. Analysts attribute their success to a recovery in domestic sales and aggressive expansion in neighboring countries. However, their stocks may be exposed to a possible correction in the short term due to stretched valuations and excessive earnings optimism.

site_title: Downside trajectory for US$ on weak data, likely rate cut
summary: The US dollar is expected to decline against the Singapore dollar (USD/SGD) due to weak US economic data and increased market expectations of a 25-basis point interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve. A "head and shoulder" reversal pattern and bearish crossover of moving averages signal a downtrend, with a potential target price of 1.3536, which coincides with a 23.65% Fibonacci retracement level. The Fed's uncertainty over the Sino-US trade war and slowing global growth also supports the bearish outlook.

site_title: Singapore: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Singapore's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday, reopening on Tuesday. In other news, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share. Meanwhile, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors staying positive despite mixed Fed views. A Dutch firm also made a bid to privatize Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: Australian bank returns to shrink on extra low rates, competition
summary: Australia's "Big Four" banks are expected to report a second consecutive fall in full-year cash earnings due to record low interest rates and increased competition from smaller lenders and foreign players. The banks are also facing one-off customer remediation charges totaling almost A$5 billion. Analysts predict Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, National Australia Bank, and Westpac Banking Corp will report flat to 10% returns on equity (ROE) in the coming days, down from over 20% in the years following the global financial crisis.

site_title: Consumer shaming a social threat: H&M CEO
summary: H&M CEO Karl-Johan Persson warns that consumer shaming, fueled by climate activist Greta Thunberg's movement, poses a significant social threat to the fashion industry. The movement, which initially targeted air travelers, is now expanding to other industries, including fashion. Persson's comments come as the industry faces increased scrutiny over pollution and workers' rights.

images.alt_text: Mr Persson says things like "environmental innovation, renewable energy, improved materials" are better ways to tackle climate change than a moratorium on consumption, adding that there is a need for an open discussion.

Mr Persson says things like "environmental innovation, renewable energy, improved materials" are better ways to tackle climate change than a moratorium on consumption, adding that there is a need for an open discussion.

site_title: Australian financial regulator slaps additional conditions on IOOF unit
summary: Australia's financial regulator, ASIC, has imposed additional licence conditions on IOOF Investment Services, a unit of wealth manager IOOF Holdings. The conditions, part of a broader restructure, focus on governance, structure, and compliance. The changes include requiring a majority of independent directors on the board and were implemented amid concerns highlighted by a government-backed inquiry and ongoing class action lawsuit. IOOF has already started implementing the changes, following the departure of CEO Christopher Kelaher in July.

site_title: Early Renaissance painting found in French kitchen fetches 24m euros
summary: A rare 14th-century painting "Christ Mocked" by Italian early Renaissance master Cimabue was sold at an auction in Senlis, France for 24 million euros, exceeding the initial estimate of 4-6 million euros. The painting was discovered in a French kitchen and was sold by the Acteon auction house without revealing the winning bidder. The sale price includes costs and marks a significant milestone in the art world.

images.alt_text: A rare masterpiece by Italian early Renaissance master Cimabue that was discovered in a French kitchen was sold on Sunday for 24 million euros (S$36.3 million), about five times the initial estimate.

site_title: Hong Kong protests push insurer AIA to worst quarterly new business growth
summary: Asia-focused insurer AIA Group Ltd reported its smallest ever quarterly growth in new business value due to Hong Kong's anti-government protests, which have reduced tourist arrivals from mainland China and impacted sales of luxury goods and insurance policies. The protests, which began in June, have resulted in a sharp drop in sales, mainly from China visitors seeking better products and overseas investment opportunities. This decline has affected AIA's sales, leading to its worst quarterly new business growth.

site_title: Keong Hong buckles up as it rides construction roller-coaster
summary: Keong Hong Holdings, a Singaporean homegrown builder, is diversifying its portfolio to increase recurring income amid slowing jobs and squeezed margins. The company, which has a market capitalization of S$100 million, earned S$22 million last year on S$165 million in revenue. Founder Ronald Leo Ting Ping has led the company through multiple boom and bust cycles over the past 30 years.

images.alt_text: Keong Hong Holdings founder and majority owner Ronald Leo Ting Ping started the company in the early 1980s. It has since gravitated to institutional buildings given the Singapore government's continued investments in health and education.
The company's luxury hotel Pullman Maldives Maamutaa resort. The company has another hotel in the tropical nation, the mid-scale Mercure Maldives Kooddoo.

site_title: Philippines plans to allow banks to set up Islamic banking units
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) plans to allow local banks to set up Islamic banking subsidiaries, promoting Shariah-compliant finance in the Philippines. The central bank's Deputy Governor Chuchi Fonacier stated that conventional banks can operate Islamic banking windows or establish subsidiary Islamic banks, offering a wider range of Shariah-compliant services. The BSP aims to issue implementing rules by the end of the year, allowing foreign Shariah-compliant banks to operate locally as well. This move is seen as a step to increase the share of Islamic finance in the country, with around 10% of the population being Muslim.

site_title: Art by the numbers
summary: A new exhibition at the National Museum of Mathematics in New York showcases the art of mathematical origami, combining geometry, algorithms, and math formulas to create intricate 3D sculptures. Featuring 66 pieces of art made by 24 artists from around the world, the exhibit demonstrates the beauty and potential of math in art. Artists used calculated folds, pleats, and colors to create realistic pieces, often from a single piece of paper, and each comes with a description of the math behind the art. The exhibit aims to inspire visitors to explore the intersection of art and math.

site_title: US lawmakers will press Boeing CEO for answers on 737 MAX crashes
summary: US lawmakers will question Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg about the 737 MAX crashes, which killed 346 people. The Senate Commerce Committee will hold hearings starting Tuesday, with Muilenburg testifying for two days. Senator Roger Wicker says the plane won't return to US skies until 99.9% of the public and policymakers are convinced of its safety. Investigations have found Boeing failed to adequately consider pilot responses to cockpit emergencies in designing the airplane, and the FAA is reviewing proposed software upgrades and training changes.

site_title: Australia: Shares advance on trade progress; mining stocks lead
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by hopes of a US-China trade deal and firm commodity prices, with mining stocks leading the gain. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,759.60, boosted by resource stocks such as BHP Group and Rio Tinto, which jumped 1.4% and 1.5% respectively. The news also lifted investor sentiment, with the S&P 500 index nearing a record high.

images.alt_text: Australian shares notched gains on Monday, propelled by hopes that Washington and Beijing were close to finalising parts of a trade pact, while firm commodity prices gave an added fillip to resource stocks.

site_title: World's priciest bank saves water to cut costs
summary: Indonesia's PT Bank Central Asia (BCA), the world's most expensive bank, has maintained a strong track record of profitability and efficiency, with profits rising over 10% annually for the past decade. The bank's stringent cost control measures, including limiting drinking water and internet usage, have contributed to its low operating-expense ratio and high operating margin. Despite being valued at over $50 billion, investors remain bullish on BCA, citing its strong management capabilities, proven track record, and growth potential in Indonesia's growing middle class.

site_title: WhatsApp in the Arab world: an essential but controversial tool
summary: WhatsApp has become a crucial tool in the Arab world, facilitating mass protests, rescue missions, and coordination among citizens. In Lebanon, the government's attempt to tax WhatsApp calls sparked widespread protests, while in Syria, the app is used to coordinate rescue efforts and communicate with rescue teams. Despite governments' efforts to block or restrict the app, WhatsApp remains the most popular social media platform in the region, with over 1.5 billion users worldwide. The app's widespread use has made it a key factor in mobilizing protests and disseminating information, prompting governments to consider its potential benefits and threats.

site_title: Money FM podcast: What's in Robert Kiyosaki's portfolio?
summary: Robert Kiyosaki, author of 'Rich Dad, Poor Dad', shares insights on his portfolio in a podcast interview. He discusses his investment strategies and business ventures, including real estate, stocks, and businesses. Kiyosaki also touches on his friendship with US President Donald Trump, citing their shared passion for wealth creation. The conversation provides a glimpse into Kiyosaki's investment philosophy and his approach to building wealth.

site_title: China studying blockchain application for forex: regulator
summary: China is studying the application of blockchain and artificial intelligence in cross-border financing, focusing on risk management, amid global interest in digital currencies. Deputy head of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, Lu Lei, emphasized the need for effective financial infrastructure and plans to further liberalize capital markets, including bond markets. China also plans to reduce red tape in an outbound investment scheme and study the rollout of yuan interest rate options. These efforts come as the country gears up to launch its own digital currency and responds to concerns over digital finance and fintech.

site_title: Trump suggestion of taking Syrian oil draws rebukes
summary: US President Donald Trump suggested operating Syrian oil fields with Exxon Mobil or another US oil company, but drew rebukes from legal and energy experts. Trump stated he intended to "spread out the wealth" in a deal. Exxon Mobil and Chevron declined to comment on the remarks.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's suggestion on Sunday that Exxon Mobil or another US oil company operate Syrian oil fields drew rebukes from legal and energy experts.

site_title: Hamilton wins Mexican Grand Prix, but waits for sixth title
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his 10th win of the season, claiming a near-flawless victory at the Mexican Grand Prix. He finished ahead of Sebastian Vettel and Valtteri Bottas, keeping his title bid alive. Hamilton fell short of his sixth drivers' world championship, but remains in contention. The victory marked a well-judged triumph by the champion-elect.

site_title: A key partner in the digital age
summary: Singaporean business leaders emphasize the importance of unions in the digital age. Victor Mills, CEO of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, believes unions should continue to play a constructive role in industrial relations, promoting collaboration between businesses, government, and unions. John Bittleston, founder of Terrific Mentors International, argues that unions should focus on upskilling workers, as the Rice Bowl is more universal than personal today. Max Loh, managing partner of Ernst & Young, suggests unions should adapt to the gig economy and digital-first approach to engagement channels.

site_title: EU states to discuss flexible Brexit delay Monday: report
summary: EU member states will meet Monday to discuss a flexible Brexit delay of up to three months to end-January, with possible departure dates of Nov 30 or Dec 31 if British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's deal is approved by parliament earlier. EU states have reservations about the delay, with France saying a strong justification is needed to grant another extension. The discussion comes as British lawmakers vote on a proposed early election for Dec 12, and Johnson's Brexit deal will be put before parliament for approval next month.

site_title: US utility outfit slammed for greed as millions face power cuts amid wildfire
summary: California officials have warned of extreme wind conditions that will fan wildfires across the US state, prompting evacuations and power cuts. Nearly 90,000 people were ordered to flee their homes in Sonoma County, north of San Francisco, as the Kincade Fire spread. The utility outfit has faced criticism for its handling of the situation, with many accusing it of prioritizing profits over public safety. The power cuts, which affect millions, have further exacerbated the crisis.

site_title: Contenders cramming TV streaming arena
summary: The television industry is experiencing a shift as people increasingly watch shows on devices of their choice. This trend is shaking up the traditional television landscape. The competitive streaming television market is becoming more crowded, with various contenders vying for viewers' attention.

site_title: Singapore preschool education growing second wing abroad
summary: Singapore-based private preschool operators are expanding overseas due to the country's shrinking market, with some aiming for Central Asia and Africa. The government's plans to increase the percentage of government-supported preschool places to 80% have led to a saturation point, prompting private operators like Modern Montessori International (MMI) to expand globally. MMI has a presence in over 10 countries, including Thailand, Indonesia, and Central Asia, while other operators like EtonHouse and Crestar Education Group are focusing on emerging markets in Asia, such as China, Vietnam, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: EtonHouse International Education Group's first centre in Kazakhstan offers preschool, primary and secondary education programmes.
Dr Chandroo says MMI has plans to expand from preschool to primary school programmes and is eyeing Vietnam for such a move. But he also says plans will have to wait until the firm raises more funds.

site_title: Sterling falls against US$ on Brexit uncertainty
summary: The British pound fell 1.5% against the US dollar after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit timetable was rejected by Parliament, leading to a request for a Brexit extension. However, the dollar strengthened against the pound, rising 0.29% to US$1.281. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the pound remains up 4.34% this month, with traders focusing on other events such as the APEC summit and the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: More investors buy into megatrends amid search for better yield
summary: Investors are shifting towards thematic funds and instruments tracking long-term megatrends, such as demographic changes, technological advancements, and climate change, in pursuit of better yields and hedging against the risks of a more insular world. Thematic investing has generated positive returns, with Credit Suisse's supertrend portfolios achieving absolute returns, and CPR AM managing 10 billion euros under thematic investment. Indices have been created to capitalize on this trend, and sustainable investing is also gaining traction, with UBS reporting double-digit returns on sustainable investment strategies.

site_title: Tankers sail after US allows sanctions-hit Cosco unit to wind down oil deals
summary: The US has granted temporary waivers for the wind down of oil deals with Chinese shipping company Cosco Shipping Tanker (Dalian), allowing at least three tankers to sail with US oil cargoes to Asia. The sanctions, imposed last month, had caused record-high oil freight costs worldwide. The US Treasury's notice, effective until Dec 20, allows for the "maintenance or wind down of transactions" involving the Cosco subsidiary. This move is seen as a relief for shippers, with one source stating that ships with cargoes on board are more comfortable to discharge their cargoes.

site_title: Midwood sells 24 units on launch weekend
summary: Hong Leong Holdings sold 24 out of 50 units of its 564-unit Midwood condominium on its launch weekend, with prices averaging S$1,560 to S$1,750 per square foot. The project, near Hillview MRT station, offers childcare facilities and a rooftop infinity pool. Developer Betsy Chng attributes the strong turnout to attractive pricing and the condo's unique features, with a majority of buyers being Singaporeans and others viewing it as a good investment due to its proximity to the MRT station.

images.alt_text: Located at Hillview Rise, Midwood comprises two 29-storey residential blocks 120 metres apart. In between is a six-storey block that has a 569-lot carpark, a covered link bridge connecting the residential towers, and a clubhouse.

site_title: Golden age ending as India's demand, demographics shift
summary: India's demand for gold is declining, with imports falling 24% over the past decade. The country's traditional role as a major gold market is shifting due to demographic changes, with rural population growth slowing down and urbanization increasing. As a result, consumers are increasingly tempted by alternatives such as luxury fashion and smartphones. The decline in gold demand is also linked to the growing availability of banking services and savings accounts, which offer a better way to protect wealth against inflation.

site_title: Beijing's new US$63b mega airport begins international flights
summary: Beijing's Daxing airport, a $63 billion mega airport designed by Zaha Hadid, began its first scheduled international flights on October 27, 2019. The airport, which can handle up to 100 million passengers annually, will initially be used by 50 foreign airlines, with Air China and British Airways being among the initial operators. The relocation of airlines is expected to be completed by 2021, with the airport aiming to relieve pressure on the city's existing Capital airport. The airport's design has been criticized due to its distance from central Beijing.

images.alt_text: About 50 foreign airlines, including Finnair, plan to move all or part of their China operations to the airport, expected to become one of the world's busiest, in the coming quarters.

site_title: Islamic State terror leader killed in US military raid, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the death of Islamic State terror leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in a raid in northern Syria, confirming the leader blew himself up and was later identified through DNA tests. The operation, built on CIA planning, resulted in the death of al-Baghdadi and a large number of his fighters. Trump stated the operation was a success, with no US personnel lost, and praised the involvement of various regional forces, including Iraq and Turkey. The death marks the highest-ranking terrorist leader killed since Osama bin Laden in 2011.

site_title: Open-minded, thoughtful approach the way to regulating fintech, says economist
summary: Singapore is taking an open-minded but thoughtful approach to regulating financial technology, according to economist Beatrice Weder di Mauro. Regulators should look beyond new technologies and base decisions on how instruments operate, she advised. This approach would enable authorities to move quickly and decisively as the ground shifts in the fintech landscape. Weder di Mauro's comments come as Singapore navigates the evolving fintech industry and its implications for the financial sector.

site_title: Row over Kashmir sparks KL-Delhi palm oil tensions
summary: A diplomatic row over Kashmir has sparked tensions between Malaysia and India, with calls to boycott Malaysian palm oil imports. The crisis, fueled by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir's criticism of India's 'invasion and occupation,' has led to potential cutbacks in Europe and further pressure on Malaysia's palm oil sector, the country's second-largest export. The palm oil industry has long been criticized for its environmental impact, including deforestation.

images.alt_text: The boycott calls are a blow to Malaysia - India is the country's third-biggest market for palm oil and palm oil products in 2018, with a value of RM6.84 billion.

site_title: China should ease regulations for foreign financial institutions: HSBC exec
summary: HSBC executive Peter Wong calls for China to ease regulations for foreign financial institutions, citing the need for improved corporate governance and investor protection to mitigate systemic risks. Wong, deputy chairman and CEO of HSBC's Asia-Pacific operations, notes that relaxed foreign ownership rules and deposit requirements would be beneficial for HSBC's expansion in China. He also expresses concerns about the difficulties foreign banks face in accessing deposits in China, which he believes hinders their growth. Wong's comments come as China steps up its financial opening amid a trade war with the US.

site_title: Rich Capital JV receives termination notice from Batam project contractor Rich-Link Konstruksi
summary: Rich Capital's 50-50 joint venture Oxley Karya Indo Batam (OKIB) has received a termination notice from its main contractor Rich-Link Konstruksi (RLK) due to alleged breaches, including non-payment for the Oxley Convention City project in Batam, Indonesia. The notice, received on Oct 23, allows RLK to remove equipment and materials within three days. OKIB denies the allegations and reserves its rights against RLK for losses.

site_title: Advanced manufacturing in tomorrow's factories
summary: Singapore is poised to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. The city-state is also exploring opportunities in sustainable aviation, with a new centre set up to advance the sector in Asia-Pacific. Meanwhile, the government is offering a new grant of up to S$100,000 to businesses hit by tariffs. Graduates are advised to stay calm, with early data showing better employment rates, and workers are encouraged to future-proof their careers before a potential crisis strikes. These initiatives aim to support Singapore's economy and workforce development.

site_title: British govt steps up pressure on Parliament over election vote
summary: The British government, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, is pressing Parliament to back an early election to break the Brexit impasse. However, with the main opposition Labour Party waiting for the EU to grant a Brexit delay, the government's bid is unlikely to succeed. Johnson has threatened to consider options from other opposition parties if Labour opposes an election, raising concerns about his commitment to delivering Brexit. The government's efforts to force an election come as the country is still debating the terms of Brexit, with the EU agreeing to another delay until January 31.

site_title: Lebanese protesters form human chain across country amid mounting tensions
summary: Tens of thousands of Lebanese protesters formed a human chain across the country, spanning 170 kilometers, to demonstrate national unity and reject sectarian affiliations. The chain, formed on October 27, 2019, was a result of an unprecedented cross-sectarian mobilization, with protesters demanding a complete overhaul of the political system. The movement, driven by a young generation, has been relatively incident-free despite tensions with security forces, with protesters calling for the removal of the ruling class.

site_title: Hong Leong sells 24 Midwood condo units on launch weekend
summary: Hong Leong Holdings sold 24 out of 50 Midwood condo units on the launch weekend, achieving a 48% take-up rate. The 564-unit project, located near the Hillview MRT station, offers unique facilities such as a childcare centre. Selling prices averaged S$1,560 to S$1,750 per sq ft. Developer Betsy Chng attributed the strong turnout to attractive pricing and the project's mass market appeal. Experts praised Midwood's value proposition, citing its proximity to lifestyle amenities and natural surroundings.

site_title: Downfall of Britain's top fund manager a blow to market confidence: analysts
summary: Neil Woodford, Britain's top fund manager, has seen his investment management firm collapse due to a series of disastrous investments, resulting in significant losses for customers, including pension funds and wealthy individuals. The collapse has tarnished the reputation of London's City finance district and hurt market confidence, with analysts describing it as a blow to the industry. Woodford had taken on too much risk, including investing in unlisted healthcare and technology companies, and was unable to raise sufficient cash to meet investor demands. The incident has sparked calls for the sector to regain trust and has raised concerns about the long-term impact on investors.

site_title: A-Sonic Aerospace to divest associate company for HK$11.8m
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace plans to divest its 40% interest in Hong Kong-based cargo handling firm Silver Express International Limited for HK$11.8 million (S$2.04 million). The move is part of the company's plan to divest non-core and non-strategic business units. The proceeds will be used to fund working capital and/or reduce bank borrowings, without changing the risk profile of the group. The transaction requires shareholder approval and will result in a surplus of proceeds over net book value, increasing net tangible assets per share.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: There is no article content to summarize, only a list of unrelated news headlines.

site_title: US stocks ride trade, Brexit hopes to record high but risks loom
summary: US stocks rose to record highs last week, driven by optimism over Brexit and US-China trade relations, despite weak earnings and economic data. However, the optimism may be short-lived, with the Federal Reserve set to reveal its latest rate decision this week, which could impact the stock market. Apple's growth outlook and earnings report will also be closely watched, and the Phase One trade deal between the US and China may not prevent tensions from weighing on global trade.

site_title: Resilient demand for commercial, retail properties in Bangkok
summary: Bangkok's commercial and retail property market remains optimistic, driven by resilient demand. Total investment sales volume increased 1.1% to 12.1 billion baht in Q3, with the largest deal valued at 4.3 billion baht. Occupancy rates in the central business district (CBD) are expected to hold firm, but competition is expected to intensify in the next few years. Average rents for prime office spaces in the CBD increased 0.5% to 1,075 baht per square meter, while retail occupancy is expected to perform better in Q4.

site_title: She's in the fast line, but she knows howto balance life
summary: Brenda Pek, a Network Development Manager at BMW Group Asia, joined the company in 2015 and rose to Marketing Director two years later. Pek's career success is highlighted in an article titled "She's in the fast line, but she knows how to balance life."

site_title: JS Global pulls Hong Kong listing amid trade gloom - sources
summary: JS Global Lifestyle Company Ltd pulled its HK$3.62 billion IPO, the third float delayed in Hong Kong this year, due to insufficient investor orders amid trade gloom. The company planned to price the IPO at the lower end of the indicative range, but was unable to secure enough solid orders to proceed. Investors have been wary of the impact of the trade war on the consumer sector, with Chinese consumers scaling back purchases.

site_title: Upcoming reports from money-losing unicorns may test Wall Street patience
summary: Investors are becoming increasingly cautious as "money-losing unicorn" startups, such as Beyond Meat and Uber, prepare to report quarterly results. Wary of an ageing bull market and US-China trade war fallout, investors are scrutinizing companies' fundamentals and management teams before making new bets. This trend has led to a decline in stocks like Lyft, Uber, and Peloton Interactive, which have fallen after their initial public offerings. Analysts expect Beyond Meat to report a net profit of $2.48 million, but the stock has still tumbled 33% in October, leaving its gain since its May IPO at about 300%.

site_title: SoftBank eyeing burgers, digital pharmacy for second Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank's successor to its $100 billion Vision Fund is in talks to invest in pharmaceutical delivery startup Alto Pharmacy, robotic burger-making company Creator, and lab-grown meat maker Memphis Meats. The new fund, expected to be even larger than the first, is being raised to invest around $50 billion annually. This marks a shift towards earlier-stage investments, with Creator and Memphis Meats raising significantly less than Alto Pharmacy. The fund's size and scope remain uncertain, amid concerns over the performance of some of its previous investments, including WeWork and Uber.

site_title: Greece's rating raised by S&P as budgetary risks subside
summary: Greece's credit rating was raised by Standard & Poor's by one notch to BB- from B+, reflecting confidence in the country's new government and policies. The rating remains three levels below junk, indicating Greece still needs to implement more reforms to regain its investment-grade rating. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi emphasized the need for continued reforms, saying Greece has turned the corner but still faces challenges.

site_title: US bars airline flights to all Cuban airports except Havana from Dec 10
summary: The US government will bar US airlines from flying to all Cuban airports except Havana starting on December 10, in an effort to pressure the Cuban government. This move affects about eight flights a day, primarily impacting Cuban Americans visiting home. The action is part of the Trump administration's policy to strengthen economic consequences for Cuba's repression of its people and support for Nicolas Maduro in Venezuela. Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez condemned the move, stating it would not force Cuba to make concessions to US demands.

site_title: Trumps put their Washington hotel on the market
summary: The Trump Organization has listed the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C. for sale, citing a desire to explore options and address criticism over the hotel's foreign government business and potential conflicts of interest. The hotel, which opened in 2016, has been a source of revenue for the Trump family, collecting $40.8 million last year. The sale would need to be approved by the General Services Administration and the company's ethics adviser. The move comes amid impeachment proceedings and a tough 2020 reelection campaign, with critics accusing Mr. Trump of violating the Constitution by accepting payments from foreign governments.

site_title: Limited impact from US trade benefits suspension: Thailand
summary: Thailand's exports to the US are expected to be limited impacted by the suspension of US trade benefits, with an estimated annual loss of US$32.8 million in 2020. The US decision, triggered by concerns over workers' rights, will affect a small proportion of Thai exports and primarily target products for which the US is a relatively important market. Thai seafood products will also be removed from the generalised system of preferences, which provides duty-free treatment for developing nations. The impact is seen as limited, with Thai Union Group stating it doesn't expect a material operational impact.

site_title: US budget deficit soars to almost US$1t, highest since 2012
