summary: The US budget deficit surged to nearly $1 trillion in the 2019 fiscal year, the highest since 2012, with borrowing swelled and spending outpacing tax receipts. Republican lawmakers' concerns about fiscal discipline have diminished, and trillion-dollar annual deficits are expected to become a new normal. The deficit jumped 26% to $984 billion, driven by the 2017 tax cuts and rising interest on public debts. The Treasury Secretary attributed the increase to "wasteful and irresponsible spending," but the White House has prioritized other priorities, including a stronger military.

site_title: Rich Capital JV receives termination notice from Batam project contractor
summary: Rich Capital's Oxley Convention City project in Batam, Indonesia has received a notice of termination from contractor Rich-Link Konstruksi (RLK) due to continued breaches by OKIB, a 50-50 joint venture between Rich Capital and an Indonesian partner. RLK intends to remove equipment and materials within three days and reserves rights for losses suffered. OKIB denies allegations and reserves its rights for wrongful termination and abandonment of works. The notice comes after a notice of default was received by OKIB in September, alleging non-payment despite certified progress payments.

site_title: Fed rate decision, trade truce to set market direction
summary: The global market outlook is expected to be influenced by the US Federal Reserve's rate decision on October 31 and the potential completion of a Phase One trade deal between the US and China. Despite China's industrial profits declining 5.3% in September, investors remain optimistic, with many expecting a 25-basis point interest rate cut by the Fed. The US stock market has been resilient, with the S&P 500 nearing its record high, and analysts predict further positive steps in the trade war between the US and China will support record highs.

site_title: Australia to settle more immigrants outside major cities
summary: The Australian government has announced plans to increase the number of visas for skilled workers willing to migrate to the country's regions, aiming to ease population pressure on major cities. The intake under the regional migration program will rise to 25,000 from 23,000. The move is part of the annual migration cap, which has been reduced to 160,000 people. The goal is to support regional growth and create a stronger economy for Australia.

images.alt_text: The Australian government said on Saturday it is increasing the number of visas for skilled workers willing to migrate to the country's regions in a bid to ease pressure on major cities, where populations are growing twice as fast as elsewhere.

site_title: Protecting oil: Trump's latest Syria strategy under question
summary: US President Donald Trump has shifted his strategy in Syria, focusing on protecting oil fields from the Islamic State group. However, experts question the new approach's legality and realism, as the US is not authorized to control Syria's resources. Defense Secretary Mark Esper confirmed US troops are reinforcing positions in Deir Ezzor to prevent the group from accessing oil fields. The move has raised concerns that the US is holding Syria's oil hostage, potentially forcing changes in President Bashar al-Assad's behavior.

site_title: UAW turns to Ford after GM workers approve new contract
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) union has chosen Ford Motor Co as its next US carmaker to negotiate with after General Motors Co workers approved a new contract deal. The UAW reported 57% of hourly workers at GM voted to approve the deal, ending a 40-day US strike. Talks with Ford are expected to begin on Monday, following the completion of a similar negotiation with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA), which was agreed upon last week.

site_title: A Paris colony for exiled artists needs a new home
summary: A Paris-based colony for exiled artists, L'Atelier des Artistes en Exil, is facing an uncertain future after its current location near the Gare de Lyon station is set to be vacated in December. The non-profit association, which supports over 200 artists from 40 countries, relies on public funding and relies on volunteers for various services. Founded in 2017, L'Atelier aims to provide a permanent home for artists fleeing war, poverty, and oppression, and has welcomed artists who have received asylum status in France. The colony's future remains uncertain, highlighting the challenges faced by refugees and artists in finding a safe and supportive community.

site_title: A-Sonic to divest 40% stake in HK-based associate company
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace plans to divest its 40% stake in Hong Kong-based cargo-handling firm Silver Express International Limited for HK$11.8 million (S$2.04 million), aiming to fund working capital and reduce bank borrowings. The transaction, subject to shareholder approval, will not change the group's risk profile. If completed on Dec 31, 2018, the group expects to realize a surplus of proceeds over net book value of US$2.419 million, increasing net tangible assets per share. The proceeds will be used to fund working capital and/or reduce bank borrowings.

site_title: Bitcoin surges 15% in bounce back from 5-month lows
summary: Bitcoin surged 15% to US$8,574, rebounding from its lowest levels since May, amid a general risk-on rally in financial markets. Traders cited speculation and arbitrage as reasons for the price increase. Altcoins also rallied, with Ether jumping 12% and Litcoin gaining 14%. The recovery is seen as a positive sentiment, with more buyers than sellers, leading to a market going higher. This surge may also be influenced by China's plans to speed up development of blockchain technology and industry.

site_title: Mexican town turned to war zone fears new era of narco violence
summary: A recent wave of violence in Culiacan, Mexico's Sinaloa state capital, has raised fears of a new era of narco violence. On October 17, a botched attempt to arrest Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman's son, Ovidio, turned the city into an urban war zone, with 13 people killed, including four civilians. Residents fear this could mark the start of a violent new chapter in the city's uneasy coexistence with the Sinaloa cartel, which has become increasingly brazen and violent under the leadership of Guzman's sons.

site_title: Judge validates Trump impeachment inquiry, orders Mueller document release
summary: US District Judge Beryl Howell validated the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, ruling that the House of Representatives has the authority to initiate the inquiry without a formal resolution. The judge ordered the Justice Department to release unredacted copies of former special counsel Robert Mueller's report detailing Russian interference in the 2016 election. The decision affirms Congress's authority to expose the truth and holds Trump accountable for his actions, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling it "another blow to President Trump's attempt to put himself above the law."

site_title: Hong Kong medics join anti-govt protests to "resist tyranny"
summary: Hong Kong medical workers plan to rally against perceived police brutality during anti-government protests. The rallies come after months of violent clashes between protesters and police, with protesters using petrol bombs, rocks, and lasers, while police responded with tear gas, water cannon, and rubber bullets. The protesters are angry about perceived Chinese interference in Hong Kong, which they see as a breach of the "one country, two systems" formula. The rally, titled "resisting tyranny," is set to begin at 7pm on Saturday.

site_title: After WeWork, the market is concerned about SoftBank's massive debt load again
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's massive debt load is raising concerns after unveiling a US$9.5 billion bailout for WeWork, hurting its shares and bonds. Analysts expect the company's loan-to-value ratio to rise, potentially exceeding 25%, as a result of the acquisition. SoftBank's leverage is already at 18% and the company's CEO, Masayoshi Son, aims to keep it below 25%. The company is also planning a US$5 billion writedown in its Vision Fund to reflect declining investment values. Rating companies have maintained its junk debt score, and its shares have dropped 6.6% this week.

site_title: Hong Kong led global IPO market since start of Sept
summary: Hong Kong led the global initial public offerings (IPO) market since September, with a total value of $7.9 billion in first-time share sales, surpassing the Nasdaq and New York stock exchanges. Despite protests and a trade war, Hong Kong's market has shown resilience, with several high-profile deals, including Anheuser-Busch InBev's $5.8 billion IPO and Topsports International Holdings' $1 billion sale. The city's IPO volumes have dropped 43% from last year, but experts remain optimistic, predicting a busy end to the year with several deals in the pipeline.

site_title: Death toll climbs to 10 as heavy rains hit typhoon-ravaged eastern Japan
summary: Heavy rains in eastern Japan have raised the death toll from 7 to 10, with three others missing, just two weeks after the region was hit by a powerful typhoon. Torrential downpours caused flooding and mudslides in Chiba and Fukushima prefectures, with some areas receiving over a month's worth of rain in a single day. Evacuation orders and advisories were issued, and hundreds of residents were still in shelters. Authorities warned of further landslides and floods, especially in areas hit by levee breaks after Typhoon Hagibis. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is leading disaster relief efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong court bans publishing police details, including photos
summary: A Hong Kong court has issued a 14-day temporary injunction banning the publication of personal details about police officers and their families, including photos, in an effort to halt "doxxing" by pro-democracy protesters. The ban, which leaves no exceptions, has been criticized for its broad wording and potential impact on media freedoms. The move comes amid nearly five months of violent protests in the city, with police and protesters clashing over democracy and police actions.

site_title: Moderate Peronist Fernandez closes in on Argentine presidency
summary: Alberto Fernandez, a 60-year-old law professor and Peronist, is closing in on the Argentine presidency after trouncing President Mauricio Macri in August primaries. Opinion polls suggest a repeat performance in Sunday's elections. Fernandez, a former chief of staff in Nestor Kirchner's administration, has positioned himself as a "leftist liberal, a progressive liberal" with a focus on individual freedoms and state intervention in the market. He has sought to reassure markets and calm ordinary Argentines, and has taken a stance on foreign policy that differs from Macri's, including recognizing Nicolas Maduro as president.

site_title: Microsoft wins Pentagon's US$10b cloud computing contract, beating Amazon
summary: Microsoft has won a $10 billion cloud computing contract with the US Pentagon, beating Amazon in a process marred by conflict of interest allegations. The Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure Cloud (JEDI) contract aims to modernize the Defense Department's IT systems. The decision comes after a long and contentious process, with Microsoft's win seen as a significant victory for the company. The contract is part of a broader effort to make the Defense Department more digitally agile and secure.

site_title: Qatar Airways, JAL among suitors for Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia Airlines is being considered for a strategic stake by three international carriers: Qatar Airways, Japan Airlines, and China Southern Airlines. The Malaysian government's sovereign fund, Khazanah Nasional Bhd, has shortlisted four potential investors, with the three airlines being the most likely candidates. The airline's financial performance took a hit last year, with a significant impairment due to sustaining operations, and it only has enough cash to last until April next year. A decision on the preferred candidate is expected soon.

images.alt_text: Three international carriers have put in bids to buy a strategic stake in the ailing Malaysian carrier, Malaysia Airlines, according to a report published on Saturday by business weekly The Edge Malaysia.

site_title: Close to a million protesters demand Chile president's resignation
summary: Approximately 900,000 protesters in Chile's capital, Santiago, demanded President Sebastian Pinera's resignation, calling for economic reforms and an end to a state of emergency. The protests, which began a week ago, have resulted in 19 deaths, 584 injuries, and 2,410 detentions. Demonstrators, mostly from low-income backgrounds, chanted against the country's socio-economic structure, with some calling for a more state-led economy. Pinera announced measures to address the protests, but protesters say his proposals will not be enough.

site_title: Barclay family puts Telegraph newspapers up for sale: The Times
summary: The Barclay family, owners of the Daily and Sunday Telegraph newspapers, has put the publications up for sale as part of a review of its multibillion-pound business investments in the UK. Potential buyers include Daily Mail and General Trust, owner of the Evening Standard and The Independent newspapers. The sale is part of a generational shift within the family, with slimming down the portfolio expected to generate capital to buy out some family members. David and Frederick Barclay, who own The Ritz London, have also hinted at selling the hotel for $1 billion.

site_title: Russian agent Butina released from US prison, deported
summary: Convicted Russian agent Maria Butina was released from a Florida prison on Friday after serving 18 months of her sentence for conspiring to influence US conservative activists and infiltrate the National Rifle Association. She was taken into custody by immigration officials and deported to Russia. Butina, 31, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to act as a foreign agent and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed "outrage" over her prison sentence, saying she did not carry out any orders from Russian security services.

site_title: S&P cuts Ford's debt rating, citing weak profits
summary: Ratings agency S&P cut Ford's debt rating to BBB- due to weak profits from falling sales and rising costs. The downgrade follows Moody's similar move last month, and Ford's own profit outlook cut in October. S&P expects Ford's restructuring efforts to face execution risks, but notes the outlook remains stable. The company has incurred significant restructuring charges, with up to $11 billion in costs over four years, and expects profits to improve and liquidity to remain strong.

site_title: UE offer: Yanlord and Perennial cut another curious deal
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has sold its shares in United Engineers (UE) to Yanlord Land for zero profit, at a price below market, with Perennial making a 25.3% gain from the sale. The deal suggests WBL Corp, a subsidiary of UE, is valued richly relative to UE, with WBL's net asset value barely changing since 2017. Yanlord has increased its exposure to WBL, raising concerns among UE's minority shareholders, who may face a mandatory offer at the same price. The deal provides Perennial with S$202.7 million in fresh cash to alleviate near-term liquidity.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts 0.4% dip in Q3 DPU on enlarged unit base
summary: ESR-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 0.4% decline in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to 1 Singapore cent, driven by higher expenses and an enlarged unit base. The trust's gross revenue rose 91.5% to S$62 million, while net property income more than doubled to S$45.3 million, due to acquisitions and rental escalations. Despite this, the trust expects headwinds from global demand and US-China talks to impact business performance in the short-to-medium term.

site_title: Wells Fargo lays off more than 200 business bankers in US: sources
summary: Wells Fargo has laid off more than 200 business bankers in its US lending divisions, primarily affecting energy and agriculture portfolios. The cuts, which include a 25% reduction in agricultural lending, aim to centralize operations and shed risk. The move is seen as a blow to energy companies and cash-strapped farmers, who will need to find new lenders. Despite the cuts, Wells Fargo plans to retain its position as the largest bank lender to the US agriculture sector and is currently hiring agricultural bankers in certain markets.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co has laid off more than 200 bankers in its US lending divisions in recent months, as the bank reacted to business trends and restructured some units, sources familiar with the matter said this week.

site_title: HDB resale flats demand still strong in third quarter
summary: Demand for Housing Board (HDB) resale flats in Singapore remained strong in the third quarter of 2019, with 6,264 transactions recorded between July and September. Analysts attribute this to government measures aimed at improving affordability, including enhanced housing grants and greater flexibility in using Central Provident Fund monies. The number of transactions was 11.3% lower than the same period last year, but still the second-highest Q3 transaction in the last seven years. Experts expect sustained demand and prices to stabilize, with forecasts of 22,000 to 24,000 transactions for the full year.

site_title: US, China "close to finalising" part of a Phase One trade deal: USTR
summary: US and Chinese officials are "close to finalizing" parts of a Phase One trade deal after high-level telephone discussions, the US Trade Representative's office said. The deal aims to address US concerns over trade and intellectual property practices in exchange for China's increased purchases of US commodities. Beijing wants the US to cancel existing tariffs on Chinese imports in return, while the US wants a commitment to buying products at a specific time and price. The deal is expected to include exemptions for US agricultural products from tariffs, including soybeans, wheat, and corn.

site_title: Musk says Tesla has finally made a ready-to-deploy solar roof
summary: Tesla has finally developed a mass-producible version of its solar roof shingles, nearly three years after Elon Musk unveiled the product in 2016. The sleek roof tiles, designed to resemble regular shingles, are a key part of Tesla's push to revive its struggling solar business. Musk acknowledged the complexity of integrating electrification into the roof, but expressed confidence in the product's readiness for deployment. This development is seen as a significant step forward for Tesla's solar business.

site_title: Trump reinstates duty-free trade for some Ukrainian goods, suspends it for some Thai goods
summary: US President Donald Trump reinstated duty-free trade for about a third of $36 million in Ukrainian goods, ending a suspension due to inadequate intellectual property protection. The move comes after Ukraine made progress in protecting IP rights. In contrast, duty-free trade for certain Thai goods was suspended due to similar concerns. The changes were announced in a presidential proclamation by the US Trade Representative's office.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Friday reinstated duty-free trade for certain items from Ukraine, but suspended it with Thailand.

site_title: SoftBank eyes burgers, digital pharmacy for second Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank's successor to its $100 billion Vision Fund is seeking investments in a pharmaceutical delivery startup, a robotic burger-making company, and a lab-grown meat maker. The fund, expected to be larger than the first, is in talks with startups Alto Pharmacy, Creator, and Memphis Meats. The investments come as the original Vision Fund is nearing its end and faces potential writedowns due to the decline in value of some of its holdings, including WeWork and Uber. SoftBank has secured commitments from investors including Apple and Microsoft, but some major backers have reconsidered their investment due to the fund's performance.

site_title: Oil spill clean-up on Brazilian beaches making volunteers sick
summary: Hundreds of volunteers in northeastern Brazil are getting sick from cleaning oil spills on beaches without proper equipment. The mysterious oil, believed to be Venezuelan crude, has been washing up for nearly two months, and authorities have been baffled by its origin. 19 people have been treated in hospital for intoxication, and hundreds more have reported symptoms. Experts warn that exposure to the oil is hazardous and can cause injury or death. Authorities claim to have followed standard protocols, but critics say their response has been inadequate.

site_title: US: S&P 500 nears record high on trade progress, upbeat Intel earnings
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the S&P 500 nearing a record high after Washington said it was close to finalizing parts of a trade pact with Beijing. Intel's strong quarterly earnings report also boosted investor sentiment, sending the S&P 500 briefly over its record high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.57%, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.7%. The S&P 500 ended the day at 3,022.55, surpassing its closing record of 3,025.86 set in July.

site_title: What can AI and Big Data do for investing?
summary: AI and Big Data are transforming the investment management industry, enabling professionals to access more and different types of information in real-time. By harnessing machine learning and deep learning, analysts can uncover new relationships and patterns in unstructured data, such as social media postings and satellite imagery. This will allow for more efficient and accurate investment decisions. To succeed, investment professionals will need to develop T-shaped skills, combining specialized investment knowledge with technology and soft skills, and prioritize continuous professional development to stay adaptable in an evolving landscape.

site_title: In search of intelligence in the business world
summary: The article explores the concept of intelligence in the business world, challenging the notion that academics and business people are mutually exclusive. Intelligence is defined as judgment, guesswork, luck, and confidence, requiring a mix of measuring, forecasting, persuading, and courage. To assess an employee's intelligence, one should look for perception, creativity, and the ability to see relationships. This can be done through role plays and real-life scenarios, rather than relying on numerical intelligence tests. The article also highlights the importance of developing one's own intellect to keep up with the increasing use of AI in decision-making.

site_title: There are symbiotic values between golf and business
summary: There are symbiotic values between golf and business, according to Datuk Karunakaran, as seen during a meeting at the Singapore Open. The connection between the two fields was discussed, but no specific details or events were mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Top F1 teams wanted rule changes delayed to 2022
summary: Leading Formula One teams, including Red Bull, expressed disappointment over the proposed 2021 technical regulations, calling them "immature" and leaving many questions unanswered. The teams had initially wanted to delay the rule changes until 2022, but now see little chance of this happening. Red Bull principal Christian Horner stated that a "bit of an opportunity" had been missed, implying that the teams may have to adapt to the current regulations. The proposal, the result of years of debate, aims to introduce a cost cap in 2021.

site_title: Indonesia 2019 fiscal deficit seen widening up to 2.2% of GDP, says official
summary: Indonesia's fiscal deficit is expected to widen to 2.0-2.2% of GDP in 2019, exceeding initial forecasts of 1.93%. The country's economic growth is forecast to slow to 5.1% for the first time in four years due to weak investment and falling exports. To finance the deficit, the government may slash operational allocations and raise funds through bond sales. The Asian Development Bank has approved a $500 million loan to improve fiscal management. The government's 2020 fiscal deficit projection remains unchanged at 1.76% of GDP.

site_title: Oil prices clock strong weekly gains on trade hopes, crude supply
summary: Oil prices surged, posting the strongest weekly gains in over a month, driven by optimism over a US-China trade deal, falling US crude stocks, and possible OPEC action to extend output cuts. West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.8% to $56.66 a barrel, and Brent crude rose 0.6% to $62.02 a barrel. The gains were fueled by signs of progress in US-China trade talks and a surprise drop in US inventories. However, concerns over weakening economic growth continue to weigh on prices.

site_title: Citi names Jane Fraser as president, putting her in line to be first female CEO
summary: Citi has named Jane Fraser as its president, a role that puts her in line to become the bank's first female CEO. Fraser, 52, will replace Stephen Bird, who is leaving after 20 years to pursue an external opportunity. The promotion indicates that Fraser is being groomed for the top spot, which has been vacant since Jamie Forese's departure earlier this year. Fraser has been a rising star on Wall Street, with a 15-year tenure at Citi and a track record of helping the bank recover after the financial crisis.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Emas Offshore has been granted judicial management by the Singapore Court, with PricewaterhouseCoopers appointed as joint judicial managers to manage the company's affairs and assets. Meanwhile, Darco Water Technologies has signed a non-binding letter of intent with Emsus to acquire 75% of PT Panghegar Energy Indonesia, with the deal expected to provide a profitable and recurring revenue stream.

site_title: Europe: Luxury stocks drive fifth day of gains
summary: European luxury stocks drove gains for a fifth consecutive session, with the main European equities benchmark rising 0.2% on Friday. The S&P 500 surpassed its record closing high after US-China trade talks made progress, while luxury goods makers like Gucci and Moncler reported upbeat earnings. However, the food and beverage sector led losses after AB InBev reported weaker-than-expected earnings growth. The EU failed to set a Brexit deadline, with the UK parliament squabbling over Prime Minister Boris Johnson's call for an election.

site_title: Sony WF-1000XM3 wireless earbuds: the sweet sound of silence
summary: The Sony WF-1000XM3 wireless earbuds have received high praise for their superior active noise cancellation, great sound quality, and clever features. Unlike its predecessor, the WF-1000X, the WF-1000XM3 has addressed previous issues such as audio dropouts and battery life. As a result, it is considered the ultimate pair of wireless earbuds available today, offering a seamless listening experience.

site_title: A duff and a 75
summary: A golfer hit a 75 on the 180-meter first hole of the Singapore Island Country Club's Sime course, with his five-iron tee shot rolling 120 meters into the left rough.

site_title: Canada's national housing agency says market expected to recover in the next 2 years
summary: Canada's national housing agency, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC), predicts the housing market will recover in the next two years. Housing starts are expected to decline to 188,500-196,000 units in 2019 before stabilizing at 200,000 units in 2020 and 2021. Home sales and prices are expected to increase due to income and population growth, reaching 498,000-519,100 sales by 2021. The average home price is projected to be around C$488,000 in 2019 and C$539,800-569,600 by 2021. Global trade tensions and high household debt remain vulnerabilities.

site_title: Positive reading for retail property market in Q3 but risks remain
summary: Singapore's retail property market showed a positive performance in Q3 with a 2.3% increase in rents, the steepest gain since 2011. This was driven by retailers' cautious optimism and confidence in government initiatives. However, challenges in the retail landscape and subdued economic conditions are expected to continue to pressure the industry, with some brands shutting stores. Analysts predict a limited supply of new retail space and a tightening of the islandwide vacancy rate, which could cushion any decline in rents.

site_title: Yanlord makes new mandatory offer for United Engineers
summary: Yanlord Investment (Singapore) is making a new mandatory offer for United Engineers (UE) at S$2.60 per share, valuing the company at S$1.66 billion. This is the same offer price as in 2017, when a consortium led by Yanlord bought out Perennial Real Estate and Heng Yue Holdings. The offer will turn unconditional if Yanlord gains control of at least 50% of UE's shares. Yanlord aims to consolidate its interest in UE and WBL Corp, with no plans to delist UE or make major changes to its business.

images.alt_text: UE BizHub City (formerly known as UE Square) is the flagship building of United Engineers Limited, at least half of which Yanlord Land Group is seeking to gain control.

site_title: SGX surges nearly 7% after reporting highest quarterly profit in over a decade
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) surged nearly 7% after reporting its highest quarterly net profit in over a decade, reaching a five-year high. The stock ended the day at S$8.85, up 57 cents, with analysts differing on its outlook. DBS Group Research and JP Morgan were bullish with "buy" ratings, while OCBC had a "hold" call. Key risks include competition from HKEx and potential earnings downside if SGX faces increased competition in its derivatives business.

site_title: No effort spared in preparing SEA Games golf team
summary: The Singapore men's South-east Asia Games golf team has been thoroughly prepared for the upcoming SEA Games, with no effort spared. The team, which aims to secure two crowns, has been training intensively to perfect their skills and strategies. The team's dedication and hard work are expected to pay off as they compete against the best golfers from the region. With a strong focus on teamwork and mental preparation, the Singapore golfers are poised to make a significant impact in the SEA Games.

site_title: Gold strengthens over global growth anxieties
summary: Gold prices strengthened due to global economic growth anxieties, despite disappointing US economic data. Investors remain cautious about recessionary fears and a weaker global backdrop, supporting safe haven assets. Central banks' monetary policy loosening is expected to keep bullion appeal positive for Q4 2019.

site_title: State of transition in the Sustainability Revolution
summary: The Sustainability Revolution is a significant investment opportunity in modern history, driven by the need to decouple economic growth from its adverse social and environmental footprint. As the global population continues to change, economic growth must be inclusive and sustainable to address societal challenges. Companies that adapt to this transition, embracing sustainability, will thrive, while those that fail will face mounting challenges. Asset managers like Lombard Odier are identifying "Eagles" – forward-looking companies that embed sustainability – and "Ostriches" – those with poor governance structures – to capitalize on opportunities and manage risks.

images.alt_text: It is essential that we continue to generate economic growth, but our model for doing so has to change. We urgently need to decouple economic growth from its adverse social and environmental footprint.

site_title: Elite eight of women's tennis ready for battle
summary: Eight top women's tennis players, including Ashleigh Barty, Karolina Pliskova, and Naomi Osaka, are competing in the inaugural WTA Finals in Shenzhen, China, with a record $14 million prize purse. The tournament, which began on Sunday, features the top singles players and doubles pairings, with Barty as the top seed. Other notable players include Simona Halep, Bianca Andreescu, Petra Kvitova, Belinda Bencic, and Elina Svitolina. The event marks the first of ten editions of the WTA Finals, with the winner earning the title of world No. 1.

images.alt_text: Above: Ashleigh Barty, the current world No 1 player and the reigning French Open champion, boasts one of the best serves on the women's tour.
Karolina Pliskova, known as the "ace queen" for her powerful serve, has had a fine year so far, claiming four trophies already.

site_title: EHT dives 15.5% on Queen Mary lease worries
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) saw its stock price plummet 15.5% to 54.5 cents after a lease dispute with the city of Long Beach over the historic Queen Mary. Despite the trust's assurance that its sponsor Urban Commons is not at risk, concerns remain. Analysts predict a 22% decline in distribution per unit and 21% drop in net asset value per share if the Queen Mary's valuation is written down to zero. However, some traders see the counter as oversold, with one dealer calling it an "attractive level" for buying.

images.alt_text: EHT's sponsor has confirmed it is not in default on the lease and that the Queen Mary floating hotel is 'safe and structurally sound'.

site_title: Four million slum dwellers in Delhi to win property rights
summary: India's cabinet has passed a bill to regularize 1,797 unauthorised slums in Delhi, giving over 4 million residents property rights at "minimal rates". The plan, which has been floated for over a decade, aims to provide residents with ownership, improve living conditions, and encourage investment in safe structures. The law will be presented for passage in parliament in mid-November, with mapping and registration to begin shortly. The move is seen as a step towards addressing the issue of urban squalor and providing access to affordable housing for millions of residents.

site_title: HPH Trust Q3 earnings dip due to higher tax
summary: HPH Trust, a Singapore-based container terminal trust, reported a 2.9% drop in profit to HK$232.5 million for its third quarter due to higher taxation. Revenue and other income remained steady at HK$3.03 billion. The trust expects global trade to be sluggish due to intensifying trade tensions and geopolitical risks, and will focus on cost discipline and efficiency improvements. Despite a decline in US cargo, outbound cargo to the European Union grew by 6% compared to last year.

site_title: New single-family home sales in the US dip in September
summary: US single-family home sales declined 0.7% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 701,000 units, matching expectations. This follows a 15.5% year-over-year gain. The median new house price fell 8.8% to $299,400, the largest monthly drop in five years. Low inventories and high prices continue to weigh on the market, despite a reduction in interest rates and a fourth consecutive month of single-family home construction growth.

site_title: CRCT's Q3 DPU edges up 0.8% on malls' growth, contributions
summary: CRCT's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.8% to 2.43 Singapore cents for Q3 2019, driven by growth from existing malls and contributions from three newly acquired malls. Distributable income and net property income increased 13.9% and 11.9%, respectively. The trust's CEO attributed the growth to China's resilient consumer confidence, with retail sales and urban household disposable income growing 8.2% and 7.9% year-on-year. The acquisitions boosted the portfolio size by 17.1% and gross rentable area by 23.5%.

site_title: Modest recovery in factory output for September
summary: Singapore's factory output recovered modestly in September, driven by a 21.9% expansion in biomedical manufacturing. Despite economists' expectations of a contraction, total manufacturing output grew 0.1% year-on-year, with electronics sector showing improvement. The electronics cluster, which had been hit hard by trade disruptions, is expected to benefit from the US-China trade deal. The overall economy is expected to escape a technical recession in Q3, with GDP growth potentially reaching 0.5% for the full year.

site_title: URA's Q3 private home price index posts 1.3% q-o-q rise
summary: Singapore's overall private home price index rose 1.3% in Q3 2019, higher than the 0.9% flash estimate, driven by a 1.0% increase in landed home prices due to the inclusion of transacted prices for the Luxus Hills project. This is the second consecutive quarter-on-quarter rise in the index. Non-landed home prices in prime areas like Core Central Region (CCR) and city fringe increased, while the CCR rental market declined. The vacancy rate for completed private homes improved to 6.1%, but the rental index for non-landed homes in OCR rose 0.8%.

site_title: Singapore shares extend gains on Friday, up 2.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's stock market ended the week on a high note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 2.3% for the week, boosted by better-than-expected factory output and talks of China scrapping punitive tariffs. However, caution remained over US-China trade talks, with US Vice-President Mike Pence criticizing China. Asian markets were mixed, with Australia, China, and Japan finishing higher, while South Korea was flat and Hong Kong and Malaysia ended lower.

site_title: Reits (October 26-27, 2019)
summary: Realtors in Singapore reported a surge in demand for luxury properties above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark, amid a Q3 wave of condo launches. This increase in demand is expected to test the market for prime projects. Meanwhile, global market trends show rising mortgage rates in the US and increasing home prices in Manhattan, with record-breaking rents also reported in the city. In other news, a South Korean conglomerate has acquired a large portfolio of hotel and retail assets in Seoul, and a UK index shows a rebound in homebuyer demand.

site_title: Stay in shape even during a vacation
summary: A vacation doesn't have to derail a workout regimen. Eight tips can help maintain a healthy exercise routine while traveling: choose a hotel with good fitness facilities, pack essential workout gear, and consider activities like walking or swimming. These tips can be applied in cold or warm climates. With some planning, a holiday can be a great opportunity to stay active and refreshed.

site_title: A menagerie of French whimsy takes auction prices 'to the next level'
summary: French sculptors François-Xavier Lalanne and Claude Lalanne's auction at Sotheby's in Paris raised 48 million euros, exceeding the low estimate of 15.9 million euros. The sale featured 41 lots, including unique pieces like a rhinoceros-shaped writing desk, which sold for 5.4 million euros, and a trio of gilded bronze sheep sculptures that sold for 2.1 million euros. The couple's whimsical and surreal creations have had a cult following since the 1960s, with collectors like Peter Marino and Bernard Arnault. The sale has set new prices for the artists, with some pieces selling for almost four times their high estimates.

site_title: India telco fines could cut competition for Singtel Bharti Airtel
summary: India's mobile operators have been ordered to pay the state 920 billion rupees (S$17.6 billion) after a protracted legal tussle over licence fees. Bharti Airtel, a key regional associate, may benefit from the ruling as rival Vodafone Idea is likely to struggle to pay its dues, potentially forcing it out of the market. This could lead to a duopoly between Bharti Airtel and Reliance Jio, benefiting Bharti Airtel and, by extension, Singtel, which saw its net profit decline due to regional associates' results.

site_title: Higher rental income from HK property lifts MNACT's Q2 payout
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 1.3% increase in net property income to S$84.7 million in Q2, driven by higher rental income from Festival Walk in Hong Kong and average rates of the Hong Kong dollar and Japanese yen. Distributable income rose 1.5% to S$61.7 million. Revenue remained flat at S$105.5 million. The Reit attributed the increase to steady leasing demand and positive rental reversion at Festival Walk, despite a decline in tenants' sales and shopper traffic in Hong Kong.

site_title: 10 Singapore private estates to undergo upgrading works over 4 to 5 years
summary: The Ministry of National Development announced that 10 private estates in Singapore will undergo upgrading works over 4 to 5 years, costing S$29 million. The works include footpath lighting, wheelchair-accessible ramps, and improved landscaping. Over 7,000 households will benefit from the upgrades, which will be completed by 2023. The Estate Upgrading Programme, started in 2000, aims to upgrade infrastructure in ageing private estates without residents paying.

site_title: Lessons from the career of a career coach
summary: A career coach reflects on his 20-year journey, sharing lessons learned from his experience of nearly being sacked for speaking with a non-standard accent. He credits the experience for his empathetic approach to coaching others through outplacement services. Key takeaways include: focus on core expertise, humility, and giving back to others. For Singaporean workers, he advises being loyal to one's boss but prioritizing one's own career, staying adaptable to change, and having a Plan B for post-full-time corporate life.

site_title: GE a massive roll of the dice for Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is pushing for a general election on December 12, despite uncertainty surrounding his ability to pass the necessary two-thirds majority in the House of Commons. The decision comes as Johnson's promise to leave the EU by October 31 has "vapourised," and he seeks to deflect an electoral challenge from the hard-line Brexit Party. However, this gamble could backfire due to the exceptional unpredictability of modern UK politics and the current unprecedented voter volatility.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson walking towards a polling station during the Brexit referendum in North London, Britain, June 23, 2016. Mr Johnson perceives his best opportunity to win an electoral mandate is to go to the polls as early as possible, and try to outflank opposition parties with a claim to being the competent leadership to oversee the UK's planned departure from the EU.

site_title: Made-in-China Lafite? It costs 2,388 yuan
summary: China's Domaines Barons de Rothschild, the maker of Château Lafite Rothschild, has released a world-class wine made entirely in China, priced at 2,388 yuan. This marks a significant departure from the estate's historical reputation for being associated with Chinese corruption and counterfeiting. The new wine is a result of the company's efforts to revamp its brand and tap into the Chinese market. The release is seen as a significant step in China's growing wine industry, which is expected to continue expanding in the coming years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 0.1% in September, defying expectations of a decline. Biomedical manufacturing led the expansion with a 21.9% increase. The URA private home price index rose 1.3% q-o-q in Q3, higher than the initial estimate. Office prices fell 3.9% q-o-q, while over 7,000 households will benefit from private estate upgrading projects. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed up 0.5% on the week, with shares extending gains 2.3% on the week.

images.alt_text: Biomedical manufacturing was the star performer in September with an expansion of 21.9 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.11 points to 1,570.00. Volume reached 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.4 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 429 to 322.

site_title: Norway wealth fund grows to record 10 trillion crowns
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund reached a record 10 trillion Norwegian crowns ($1.48 trillion) due to rising global stocks and currency strength, surpassing the previous record. The fund's growth is amid strategy changes, including handling climate risk and a potential shift into US investments.

site_title: Use trends as guiding beacons in gloomy markets
summary: Investors can benefit from trend-based investing, which involves following market trends to increase investment success. Despite the current bear market, the author believes that most retail and institutional investors are under-exposed to equities, increasing the odds of a future "bull" run. Megatrends, such as changing demographics and rising demand for sustainability, offer significant investment opportunities. Investors can access these megatrends through various thematic funds, allowing them to align their ideals with their portfolio and potentially create immense wealth.

images.alt_text: Megatrend investing is not just an avenue to profit from investments. It is also an opportunity to align your ideals, beliefs, and perhaps dreams of a better future with your portfolio.

site_title: Facebook calls truce with publishers as it unveils Facebook news
summary: Facebook has launched Facebook News, a new section of its mobile app dedicated to news content. The platform will feature stories from various publishers, including The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, and digital-only outlets like BuzzFeed and Business Insider. Facebook will pay for content from dozens of publishers, including striking deals worth millions of dollars, and will also provide local news from smaller publishers in metropolitan markets. The move aims to support high-quality journalism and bring users back to the site regularly to consume news.

site_title: Lagarde wants to end ECB infighting, Spiegel reports
summary: ECB chief-elect Christine Lagarde aims to end infighting at the European Central Bank, following a public spat between rate setters over a stimulus package. She plans to review policy and involve Governing Council members, prioritizing growth, inflation, climate change, and women's representation. Lagarde also seeks to bring the ECB's work closer to the public, repeating her predecessor's message that fiscal policy must do more to lift growth and inflation.

site_title: US consumer sentiment pares gains as economic outlook dims
summary: US consumer sentiment rose to 95.5 in October, but pared gains from earlier in the month, suggesting Americans' spending will continue to support the economy despite weakness in manufacturing. The gauge of current conditions rose to 113.2, while inflation expectations remained at a record low at 2.3%. Analysts expect a third straight interest-rate cut, citing risks that price gains could miss the Federal Reserve's 2% target. Consumer sentiment remains elevated, with a three-month high, amid persistent trade tensions and global weakness.

site_title: Truths and myths about stroke
summary: Young people can suffer a stroke, contrary to the popular belief that stroke is rare in this age group. Studies show that up to 15% of brain infarcts occur in young adults, and the incidence rate of stroke in Singapore increased in those aged 15 to 59 years. Controlling risk factors such as hypertension, high cholesterol, diabetes, and smoking can help prevent stroke. Preventive measures include stopping smoking, managing blood pressure and diabetes, and avoiding excessive calcium intake. Recognizing symptoms such as drooping face, slurred speech, and inability to lift arm can lead to timely medical treatment and improved outcomes.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 profit slips 4% on non-operating losses
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 4% drop in net profit to S$205.1 million for the third quarter, weighed down by non-operating losses of S$31.8 million. Operating profit grew 24% to S$179 million, thanks to improved contributions from Singapore and Malaysia businesses. Total weighted new sales fell 9% to S$318.1 million, while new business embedded value rose 30% to S$163.3 million. Group CEO Khor Hock Seng attributed the strong operating results to the agency and bancassurance channels, and expressed confidence in growing the business through digital transformation and product management.

site_title: Thailand's CP Group signs US$7.4b rail deal
summary: Thailand's CP Group has signed a $7.4 billion deal to build a high-speed railway connecting three airports, including Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi and Don Muang, to a third airport near Pattaya. The 220-kilometer line is expected to be completed in five years and will serve as a link to the Eastern Economic Corridor, a $50 billion scheme attracting investment from industries like vehicle and tech manufacturing. The government will foot 65% of the deal, with construction set to begin within 12 to 24 months.

site_title: Investors falling out of love with market darlings
summary: European investors are shifting focus from defensive and growth sectors to cyclical and value stocks, causing shares in food, healthcare, and personal goods to weaken. In contrast, banks, insurance, basic resources, autos, and oil & gas counters are seeing gains. This trend may be driven by macro sentiment and bond yields, and its long-term implications are uncertain.

images.alt_text: The strong run in food-and-drinks stocks created an extreme valuation gap against beaten-down sectors like banks, when earnings started to disappoint. AB InBev cut its forecast amid bad news from F&B counters.

site_title: HPH Trust Q3 earnings dip due to higher taxation
summary: HPH Trust, a Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, reported a 2.9% drop in profit to HK$232.5 million (S$40.4 million) in Q3 due to higher taxation. Revenue and other income remained steady, while global trade outlook is expected to be sluggish due to intensifying trade tensions. The trust expects to face challenges and will adhere to cost discipline and efficiency improvements to address the uncertainties ahead.

site_title: European stock markets mostly rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 0.1% and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.3%. London's FTSE 100 index remained unchanged. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson proposed an early election on December 12 to break the Brexit deadlock, potentially resolving the crisis.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund planning writedown of over US$5 billion
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is planning a writedown of at least US$5 billion to reflect a decline in the value of its biggest holdings, including WeWork and Uber Technologies. The writedown, expected to be announced in November, is driven by the decline of Uber and WeWork, which have seen their valuations shrink. SoftBank's shares have slid 2.7% to their lowest since January, raising questions about billionaire Masayoshi Son's investment credibility. The writedown could be as high as US$7 billion, surpassing some market projections, and may impact SoftBank's finances and its ability to raise funds for its next Vision Fund.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q3 profit jumps 30.3% on strong pre-sales for China projects, hotel addition
summary: Singapore-listed property developer First Sponsor Group reported a 30.3% surge in Q3 net profit to S$33.3 million, driven by strong pre-sales for Chinese projects and the acquisition of a Dutch hotel. Revenue dropped 16.6% to S$44.6 million, but share of associates' after-tax results jumped to S$15.1 million. The company is optimistic about its expansion plans in Australia, the Netherlands, Germany, and China, with a strong balance sheet to capitalize on business opportunities.

site_title: Authorities end 4-year probe on Pacific Andes, China Fishery
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have concluded a 4-year investigation into Pacific Andes Resources Development (PARD) and China Fishery Group, finding no further action will be taken. The probe began in 2015 and involved requesting information on the companies' operations and dealings. Both companies filed for US bankruptcy protection in 2016 to avoid a forced sale of assets, and their restructuring processes are ongoing. No specific offence under the Securities and Futures Act was disclosed.

site_title: Play it
summary:

Thevar 2.0 showcased mod-Indian cuisine, while Asean agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year. Additionally, China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, and a meeting between China and the US on tariffs was not mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: Cypriot rebuilds home in native village decades after exodus
summary: Nikolas Skourides, 79, has become the first Greek Cypriot to rebuild his home in the village of Larnaca tis Lapithos, Cyprus, 45 years after fleeing the 1974 Turkish invasion. Skourides, who had dreamed of returning, successfully navigated bureaucracy and won the right to rebuild his home through the Immovable Property Commission. He chose not to erect barriers around his property, instead fostering a sense of unity with his Turkish Cypriot neighbors. Skourides' story serves as a testament to the power of empathy and dialogue in overcoming division on the island.

site_title: Higher Festival Walk rents, stronger HKD, yen boost MNACT Q2 DPU
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 1.5% increase in distributable income to 61.7 million Singapore cents for its second-quarter, driven by higher rental income from Festival Walk and stronger Hong Kong dollar and Japanese yen. However, revenue remained flat at 105.5 million Singapore dollars, while net property income rose 1.3% to 84.7 million Singapore dollars. The Reit's Festival Walk mall saw a 4.2% year-on-year increase in gross revenue, but tenants' sales and shopper traffic declined 6.6% and 3.6%, respectively.

site_title: Wall Street slips at open as Amazon weighs
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 15.92 points, or 0.06%, to 26,789.61. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with losses of 6.97 points, or 0.23%, and 35.20 points, or 0.43%, respectively. The downturn was largely driven by Amazon's disappointing sales forecast, overshadowing strong results from other companies in the third-quarter earnings season.

site_title: World's most expensive bottle of whisky sells for £1.5m
summary: A bottle of Macallan 1926 60-year-old single malt whisky sold for £1.45 million at a London auction, setting a record for the most expensive bottle ever sold. The whisky, distilled over 90 years ago and aged for 60 years, was one of only 40 bottles confirmed to be from Cask 263. The sale surpassed the previous record of £1.2 million, with Sotheby's auction house describing the bottle as the "Holy Grail" of Scotch whisky.

site_title: EU shelves Brexit delay decision as Britain squabbles over election
summary: The European Union has agreed to a Brexit deadline extension for the UK, giving Britain's divided parliament time to decide on Prime Minister Boris Johnson's call for a snap election. The current deadline of October 31 has been pushed back, but no new departure date has been set, allowing lawmakers to discuss the possibility of a pre-Christmas election. Johnson has demanded a vote in parliament on Monday on whether to hold an election on December 12, while opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn has said he will wait to see what the EU decides on a Brexit delay before deciding how to vote.

images.alt_text: The European Union agreed to London's request for a Brexit deadline extension on Friday but set no new departure date, giving Britain's divided parliament time to decide on Prime Minister Boris Johnson's call for a snap election.

site_title: Hot stock: Creative shares jump 24% in afternoon trade, prompting SGX query
summary: Creative Technology's shares surged 24% in afternoon trade, reaching S$3.52, after a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over an "unusual price movement". The company responded to a separate SGX query on a director's re-election and compliance with Listing Rule 720(6). Its shares later traded up 23.2% to S$3.50.

site_title: Singapore shares extend gains on Friday, up 2.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed the week at 3,185.53, up 2.3% from last Friday's close. The positive trend was driven by China's efforts to scrap tariffs in exchange for buying more US agricultural products and local factory output. However, US Vice-President Mike Pence's mixed comments on Hong Kong and China's actions against protesters raised concerns. Despite this, the STI opened 0.2% higher and closed the week on a high note, marking a strong week for Singapore equities.

site_title: French insurer AXA to sell its Belgian bank for 620m euros
summary: French insurer AXA is selling its Belgian banking business, AXA Belgium, to cooperative bank Crelan for 620 million euros, simplifying its businesses as part of its restructuring efforts under CEO Thomas Buberl. The deal, expected to be finalized in the second quarter of 2020, will strengthen AXA's balance sheet and simplify its business profile. Crelan, which will become Belgium's fifth-largest lender, will also acquire 100% of Crelan Insurance.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei hits one-year high on cheap yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index reached a one-year high, closing at 22,799.81, after a 0.22% gain. The index's rise was supported by a relatively cheap yen and US indexes finishing higher. This marks the fifth consecutive session of gains for the Nikkei.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose to a one-year high on Friday, supported by a relatively cheap yen and after some US indexes finished higher.

site_title: Erdogan files complaint after French magazine calls him 'The Eradicator'
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan filed a complaint in Turkey against the French magazine Le Point for labeling him "The Eradicator" in a cover story. The magazine's use of a photo of Erdogan giving a soldier's salute with a tagline that reads "Ethnic cleansing, Erdogan style" sparked the complaint, which carries a prison sentence of up to four years and eight months. Erdogan's lawyer claims the magazine insulted the president, while the magazine's publisher defends its right to freedom of speech.

site_title: Reaping wind at sea could become US$1t industry says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that offshore wind could become a $1 trillion industry by 2050, driven by cost reductions and improved technology. Currently, wind power at sea accounts for 0.3% of global electricity generation. Expanding offshore wind could avoid 5-7 billion tonnes of CO2 emissions from the power sector globally, helping to meet the goal of limiting temperature rise to below 2°C this century.

site_title: South Korean stocks end flat ahead of Fed meeting
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Friday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with the benchmark KOSPI index rising 0.11% to close at 2,087.89. Investors were cautious due to Brexit anxiety and uncertainty over the Fed's decisions. This marks the third consecutive weekly gain for the KOSPI, which has risen 2.30% this year.

images.alt_text: The benchmark stock index KOSPI rose 2.23 points, or 0.11 per cent, to close at 2,087.89.

site_title: Restored to former glory, Russia tsars' home to reopen in summer
summary: Russia's Alexander Palace, the last home of Emperor Nicholas II, is set to reopen to the public next summer after a $42.6 million renovation. The palace, built in the late 18th century, was the permanent residence of the last Russian tsar in 1905 and features eight rooms, including the Mauve Boudoir and the tsar's bathing chamber. The renovation, which began in 2012, has been completed and the first rooms will open to visitors in June or July, offering a glimpse into the private life of the imperial family.

images.alt_text: Russia's Alexander Palace, the last home of Emperor Nicholas II before he and his family were executed by the Bolsheviks, will reopen to the public next summer after million-dollar renovations, officials said Friday.

site_title: Norway wealth fund grows to record 10t crowns
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, reached a record 10 trillion Norwegian crowns (S$1.48 trillion) due to rising global stocks and the strength of the euro and dollar. The fund, built since 1996 to save petroleum revenues, has grown to almost three times Norway's annual GDP. Its value surpassed US$200,000 for every man, woman, and child in Norway, with investments in global equities and fixed-income assets driving the growth. The fund's government regulators are considering a large-scale shift of investments into the US.

site_title: Office rents fall 0.6% in Q3, rental growth projected to slow
summary: Office rents in Singapore's Central Region fell 0.6% in Q3, led by a 2.8% decline in fringe area rents. Analysts attribute this to supply pressures and softer occupier demand amid an uncertain business environment. Rental growth is expected to slow, with projections of 5-6% in 2020, and vacancy rates remaining below 6% until 2022. The decline in office space prices, 3.9% in Q3, was also attributed to a shift in investment activity to sub-markets outside the core Central Business District.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks finish with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with a 0.49% loss, ending a positive week on a negative note. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,667.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.48% and 0.99% respectively. Investors are focused on Brexit and China-US trade talks, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.48%.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.49 per cent, or 130.56 points, to 26,667.39.

site_title: AB InBev sees slower growth as Brazil, South Korea buy less beer
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, lowered its profit growth forecasts for 2019 after a "challenging" third quarter, citing weaker beer sales in Brazil and South Korea due to price hikes. The company's core profit was unchanged year-on-year, missing market expectations. Shares fell 10.5% in early trading, and the company expects "moderate" growth of core profit in the fourth quarter. AB InBev also sold its Australian subsidiary for $11 billion and raised $5.6 billion for a second attempt to float part of its Asian business.

site_title: Pakistan's tycoons offer to take over former Barrick mine
summary: Pakistan's top business tycoons, including Arif Habib and Muhammad Ali Tabba, have offered to invest $1 billion to take over the disputed Reko Diq copper and gold mine, previously explored by Barrick Gold and Antofagasta. The consortium plans to go through a bidding process to acquire the project, which could produce 200,000 tons of copper and 250,000 ounces of gold annually. The move comes after an international tribunal ordered Pakistan to pay $5.8 billion in damages to the companies. Pakistan's provincial government has expressed a preference for local companies to take over the mine.

site_title: MAS, CAD end 4-year probe on Pacific Andes, China Fishery with 'no further action'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have closed a four-year investigation into Pacific Andes Resources Development (PARD) and China Fishery Group, concluding there will be no further action. The probe, initiated in 2015, looked into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. Both companies, which filed for US bankruptcy protection in 2016, will continue their restructuring processes. Shares of China Fishery and PARD remain suspended from trading on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Singapore's September factory output grows 0.1%; defies expectations of a fall
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output grew 0.1% in September, defying private economists' expectations of a 4.8% decline. Biomedical manufacturing was the standout performer, expanding 21.9% with significant growth in the pharmaceutical and medical technology sectors. Electronics, however, continued to struggle, contracting 9.6% year-on-year. Other sectors, including general manufacturing, precision engineering, and transport engineering, also experienced declines, with some segments showing modest growth. Overall, the modest growth in manufacturing output is a positive surprise, but the sector still faces challenges.

site_title: South-east Asia: Most fall as trade uncertainty, slowdown worries bite
summary: South-east Asian stock markets declined on Friday amid revived uncertainty over the Sino-US trade deal and concerns about a global economic slowdown. US President Donald Trump's hopes to finalize a partial trade deal with China's Xi Jinping were dampened by a Reuters poll finding the recent truce is not an economic turning point. The Indonesian index fell, while Thai stocks opened lower, with Philippine banking stocks advancing. In contrast, Singapore shares rose, posting their biggest weekly gain in over four months.

site_title: Solomons government says China's island lease 'unlawful'
summary: The Solomon Islands government has declared a contract leasing the island of Tulagi to a Chinese company "unlawful" and "must be terminated immediately". The agreement, signed in September, granted the Chinese conglomerate, Sam Group, powers to develop infrastructure on Tulagi and surrounding islands. The Solomon Islands Attorney General stated that the agreement was not vetted by the government, sparking concerns of China's growing influence in the Pacific region. The move comes as China has expanded its financial and political influence in the Pacific, winning over two previous Taiwanese allies in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.32% at the open on Friday, following a positive week, amid uncertainty over the China-US trade row and Brexit. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,711.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Investors are watching developments in these areas, despite recent rallies in US stocks.

site_title: UK police say 39 found dead in truck were Chinese
summary: UK police confirmed 39 people, believed to be Chinese nationals, were found dead in a refrigerated truck near London. The bodies were discovered early Wednesday after the truck arrived from Belgium. This case has triggered a massive murder probe, described by Prime Minister Boris Johnson as an "unimaginable tragedy." The incident has sparked national outrage over human trafficking.

site_title: iFast unit, Raffles Family Office form JV to serve China's ultra high net worth market
summary: iFast China Holdings, a subsidiary of mainboard-listed fintech firm iFast Corporation, has formed a joint venture with Raffles Family Office to serve China's ultra high net worth market. The JV will be owned 70% by RFO Holdings and 30% by iFast China Holdings, aiming to capitalize on the fast-growing ultra high net worth market in China.

site_title: Healthcare stocks drive Australian market higher; NZ down
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.7% on Friday, driven by gains in healthcare plays, led by Resmed Inc's 11% jump. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,739.20, adding 1.4% for the week. Healthcare and mining stocks also rose, while technology stocks followed Wall Street peers. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4% and shed 2.5% for the week, dragged by major power retailers.

site_title: North Korea asks South to discuss removal of 'capitalist' Mt Kumgang facilities
summary: North Korea has proposed to South Korea that the "capitalist" facilities at Mount Kumgang resort be removed and rebuilt. The North's leader, Kim Jong Un, described the South's facilities as "backward" and "hotchpotch." The proposal was made through notices sent to the South's Unification Ministry and Hyundai Group, which built the resort. The move is seen as a sign of cooling ties between the two nations, with the North criticizing the facilities as "shabby." The South has agreed to discuss the proposal through the exchange of documents.

images.alt_text: Mount Kumgang resort. North Korea has proposed that Seoul discuss the removal of its facilities from the North's resort, a key symbol of cooperation that Pyongyang recently criticised as "shabby" and "capitalist," the South's officials said on Friday.

site_title: Hunting for 'black gold' in Albania's lawless truffle trade
summary: Albania's truffle trade is plagued by a lawless and violent industry, with threats, poisoned dogs, and massacred trees. Truffle hunters, like Evgjeni Pano, risk their lives to find the prized fungi, selling them to foreign traders for up to 140 euros per kilogram. A lack of regulations has led to reckless hunting, damaging tree roots and reducing truffle production. Authorities are working to develop a legal framework, but the market remains chaotic, with many truffles being sold abroad for high prices.

site_title: SoftBank to write down minimum US$5b for WeWork, other losses
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is set to write down at least $5 billion due to a sharp drop in WeWork and Uber Technologies' values. The writedown will be announced along with its second-quarter earnings on November 6. SoftBank runs the $100 billion Vision Fund, which is affected by the decline in these major holdings. The company has declined to comment on the report.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group Corp is poised to write down at least US$5 billion to account for a sharp drop in the value of some of its biggest holdings including WeWork and Uber Technologies, Bloomberg reported.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts 0.4% dip in Q3 DPU to S$0.01 on enlarged unit base after placement
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 0.4% decline in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01, due to higher expenses and an enlarged unit base resulting from a new placement of 194.2 million units. Despite this, gross revenue rose 91.5% to S$62 million and net property income more than doubled to S$45.3 million. The trust's total distribution more than doubled to S$33.8 million, with an advanced distribution of 1.145 cents to be paid out on November 8.

site_title: Australia: Healthcare shares lift market; New Zealand up but faces big weekly loss
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Friday, with healthcare stocks leading gains after strong results from Resmed Inc. The S&P/ASX 200 index is set to rise a third straight week, tracking overnight gains from US stocks. Healthcare stocks surged 1.6% and gold stocks advanced 1.9% after bullion prices rose. New Zealand shares edged up slightly but are set to shed nearly 2% for the week.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,183.32, up 0.46% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday with a 0.46% gain, reaching 3,183.32, driven by gains in CWX Global, TEE International, and Rex International. SGX surged 7.4% after reporting its highest quarterly net profit in over a decade. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.7% in Australia, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.44%. US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars back to earth as bulls bail out
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced losses on Friday due to Brexit uncertainty and a decline in risk sentiment. The Aussie slipped to US$0.6819, down 0.6% on the week, while the kiwi dollar eased to US$0.6376. Investors are awaiting the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting on October 30, where a quarter-point rate cut is expected, which could pressure the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to ease rates.

site_title: Singapore retail rents up 2.3% q-o-q in Q3; vacancy rate drops to 7.5%: URA
summary: Singapore retail rents rose 2.3% in Q3, following a 1.5% decline in the previous quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The vacancy rate dropped to 7.5% as the amount of occupied retail space increased by 29,000 sq m. The total supply of retail space remained at 288,000 sq m, with the stock of retail space increasing by 16,000 sq m. The Q3 increase was driven by the 1.1% increase in URA's price index of retail space in the central region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.81 points to 1,572.92 at 9am. Volume reached 49.9 million lots worth RM15.12 million. Gainers outpaced losers 90 to 54.

site_title: US senators call for security probe of Chinese-owned video app TikTok
summary: US senators Chuck Schumer and Tom Cotton have called for a security probe into Chinese-owned video app TikTok, citing national security risks due to its potential for Beijing's spying. The app, with 500 million users worldwide, could leave American users vulnerable to Chinese intelligence if ByteDance, its owner, is forced to share user information. The senators also raised concerns about censorship and manipulation of content, particularly regarding politically sensitive topics, and urged the intelligence community to assess the national security risks posed by the app.

site_title: Pound struggles as Johnson eyes election to break Brexit logjam
summary: The British pound fell as Boris Johnson proposed a general election to resolve Brexit uncertainty, giving up his Halloween deadline. The election, set for December 12, may not pass the agreement, as opposition lawmakers require a guarantee Britain won't leave the EU without a deal. This has raised doubts about Johnson's election bid, which could fail to break the Brexit logjam.

images.alt_text: Sterling struggled to bounce back from losses owing to renewed Brexit uncertainty after Boris Johnson proposed a general election to resolve the long-running saga, while Asian markets were mostly down after a broadly positive week.

site_title: Hot stock: Eagle Hospitality Trust sinks 14% despite assurance on Queen Mary lease
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) fell 14% in value after the trust clarified that its sponsor, Urban Commons, is not at risk of losing its lease on the historic Queen Mary hotel in California. The trust stated that Urban Commons is preparing a response to a letter from the city of Long Beach, which claimed the developer had not met lease obligations. Despite the clarification, analysts at UOB Kay Hian and KGI Securities maintained their "buy" and "outperform" recommendations on EHT, citing the trust's attractive dividend yield and potential for upside.

site_title: Offshore wind set for 15-fold increase: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a 15-fold increase in offshore wind capacity worldwide by 2040, making it Europe's largest single source of electricity. Falling costs, supportive government policies, and technological breakthroughs are driving the growth, with the EU and China leading the transition. Europe's offshore capacity is expected to surge from 20 to 130 gigawatts by 2040 under current policies and pricing.

site_title: China's WeWork equivalent Ucommune files for US IPO: sources
summary: China's Ucommune, a shared workspace provider similar to WeWork, has filed a confidential prospectus with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for an initial public offering (IPO) before the end of the year. The company, valued at $2.6 billion, has appointed Citigroup and Credit Suisse to work on the listing. This move comes after WeWork's failed IPO plan, with Ucommune aiming to raise funds before the end of the year, depending on investor feedback.

site_title: Thailand's largest company CP Group signs 224.5b baht rail deal
summary: Thailand's largest company, CP Group, signed a 224.5 billion baht (S$10.1 billion) deal to build a high-speed railway connecting three airports, transforming the southern coast into a tech hub. The project involves a consortium of CP Group, construction billionaire-turned-health minister Anutin Charnvirakul, and Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha. The deal is part of an infrastructure scheme aimed at developing the southern coast into a tech hub, with CP Group's CEO Suphachai Chearavanont's family being Thailand's richest, worth an estimated US$17.6 billion.

site_title: 10 private estates to undergo S$29m upgrading projects over 4 to 5 years
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development has announced that 10 private estates will undergo upgrading projects worth S$29 million over 4-5 years. The projects include footpath lighting, wheelchair-accessible ramps, and improved landscaping and parks, benefiting over 7,000 households. The upgrades, part of the Estate Upgrading Programme, will be completed in about four to five years and are funded by the government, with no costs to residents. This is part of a larger S$1 billion investment in upgrading private and public housing estates in Singapore.

site_title: First Sponsor Q3 profit jumps 30.3% on pre-sales of China projects, hotel addition
summary: First Sponsor Group posted a 30.3% surge in net profit to S$33.3 million in Q3, driven by strong pre-sales for Chinese projects and the acquisition of a Dutch hotel. Revenue dropped 16.6% due to lower property sales and rental income. The company's Star of East River and Emerald of the Orient projects in Dongguan continue to generate good cash flows. First Sponsor's CEO, Neo Teck Pheng, expressed confidence in the company's ability to expand its business footprint in Australia and capitalize on opportunities in the Netherlands, Germany, and China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord, UE, Perennial, Great Eastern, ESR-Reit, CRCT, GuocoLand
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include Yanlord Land Group's mandatory conditional cash offers for United Engineers (UE), while UE and Perennial Real Estate Holdings also requested trading halts. Other notable announcements include Great Eastern Holdings' 4% drop in net profit, ESR-Reit's 0.4% decline in distribution per unit, and GuocoLand's 61% increase in net profit. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Retail China Trust's DPU edged up 0.8%, and Sabana Reit posted a DPU of 0.78 Singapore cent for its third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.22% to 3,176
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.13 points or 0.22% to 3,176 on Friday, following gains in US and European markets driven by stronger company earnings. Trading volume was high, with TEE International and Golden Agri-Resources among top gainers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 indices also reached fresh records, driven by strong results from Tesla and Microsoft.

site_title: Ping An's US$22b push to shed old-school insurance skin
summary: Ping An Insurance Group Co, a major Chinese insurer, is investing $22 billion in technology and research and development to transform its business model and compete with tech giants like Tencent and Alibaba.
