Despite the investment, analysts are skeptical about the company's ability to deliver on its promises, citing underwhelming results from its tech startups. The company's co-CEO Lee Yuan Siong believes that the benefits of its tech push will eventually be reflected in its valuation, but others argue that the progress is below expectations.

site_title: Japan police hunt stolen diamond worth 200m yen
summary: Japanese police are searching for a stolen 50-carat diamond worth over $1.8 million after it was taken from a jewelry trade show in Yokohama city. The diamond, valued at 200 million yen, was displayed at a three-day show featuring companies from Japan, Russia, China, and others. Authorities believe the diamond was stolen from a display case on Thursday. The investigation is ongoing, but no arrests have been made.

site_title: Speedy delivery hits Amazon's bottom line; shares slump
summary: Amazon reported a 27% decline in quarterly profits to $2.1 billion, missing Wall Street forecasts. The decline was attributed to increased spending to speed up most deliveries to one day, resulting in a 24% revenue increase to $70 billion in the quarter. The company's share price plummeted in after-market trades following the announcement.

site_title: Samsung scion faces new bribery trial
summary: Lee Jae Yong, vice-chairman of Samsung Electronics, is facing a retrial for bribery, embezzlement, and other offenses related to a corruption scandal that brought down South Korean President Park Geun Hye. Lee was jailed for five years in 2017 but released after an appeals court dismissed most of his convictions. The Supreme Court has ordered a retrial, which could result in a longer prison sentence. The case centers on millions of dollars paid to Park's confidante for government favors, and Samsung's profits have been falling due to global chip market slump and export restrictions.

site_title: Chuan Hup in JV with associate to buy and develop Perth site
summary: Chuan Hup Holdings has formed a joint venture with Finbar Group to acquire a 1,697 square meter land parcel in Perth for A$6.5 million. The site will be developed into 115 residential apartments across 28 levels with commercial office space. Ownership is split 50-50, and the JV company, Finbar Sub 106, will be an associate of Chuan Hup. The project is expected to have minimal impact on Chuan Hup's financials, and shares rose 1.9% following the announcement.

site_title: US to send 'additional military assets' to protect Syrian oil: Pentagon
summary: The US plans to deploy additional military assets to northeast Syria to protect oil fields from potential Islamic State (ISIS) retake. This move comes in coordination with the SDF partners to prevent ISIS or other destabilizing actors from regaining control. The US aims to reinforce its presence in the region and prevent a resurgence of ISIS.

site_title: Chinatown Vacation
summary: Two new boutique hotels in Singapore's Chinatown and Keong Saik enclave are attracting attention from travelers and staycationers. ST Signature Chinatown, a co-living hotel, offers 40 smartly-designed cabins with varying room sizes, communal kitchen, and seating areas. Hotel Soloha, another co-living hotel, boasts vibrant decor, a communal gathering space, and a games room. Both hotels cater to tourists and business travelers, with rates starting from S$60 and S$185, respectively.

site_title: Singapore office prices fall 3.9% q-o-q in Q3; vacancy rate eases to 10.6%: URA
summary: Singapore's office prices decreased 3.9% in Q3, with a 0.6% decline in the rental index, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The vacancy rate eased to 10.6% from 11.5% in the previous quarter. A total of 738,000 square meters of office space were available in the pipeline, while the stock of occupied office space increased by 71,000 square meters. This decrease in vacancy and supply indicates a stable market for office space in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Prices of office space in Singapore's central region decreased by 3.9 per cent in the third quarter, compared with the 0.9 per cent increase in the previous quarter, according to the latest data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA).

site_title: URA private home price index up 1.3% q-o-q in Q3, higher than flash estimate rise of 0.9%
summary: Singapore's benchmark private residential property price index rose 1.3% in Q3 2019, faster than the 0.9% increase in the flash estimate. Prices of landed properties increased 1.0% and non-landed properties rose 1.3% quarter-on-quarter. Rentals of non-landed properties rose 0.4%, while landed properties retreated 2.3%. Developers launched 3,628 uncompleted private residential units and sold 3,281 private homes in Q3 2019. The vacancy rate of completed private homes decreased to 6.1% and 34,089 units with planning approvals remained unsold.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX surges 4.6% on highest quarterly profit in over a decade
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares surged 4.6% on Friday, reaching a new 52-week high, after reporting its highest quarterly net profit in over a decade. The bourse's quarterly net profit surged 25% to S$114.2 million, driven by higher demand for its investments and risk management tools. Earnings per share rose 26% to 10.7 Singapore cents, allowing the board to declare an interim dividend of 7.5 cents per share. SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the strong start to FY2020 to robust performance across key financial metrics.

site_title: White House stalled pro-Ukraine trade ruling in August: report
summary: The White House stalled a proposal to restore trade privileges to Ukraine in August 2019, with then-White House national security advisor John Bolton advising US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to drop the idea due to President Donald Trump's likely opposition. The proposal was part of a broader effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate Trump's political rival, Joe Biden. The delay was part of a routine review, but it has raised questions about Trump's use of his powers for political purposes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a relatively cheap yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.10% to 22,773.07, while the Topix index increased 0.10% to 1,645.31. Investors were monitoring Chinese markets and US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday supported by a relatively cheap yen with investors watching the Chinese markets.

site_title: CRCT's DPU up 0.8% for Q3 on existing mall growth, new malls' contributions
summary: CRCT's distribution per unit (DPU) increased 0.8% to 2.43 cents for Q3, driven by 13.9% growth in distributable income and 11.9% growth in net property income. The trust acquired three new malls, boosting its portfolio size by 17.1% and gross rentable area by 23.5%. CEO Tan Tze Wooi attributed the growth to resilient consumer confidence and government policies encouraging domestic consumption, positioning the trust for future growth.

site_title: Japan trade minister resigns over donation scandal: media
summary: Japan's trade minister, Isshu Sugawara, has resigned amid allegations of violating election law by offering voters money and gifts. The amounts, totaling 20,000 yen, are below the threshold of Japan's public office election law. Sugawara had been accused of such practices after a magazine reported on the incidents. His resignation comes after a media report highlighted the allegations.

site_title: UK PM offers Dec 12 election to break Brexit impasse
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has offered parliament the option to hold a snap general election on December 12 if they agree to scrutinize his Brexit deal. This comes after MPs refused to rush the deal through parliament, forcing Johnson to request a delay. Johnson is opposed to delaying Britain's exit from the EU for a third time this year, but parliament's delay has led to a request for an extension. The proposed election date is seen as a way to break the Brexit impasse.

site_title: Software under scrutiny in Airbus A220 engine failures
summary: A US-led investigation into engine failures on Airbus's A220 jet is scrutinizing whether a software change allowed unexpected vibrations that led to three emergency landings. The software update, made recently, may have caused mechanical resonance or destructive vibrations in engine parts. Airbus and Pratt & Whitney have restricted engine thrust above 95% above 29,000 feet, and a new software version is expected to lift these restrictions, but the underlying cause has not been confirmed.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 profit slips 4% on non-operating losses
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 4% drop in net profit to S$205.1 million for the third quarter, driven by non-operating losses of S$31.8 million. Operating profit grew 24% to S$179 million, thanks to improved contributions from Singapore and Malaysia businesses. Total weighted new sales fell 9% to S$318.1 million, and gross premiums shrank 13% to S$3.1 billion. Despite this, the company's new business embedded value rose 30% to S$163.3 million. No dividend was declared for Q3, and shares closed at S$21.72, down 0.4%.

site_title: Warren, Biden top new 2020 Democratic presidential polls
summary: Democratic presidential polls show Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren leading with 28% support, followed closely by former Vice President Joe Biden at 21%. The polls come as Congressman Tim Ryan drops out of the race. Warren has been surging lately, while Biden has been battling for primacy despite being the frontrunner in some polls. Other candidates, including Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg, trail behind. The intense competition in the Democratic field could impact the party's chances in the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Air Zimbabwe banned from South Africa for failing to pay fees
summary: South Africa has banned Air Zimbabwe, the national airline of Zimbabwe, from using its airports due to unpaid fees. The decision follows the airline's failure to pay airport fees, which has led to a significant deterioration in Zimbabwe's economy. The airline has laid off hundreds of staff over the past two years, exacerbating the economic crisis. This ban marks another challenge to Zimbabwe's struggling economy, which has been plagued by inflation, food and fuel shortages, and crippling debt.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Returning to the workforce after a long career gap?
summary: A study led by Mums@Work and Ngee Ann Polytechnic found that mothers returning to the workforce face significant obstacles, including age, technological and skills gaps, and generational diversity. The study, which involved over 40,000 Mums@Work members, highlights the need for better support systems, such as flexible work arrangements and affordable childcare. Mums@Work founder Sher-li Torrey emphasized the importance of addressing these challenges to support women re-entering the workforce. The study's findings underscore the need for targeted initiatives to support mothers transitioning back into the workforce.

site_title: Utico agrees in principle with Hyflux to cap all adviser fees at S$40m
summary: Utico, a UAE-based utility firm, has agreed in principle with Hyflux to cap adviser fees at S$40 million, resolving a contentious item under the restructuring agreement. This move brings the company closer to finalizing a rescue deal for the insolvent water treatment firm. The agreement also limits the S$300 million equity injection for senior unsecured creditors to S$200 million if the definitive restructuring agreement is not signed by early next week.

site_title: Citigroup names Jane Fraser as president
summary: Citigroup has promoted Jane Fraser, 52, to president and head of its global consumer bank, positioning her for a potential future CEO role. Fraser, who has been at Citigroup for 15 years, will succeed Stephen Bird, who is leaving after over 20 years to pursue an external opportunity. The move does not indicate an imminent change at the top of the bank, according to CEO Michael Corbat. Fraser, a rising star on Wall Street, has a track record of helping Citigroup recover from the financial crisis and has experience in global business strategy.

site_title: Singapore Q3 unemployment hits 10-year high
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate rose to 2.3% in September, the highest level since 2009, despite a significant increase in employment growth. Retrenchments rose to 2,900, mainly in the services sector. Employment growth, excluding foreign domestic workers, increased by 22,400, driven by 16,100 new hires in services. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo attributed the rising unemployment to mismatches in the labor market, citing job seekers' skills and employers' preferences.

site_title: Singapore sees cash starting to flow from turbulent Hong Kong
summary: Singapore is experiencing a surge in financial activity due to the ongoing unrest in Hong Kong, with hotel occupancy rates reaching an all-time high and luxury home sales and gold storage increasing. An estimated $4 billion has moved to Singapore from April to August, a "very miniscule" amount compared to Hong Kong's $1.7 trillion, but expected to continue as the situation worsens in Hong Kong. This influx of funds is seen as a boon for Singapore's economy, which is slowly slipping into recession, and may lead to more business and investment shifting to Singapore.

site_title: US Republicans introduce measure knocking Trump impeachment effort
summary: US Senate Republicans introduced a resolution condemning the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, calling the process illegitimate. The measure, crafted by Senate Majority Mitch McConnell and Senator Lindsey Graham, aims to pressure the House of Representatives into making adjustments that would give Republicans a greater say. The resolution comes as administration witnesses provide testimony painting a damning picture of presidential abuse of power, further fueling the Republican pushback against the inquiry.

site_title: Singapore keeps 2nd place for ease of doing business: World Bank
summary: Singapore retained its second place in the World Bank's "ease of doing business" rankings, with New Zealand topping the global list. China jumped 15 places to 31st, thanks to improvements in minority investor protections and trade facilitation. India also made the top 10 list, moving up 14 places to 63rd, with reforms in starting a business and trade facilitation. The World Bank attributes better business climates to sound regulation and widespread use of electronic systems, with online business incorporation, electronic tax filing, and online property transfers common among top-performing economies.

site_title: Leaving no stone unturned
summary: New rules regulating the trade of precious stones and metals in Singapore have kicked in, aimed at combating money laundering and financing of terrorism. The new regime poses challenges for dealers and lawyers, who must ensure compliance. Meanwhile, other news topics include Citroën's new CEO, emerging trends in investing and money management, and the Women's Tennis Association Finals in Shenzhen.

site_title: HK businessman pays HK$7.6m for parking space
summary: A Hong Kong businessman paid HK$7.6 million (approximately US$1 million) for a parking space in the city's luxury skyscraper, The Centre. This purchase highlights the stark inequality in Hong Kong, where one in five people lives below the poverty line, despite the city's economic struggles. The purchase comes as the city faces recession concerns and growing concerns about the impact of pro-democracy demonstrations on the real estate market.

site_title: The makings of a true future city
summary: Singapore aims to remake itself into a "future city" through its plans to develop the Greater Southern Waterfront into a vibrant and thriving destination. The city-state's bid to lead in smart infrastructure and data-driven decision-making is part of its strategy to create a high-quality of life for citizens, a competitive economy, and a sustainable environment. With a growing population expected to reach 6.9 million by 2030, Singapore plans to harness technology and data to inform public services decisions, improve citizen satisfaction, and enhance transparency.

site_title: A digital currency? MAS is not convinced
summary: Singapore's managing director of the Monetary Authority of Ravi Menon stated that there is no compelling reason for central banks to issue digital currencies. He believes that embracing electronic payments of fiat currencies could reduce transaction costs and bring greater convenience, generating real economic benefits. Menon's comments come as it remains unclear what problem digital currencies would solve, and he is not convinced of their necessity.

images.alt_text: There is no compelling reason for central banks to issue digital currencies, said managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Ravi Menon.

site_title: Smart photos
summary: Google's Pixel 4 phones have enhanced camera capabilities with AI and machine learning, making it difficult to take a bad photo. The device features a second 16MP rear telephoto lens and Super Res Zoom software, as well as improved Night Sight with astro-photography capability. Additionally, Motion Sense allows for phone unlocking, song skipping, and alarm setting without touching the device. The Pixel 4 is available now in three colors for S$1,119 to S$1,469 from various retailers.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up as Tesla, Microsoft gain
summary: US stocks finished mostly higher on Thursday, driven by strong results from Tesla and Microsoft. Tesla surged 17.7% after reporting a surprise profit, while Microsoft gained 2.0% on a 21% increase in quarterly profits. Despite weak profits from Ford and some other companies, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index closed near record levels. American Airlines and Southwest Airlines also reported higher earnings, while Twitter plummeted 20.9% due to a sharp drop in quarterly profits.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished mostly higher on Thursday, with strong results from Tesla and Microsoft offsetting weak profits from Ford and some other companies.

site_title: Euro hit by weaker data as ECB keeps rates on hold
summary: The euro declined after business surveys showed stagnating economic momentum in the euro zone, ahead of Mario Draghi's final ECB news conference. The ECB maintained interest rates on hold and its ultra-easy monetary policy unchanged, sparking speculation about a rift among policymakers. Investors await Draghi's news conference for any hints about stimulus plans. The decision not to adjust rates was seen as a sign of caution, reflecting concerns about the euro zone's economic growth.

site_title: Europe: Earnings relief spurs gains with no surprises from Draghi's last act
summary: European stocks surged to their strongest close since January 2018, driven by earnings relief from German heavyweights and British pharma giant AstraZeneca. BASF rose 3.4% and Daimler 3.3% after reporting upbeat quarterly results, while trade-sensitive automakers and chemical companies also gained. The pan-European stocks index rose 0.6% to 397.37, with healthcare stocks leading gains. The European Central Bank, led by Mario Draghi, made no policy changes, and the euro weakened against the dollar.

images.alt_text: With no fireworks from European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi's last policy meeting on Thursday, encouraging results from German heavyweights and British drugmaker AstraZeneca drove European stocks to their strongest close since January 2018.

site_title: Telcos need to up their game as 5G promises to change telecom industry
summary: Singapore's telecom industry is poised for a significant transformation with the rollout of 5G networks starting in 2020. The government has decided to allocate 5G spectrum through a Call for Proposal (CFP) to identify which two operators can deliver the best value to the economy. This approach aims to foster innovation and value creation, rather than maximizing revenue. The move is expected to open up new business streams, but also poses challenges for telcos to adapt their business models, build new expertise, and invest in new networks.

site_title: Watchmen Remixed
summary: HBO's limited series 'Watchmen Remixed' premiered with a new story from the dark graphic novel, set in an alternate reality in 2019 with Robert Redford as the longest-serving US president. The 9-episode series, created by Damon Lindelof, features an ensemble cast including Redford, Regina King, Don Johnson, and Jeremy Irons. New episodes air every Monday at 9am ET on HBO Go and HBO, with encore episodes at 10pm. This remix version is not a remake or reboot, offering a fresh take on the original story.

images.alt_text: New episodes of Watchmen are broadcast every Monday at the same time as the US at 9am (10am from Nov 4) on HBO Go and HBO.

site_title: Festival of Lights
summary: The Festival of Lights, a celebration of Diwali, has been a part of Little India in Singapore since Indian migrants brought it in the 1900s. The event, which means "row of lights," features a large-scale light-up, fireworks, and various activities, including a countdown concert and craft exhibition. Temples also offer traditional dishes, and tourists visit to experience the colorful atmosphere. The celebration has grown more elaborate over the years, with added activities and events.

site_title: Self-driving vehicles to be tested on roads in all of western Singapore
summary: Western Singapore to be designated a testbed for autonomous vehicles, with over 1,000km of public roads available for testing. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) aims to speed up the development of the technology, supporting the robust testing of AVs' capabilities and paving the way for pilot deployments in the early 2020s. AVs must display decals, pass safety assessments, and have a qualified safety driver on standby, with public safety remaining the top priority.

site_title: Yanlord revives takeover bid for United Engineers at same S$2.60-per-share price
summary: China-based property developer Yanlord Land Group has renewed its takeover bid for Singapore-listed United Engineers, offering to acquire ordinary and preference shares at S$2.60 apiece in cash, valuing the company at S$1.66 billion. The bid, which was first made in 2017, is conditional upon receiving acceptances that result in Yanlord and its concert parties holding more than 50% of UE's voting rights. If successful, Yanlord plans to delist UE and also has the option to make a mandatory offer for WBL Corporation if the bid becomes unconditional.

site_title: Tesla posts surprise Q3 profit; Daimler's, Volvo's Q3 up slightly, but Ford's down
summary: Tesla posted a profitable third quarter, exceeding expectations with a profit of $1.86 per share, despite a 8% decline in revenue to $6.30 billion. Daimler's operating profit rose 8% to $2.69 billion, while Volvo Cars reported a 90% increase in operating profit to $3.49 billion. However, Ford's net profit fell 57% to $425 million, and the company reduced its full-year operating profit forecast due to higher warranty and incentive costs. Analysts expect a lower-than-expected earnings season, with Hyundai Motor Co missing estimates due to a slump in demand in China.

site_title: BreadTalk's aim for 8% profit margin by 2022 won't be a walk in the park
summary: BreadTalk Group's CEO George Quek aims for an 8% net profit margin by 2022, but achieving this goal may be challenging. The company's top line is expected to rise 10% in 2020, driven by its newly acquired Food Junction, with a projected net profit of S$28.6 million. Assuming incremental 2% net profit margin growth each year, BreadTalk's net profit would reach S$57.2 million by 2022, with revenue staying flat at S$715 million. This ambitious target may be difficult to meet, especially given the competitive food and beverage industry.

site_title: In about 4 yrs: Retail payments across Asean via mobile numbers
summary: Singapore is set to link up its real-time payment systems with other Asean countries over the next four years, allowing small retail payments via mobile numbers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also open to stablecoins, a new form of cryptocurrency pegged to fiat currencies, but is concerned about the risks of money laundering and terrorist financing. The MAS will engage in a deeper discussion on how to manage these risks, which could impact financial stability and monetary policy. Meanwhile, experiments with blockchain technology for cross-border payments are ongoing, but the platform is still years away from becoming scalable and economically viable.

site_title: Viacheslav Fetisov, Sporting Legend/Climate Change Activist
summary: Viacheslav Fetisov, a former Soviet ice hockey player and climate change activist, is raising awareness about the Arctic region's fragile ecosystem through his "The Last Game" initiative. Fetisov, 61, has played exhibition hockey matches in various locations, including the North Pole, to draw attention to the issue. As a UN Environment Programme ambassador, he aims to promote individual action and raise awareness about the consequences of climate change, including rising sea levels and melting ice. Fetisov's past includes a Hall of Fame career and a stint as a Russian parliament member, and he has partnered with prominent figures like Prince Albert of Monaco to spread the word.

site_title: Farm-to-table dining in Taipei
summary: Three foreign-born chefs, Richie Lin, Jimmy Lim, and Ryohei Hieda, are driving Taiwan's locavore movement with their 100% locally sourced restaurants. Despite initial challenges in convincing Taiwanese diners of the quality of local produce, the chefs have successfully built relationships with local farmers and created new markets for unique ingredients. Their efforts have led to the creation of unique, high-quality dishes that showcase the diversity of Taiwan's terroir. The success of these chefs has paved the way for a sustainable dining movement in Taiwan, with diners increasingly appreciating locally sourced ingredients.

site_title: California mass blackout set to affect more than 1.5m people
summary: A mass blackout in Northern California, initiated by PG&E, will affect over 1.5 million people, with 100,000 homes and businesses already losing power. The blackout aims to prevent wildfires sparked by high winds, following a series of devastating blazes in 2017 and 2018. The power outage is part of PG&E's efforts to reduce liabilities and prevent future fires, with the company warning of potential shutoffs in other parts of the state, including Southern California, due to an "elevated risk" of more shutoffs starting Sunday.

site_title: Tokyo tech suggests life beyond cars for Toyota
summary: Toyota is unveiling its electric four-seater LQ at the Tokyo motor show, featuring a virtual companion named Yui, which uses artificial intelligence to make the car feel more personal and affectionate. The move is part of Toyota's strategy to shift focus from cars to mobility and relevance, as the company faces declining attendance at the Tokyo auto show and a changing market. Toyota aims to make Yui a key feature of its future vehicles, aiming to build bonds similar to those between riders and horses, and to create a new type of car that prioritizes emotional connection over performance.

site_title: Perfect Pairing
summary: A corporate fashion expert, Denise Yeo, shares her tips for pairing white shirts with statement skirts and flats, while IT business analyst Karen Fong swears by classic black and navy skirt suits. PR consultant Sandra Cameron advocates for matching tops and bottoms, while communications manager Deborah Krish recommends effortless wide-legged trousers with cashmere sweaters, offering versatility and easy styling options. These fashion tips provide a fresh take on corporate wardrobe essentials.

site_title: Gojek says it is still planning IPO, but not in near future
summary: Gojek, Indonesia's first startup unicorn, has no immediate plans for an initial public offering (IPO) but is still considering a listing with the Indonesian exchange, IDX, as its primary market. Co-founders Andre Soelistyo and Kevin Aluwi will oversee different functions, with Soelistyo handling corporate and fundraising and Aluwi focusing on product development and marketing. Gojek aims to expand its user base, with plans to fill up to half of its users from outside Indonesia and half from its home market. The company also plans to launch more transportation features in Singapore, where it has a significant market share despite being dominated by rival Grab.

site_title: Nissan Serena E-Power review: Electric serenade
summary: Nissan's Serena E-Power is a petrol-electric hybrid MPV that offers an efficient and environmentally friendly driving experience. The vehicle's unique system combines a 1.2-litre engine with a 1.8kWh lithium-ion battery pack, providing instant torque and near silence. With a fuel efficiency of 5.4L/100km, the Serena E-Power outperforms other MPVs of similar size. Its spacious interior and panoramic glass panels make it ideal for family transportation, while its low profile and smooth acceleration make it a comfortable and enjoyable drive. The Serena E-Power is priced under S$150,000, making it an attractive option for consumers seeking a cost-effective and environmentally friendly vehicle.

site_title: SGX Q1 profit up 25%, highest quarterly profit in over 10 years
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 25% increase in its first quarter net profit to S$114.2 million, the highest quarterly net profit in over a decade. Earnings per share rose 26% to 10.7 Singapore cents, sufficient for an interim dividend of 7.5 cents a share. The growth was driven by higher demand for its suite of investments and risk management tools across asset classes, with total revenue rising 19% to S$248 million. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the growth to broad-based efforts in expanding the global client base and meeting clients' risk management needs.

site_title: 6 in 10 clients will be digital customers before 2023: OCBC
summary: OCBC Bank expects 6 out of 10 customers to be digital customers by 2023, citing a significant boost to revenue and cost savings. Digital customers contribute twice as much revenue as non-digital customers and drive down cost-to-income ratio by 6 percentage points. The bank is in talks with potential partners to obtain a digital banking license in Singapore, but faces competition from its own virtual entity and other fintechs. OCBC's digital initiatives include self-service kiosks, robo-investing, and cardless ATM cash withdrawals.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust says sponsor won't lose its key Queen Mary lease
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has confirmed that its sponsor, Urban Commons (UC), is not in danger of losing its lease on the Queen Mary floating hotel. UC has responded to a letter from the city of Long Beach, California, which had raised concerns about the ship's maintenance and repairs. UC has stated that the Queen Mary is "safe and structurally sound" and is preparing a response to the city, which will include specific maintenance items. The city has a deadline of October 31 for UC to respond with a plan to fix the ship's most urgent repairs.

site_title: An election is the only answer for Britain
summary: Britain is on the brink of a crisis as the country's Brexit deadline of October 31 approaches, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's deal stalled due to parliamentary opposition. The deal, similar to his predecessor Theresa May's, would leave Northern Ireland in the European customs union while the rest of the UK drifts off into uncertainty. The country is divided, with the Conservative party hell-bent on delivering a Brexit that many believe makes no sense. With Johnson's "get Brexit done" mantra failing, a general election is being seen as the only way to break the stalemate and give the country a fresh mandate.

site_title: Industrial market posts stable Q3 despite external headwinds, but outlook cloudy
summary: Singapore's industrial market posted stable Q3 results despite external headwinds, with a 0.1% price index increase and flat rental index. Occupancy rates remained at 89.3%, unchanged for four consecutive quarters. However, demand is fragmented, and the warehouse segment experienced a 0.6% quarter-on-quarter decline in occupancy rates. Experts forecast weak rents and occupancy in the next few quarters, with new supply expected to hit 1.9 million sq m in 2020, potentially leading to a temporary glut in the market.

site_title: SGX licenses global Internet index to Nikko Asset Management
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has licensed its iEdge-FactSet Global Internet Index to Nikko Asset Management, a US-based asset manager with $224 billion in assets under management. The index tracks companies in internet services, including Facebook, Amazon, and Alphabet, and will be used for exchange-traded fund (ETF) listings. This partnership aims to cater to thematic investing, where investors seek to capitalize on long-term trends and trends in emerging sectors. The license agreement was announced on October 24, 2019.

site_title: Whole-of-nation approach needed to power Singapore's energy sector into the future
summary: Singapore needs a whole-of-nation approach to power its energy sector into the future, balancing climate goals with energy security and cost-effectiveness. The country relies on imported natural gas for 95% of its power generation, and must find a unique path to a low-carbon future. A multi-stakeholder approach is key, involving government, industry, and public sectors to develop strategic investments in clean technologies and promote the efficient use of available technology. Singapore must also review its energy policies and frameworks to ensure they are nimble and open to recalibration.

images.alt_text: Singapore is a good example of a country in the process of crafting its own unique path to a low-carbon future, including greener power.

site_title: Special Feature: Home-Style Chinese Cooking in the City
summary: TCC (Chinese Concept) in Orchard Road offers a tranquil retreat from the bustling shopping street, featuring a sumptuous Asian spread and elegant interiors. The second-floor restaurant boasts large windows for a city view, while the premium space exudes a sense of quiet luxury. This hidden gem provides a respite from cookie-cutter cafes and fast food, allowing diners to linger and enjoy their meal in a comfortable setting.

images.alt_text: Sri Lankan Crab wok-baked in fragrant salt.
Crispy suckling pig with prawn paste.

site_title: Heart over haute at Roketto Izakaya
summary: Chef Willin Low's new casual eatery, Roketto Izakaya, pays homage to Singapore's food heritage with a vibrant and eclectic menu. The restaurant, located in Frasers Tower, offers a range of dishes that blend local flavors with creative combinations, such as oyster omelette spaghetti and har cheong tin kai. While some dishes, like the Aburaage rojak salad, feel contrived, the restaurant's focus on heart over haute cuisine makes it a standout. With a rating of 6.5, Roketto Izakaya is a must-visit for foodies looking for a casual, satisfying dining experience.

images.alt_text: Chef Low clearly knows his local food and that strength plays out with his instinct for out-of-the-box combinations. Thai green curry and roti are revisited with Krapow prata pizza (above) where chicken fried with basil is piled on top of a crispy prata and grilled with mozarella cheese.

A lot of the dishes, like the oyster omelette spaghetti (above), feel like a larder raid in the way Chef Low mixes and matches things, albeit in a very good way. And the way he pulls together a 'bah chor mee' with negitoro (minced tuna) instead of minced pork.

A lot of the dishes, like the oyster omelette spaghetti, feel like a larder raid in the way Chef Low mixes and matches things, albeit in a very good way. And the way he pulls together a 'bah chor mee' (above) with negitoro (minced tuna) instead of minced pork.
Above: Har cheong tin kai or Kentucky fried frogs legs seasoned with shrimp paste instead of 11 herbs and spices.
Above: Bubur hitam - a combination of sticky black rice, ice cream and coconut foam and the original Wild Rocket chendol with its salted caramel honeycomb and cookie bits.

site_title: M&A not slowing down despite gloom; SEA still a bright spot: reports
summary: Despite economic and political uncertainty, dealmakers are not slowing down on mergers and acquisitions, with over half expecting activity to increase in the year ahead. Cross-border M&A continues to hold its own, accounting for 40-50% of deal values since 2013. South-east Asia remains a bright spot for investments due to expanding middle-class populations and rapid growth, with Singapore and Indonesia being major destinations. Private equity firms are seizing opportunities in the pharmaceutical, medical, and consumer sectors.

site_title: Singapore beating fresh path to the world of e-commerce
summary: Singapore is pioneering a new approach to global liberalization by building secure digital corridors for cross-border transactions. The country's move aims to enhance data connectivity and seize opportunities in the digital economy, which is expected to grow to $300 billion by 2025. With no end in sight for the US-China trade war, Singapore's non-oil exports are vulnerable, but its Internet economy is expanding at 17% a year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is in talks with like-minded partners, including Australia, New Zealand, and Chile, to build secure data corridors and shape a new digital trade architecture.

site_title: Walking Dead
summary: Zedtown, a real-life gaming experience, has arrived in Singapore, taking place at the National Stadium on Oct 26. Participants will be assigned to teams and armed with NERF blasters to fend off zombies. If bitten, they'll become zombies and join the attack. The event has been played 33 times worldwide and offers a unique experience for fans of The Walking Dead. Tickets are available at sg.zedtown.com.

site_title: Craft Kingdom
summary: Japan's Ishikawa prefecture has opened its first-ever pop-up store in Singapore's Ngee Ann City, showcasing its exquisite craft and food products. The store features gold leaf, porcelain, lacquerware, and unique souvenirs like Merlion-themed dishes. The pop-up aims to attract more visitors to Ishikawa, now that the Hokuriku Shinkansen has reduced travel time from Tokyo to 2.5 hours. The store is located at #B2-25A, Takashimaya Shopping Centre, until an unspecified date.

images.alt_text: The Ishikawa Prefecture Pop-Up Store is located at #B2-25A, Takashimaya Shopping Centre.

site_title: Grandma's Cooking
summary: The New Mrs Lee's Cookbook: Volume 1 and Volume 2 are being relaunched by popular demand, featuring Peranakan and Asian recipes by Mrs Lee Chin Koon. The cookbooks can be purchased for S$60 at major bookstores, and a special dinner service is offered at Shangri-La Hotel's Grandma's Kitchen every Tuesday, featuring 15 curated dishes from the cookbooks for S$88++ per adult.

site_title: Positive cues from Wall St cheer Asia markets
summary: Asian markets saw a surge in confidence on Thursday, driven by strong US corporate performances and risk appetites returning. The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 0.8% to 3,168.87, following positive cues from Wall Street. Investors took solace from earnings reports, which provided optimism against concerns of stagnant global economic growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.32 points higher at 1,571.11 on Thursday, with a total of 2.1 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 438 to 371.

site_title: Lendlease's S$3.7 billion mixed-used Paya Lebar Quarter officially launched
summary: Lendlease's S$3.7 billion Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ) in Singapore officially launched on October 24, 2019. The four-hectare mixed-use development features retail, office, and residential components, including a 1.8 million square foot mall, office space, and 429 condominium units. The project was praised for its proximity to the airport and central business district, with 90% of available office and retail spaces leased or under negotiation. The development is part of Singapore's decentralisation strategy and will be redeveloped as a commercial hub through the Business Improvement District programme.

site_title: China bond investor who predicted sell-off now sees recovery
summary: A China bond investor who predicted a sell-off in the market now believes a recovery is imminent. The yield on benchmark 10-year sovereign debt rose 20 basis points since a three-year low, while stocks have become less volatile. The yuan has also traded relatively stable. The investor attributes the sudden change to market sentiment, which is expected to reverse as the sell-off is not sustainable. The investor's prediction suggests that the market may soon return to normal, with government bonds potentially becoming a more attractive investment option.

site_title: Crazy Rich White People
summary: HBO's Succession has concluded its second season, solidifying its position as a highly talked-about show. The series follows the power struggle within the Roy family, media moguls, as they vie for control of their global company, Waystar Royco. The show's witty dialogue, sharp satire, and complex characters have captivated audiences, drawing comparisons to Shakespeare's King Lear. Season 2 features impressive performances, including lead actor Brian Cox, and has become a cultural phenomenon, with memorable moments and quotes being shared on social media.

site_title: BreadTalk Group eyes margin boost, targets S$1b market cap
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, aims to boost its market value to over S$1 billion by 2022. The group's current market cap of S$335 million is considered "extremely undervalued" with its investment properties valued at S$245 million. Led by founder George Quek, the company is focusing on sharpening its bread-and-butter businesses, leveraging its domain knowledge and resources to achieve greater productivity. Key strategies include expanding its footprint in the Greater China region and South-east Asia, particularly in Thailand, and rejuvenating its flagship bakery brand.

site_title: The time has come for expansionary fiscal policy, say economists
summary: Economists, including UBS experts and Monetary Authority of Singapore chief Ravi Menon, suggest expansionary fiscal policy is necessary despite no full-blown recession. Keynote speaker Beatrice Weder di Mauro floated central bank-issued digital currencies as a solution, citing low interest rates and the need for diversified investment. UBS expects an economic turning point next year, while Menon warned of "unrealistic expectations" for central banks to prop up struggling economies. China's plans for a digital yuan and potential supra-digital currency from the International Monetary Fund are also being considered.

site_title: Asterix returns - with a feisty female character in tow
summary: Asterix, the iconic Gaulish hero, returns in his 38th comic book adventure, Asterix and the Chieftain's Daughter. For the first time in 60 years, the series features a female heroine, Adrenaline, the teenage daughter of King Vercingetorix. Created to update the classic format, Adrenaline is not a seductive temptress but a feisty and independent character who explores adolescent rebellion. The new addition aims to bring a fresh perspective to the beloved series, which has sold over 370 million copies worldwide and been translated into over 100 languages.

site_title: Consumers to be able to aggregate and share financial data next year
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to announce a single platform for consumers to aggregate financial data from various accounts, enabling better financial planning and comparison of competing products. This "Open Banking" concept is expected to be implemented by mid-2021, allowing consumers to share consolidated financial data with financial institutions and non-banking entities. The move aims to promote competition and innovation in the financial sector, with the potential to push interest rates higher and benefit consumers.

site_title: US new home sales dip in September; prices fall
summary: US new home sales declined 0.7% to 701,000 units in September, matching expectations, despite low inventories weighing on sales. The median new house price fell 8.8% to $299,400, the biggest monthly decline in five years. Sales were up 15.5% from last year, while prices have outpaced wage growth. The housing market remains volatile, with sales of previously owned homes also falling in September due to rising prices.

images.alt_text: Sales of new US single-family homes fell in September as low inventories continue to weigh on sales even as prices saw the biggest monthly fall in five years.

site_title: SoftBank to seek US national security review of WeWork deal
summary: SoftBank plans to file with the US Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (Cfius) to review its $3 billion bailout package for WeWork, a deal that includes SoftBank taking over 80% of the company. The review could be a significant hurdle due to SoftBank's past issues with Cfius. The committee reviews investments by foreign firms in US companies, potentially imposing conditions or blocking transactions deemed national security risks.

site_title: Jokowi's Cabinet picks signal bold moves in a fresh direction
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has announced his Cabinet lineup, which includes opposition leader Probowo Subianto as Minister of Defence and Go-Jek founder Nadiem Makarim as Minister of Education. This move is seen as a bold step to revamp the education sector, aligning with Widodo's campaign promise to focus on human capital. Historically, the education portfolio has been held by heads of religious organizations, making Makarim's appointment a significant departure. The new lineup signals a fresh direction for Widodo's administration, raising expectations for significant changes in various sectors.

site_title: Google unveils quantum computer breakthrough
summary: Google has achieved a breakthrough in computing research by using a quantum computer to solve a complex problem in minutes, while today's most powerful supercomputer would take thousands of years. The breakthrough, described in a paper published in Nature, follows weeks of controversy over Google's claim of "quantum supremacy." Researchers expect quantum computers to fuel advancements in fields like AI, materials science, and chemistry, with Google aiming to manufacture chips with thousands of qubits. The US government has pledged billions of dollars in funding to support quantum development, with the US chief technology officer calling it a "great leap forward."

images.alt_text: Sundar Pichai with one of Google's quantum computers in the Santa Barbara lab in California. Google researchers expect quantum computers within a few years to fuel advancements in fields such as artificial intelligence, materials science, and chemistry.

site_title: Mazda MX-30: First electric vehicle is a rebel with a cause
summary: Mazda has unveiled its first full-production electric vehicle, the MX-30, at the Tokyo motor show. The compact SUV boasts a unique design, including a smaller battery and "freestyle doors" that improve rear-seat access. With a 35.5kWh lithium-ion battery, the MX-30 is expected to deliver approximately 200km of range per full charge, compared to over 400km for comparable electric SUVs. Mazda aims to offer a range of electrified options, including gasoline engines, hybrids, and BEVs, with the MX-30 priced at 33,990 euros, less than a Nissan Leaf. The vehicle is set to be sold in Europe and Singapore, marking a significant step for Mazda in its electrification efforts.

site_title: Oil prices ease on weak demand outlook
summary: Oil prices eased on Thursday as concerns about a weak demand outlook persisted. Brent crude futures fell 17 cents to $61 a barrel, following sharp gains the previous session. The decline came after a surprise crude inventory drawdown in the US. A weak demand outlook, combined with global economic uncertainty, led to a bearish outlook on the market.

site_title: Guilt-free ice cream
summary: Local ice cream brand Udders has launched Nuude Ice Cream, a healthier alternative to traditional premium ice cream. The new creation comes in four flavors and contains up to 35% less calories, sugar, and fat than regular ice cream. Certified as a "Healthier Choice" by the Health Promotion Board, Nuude Ice Cream is available for S$5.50 per single serve pot or pint, with prices starting from S$5.50. This move aims to cater to consumers looking for guilt-free indulgence during the hot and humid weather.

site_title: Eurozone economy needs ongoing stimulus: Draghi
summary: Mario Draghi, outgoing head of the European Central Bank, warned that eurozone economy risks remain on the downside and require ongoing stimulus. He cited geopolitical factors, rising protectionism, and emerging market vulnerabilities as concerns. Draghi reiterated the ECB's commitment to monetary policy accommodation, including asset purchases, to boost the flagging economy. The ECB kept its benchmark deposit rate unchanged and reaffirmed its open bond purchases, which will run as long as necessary, to drive up growth and shore up low inflation.

site_title: JTC, Delta Electronics set up training centre to drive Industry 4.0
summary: JTC Corporation and Delta Electronics have partnered to set up a training centre to drive the adoption of Industry 4.0 technology in Singapore. The centre, part of the JTC-Delta Industry Transformation Initiative, aims to support JTC customers, upskill SME partners, and offer automation solutions to tackle manufacturing issues. Delta will provide connectivity and digitalisation packages, training, and consultation services to help SMEs adopt Industry 4.0 technology, while JTC will provide infrastructure and expertise. The partnership aims to foster Industry 4.0 adoption and optimise manufacturing through smart systems.

site_title: Art versus Artist
summary: A new play, "Heather," raises questions about the separation of art from the artist amidst the #MeToo controversies. The play follows a successful children's book author, Karen Tan, whose moral integrity is questioned. The story explores whether the narrative or the storyteller matters more. The play, produced by Adeeb&Shai, runs from October 24 to 27 at the Gateway Theatre Blackbox. It prompts audiences to consider whether they can enjoy good art made by problematic individuals.

images.alt_text: Heather runs from Oct 24 to 27 at the Gateway Theatre Blackbox.

site_title: BOJ warns economy vulnerable to riskier lending practices
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BOJ) has warned that the country's banking system is vulnerable to riskier lending practices due to prolonged ultra-low interest rates. Regional banks have increased lending and investment, leading to declining capital adequacy ratios and potential downward pressure on the economy. The BOJ's semi-annual report also notes that major financial institutions have expanded overseas lending, making the system more susceptible to global economic conditions. This warning may influence the BOJ's decision on monetary policy at its rate review on October 30-31.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GuocoLand reported a 61% increase in net profit to S$42.1 million for its first quarter, driven by a 62% surge in revenue. Ascendas India Trust posted a 16% increase in income available for distribution, driven by higher rental income and occupancy. Sasseur Reit reached a voluntary settlement of S$10.6 million with a construction company after a legal dispute.

site_title: Global banks, funds call for more capital from derivatives clearinghouses
summary: Global banks and five major fund managers have urged international regulators to require more capital from derivatives clearinghouses to protect against potential losses in the financial system. The group, including Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, and BlackRock, claims current capital requirements are insufficient and calls for changes in governance rules to give clearing members more say in risks the clearinghouses may take on. This comes as large clearinghouses have become too big to fail, and regulators have yet to agree on detailed protocols for shoring up or safely winding down clearinghouses.

site_title: House of Coco
summary: The Mademoiselle Privé exhibition, showcasing the creative mindset of Coco Chanel, has opened in Tokyo's B&C Hall on Tennozu Isle. The exhibition, the fifth to be held in various cities, explores Chanel's Haute Couture, iconic perfume Chanel N°5, and High Jewelry, including her 'Bijoux de Diamants' collection. The pop-up exhibition runs until December 31, offering a glimpse into the legendary fashion icon's creative studio.

images.alt_text: Mademoiselle Privé is at the B&C Hall - Tennoz, 2-1-3 Higashi-Shinagawa, Tokyo

site_title: Sasseur Reit reaches settlement with Chinese construction firm
summary: Sasseur Reit has reached a voluntary settlement with Chinese construction firm ZS2 for 55 million yuan (S$10.6 million), following a lawsuit over construction costs for Sasseur Hefei's outlets completed in 2016. The settlement is lower than initially budgeted, with Sasseur Reit expecting no impact on its distribution per unit or net asset value for FY19. The final payment is due before November 29, 2019, and is considered legally binding.

site_title: Wine in a warming world
summary: Mimi Casteel, a regenerative agriculture advocate, believes that wine can serve as a gateway to a deeper discussion about climate change and sustainable farming practices. She practices what she preaches at her Hope Well vineyard in Oregon, using methods that emphasize rebuilding and restoring the natural balance of the ecosystem. Casteel argues that conventional farming techniques, including plowing and tilling, can disrupt the soil's ecological balance and contribute to greenhouse gas emissions. She advocates for a shift towards regenerative agriculture, which prioritizes soil health and biodiversity, and encourages wine growers to adopt more holistic approaches to farming.

site_title: US business investment still soft; jobless claims fall
summary: US business investment remains weak, with new orders for capital goods falling 0.5% in September, according to the Commerce Department. Shipments of core capital goods also declined 0.7% last month. Despite this, jobless claims fell unexpectedly to 212,000, indicating a still-tight jobs market. The US economy continues to grapple with the fallout from the US-China trade war, with the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates twice this year. Economists expect another rate cut when policymakers meet next week.

site_title: Lexus flexes its electric muscles
summary: Lexus unveiled the LF-30 Electrified, a battery-powered concept car, at the Tokyo auto show, signaling its plans to launch a battery electric vehicle (BEV) next year. The car's unique design features individual wheel motors, solid-state lithium batteries, and advanced posture control. Lexus aims to launch its first production-ready BEV, plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV), and dedicated BEV in the early 2020s, with the goal of having 10 BEVs on the market by 2025. The company's multi-pronged approach to future propulsion includes fuel-cell vehicles and self-charging hybrids, catering to different markets and technical solutions.

site_title: Treasures from the Deep South: the heart of Korean cuisine
summary: In South Korea's Jeollanam-do province, known as the heart of Korean cuisine, visitors can experience authentic rural flavors by venturing away from Seoul. Chef Ryu Tae Hwan of Ryunique restaurant in Seoul embarked on a journey to find artisanal growers and discovered the region's unique produce. Key highlights include the samhap dish combining hanwoo beef, shiitake mushrooms, and pen shell clams, as well as local specialties like Maesaengi seaweed, musan laver, and abalone. Other notable destinations include the Wando abalone processing plant, Haenam's sweet potato and cabbage farms, and Muan's octopus street. Geographic Indication System certification ensures the quality and provenance of the region's produce, making it a must-visit for food enthusiasts.

site_title: Loss of Harbin project due to inability to raise funds, funds misuse: YuuZoo
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group has lost the contract for the Nordic Sport Town project in Harbin, China, due to its inability to raise funds. The loss comes after the company's share trading suspension and the misuse of company funds by a former employee. YuuZoo had signed a framework agreement with Harbin Water Investment Group in December 2017 to develop an 85-hectare river-fronting area in Harbin. The company's failure to secure funds has led to the cancellation of the project, resulting in a significant loss.

site_title: Living ecologically
summary: The Conscious Festival, founded by Stephanie Dickson and Paula Miquelis, returns for its fifth edition on November 2-3 at South Beach. The eco-conscious celebration features over 100 sustainable brands, including F&B pop-ups, jewelry, home furnishings, and body care products, all made from vegan, carbon-neutral, and zero-waste materials. The festival aims to promote profitability, sustainability, and fun in tandem, and has attracted a main sponsor, UK health and wellness chain Holland & Barrett. Despite initial challenges in attracting sponsorship, Dickson believes the festival's message is gaining traction and that it will eventually resonate with a wider public.

site_title: Jumbo opens fourth Ng Ah Sio Bak Kut Teh outlet in Taiwan
summary: Jumbo Group announced the opening of its fourth Ng Ah Sio Bak Kut Teh outlet in Taoyuan City, Taiwan. This marks the group's fourth franchised outlet in Taiwan and its eighth in Asia, following four outlets in Singapore. The new outlet brings the total number of Ng Ah Sio Bak Kut Teh outlets in Asia to eight.

site_title: Wall Street opens higher on Microsoft, Tesla results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by solid results from Microsoft, Lam Research, and Tesla. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.22%, the S&P 500 gained 0.34%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.74%. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4%. The rally extended despite new US President Trump's threats.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q3 DPU rises on higher occupancies, one-off recovery of revenue
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 0.78 Singapore cent DPU for Q3, up slightly from the previous year. Gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$20.2 million, driven by higher occupancies and a one-off revenue recovery. Net property income increased 10.1% to S$13.9 million, while distributable amount rose 1.7% to S$8.2 million. Rental reversions were positive at 5.5%, with eight new leases totaling 75,879 sq ft secured in the quarter.

site_title: 3 local golfers win trip to BMW World Final in South Africa
summary: Three local golfers, Brian Seah, Lem Kean Su, and Dily Ng Lay Choon, won a trip to the BMW World Final in South Africa after a two-day tournament at the Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines course. They will compete alongside golfers from nearly 50 countries at the 30th BMW Golf Cup International World Final in March 2020. The event, now in its 26th year, attracts over 100,000 golfers annually and offers a unique sporting experience. Winners will face off in the grand finals in South Africa, with the managing director of BMW Group Asia wishing them good luck.

site_title: Germany nominates economist Isabel Schnabel for ECB board seat
summary: Germany has nominated economist Isabel Schnabel for a seat on the European Central Bank's executive board, replacing Sabine Lautenschlaeger, who resigned after opposing more ECB stimulus. Schnabel, a member of Germany's "wise men", is considered an expert in monetary policy and a skilled communicator. Her nomination could change Germany's influence on the ECB, with some analysts predicting she could get a more influential portfolio under new ECB President Christine Lagarde.

site_title: American, Southwest profits rise even as 737 MAX impact swells
summary: American Airlines Group and Southwest Airlines posted quarterly profits despite the ongoing Boeing 737 MAX grounding, which has impacted over 100 daily flights. Both carriers are in negotiations with Boeing for compensation. American trimmed its adjusted 2019 forecast and raised estimated costs related to the MAX grounding, while Southwest took a $210-million hit to operating income. Despite the challenges, both airlines saw revenue rises, with American's net income increasing to $425 million and Southwest's to $659 million, driven by robust US travel demand and higher fares.

images.alt_text: American Airlines Group and Southwest Airlines posted quarterly profit rises on Thursday even as the two US carriers pointed to rising impact from the continued grounding of Boeing 737 MAX.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust posts rise in Q2 DPU to 2.28 S cents
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 14% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.28 Singapore cents for its Q2, driven by higher total property income of 11% to S$49.6 million and net property income of 18% to S$39 million. The increase was attributed to incremental rental income from the Anchor building, higher occupancy in aVance, and positive rental reversions. The trust's income available for distribution rose 16% to S$23.8 million.

site_title: 'Prolonged presence of uncertainties' weighs on eurozone: Draghi
summary: Mario Draghi warned that eurozone risks remain on the downside, requiring ongoing stimulus, citing prolonged uncertainties related to geopolitics, protectionism, and emerging market vulnerabilities. He reiterated the need for "ample degree of monetary policy accommodation" after cutting interest rates and restarting asset purchases to boost the flagging economy. Draghi's successor, Christine Lagarde, takes over on November 1, and Draghi said she knows what to do, but no advice was needed. Eurozone growth is forecasted at 1.2% this year and 1.4% in 2020, according to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday with a 0.32% gain, tracking positive leads from Wall Street and easing Brexit worries. The Hang Seng Index rose to 26,651.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.08%. The Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.06%. The gains come as investors remain positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's next move.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks edged up in the first few minutes of Thursday, tracking a positive lead from Wall Street and on easing worries about a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's jobless rate rose to a decade-high of 2.3% in Q3, but employment growth also increased. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that digital currencies are not a compelling reason for central banks to issue them. Lotte Duty Free will take over Changi Airport's liquor and tobacco business from DFS, starting next June. SingPost maintained its 'BBB+' S&P rating with a stable outlook. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day 0.8% higher.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare buys majority stake in Wuxi Bohai Hospital
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare has acquired a 70% stake in Wuxi Bohai Hospital for approximately 9.8 million yuan (S$1.9 million). The vendor will retain a 30% stake, and OUELH will manage and operate the 100-bed Grade II hospital in Wuxi, Jiangsu, under a joint-venture agreement. The hospital will be renamed Wuxi Lippo Xi Nan Hospital, pending approval.

site_title: Warren is 'single biggest risk for the market,' Citrone says
summary: US presidential contender Elizabeth Warren's rise is seen as a significant risk to the market by Rob Citrone, founder of Discovery Capital Management, with a potential S&P decline of 10-20% if she leads the February primaries. Citrone attributes this concern to Warren's substantially different policies on regulation, taxes, and private equity. His comments come as Democrats prepare to choose a candidate to run against President Donald Trump, sparking fear on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: The rise of US presidential contender Elizabeth Warren is "the single biggest risk for the market," according to Rob Citrone, founder of hedge fund Discovery Capital Management.

site_title: French media take copyright fight to Google
summary: French media groups are taking Google to the French competition regulator over the company's refusal to pay news companies for displaying their content online, despite the country's strict new EU copyright law. The APIG press alliance claims Google's decision will result in a loss of visibility and ad revenue for publishers. The move comes after Google stated it would only display content in search results if media firms consent to use it for free. The French government has promised to take action against Google, and EU member states must translate the law into domestic legislation by June 2021.

site_title: Lian Beng bags S$173m contract to build condo at River Valley Close
summary: Lian Beng Group secured a S$173 million contract to build a condominium development at River Valley Close. The project involves demolishing existing buildings and constructing two 36-storey towers with 376 residential units. Work is scheduled to start in November 2019 and complete in November 2022, with the contract expected to positively impact the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for FY2020. This latest award boosts Lian Beng's order book to a record S$1.6 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong shares finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.87% to 26,797.95, following an advance in Asian markets and a lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index was barely moved, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.13%. The gains came despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's new bankruptcy law faces key test in the courts
summary: Saudi Arabia's new bankruptcy law, introduced in 2018, is set to face its first major test in the courts in about a year. The law aims to help the kingdom attract investors and diversify its economy. Courts will handle initial cases, which should provide evidence of the law's success. Only three cases have been settled so far, with around a dozen others in the courts. Resolving insolvency has improved Saudi Arabia's ranking in the World Bank report, climbing 30 places to 62nd. The government expects further advances next year as the law and other reforms come fully online.

site_title: Sales at Martin Modern condo boost GuocoLand's Q1 earnings
summary: GuocoLand, a Singaporean property developer, reported a 61% increase in net profit to S$42.1 million in its Q1 earnings, driven by a 62% surge in revenue to S$272.5 million, mainly due to higher sales from its Martin Modern condominium. Earnings per share rose to 3.36 Singapore cents from 1.93 cents a year ago. This contrasts with GL Limited, another company owned by the same parent, which posted a 26% drop in net profit to US$12 million due to lower revenue from its oil and gas segment.

site_title: ECB keeps money taps open as Draghi denied grand finale
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept its ultra-easy monetary policy unchanged, ending Mario Draghi's eight-year tenure with no significant changes to interest rates or stimulus packages. Despite concerns over the eurozone's slow growth, inflation, and debt crisis, Draghi defended his policies and left the door open for further stimulus. The ECB's benchmark deposit rate remained at -0.5% and bond purchases will start in November at a rate of 20 billion euros per month.

site_title: Britain awash with corrupt cash: study
summary: Britain is awash with dirty money, with over £300 billion flowing in via UK-based accountancy firms, banks, and law firms, according to a study by Transparency International. The suspect money is used to buy luxury items, access prestigious institutions, and fund private lifestyles. The study identified 86 financial institutions, 81 law firms, and 62 accountancy firms that have helped individuals funnel funds, and 421 properties worth £5 billion bought with suspicious wealth. The organization warns that this could be the tip of the iceberg, with 87,000 properties owned by companies in secrecy jurisdictions.

site_title: Three professionals charged with defrauding banks of more than S$3.6m
summary: Three financial professionals, Shen Tsu-kuang, Tan Chen Yen, and Ng Eu Hou, have been charged with defrauding banks of over S$3.6 million. Shen allegedly misappropriated funds as a proxy for a customer, while Tan misappropriated cash from a bank safe. Ng deceived victims into applying for loans without their consent. The charges include cheating, criminal breach of trust, and money-laundering offences.

site_title: JTC partners Delta Electronics for Industry 4.0 technology push
summary: JTC Corporation has partnered with Delta Electronics to drive Industry 4.0 technology adoption in Singapore. Delta will set up a solutions and training centre to support JTC customers, upskill SME partners, and offer automation solutions to tackle manufacturing sector issues. The partnership aims to address connectivity and digitalization challenges, and co-develop training content in leading manufacturing technologies. Delta will also work with JTC customers to identify problems and propose solutions to top Singapore technical universities. The initiative is part of the JTC-Delta Industry Transformation Initiative.

site_title: China's leaders to hold key conclave next week
summary: China's ruling Communist Party will hold a key leadership meeting from October 28 to 31, the first since February 2018. The meeting, known as the Fourth Plenum of the party's Central Committee, will discuss the country's roadmap and future direction amidst ongoing unrest in Hong Kong, a lingering trade war, and a slowing economy. The closed-door meeting is seen as a crucial moment for China's policymakers, who face increasing pressure to address the country's economic slowdown. The outcome of the meeting is expected to have significant implications for China's economic and political landscape.

site_title: Self-driving vehicles to be tested on roads in all of western Singapore
summary: Singapore is set to expand its self-driving vehicle testing grounds to cover over 1,000 km of public roads in western Singapore, including Bukit Timah, Clementi, and Jurong. The expansion aims to support the development of autonomous mobility and pave the way for pilot deployments in the early 2020s. Public safety will remain a top priority, and companies must meet stringent safety assessments and display prominent decals to ensure easy identification by other road users.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.8% following strong Wall St performance
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by Wall Street's positive performance and risk appetite returning to Asia's equity markets. Other gains were seen in Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea. Key sectors including technology and banking outperformed, with Keppel Corp advancing 2.2% and the banking trio DBS, OCBC, and UOB rising 1-1.2%. The market saw a higher trading volume and turnover, with 244 advancers outpacing 136 decliners.

site_title: BOJ warns economy vulnerable to riskier lending practices of financial firms
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has warned that Japan's banking system is becoming increasingly fragile due to financial institutions taking on riskier lending and investment practices. Regional banks are seeking higher returns due to prolonged ultra-low interest rates and a dwindling population. The BOJ notes that credit costs are rising, particularly for regional financial institutions, and urges caution to prevent a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Singapore in 2nd place for ease of doing business: World Bank
summary: Singapore has retained its second place in the World Bank's Doing Business 2020 study, with 33 business-climate-enhancing reforms implemented in the East Asia and Pacific region, a 10-reform decrease from the previous period. The region's overall pace of reforms slowed, with fewer than half of economies (12 out of 25) implementing reforms.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,168.10, up 0.76% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday at 3,168.10, up 0.76% on the day, with the Straits Times Index advancing 23.82 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 177 to 115, with key performers including Rex International, Singtel, Keppel Corp, and Sembcorp Marine. Most Asian markets rose, following a positive lead from Wall Street, despite US economic growth slowdown concerns.

site_title: Paya Lebar Quarter officially launched as new precinct
summary: Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ), a mixed-use development in Singapore, was officially launched on October 24, 2019. The S$3.7 billion project, developed by Lendlease and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, features retail, office, and residential components. Key attractions include PLQ Mall, PLQ Workplace, and Park Place Residences, with over 90% of available office and retail spaces leased. The project's end development value is estimated at S$3.7 billion, with Park Place Residences offering 429 condominium units.

site_title: Rents, prices of industrial space hold steady in Q3: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents and prices remained steady in Q3, with a 0.1% quarter-over-quarter increase and flat rental index. The price index decreased 0.1% year-over-year, while the rental index rose 0.1%. The overall industrial property market occupancy rate held at 89.3%, up 0.2 percentage points from a year ago.

site_title: Global dealmakers powering ahead with M&A deals despite geopolitical storms: poll
summary: Dealmakers remain optimistic about M&A activity despite geopolitical tensions and economic uncertainties. A survey of 150 global dealmakers found 54% expect M&A activity to increase through 2019 and beyond, with 71% planning to ramp up cross-border investments. Strong interest from buyers despite turbulence worldwide is expected to continue into the year ahead.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street gains, pound flat with eyes on Brexit
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday following a positive lead from Wall Street, with the pound remaining flat as traders await the next Brexit move. The EU is expected to extend Britain's divorce deadline, while China and the US appear on track to sign a mini trade deal next month. The rally was also driven by improved sentiment over Britain's potential divorce pact and the lifting of sanctions on Turkey.

images.alt_text: Most Asian markets rose on Thursday following a positive lead from Wall Street, while the pound was marginally higher as traders await the next Brexit move with the EU expected to extend Britain's divorce deadline yet again.

site_title: Chinese-owned teen sensation TikTok losing appeal, data shows
summary: TikTok, a Chinese-owned social media app, has seen a decline in global user downloads for the first time since its inception two years ago, according to data from Sensor Tower. The app's 3rd quarter user downloads dropped 4% from last year, with an estimated 177 million first-time users. This decline comes as the app faces criticism over its handling of politically sensitive content and concerns over user data. ByteDance, the app's parent company, is spending hundreds of millions on advertising to counter these concerns, but may need to rethink its strategy.

site_title: India's mobile operators face US$13b in charges after court ruling
summary: India's top court upheld a demand by the telecoms department for $17.6 billion in overdue levies and interest from wireless carriers, sending shares tumbling. Telecom providers pay 3-5% of revenue in usage charges and 8% as licence fees, with the court ruling that Adjusted Gross Revenue (AGR) should include all revenue, not just core services. Shares in Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea dropped 9.7% and 23% respectively, with Bharti Airtel expressing disappointment and calling for a reduction in the burden on the industry.

site_title: As more stablecoins emerge, MAS mulls impact on Singdollar stability
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is considering stablecoins, including Libra, due to their potential to impact monetary policy control. Managing director Ravi Menon expressed a cautious approach, emphasizing the need for a deeper discussion on managing risks. Stablecoins, pegged to fiat currencies or commodities, aim to reduce price volatility. The MAS will take an "open mind" approach, weighing the benefits and risks of stablecoins in the region.

site_title: European stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, following gains in Tokyo and overnight on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.5%, and Paris's CAC 40 advanced 0.5%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, with investors staying positive despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian shares supported by energy, mining firms; NZ edges down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,693.6, driven by gains in energy and mining firms, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto Ltd. New Zealand shares edged down 0.2% due to utilities taking a breather after a sharp sell-off the previous day.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 0.3 per cent or 20.5 points to 6,693.6, having ended little changed Wednesday.

site_title: 'White terror': Hong Kong's China critics beaten in targeted attacks
summary: Targeted attacks on prominent Hong Kong pro-democracy figures, dubbed "white terror," have increased since late August, with eight dissidents beaten by unknown assailants. The victims include rally organizers, lawmakers, and students. The attacks are believed to be linked to triad crime networks that have allegedly joined Beijing's cause amid five months of pro-democracy protests. The incidents have raised concerns about the safety of dissidents and opposition figures ahead of upcoming polls.

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by resource stocks; New Zealand inches up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,709.20, driven by resource stocks tracking higher commodity prices and easing concerns over slowing global growth. Mining and energy stocks led gains, with BHP and Rio Tinto up 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively. Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi jumped 7.3% after posting higher sales growth.
