Meanwhile, Qantas Airways dropped 3.7% due to sluggish domestic growth and higher fuel costs. New Zealand shares rose 0.1% after a record fall on Wednesday.

site_title: South Korean stocks end the day higher
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Thursday, driven by SK Hynix's upbeat third-quarter earnings. The chip maker's shares jumped 3% after it forecast a recovery in the global memory market due to 5G-enabled smartphones. The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI index closed 0.24% higher, with a total trading volume of 352.69 million shares. This marks the 2.19% year-to-date gain for the KOSPI, following a 3.8% gain in the previous 30 trading sessions.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI ended up 5.04 points, or 0.24 per cent, at 2,085.66.

site_title: Lotte Duty Free to take over Changi Airport's liquor, tobacco business from DFS
summary: Lotte Duty Free, the world's second-largest travel retailer, has won the concession tender for Changi Airport's liquor and tobacco business from DFS, which will exit the business after a four-decade tenure. Lotte's six-year tenancy will begin in June 2020 and will see the renovation of 18 stores across four terminals, featuring new store concepts and product personalization. The move marks the first time a new operator will helm the airport's duty-free liquor and tobacco stores, with DFS citing tighter regulations and steep losses as reasons for its exit.

site_title: Temasek-backed Israeli-US retail logistics startup Fabric raises US$110m
summary: Fabric, a Temasek-backed Israeli-US retail logistics startup, has raised US$110 million in a funding round led by Corner Ventures. The company, formerly known as CommonSense Robotics, aims to accelerate growth in the US market by building micro-fulfilment centers and expanding its commercial operations. With a total raised of US$136 million, Fabric plans to launch micro-fulfilment centers in several US cities in 2020 and has 14 sites under contract. The funding will also be used to grow technical support and engineering teams.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close higher on US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a four-day winning streak on Thursday, driven by US rallies and a cheaper yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.55% and the Topix index rose 0.34%. This marks the fourth consecutive day of gains, following a string of positive market movements.

site_title: Ghosn's lawyers accuse Japan officials, Nissan executives of collusion
summary: Lawyers for former Nissan Motor Co chairman Carlos Ghosn submitted a statement to the Tokyo District Court, accusing Japanese officials and executives of collusion in his prosecution. They claim the prosecution was formed to remove Ghosn as head of the Alliance, citing "unlawful collusion" between prosecutors, government officials, and Nissan executives. The statement seeks the dismissal of all charges against Ghosn, who remains in detention.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, increasing 1.63 points to 1,570.42. The FTSE index saw a trading volume of 110.18 million lots worth RM43.88 million. Gainers outpaced losers 139 to 59.

site_title: India telecom regulator says 'market forces' easing price war
summary: India's telecommunications regulator says market forces are easing a price war among the country's three major carriers, despite courts blocking its efforts to regulate "predatory pricing." This move comes after Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd imposed a charge on free voice calls, reversing a promotional offer that had driven down the market price for 1GB of data to less than $1. TRAI chairman Ram Sewak Sharma notes that "market forces are working on predatory pricing," suggesting a shift towards more sustainable competition.

site_title: SK Hynix posts lowest profit in three years
summary: SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chip maker, posted its lowest quarterly profit in three years due to a decline in the global chip market. Operating profit dropped 93% to 473 billion won, and net profit plummeted 89% to 495 billion won. The company attributes the decline to weak DRAM prices, which led to a 16% drop in average selling price. SK Hynix plans to cut output and adjust its product mix to increase profitability and expects chip prices to recover next year as demand rises for ultrafast 5G handsets.

site_title: Utico says adviser fees capped at S$40m; may cut Hyflux investment next week
summary: Utico has agreed to cap adviser fees at S$40 million as part of its proposed rescue deal for insolvent water treatment firm Hyflux. This move resolves a key item under Hyflux's restructuring agreement. If Hyflux does not sign the definitive agreement by early next week, Utico plans to reduce its S$300 million equity injection to S$200 million. The deal also includes a S$100 million shareholder loan and options for Hyflux's 34,000 retail shareholders to recover their S$900 million investment.

site_title: SingPost maintains its 'BBB+' S&P rating; outlook stable
summary: SingPost has maintained its "BBB+" S&P rating with a stable outlook, reflecting its expectation of consolidating logistics and express delivery operations and managing costs to support earnings growth. The rating agency expects SingPost to rein in large acquisitions and maintain a debt-to-Ebitda ratio below 2.5 times to avoid a further downgrade. An upgrade is unlikely in the next two years due to declining mail volumes and strong competitive pressures.

site_title: Kim and Trump have 'special' relationship: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump have a "special" relationship, according to a top Pyongyang official. This comes after Trump's recent comments about his good relationship with Kim. Analysts believe the North is trying to exploit this relationship to secure US concessions in nuclear talks, despite Washington's insistence on denuclearization before sanctions are lifted. Pyongyang hopes to negotiate directly with Trump to overcome obstacles in talks, which stalled after the failed Hanoi summit in February.

site_title: Singapore in 2nd place for ease of doing business: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has released a report ranking economies by ease of doing business, with Singapore retaining its second spot and New Zealand topping the global rankings. China has improved its business climate for the second year in a row, moving up 15 places to 31st, while India jumped 14 places to 63rd. The report credits China with improving protections for minority investors and trade procedures, and notes that countries with sound business regulation and electronic systems tend to perform better.

site_title: New digibanks may push interest rates higher, but not for reckless market grab: MAS
summary: Singapore's digital banks may increase interest rates amid heightened competition, but not for predatory purposes, said MAS managing director Ravi Menon. Digital banks will prioritize profitability in the medium term, and customers still value physical bank presence, giving incumbents an edge. This rebundling of financial services as a one-stop digital shop will not necessarily harm traditional banks.

site_title: Trump lifts Turkey sanctions, says Kurds 'thankful'
summary: President Donald Trump announced the lifting of US sanctions against Turkey, stating that Kurdish guerrillas are "extremely thankful" for the decision. The sanctions were imposed after Trump's abrupt pullout from Syria, which allowed Turkish troops to occupy a swath of northern Syria. A ceasefire was reached, allowing Turkish troops to move in with Russian support. Trump defended his decision, saying the US has no business in Syria and that there was never a question of stopping Turkey's invasion, citing a "major breakthrough" and fulfilling a campaign promise.

site_title: Hong Kong money is fleeing? Not around here
summary: Hong Kong's financial woes may be overstated as two major IPOs, including ESR Cayman Ltd and Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, have successfully raised over $1 billion each since June. Despite market turmoil, Hong Kong remains a top hub for capital-raising, with companies like ESR and Budweiser choosing to list in the city over Singapore. The city's deep stock market and favorable investor appetite have encouraged companies to return to the market, with the benchmark Hang Seng Index climbing 5% from its August low.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong may have been seeing money flow out as the city's turmoil undermines its reputation as a stable financial centre, but one important source of capital keeps on coming: cash for initial public offerings (IPOs).

site_title: No compelling reason for central banks to issue digital currencies: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon stated that central banks have no compelling reason to issue digital currencies. Instead, embracing electronic payments of fiat currencies could reduce transaction costs and bring greater convenience. However, issuing digital currencies could lead to holding wealth as a direct liability of the central bank. This is a key concern, as it may impact the economy.

site_title: Qantas reports dip in domestic demand, shares slide
summary: Qantas Airways reported a 1.8% increase in total revenue, but a 1% decline in domestic revenue, largely driven by a drop in Jetstar bookings. Shares slid 5.8% to a near four-week low due to concerns over rising fuel costs and weak consumer spending. The company cited higher fuel costs and reduced capacity as factors affecting profitability, but still expects total domestic capacity to grow by up to 1% in the second half. Qantas also flagged potential impacts from anti-government protests in Hong Kong and weaker freight demand.

images.alt_text: Australia's Qantas Airways on Thursday reported lower revenue from its domestic routes, particularly at its budget carrier Jetstar, sending its shares tumbling almost 6 per cent to a near four-week low.

site_title: Singapore jobless rate rises to decade-high in Q3, but employment growth also up
summary: Singapore's jobless rate rose to a decade-high of 2.3% in Q3, driven by an increase in retrenchments to 2,900. However, employment growth also surged to the highest level since 2014, driven by gains in the services sector and manufacturing. The government attributes the rising unemployment to skills mismatches in the labor market, with job seekers and employers being less open to flexibility. Despite this, employment rates for older Singaporeans have improved, with the employment rate for citizens aged 55-64 reaching 66.8% last year.

site_title: Trudeau rules out coalition as he forms new Canadian government
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has ruled out forming a coalition government despite winning the election with a minority of seats. Trudeau will consult with leaders of other parties to discuss priorities and potential collaboration, focusing on issues such as climate change, indigenous partnerships, and middle-class tax cuts. His new cabinet, sworn in on November 20, will have an equal number of women and men. Trudeau acknowledged the need for unity and cooperation, particularly in addressing regional concerns in Alberta and Saskatchewan.

images.alt_text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Wednesday ruled out forming a coalition government despite an election victory that left his Liberals short of a majority.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.4% to 3,156.19
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% to 3,156.19 on Thursday, tracking a positive US market session. The Straits Times Index gained 11.91 points, driven by gains in financials such as DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. Asian equities also followed the US rally, with Japan's Topix and Australia's stocks rising 0.6% each. Despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, investors remained positive, with 65 gainers outnumbering 31 losers in the Singapore bourse.

site_title: A parking space in Hong Kong just sold for almost US$1m
summary: A parking space in Hong Kong's Central district, located in the world's priciest office tower, The Center, sold for approximately US$1 million. The buyer, businessman Johnny Cheung, is known for flipping properties and made around HK$900 million last year. The sale highlights Hong Kong's severe income inequality, with one in five residents living below the poverty line, and a Gini coefficient at a 45-year high in 2016. The price is comparable to buying a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, further emphasizing the gap between the ultra-rich and ordinary people in the city.

site_title: 'Flight shame' will make carbon big business: Citi
summary: "Flight shame" is fueling a growing trend of offsetting carbon emissions from air travel, with the cost expected to rise 10 times higher than current estimates. Airlines, consumers, and companies will bear the costs, while rail operators, governments, and carbon schemes are likely to benefit. The trend, driven by groups like Greenpeace and environmentalists like Greta Thunberg, may lead to a significant increase in rail usage and higher taxes on airlines, potentially curbing passenger volumes. The aviation industry faces years of technological limitations in reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on October 24, 2019, due to rallies on Wall Street and a cheaper yen against the dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.46% or 103.56 points to 22,728.94. The broader Topix index also increased 0.54% or 8.82 points to 1,646.96.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars stuck in a news lull, eye resistance
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were stagnant on Thursday due to a lack of progress on Brexit and the Sino-US trade dispute. The Aussie was at US$0.6854, while the kiwi dollar was steady at US$0.6418. Economists expect a potential rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia, with a 16% chance in November and 82% in February. Bond yields remained near record lows, and a rare event in a government debt auction drew bids worth less than the offered amount, indicating market uncertainty.

site_title: MAS chief sees slow economic recovery for Singapore
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon expects Singapore's economy to recover slowly, with growth expected to come in around the midpoint of the official 0-1% forecast range this year and improve modestly in 2020. The recovery is expected to be contained in the trade and manufacturing sectors, with no signs of it spilling over into other parts of the economy. Menon noted that the MAS has policy space and can use unconventional tools if necessary, but emphasized the need for a balance between monetary and fiscal policy to avoid over-reliance on monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economy may be a few quarters away from a recovery as the decline in trade and manufacturing this year hasn't really spread to other sectors, said the head of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: Japan's Credit Saison launches new Asia-focused fund for early-stage startups
summary: Japan's Credit Saison launches a US$55 million venture fund focused on early-stage startups in South-east Asia and India, its first dedicated corporate venture capital (CVC) fund. The fund, Saison Capital, aims to invest in six to eight companies annually, prioritizing fintech startups that can reach underbanked regions and complement Credit Saison's financial services. The CVC will deploy funds through equity investments of up to US$1 million, with a focus on scalability, unit economics, and founder ambition.

site_title: No gifts, please: Diwali blues hit corporate India
summary: Diwali celebrations in corporate India are losing their luster due to the economic slowdown. Executives like Bibhas Chakraborty are no longer receiving extravagant gifts, instead receiving sweets and nuts. The quality of gifts has decreased, with some not even receiving gifts at all. This trend is a concern for those who view Diwali as an opportunity to strengthen business relationships through gifts. The economic slowdown is seen as a contributing factor to this change, as companies are struggling to maintain consumer demand.

images.alt_text: For Indian executive Bibhas Chakraborty, Diwali used to mean shiny expensive gifts from business associates keen to use the auspicious - and spectacular - Hindu festival to deepen ties. Now it's mostly sweets and nuts.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust calls for trading halt after reports on possible lease default
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has requested a trading halt pending an announcement about possible lease default by its sponsor, Urban Commons, over repairs to the historic Queen Mary ship in California. The city of Long Beach had sent a letter to Urban Commons, claiming the company had failed to make necessary repairs, giving it 30 days to respond with a plan. The trust's stapled securities ended at US$0.645, down one US cent, on Wednesday.

site_title: Valuation doubts behind PropGuru's weak demand
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian real estate portal, has abandoned its proposed initial public offering (IPO) on the Australia Securities Exchange (ASX) due to uncertainty in the market. The company cited strong investor support, but lack of interest from strategic investors, including those from Australia. The IPO would have raised A$380.2 million, valuing the company at A$1.16 billion to A$1.36 billion. The move follows a recent trend of failed IPOs in Australia, with the company instead opting to rely on its existing shareholder base and private capital markets to fund its growth strategy.

site_title: Google accused of creating spy tool to squelch worker dissent
summary: Google employees are accusing the company's leadership of developing an internal surveillance tool to monitor worker dissent and organize protests. The tool, set to be rolled out in late October, automatically reports employees who create large-scale meetings, allegedly to monitor worker organization attempts. Google denies the claims, stating the tool is a pop-up reminder to be mindful of large meetings and does not collect personally identifiable information. The move has fueled growing tensions between Google's leadership and rank-and-file employees, who have protested leadership's handling of sexual harassment complaints and unionization efforts.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher as Boeing, Caterpillar gain
summary: US stocks rose modestly on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.2% to 26,833.95. Boeing and Caterpillar shares rose 1.1% and 1.2% respectively, despite mixed earnings reports. Boeing missed analyst expectations but confirmed it expects to win regulatory approval for the 737 Max this year. Semiconductor shares slumped after Texas Instruments reported a 11% drop in quarterly revenues. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the Nasdaq advancing 0.2% to 8,119.79.

site_title: SGX licenses global Internet index to Nikko Asset Management
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has licensed its iEdge-FactSet Global Internet Index to Nikko Asset Management, a global asset manager. The index tracks companies in internet and data services, and Nikko AM will use it for exchange-traded fund (ETF) listings. This partnership expands SGX's global reach and provides Nikko AM with a comprehensive internet index, enhancing its passive investment strategies.

site_title: Pound firms awaiting Brexit extension date
summary: The British pound firmed against the dollar and euro on Wednesday as the European Union prepared to grant a further Brexit delay, averting a no-deal departure next week. The EU is set to extend the Brexit deadline, likely until the end of January, after British MPs rejected Prime Minister Boris Johnson's divorce deal. The pound briefly dropped before bouncing back, with analysts citing the prospect of a no-deal Brexit as a major factor in its volatility. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.7%, while Wall Street edged higher in response to mixed earnings reports.

site_title: Cloud computing gains drive up profit for Microsoft
summary: Microsoft reported a 21% increase in quarterly profits to $10.7 billion, driven by its thriving cloud computing business. Revenue rose 14% to $33.1 billion, with cloud services generating $11.6 billion in revenue. CEO Satya Nadella attributes the growth to investments in the cloud and its ability to serve multinational corporations. However, revenue growth in Microsoft's cloud unit Azure may be slowing, and the company's Xbox gaming unit saw no growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Wing Tai, SembMarine, San Teh, Ascott Reit, A-HTrust
summary: ST Engineering faces a US$18 million arbitration payment, resulting in an additional S$14.2 million provision. Wing Tai's Q1 net profit more than triples to S$6.8 million, driven by lower costs and higher associate profits. Shares of ST Engineering fell 0.51% and Wing Tai's shares dropped 1% after the announcement.

site_title: US Republicans storm secure impeachment deposition, delay testimony
summary: US Republicans stormed a secure impeachment deposition room, delaying testimony from a Pentagon official, in a move that escalated a showdown over the investigation of President Donald Trump's pressure campaign against Ukraine. The incident, which violated House rules, occurred after over 30 lawmakers, mostly Republicans, entered the SCIF without permission, with some tweeting from within the secure facility. The move was branded a "stunt" by Democrats and delayed the deposition of Laura Cooper, a deputy assistant secretary of defense.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg open to scaling back Libra plan
summary: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's CEO, expressed openness to scaling back plans for the digital currency Libra if it cannot secure regulatory approvals. The project aims to build a global payment system rather than a currency, with the possibility of linking it to individual currencies or the US dollar. Lawmakers criticized Facebook's data practices and questioned the trustworthiness of the company, with some expressing concerns about the potential for Libra to be used for illicit activities. Regulatory bodies, including the G-7 and US Treasury Secretary, have also expressed concerns about the project's readiness for launch.

site_title: CCT posts flat Q3 DPU; inks more leases for CapitaSpring
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported an unchanged distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.2 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, with advanced distributions of 0.62 cents and 1.58 cents for the respective periods. CCT also inked more leases for its CapitaSpring property.

site_title: Europe: Shares nudge up, earnings a mixed bag
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Wednesday, despite investor concerns over a potential delay to Britain's departure from the EU. The Stoxx 600 index was boosted by mining stocks, which jumped 1%, and technology stocks, which fell 0.4% due to a sales warning from Texas Instruments. Earnings reports from companies like Peugeot and LVMH showed mixed results, with some reporting strong demand for SUV models. The FTSE 100 gained 0.7% as a weaker pound boosted exporters, but parliament's rejection of Boris Johnson's Brexit deal left EU leaders considering a potential extension.

images.alt_text: European shares struggled to make headway on Wednesday as investor concerns about a further delay to Britain's departure from the EU offset gains for London's exporter-heavy FTSE 100 from a weaker pound and some decent corporate earnings.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Buy or sell? How to read and use the URA price indices
summary: The Money FM podcast "Buy or Sell? How to read and use the URA price indices" explores how to use the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) price indices to inform buying or selling decisions in the real estate market. Mohamed Ismail Gafoor, Chairman & CEO of Propnex Limited, discusses the current market trends and provides insights on when to buy or sell, favoring buyers or sellers, and the impact of the URA price indices on real estate investments.

site_title: Indonesia Cabinet includes Jokowi's rival, Gojek founder
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled his Cabinet for a second term, retaining finance minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati and naming opposition leader Prabowo Subianto as defense minister. Prabowo, a former general accused of human rights abuses, was a key challenger to Widodo in the 2019 election. The Cabinet includes around half technocrats, who are likely to support Widodo's plans for boosting growth and investment. The move has been criticized by activists, but may help the government push through legislation.

site_title: New York Federal Reserve bumps up overnight cash injections
summary: The New York Federal Reserve has increased overnight cash injections to $120 billion daily, from $75 billion, and $45 billion for 14-day "repo" operations, through mid-November. This move aims to prevent a liquidity shortage that could cause short-term interest rates to spike. The Fed has also been purchasing Treasurys to inject more cash into the financial system, expanding its balance sheet, and is set to continue this through the second quarter of 2020. Economists attribute the liquidity shortage to quarterly corporate tax payments and a surge in government debt sold to investors.

images.alt_text: The New York Federal Reserve Bank is jacking up the amount of cash it injects into the US financial plumbing on a nightly basis, officials said on Wednesday.

site_title: Startup IPO jitters spill over into South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asia's initial public offering (IPO) market for venture-backed startups is experiencing jitters following the recent flops of startup IPOs in the US. Market sentiment is becoming more cautious, with analysts warning of potential delays in listings. The struggles of US IPOs are having a ripple effect on the region, with investors becoming more risk-averse. This trend may impact venture-backed startups planning to list in the region, potentially delaying their IPOs.

site_title: 737 Max design flaws linked to crash, Indonesian investigators tell families of victims
summary: Indonesian investigators have concluded that design flaws, including incorrect assumptions about the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), contributed to the Lion Air 737 Max crash in October 2018, resulting in the deaths of 189 people. The investigation revealed that the MCAS system was not properly designed or communicated to pilots, leading to a series of events that ultimately caused the crash. The findings are set to be released in a final report.

site_title: Oil rises on surprise US crude drawdown, prospect of Opec action
summary: Oil prices rose 2.5% on Wednesday after a surprise drawdown of 1.7 million US crude barrels, with Brent crude futures reaching $61.17 a barrel and WTI crude futures at $55.97 a barrel. The drawdown was attributed to higher refinery runs and lower oil imports, despite concerns about the global economy. The prospect of deeper output cuts by Opec and its allies also supported prices, with Goldman Sachs forecasting Brent prices to reach $62 a barrel by year-end.

site_title: Oil and gas giants spend over 250m euros on EU lobbying: green groups
summary: Oil and gas giants, including BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil, Shell, and Total, spent over 250 million euros lobbying the European Union since 2010, with at least 327 high-level meetings with EU officials. Environmental groups argue that this funding is an attempt to influence climate action decisions, despite claims of no conflict of interest. The EU is seen as a leader in climate action, but green groups fear that the continent's fossil fuel infrastructure projects could hinder efforts to meet the 2015 Paris climate accord's 1.5°C goal.

site_title: Facebook's Washington strategy falters as Zuckerberg testifies in another hearing
summary: Facebook's efforts to influence Washington policy have yielded little success, despite spending a record $4.8 million on lobbyists in the third quarter. The company's struggles in Washington are attributed to its handling of issues such as Libra, repeated privacy lapses, and antitrust concerns. Mark Zuckerberg is set to testify before the House Financial Services Committee, acknowledging some of the company's missteps and expressing a desire to move forward with Libra projects. The hearing marks Zuckerberg's third public appearance in Washington in the past month.

site_title: Ford cuts profit outlook, sending shares lower
summary: Ford reported lower quarterly profits and slashed its full-year forecast due to increased incentive spending in North America and lower sales in China. Earnings fell 57.1% to $425 million, and revenues dropped 1.8% to $37 billion. Despite higher operating profits in North America, the company suffered operating losses in China. Shares fell 2.6% to $8.97 after the announcement, amid a weakened financial outlook. Ford's restructuring efforts, including phasing out low-selling sedans, aim to improve the company's financial position.

site_title: Saudi Arabia names prince with Western experience as foreign minister
summary: Saudi Arabia appointed Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud as foreign minister, replacing Ibrahim al-Assaf, in a partial cabinet reshuffle. Prince Faisal has Western diplomatic experience, having served as Saudi ambassador to Germany and as a political adviser at the US embassy. The move aims to improve the kingdom's international image ahead of its 2020 G20 presidency. Prince Faisal's previous career included a business stint with Boeing. Other cabinet changes included the replacement of Nabil al-Amoudi as transport minister with Saleh al-Jasser, director general of Saudi Arabian Airlines.

site_title: Tesla shares rev higher after update on profits, China
summary: Tesla shares surged 15% in after-hours trading after the company reported a profit of $143 million on $5.4 billion in revenue for the third quarter. The electric carmaker stated it has started production at its factory in Shanghai, China, which will boost global production and sales. This news comes as Tesla marks its formal entry into India and plans to expand its robotaxi service to California and Arizona. The company's financial results exceeded analyst expectations, providing a positive update on its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Tesla shares raced higher in after-hours trading after the company announced its factory in China had started production, while a quarterly update showed better-than expected financial results.

site_title: Nissan may axe Datsun brand, shut some assembly lines globally
summary: Nissan is likely to axe its Datsun brand and close some assembly lines globally as part of its "performance recovery plan," a significant departure from ousted CEO Carlos Ghosn's aggressive expansion strategy. The plan aims to boost profits by reducing costs and focusing on more profitable products. The move marks a shift in Nissan's strategy, as the company seeks to get smaller and more efficient.

site_title: Investors book profits after strong start to week
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,144.28, dropping 16.39 points or 0.5% following a strong early-week rally. Investors locked in profits amid Brexit worries and a weak revenue forecast from Texas Instruments. Most Asian markets, including China, Hong Kong, and Japan, posted losses, while Australia remained flat. The Hang Seng Index hit a one-week low, and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson received an approval in principle from Parliament for the withdrawal agreement, but with a delayed deadline.

site_title: Take a road trip to see Korea's southern gems
summary: South Korea's southern province of Jeollanam-do is a culinary gem, boasting warm summers, mild winters, and rich terroir. The region is home to bountiful produce, including fresh seaweed, abalone, and dried croaker, which are showcased in local specialties like samhap and fine-dining restaurants in Seoul. Meanwhile, a growing locavore movement in Taipei highlights the country's home-grown produce.

site_title: Heated row over plans to move Greek antiquities from construction site
summary: Greek government plans to relocate ancient city district unearthed during a subway tunnel construction project in Thessaloniki to a museum, sparking outrage among archaeologists and locals. The site, featuring 6th-century buildings and artifacts, is considered priceless and would require breaking up 700 tonnes of finds into at least 100 pieces, causing irreparable damage. The move has been met with resistance from opposition politicians, archaeologists, and locals, with over 15,000 citizens signing an online petition to keep the relics in place.

site_title: Brexit moves one step forward, one step back
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson scored a symbolic win with his withdrawal bill, securing a 329-299 victory in the second reading. However, the bill's passage was delayed due to the rejection of the accelerated timeline, with MPs voting 322-308 against the proposed October 31 deadline. Johnson's renegotiation of the Northern Ireland "backstop" contributed to his win, as it won support from hardcore Conservative Brexiteers and 19 Labour MPs. The outcome is likely to delay the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc rise as investors seek safer assets
summary: Investors sought safer assets as Brexit uncertainty delayed, causing the Japanese yen to rise to a one-week high and the Swiss franc to gain. The yen rose to 108.465 per US dollar, while the Swiss franc rose 0.1% to 1.1003 francs per euro. The move follows British lawmakers opposing Boris Johnson's Brexit timetable, leading to speculation of a general election before Christmas. The US dollar index fell 2% since the start of the month, while sterling slipped to a low of US$1.2842.

site_title: Singapore to stay nimble in its global strategy by keeping digital trade open: Iswaran
summary: Singapore aims to stay nimble in its global trade strategy by keeping digital trade open, Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran said at a symposium on free trade agreements. The country has a network of over 24 FTAs with 36 trading partners, and is working with like-minded countries to establish clear and harmonized rules for digital trade. Singapore is also leading digital trade efforts at the World Trade Organisation, aiming to develop baseline rules on digital trade and protect against digital fragmentation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Court has scheduled the applications for sanction of the Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) scheme and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) scheme for November 19, following overwhelming support from unitholders for their proposed merger.

site_title: Asia's red-hot bond funds are raising risks for investors
summary: Asia's red-hot bond funds are raising concerns for investors due to the high risks associated with these financial products. Fixed-maturity funds offer regular payouts but don't guarantee returns, and their limited options can lead fund managers to invest in riskier notes. As market strains occur, these funds can crumble, causing losses for investors. The lack of diversification and the reliance on short-term income make these funds vulnerable to economic downturns, highlighting the need for investors to carefully assess the risks before investing.

site_title: Malaysia may consider lower Goldman penalty: sources
summary: Malaysia is considering a lower settlement with Goldman Sachs, potentially around $2-3 billion, for its role in the 1MDB scandal. This is a significant departure from the bank's initial demand of $7.5 billion. Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is keen to reach an accord before the end of the year to show progress on his pledge to recoup stolen funds. However, the US Department of Justice is expected to extract a serious penalty from Goldman Sachs, and the outcome of the settlement remains uncertain.

site_title: Opec, allies to mull deeper oil cut amid demand worries
summary: OPEC and its allies will consider deeper oil cuts in December due to weak demand growth in 2020, sources say. Saudi Arabia wants to boost adherence to the OPEC+ pact with Russia and other non-members before committing to more cuts, particularly for countries like Iraq and Nigeria that have failed to comply with pledged output reductions. The group's demand forecast shows a drop of 1.2 million barrels per day, with global demand averaging 29.6 million bpd.

site_title: Boeing ousts senior exec Kevin McAllister as 737 MAX crisis grows
summary: Boeing ousted senior executive Kevin McAllister as president and chief executive of its commercial airplanes division, amid the 737 MAX crisis that has resulted in a 346-person death toll from two fatal crashes. Veteran executive Stan Deal took over effective immediately, tasked with resolving the crisis and getting the MAX back into service. The move comes as Boeing faces significant challenges, including deliveries of new aircraft and boosting production of single-aisles, while also addressing a potential new mid-market jetliner.

site_title: COE prices mixed; seen to hover at current levels
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices ended mixed in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600 cc and 130 bhp selling at S$32,309, down from S$34,001 previously. Cars above 1,600 cc or 130 bhp saw a slight increase to S$41,805. The next tender will have a smaller quota, which may impact prices.

site_title: Gold rally driving rush to West Africa, one of metal's final frontiers
summary: West Africa is experiencing a surge in gold mining activity as prices rise and the industry shrinks in other parts of the world. New projects have begun or are scheduled for 2020, with companies like AngloGold Ashanti and Iamgold expanding their operations in Ghana and Senegal. The Birimian belts, ancient volcanic rock formations, hold significant gold deposits that have yet to be fully explored. Despite challenges such as terrorist threats and infrastructure limitations, investors are drawn to the region's potential, with several companies exploring for gold and aiming to develop mines.

site_title: Huawei to launch 5G Mate X smartphone in China, finally
summary: Huawei has started taking orders for its 5G Mate X foldable smartphone in China, priced from 16,999 yuan (S$3,230), after being delayed twice due to US trade sanctions. The company's smartphone sales have been impacted by the sanctions, but revenue rose 27% in the third quarter thanks to solid sales in China. The global launch plan for the Mate X remains under review. Huawei has sold over 200 million phones in 2019, beating its 2018 milestone. The 5G Mate X is a competitor to Samsung's Galaxy Fold, launched in October.

site_title: Dubai's vast Expo 2020 site rises from the desert
summary: Dubai's Expo 2020 site is nearing completion, with a year to go before the six-month global trade fair begins in October 2020. The event aims to deliver an economic boost to the emirate, which has been hit hard by a downturn in its property, tourism, and trade sectors. The $8 billion Expo will feature over 200 countries, 200 restaurants, and dozens of daily events, and will be followed by a planned development into a 4.4 sq km innovation district, including homes, an exhibition center, and corporate headquarters.

images.alt_text: With a year to go until the Expo 2020 trade fair, the mammoth venue in Dubai's desert is currently a tangle of steel, concrete and dust.

site_title: Robo portfolios may move needle on high fund fees in Singapore
summary: Singapore's median asset-weighted fund expenses remain high, with median fees for equity funds at 1.89%, asset allocation funds at 1.54%, and fixed income funds at 1.41%. This is comparable to Taiwan's "bottom" rating. However, Singapore's fixed income fees are higher than those in China (0.44%) and India (0.54%). The use of exchange-traded funds and independent advisers in low-cost markets such as Australia and the US is linked to lower fees. Robo portfolios and the CPF Investment Scheme's efforts to lower fees may help reduce costs in Singapore.

site_title: OCBC Arboretum an initiative to reduce Singapore's carbon footprint
summary: OCBC Bank has launched the OCBC Arboretum, a high-tech tree bank in Singapore to combat climate change. The arboretum, located in the Singapore Botanic Gardens, aims to grow and conserve 200 species of endangered dipterocarps, slow-growing forest giants that can store up to 80 million kg of carbon dioxide in their lifetimes. The arboretum uses a unique monitoring system to track tree health and growth, and will act as a gene bank to preserve the species. This initiative is part of OCBC's commitment to fighting climate change and is a first-of-its-kind project in the region.

site_title: Singapore can assert new source of soft power in culture and creativity
summary: Singapore's soft power ranking remains stagnant at 21st place in the 2019 Soft Power 30 index, despite its recent high-profile appearances in the global limelight. The country's enterprise and digital sectors continue to drive its soft power, but areas for improvement include culture and global engagement. A bicentennial celebration of Sir Stamford Raffles' arrival highlights the importance of showcasing Singapore's multi-ethnic, multi-religious history and its ability to forge different cultures into a shared identity. To boost its soft power, Singapore must leverage its cultural diversity, technological innovation, and positive purpose to position itself as a champion of multilateral collaboration and a level global playing field.

site_title: MLT prices new units at top of range on strong demand
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust priced new units at the top end of an indicative range on strong investor demand, with over 13 times subscription. The Reit raised around S$250 million from the issue of 154.6 million units, primarily to fund S$493.4 million worth of logistics property acquisitions in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China. The new units are priced at a 3.1% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$1.6685 per unit. Trading is expected to start on November 1, with the trust's manager stating that holders of the new units will not be entitled to any prior distributable income.

site_title: Sustenir plants seed in Hong Kong, eyes growth in the Asia-Pacific
summary: Sustenir Agriculture, a Singapore-based hydroponics farm, has launched its first international operation in Hong Kong. The 50,000 sq ft vertical farm aims to increase efficiency and reduce waste through its patented technology. The farm can grow 127 times more produce per square unit than conventional farms and produces non-native crops for the local climate. Sustenir plans to expand to four more "smart farms" in the Asia-Pacific region over the next 12 months, with the goal of building local ecosystems for sustainable food production.

site_title: Changes afoot in the alternative investments industry
summary: Singapore's alternative investment industry is thriving, with assets under management (AUM) tripling to over $9 trillion in the past decade. The city-state is a hub for hedge funds, private equity, and real estate managers, with many firms choosing to base their operations there to access Asian and global markets. A new corporate structure, the "Variable Capital Company" (VCC), is set to launch, providing a local onshore fund vehicle with global appeal. The Alternative Investment Management Association (AIMA) is supporting Singapore's efforts to attract investment fund assets and boost the local industry, with plans for increased events and research papers to educate stakeholders.

site_title: Libra retreat would bring joy and relief to Asia
summary: Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency plan faces opposition from Asian central banks due to concerns over its potential impact on monetary policy and domestic currency values. A global stablecoin like Libra could weaken the effect of monetary policy and reduce seigniorage income for governments, prompting a shift towards smaller, country-specific stablecoins. This could allow China to gain an advantage in the digital currency space, potentially making the yuan the dominant global currency. As a result, Facebook may consider scaling down Libra to avoid these obstacles, potentially ceding the lead to China.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust Q4 DPU up 1.8%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 1.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter ended Sept 30, 2019, driven by higher portfolio occupancy and contributions. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) declined 0.5% and 0.1% year-over-year, respectively. Despite this, income available for distribution rose 17.9% to S$30.4 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy stood at 96.5% and shopper traffic increased 8.9% year-over-year. FCT's management plans to focus on improving portfolio performance in the next few years.

site_title: Morgan Stanley gets plum role in US$1.45b HK IPO relaunch
summary: Morgan Stanley has taken the lead role in relaunching a US$1.45 billion IPO for Hong Kong-based ESR Cayman, surpassing rival banks such as Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs. The Wall Street bank was approached in August to develop a rescue plan for ESR's IPO after the initial float was cancelled in June. Morgan Stanley's new role comes after a "brutal shuffling" of banks' roles on the big deal, with the bank's expertise in handling complex transactions seen as a key factor in its selection.

site_title: Yet another Brexit delay in tying up loose ends with EU
summary: The UK government is facing another Brexit delay as the parliament voted to delay the Brexit deal, citing a need for more time to scrutinize the 110 pages of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill. The delay is expected to push the Brexit deadline to the end of January 2020, with the possibility of a general election if the government fails to secure a majority. EU leaders have agreed to flexible delays, and the UK may seek a fixed delay until the end of January. The delay has sparked concerns about the impact on the UK and EU economies, with both sides suffering from "acute Brexit fatigue."

site_title: IMF cuts Singapore 2019 growth forecast to 0.5%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) cut its growth projection for Singapore to 0.5% in 2019, citing strong export headwinds and the electronics cycle downturn. The IMF's projection for Asia is 5% in 2019 and 5.1% in 2020, with China's growth expected to decline moderately to 6.1% in 2019 and 5.8% in 2020. The IMF warns that a further intensification of trade tensions could weigh on confidence, weaken trade, and growth.

site_title: US existing home sales drop more than expected in Sept
summary: US existing home sales dropped 2.2% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.38 million units in September, reversing two straight months of gains. This decline was more than expected, following a decline of 0.7% in August. The median existing house price increased 5.9% from a year ago to $272,100, the strongest price appreciation since January 2018. The housing market continues to struggle with a lack of properties for sale, especially for cheaper homes, despite the US Federal Reserve cutting interest rates twice this year.

site_title: UK fintech Revolut rolls out services to Singapore public
summary: Revolut, a UK-based fintech firm, has officially rolled out its services to the public in Singapore, following a beta launch that attracted over 30,000 customers. The app offers multicurrency e-wallet services, free money transfers, and a FX-linked Visa debit card. Revolut plans to double its currency offerings in the coming months and aims to expand into the US and Canada by the end of the year, with a goal of tripling its Singapore staff size. The service is free for most major currencies on weekdays, with a small mark-up applied on weekends.

site_title: Online banks need to stay relevant with virtual financial services
summary: Online banks in Hong Kong and Singapore are embracing virtual financial services to remain relevant. Since March 2018, Hong Kong has granted eight virtual bank licences, and Singapore's Monetary Authority has announced plans to issue up to five new digital bank licences. This trend is gaining momentum in Asia, with virtual banking being introduced in other countries. To stay competitive, online banks must innovate and adapt to changing market conditions, prioritizing digital services and customer experience.

site_title: Facebook devotes US$1b to affordable housing in US
summary: Facebook is devoting $1 billion over the next decade to affordable housing in the US, with most of it going towards California. The company will partner with state officials and community groups to create up to 20,000 new housing units for essential workers. Facebook has already committed $250 million to California's affordable housing efforts and plans to use its own land to develop 1,500 units of mixed-income housing in Menlo Park. The initiative aims to address economic inequality and restore social mobility in California and beyond.

site_title: One neat trick turns WeWork into a winner
summary: SoftBank chairman Masayoshi Son has restructured his deal with WeWork by classifying the co-working space operator as an associate instead of a subsidiary, avoiding WeWork's $22 billion debt and allowing SoftBank to benefit from WeWork's net assets. SoftBank will increase its stake to 80% and Marcelo Claure will become executive chairman of WeWork's board, with voting control over founder Adam Neumann's shares. This move allows SoftBank to avoid consolidating WeWork into its financial statements and reduces its exposure to WeWork's operating losses.

site_title: Investors pile into SembMarine, seeing it as a proxy play on Keppel
summary: Investors are flocking to SembCorp Marine (SembMarine), a proxy for conglomerate Keppel Corp, after Temasek's partial offer to take its stake in Keppel to 51% was announced. SembMarine's stock surged 5.2% and closed 3.7% higher, reaching a three-month high. Analysts predict a potential restructuring of the business through an amalgamation with Keppel Offshore Marine, potentially benefiting SembMarine in the long term. However, some analysts caution that SembMarine faces headwinds in the next quarter due to a lack of order flow.

site_title: Wing Tai's Q1 net profit more than triples to S$6.8m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' net profit more than tripled to S$6.8 million for Q1, driven by a 20% reduction in cost of sales and higher profits from associates and joint ventures. Revenue increased 2% to S$79.3 million, with Le Nouvel Ardmore contributing significantly. The group's share price ended 1% lower at S$2.05 following the financial results release.

site_title: ST Engineering to pay customer US$15.9m net in arbitration case
summary: ST Engineering's US marine subsidiary, VT Halter Marine, will pay a customer US$18 million following arbitration proceedings. The payment is related to a 2011 deal for vessel design and construction. As a result, ST Engineering will make an adjusting subsequent event provision of about S$14.2 million in its financial statements.

site_title: San Teh cash offer to delist extended to Nov 7
summary: San Teh Real Estate, a Singaporean property development and investment company, has extended its voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire 90% of its shares to November 7. The offer, valued at S$0.28 per share, was initially set to close on October 24. The company's shares ended at S$0.275 on Wednesday, down 0.5 cents or 1.79%. The extension aims to garner the required 90% stake to delist the company from the mainboard.

site_title: Two Kampong Glam shophouses being sold
summary: A South Korean party has acquired two historic shophouses in Singapore's Kampong Glam for a total of S$29 million. The properties, 11 Bali Lane and 241 Beach Road, house the Blu Jaz Cafe and Piedra Negra Mexican Bar and Restaurant, respectively. Both shophouses are on 999-year leasehold sites and have sold for S$18.8m and S$10.2m, translating to S$4,000 and S$3,200 per square foot, respectively.

site_title: Thai king fires palace officials for 'extremely evil' conduct
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn has dismissed six palace officials for "extremely evil" conduct, according to palace announcements. The officials, including a woman, a senior police official, and two royal guards, were fired and stripped of their official ranks for severe disciplinary misconduct. This comes days after the sacking of the king's royal consort, Sineenat Wongvajirapakdi, who was accused of being "disloyal" and conducting a rivalry with Queen Suthida Bajrasudhabimalalakshana. The dismissals are part of the king's assertive rule, which has taken direct control of royal affairs and the crown's vast wealth.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom tries for the big leagues with Euro 2024 rights
summary: Deutsche Telekom AG acquired the rights to broadcast Euro 2024 soccer championship in Germany, aiming to boost its MagentaTV service with exclusive sports content. The company will show all 51 games via its TV and streaming platforms, displacing public broadcasters ARD and ZDF. Although ARD and ZDF will air next year's installment, there's hope for them to get some 2024 games through sub-licensing. This move is part of Deutsche Telekom's strategy to increase subscribers and viewership, particularly with the high-profile Euro tournament.

site_title: Purpose is the linchpin of corporate strategy
summary: A company's purpose is a critical driver of growth, profitability, and organisational relevance. Research by IMD Business School found that purpose plays two key strategic roles: redefining the playing field and reshaping the value proposition. Companies like Mars Petcare, Neste, and Mahindra Finance have successfully used purpose to drive growth and transformation. Purpose-driven strategy involves responding to trends, building on trust, and focusing on pain points. Companies must ask why they exist, what impact they have on society, and why people want to work for them. By putting purpose at the core of corporate strategy, businesses can create a compelling narrative, unify the organisation, motivate stakeholders, and drive wide-ranging impact.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings Q1 net profit rises threefold to S$6.8m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' net profit more than tripled to S$6.8 million for the first quarter, driven by a 20% reduction in cost of sales and higher profits from associates and joint ventures. Revenue was 2% higher at S$79.3 million, mainly due to the sale of additional units in Le Nouvel Ardmore. The company's cash and cash equivalents declined 75.2% to S$211.9 million, but net asset value per share improved marginally to S$4.20.

site_title: Rumours swirl on possible candidates to succeed Carrie Lam as Hong Kong leader
summary: Speculation surrounds Carrie Lam's potential succession as Hong Kong leader, with protesters demanding systematic change to nominate and elect leaders. Beijing denies the report, calling it a "political rumour with ulterior motives." Lam's departure could occur by March 2020, amid ongoing protests and calls for reform.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX flight control system key factor in Lion Air crash
summary: Indonesian investigators have concluded that a faulty Boeing 737 MAX flight control system, specifically the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), was a contributing factor in the Lion Air crash that killed all 189 people on board. The system's reliance on a single sensor and lack of guidance for pilots were key issues. Despite some relatives expressing frustration that investigators will not assign blame to Boeing or Lion Air, the report is expected to be released on Friday.

images.alt_text: Mechanical and design problems with a Boeing 737 MAX flight control system were key factors in the crash of a Lion Air jet last year, Indonesian investigators told victims' families in a briefing on their findings Wednesday.

site_title: China expected to lead race to exploit deep sea minerals
summary: China is likely to become the first country to start mining seabed minerals, such as nickel, copper, and cobalt, if international rules are approved by July 2020. The International Seabed Authority has signed 30 contracts with governments and entities for exploration, with China holding five contracts. The demand for these minerals drives the quest for seabed mining, mainly for smartphones and electric car batteries. China's interest in seabed mining is driven by its enormous mineral demand and increasing market. The ISA aims to adopt exploitation rules, but agreement on financial payments is still pending.

site_title: HDB annual deficit grows to S$1.98b
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) reported a financial year-end deficit of S$1.98 billion, largely due to a gross loss on flat sales, disbursement of CPF grants, and development losses. This is a significant increase from the previous year's deficit of S$532 million. Despite this, HDB chairman Bobby Chin remains optimistic, citing a stable public residential market and a healthy take-up rate for new flats. The Ministry of Finance will provide a S$2.03 billion grant to cover the deficit, and HDB aims to innovate and harness technology to deliver quality homes for Singaporeans.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.30 points to 1,568.79. Losers outnumbered gainers 442 to 363, with a total of 2.6 billion lots traded worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Helping ideas set sail
summary: The Pro-Enterprise Panel (PEP) in Singapore helps entrepreneurs navigate regulations and connects them with the right authorities, facilitating the approval of innovative ideas. The PEP's role was instrumental in the approval of Marina Bay's "doughnut boat" dining cruises, and a microbrewery licence was also simplified for Binjai Brew. A new container hotel at startup cluster JTC Launchpad @ one-north is set to open, offering investors a chance to immerse themselves in the ecosystem. The PEP's efforts aim to lower entry barriers and encourage entrepreneurship, with plans to extend its concept to other licences.

images.alt_text: Miriam Becker, founder of Floating Donut.
Seah Liang Chiang, founder of an upcoming container hotel.
(L to R) Binjai Brew's Heetesh Alwani and Rahul Immandira.

site_title: Peugeot maker PSA weathers industry slump
summary: PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot cars, weathered a slump in the vehicle industry in the third quarter by introducing revamped models and maintaining a "strict" pricing policy. Revenue grew 1% from a year earlier, beating analysts' estimates, while automotive revenue remained stable. Despite flat sales in Europe, PSA gained market share, and the company stuck to its target of generating an automotive recurring operating margin above 4.5% on average for 2019-2021. However, the company cut its market outlook for Russia and predicted a decline in total vehicle sales to 2.58 million units in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Wall St opens mixed as Boeing offsets weak earnings reports
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, with Boeing rising 0.18% after reaffirming the 737 MAX return to service timeline, offsetting losses from Caterpillar and Texas Instruments. The Dow Jones rose 47.14 points to 26,835.24, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.07% and 0.17% respectively.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q3 DPU falls 5.1% on enlarged unit base
summary: Suntec Reit's Q3 DPU fell 5.1% to 2.365 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base resulting from a S$200 million private placement in May. This was compared to 2.491 cents in the same period in 2018. The decline was primarily caused by the increased number of units, rather than a decrease in earnings.

site_title: Third launch for Katong Plaza collective sale
summary: The collective sale for Katong Plaza in Singapore has been launched for the third time via public tender at S$188 million, translating to a land rate of S$1,947 per square foot (psf). This is the second en bloc exercise for the mall, following an outline planning permission for hotel use granted by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA).

site_title: WeWork will 'transform' SoftBank headquarters, Claure says
summary: WeWork will revamp SoftBank Group Corp's headquarters in Tokyo and potentially undertake similar projects globally, according to newly appointed Executive Chairman Marcelo Claure. Claure stated that WeWork will "transform" the SoftBank headquarters, citing the company's success in reimagining the Sprint Corp headquarters. SoftBank now controls 80% of WeWork after a $9.5 billion bailout, and Claure acknowledged layoffs will occur. Claure expressed confidence in WeWork's ability to make a successful comeback, despite challenges ahead.

site_title: Hyflux group EVP, CFO Lim Suat Wah to take sabbatical leave
summary: Hyflux announced that EVP and CFO Lim Suat Wah will take sabbatical leave from Nov 8, citing personal family commitments. This comes as the water treatment firm is restructuring and struggling with debt, with a debt moratorium in place until Dec 2. Hyflux has appointed Agnes Tan to assume full responsibility for finance matters, amid efforts to find a white knight investor to bail out the company.

site_title: WeWork staff, facing job cuts, express outrage at founder's payout
summary: WeWork's founder Adam Neumann will receive up to $1.2 billion from SoftBank Group Corp as part of a $6.5 billion bailout deal. The deal will secure an 80% stake in the company and allow Neumann to step down as chairman. However, many former employees are outraged at the payout, citing the company's financial struggles and impending job cuts. Employees expressed indignation, calling the deal an "injustice" and criticizing Neumann's "platinum parachute".

site_title: Rotimatic maker doughs out losses, burns through its cash reserves
summary: Zimplistic, the Singapore-based startup behind the automated kitchen appliance Rotimatic, reported losses of US$23.6 million in 2019 despite revenue of US$21.2 million. The company's cash reserves dwindled to US$6.8 million at the end of 2018, and it raised US$7.7 million in preference shares in July 2019 to extend its cash flow. Zimplistic's CEO, Rishi Israni, attributed the losses to high manufacturing costs and a significant increase in administrative expenses, including salaries. Market watchers question the sustainability of Rotimatic's single-product offering model, citing competition from cheaper alternatives.

site_title: Sengkang Grand Residences units to start from S$798,000
summary: CapitaLand and City Developments (CDL) announced the unit prices for Sengkang Grand Residences, starting from S$798,000 for a one-bedroom plus study unit. The integrated development features 680 units, a retail mall, community amenities, and a bus interchange. Unit prices range from S$798,000 to S$2.1 million. The development is a joint venture between CapitaLand and CDL, with a preview for sales gallery starting October 25 and bookings beginning on November 2.

site_title: Sri Lanka parliament blames president for Easter attack lapses
summary: A Sri Lankan parliamentary report blames President Maithripala Sirisena for "actively undermining" national security and failing to prevent the Easter Sunday bombings that killed 269 people. The report criticizes Sirisena for excluding the police chief from crucial meetings, failing to act on advance intelligence warnings, and undermining the country's security systems. The report also holds Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and Deputy Defence Minister Ruwan Wijewardene accountable for their roles in the lapses. The report's findings can form the basis of criminal prosecutions or civil action against those identified as responsible for the lapses.

site_title: ST Engineering to pay US$18m to customer in US arbitration proceedings
summary: ST Engineering's US marine subsidiary, VT Halter Marine, has been ordered to pay US$18 million to customer Hornbeck Offshore Services following arbitration proceedings. The payment resolves a 2011 vessel construction dispute, with VT Halter Marine initially claiming US$2.4 million against Hornbeck. The net amount payable to Hornbeck is US$15.9 million, with ST Engineering making a further provision of S$14.2 million in the financial statements. The arbitration award is not expected to significantly impact ST Engineering's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Honda speeds up plans to electrify car models in Europe
summary: Honda accelerates plans to electrify European car models by 2022, with all new models expected to have electric options, following the closure of its UK-based Swindon plant in 2021. The company's latest hybrid model, the Jazz, will be available in Europe by mid-2020. Honda's European senior vice president, Tom Gardner, stated that the rapid electrification of Europe is a key part of the company's business strategy, with the new models being built in Japan and imported to Europe.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end with deep losses
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.82% to 26,566.73, amid concerns over China's possible plan to remove Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam. The sell-off was part of an Asia-wide market downturn. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The decline follows months of protests in Hong Kong.

site_title: Boeing profit slumps 53% as MAX grounding takes heavy toll
summary: Boeing reported a 53% drop in third-quarter profit due to the continued grounding of its 737 MAX, resulting in a negative free cash flow of $2.89 billion. The company cut production of its Dreamliner and delayed the entry of its 777X twin-aisle, citing the MAX crisis and industrial setbacks. Boeing shares rose slightly, and CEO Dennis Muilenburg's title of board chairman was stripped earlier this month. The company still expects the MAX to return to service in the fourth quarter, but faces significant challenges in recovering from the crisis.

site_title: Wild Hong Kong IPO turns 188% gain to loss in less than an hour
summary: Investors in Snack Empire Holdings' Hong Kong IPO witnessed a rapid 188% gain before the shares plummeted into a loss 45 minutes later. The IPO's retail portion was almost 14 times subscribed, following a trend of outsized gains by small-cap IPOs in the city this month. Speculators are piling into IPOs due to market uncertainty, with the Hang Seng Index falling 12% since its April high.

site_title: Tencent, NUS to launch cloud-focused incubator programme for Singapore startups
summary: Tencent Holdings and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have partnered to launch a cloud-focused incubator programme for Singapore startups. The three-year programme will provide cloud solutions, technical support, and training to up to 20 selected startups, with Tencent offering marketing support and access to its AI lab. The programme aims to support entrepreneurs and incubate startups in Singapore, leveraging Tencent's cloud products and expertise across various sectors, including finance, telecommunications, and online gaming.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives: Imitation is flattery, but results may vary
summary: Kingsmen Creatives, a Singapore-based exhibition display builder, has launched its first Nerf family entertainment centre at Marina Square, with encouraging ticket sales. The company aims to replicate Cityneon's success by adopting a sub-licensing model, where it partners with a local operator to manage risk and revenue. Kingsmen has secured exclusive rights to the Nerf brand in China and plans to expand to the US in 2021. However, the company faces challenges, including high employee benefits costs and a declining earnings base, which may impact its bottom line.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares firm on stable yen ahead of earnings season
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.34% on Wednesday, driven by the yen's stability against the dollar ahead of Japanese earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index ended at 22,625.38, while the Topix index rose 0.59%. Investors remained cautious before quarterly earnings reports from Japanese businesses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: PropertyGuru scraps its Australian IPO plan due to market uncertainty. Singapore's September core inflation fell to 0.7% and the IMF cut its growth forecast for the country to 0.5% in 2019. The Straits Times Index dropped 0.5% due to Brexit worries and tech sell-offs. Tencent and NUS will launch a cloud-focused incubator program for Singapore startups.

images.alt_text: The withdrawal is due to uncertainty in the current IPO market, despite "strong investor support" from a number of global and Australian investors, PropertyGuru's board announced on Wednesday.

site_title: London stocks, pound steady on new Brexit delay
summary: London's stock market opened flat at 7,210.84 points, mirroring the stability of the pound against the dollar and euro. The EU is set to grant a further Brexit extension after British MPs rejected Prime Minister Boris Johnson's bid to pass his divorce deal. The FTSE 100 index and sterling remain steady, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices dropped 0.4% and 0.7% respectively.

images.alt_text: The capital's benchmark FTSE 100 index opened flat at 7,210.84 points, mirroring sterling's steadiness.

site_title: CapitaLand, CDL price Sengkang Grand Residences units from S$798,000
summary: CapitaLand and City Developments (CDL) have announced the unit prices for Sengkang Grand Residences, starting from S$798,000 for a one-bedroom plus study unit. The integrated development comprises 680 units across nine blocks, with unit sizes ranging from 474 sq ft to 1,324 sq ft. Unit prices increase with unit size, ranging from S$998,000 for a two-bedroom unit to S$2.1 million for a four-bedroom premium plus flexi unit.

site_title: South Korean stocks drop on Brexit anxiety, profit-taking
summary: South Korean stocks dropped on Wednesday due to renewed uncertainty over Brexit, leading to profit-taking by investors. The KOSPI index ended down 0.39% at 2,080.62 points, snapping a two-session gain streak. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that the EU should decide on Brexit delays, making ratification of the deal by the October 31 deadline nearly impossible. Foreigners bought US$52.55 million worth of shares, while domestic investors booked profits after a 1% rise in the previous session.

site_title: China to boost imports of goods including farm products
summary: China has announced plans to boost imports of certain goods, including agricultural and consumer products, as part of efforts to stabilize foreign trade. The State Council has also decided to improve policies on tax rebates, trade finance, and insurance, and ease restrictions on capital account transactions. The move aims to support trade and foreign investment, with steps including allowing foreign firms to conduct domestic equity investment and banks to make cross-border transfers of bad loans. This comes as China's economy is expected to slow, with GDP growth predicted to reach a 30-year low of 6.2% this year.

images.alt_text: China will boost imports of certain goods including agricultural, consumer and components products as part of its efforts to stabilise foreign trade, Chinese state television said on Wednesday, citing the Cabinet.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% on Brexit worries, global tech concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.5% on Wednesday, closing at 3,144.28, amid Brexit worries and concerns over the global tech sector. The index was influenced by a weak revenue forecast from US semiconductor giant Texas Instruments and profit-taking after an early-week rally. Decliners outpaced gainers 206 to 175, with 20 of the blue-chip index's 30 counters ending in the red.

site_title: Tencent shares risk losing support level as losses accelerate
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd shares fell 2.1% in Hong Kong, approaching a key support level of HK$320, after no apparent trigger. Theories include souring sentiment in China and concerns over airing NBA games. The stock briefly fell below HK$320, but recovered to HK$320.60. Holding above HK$320 is crucial, as smaller bounces suggest the support level is at risk of breaking.

site_title: Huawei launches foldable phone in China
summary: Huawei launched its foldable 5G Mate X smartphone in China, starting presales on October 23, 2019. The device was originally set for a June launch but was delayed for certification tests with carriers. Huawei reported selling over 200 million phones in 2019, 64 days ahead of the same period in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia's tallest tower opens its doors
summary: Malaysia's tallest skyscraper, Exchange 106, is set to open its doors in December, marking a new beginning for the country's real estate market after the 1MDB scandal. The 492-meter tower, developed by Mulia Group, is part of the Tun Razak Exchange (TRX) financial district, which has been "detoxified" of 1MDB's taint. With 1.3 million square feet of rental space expected to be occupied, the project aims to revitalize Kuala Lumpur's oversupplied property market and capitalize on the TRX's future potential.

site_title: Hong Kong says Taiwan obstructing murder suspect case for political reasons
summary: Hong Kong officials claim Taiwan is obstructing a murder suspect case for political reasons, after Chan Tong-kai walked free from jail. Chan was accused of murdering his girlfriend in Taiwan. The Hong Kong government is squabbling with Taiwan over how to handle Chan's voluntary surrender. Taiwan denies any obstruction and says it is following its own laws.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to ongoing uncertainty over Brexit. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.05%, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.08%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.10%.

site_title: Lebanon's most senior Christian cleric steps into crisis
summary: Lebanon's Maronite Patriarch Bechara Boutros Al-Rai has called for a change in government to include qualified technocrats, urging President Michel Aoun to begin talks with protesters demanding reforms. The patriarch welcomed Prime Minister Saad al-Hariri's announced emergency reform package but emphasized the need for replacing current ministers with national, qualified figures. The protests, which have blocked roads and shut down banks and schools, have been ongoing for a seventh day, with demonstrators demanding an interim government and early elections.

images.alt_text: Lebanon's highest Christian authority called on Wednesday for a change in government to include qualified technocrats and urged the president to begin talks to address demands of demonstrators in the streets for a seventh day.

site_title: Hong Kong extradition bill officially killed, but move unlikely to end unrest
summary: Hong Kong's legislature formally withdrew the planned extradition bill to mainland China, but it's unlikely to end the months of unrest. The move meets only one of five demands by pro-democracy protesters, who continue to call for universal suffrage, an amnesty, and the leader's resignation. The extradition bill was seen as a move by Beijing to erode Hong Kong's freedoms, but its withdrawal has been met with skepticism by protesters, who claim it's "too little, too late."

site_title: Boris Johnson eyes election after parliament forces Brexit delay
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson is likely to call an election after Parliament blocked his plan to rush his Brexit deal into UK law. A day of threats and promises from Johnson ended with an official warning that if the EU agrees to delay Brexit, Johnson would instead seek an election. This comes after European Council President Donald Tusk signaled the EU's likely response. Johnson has the votes to pass his Brexit deal but may put it on hold in favor of securing a parliamentary majority.

site_title: Cocoa prices in Cameroon go up as bean quality improves
summary: Cocoa prices in Cameroon have risen sharply this season due to improved bean quality. Farmers are selling ordinary quality beans for 1,050 CFA francs (S$2.43) per kilogram and premium quality beans for 1,650 CFA francs. This marks a significant increase from last season's prices. The government's efforts to improve fermentation and drying techniques have contributed to the improvement in quality. The price increase may benefit French chocolate makers, who are already purchasing high-quality beans at 1,650 CFA francs per kilogram.

images.alt_text: Cocoa farmers are selling their beans for 1,050 CFA francs(S$2.43) per kilogram for ordinary quality and 1,650 for premium quality, up from between 800 and 900 CFA francs last season.

site_title: Google claims 'quantum supremacy'; others say hold on a qubit
summary: Google claims to have achieved "quantum supremacy" by solving a complex problem in 3 minutes and 20 seconds using a quantum computer, whereas the world's most powerful supercomputer would take 10,000 years to solve it. The breakthrough was announced in a paper published in Nature, after weeks of controversy. Google's quantum computer, Sycamore, packs 54 qubits and was able to interact in a quantum state, demonstrating exponential speedup over classical computers. However, rivals at IBM say Google's achievement is overhyped, and quantum computers will not replace classical ones but rather work in concert with them.

site_title: Australia shares end flat as healthcare hurts, utilities batter NZ
summary: Australian shares ended flat, with the S&P/ASX 200 index remaining unchanged at 6,673.10 points, after healthcare firms fell 0.4% and miners offset gains. New Zealand's market was hit by steep losses for energy stocks following Rio Tinto's announcement to shut a smelter, causing the benchmark NZX 50 index to drop.

site_title: COEs end mixed
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices ended mixed in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp priced at $32,309, down from $34,001. COE for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at $41,805, while open COE for any vehicle type ended at $42,020. The mixed results come ahead of the next, slightly smaller quota kicking in next month.

site_title: Pound, Asian markets slip as Johnson Brexit bid fails again
summary: The British pound slumped to a low of US$1.2843 after Boris Johnson's Brexit deal failed to pass in a truncated debate, potentially delaying the UK's departure from the EU. The failure means a general election before the end of the year is now likely, and EU chiefs are expected to recommend another extension to the withdrawal date. Asian markets also fell, with the Shanghai and Sydney indexes down 0.1% and 0.2% respectively, as investors took a step back after recent gains.

site_title: Hot stock: SembMarine shares hit 3-month high, up 3% at midday break
