summary: SembCorp Marine shares reached a three-month high, increasing by 3% at midday break, amid speculation that the company may also receive a partial offer similar to Keppel Corp's recent stake acquisition. The move follows Temasek's partial offer for Keppel Corp, which has fueled hopes of similar offers for other local proxies. Analysts note that SembMarine's surge could be positive for the long term, but also caution that the company faces earnings headwinds in the next quarter.

site_title: Malaysia privately discusses Goldman penalty of just US$2b over 1MDB
summary: Malaysia is privately discussing a settlement with Goldman Sachs over its role in the 1MDB scandal, with figures ranging from $2 billion to $3 billion, significantly lower than the $7.5 billion demanded. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad aims to reach an accord before year-end to show progress on his pledge to recoup money plundered from the scandal. However, US prosecutors may not give Goldman credit for a costly deal, and it's unclear whether a settlement would lead to charges against the bank and its executives being dropped.

site_title: Australia: Healthcare stocks lead market slip, energy retailers pull New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Wednesday, with healthcare stocks leading the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 21.50 points to 6,650.70. The decline was partly due to investors locking in profits in the healthcare sector. Meanwhile, US stocks fell after British lawmakers rejected a Brexit timeline, raising concerns about the global economy.

site_title: North Korea's Kim orders demolition of South-built resort
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has ordered the demolition of the Mount Kumgang tourist complex, built by Hyundai Asan on a South Korean mountain. The complex, which drew hundreds of thousands of Southern visitors, was closed in 2008 after a North Korean soldier shot a Southern tourist. The move is seen as a stark illustration of dire relations between North and South Korea. This comes after years of tensions and no significant progress in reconciliation efforts between the two nations.

site_title: Trump and Ukraine: the case for impeachment grows
summary: US President Donald Trump's case for impeachment grew stronger as top diplomat Bill Taylor testified that the White House withheld military aid to Ukraine for domestic political reasons. Trump allegedly pressured Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden and his son's business dealings. The testimony, supported by other officials, suggests Trump abused his power, violated election laws, and obstructed a congressional investigation. The mounting evidence could support multiple impeachment charges against Trump.

images.alt_text: Democratic lawmakers' case for impeaching US President Donald Trump grew stronger on Tuesday when the top US diplomat in Ukraine testified that the White House withheld assistance to Kiev "for domestic political reasons."

site_title: Bangkok residential market softening but other sectors remain resilient: Edmund Tie Research
summary: The Bangkok residential market is softening, with only 6,562 condominium units launched in Q3, down 51.6% from Q2. In contrast, commercial and retail space saw a 1.1% increase in total investment sales volume, with the largest deal valued at THB4.3 billion. The office sector remains resilient, with occupancy rates expected to hold firm in Q4 and supply outpacing demand in the next few years. Retail occupancy is also expected to perform better in Q4, driven by newly completed malls.

images.alt_text: While Bangkok's residential market appears to be softening, with shrinking launches and take-up rates, other sectors remained resilient.

site_title: Indonesia Cabinet unveiled, includes president's main rival
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled his second-term Cabinet, retaining Sri Mulyani Indrawati as finance minister and appointing Prabowo Subianto, his main rival, as defence minister. The Cabinet includes 17 technocrats and 17 politicians, with the majority having ties to political parties. Widodo's move is seen as a bid to push through reforms and boost growth, despite controversy surrounding Prabowo's inclusion. The Cabinet's composition is being closely watched, with some analysts warning that party representatives may hinder the president's reform campaign.

site_title: Nike's tech ambitions on full display in its pick of ex-eBay CEO
summary: Nike Inc has appointed former eBay CEO John Donahoe as its new CEO, replacing Mark Parker, in a move to emphasize the company's tech ambitions. Donahoe, 59, will take over on January 13, and will focus on expanding Nike's digital presence, with the goal of increasing online sales to 30% of total sales. The move comes after a shake-up at Nike, including the departure of former CEO candidate Trevor Edwards amid a review of sexist behavior. Donahoe brings extensive tech experience, having previously served as president and CEO of ServiceNow and chairman of PayPal.

site_title: Malaysia's Sept CPI rises 1.1% y-o-y, slows from August and misses forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index rose 1.1% in September from a year earlier, slowing from the previous month and missing forecast. The annual inflation rate was below the 1.4% increase predicted by economists. Inflation was higher in nine sectors, particularly food and beverages. The country's inflation has remained mild since a consumption tax was scrapped in 2018, but Bank Negara Malaysia expects headline inflation to average higher in the second half of the year. This is a departure from the May interest rate cut due to low inflation and slowing growth.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to lead US$1.5b ESR Cayman's Hong Kong IPO relaunch: sources
summary: Morgan Stanley has led the relaunch of ESR Cayman's US$1.45 billion Hong Kong IPO, a significant shift from its initial role in the failed June attempt. Morgan Stanley, along with Deutsche Bank, retained their official roles as sponsors, while Citigroup and CLSA were dropped to bookrunner roles. The relaunched deal aims to sell shares worth up to US$1.45 billion, giving ESR a market capitalization of up to US$6.74 billion. The decision marks a rare instance of a bank not working on a deal initially taking a senior role.

site_title: TUV SUD partners NUS to promote R&D in 3D-printed biomedical implants
summary: German testing and certification company TUV SUD partnered with the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Additive Manufacturing to promote research and development in 3D-printed biomedical implants. The centre aims to apply 3D-printing in personalized patient treatments and fabricate metal implants for clinical trials, meeting global standards. This partnership comes as additive manufacturing technologies reduce production time and costs, and Singapore is introducing standards to guide the development and adoption of such technologies.

site_title: PropertyGuru scraps Australian IPO plan on 'market uncertainty'
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian property technology firm, has scrapped its proposed initial public offering (IPO) on the Australia Securities Exchange (ASX) due to market uncertainty. Despite strong investor support, investor demand was at the lower end of the price range, and the company does not require new funds to fund its current operations. The decision was made by the company's board, citing current IPO market sentiment. The company remains positive about its performance and has access to existing shareholders and private capital markets.

site_title: Deutsche Bank Wealth Mgt names new head of global products & solutions for EM
summary: Deutsche Bank Wealth Management has appointed Rajesh Mahadevan as its new head of global products and solutions for emerging markets, effective January 2020. Based in Singapore, Mahadevan will focus on expanding product capabilities in Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, and Africa. He brings experience from previous roles at Bank of America and Citigroup, and will work to accelerate growth plans, including introducing innovative investment solutions and enhancing the bank's environmental, social, and governance strategy. This move follows the recent appointment of Sam Descovich as head of GPS in the Americas.

site_title: September core inflation at new 3-year low; MAS may go down 'zero-slope' next, say analysts
summary: Singapore's September core inflation eased to 0.7%, the lowest since March 2016, with headline inflation remaining unchanged at 0.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may consider a "zero-slope" monetary policy next year, according to analysts, despite a slowdown in inflationary pressures. The MAS reiterated its forecast for core inflation to average 0.5-1.5% in 2020, but some analysts predict milder inflation due to weak global and domestic price pressures.

images.alt_text: Consumer price increases stayed largely flat in September, a week after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) moved to ease monetary policy on the back of subdued inflation.

site_title: IMF cuts Singapore growth forecast to 0.5% in 2019
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its growth forecast for Singapore to 0.5% in 2019, down from 2% earlier, due to strong export headwinds and the electronics downturn. The IMF also lowered its growth projection for Asia to 5% in 2019 and 5.1% in 2020. This represents the slowest pace of expansion for Asia since the global financial crisis a decade ago. The IMF projects Singapore's growth to moderate to 4.6% in 2019 and 4.8% in 2020.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Wednesday cut its growth projection for Singapore to 0.5 per cent in 2019, down from an earlier estimate of 2 per cent in July, due to strong export headwinds and the downturn in electronics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.14 points to 1,571.95 at 9am. Volume was 61.99 million lots worth RM22.29 million. Gainers beat losers 111 to 49.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI edges down 0.02% to 3,160.02
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging down 0.02% to 3,160.02. The STI had mixed corporate earnings, with gains outnumbering losses 63 to 46. Key movers included Golden Agri-Resources, SunMoon Food Company, and Mapletree Logistics Trust. Globally, US stocks declined, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 falling 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively, while European stocks remained almost flat.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CCT, FCT, Suntec Reit, MLT, MIT, Kimly, Addvalue
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Wednesday, with key companies reporting DPU and revenue growth. CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) and Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported unchanged DPU, while Suntec Reit's DPU fell 5.1%. Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) raised S$250 million through an overnight placement, and Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) posted a higher DPU of 3.13 cents due to new revenue contributions. Kimly plans to acquire several coffee shops for S$59 million, and Addvalue Technologies' subsidiary delivered a flight model of its inter-satellite data relay system.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,138.41, down 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,138.41, down 0.7% on the day, with the Straits Times Index losing 22.26 points. Decliners outnumbered advancers 189 to 114, with Sembcorp Marine gaining 3.7% and DBS slipping 0.4%. Financials also faltered, with OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank dropping 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. The STI remains below pre-Brexit levels, with investors monitoring geopolitical developments and mixed US earnings.

site_title: MLT private placement over 13 times subscribed at S$1.617 per unit
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) announced a private placement, which was over 13 times subscribed, with an issue price of S$1.617 per unit. The trust raised approximately S$250 million from the sale of 154.6 million units, primarily to fund the acquisition of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China. The remaining amount will be used for professional fees and expenses. Trading of the new units is expected to start on November 1, and MLT will make a formal application to the Singapore Exchange for the listing, dealing, and quotation of the new units.

site_title: Indonesia's Jokowi set to announce new cabinet
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is set to announce a new cabinet, which may include his election rival Prabowo Subianto as defense minister, despite human rights concerns. Subianto, a former military general accused of rights violations, hinted at a potential job in the defense sector. Other expected appointments include Sri Mulyani Indrawati as finance minister and Nadiem Makarim, co-founder of ride-hailing startup Gojek, in an unspecified ministerial post. Media mogul Erick Thohir is also expected to land a cabinet job.

site_title: US House approves bill exposing shell company owners
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a bill, known as the Bipartisan Corporate Transparency Act, which would expose the owners of shell companies to help curb money laundering and other crimes. The bill requires corporations and limited liability companies to report the names of owners and those with a large financial stake, aiding law enforcement in detecting and preventing crimes. The measure was approved by a 249-173 vote and now goes to the Senate, where its fate is unclear.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust posts 1.8% rise in Q4 DPU to 2.913 S cents
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 1.8% rise in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.913 Singapore cents, driven by higher portfolio occupancy and contributions. Gross revenue decreased 0.5% to S$48.3 million, while net property income (NPI) edged down 0.1%. For the full year, DPU rose 12.07 cents and income available for distribution grew 6.6%. FCT's portfolio occupancy increased to 96.5% and shopper traffic rose 8.9% year-on-year. The trust plans to focus on improving property performance in Singapore and the suburban retail sector for the next few years.

site_title: Tesla's futuristic door handles blamed for death in fiery wreck
summary: A fatal car crash in Florida has blamed Tesla's futuristic door handles for the death of a 48-year-old anesthesiologist. Omar Awan lost control of his leased Model S, crashing into a palm tree, and the police officer couldn't open the doors due to the retracted handles. The car's battery allegedly caused a fire that killed Awan from smoke inhalation. This is not the first case to fault Tesla's lithium-ion batteries as flammable, with another family suing over a 2019 crash that killed an 18-year-old.

site_title: Digitalisation key to ASEAN attracting China trade war exodus
summary: ASEAN's manufacturing economy faces significant challenges from the Sino-US trade war, prompting companies to relocate production from China. Digitalisation is key to attracting these companies, with Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam among early beneficiaries. The shift is mainly in parts and electronic components for automobiles and consumer electronics, strategic industries that will benefit from technological change. ASEAN must adopt new technologies to remain competitive and benefit from global realignments, shifting beyond low-cost labor for a competitive advantage.

site_title: Boeing replaces head of commercial plane division amid 737 Max crisis
summary: Boeing replaced Kevin McAllister, head of its commercial plane division, effective immediately, amid the ongoing 737 Max crisis. McAllister will be replaced by Stan Deal, who is currently chief of Boeing Global Services. The move comes seven months after the grounding of the 737 Max, which has significantly impacted the company.

site_title: Lion Air families to meet Indonesia safety agency ahead of report
summary: Families of Lion Air victims are set to meet Indonesia's safety agency to receive a final report on the 2018 crash that killed 189 people. The report, expected to be released within days, will provide insight into the cause of the disaster. The Lion Air crash occurred shortly after takeoff from Jakarta in October 2018, and the Boeing 737 Max model was grounded worldwide following a similar crash in Ethiopia in March 2018. The meeting comes after a thorough investigation into the incident.

images.alt_text: Families of those killed when a Lion Air plane crashed off Indonesia last year are expected to meet safety regulators on Wednesday to be briefed on a final report into the disaster that could be released within days.

site_title: Jewellers already nostalgic for the end of pink diamonds
summary: The world's largest producer of pink diamonds, Rio Tinto's Argyle mine in Western Australia, is set to close at the end of 2020, leaving only 150 carats of polished pink diamonds. Industry experts predict a surge in demand and prices for the rare stones, which have risen 300% in the past decade. The closure of the mine may kick-start prices, with some predicting a massive increase in value. Lab-grown pink diamonds are also becoming more accessible, but natural stones remain rare and highly prized, with some selling for over $1 million per carat.

site_title: ExxonMobil trial likely to star Rex Tillerson begins
summary: ExxonMobil's trial over alleged misleading investors about climate change risks began, with former US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson expected to testify. The lawsuit, filed by the New York attorney general, claims Exxon defrauded investors by downplaying the costs of climate change mitigation policies. Exxon's internal projections showed less severe risks to avoid negatively impacting profitability forecasts, allegedly leading to overvalued shares worth $416 million to $1.16 billion. The trial is seen as historic and may impact how large energy companies communicate their climate risk.

images.alt_text: Did ExxonMobil mislead investors about the financial risks of climate change? That's the charge in an unprecedented trial against the oil and gas giant that got underway on Tuesday and is likely to feature testimony by Rex Tillerson.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars backtrack on Brexit woes, resistance intact
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars retreated from major resistance levels due to the Brexit saga's latest twist, tempering global risk appetites. The Aussie eased to US$0.6855 and the kiwi dollar backtracked to US$0.6409. The uncertainty surrounding the Brexit extension, which could last from a few days to three months, contributed to the currency fluctuations. Analysts expect potential Brexit twists ahead, with the Aussie and kiwi dollars having room to move higher.

site_title: Samsung heir's corruption retrial hangs over phonemaker
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong is set to return to court for a retrial over a corruption scandal, potentially leading to a prison sentence and impact on the company's leadership. Lee, 51, was previously jailed for five years for bribery, embezzlement, and other crimes in 2017, but a retrial was ordered by the Supreme Court after an appeals court's decision was overturned. This could deprive Samsung Electronics, the world's largest smartphone manufacturer, of its top decision-maker, amid declining profits.

site_title: Hover-taxi whizzes over Singapore, firm eyes Asian push
summary: A German firm, Volocopter, successfully tested a drone-like flying taxi in Singapore, with a pilot onboard for safety. The two-seater, battery-operated vehicle flew for 2 minutes and 30 seconds around Marina Bay, marking the company's first test in a city center. Volocopter aims to introduce the service in traffic-clogged Asian cities, including Jakarta, Manila, and Bangkok, with a commercial rollout expected in 2-4 years. The flying taxi is seen as a solution to monster traffic jams in these cities, with a potential expansion to India and China.

site_title: UBS adds US$16b from rich clients as assets hit record
summary: UBS Group AG reported a record US$2.5 trillion in assets overseen by its affluent clients, with US$15.7 billion in new money added in the last quarter. The influx boosted the wealth management unit, led by star hire Iqbal Khan, and lifted long-term net inflows to US$24.1 billion. Despite beating analyst estimates, UBS warned of a US$100 million charge to restructure its investment bank and lower interest rates affecting lending income. CEO Sergio Ermotti stated that the company continues to take actions to grow profitability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with stable yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on October 23, 2019, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.27% and the Topix index up 0.28%. The stable yen contributed to the gains, following a narrow global market move during a Japanese holiday.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, helped by a stable yen against the dollar after the global market moved narrowly during a holiday in Japan.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Opec mulls deeper output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 1.3% to $59.70 a barrel, with Brent crude up 74 cents and US West Texas Intermediate up 85 cents, due to Opec's consideration of deeper production cuts in December amid weak demand growth in 2020. China's trade talks with the US showed progress, but US crude stockpiles are expected to rise. Opec's move aims to stabilize oil prices amid global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Tuesday after China signaled progress in trade talks with the United States and Opec and its allies mulled deeper production cuts, but gains were capped by forecasts of a buildup in US crude stockpiles.

site_title: Tusk recommends EU leaders back Brexit extension
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk recommended EU leaders accept a Brexit extension, citing the need to avoid a no-deal Brexit. This comes after Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to pause the Withdrawal Agreement ratification process. Tusk proposed a written procedure, allowing the 27 member state leaders to consider the UK's request without an emergency summit. The October 31 deadline is now at risk of being pushed back, with no specific date announced.

site_title: Startups may scale back top gun packages as they set sights on profit
summary: High-growth startups like Grab and Razer are scaling back top gun packages as they focus on profitability. These companies lure senior hires with generous sign-on bonuses and equity packages, but as they mature, compensation packages may become less generous. Experts say the risk comes from stock options, which depend on business valuation and investor confidence. Despite this, startups continue to attract top talent with premium access to equity, exciting work culture, and lucrative possibilities. However, consultants warn that dangling premium pay packages is not sustainable in the long run, and senior executives are drawn to the possibility of shaping the future of the industry.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q3 DPU flat at S$0.022; inks new leases for CapitaSpring
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.022 for the third quarter, unchanged from the previous year. The trust's distributable income rose 2.6% to S$84.8 million, driven by higher net property income and lower interest expenses. CCT inked new leases for its CapitaSpring development, with committed occupancy increasing to 31%. The 51-storey integrated development will offer integrated solutions comprising core and flex spaces, catering to growing occupier expectations for amenities and services.

site_title: Addvalue delivers first flight model for real-time satellite comms terminal
summary: Addvalue Technologies has delivered the first flight model of its inter-satellite data relay system (IDRS) terminal to Capella Space, a micro-satellite firm. The IDRS system provides real-time, on-demand connection for LEO satellites, reducing communication time by 80-99%. Capella plans to launch its first commercial LEO satellite in early 2020, equipped with the IDRS terminal. The system was developed in tandem with Inmarsat and is expected to revolutionize the commercial imagery market. Addvalue has secured orders for six more flight units, set to be delivered in early 2020.

site_title: Sterling softens as more Brexit votes loom
summary: The British pound softened as more Brexit votes loomed, extending losses after lawmakers rebuffed Prime Minister Boris Johnson's plans to rush his EU divorce deal through parliament. The vote upended Johnson's pledged timetable, potentially delaying Britain's exit from the EU. Sterling fell to US$1.2880, down from US$1.2960 the previous day. Global stocks were mixed, with investors awaiting a potential partial trade deal between the US and China, while Asian and European bourses posted gains.

site_title: Macy's to stop selling fur products by 2021
summary: Macy's plans to stop selling fur products by early 2021, closing 34 Fur Vaults and 22 Maximilian salons. The decision comes after two years of research and aligns with guidelines from animal rights organizations. The retailer will continue to sell ethically sourced sheep and cattle fur products, such as shearling and sheepskin. The move is seen as a response to shifting consumer views on animal welfare and luxury, with the Humane Society of the US praising the company for its new policy.

site_title: MAS said to be investigating claims UBS overcharged wealthy clients in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is investigating claims that UBS overcharged wealthy clients in Singapore on debt securities transactions. The Swiss bank has reported the matter to MAS and intends to reimburse affected customers. UBS's investment bank has seen a 59% adjusted profit decline, while its core global wealth management unit saw a 15% return on common equity target missed. The bank has announced restructuring measures, including a US$100 million charge in the fourth quarter, and aims to boost share price through US$2 billion in share buybacks.

site_title: More US states join anti-trust probe of Facebook
summary: New York's attorney general has expanded a probe into Facebook's anti-trust practices to include 45 US states and the District of Columbia, with the support of 47 attorneys general. The investigation concerns whether Facebook has put consumer data at risk, reduced consumer choices, and increased advertising prices. Letitia James, New York's top attorney, stated that the probe is focused on these concerns. The investigation is ongoing, with the nation's top law enforcement officials working together to address potential issues with the social media giant.

site_title: Zuckerberg calls Libra coin a key for American leadership
summary: Facebook's proposed digital coin Libra aims to extend America's financial leadership and promote financial inclusion by providing a safe, low-cost, and efficient way to send and receive payments globally. CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that Libra will be backed mostly by dollars and governed by an independent board, addressing concerns about money laundering and illicit activity. However, regulators and lawmakers are skeptical about the plan, citing risks and unaddressed regulatory challenges, and the US Treasury Secretary has described a Libra launch as "premature."

site_title: Trump may be down now, but he's not out
summary: Donald Trump's support base remains strong despite recent scandals, including the Ukrainegate controversy. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi has launched an impeachment inquiry against him. The Democratic Party lineup is also facing challenges, with some candidates struggling to gain traction. Trump's policies, although unpopular, continue to have a significant following, suggesting he is not out of the presidential race yet.

site_title: White House denounces 'smear campaign' against Trump
summary: The White House has denounced testimony from a US diplomat in Donald Trump's impeachment probe as part of a "smear campaign" from the far left of the Democratic Party. The testimony, from Bill Taylor, appears to confirm allegations that Trump abused his office by conditioning foreign aid to Ukraine on its leader interfering in the 2020 election. White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham stated that Trump has done nothing wrong, calling the allegations a "coordinated smear campaign" that is waging war on the Constitution.

images.alt_text: The White House rejected damning testimony on Tuesday from a US diplomat in Donald Trump's impeachment probe as part of a "smear campaign" from the far left of the Democratic Party.

site_title: BRI: Need to woo global private investors
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) needs to attract global private investors to overcome funding obstacles and achieve economic efficiency. The government's reliance on state-owned enterprises and limited private capital has led to criticism and questions about national interests and geopolitical competition. Private investment can bring in new technology, management experience, and global best practices, making the BRI more inclusive and acceptable. However, addressing risks, such as non-traditional issues and geopolitical conflicts, is crucial to attracting private investment. China can leverage public capital to unlock and maximize private investment, and multilateral development banks can play a key role in coordinating government actions and mitigating investment risks.

site_title: Japanese defence forces plan Middle East mission: Kyodo
summary: Japan plans to send its military to protect waterways in the Middle East, particularly in the Persian Gulf, following attacks on tankers and oil installations. The move will not involve joining a US-led maritime coalition. Japan's Foreign Minister informed the US Secretary of State of the plan, citing concerns over global oil supplies. The country's military, known as the Self-Defence Forces, will send two destroyers to the region, but they will not operate in the Strait of Hormuz. Japan's decision comes as the US has formed a naval coalition to protect navigation in the region.

site_title: Erdogan hails 'historic agreement' with Putin over Syria
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Russian President Vladimir Putin reached a "historic agreement" in Sochi, Russia, to push back Syrian Kurdish fighters from a safe zone along the border. Erdogan announced a 150-hour deadline for the fighters and their weapons to be moved back 30km from areas on the Turkish border. The agreement aims to prevent a separatist agenda on Syrian territory, according to Erdogan.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after deluge of mixed earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with tech companies particularly weak, following mixed corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped 0.4% and 0.7%, respectively. Procter & Gamble rose 2.6% after lifting full-year targets, while McDonald's slumped 5.0% due to disappointing earnings. Biogen surged 26.1% after announcing FDA approval for an Alzheimer's treatment, and Under Armour gained 6.9% after its CEO stepped down.

site_title: Trying to get on robots' softer side
summary: A new industry group, the Asia Pacific Assistive Robotics Association (Apara), is promoting the integration of robots into homes, focusing on their potential to improve elderly care and community health. The group, with 50 members, is hosting a conference on ethics in artificial intelligence and robotics, with the second "Robot Of The Year" award to be given out on November 18. Industry consultant Oliver Tian hopes to engage a wide audience, including policymakers, executives, and the general public, to explore how AI and robotics can change the future of work and improve human experiences.

images.alt_text: The time has come for robots to leave factories and enter homes, one new industry group here believes.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Falcon Energy's debt moratorium has been extended to Nov 30 by the High Court, less than the four-month stay requested by the company and its subsidiary Asetanian Marine. The extension is due to be heard on Oct 21.

site_title: Trudeau's Liberals win Canada vote, will form weakened minority government
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's Liberal Party won a minority government in a general election, securing 156 seats in the 338-seat parliament. The Conservatives, led by Andrew Scheer, came in second with 122 seats. Trudeau will form a weakened minority government, likely requiring an alliance with smaller parties. The election saw a record 97 women elected to parliament, and Trudeau has vowed to address climate change and Quebec's concerns. Trudeau's popularity was damaged by ethics issues and controversy surrounding his handling of the SNC-Lavalin bribery case.

images.alt_text: Mr Trudeau will have to form an alliance with one or more smaller parties in order to govern a fractured nation.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks hit record ahead of final pension bill vote
summary: Brazil's benchmark Bovespa index reached a record high of 107,381.1 ahead of the expected Senate approval of President Jair Bolsonaro's pension reform bill. The bill, which aims to save over 800 billion reais (S$267.1 billion) over 10 years, introduces a minimum retirement age and increases contributions over a longer period. The measure is seen as crucial to unleashing other reforms and is expected to pass with overwhelming support in the Senate.

site_title: Europe: Stocks subdued by mixed corporate earnings and Brexit
summary: European stocks closed with a 0.1% gain, despite mixed corporate earnings reports, due to a weaker pound supporting London's FTSE 100. The FTSE 100 rose 0.7%, driven by Just Eat's 24% jump, while Reckitt Benckiser fell to its lowest level in seven months after cutting its sales forecast. Other European indices, including Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40, were marginally higher.

site_title: S$38m initiative for hyper-personalised manufacturing among new Industry 4.0 moves
summary: A*Star-led Singapore is investing S$38 million in a public-private partnership to develop hyper-personalised manufacturing, enabling "minimum order quantity of one". The initiative, part of the Model Factory Initiative, aims to create a smart, scalable, and automated factory line for fast-moving consumer goods. The project will partner industry players to test-bed solutions and provide a platform for firms to test their hyper-personalisation capabilities.

site_title: Instabase joins Silicon Valley's unicorns despite turmoil in the stable
summary: Instabase, a business tools company, has raised US$105 million at a US$1.05 billion valuation, joining Silicon Valley's unicorns despite the turmoil in the tech industry. The company sells customizable apps and building blocks to companies seeking easy-to-use software for employees. Despite the high valuation, Instabase's CEO, Anant Bhardwaj, emphasizes the importance of executing and not behaving like WeWork, which was ousted as CEO last month. Instabase plans to use the funding to build up its sales force and expand into new sectors.

site_title: Emerging markets are next 'asset bubble' amid yield hunt, debt
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a yield hunt, leading to ballooning debt levels and fueling concerns of an asset bubble. Protests in Chile, Ecuador, Argentina, and Lebanon are highlighting the risk of investing in these markets. Debt issuance from emerging markets has reached $525 billion, a 20% increase over last year. Experts warn that investors may be ignoring geopolitical risks, which could lead to significant problems in the next recession. Chairman of the Jerome Levy Forecasting Center, David Levy, says the emerging-market sector is experiencing a similar cycle to the US housing market before the global financial crisis.

site_title: Euro steadies as investors await Brexit vote
summary: The euro remained steady on Tuesday as investors awaited the British parliament's vote on the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which will determine the UK's exit from the EU. The euro had risen to a two-month high against the US dollar earlier in the session, driven by Brexit developments and trade tensions between the US and China. However, hopes of a US-China trade deal supported the US dollar, and the euro was flat at US$1.1146.

site_title: Collaboration with public agencies needed to drive Industry 4.0 forward in South-east Asia
summary: Manufacturers in South-east Asia are adopting advanced technologies known as Industry 4.0, which includes advanced analytics, machine learning, and automation. A McKinsey survey found that while enthusiasm for these technologies has waned, many companies plan to achieve operational goals within one to three years. However, challenges such as a lack of expertise and weak cross-functional alignment are hindering broader deployment. To overcome these obstacles, collaboration between companies and public agencies is crucial, particularly in addressing the region's skills gap. Indonesia's strong government effort in implementing Industry 4.0 has been a notable exception.

site_title: Nike's Mark Parker to step aside as CEO next year; remains board chair
summary: Nike has announced that John Donahoe will replace Mark Parker as CEO on January 13, 2020, as part of the company's efforts to accelerate its "digital transformation." Parker will remain board chair, working closely with Donahoe. The change is aimed at boosting the company's output and efficiency through technology, following a scandal that led to the shutdown of an elite training program and the departure of several executives. Nike shares were largely unchanged following the announcement, with revenue rising 25% in the latest quarter.

site_title: Oil prices slip as demand concerns outweigh US-China trade optimism
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday as concerns over a global economic slowdown outweighed optimism over US-China trade talks. Brent crude oil futures fell 10 cents to $58.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 12 cents to $53.19 per barrel. Despite US President Donald Trump's comments that trade talks were progressing, lingering worries over a slowdown and a Phase 1 trade deal weighed on sentiment. Goldman Sachs trimmed its global oil demand growth forecast to 1.3 million barrels per day, citing ongoing economic weakness.

site_title: Kimly looks to buy stakes in coffee shops, canteens for S$59m
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffee shop operator, plans to acquire interests in 81 coffee shops and industrial canteen units for S$59 million. The move is part of its strategy to expand its footprint in Singapore. The acquisition is made through Jin Wei Food Holdings, Kimly's wholly-owned subsidiary, and is a non-binding term sheet with third-party vendors. The deal aims to increase Kimly's presence in the market and enhance its offerings.

site_title: India group tells members to avoid buying M'sian palm oil
summary: India's influential processors' group has asked its members to refrain from buying Malaysian palm oil due to strained relations between the two countries. The move follows Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir's comments that India "invaded and occupied" Kashmir, which has led Indian buyers to turn to Indonesia for supplies. The decision is expected to negatively impact Malaysia's palm oil industry, with palm oil futures falling 0.7% in Kuala Lumpur. Indian processors are advised to boost purchases from other countries to make up for the shortfall.

site_title: Infosys investigates alleged 'unethical practices' by top officials
summary: Infosys is investigating allegations of "unethical practices" by top executives Salil Parekh and Nilanjan Roy, who allegedly forced revenue recognition to boost short-term profits. The claims, made in a whistleblower letter, also stated that the executives did not adhere to accounting standards. This led to a significant drop in Infosys' shares, their worst intraday fall in over six years.

site_title: Spectre of startup downcycle not a downer for Eight Roads
summary: Eight Roads Ventures, backed by Fidelity, remains bullish on Southeast Asia's startup scene despite slowing economic growth, focusing on resilient business models and verticals like social and B2B commerce. The firm's head, Dave Ng, sees growth areas in social commerce, e-commerce B2B platforms, and mid-mile logistics, as well as democratising financial access through online insurance. Eight Roads will continue to invest "patient capital" in the region, prioritizing startups that build long-term value and solve market problems.

site_title: New revenue contributions boost MIT's Q2
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.13 Singapore cents for its second quarter, up from 3.01 Singapore cents a year ago. Revenue rose 10.5% to S$101.9 million, driven by new revenue contributions from refurbished or completed properties. Net property income increased by 13.3% to S$80 million, while distributable income rose 12.1% to S$63.5 million. The trust's average portfolio occupancy fell to 90.5% due to lower occupancies in Singapore's light industrial buildings.

site_title: PropertyGuru finds support at lower end of IPO range: sources
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian online realty company, is offering shares at the lower end of its A$3.70 to A$4.50 IPO range, citing oversubscribed institutional demand. This successful IPO would buck the recent trend in Australia, where two deals failed to raise sufficient investors. The company, backed by KKR and TPG Capital, aims to raise up to A$380.2 million.

site_title: KrisEnergy won't redeem notes to conserve cash amid restructuring bid
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based oil and gas firm, has decided not to pay out redemption amounts under its notes, citing a need to conserve cash while working on a restructuring proposal. The company is under court protection and has paused repayments on some debts, including a $558.8 million total debt load. KrisEnergy is working with its advisers to conserve cash and protect stakeholders during the restructuring period, which is expected to involve a strategic review of its operations.

site_title: Louvre's Leonardo blockbuster showcases a master's progress
summary: The Louvre is staging a retrospective exhibition marking the 500th anniversary of Leonardo da Vinci's death, featuring 160 works, including eight paintings by the artist, 22 drawings, and loaned pieces from institutions worldwide. The exhibition showcases Leonardo's artistic progression through his own works and those by others, highlighting his innovative techniques and artistic range. Notable works on display include the Mona Lisa, Vitruvian Man, and a portrait of a male figure believed to be a musician, while the exhibition also explores Leonardo's scientific and anatomical interests.

images.alt_text: Workers hanging a poster showing the painting entitled La Belle Ferroniere at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Tuesday.
Vitruvian Man (left). Portrait of a Musician (right).
The Virgin and Child With Saint Anne (left) and Saint Jerome (right). The blockbuster show opens on Oct 24 and runs through Feb 24 next year.

site_title: Olam buys US almond processor and its real estate assets for US$54m
summary: Olam International has agreed to acquire US-based almond processor Hughson Nut Inc and its real estate assets for US$54 million. The acquisition is expected to be earnings and returns accretive from the first year after consolidation. Olam aims to offer an integrated solution across the almond value chain, complementing its existing capabilities in Australia and Vietnam. The deal is part of Olam's strategy to target new customer segments and grow its almond business into a vertically integrated player with a strong upstream presence.

site_title: Obama to speak at Dec 14 charity gala in Singapore
summary: Former US President Barack Obama will attend a charity gala in Singapore on December 14 to raise up to S$5 million for four local charities: Dreams Institute, SCWO Service Fund, Daughters of Tomorrow, and PPIS. This event is part of Obama's high-profile visit to Singapore, where he will participate in other high-profile events.

site_title: Leveraged loan buyers head for cover as fear ramps up over risky junk debt
summary: Leveraged loan investors are fleeing risky junk debt amid market jitters, causing prices to drop and interest rates to rise. Since October, lower-rated B loans have fallen about 1%, while less risky BB-rated loans have lost 0.26%. This is a surprising turn for loans, which have traditionally been considered lower-risk. Investors are taking less risk and favoring safer loans, with some loans losing up to 10% of their face value in just three months. The market's fear may be a harbinger of more pain in credit markets, with some experts warning of additional risks due to weakened investor protections and limited demand for riskier credits.

site_title: Using tech to drive a better employee work experience
summary: A recent global study by The Economist Intelligence Unit found that technology plays a key role in creating a positive work experience, driving productivity and employee engagement. In Singapore, where workers are among the least engaged in the Asia-Pacific, companies are focusing on employee experience to retain talent. The study suggests that having ready access to data and insights, as well as greater employee choice and control over technology, is crucial for an improved overall experience. A collaboration between IT and HR departments is also necessary to ensure technology's positive contribution to the employee experience.

site_title: Shift in behavioural approach to investing needed in a zero interest-rate world
summary: Investors face a catch-22 in a zero-interest-rate world, where bonds with negative yields pose a risk, while equities fail to sustain their uptrend. To navigate this, investors need a shift in mindset and attitude, focusing on diversifying across geographies, asset classes, and investment styles. Behavioral biases, such as being heavily invested in domestic assets and ignoring risk, must be addressed. A disciplined approach, like "buying low and selling high", can help mitigate emotional biases and unlock alternative investment opportunities, despite a seemingly low-yield environment.

site_title: Card networks team up to make mobile shopping easier
summary: The world's biggest card networks, including Visa, Mastercard, American Express, and Discover, have teamed up to make mobile shopping easier by introducing a new checkout option that eliminates the need to key in card details. This option, available on select retailers' websites, allows consumers to save their payment details and use a "click to pay" button, reducing online cart abandonment. Early adopters include Saks Fifth Avenue, Staples, and Papa John's, but getting consumers to switch from established options like PayPal and Apple Pay may be a challenge.

site_title: South-east Asia a major beneficiary of Sino-US rivalry, says George Yeo
summary: Former Singapore foreign affairs minister George Yeo says South-east Asia is a major beneficiary of the Sino-US rivalry, benefiting from China's growth. Yeo urges the US to "ride on China's growth" instead of forcing a choice between the two. He notes that China has been a defensive power, not an aggressive one, and its Belt and Road Initiative is an inevitable outcome of its economic growth. Yeo also expresses concern about anti-China sentiment in the US and predicts that China will become a more important market than the US for American companies.

site_title: Singtel needs digital bank licence to be major e-payment player
summary: Singtel is seeking a digital bank licence to expand its mobile wallet services, with the aim of becoming a major e-payment player in Southeast Asia. The telco has already linked its digital wallet platforms with OCBC Bank and plans to expand to Malaysia and Indonesia. However, Singtel's progress in this area is slow, and the company needs to demonstrate greater insight into its mobile wallet business to win over shareholders. Singtel may bid for one of the five new digital bank licences in Singapore by the end of the year, but faces stiff competition from established banks and legacy regulations.

site_title: Keppel soars on Temasek's wings, lifting STI along
summary: Keppel Corp's stock price surged 17% on a day after Temasek Holdings made a bid for a controlling stake in the diversified marine conglomerate, lifting the Straits Times Index (STI) along with it. Temasek's offer of S$7.35 a share for an additional 30.6% stake is seen as a premium of 26% over Keppel's last traded price. Analysts expect a strategic review to refocus and strengthen certain businesses, potentially leading to a restructuring that could unlock long-term value within the company.

site_title: Hong Kong announces fresh relief measures of HK$2b to boost economy
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan announced a fresh relief package of HK$2 billion (S$347.3 million) to support the economy amid five months of protests. The move follows an August package worth HK$19.1 billion. The city is on the verge of its first recession in a decade due to violent protests and economic downturn. The protests, sparked by concerns over freedoms under "one country, two systems," have led to over 2,600 arrests, two shootings, and widespread destruction.

site_title: Independent hotels disappearing as chains grow
summary: Independent hotels are facing significant challenges as large hotel chains and online booking agencies gain market share. Over the past 30 years, the number of independent hotels has declined from two-thirds to less than 40%, with many joining chains or shutting their doors. The main reason is acquiring marketing power and resources from large hotel companies. With the rise of Airbnb, independent hotels face increased competition, driving down prices and making it harder to operate profitably. Only hotels with strong established positions in their markets are likely to reject offers to join larger groups, but even they face stiff competition from online booking agencies.

site_title: Singaporeans' education, wages, health have improved over the generations: MOF report
summary: Singaporeans in their 40s have seen significant improvements in education, wages, and health compared to earlier generations. According to a Ministry of Finance report, 44% of those born in the 1970s have university degrees, and the median real gross monthly income is twice that of those in their 60s. The report also shows that Singaporeans in their 40s have higher CPF balances, own more properties, and live longer, with an average life expectancy of 41 years at age 45. However, the report notes that younger generations may face reduced family support due to lower marriage rates and smaller family sizes.

site_title: Semiconductor, pharma lead in Industry 4.0 readiness: EDB study
summary: A Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) study found that semiconductor and pharmaceutical firms lead the way in adopting Industry 4.0 technologies within Singapore's manufacturing sector. The Smart Industry Readiness Index (SIRI) report, based on 200 assessments across 12 industries, ranked the pharmaceuticals sector as the most mature, followed by medical technology and electronics. The report highlights the importance of connectivity and data leverage in driving Industry 4.0 transformation, with the top 10% of firms excelling in this area.

site_title: Why Trump should be impeached, removed from office
summary: President Trump's behavior poses an immediate threat to the US, warranting impeachment and removal from office. He has consistently demonstrated a lack of civility, honesty, and respect for institutions, with over 13,000 lies and deceptions documented. His policies have collapsed, and his actions have sparked racial and ethnic tensions, raised concerns about national security, and undermined alliances. The author argues that Trump's erratic behavior and disregard for reality pose a risk to democracy, making impeachment a necessary step to protect the country.

site_title: China's 2019 coal imports set to rise more than 10%: analysts
summary: China's coal imports are expected to rise more than 10% in 2019, contrary to earlier expectations of capping shipments at 2018 levels. The country has already seen a 9.5% surge in coal imports in the first nine months, with total volumes likely to reach 276 million tonnes before the end of the year. Analysts predict imports could reach 300-320 million tonnes, driven by a moderate recovery in demand and a desire to boost the economy. The move contradicts Beijing's previous efforts to curb coal use and reduce pollution.

images.alt_text: China's coal imports have already surged 9.5 per cent in the first nine months of 2019 to 250.57 million tonnes, and at least 18.84 million tonnes of seaborne coal are due to arrive this month.

site_title: Employers can help raise financial literacy of staff by offering classes
summary: A recent survey by OCBC Bank found that 39% of Singaporean women have no investments, 43% are unsure about growing their wealth, and 54% have no passive income, compared to 31%, 32%, and 44% of men respectively. This disparity is attributed to societal stereotyping and lack of knowledge and confidence, with women more likely to leave financial decisions to their partners. Offering financial literacy classes in the workplace could help address this issue, with employers and financial planners recommended to provide tailored plans and education for women of different age groups.

site_title: Softbank makes bailout offer to WeWork, plans to oust its chairman
summary: SoftBank Group has made a nearly $10 billion bailout offer to WeWork, aiming to keep the office-space sharing startup afloat and oust its chairman Adam Neumann. Without this financing, WeWork could run out of cash as early as next month. SoftBank is proposing a debt package, accelerating a previous $1.5 billion equity commitment, and launching a tender offer for up to $3 billion to acquire WeWork shares. WeWork's board will meet to evaluate the offer against JPMorgan Chase's alternative proposal, with Marcelo Claure set to succeed Neumann as chairman.

site_title: MLT proposes private placement to raise some S$250m
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) is proposing a private placement to raise approximately S$250 million to fund acquisitions. The trust plans to issue new units at an issue price ranging from S$1.579 to S$1.617 per unit, representing a discount of 1.5% to 3.8% of the VWAP. The funds will be used to partially fund the acquisition of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China for S$493.4 million.

site_title: US, China comments lift investor sentiment
summary: US and Chinese officials made positive comments on trade talks, boosting investor sentiment and driving gains in Asian equities. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,160.67, with Keppel Corp seeing heavy activity after Temasek made a partial offer to buy a further 30.55% stake. Other Asian markets also posted gains, with the US-China trade talks expected to reach a deal by mid-November.

site_title: Japan's ruler marks official ascension
summary: Japan's Emperor Naruhito formally proclaimed his ascension to the throne on Tuesday, marking a centuries-old ceremony attended by dignitaries from over 180 countries. He became emperor on May 1, but Tuesday's "Sokui no Rei" ritual officially announced his change in status. Naruhito pledged to fulfill his duty as a symbol of the state, with his wife Masako becoming empress. The ceremony comes after a brief transition period, with Naruhito and Masako taking on their new roles.

site_title: Trump Tower builder dumps luxury for cheap homes as India slows
summary: Macrotech Developers, a Trump Tower developer in Mumbai, India, is shifting focus to cheaper apartments and office space due to a credit squeeze reducing demand for luxury properties. The company will cut the share of premium housing in its portfolio from 30% to 17%. This move comes as India's financial hub experiences a slowdown.

site_title: High crimes on the high seas
summary: Piracy and armed robbery on ships remain a concern, despite a decline in reported incidents. The International Maritime Bureau's (IMB) report for the third quarter of 2019 recorded 95 vessels boarded, 10 fired upon, and 4 hijacked, with 49 crew members taken hostage. While statistics show an improvement, key indicators such as gun and knife-related incidents remain consistent. The Gulf of Guinea and Sulu-Celebes seas remain hotspots for piracy and armed robbery, with kidnappings of crew members increasing in scale and frequency.

site_title: UOB unveils programme to link businesses, consumers with solar firms
summary: UOB has launched a programme called U-Solar, connecting Asian businesses and individuals with solar company partners to help them switch to solar power. The programme, launched in Malaysia, aims to address concerns about upfront costs and maintenance. UOB offers flexible repayment plans and financial solutions, including loans and sukuk certificates, to fund solar projects. The bank plans to roll out the programme in Singapore and other South-east Asia countries, providing installation, commissioning, and after-sales services for solar power systems.

site_title: US bank to slash branch jobs nationwide in digital push
summary: US Bancorp plans to slash branch jobs nationwide, with some positions being eliminated or significantly reduced, as it shifts focus to digital banking. The move, which affects less than 2% of the bank's 74,000 employees, aims to adapt to changing customer behaviors. US Bancorp will add new roles and a training program to help existing employees develop new skills. The bank will not close any branches, instead focusing on a "branch-light concept" to enter new markets. This move is part of the industry's shift towards digital offerings, with fintech startups competing for market share.

site_title: Johnson threatens to pull deal and seek election
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson threatened to scrap his Brexit deal and seek an election if members of Parliament vote against his fast-track timetable. The Second Reading vote on his deal will take place Tuesday evening, with the outcome determining his chances of passing the law ahead of the October 31 deadline. Johnson warned that a vote against his fast-track timetable will lead to an election, stating it will "unleash a tide of investment" into Britain. The outcome of the vote remains uncertain, with Johnson's deal facing opposition from MPs.

site_title: US-China 'Cold War' can evolve into a deeper strategic partnership
summary: The US-China 'Cold War' may evolve into a deeper strategic partnership rather than a traditional rivalry. The 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall marks a significant moment in international relations, but optimism has faded as geopolitical risks have increased. The US remains a powerful country, but its influence is being challenged by China's growing economic strength and assertive foreign policy. A potential bilateral partnership could lead to a new era of global growth and stability, with cooperation on issues like climate change and trade. The outcome will depend on the success of the US-China trade agreement and the ability of the two nations to resolve their differences.

site_title: Boeing's 737 MAX crisis deepens, hitting shares
summary: Boeing faces increased pressure as newly released documents raise doubts about the company's ability to return its 737 MAX jet to service soon. The Federal Aviation Administration sharply criticized Boeing for withholding key documents in probes following two crashes that killed 346 people. Shares tumbled for a second day in a row, with calls for a leadership shakeup intensifying.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust posts flat DPU of S$0.024 for Q4
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) posted a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.4 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue inched up 1.3% to S$32.9 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 0.5% to S$21.7 million. The Reit manager remains confident in the long-term prospects of the UK market despite Brexit uncertainties.

site_title: Car industry woes to push Continental into 2019 loss
summary: Continental, a German car components maker, expects a loss in 2019 due to a slowdown in the global car industry. The company's assets lost 2.5 billion euros in value amid the decline. Continental attributed the decline to a lack of improvement in global light vehicle production over the next five years. The company plans to spin off its powertrain division Vitesco for a stock market listing, despite initially planning a partial flotation. This move aims to boost the company's value amidst the industry slowdown.

site_title: Netanyahu suffers defeat in failing to form Israeli government
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has failed to form a new coalition government, leading to a repeat election after the previous polls in September. President Reuven Rivlin is expected to give Benny Gantz, leader of the Blue and White alliance, a chance to try to negotiate a coalition. Netanyahu remains premier as long as no new government is formed, and a deadlock remains, with a third election possible. Netanyahu's future in office is uncertain, with corruption charges looming and a rotation between him and Gantz gaining public support.

site_title: South Korea scrambled jets to warn Russian warplanes in air defence zone
summary: South Korea scrambled fighter jets to warn Russian warplanes entering its air defence zone, the 20th breach this year. Russian bombers, accompanied by other warplanes, reportedly flew over neutral waters, not entering South Korean airspace. The incident occurred as South Korean and Russian military officials are set to discuss plans to establish a hotline between their air forces. Russia's defense ministry denied any airspace violation, while South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff stated that the aircraft repeatedly entered the Korea Air Defence Identification Zone.

site_title: Uniqlo ad sparks protest, parody in S Korea
summary: A Uniqlo ad in South Korea sparked controversy after a 97-year-old American style icon, Iris Apfel, was parodied in a commercial, with subtitles suggesting she couldn't remember her past 80 years. A South Korean student created a parody video criticizing the ad as mocking victims of wartime forced labor and brothel workers. Protests and boycotts ensued, with Uniqlo pulling the ad in South Korea and facing a sharp drop in sales and customers. The incident reignited a bitter dispute between South Korea and Japan, which colonized the Korean peninsula from 1910 to 1945.

images.alt_text: South Korean protesters denounced the Uniqlo advertisement in a rally in Seoul and demanded an apology from the Japanese clothing brand.

site_title: Britain's Labour Party will not support Brexit deal or timetable - Corbyn
summary: Britain's Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn stated his opposition to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal and timetable. Corbyn recommended voting against the bill and the programme motion, which sets the legislation's passage through parliament. This decision reflects the party's continued opposition to the Brexit process.

images.alt_text: British Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Tuesday his opposition party would not support Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal or his timetable to pass the legislation for it through parliament.

site_title: Uber CEO expects to ride developing market growth in next decade
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi expects the company's growth over the next decade to be driven by developing markets like India, Africa, and the Middle East, rather than the US and Europe. Despite facing challenges in these regions, Khosrowshahi sees "improving profitability characteristics" in India, where Uber operates in 40 cities and accounts for 11% of its global rides. The company is also investing in logistics and food delivery services to drive growth, and Khosrowshahi believes a shift towards on-demand services will reduce car ownership and drive innovation.

site_title: Australia panel backs tougher oversight of airport costs but won't control pricing
summary: Australia's Productivity Commission recommends that airport operators provide more information on service costs to the competition regulator, but stops short of recommending pricing controls or intervention in disputes. Airlines had sought tougher oversight to curb rising access fees that contribute to high profit margins at Australian airports. The current light-handed regime remains valid, with the government panel also recommending that airports report revenues and costs to airlines and remove anti-competitive clauses. The Australian Airports Association welcomes this approach, citing the need for stability to support airport investment and growth.

site_title: Renault chairman vows to get Nissan alliance back on track
summary: Renault Chairman Jean-Dominique Senard vows to revive the alliance with Nissan, citing a focus on combined efforts to cut costs and invest in new technologies. Senard stated that a potential tie-up with Fiat Chrysler is secondary to repairing relations with Nissan. Renault has recently overhauled management and is reviewing mid-term targets amid a profit warning. Senard aims to get the alliance back on track by 2020, considering it a failure if progress is not made, and reducing Renault's stake in Nissan is not a priority.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.16 points to 1,574.09 on Tuesday, driven by a 3.3 billion lots volume worth RM2.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 411.

site_title: Qatar to expand airport ahead of World Cup 2022
summary: Qatar has announced a major expansion of its Hamad international airport, aiming to increase its capacity from 35 million to 53 million passengers annually, and eventually up to 60 million. The expansion, which includes two phases, is set to begin in 2020 and be completed by 2024, ahead of the 2022 World Cup. The move aims to boost tourism and counter the impact of a two-year boycott by neighboring countries, despite a 20% decline in visitors to Qatar since the boycott began in 2017.

site_title: Lebanese keep up protests despite emergency measures
summary: Lebanese protesters continued their six-day demonstrations despite the government's adoption of an emergency economic rescue plan, which includes a 2020 budget, no new taxes, and measures to support the underprivileged. The protesters, who initially demanded a tax on WhatsApp and other messaging apps, now seek broader systemic change and the removal of the entire political elite, which they see as corrupt. The government's efforts to restore confidence have been met with skepticism, and it remains unclear how long the protests will last.

site_title: Wall St opens higher on upbeat earnings, healthcare boost
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday following upbeat earnings reports that alleviated concerns over domestic growth and the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.08%, the S&P 500 gained 0.13%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.31%. A surge in Biogen boosted the healthcare sector, contributing to the positive market trend.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 22.79 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 26,850.43.

site_title: PM Johnson tells lawmakers: pass Brexit deal and Britain can unite again
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged lawmakers to pass the government's Brexit deal to unite the country. If the deal is approved, the government will de-escalate no-deal Brexit preparations before the UK's planned departure from the EU next week. Parliament is set to vote on the legislation, with the government hoping to get it through by the end of Thursday.

site_title: The Vatican out of money? Heavens no, says pope ally
summary: Vatican officials have denied reports of a potential default, with Cardinal Oscar Maradiaga stating that allegations are part of a discrediting campaign against Pope Francis. Maradiaga, economic adviser to the Pope, said the Vatican is financially stable and that the claims are "false". This comes after concerns were raised about the Vatican's financial situation, sparking speculation about its ability to pay its debts. The Vatican has maintained its financial stability, and officials have dismissed the reports as part of a strategy to undermine the Pope's economic reforms.

site_title: NTUC FairPrice, Foodfare and Kopitiam to be grouped under one umbrella to keep food costs low for consumers
summary: NTUC FairPrice, Foodfare, and Kopitiam will be grouped under a new umbrella, NTUC FairPrice Group, to drive greater efficiencies and cater to evolving consumer needs. The move aims to keep food costs low for consumers, with the three entities working together to address the rising cost of living. The new group will have 573 outlets and will focus on seamless customer experiences, with cross-promotions and collaborations between the entities. This move is in response to the increasing trend of consumers eating out and the growing proportion of food expenditure in households.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.7% after positive US-China trade comments
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,160.67, driven by positive US-China trade comments suggesting productive negotiations. Other Asia-Pacific indices also gained, including Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea. Market strategist Pan Jingyi noted a "clear break" in trade talks could aid the long-term uptrend, boosting Asian equities.

site_title: Eurozone firms keep borrowing as growth fears mount
summary: Eurozone firms continue to borrow at a steady pace, despite concerns over a slowdown, according to the European Central Bank's quarterly survey. Net demand for loans to enterprises remained unchanged in the third quarter, with demand slightly increasing for small- and medium-sized enterprises but decreasing for large firms. The ECB now expects expansion of 1.1% this year and 1.2% in 2020, as external factors such as trade wars and Brexit weigh on the bloc.

images.alt_text: Companies' demand for bank loans held up in the eurozone in the third quarter, the European Central Bank found in a survey published Tuesday, in a mildly positive sign amid fears of a slowdown.

site_title: Hong Kong announces fresh relief measures of HK$2b to boost economy
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan announced a fresh relief package of HK$2 billion to support the economy amid its first recession in a decade. This move follows an August HK$19.1 billion package to support underprivileged individuals and businesses. The government is grappling with five months of protests that have impacted the retail and tourism sectors.

site_title: New revenue contributions boost MIT's Q2
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) posted a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.13 Singapore cents for its second quarter, driven by 10.5% gross revenue growth to S$101.9 million. Net property income increased by 13.3% to S$80 million, while distributable income rose 12.1% to S$63.5 million. The trust's US portfolio occupancy rate remained steady at 97.4%, while the Singapore portfolio occupancy fell to 90.2%. CEO Tham Kuo Wei attributed the growth to contributions from acquisitions and development projects, including the acquisition of 13 data centers in North America.

site_title: Gold and diamonds are an Indian guru's best friend
summary: Indian investigators seized over $14 million in cash, gold, and diamonds from 40 properties belonging to spiritual guru Kalki Bhagavan, accused of tax evasion, fraud, and amassing unaccounted wealth. The guru, who claims to be the reincarnation of a Hindu god, denied fleeing India after reports surfaced of him and his wife leaving the country. The raids involved 300 investigators and uncovered documents showing the group had channeled money through shell companies into real estate and foreign countries. The guru's group is also accused of preying on the poor and vulnerable for power, fame, and money.

site_title: KrisEnergy will not pay off notes amid restructuring
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas firm, has decided not to pay out redemption amounts under its notes amid restructuring efforts. The company, under court protection from creditors in Singapore, needs to conserve cash while working on a restructuring proposal. Total debt stood at around US$558.8 million as of June 30. KrisEnergy is working closely with its advisers to meet its funding requirements during the restructuring period.

site_title: Renault chairman sets ambitious goal for troubled Nissan alliance
summary: Renault Chairman Jean-Dominique Senard has set an ambitious goal for the troubled Nissan alliance, aiming for the partnership to "take off" in 2020. Senard wants to strengthen the industrial side of the alliance, addressing Nissan's demand for more sway, without lowering Renault's 43% stake in Nissan. The new management teams at both companies must work together to achieve this goal, with Senard warning that failure to do so would be a failure for him and his teams.

site_title: China blocks almost a quarter of accredited foreign news sites: watchdog
summary: China's "Great Firewall" system blocks domestic access to nearly a quarter of accredited foreign news sites, according to the Foreign Correspondents' Club of China. 23% of 215 international news organizations with journalists in China are blocked, including major outlets like the BBC, Bloomberg, and The New York Times. This move prevents Chinese citizens from accessing valuable sources of independent reporting on international and domestic matters, contradicting the ethos of internet openness. The FCCC notes that 536 foreign journalists have accreditation to report in China, but this censorship apparatus further restricts access to global news sources.

site_title: Big Four auditors failing to learn from company collapses - UK lawmaker
summary: UK lawmaker Rachel Reeves criticizes Big Four auditors for not learning from the collapse of Thomas Cook and Carillion, stating urgent reform is needed to improve audit quality. The auditors claim they followed rules at the time, but Reeves questions their proactive approach. A government-backed review proposes setting up a new regulator, requiring two auditors, and separating audit and advisory services. The government plans to propose legislation in early 2020, but change may take a year or two.

images.alt_text: Accounting firms have not shown a "learning curve" from the collapse of travel company Thomas Cook and builder Carillion, with urgent reform the only way to improve audit quality, a senior British lawmaker said on Tuesday.

site_title: Residential site off Upper Serangoon Rd for sale for some S$13.5m
summary: A residential development site off Upper Serangoon Road in Singapore is up for sale via public tender at an indicative price of S$13.5 million, or S$850 per square foot. The site, zoned for residential use, offers redevelopment options and is near popular schools and amenities. The tender closes on December 5, with keen interest expected from investors and boutique developers. The site's plot ratio is underutilized, making it an attractive option for those looking to create a unique boutique development.

images.alt_text: The site, which is delta-shaped, is located at 62 Florence Road and enjoys a dual road frontage of 55 metres along Florence Road and 45 metres into Lim Ah Pin Road.

site_title: Malaysia 5G: Wholesale network proposals unlikely to be favoured
summary: Malaysia's telecoms regulator is unlikely to support a government-led 5G wholesale network rollout, despite the country being one of the first Southeast Asian markets to launch 5G. The regulator will instead encourage operators to pursue network sharing agreements, citing low consumer appetite for 5G services and a lack of allocated 5G spectrum. Network commercialization for mobile services is expected to occur in 2021 or 2022, with operators prioritizing upgrading legacy 4G networks. The new Malaysian government's openness to Chinese companies will also be beneficial for operators planning their 5G roadmaps.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian online realty company, is offering shares at the lower end of its IPO range of A$3.70 to A$4.50. A residential site in Singapore is also up for sale for S$13.5m. Meanwhile, Falcon Energy has received another month of court protection against creditors until November 30. Agri-business firm Olam has acquired a US almond processor for US$54m. The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by positive US-China headlines.

images.alt_text: PropertyGuru, the South-east Asian online realty company, is offering shares at the lower end of the A$3.70 to A$4.50 indicated range as it takes orders for its Australian initial public offering (IPO), according to two sources close to the deal.

site_title: Duterte cuts short Japan trip due to 'unbearable pain'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is cutting short his trip to Japan due to "unbearable pain" in his spine, stemming from a motorcycle accident. The 74-year-old had recently disclosed his struggles with an autoimmune disease, myasthenia gravis. Duterte will leave Japan sooner than planned, having attended the enthronement ceremony of Emperor Naruhito, and will see his neurologist upon returning to Manila. The palace assures the public that there is nothing to worry about regarding the president's physical health. Duterte's health concerns have been a subject of speculation since he took office in 2016.

site_title: Najib engaged in 'well-planned' plot to plunder 1MDB, say prosecutors
summary: Malaysian ex-leader Najib Razak is accused of engaging in a "well-planned" plot to plunder the state fund 1MDB, with prosecutors presenting evidence of 42 million ringgit (S$13.65 million) allegedly stolen from a former unit of the fund. Najib's defence team argues that the evidence does not prove his guilt, and a judge will decide whether the case should proceed. Najib faces seven charges of corruption and money-laundering, with each charge carrying a maximum jail term of 20 years. A trial is expected to begin in December if the case is allowed to proceed.

site_title: WeWork board accepts SoftBank rescue deal
summary: WeWork's board has accepted a $9.5 billion rescue deal from SoftBank Group, handing control of the office-sharing startup to the Japanese firm.
