This marks a reversal of fortunes for WeWork, which lost nearly $39 billion of its valuation over five weeks, scrapping its public debut, ousting co-founder Adam Neumann as CEO, and launching a cost-cut plan. WeWork's board chose SoftBank's offer over a $5 billion debt financing package from JPMorgan Chase & Co.

site_title: Hong Kong shares close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Tuesday, following Wall Street's positive trend. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.23%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.50% and 1.01%, respectively. Investors are optimistic about a potential trade deal between China and the US, which could be finalized by next month.

site_title: Semicon, pharma manufacturers lead in Industry 4.0 readiness: EDB study
summary: Semiconductor and pharmaceutical manufacturers in Singapore lead the industry in adopting Industry 4.0 technologies, according to a Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) study. The study analyzed data from 200 firms that have undergone Smart Industry Readiness Index (SIRI) assessments, finding that the pharmaceuticals sector has a high and uniform level of smart industry maturity. The semiconductor industry also ranked high, but with a more varied pace of transformation. The report highlights the importance of connectivity in Industry 4.0, with the biggest divide between top and bottom performers being in connectivity.

site_title: Australia panel backs tougher oversight of airport costs, won't control pricing
summary: Australia's Productivity Commission recommends tougher oversight of airport costs, requiring operators to provide more information to the competition regulator. However, the report stops short of recommending pricing controls or intervention in disputes. Airlines had sought more oversight to curb rising access fees, which have driven profit margins to high levels. The existing light-handed regime remains valid, and the government panel also recommended reporting revenues and costs, as well as removing anti-competitive clauses from airport contracts.

site_title: South Korea's Q3 GDP q-o-q growth seen slowing, no quick recovery seen: poll
summary: South Korea's Q3 GDP growth is expected to slow to 0.5% from 1.0% in Q2, according to a Reuters poll. Despite government spending supporting growth, economists predict sluggish domestic demand and a possible decline in exports. Annual growth is forecast to remain steady at 2.1%. Economists do not expect an immediate recovery due to global risks and weak demand. The Bank of Korea may release advance estimates of Q3 GDP on Thursday.

site_title: European stocks mostly dip amid Brexit saga
summary: European stocks declined amid parliamentary votes on British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's withdrawal agreement bill. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2%, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also lost 0.2% and remained flat, respectively. Sterling declined 0.1% to $1.2943, while the euro edged 0.1% higher to 86.07 pence. Investors kept an eye on Asia, where growing hope for a partial China-US trade deal next month lifted markets.

site_title: American retail chain Macy's to go fur-free
summary: Macy's, the American retail chain, announced it will stop selling real fur in all its stores starting 2021, following growing pressure from animal protection agencies. The company cited consumer trends and research on alternatives to fur as reasons for the decision. Macy's private brands and items from brand partners will also be fur-free. The move comes after luxury fashion house Prada's decision to remove animal fur from its collections. Macy's will continue to offer high-quality and fashionable faux fur alternatives.

site_title: Drugstore drones: UPS will fly CVS prescriptions to US customers
summary: UPS's Flight Forward unit will start delivering prescriptions to US customers via drones in one or two cities in the coming weeks. This service is part of UPS's expansion of its drone business, which has recently gained US government approval to operate a drone airline. The company plans to use drones to deliver pharmaceuticals, supplies, and records to medical campuses, and has signed deals with CVS Health, Kaiser Permanente, and AmerisourceBergen. The move aims to address last-mile and urgent delivery challenges, with UPS aiming to scale the business.

site_title: PropertyGuru leans towards lower end of IPO range: sources
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian online realty company, is offering shares at the lower end of its A$3.70 to A$4.50 IPO range, according to sources. Institutional demand is oversubscribed, with retail broker allocations exceeding the deal size at the bottom end of the price range. The company, backed by KKR and TPG Capital, plans to raise up to A$380.2 million through the IPO, with shares set to start trading on Friday.

site_title: UBS tightens investment banking belt as earnings slide continues
summary: Swiss bank UBS is reducing investment banking staff after a disappointing performance led to a 16% slide in third-quarter net profit. The bank aims to save $90 million annually and expects to take $100 million in restructuring expenses in the fourth quarter. Despite a strong core global wealth management unit, the investment bank saw a 59% adjusted profit decline, with advisory revenue falling 21%. The bank's share price has dropped 16% over the past year, hitting a six-year low in August.

site_title: Hover-taxi whizzes over Singapore, firm eyes Asian push
summary: A German firm, Volocopter, successfully tested a hover-taxi in Singapore, with plans to introduce the service in the city-state in two to four years. The autonomous, two-seater vehicle flew for about two minutes and 30 seconds over Marina Bay, with a pilot onboard for safety reasons. Volocopter aims to expand the service to other Asian cities, including Jakarta, Manila, and Bangkok, to address traffic congestion issues. The company faces competition from Uber and Kitty Hawk, but sees the flying taxi as an alternative transport option.

site_title: UBS, authorities looking into client overcharges in Singapore and Hong Kong
summary: UBS is investigating overcharges made to wealthy clients in debt securities transactions in Hong Kong and Singapore between 2008 and 2015. The bank expects to reimburse affected customers and faces potential reprimands and fines from authorities. UBS has identified the issues and is working with relevant authorities to address the matter. The bank's third-quarter report highlights the findings and the steps being taken to rectify the situation.

images.alt_text: UBS is working with relevant authorities to address inappropriate spreads it may have charged wealthy clients whose money was booked in Hong Kong and Singapore in debt securities transactions, it said in its third-quarter report on Tuesday.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares cheered by Sino-US trade optimism
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over Sino-US trade talks, with China's Vice-Foreign Minister Le Yucheng stating progress had been made. Mining stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, also gained, boosted by higher commodity prices. Energy stocks rebounded after oil prices steadied, while wealth manager AMP Ltd jumped 2.3% on a US$6.2 billion fundraising. However, some stocks fell, including Cochlear Ltd and Super Retail Group, which flagged lower earnings and margins.

site_title: Fosun mulling bid for German pudding tycoons' private bank: sources
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International Ltd is considering a bid for Bankhaus Lampe KG, a German private bank owned by the Oetker family. ABN Amro Bank NV and Oddo BHF are also weighing offers for the bank, which could value it at 200 million euros. The sale is seen as a result of challenges in wealth management in Germany due to negative interest rates and conservative clients, prompting the Oetker family to divest assets in recent years.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on progress in US-China trade talks
summary: South Korean stocks rose over 1% on Tuesday as optimism around US-China trade talks boosted investor confidence. Vice-Foreign Minister Le Yucheng stated that progress had been made in talks, with US President Donald Trump expressing optimism about a potential deal. The Kospi index ended 1.16% higher, with foreigners net buying 76.3 billion won worth of shares. The won also gained, while the benchmark bond yield fell, as investors took on more risk.

site_title: Australia's Chris the sheep, the world's woolliest, dies
summary: Chris, the world's woolliest sheep, has died at the age of 10 due to old age. The Australian Merino was a record holder for the heaviest fleece, and his death was announced by the Little Oak Sanctuary, where he was cared for. Chris's carers described him as a "sweet, wise, friendly soul" and expressed their heartbreak at his loss.

images.alt_text: In 2015, Chris the sheep was discovered on the northern outskirts of Australian capital Canberra, struggling to walk under the weight of his wool, which had not be shorn in more than five years.

site_title: Indonesia's Indrawati to stay on as finance minister
summary: Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has agreed to stay in her post under President Joko Widodo, who has tapped over a dozen candidates for ministerial positions for a second five-year term. Indrawati expressed her commitment to supporting the president's priorities, including improving human resources and executing government budgets well amidst a global economic slowdown. Her continuation is seen as crucial for Indonesia's economic stability, and she has been praised for her fiscal discipline and leadership in driving deeper fiscal reforms.

site_title: Falcon Energy gets another month of court protection against creditors
summary: Falcon Energy has received a one-month extension of its court-protected debt moratorium, now set to expire on November 30. This is less than the four-month stay requested by the company. The extension prevents creditors from appointing a receiver, commencing or continuing legal proceedings, enforcing security, or repossessing goods. Significant asset disposals also require court approval. A further hearing is scheduled for November 26.

site_title: Malaysia warns new EU rules could hurt palm oil used in food
summary: Malaysia warns that new EU rules limiting contaminants in refined fats and oils, including palm oil, could hurt the US$60-billion industry, threatening food demand and prices. The EU aims to set limits for glycidyl esters and 3-MCPD esters, citing potential health concerns. Malaysian Minister Teresa Kok urged the industry to address food safety issues and prepare for trade challenges. The move could cast a negative sentiment on the international palm oil market and impact the reputation of the Malaysian palm oil industry.

site_title: You're only as old as you feel
summary: A study found that people's subjective age, or how old they feel, is a strong predictor of their health and well-being. Those who feel younger than their chronological age tend to be healthier and more resilient, while those who feel older are at higher risk for hospitalization and cognitive decline. Research suggests that a youthful mindset can have a powerful effect on physical and mental abilities, and that internalizing ageism can worsen one's outlook and health. Experts recommend adopting healthy habits and a positive attitude to combat age-related deterioration and promote overall well-being.

site_title: Aramco seeks top refining and chemicals spots to bolster growth
summary: Saudi Aramco is expanding its refining and chemicals business to boost growth and profitability. The company aims to invest in projects in India and China, processing crude into fuels and products like plastics. Aramco's downstream expansion is part of Saudi Arabia's diversification plan, which relies on the company's ability to create jobs and spur new manufacturing industries. The company has recovered from aerial strikes on its oil facilities and is processing all crude to export quality. Aramco's acquisition of a majority stake in Saudi Basic Industries Corp is set to close in the first or second quarter next year.

site_title: Australian mining magnate applies for big new coal mine
summary: Australian mining magnate Clive Palmer has applied for a 35-year coal mining lease in the Galilee Basin in Queensland state, a region that has been cleared for development. The application, made by Waratah Coal, follows a previous proposal in 2011 and comes as India's Adani Enterprises develops a nearby coal mine. The Galilee Basin is expected to increase Australia's coal exports, which are forecast to reach A$57 billion this year, and could make other coal projects in the region more viable. Palmer's application signals a resumption in development planning for the mine.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,164.53, up 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% to 3,164.53 on Tuesday, driven by gains from Keppel Corp, which surged 15.9% after Temasek made a surprise S$4 billion partial offer. Banking stocks were mixed, while other active index stocks included City Developments and Singapore Press Holdings. Asian equities generally trended higher, with positive signs on trade talks and upcoming earnings from major conglomerates.

site_title: Tickled Media names ex-Rocket Internet executive as finance lead
summary: Tickled Media, a parenting portal operator, has appointed Jatin Detwani, former chief financial officer of Rocket Internet JV Asia Pacific, as its finance lead. Detwani aims to push the business towards a revenue of US$100 million within a few years. He joins Tickled Media just a month after Susana Tsui, former Dentsu Aegis Network China CEO, was appointed as its CEO of media. The company, which runs theAsianparent, has over 200 employees spread across 12 markets and recently raised an undisclosed amount of Series C funding.

site_title: Luxury developer Candy may bid for massive swath of London land
summary: A group led by luxury property developer Nicholas Candy is considering a bid for Capital & Counties Properties Plc, a company struggling to sell its London land holdings. The bid comes as the company's shares have risen 8% in London, valuing it at £2.3 billion. Candy has held talks with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund about a joint takeover. An offer is expected to be made by November 18, although no certainty exists. The company's Earls Court holdings, valued at £389 million, have seen significant price cuts since 2015 amidst London's longest prime real estate slump.

site_title: US wins ownership of seized North Korean vessel
summary: The US Justice Department has awarded ownership of a seized North Korean cargo ship, the Wise Honest, to the US government. The vessel was seized for violating international sanctions and was carrying a $3 million shipment of coal in Indonesian waters last year. The court ordered the vessel to be forfeited to the US government, ending its use in a "criminal scheme". The decision comes as nuclear talks between the US and North Korea remain deadlocked.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by China-US trade hopes, pound stands ground
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by growing optimism that China and the US will sign a partial trade deal next month. China had begun promised purchases of farm goods, and the US and China are on the same page about the intent to work towards phase one of a 'deal' by mid-November. The pound held firm around five-month highs as dealers bet Britain will leave the EU with a Brexit agreement, with traders cautiously optimistic about the government's chances of passing the bill through parliament.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.66 points to 1,570.27, with 52.48 million lots traded at RM19.52 million. The market saw a 100-49 gainers-to-losers ratio.

site_title: Trudeau's Liberals to form minority government: TV projections
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's Liberals are set to form a minority government after winning 145 electoral districts, compared to 107 for Andrew Scheer and the Conservatives, according to preliminary election results. Trudeau's first term was marked by controversies, including ethics lapses and racist incidents. The Liberals' minority government will likely require coalition support to pass legislation. Trudeau's victory comes despite a grueling election campaign and challenges to his leadership.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.33% on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street and boosted by progress in China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 26,813.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. Despite recent US threats, traders remain optimistic about the market's rally.

site_title: Infosys dives most in 6 years as whistleblowers target CEO
summary: Infosys shares plummeted 16% on Tuesday, their biggest intraday fall since 2013, following allegations of "unethical practices" by CEO Salil Parekh. Whistleblowers accused Parekh of boosting profits through irregular accounting and questionable revenue margins, prompting Chairman Nandan Nilekani to pledge a full investigation. The allegations have raised concerns about the company's pristine brand and potential impact on short-term sales, with analysts warning of a challenging business environment for the IT services industry.

site_title: China, US made progress in trade talks: Chinese vice foreign minister
summary: China and the US have made progress in trade talks, according to Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng, who stated that as long as both sides respect each other, no problem cannot be resolved. Le emphasized the importance of openness in international relations, warning against a "de-coupling" of countries or a new Cold War. This comes as the world seeks an end to the ongoing trade war between the two nations.

site_title: UOB unveils programme to link businesses, consumers with solar firms
summary: UOB has launched U-Solar, a programme connecting Asian businesses and individuals with solar companies to help clients switch to solar power. The platform, initially launched in Malaysia, offers installation and financing solutions for solar power systems, as well as financial solutions and loans. The bank aims to address concerns about upfront capital and costs, providing flexible repayment plans at competitive market rates. The programme is expected to be rolled out in Singapore and other South-east Asia countries later this year.

site_title: Probe ordered into 'industrial' slaughter of Aussie racehorses
summary: A government inquiry has been ordered to examine the "industrial scale" killing of Australian racehorses, following an outcry over alleged animal cruelty. An investigation by the national broadcaster ABC found that thousands of retired racehorses were being secretly slaughtered for human consumption and pet food, with footage showing workers beating and abusing horses. The racing industry has condemned the mistreatment and called for reforms. The Queensland Racing Integrity Commission will oversee the probe, expected to report its findings in early 2020.

images.alt_text: The secret and "industrial scale" killing of retired Australian racehorses will be examined in a government inquiry, officials said Tuesday, after an outcry over alleged animal cruelty.

site_title: Sequoia-backed fashion startup Zilingo to pump US$100m into new US ops
summary: Zilingo, a fashion technology platform backed by Sequoia Capital, is investing $100 million in its US operations to digitally transform the fashion supply chain. The investment will support hiring staff and improve manufacturing processes, making responsible manufacturing faster and more accessible for US retailers. Zilingo plans to enter new markets including Australia, Europe, and the Middle East, and is valued at $970 million following its latest funding round. The company aims to level the playing field in fashion by providing a fair, transparent, and affordable supply chain for businesses of all sizes.

site_title: S$38m public-private partnership launched for hyper-personalised manufacturing
summary: Singapore has launched a S$38 million public-private partnership to develop hyper-personalized manufacturing solutions, with the goal of enabling firms to produce products with "minimum order quantities of one". The initiative, led by A*Star's Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre, will partner industry players to build a smart, scalable, automated factory line for fast-moving consumer goods. The project aims to support the growth of Industry 4.0 in South-east Asia, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat calling for regional cooperation to attract companies and build capabilities.

site_title: Australian IPO market on tenterhooks after deals pulled
summary: Australia's IPO market is on edge after two failed listings in two weeks, including a highly anticipated float by PropertyGuru, backed by TPG Capital and KKR & Co. Fund managers are skeptical about valuations, citing a weak domestic economy and global recession concerns. Despite a record low interest rate, the market has seen a significant decline in IPOs, with just $416 million raised in the year to September. Bankers are working on new listings, including Onsite Rental and Retail Zoo, but investors are cautious due to market uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares jump 1.1% at Tuesday's open to 3,172.15
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% at the open on Tuesday, driven by major corporate developments from the previous day. Singtel rose 1.6%, Keppel Corp surged 13.9% after Temasek Holdings' partial offer to acquire a 30.55% stake, and Sembcorp Marine extended its rally. Analysts predict a possible merger between Keppel O&M and SembMarine, which could lead to consolidation in the offshore & marine sector. Other key movers included OCBC Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and Spackman Entertainment Group.

site_title: Banks must reinvent themselves before next downturn: McKinsey
summary: McKinsey warns that a third of banks globally are unlikely to survive a serious economic downturn due to weakened investor confidence, tightening margins, and slow revenue growth. The consultancy advises banks to reinvent themselves by investing in AI-driven risk analytics, cutting costs, and improving customer services to grow revenue. This may involve mergers and acquisitions, outsourcing, and seeking new revenue sources to prepare for digital disruption.

site_title: Hard Rock CEO ponders buying a hotel on the Las Vegas strip
summary: Hard Rock International Inc CEO Jim Allen is considering buying a hotel on the Las Vegas Strip, a possibility that aligns with the company's expansion plans. Allen mentioned Caesars' Planet Hollywood and Bally's casino as potential targets, but ruled out the Cosmopolitan resort. The company's US$1.5 billion casino expansion in Florida is set to open this week, and Allen believes Las Vegas would be a great opportunity for the brand.

site_title: Olam buys US almond processor and its real estate assets for US$54m
summary: Olam International has acquired US almond processor Hughson Nut Inc and its real estate assets for US$54 million. The deal will provide Olam with integrated almond processing capabilities across the US, Australia, and Vietnam, enhancing its value chain offerings. HNI's facilities include two primary processing plants and an ingredients processing plant with steam sterilisation and pasteurisation facilities. The acquisition is expected to complement Olam's existing capabilities and strengthen its position in the almond market.

site_title: Japan emperor to complete enthronement in ritual-bound ceremony
summary: Japan's Emperor Naruhito completed a series of ritual-bound ceremonies to officially proclaim his enthronement on the Chrysanthemum throne, amidst the aftermath of deadly Typhoon Hagibis. The ceremonies, attended by foreign dignitaries, marked the end of the transition to his new role, following his father's abdication in 200 years. The events were scaled back due to the typhoon, but Naruhito began the day by "reporting" his enthronement to deities and ancestors. The ceremonies included a proclamation, a banqueting event, and a pardon for over half a million people convicted of minor offenses.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars extend rally, near major resistance
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars continue their rally, with the Aussie reaching a five-week high of US$0.6883 and the kiwi reaching a five-week high of US$0.6435. Optimism over Sino-US trade talks and the Brexit standoff is driving the rally, with investors betting that a deal will be reached, reducing the risk of a hard Brexit. As a result, bond yields have risen, with Australian 10-year yields up to 1.18% and New Zealand 10-year yields up to 1.35%.

site_title: MLT proposes private placement to raise some S$250m
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) is proposing a private placement to raise around S$250 million, with new units priced between S$1.579 and S$1.617 per unit. The funds will partially fund acquisitions of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China, worth S$493.4 million. The remaining funds will cover professional fees and expenses. The trust's manager has also announced an advanced distribution for the period from Oct 1 to Nov 1, with a quantum of between 2.695 and 2.715 cents per unit.

site_title: China asks WTO for US$2.4b sanctions against US in latest clash
summary: China is seeking $2.4 billion in retaliatory sanctions against the US for failing to comply with a World Trade Organization ruling on tariffs imposed on Chinese solar panels, wind towers, and steel cylinders. The WTO's Dispute Settlement Body will review the case on October 28. The US had challenged the validity of the ruling, potentially sending the matter to arbitration. This dispute highlights the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, with the US accusing China of benefiting from easier treatment at the WTO while subsidizing manufactured goods.

site_title: Hot stocks: Keppel soars 16%, SembMarine up 2% on the back of Temasek bid
summary: Temasek has made a surprise S$4 billion partial offer for Keppel Corp, potentially raising its stake to 51% and reigniting market speculation of a consolidation in Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector. Keppel shares soared 15.9% and Sembcorp Marine jumped 1.5%. Analysts deem the offer "reasonable" and "fair", with some predicting a strategic review of businesses and potential transactions. Temasek plans to work with Keppel's board on a comprehensive review to create sustainable shareholder value, fuelling speculation of a merger between Keppel and SembMarine.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Tuesday for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Japan were closed on Tuesday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, in the Asia-Pacific region, traders largely disregarded US President Donald Trump's latest threats to extend a stock rally. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. An eSIM platform, Airalo, raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over US$1 billion. A Dutch firm also initiated a privatization process for Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, CMT, MLT, Ascott Reit, A-HTrust, FCOT
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include ST Engineering, which secured new contracts worth S$1.8 billion, and Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT), which posted a 17.6% increase in net property income. Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) also reported a 3.4% increase in DPU, while proposing a private placement to raise S$250 million. Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) received overwhelming support for a merger, and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) had an unchanged DPU.

site_title: Fears are growing among mainland Chinese living in Hong Kong
summary: Mainland Chinese living in Hong Kong are growing fearful due to the increasingly violent protests. Many have stopped speaking Mandarin in public, avoiding potential confrontations, and some have even considered relocating back to the mainland. Professionals from the mainland, who make up over 1 million of the population, are divided between sympathizing with protesters and aligning with Beijing. The tensions have led to clashes between mainlanders and locals, with some gangs targeting Chinese businesses and individuals. The situation has become so dire that some are seeking to leave the city, with many considering moving to Canada.

site_title: SkillsFuture Singapore partners Bosch Rexroth for SME training centre; starts engineer bootcamp
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore has partnered with Bosch Rexroth to establish a training centre for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the advanced manufacturing sector. The centre, set to open by 2020, will provide mentorship, skills training, and proof-of-concept projects to SMEs. Additionally, a rapid upskilling programme, the SkillsFuture Work-Learn Bootcamp for Engineer 4.0, has been launched to train up to 200 engineering talent over two years, focusing on industry-demand skills such as lean manufacturing and IoT.

site_title: Facebook steps up security amid fresh signs of Russia meddling
summary: Facebook has tightened its security for the 2020 US elections amid signs of fresh Russian meddling, including attacks on Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, and Kamala Harris. The social network has taken down more accounts for "inauthentic" activity and will label messages from state-controlled media outlets. Facebook also plans to curb the spread of misinformation by using a pop-up on Instagram debunked by fact-checkers. The company has removed four networks of accounts from Russia and Iran for "coordinated inauthentic behavior" and offers new protections for candidate accounts.

site_title: Independent hotels are disappearing as chains grow
summary: Independent hotels are declining as large hotel chains expand their soft brands, which offer marketing power and resources to affiliated hotels. Thirty years ago, about two-thirds of hotels were independently owned, but now less than 40% are. Chains like Accor and Marriott are acquiring independent hotels, and some join as affiliates to tap into their marketing power. This trend is also driven by competition from Airbnb, which is adding to the alternative lodging market, driving down prices and making it harder for independent hotels to operate.

site_title: Netanyahu says cannot form Israel government, allowing opponent to try
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has informed President Reuven Rivlin that he cannot form a new government following the deadlocked September elections, allowing his opponent Benny Gantz to try. Netanyahu blames Gantz for refusing to negotiate on his preferred terms, while Gantz claims he cannot negotiate based on those terms. Gantz will face long odds in forming a government, and if unsuccessful, President Rivlin could ask a majority of parliament members to agree on a candidate.

site_title: Democrats seek probe of market bets timed to Trump moves
summary: US Democratic lawmakers are urging authorities to investigate potential insider trading by traders who may have timed their market moves in response to President Donald Trump's remarks. The senators claim some traders made over $1 billion per trade, just ahead of Trump's comments or administration actions, suggesting a possible unfair trading advantage. The lawmakers express concerns about the integrity of financial markets and public institutions, raising questions about the potential manipulation of market prices.

site_title: No more delays, UK PM Johnson appeals to parliament to back Brexit bill
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson appealed to parliament to approve his Brexit bill, urging lawmakers to avoid further delays and approve the deal by October 31. Johnson secured a new deal, which he claims will allow Britain to move forward on issues like healthcare and education. Parliament has set hurdles for the bill, and opposition lawmakers are concerned about the government's plan to rush it through. Johnson's team believes he has the numbers to pass the bill, but the outcome remains uncertain as lawmakers debate the bill's passage.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson appealed to lawmakers on Monday to approve his Brexit bill this week, saying neither he, the European Union or the public wanted any more delays to Britain's departure from the bloc.

site_title: Trump says 'phase 1' China trade pact on track for November
summary: US President Donald Trump announced progress in the development of the partial trade pact with China, known as "phase one," which he expects to sign in November. The mini-deal includes increased Chinese purchases of American farm exports and covers intellectual property, financial services, and currency exchange. However, US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed caution, stating that the US side is not rushing to sign the deal and wants to ensure it's the right agreement. The deal aims to ease tensions in the ongoing trade war between the US and China.

site_title: Paris reveals golden Marianne logo for 2024 Olympics
summary: The logo for the 2024 Olympics and Paralympics, featuring the Olympic flame within a gold medal with the golden Marianne symbol, was unveiled in Paris. The art deco design incorporates the French Republic's personification, Marianne, and marks a break from the previous colourful Eiffel Tower '24' logo. The golden Marianne represents the objective of putting people at the heart of the Games, honouring French culture and creativity, and welcoming the world to Paris in 2024.

images.alt_text: The logo for the 2024 Olympics and Paralympics, depicting the Olympic flame within a gold medal, was unveiled in host city Paris on Monday.

site_title: Chile orders new curfew as violent protests rage
summary: Chile has ordered a new overnight curfew for the third consecutive day as violent protests and looting continue to rage across the country. The curfew, announced by Army General Javier Iturriaga, comes after 11 people were killed and over 1,500 detained in the past two days. The protests, sparked by a metro fare hike, have turned into anger against President Sebastian Pinera and the military, with demonstrators demanding action on social inequality and economic issues. The country is under a state of emergency, with troops deployed onto the streets, and thousands of people remain stranded due to flight cancellations.

site_title: Boeing's 737 Max crisis deepens, hitting shares
summary: Boeing's 737 Max crisis deepened as newly-released documents raised questions about the company's handling of a key flight handling system implicated in two crashes that killed 346 people. The Federal Aviation Administration sharply criticized Boeing for withholding key documents for months, leading to a downgrade of the company's shares. The FAA's rebuke added to the pressure on Boeing's leadership, with speculation growing that CEO Dennis Muilenburg could be ousted. The company's board is set to conclude a meeting ahead of the company's earnings release and a congressional hearing, amid calls for a leadership shakeup and potential production pause on the 737 Max.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on trade progress; Boeing tumbles
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as optimism over US-China trade talks and upcoming earnings reports boosted markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.7% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.9%. Boeing tumbled 3.8% after the FAA criticized the company for not providing key documents in the 737 Max. Despite this, other stocks, including Apple and large banks, advanced. US President Donald Trump expects to sign a partial trade pact with China next month, citing progress in developing a preliminary agreement.

site_title: US dollar underpinned by trade optimism; pound steady
summary: The US dollar remains steady, supported by optimism over US-China trade talks, while the pound holds steady near a 5-1/2-month high due to Brexit uncertainty. The Canadian dollar rises as voters go to the polls in a closely-fought election, and trade-exposed currencies like the Australian and New Zealand dollars also gain ground. US President Donald Trump suggests tariffs scheduled for December could be withdrawn if progress is made in negotiations, while Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He expresses a willingness to approach talks from a basis of mutual respect.

images.alt_text: Signs that the US and China were making progress in efforts to resolve their trade dispute supported both the dollar and trade-exposed Asian currencies on Tuesday, while the Canadian dollar rose as voters went to the polls in a closely-fought election.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust declares stable Q4 DPU of 2.4 S cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a stable quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.4 Singapore cents for Q4 2019, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also remained flat, growing 1.3% and 0.5% respectively. The Reit's manager attributed the growth to higher rental incomes and lower expenses, while offsetting it with higher amortisation and property tax. The distribution will be paid out on November 29, with a flat full-year DPU of 9.6 Singapore cents.

site_title: Uganda says its economy 11% larger after rebasing
summary: Uganda's economy has been revised to be 11.6% larger than previously thought, with a new gross domestic product (GDP) figure of 122.7 trillion shillings at the end of the 2018/2019 fiscal year. The country rebased its calculations to 2016/2017 from 2009/2010 to capture new sectors such as oil and gold. The revised GDP figure increases Uganda's room to borrow, but economists caution against a move citing stagnant revenue growth, which is expected to rise above 50% of GDP by 2021/22.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% as global demand concerns grow
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 1% on Monday due to concerns over the US-China trade war and a slowing global economy. US oil prices dropped 0.9% to $53.31 a barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 0.8% to $58.96 a barrel. The US commerce secretary, Wilbur Ross, expressed concerns that a trade deal may not be finalized by November's Apec summit, adding to worries about reduced oil demand.

site_title: Alphabet's virus scanner: Misuse can leak data
summary: Alphabet's virus scanner, VirusTotal, has been found to be misused by companies, leaking sensitive data such as factory blueprints and intellectual property online. Thousands of unprotected files from pharmaceutical, industrial, automotive, and food industries were discovered, including confidential documents that could be used to infiltrate production floors. The misuse occurred due to companies uploading files indiscriminately without understanding the terms of use, raising concerns about the potential risk of data breaches and cyber attacks.

site_title: Keeping nimble to stay the course
summary: Soilbuild Group, a Singapore-based real estate company, aims to stay nimble in the face of economic uncertainty by reviewing sectors and geographies. The company's director, Lim Han Qin, notes that Singapore's economy could be headed for a recession, which is why it's crucial to recalibrate and shorten investment to sales cycles. Soilbuild has diversified its sectors and geographies, with a focus on industrial, green, and sustainable projects. The company has also prioritized innovation, investing in new construction methods and technologies to improve productivity. Its corporate culture emphasizes equity, fairness, and mutual trust with stakeholders.

site_title: Saks Fifth Avenue owner Hudson's Bay in US$1.5b deal to go private
summary: Hudson's Bay Co, owner of Saks Fifth Avenue, agreed to a C$1.9 billion (US$1.98 billion) deal to go private after a shareholder group led by executive chairman Richard Baker sweetened its offer to C$10.30 per share. The deal, which values the company at a third of its 2015 worth, aims to take the struggling Canadian department store operator private amid challenges in brick-and-mortar retail. The offer must be approved by a majority of non-affiliated shareholders, with a 27% stake required for approval.

site_title: OCBC seeks more green loans to maintain lead in S-E Asia
summary: OCBC Bank aims to expand its lending to environmentally-friendly projects, aiming for a sustainable finance portfolio of S$10 billion by 2022. The bank has already participated in over US$500 million of green lending this year and is building a team to focus on sustainable financing. OCBC's head of structured and sustainable finance, Mike Ng, notes that there is greater awareness and pressure on companies to adopt environmentally-focused loans, but Asia still has a long way to go in terms of sustainable debt, accounting for just 21% of global sustainable debt.

site_title: SoftBank in talks to take control of WeWork
summary: Japan-based SoftBank is in talks to acquire a controlling stake in WeWork, providing the shared office space startup with desperately needed funding at a slashed valuation of $8 billion. SoftBank is ready to invest $4-$5 billion, taking a majority stake in WeWork, and valuing it at $47 billion, down from earlier this year. The deal would limit the influence of co-founder Adam Neumann, who stepped down as CEO amid questions over self-dealing and personal conduct. WeWork needs to raise at least $3 billion to cover its financing needs through the end of the year.

site_title: Building a business and community through empathy
summary: Lee Li Ping, founder of Sogurt, created a community for her female employees by connecting personally with them, fostering a "safe space" for bonding and growth. This approach improved employee performance and helped them overcome barriers. After consolidating outlets, Sogurt introduced a new concept, KARA Cafe and Dessert Bar, which hosts community events. With a focus on locally-produced frozen yogurt and mentorship, Sogurt continues to build a community and fulfill its mission of creating "healthy individuals, families, and communities."

site_title: Retail woes have warmed tenant-landlord relationship
summary: CapitaLand Group's president, Jason Leow, discussed the company's approach to treating retail tenants as partners. The group provides support through advising on storefront design and technology, hosting seminars, and helping tenants achieve success. This collaborative approach has improved the tenant-landlord relationship, with retailers benefiting from the partnership. Leow stated that when retailers do well, CapitaLand does well, emphasizing the mutual benefit of their relationship. This shift in approach is a positive development for retail tenants.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering secured new contracts worth S$1.8 billion in its aerospace and electronics sectors for the third quarter of 2019. Sen Yue Holdings raised about S$6 million from a research and development company through a subscription of new shares at S$0.05 each. These developments are expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's earnings per share, but Sen Yue Holdings' enlarged share capital will now represent 13.88% of its existing capital.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise amid Brexit tussle as focus shifts to earnings
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Monday amid hopes that Britain will avoid a disorderly exit from the EU, while positive corporate updates and US-China trade talks added to the upbeat mood. The Stoxx 600 index ended the session higher, despite a strong pound weighing on London's FTSE 100. Business software group SAP's shares gained 2.5% after reaching a deal with Microsoft, and defensive sectors such as miners and banks led the gains. Investors await third-quarter report cards from European firms to assess their health amid Brexit and trade uncertainties.

site_title: Money FM podcast: CSR in the food & beverage industry - Fika, Konditori, Lickety
summary: Claressa Monteiro spoke to Tasneem Noor, Managing Director and Founder of Fika Swedish Cafe and Bistro, Konditori Artisan European Bakery and Lickety Waffles and Ice Cream, about corporate responsibility in the food and beverage industry. Noor discussed the challenges of sustainability and social responsibility in their business operations, and how they strive to give back to the community. The conversation highlighted the importance of CSR in the industry, with Noor citing initiatives such as reducing waste and supporting local suppliers.

site_title: Unitholders give overwhelming support to merger of Ascott Reit, A-HTrust
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) have received overwhelming support for their proposed merger, with both entities passing resolutions in their respective extraordinary general meetings. The move aims to create a leading hospitality trust in Singapore.

site_title: Embrace thematic investment, steer clear of value play: CPR AM fund manager
summary: CPR Asset Management's deputy head of global thematics equities, Estelle Menard, advises investors to steer clear of value stocks due to challenging economic conditions and focus on long-term growth opportunities in thematic funds. Thematic funds, which track macro trends such as innovation and socio-economic factors, have shown resilience during market downturns. CPR AM manages over $15.2 billion in thematic investments, with a focus on 10-year cycles, and has integrated ESG factors into its funds since 2017. The firm plans to launch new themes in Europe and Asia, capitalizing on growing demand for thematic investment funds.

site_title: WeWork rescue plan could backfire on SoftBank
summary: SoftBank is considering a US$8 billion rescue package for WeWork, a significant haircut from the company's original valuation of US$47 billion. The deal could benefit SoftBank, but harm existing shareholders, who may see their stakes diluted and investment value slashed. WeWork's board is weighing two options: the SoftBank equity deal and a debt package from JPMorgan Chase. However, SoftBank's reputation is under scrutiny, with Japan's Finance Ministry planning to close a tax-avoidance loophole used by SoftBank, potentially eroding trust and access to future funding.

site_title: Using data to rethink the architecture of transport
summary: The European Union is rethinking the architecture of transport, focusing on digitalization and intelligent transport systems (ITS) to make mobility more efficient and sustainable. The EU aims to promote cleaner, alternative fuels, and has set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions from new cars and lorries. Digitalization is key to enabling shared, collaborative, and multimodal services, and the EU is working to accommodate drones in its airspace through the "U-space" system. Collaboration with like-minded partners, such as Singapore, is crucial for achieving these goals, particularly in developing international standards and regulations.

site_title: Indonesia seeks to increase coffee output amid world glut
summary: Indonesia aims to boost its coffee output, expecting 50-60% more beans within the next five years, amid a global glut. The country, the world's third-largest robusta producer, plans to increase supply to meet growing demand, particularly in China, where coffee consumption has surged ninefold in the past decade. To achieve this, the government and industry stakeholders will work together to improve productivity, use fertilizers, and protect crops from pests and diseases.

site_title: Vanuatu citizen pays S$32m for TwentyOne Angullia Park penthouse
summary: A Vanuatu citizen, Xie Zhijing, has paid S$32 million for a penthouse at TwentyOne Angullia Park in Singapore, with a price of S$4,146 per square foot. This is 25% lower than the S$42.9 million paid by fugitive Malaysian financier Jho Low in 2013. The 54-unit project, which received a Temporary Occupation Permit in 2014, has seen parties from China purchasing high-end condo units in recent months, including a S$20 million deal for a unit at The Ritz-Carlton Residences, Singapore.

site_title: Renault's weaker outlook raises the odds for a deal on Nissan stake
summary: Renault's worsening financial situation has raised the possibility of selling its 43% stake in Nissan Motor Co, potentially easing strained relations between the two companies. A profit warning and management shakeup have led analysts to suggest that Renault may consider asset sales, including its Nissan shares, to defend its balance sheet. The move could resolve the lopsided cross-shareholding structure at the heart of a dispute between the partners, allowing for deeper operational ties and investment in electric and autonomous cars.

site_title: Minimising environmental impact
summary: Two Singaporean companies, BIG Tiny and Amici Events and Catering, are making significant strides in protecting the environment through their business models. BIG Tiny offers eco-friendly tiny houses on wheels in rural settings, reducing carbon footprint by up to 48% and providing a sustainable income source for local farmers. Amici Events and Catering reduces plastic waste by using biodegradable utensils and encourages the use of eco-friendly materials, earning it a spot as an Honouree in the "Environment - Managing Environmental Impact" category at the Brands for Good Awards.

site_title: Mahathir warns of possible trade sanctions on Malaysia
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad warned that his country could face trade sanctions due to its reliance on exports and its position in the US-China tariff war. He expressed disappointment in the increasing protectionism and stated that Malaysia is caught in the middle, economically linked to both markets. The US and China are among Malaysia's top export destinations, and the country is also facing challenges from European countries and India due to diplomatic tensions over palm oil exports. Mahathir urged regional cooperation to mitigate the impact of rising protectionism.

site_title: Heng calls for more industry-higher education tie-ups
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat launched a research collaboration between chipmaker GlobalFoundries, Nanyang Technological University, and the National Research Foundation, with a focus on developing a new data-storage technology using 12-inch wafers. The project, valued at S$120 million, aims to create "more good jobs" in Singapore's manufacturing sector. Heng emphasized the importance of industry-higher education tie-ups in driving innovation and economic growth, citing the potential to retain high-value advanced manufacturing as a core pillar of Singapore's economy.

site_title: It looks like blockchain's time hasn't come
summary: Blockchain technology faces significant obstacles to widespread adoption, despite its potential to revolutionize industries. Five key challenges must be addressed: governance, scalability, standards, liability, and transparency and identity. Governance issues, such as the lack of a central authority, hinder decision-making and update processes, while scalability limitations prevent blockchains from handling large transaction volumes. Standards for transaction data structure and liability concerns must also be established. Furthermore, blockchain's transparency and anonymity features pose a risk to users' identities and trust. Until these challenges are resolved, blockchain's potential to transform the financial system remains unfulfilled.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Key Singapore stock market developments include CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth, and OCBC CEO Helen Wong's retirement with Tan Teck Long as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Tesla marked its formal India entry, and Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts are optimistic about SGX earnings, raising target prices, despite Chinese banks stumbling on Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Keppel faces shake-up with Temasek's bid for control
summary: Temasek Holdings, Singapore's state-owned investment firm, has made a surprise S$4 billion partial offer to acquire an additional 30.55% of shares in Keppel Corp, giving it a 51% stake in the conglomerate. The offer price is a 26% premium over Keppel's last traded price, with a distant long-stop date of October 21, 2020. Temasek plans to conduct a strategic business review, potentially leading to the consolidation of Keppel's offshore & marine (O&M) assets, a move analysts see as a prelude to a merger with Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: Qantas, Virgin Australia get slots at Haneda Airport
summary: Qantas and Virgin Australia have been awarded one slot each to operate flights at Tokyo's Haneda Airport. The decision comes as Virgin Australia's new CEO aims to restructure the airline's route network. Virgin Australia plans to operate a daily service between Brisbane and Haneda starting in March next year, with a codeshare agreement with ANA Holdings. A final decision by the International Air Services Commission is expected after a submission deadline on October 24.

site_title: China's open moves to tap overseas Chinese influence
summary: China is intensifying its efforts to sway overseas Chinese influence in favor of a Beijing-friendly candidate in Taiwan's upcoming presidential election. The country has successfully stripped Taiwan of its diplomatic allies, now having only 15 governments that maintain relations with Taipei. China has also strengthened its global influence through its Overseas Chinese Affairs Office, which aims to secure support for reunification with Taiwan. President Xi Jinping emphasized the shared ideals of all Chinese people, regardless of nationality, in his National Day address, highlighting the importance of ethnic Chinese identity.

site_title: UBS cutting 40 banking jobs in Asia
summary: UBS is cutting about 40 jobs in its Asia-Pacific region, primarily in markets and investment-banking teams, with a majority at the vice-president or below level. The staff reductions are smaller compared to planned cuts in Europe, as UBS views the region as a growth driver. This is part of a global restructuring effort, which also includes combining trading units and reshuffling senior management.

site_title: Start small and use standards wisely in Industry 4.0 game
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can adopt Industry 4.0 technology in manageable phases to build capabilities incrementally. By developing a roadmap with incremental milestones, SMEs can implement I4.0 solutions in bite-sized phases. Adopting standards, such as Open Platform Communications Unified Architecture (OPC UA), can also facilitate seamless integration of new solutions with existing systems, reducing the need for additional equipment. Additionally, SMEs can benefit from managing information security through frameworks like ISO/IEC 27001, ensuring the safe exchange of information with stakeholders.

site_title: Japan exports shrink for 10th month; BOJ could hit 'ease' button next week
summary: Japan's exports contracted for the 10th consecutive month in September, with a 5.2% drop from the previous year, driven by reduced car and airplane parts shipments to the US and semiconductor production equipment to South Korea. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in global demand, particularly from China, Japan's largest trading partner. The Bank of Japan may ease monetary policy as early as next week to support the economy, which has been hit by a global recession.

site_title: Market abuzz over partial offer for Keppel
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 0.8% to 3,139.15, outperforming regional indices, despite uncertainty surrounding the Brexit saga. Other Asian markets saw limited gains, with China's Shanghai Composite Index up 0.5% and Hong Kong's indices flat. The Singapore market's strong performance was a notable exception.

site_title: IEA: Booming green power not enough to meet climate targets
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that the growth of green power is not enough to meet climate targets, citing a 50% increase in renewable energy capacity by 2024. This represents a 1,200-gigawatt expansion, but the agency believes more is needed to slow global warming. Countries must accelerate their use of renewable energy sources to meet the goals set in the Paris Agreement.

images.alt_text: Distributed solar - panels that are placed on homes, offices and factories - is set to soar as costs come down. Much of the expansion will be at commercial and industrial sites.

site_title: Venezuela's Guaido holds 'exploratory' talks with China, Russia: envoy
summary: Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaido has held "exploratory" talks with China and Russia, seeking their help to end the country's political crisis. Guaido, who is widely recognized as the country's legitimate leader, has met with Chinese delegations in Caracas, asking for their assistance. The talks come as Venezuela's economy continues to crumble under the leadership of President Nicolas Maduro. Guaido's diplomatic representative, Teresa Belandria, announced the meetings, which are seen as a significant development in the country's ongoing struggle for stability.

images.alt_text: Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaido has asked China and Russia to help end a political crisis crippling the Latin American country during "exploratory" talks, his diplomatic representative in Brazil said on Monday.

site_title: Russian hackers hijacked Iranian spying operation, officials say
summary: Russian hackers, known as "Turla", hijacked an Iranian cyber-espionage operation, using Iranian tools and infrastructure to hack into organizations in at least 20 countries over 18 months. The operation masqueraded as an Iranian attack, targeting government and industry organizations. British officials say Turla developed new attacks and methods to cover its tracks, warning of the dangers of wrongly attributing cyberattacks. The incident highlights the use of "fourth party collection" by Western allies, where foreign cyberattacks are used to facilitate spying operations.

site_title: Successes that grew out of setbacks, missteps
summary: Two Singaporean entrepreneurs, Wong Peck Lin and Mervin Wee, will share their success stories at the SGSME Networking and Fireside Chat. Wong Peck Lin, co-owner of Udders, overcame setbacks in her early business ventures, including a failed attempt to sell teak furniture and a short-lived health supplement business. She credits her ability to adapt and focus on consumer needs for Udders' breakthrough. Jean Yip group managing director Mervin Wee, on the other hand, expanded his company from a single salon to over 60 outlets, differentiating himself through staff training and personalized service. Both entrepreneurs will discuss how they overcame challenges to achieve success in their respective industries.

site_title: iPhone display supplier sees OLED smartphone deluge from 2021
summary: Japan Display Inc (JDI), a struggling supplier of mobile screens, expects to decide on whether to adopt next-generation OLED displays within the next year. Despite OLED panels offering slimmer, more energy-efficient, and higher contrast displays, JDI's liquid crystal displays (LCDs) will remain competitive in smartphones through 2021 due to their price advantage. JDI's CEO Minoru Kikuoka anticipates a shift to OLED technology may occur in 2021, but the company lacks the necessary capital to invest in mass production. Apple's iPhone 11 is the only LCD model in its 2019 lineup, with a potential second LCD model planned for 2020.

site_title: Building a solid foundation to help the environment
summary: Bamco, an eco-friendly flooring firm, was founded by Charles Lim after 30 years in the construction industry. The company's product, Bamcoflor, features a sustainable core layer made from bamboo-charcoal and a diamond layer resistant to corrosion and water. Bamcoflor is durable, easy to install, and can be reused or recycled. The company received the Singapore Green Building Product certification and was an Honouree at the Brands for Good 2019 Awards. Bamco plans to expand to the US market and has also launched additional product lines, furthering its mission to create sustainable and eco-friendly flooring solutions.

images.alt_text: President Joko Widodo with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the launch of the joint issue of commemorative stamps to mark 50 years of ties between the two countries on Thursday.
Charles Lim, founder of Bamco: "We want to show society the possibility of living modestly and being grounded in one's surroundings hassle-free."

site_title: Australia home prices keep rising as auctions heat up
summary: Australia's home prices are expected to rise by their strongest margin in two years as auctions heat up in Sydney and Melbourne. Record low interest rates and relaxed lending rules are driving demand. The recovery is a welcome boost to the economy, which has been weakened by a two-year downturn. This surge in housing prices is a positive sign for household wealth and confidence, potentially leading to increased consumption and business earnings.

site_title: Gojek's 35-year-old chief to join Jokowi's new Cabinet
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has appointed 35-year-old Gojek co-founder Nadiem Makarim to his new Cabinet, marking the importance of the internet sector in Southeast Asia's economy. Makarim resigned as Gojek CEO, citing his mission to display Indonesia on the world stage, now taking on a Cabinet post. This appointment is seen as a nod to the president's desire to include professionals and millennials in his second-term team, and is expected to have minimal disruption to Gojek's operations.

site_title: Opening private equity access to retail investors levels playing field
summary: Singapore's private equity market has been opened up to retail investors through the "Preferred Access" structure by CapBridge and 1exchange, a regulated private securities exchange. This move aims to level the playing field for all investors, regardless of ticket size, by enabling retail investors to participate in private equity investments on the same terms as accredited and institutional investors. Retail investors can invest in pre-IPO, mature, or late-stage growth private companies with clear exit plans, offering a lower ticket size and potential for upside.

site_title: Promoting and upholding responsible business in Asean
summary: The ASEAN Responsible and Inclusive Business Alliance (ARIBA) was launched to promote responsible, inclusive, and sustainable enterprises in the region. ARIBA, a joint initiative of the ASEAN Business Advisory Council and the ASEAN Corporate Social Responsibility Network, aims to establish a network of businesses to support corporate social responsibility. The alliance seeks to educate businesses on the benefits of operating responsibly while turning a profit, and provide a platform for members to share information and best practices. ARIBA's goal is to create a prosperous and healthy society where businesses can contribute to the well-being of society while being profitable.

site_title: Channelling capital for the greater good
summary: GTR Ventures, a Singapore-based investment firm, supports the development of innovative trade finance solutions through its investments in technology companies. The firm aims to guide its investee companies towards achieving sustainable goals, aligning with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. By screening over 100 deals annually, GTR Ventures steers its investee firms towards ESG outcomes, providing comfort to later-stage impact investors. The company was honoured with the Capital for Good honour at this year's Brands for Good Awards.

site_title: China's home price growth steady, fewer cities post gains
summary: China's home prices grew 0.5% in September, the slowest pace since February, as fewer cities reported gains. Despite this, prices rose 8.4% from a year earlier, and the property sector remains a bright spot in the economy. Regulators are cautious about stimulating the sector due to high debt and bubble risk, and have vowed to refrain from loosening monetary policy. Some cities, such as Nanning, showed signs of rapid price growth, while others are experiencing cooling trends, with local governments being given more autonomy to make policy decisions.

site_title: MLT's Q2 DPU up 3.4% on contributions from new, existing assets
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 3.4% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.025 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from new and existing assets. Gross revenue rose 14.2% to S$121.8 million, while net property income increased 21% to S$109.1 million. The trust also announced the proposed acquisition of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China for S$493.4 million, expected to be accretive to DPU and net asset value per unit.

site_title: NUS, Keppel and SLNG tie-up to develop cooling tech for data centres
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS), Keppel Data Centres, and the Singapore LNG Corporation (SLNG) have teamed up to develop a novel, energy-efficient cooling technology for data centres. The Semiclathrate Thermal Energy Carrier System aims to boost power usage effectiveness by 20% and save space and construction costs. A prototype is expected to be designed, built, and operated by 2022, utilizing LNG cold energy from the Singapore LNG Terminal to offset energy demands in data centres.

site_title: After 50 years at Israeli orchestra, conductor Zubin Mehta takes final bow
summary: Conductor Zubin Mehta, 83, took his final bow after 50 years with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, retiring from the position. The emotional performance, which included Liszt's Piano Concerto No 2 and Mahler's Symphony No 2, was met with a long standing ovation. Mehta, who underwent cancer treatment last year, was succeeded by 30-year-old Lahav Shani and named musical director emeritus. Mehta, who conducted in poignant settings, including the Buchenwald concentration camp, will be remembered for his 3,000+ concerts with the orchestra.

site_title: Maleficent sequel dominates North American box office with US$36m haul
summary: Maleficent: Mistress of Evil, a Disney sequel, dominated the North American box office with a $36 million opening weekend, despite opening below projections. The film, starring Elle Fanning and Michelle Pfeiffer, easily outperformed competitors like Joker and Zombieland: Double Tap. The movie's success was attributed to its appeal to younger female moviegoers, with women making up 56% of ticket buyers. The film's international box office performance was also promising, with a global start of $150 million.

site_title: Dollar downbeat as Brexit optimism lifts pound and euro
summary: The dollar has fallen to its worst month since January 2018 due to Brexit optimism, pushing the pound to a 51/2 month high and keeping the euro strong. Despite a failed vote on a reworked Brexit deal, markets believe the UK is likely to pass the deal, reducing the risk of a no-deal Brexit. The pound briefly broke above US$1.30 for the first time in 51/2 months, while the euro hovered at US$1.1157 per euro.

site_title: Singapore malls roll out experiential attractions to draw customers
summary: Singapore's retail malls are evolving to attract customers by incorporating experiential and activity-based concepts, such as communal spaces and non-retail components, to boost footfall and maintain occupancy rates. In response to e-commerce disruption, malls are introducing focal points, pop-up retail, and omni-channel retailing to differentiate themselves and offer unique experiences that online retailers can't match. Examples include Funan Mall's rooftop Urban Farm and Jewel Changi Airport's iconic rain vortex, which attract crowds seeking Instagrammable moments.

site_title: Sakae to pick independent auditor to review disclaimer, applies for more time to hold AGM
summary: Sakae Holdings, a Singapore-based sushi restaurant operator, has applied for an extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) due to ongoing differences and disagreements with its independent auditor Deloitte & Touche. The auditor issued a disclaimer of opinion citing lack of audit evidence for certain associates. Sakae has begun appointing an independent auditor for a review of the disclaimer and has also applied to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) for an extension of time to hold its AGM.

site_title: GM contract terms may be a tougher fit for its rivals
summary: General Motors has reached a tentative contract with the United Automobile Workers union, which will raise the carmaker's labor costs and require a significant cash outlay. The deal includes higher wages, bonuses, and investments in US factories, with GM pledging $7.7 billion in US investments. The union is likely to push for similar terms with Ford Motor and Fiat Chrysler, which may find it more costly due to their existing plant structures. GM workers will vote on the contract this week, with a result expected on Friday, and will receive raises to reach the top wage of $32 an hour within four years.

site_title: Sen Yue to raise S$6m in share placement to new investor
summary: Sen Yue Holdings, a waste management firm listed on the Catalist, will raise approximately S$6 million through a share placement to Jiangmenshi Changxin Technology, with shares sold at S$0.05 each, a 72.4% premium to the previous day's volume-weighted average price. This represents 13.88% of the existing share capital and 12.19% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: Here's a guide on corporate activism
summary: UK business leaders are increasingly expected to take a stand on political issues, as the public demands more from CEOs. A framework has been developed to help leaders decide when to speak out, categorizing four possible stances: Forceful, Tempered, Pragmatic, and Neutral. Companies should assess the impact on their performance and core values before taking action. Some CEOs, like Marc Benioff and Tim Cook, have used their platforms to speak out on issues like LGBTQ+ rights and the environment, while others, like Delta Airlines, have faced backlash for not taking a stance. The framework advises companies to be clear and strategic in their approach, weighing the potential benefits and risks of speaking out.

site_title: Memo to Trump: Foreign policy is not a business transaction
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy approach has been criticized for being "transactional diplomacy," where he attempts to negotiate deals with rival nations through economic incentives and threats. However, this approach has failed to yield results, as seen in his failed attempts to denuclearize North Korea, renegotiate the Iran nuclear deal, and reach a deal with the Palestinians. The article concludes that nations do not operate like business corporations and are not swayed by economic pressure when their core interests are at stake, highlighting the need for a more traditional approach to foreign policy.

site_title: Eurokars adds UK brand MG to its Singapore dealership
summary: Eurokars Group has been appointed the official distributor in Singapore of British car brand MG by China's largest carmaker, SAIC Motor Corporation. Eurokars EV Pte Ltd will focus on retailing electric vehicles for the group in the long term. The new partnership will offer vehicle models like the MG HS, MG ZS, and electric models EZS and MG5 EV, and will help build a "strong foothold" in Singapore's fast-growing EV market. Eurokars Group will also introduce MG to its existing stable of luxury brands, including Porsche and Rolls-Royce.

site_title: Long-haul, fuel-efficient jets underpin demand at Las Vegas air show
summary: The world's largest business jet makers are showcasing their offerings at the NBAA annual corporate aircraft show in Las Vegas, amid a backdrop of slowing global economic growth and trade tensions. Despite this, deliveries of new business jets are expected to rise, fueled by the introduction of long-range models and sustainable aviation fuels. Industry analysts predict 7,600 new deliveries worth $248 billion from 2020 to 2029, with demand expected to remain cautious in the short and medium term.

site_title: UK speaker rules against government trying to get another vote on Brexit deal
summary: UK parliamentary speaker John Bercow ruled against the government's attempt to hold another vote on Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal, citing it as a repetition of a previous motion. Bercow advised the government to pursue legislation required for Britain's EU departure instead, rather than a straight 'yes or no' vote on the agreement.

site_title: ESR seeks up to HK$11.4 billion in year's second-biggest HK IPO
summary: ESR Cayman, a logistics real estate developer, is seeking up to HK$11.4 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), which could be Hong Kong's second-largest IPO this year. The company, which postponed its previous IPO attempt in June, has attracted Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System as a cornerstone investor. ESR aims to price the offering on October 25 and begin trading on November 1. The IPO is seen as a boost to Hong Kong's IPO market momentum, despite anti-government protests continuing to rock the city.

site_title: Global wealth expanding, despite challenges: Credit Suisse report
summary: Global wealth rose 2.6% to $360 trillion in 2019, driven by the US, China, and Europe. Wealth per adult in Singapore grew 4% to $297,870, making it one of the top economies with the highest wealth per adult. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to contribute 33% of global wealth growth in 2024, with the number of millionaires expected to rise 50% to 19 million. Non-financial assets drove growth, and millennials are expected to benefit from parental financial help and inheritance, despite being disadvantaged by high house prices and low incomes.

images.alt_text: Global wealth continues to rise, says the Credit Suisse Research Institute's Global Wealth Report 2019, despite the risks posed by the ongoing trade war and other geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Merchants hold key to growth of GrabFood Singapore
summary: GrabFood Singapore has identified its relationship with merchants as key to its growth. The company aims to help businesses lower operating costs and utilize digital resources. To achieve this, Grab has hired a top executive from the food industry to lead the charge. This move is part of Grab's efforts to engage merchants and support the sector's growth.

site_title: Tiger hints he'll pick himself for Presidents Cup
summary: Tiger Woods hinted that he may choose himself for a captain's pick in the upcoming Presidents Cup, citing his fitness being ahead of schedule after arthroscopic knee surgery. Woods stated that his season ended earlier than expected, but he had the procedure a little early and got ahead of it. He expressed confidence in his recovery and fitness, setting up the possibility of him picking himself for a spot on the US team.

site_title: Hong Kong leader apologises after police fire water cannon at mosque
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam apologized to the city's Muslim community after police fired a water cannon at a major mosque during operations to quell violent pro-democracy protests. The incident occurred on Sunday night, with police using tear gas and water cannons to disperse protesters. Lam visited the mosque on Monday, expressing her sorrow and thanking Islamic leaders for calling for calm. The police acknowledged the incident was a "mistake" and apologized, with Chief Imam Muhammad Arshad stating the Islamic community hoped to continue living in peace.

site_title: Jokowi asks opposition leader Prabowo to join Cabinet
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has asked opposition leader Prabowo Subianto to join his Cabinet, offering a ministerial post in the defense sector. Prabowo accepted the offer and confirmed his Gerindra party will fill a second post with Edhy Prabowo. The move is part of Widodo's plan to overhaul laws hindering investment and job creation, aiming to boost the economy to $7 trillion by 2045. A revamped Cabinet will be announced and sworn in on Wednesday, with several high-profile figures expected to join the team.

site_title: Helping others to succeed
summary: Three enterprises, Love & Respect Transformation Centre, DNR Wheels, and GEX Ventures, prioritize giving back to their communities. Love & Respect Transformation Centre offers education and mentorship programs to help individuals achieve their life and career goals, with a focus on marginalized communities. DNR Wheels improves the quality of lives by providing disability and rehabilitative equipment, employing people with disabilities, and offering customized products. GEX Ventures supports businesses in growth, leveraging technology to provide end-to-end solutions, while also creating wealth and impacting lives through its purpose-driven mission and charity partnerships.

site_title: US stocks edge higher despite big Boeing hit
summary: US stocks rose early Monday, despite Boeing's decline, as markets took in stride the weekend delay of the British parliament's Brexit vote. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.6%. Boeing plummeted 4.2% after the FAA criticized the company for not providing key documents in the 737 MAX crisis. This week's earnings calendar includes reports from Procter & Gamble, Caterpillar, and Amazon.

site_title: Property agent suspended, fined S$30,000 for faking offers to get bigger commission
summary: A Singapore property agent, Ngu Ping Chuan James Ethan, has been fined S$30,000 and suspended for 12 months for faking offers and counteroffers to secure a bigger commission. He misled his client into not making an offer of S$1.04 million, while claiming the seller had made a counteroffer, and instead advised his client not to proceed due to the high price. The agent's actions caused his client to lose S$20,000 to S$30,000. This is the highest sentence met by the Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) for a property agent.

site_title: It's time to create conditions to empower women with fintech
summary: Women in emerging economies face significant barriers to accessing financial services, including lack of bank accounts and limited documentation. Despite advancements, women are still less likely to own accounts and more likely to be financially excluded, with a 30% gap in ownership rates in some Asian countries.
