However, fintech innovation is bridging the gap, with some countries like the Philippines and Indonesia seeing a marked increase in women opening bank accounts. The role of technology, government support, and collaborative efforts is crucial to achieving parity in financial inclusion for women in emerging Asia.

site_title: Collapse in coal prices adds to Indonesian miners' funding woes
summary: Indonesian coal miners face significant funding woes due to the global collapse in coal prices, with prices slumping 33% this year. Bonds from coal companies have suffered more than peers in Asia, and some lenders are looking to stop financing coal power plants. Companies like Geo Energy Resources and PT Bumi Resources are at risk of restructuring or early redemption of their bonds if prices stay depressed. The Indonesian coal sector is also under pressure from investors to "go green" and reduce reliance on coal.

site_title: Controversial Amazon statues stolen from Rome church, dumped in river
summary: Ultra-conservative Catholic militants stole four Amazon statues from a Vatican church and dumped them into the Tiber River, claiming they were pagan idols. The statues were replicas of a pregnant indigenous woman and were on display at the Church of Santa Maria in Traspontina, sparking controversy over the Vatican's environmental efforts and the ordination of married men as priests. The Vatican described the theft as a "stunt," while the militants claimed they were taking action against what they saw as a betrayal of Catholic values. The statues were taken down before the start of a synod on the Amazon region.

site_title: SAP in three-year cloud partnership with Microsoft
summary: SAP has reached a three-year cloud partnership with Microsoft, dubbed "Embrace", to help large enterprise customers move their business processes into the cloud. The deal, which doubles new cloud bookings, addresses customer complaints about the complexity of shifting from SAP's traditional on-premise model. The partnership will sell SAP's cloud platform services through Microsoft's distribution channels, deepening SAP's relationship with Microsoft and its Azure cloud division. This move is expected to support SAP's cloud gross margins, which increased by 5.4 percentage points to 69% in the third quarter.

site_title: Creating personalised ads in real-time
summary: Singapore-based tech start-up Lumin(ai)re has developed an AI-powered tool to create personalized online advertisements in real-time, using elements like font types, visuals, and keywords. The firm aims to increase engagement and effectiveness of digital ads for SMEs with limited resources. Lumin(ai)re is currently working with beta customers in Singapore and plans to expand into the Japanese and Chinese markets next year, seeking to raise funds for its upcoming Seed Round.

images.alt_text: Han Phay, Lumin(ai)re's CEO and founder: "Our core mission is to enable digital and online ads to be more effective on different groups of consumers, solely based upon the understanding that human creative taste is extremely subjective."

site_title: Westgate consolidation, Funan reopening boost CMT Q3 revenue
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 17.9% increase in Q3 gross revenue to S$201.1 million, driven by the completion of Westgate's acquisition and Funan's reopening. The increase was partially offset by lower income from Lot One Shoppers' Mall due to rejuvenation works. Net property income rose 17.6% to S$144.2 million, while distributable income to unitholders increased 9.1% to S$113 million.

site_title: Temasek's Keppel move may have SembMarine in its sights
summary: Temasek's $4.1 billion acquisition of a controlling stake in Keppel Corp may be a precursor to a merger between Keppel Offshore and Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembcorp Marine (SembMarine). Temasek already owns a 20.45% stake in Keppel Corp and a 49.5% stake in Sembcorp Industries, the parent company of Sembcorp Marine. The strategic review will assess Keppel O&M's competitiveness and implement urgent reforms to revive KepCorp. A 51% majority stake will allow Temasek to push through reforms and potentially merge Keppel O&M and Sembcorp Marine.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings' S$4.1 billion move to gain a controlling stake in Keppel Corp (KepCorp) is fuelling years-long intermittent market speculation of a merger of Singapore's two major shipyards - Keppel Offshore and Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembcorp Marine (SembMarine) - or even the privatisation of the latter.

site_title: OCBC joins Singtel's regional mobile payments network
summary: OCBC Bank has joined Singtel's regional mobile payments network, VIA, as the first bank in Singapore to do so. The partnership enables OCBC account holders to make cashless payments in Thailand and Japan by Q1 2020, with over 1.7 million merchant partners on the network. The move aims to drive digital payments adoption and eliminate the hassle of carrying cash in foreign currencies. The partnership also paves the way for linking rewards and merchant programs, and is expected to grow the alliance to 50 million consumers and 2.1 million merchants across Asia.

site_title: Lauding efforts by businesses to make a difference
summary: The Brands for Good movement, launched by IPOS Society and IIPCC Singapore, recognized 43 small-to-medium-sized enterprises for their positive impact on stakeholders, communities, and the environment. The second instalment of the awards ceremony, held on September 26, honored 59 winners in four categories: Workplace, Community, Environment, and Patents. The nominees were assessed by a panel of 15 independent judges and selected from a list of 120 entrants. The winners were celebrated at a gala dinner, highlighting businesses' efforts to leverage intellectual property for a positive impact.

site_title: Jumbo opens second franchised seafood restaurant in South Korea
summary: Jumbo Group, a restaurant operator, announced the opening of its second franchised Jumbo Seafood restaurant in South Korea, marking the group's seventh in the country. This brings the total number of Jumbo Seafood restaurants in Asia to 19, including 12 own-managed outlets. The new restaurant, located in Ilsan, Seoul, occupies 760 square meters and features a 20-meter outdoor pool. Group CEO Ang Kiam Meng expressed the group's intention to progressively grow its F&B outlets in North Asia.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's new 100 per cent shisha tax sparks fury
summary: Saudi Arabia has imposed a 100% tax on shisha bills at restaurants, sparking widespread criticism and confusion. Some restaurants have stopped offering shisha, while others have lowered prices. The tax has ignited debate on social media, with many expressing outrage and frustration. The decision has also led to concerns about the economic impact on the hospitality industry.

site_title: Consolidation of Westgate, Funan's reopening boost CMT's Q3 DPU
summary: CAPITALAND Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 3.06 Singapore cents DPU for Q3, up from 2.92 cents last year, driven by the consolidation of Westgate and Funan's reopening. Gross revenue rose 17.9% to S$201.1 million, with Westgate contributing S$18.8 million and Funan's retail and office components accounting for S$12.5 million. Net property income increased 17.6% to S$144.2 million, while distributable income to unitholders rose 9.1% to S$113 million.

site_title: US-China trade deal doesn't need to be inked next month
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that the initial US-China trade deal does not need to be finalized by the end of November, contrary to President Donald Trump's intention to sign the pact at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit. Ross emphasized the importance of getting a proper deal, rather than focusing on a specific signing date. The trade deal, announced on October 11, suspends a planned tariff hike, but few details have emerged.

site_title: India minister says trade pact differences with US broadly resolved
summary: India's Trade Minister Piyush Goyal said a trade deal with the US is near resolution, with key differences addressed. The two countries have been locked in trade disputes, including tariffs on each other's products, but negotiations have made progress. The deal includes lowering US tariffs on Indian farm produce and faster approval for Indian pharmaceuticals. The US and India are also expected to expand trade, with a focus on sectors such as defence, electronics, and pharmaceuticals, and a larger trade agreement may be on the horizon.

images.alt_text: India's Trade Minister Piyush Goyal said on Monday that the broad outline of a trade deal with the United States has been worked out and suggested there could be an announcement soon.

site_title: Thailand's king strips 'disloyal' royal consort of titles, military ranks
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn has stripped his royal consort, Sineenat Wongvajirapakdi, of her titles and military ranks for being "disloyal" and failing to respect royal traditions. Sineenat, 34, was the first person to hold the title of Royal Noble Consort in almost a century after being designated by the king in July. She was deemed "ungrateful" and "disobedient" for trying to rise to the level of the queen, causing conflict and misunderstanding among royal household officials and the public.

site_title: China's 'unicorn' startups exceed US number for first time
summary: China has surpassed the US in the number of privately-held startups valued at over $1 billion, also known as "unicorns," according to a report by Hurun Report. As of June 2019, China had 206 unicorn start-ups, while the US had 203. This marks the first time China has led the world in unicorn numbers. The Hurun Report's findings highlight China's growing startup ecosystem and its increasing influence in the global tech industry.

site_title: South Korean stocks inch up with eye on earnings, Brexit tussle
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.20% to 2,064.84 on Monday, driven by improving corporate earnings estimates, particularly in the memory chip industry. Foreign investors were net sellers, but domestic investors helped push the market up. The KOSPI has gained 1.17% this year, despite Brexit uncertainty and US trade tensions. Analysts expect further earnings growth, but the market remains sensitive to global economic developments.

site_title: SAP in three-year cloud partnership with Microsoft
summary: SAP has entered a three-year cloud partnership with Microsoft, dubbed "Embrace", to help large enterprise customers move their business processes into the cloud. The partnership will support customers in extending, integrating, and orchestrating SAP systems. Jennifer Morgan, Co-CEO, stated that SAP's cloud platform services will be sold through Microsoft's distribution channels. The deal aims to provide customers with a bundled solution for cloud migration and integration.

site_title: Australian shares end flat
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday, closing at 6,652.50, despite Brexit uncertainty weighing on the tech and energy sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 0.5% on Friday. Global economic concerns and Brexit uncertainty are cited as factors. New Zealand's benchmark index also slipped 0.04%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed flat at 6,652.50, having given up 0.5 per cent on Friday.

site_title: Wirecard hires KPMG for independent audit after latest FT allegations
summary: Wirecard hires KPMG for an independent audit after the Financial Times (FT) alleged its finance team sought to inflate sales and profits in Dubai and Ireland. The allegations led to a 20% drop in its share price. The company has rejected the claims, but investors and corporate governance advocates have called for an outside audit to clear up the matter. Wirecard's supervisory board has approved the audit, which will begin immediately, and will report to the board with unrestricted access to information.

site_title: Prince Harry admits he and Prince William 'on different paths'
summary: Prince Harry acknowledged the tension between him and Prince William, stating they are "on different paths" but will always be brothers. The rift between them has led to them splitting their joint offices and charitable foundation, and no longer living in close proximity. Harry expressed concerns about the media's impact on his family, particularly his wife Meghan, comparing it to the pressures faced by his mother Diana. The couple plans to take six weeks off work to focus on their family and conservation efforts, with Harry stating he would like to live in Africa but faces challenges in finding a suitable location.

site_title: Getting patients up and going quickly
summary: Osteopore International's 3D printed scaffolds are helping patients recover faster and better from bone injuries. The unique design of the implants allows for cell and blood vessel infiltration, promoting wound healing and tissue repair. The scaffolds are made of a bioresorbable polymer that degrades into carbon dioxide and water, eliminating the need for further surgical intervention. According to Professor Teoh Swee Hin, the founder of Osteopore, the interconnected 3D micro-architecture facilitates vessel formation and nutrient access, enabling faster recovery times.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly on Monday, boosted by positive comments from China's top negotiator on US-China trade talks. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.08% to 26,740.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.05% to 2,939.62. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.11% to 1,614.87. The gains were attributed to the optimism surrounding the ongoing trade negotiations, despite ongoing uncertainty.

site_title: ST Engineering wins contracts worth S$1.8b in Q3
summary: ST Engineering secured contracts worth S$1.8 billion in Q3, primarily from its aerospace and electronics sectors. The aerospace sector secured contracts totaling S$1 billion, including a 10-year agreement with Airbus Helicopters to support the German Armed Forces' NH90 fleet. The electronics sector secured contracts worth S$833 million for various industries, including satellite communications, mobility, and cybersecurity. The contracts are expected to generate revenue for the company in the coming years.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.8% on Monday following Temasek's Keppel move
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.8% on Monday, driven by Temasek's partial offer for a 35% stake in Keppel Corporation. The offer price of S$7.35 is a 25.8% premium over Keppel's last traded price, suggesting undervaluation in Singapore blue chips. Other Asian markets, however, were capped by Brexit uncertainties, with gains limited to less than 0.5%. The STI outperformed regional indices, with Rex International and Singtel also seeing gains.

site_title: Long-persecuted Yazidis welcome new 'sanctuary' temple
summary: The Yazidi community, an ancient ethnic group persecuted for their faith, has built a massive new temple in Armenia to preserve their religion and identity. The temple, built from marble and granite, includes a prayer hall, school, and museum, and serves as a symbol of strength for the Kurdish-speaking community. The construction was partly funded by a wealthy Moscow-based Yazidi businessman, and the temple is attracting pilgrims from abroad. The Yazidi community has faced persecution and genocide, but the temple represents a new sanctuary and a sense of unity and preservation of their national awareness and religion.

images.alt_text: Yazidis, an ancient ethnic group much persecuted for their faith, now have a massive new temple in Armenia to help preserve their religion and identity.
A view of the interior of the new Yazidi Temple in the village of Aknalich, 35 kilometres from the Armenian capital Yerevan.
A man touches an image of the Melek Taus, or the Peacock Angel, in the new Yazidi Temple in the village of Aknalich, 35 kilometres from the Armenian capital Yerevan.

Women worshippers stand at the altar, they pray and tie knots in pieces of cloth that represent their wishes, during their visit to the new Yazidi Temple in the village of Aknalich, 35 kilometres from the Armenian capital Yerevan.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.25% and the Topix index gaining 0.41%, driven by expectations for Japanese corporate earnings season. The Brexit deadlock remained unresolved, with British lawmakers voting to force Prime Minister Boris Johnson to ask the EU for another delay. Despite this, investors remained cautious, and traders took to the sidelines ahead of a public holiday. Major shares, including Toyota, Panasonic, and Takeda Pharmaceutical, also saw gains.

site_title: Rich Chinese outnumber wealthy Americans for first time: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse's annual wealth survey reveals that for the first time, China has surpassed the US in the number of rich individuals, with 100 million Chinese ranked in the global top 10% compared to 99 million Americans. The report found 46.8 million millionaires worldwide, with the US adding 675,000 new millionaires. Global wealth is expected to rise 27% over the next five years to $459 trillion by 2024, with the share of the world's bottom 90% decreasing to 18%.

site_title: Can this be the real thing?
summary: Celery juice, touted as a remedy for various health issues, has gained popularity despite a lack of scientific evidence supporting its claims. Proponents, including Anthony William, a self-proclaimed "Medical Medium," attribute its benefits to its high water content, potassium, and vitamin K. However, experts argue that other factors, such as hydration and the placebo effect, may be influencing juicers' sense of well-being. While celery juice is a healthy option, nutritionists recommend consuming a variety of vegetables and their juices to reap the benefits of different phytochemicals and antioxidants.

site_title: Singapore inks S$120m wafer research tie-up with chipmaker GlobalFoundries
summary: Singapore has partnered with GlobalFoundries, a US-based chipmaker, to develop new memory technology that can store data for long periods without power supply. The S$120 million four-year project will bring together 70 researchers from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and GlobalFoundries. The collaboration aims to enable commercialization of the technology, creating new jobs and investments in Singapore's innovation-driven economy. The project will focus on applications such as the Internet of Things, electric vehicles, and consumer electronics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Monday with a slight decrease in the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index to 1,570.93 points. The market saw a high volume of 2.6 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 435 to 383.

site_title: Harnessing the potential of AI for public safety
summary: Singapore is emerging as a hub for AI and IoT innovation, with neighboring countries seeking its expertise. The country's government has announced plans to build new centers of innovation and research institutes. AI is transforming industries, including public safety, by aiding clinical judgments, enabling virtual nursing assistance, and streamlining workflows for command centers. The technology can analyze footage from video camera surveillance systems, filter through millions of images, and provide critical details to frontline workers. AI can also be used to automate dispatch platforms, track resources, and document reports, ultimately improving emergency response and saving lives.

images.alt_text: Dr Ngiam Kee Yuan, National University Health System's group chief technology officer, and Dr Feng Mengling, assistant professor at the NUS Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health, introducing a new facial recognition tool that notifies medical personnel when high-risk patients arrive. Motorola Solution's Dr Mahesh Saptharishi notes that AI is already transforming industries including healthcare but another industry that demands new technologies is public safety, especially with disasters and emergency events becoming more complex and challenging.

site_title: Stable performance, new assets support MLT's Q2 DPU
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 14.2% increase in gross revenue to S$121.8 million in Q2, driven by higher revenue from existing properties and the redevelopment of Mapletree Ouluo Logistics Park Phase 1. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 2.025 cents, up from 1.958 cents a year ago. MLT also announced the proposed acquisition of seven logistics properties in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China for S$493.4 million, expected to be accretive to DPU and net asset value per unit.

site_title: Eurokars named Singapore distributor for British car brand MG
summary: Eurokars Group has been appointed the official distributor in Singapore of British car brand MG by SAIC Motor Corporation, China's largest carmaker. Eurokars EV Pte Ltd will focus on retailing electric vehicles, with initial offerings including the MG HS, MG ZS, EZS, and MG5 EV. The partnership aims to build a "strong foothold" in Singapore's growing EV market and future-proof Eurokars' product offerings. MG joins Eurokars' stable of luxury brands, with SAIC Motor expecting to strengthen the brand's popularity and significantly increase its presence in Singapore.

site_title: Against the tide, cocoa growers plan to suspend ethical programmes
summary: Ivory Coast and Ghana, the world's largest cocoa producers, are planning to suspend sustainability programs run by private companies, contradicting the trend of corporate commitments to environmental and social responsibility. The move aims to exert more control over global cocoa prices and boost farmer income by adding a premium of $400 a ton. Cocoa regulators in both countries are frustrated with slow adoption of the new strategy, which will improve the livelihoods of small-scale producers. The suspension may impact chocolate makers' claims of sustainable sourcing.

site_title: Johnson pushes for Brexit deal vote after being forced to seek delay
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to try to put his Brexit deal to a vote in parliament on Monday after a letter seeking a delay from the European Union was sent due to opposition demands. The UK's departure from the EU, originally set for October 31, is now uncertain. Johnson's opponents argue over whether to leave with a deal, exit without a deal, or hold another referendum, putting the country's Brexit plans in disarray.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will try to put his Brexit deal to a vote in parliament on Monday after he was forced by his opponents to send a letter seeking a delay from the European Union.

site_title: Experiential- and activity-based concepts gaining traction in malls
summary: Pop-up retail and experiential concepts are gaining traction in malls, offering a way for physical retail to attract shoppers. Established brands are now incorporating pop-up retail into their strategies, with Funan Mall and ICONSIAM in Bangkok showcasing unique retail experiences. These concepts aim to boost footfall and create community spaces within malls, providing a testbed for new products and services.

images.alt_text: As part of an overall strategy to enhance the shopping experience, mall operators have been increasing the experiential and activity-based retail mix in their malls. The recently re-opened Funan Mall for instance offers a publicly accessible rooftop Urban Farm, rock-climbing facilities, a futsal court and even an indoor cycling track.

site_title: Your cup of coffee may get cheaper with a flood of Robusta
summary: Indonesia aims to boost robusta coffee output by 50-60% in the next five years, driven by a surge in production and tumbling prices. The country, the world's third-largest robusta producer, plans to increase yields through improved farming practices, fertilizer use, and financial assistance. With domestic consumption expected to rise 5-6% annually, Indonesia seeks to capitalize on the growing global demand, particularly in China, where coffee consumption has surged ninefold in the past decade. This could lead to a glut of robusta beans, putting downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Berlin freezes rents in landmark plan to tackle cost spiral
summary: Berlin's governing parties have agreed to freeze rents in the German capital for five years, aiming to tackle the city's spiraling housing costs. The plan, announced by Mayor Michael Mueller, will cap annual inflation-related rent increases at 1.3% from 2022, with small increases allowed for renovation work. The move is seen as a response to the property boom, which has doubled rents over the past decade, and is expected to ease the burden on tenants. The plan's approval is pending legislative approval.

images.alt_text: Berlin's governing parties struck a deal to freeze rents in the German capital for five years, marking one of the most radical plans to tackle spiraling housing costs in a major city.

site_title: Collapse in coal prices spurs distress for Indonesian miners
summary: A global collapse in coal prices has severely impacted Indonesian miners, with thermal coal prices plummeting 33% this year. The decline has led to financial distress for miners, including Geo Energy Resources, PT ABM Investama, and PT Bumi Resources, with bonds from the latter two companies suffering significant losses. The industry faces reduced funding options as investors shift towards renewable energy, with some lenders considering stopping financing for coal power plants. If prices remain depressed, there may be restructuring of US dollar bonds in the Indonesia coal sector, posing a risk to companies' financial stability.

site_title: Hot stock: SembMarine shares jump 11.6%, gets SGX query
summary: SembCorp Marine shares surged 11.6% to S$1.34, prompting a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query on "unusual price movements". The SGX asked if the company was aware of any unannounced information that may explain the trading. The surge came after Temasek Holdings' plan to raise its stake in Keppel Corp to 51% was announced, potentially paving the way for a merger between Keppel Offshore & Marine and SembMarine. Analysts believe SembCorp Industries could benefit from the developments, with KGI Securities raising the probability of a merger between the two shipyards.

site_title: Ascott Reit unitholders approve merger with A-HTrust
summary: Ascott Reit's unitholders have approved the merger with A-HTrust, paving the way for the combined trust to become the largest hospitality trust in Asia Pacific and the eighth largest globally. The merger, which requires 75% approval, has been approved by 99.98% of valid votes, with 1.31 billion units representing. The combined trust will have total assets of S$7.6 billion.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise offering 26 weeks of paid leave for new parents
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has announced a new initiative to support its employees' wellbeing and work-life balance. The company is offering 26 weeks of paid leave for new parents, both mothers and fathers, as well as flexible working arrangements such as Parental Transition Support and Retirement Transition Support. This move aims to promote equal parenting and recognize the importance of workplace culture in supporting it. The policy is being rolled out globally, including in Singapore, where it represents an increase of 10 weeks for mothers and 24 weeks for fathers.

site_title: Booming green power still not enough to meet climate targets
summary: Electricity capacity from renewable energy is set to expand by up to 50% in the next five years, reaching 1,200 gigawatts, but still falls short of meeting climate targets. Renewables are expected to account for 30% of global power generation by 2024, with solar power driving most of the growth. Despite declining costs, renewables will only support 12% of global heat consumption by 2024, and India's overall share of heat generation will remain flat. The International Energy Agency urges further acceleration of renewable energy deployment to achieve long-term climate goals.

images.alt_text: Electricity capacity from renewable energy is set to expand by as much as 50 per cent in the next five years, bolstered by government support and falling costs. But more would be needed to slow down warming of the globe.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek is offering S$7.35 per share to raise its stake in Keppel Corp to 51%, a 25.86% premium over the last traded price. Gojek co-founder is resigning as CEO to join Indonesia's new Cabinet. NUS, Keppel, and SLNG have partnered to develop better cooling technology for data centers. OCBC has joined Singtel's regional mobile payments network, allowing customers to go cashless in Thailand and Japan. The Singapore bourse gained 0.8% following Temasek's Keppel move, with the STI closing at 3,139.15.

images.alt_text: If successful, the S$4.08 billion deal will bump Temasek and Kyanite's total holding up to 51 per cent, on top of Temasek's current direct holding of a 20.45 per cent stake in the conglomerate.

site_title: Mahathir warns of possible trade sanctions on Malaysia
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad warned of possible trade sanctions on his country due to rising protectionism in the US-China tariff war. Mahathir stated that Malaysia's exports-reliant economy could be hit, as the country is economically linked to both markets. He also expressed disappointment over free trade proponents engaging in restrictive trade practices. Malaysia is collaborating with regional neighbors to cushion the impact, and Mahathir complained of being bullied by powerful nations, including European countries over palm oil exports.

site_title: Australia home prices keep rising as auctions heat up
summary: Australia's home prices have seen their strongest month of gains since mid-2017, with a 0.4% weekly increase and 1.2% monthly rise. Sydney and Melbourne saw 0.5% and 0.6% weekly gains, respectively, while clearance rates at property auctions reached their highest levels since early 2017. This recovery is attributed to record low interest rates and looser lending rules, potentially boosting the construction sector.

site_title: At home of Mona Lisa, a retrospective on da Vinci's life and work
summary: The Louvre museum in Paris is set to open a retrospective on Leonardo da Vinci's life and work, featuring over 160 paintings, sculptures, and drawings from the Renaissance era. The exhibition, which opens on October 24, 2019, will include 10 paintings attributed to da Vinci, including the Mona Lisa, which will not be part of the show. The inclusion of da Vinci's Salvator Mundi, sold for $450 million in 2017, remains uncertain, but the Louvre executives hope it will arrive for the show. The exhibition is expected to attract half a million visitors by its closing on February 24, 2020.

site_title: European shares nudge higher as Brexit tussle continues
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by optimism over the UK's potential avoidance of a disorderly Brexit exit. Despite a letter from Prime Minister Boris Johnson requesting a Brexit delay, the British government insisted on leaving the EU on October 31. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3%, boosted by export-heavy firms, while the domestically focused mid-caps index dropped 0.3%. The STOXX 600 index also rose 0.2%, as investors remained hopeful about the Brexit outcome.

site_title: Beijing says no one can stop Taiwan 'reunification'
summary: China's Defence Minister General Wei Fenghe stated that Taiwan's reunification with the mainland is inevitable and "no force" can stop it. The process began after the 1949 civil war, and China views Taiwan as a renegade province. General Wei emphasized that China will not stop efforts towards reunification, despite claims of promoting peaceful cross-strait relations. The comments come amid deteriorating relations between Taipei and Beijing, with China having poached allies and restricting recognition of Taiwan's government.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge higher, pound stumbles on Brexit drama
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.19% on Monday, driven by hopes for progress in resolving the US-China trade war and increased investment in Hong Kong. Chinese shares rose 0.13%, while Japan's Nikkei rose 0.28%. However, the pound dropped from a five-month high due to the UK's Brexit delay, forcing Prime Minister Boris Johnson to seek an extension to October 31.

site_title: Temasek to raise stake in Keppel Corp to 51% with S$7.35-per-share offer
summary: Temasek Holdings is set to acquire an additional 30.55% of Keppel Corporation shares at S$7.35 apiece, bumping its total holding to 51% and giving it control of the conglomerate. The offer, valued at S$4.08 billion, is subject to regulatory approvals and Keppel's financial performance. Temasek intends to keep Keppel listed on the Singapore Exchange, and a strategic review of its businesses may lead to new investments or corporate actions.

site_title: China's defence minister says resolving 'Taiwan question' is national priority
summary: China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe stated that resolving the "Taiwan question" is his country's "greatest national interest" and no force can prevent China's "reunification". This comes amid rising tensions between China and Taiwan ahead of the self-ruled island's presidential election in January. China views Taiwan as its most sensitive territorial issue, and Wei's comments indicate a strong commitment to reunification.

site_title: Vietnam prime minister says 2019 GDP growth to exceed 6.8%
summary: Vietnam Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc announced that the country's GDP growth is expected to exceed 6.8% in 2019, driven by robust exports and foreign investment. The country aims to keep inflation below 4% next year and has a record high foreign exchange reserve of $73 billion. However, Phuc noted that Vietnam's open economy exposes it to external risks, and the pace of privatisation and infrastructure spending has been slower than expected.

site_title: 'Clear risks' for stability in China's Pacific lending: Lowy Institute
summary: China's financial largesse in the Pacific poses "clear risks" for stability, a Sydney think tank warned. Between 2011 and 2018, China committed $6 billion in loans to the region, with most going to Papua New Guinea. While allegations of "debt-trap" diplomacy are overblown, fragile Pacific nations risk borrowing too much and exposing themselves to Beijing's demands. China is the single largest creditor in several island nations, and its lending practices lack strong institutional mechanisms to protect debt sustainability.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog gives conditional nod to clinical labs merger
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has granted conditional approval for the merger of two private clinical laboratories, Pathology Asia Holdings (PAH) and Innovative Diagnostics, after PAH submitted revised commitments to address competition concerns. The four-year commitments include ensuring fair prices for third-party IVD tests, allowing customers to switch suppliers, and maintaining prices for private hospitals and health-screening companies. The CCCS accepted the commitments after evaluating third-party feedback and revisions made by PAH, making the merger conditional upon PAH's implementation and compliance.

site_title: Singapore banks, casinos commended for aiding police in seizure of S$25m from financial crimes
summary: Singapore's police commended three local banks and two casinos for their efforts in combating financial crimes, resulting in the seizure of S$25 million. The banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, filed half of the 32,660 suspicious transaction reports (STRs) last year, while the casinos contributed about 20%. The seizures led to the prosecution of individuals and the recovery of over S$2 million in taxes, penalties, and fines. The police praised the banks and casinos for their vigilance and commitment to detecting and reporting suspicious transactions, and vowed to continue improving their data analytics capabilities.

site_title: Gojek co-founder resigns CEO post to join new Indonesian Cabinet
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has appointed Nadiem Makarim, co-founder of ride-hailing giant Gojek, as a Cabinet member in his second-term government. Makarim resigned as Gojek CEO to take the post, following President Widodo's preference to include professionals and millennials in his team. Makarim, from a prominent Indonesian family, co-founded Gojek in 2010, which has since become a successful startup unicorn valued at $10 billion with over 2 million drivers and 400,000 merchants.

images.alt_text: Nadiem Makarim, co-founder of Indonesia's first startup unicorn Gojek, has resigned as chief executive officer of the ride-hailing giant to take on a cabinet post in the country's new government.

site_title: Japan's Uniqlo pulls ad after South Korean fury
summary: Uniqlo has pulled an ad featuring 98-year-old US fashion figure Iris Apfel after it was criticized for whitewashing Japan's colonial history in South Korea. The ad, which showed Apfel chatting with designer Kheris Rogers, was subtitled differently in South Korea, sparking outrage over the perceived disrespect to the country's history of Japanese colonial rule. The move is part of a growing diplomatic row between Japan and South Korea. Uniqlo denied any intention to imply anything about colonial rule, but the company has withdrawn the ad amid public backlash.

site_title: China home-price growth slowest in seven months amid discounts
summary: China's home-price growth slowed to 0.53% in September, the smallest gain since February, as developers cut prices to speed up sales. This is the fourth consecutive month of slowdown, with average home prices across the country falling 0.4% last month. The challenge for policymakers is cushioning the slowdown and avoiding an all-out property crash, which could devastate the economy. Developers are offering deeper discounts, with some projects offering 5-10% discounts, to keep cash flowing in.

site_title: OCBC joins Singtel's regional mobile payments network
summary: OCBC has joined Singtel's VIA mobile payment network, allowing customers to make cashless payments in Thailand and Japan by early 2020. The partnership enables OCBC customers to use their local mobile wallets at over 1.7 million merchant partners, with competitive exchange rates. The move aims to boost digital payments adoption among customers and expand the VIA network to 50 million consumers and 2.1 million merchants across five countries.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank's chief operating officer, Ching Wei Hong (left), and CEO of Singtel's International Group, Arthur Lang, signed a memorandum of understanding to mark the two companies' partnership.

site_title: Hong Kong sees best weekend for home sales since April on heels of new policy
summary: Hong Kong saw its best weekend for home sales since April, with 20 sales recorded in the top 10 estates, more than three times the weekend before. The relaxation of mortgage rules for first-time buyers has boosted transactions, with 1,100 applications received for China Evergrande's Emerald Bay project. The government's decision to allow 10% down payment has encouraged buyers to speed up purchases, shifting them to the secondary market, which offers lower property prices. This change may help first-time buyers and upgraders, with secondary home transaction volumes expected to increase.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,142.96, up 0.9% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 3,142.96 on Monday, driven by hopes of progress on the US-China trade deal. Advancers outnumbered decliners 163 to 137, with gains seen in stocks such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Thai Beverage, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and UOL Group. Asian equities were mixed, with Japan's Topix and Hong Kong's Hang Seng also showing gains, while China's Shanghai Composite remained little changed.

site_title: UBS cutting 40 banking jobs in Asia
summary: UBS is cutting approximately 40 banking jobs in Asia-Pacific as part of a global cost-cutting push and restructuring efforts. The staff reductions primarily affect vice-president and below roles, mainly in markets and investment-banking teams. In contrast, Asian divisions will see smaller cuts due to UBS viewing the region as a growth driver. The move follows similar job cuts by other major banks in Europe and the US, amid challenging market conditions and trade tensions.

site_title: Treasury Wine CEO who led 'extraordinary transformation' retires, shares tumble
summary: Australia's Treasury Wine Estates Ltd announced the retirement of CEO Michael Clarke, effective early 2021. Clarke led the company's transformative turnaround, boosting post-tax earnings nearly tenfold and scaling a record profit in 2019. His departure sent shares down over 12%. Clarke oversaw a surge in Treasury stock from 2014, when he took over to address strained profits and cost troubles, and achieved robust demand for premium wines in China, now the company's largest market.

site_title: China's home price growth flatlines in Sept as fewer cities report gains
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% in September, unchanged from August, as the country's housing market continues to hold up despite a cooling economy. On a year-on-year basis, prices increased 8.4%, the slowest since September last year. The government has refrained from stimulating the sector due to concerns over household debt and housing affordability. Despite this, property prices have increased for the 53rd straight month, with some cities showing signs of rapid cooling. Local governments are given more autonomy in policymaking, leading to mixed price trends.

site_title: Oil prices dip on weak demand outlook, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices fell by 0.2% to $59.32 and $53.69 a barrel, amid concerns over weak economic demand and supply. Russia missed its target to cut oil output last month, while China's refinery throughput increased, suggesting robust petroleum demand. Opec+ agreed to reduce supply by 1.2 million barrels per day, but talks between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to restart oil production from jointly-operated fields added to concerns of rising supplies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.37 points to 1,568.78. The market saw 38.01 million lots traded worth RM13.47 million, with 78 gainers and 76 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Monday; STI up 0.1% to 3,115.92
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% to 3,115.92 on Monday, driven by uncertainty over Britain's Brexit deal. The Straits Times Index gained 0.06% with 65 gainers and 45 losers. Banking stocks were mostly down, while Rex International and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding were active index stocks. The US earnings season continues this week, with investors starting the week cautiously.

site_title: International Press Building in Kallang up for sale with S$30m guide price
summary: The International Press Building in Kallang, Singapore, is up for sale with a guide price of S$30 million. The six-storey, 134,000 sq ft detached property has a 60-year lease and is located near the city fringe, with easy access to the MRT and amenities. The site's plot ratio is 2.5 under the 2019 Draft Master Plan, offering a rare Business 1-use site opportunity. The property will be sold with vacant possession and is marketed by Savills Singapore.

images.alt_text: The International Press Building has a prominent and unblocked visibility facing the main Kallang Road, according to Savills Singapore's Sharon Teo.

site_title: Hands tied and paralysed: Hong Kong leader struggles to end crisis
summary: Hong Kong's government, led by Carrie Lam, is struggling to end the ongoing crisis sparked by protests demanding greater democracy and police accountability. Despite Beijing's backing, Lam's efforts have failed to quell the movement, with violent clashes and vandalism occurring frequently. Analysts attribute the crisis to Lam's lack of democratic mandate, limited room for maneuver, and Beijing's authoritarian grip on the city. With historic low approval ratings and public anger running high, Lam's position is increasingly precarious, with no clear solution in sight.

site_title: Many firms in China's third-biggest province struggling to pay debt: S&P
summary: Many privately held firms in Shandong, China's third-biggest province, are struggling to repay short-term debt due to declining industry fundamentals, entangled cross guarantees, and ill-managed investments. S&P Global Ratings attributes the issue to China's slowing economy and environmental protection rules affecting profitability and cash flow in over-capacity sectors. The ratings agency expects Shandong's private firm credit risk to remain significant for the next 12 months, with limited support from the provincial government due to its focus on high-value-added sectors. At least 28 private companies in Dongying are seeking debt restructuring.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares slip as Brexit uncertainty weighs
summary: Australian shares fell 14.5 points to 6,635.6 due to Brexit uncertainty, while digital payments stocks declined amid a central bank review of the buy-now-pay-later sector. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit withdrawal deal was derailed after lawmakers voted to withhold a decision, forcing a third postponement of Britain's departure from the EU.

site_title: Tear gas and water cannon as Hong Kong crowds defy rally ban
summary: Hong Kong police clashed with tens of thousands of protesters in an illegal march in Tsim Sha Tsui, firing tear gas and water cannon as protesters hurled petrol bombs and vandalized businesses. The rally, which began peacefully, descended into chaos as protesters defied authorities' ban on the event. Many protesters sought to show they would not be intimidated by attacks on pro-democracy leaders and authorities' efforts to suppress public gatherings. The clashes marked the latest escalation in months of unrest in Hong Kong, with protesters demanding democratic reforms and police accountability.

site_title: NUS, Keppel and SLNG tie-up to develop better cooling technology for data centres
summary: The National University of Singapore, Keppel Data Centres Holdings, and the Singapore LNG Corporation have partnered to develop innovative, energy-efficient cooling technology for data centres. The research project, supported by the Singapore government's National Research Foundation, aims to create more sustainable and compact data centres. The partnership could lead to significant advancements in cooling technology, paving the way for a more environmentally friendly data centre industry.

site_title: Boeing says FAA was told 'multiple times' of changes to 737 Max
summary: Boeing revealed that it had informed the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) multiple times about changes to the 737 Max's flight-control software, known as MCAS, which was linked to two fatal crashes. The company also stated that FAA personnel observed the system operating during flight tests before certification. A former Boeing pilot described the system as "egregious" in instant messages, which Boeing had not disclosed earlier, causing concern and pressure on the company. The FAA is reviewing the information to determine its next action.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.08% to 26,741.42, following China's top negotiator's statement of "substantial progress" in a partial trade deal with the US. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.14%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index was marginally higher.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Monday with small gains after China's top negotiator hailed "substantial progress" in pushing through a partial trade deal with the United States.

site_title: Japan's September exports fall 5.2% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 5.2% in September from a year earlier, marking a 10th straight month of decline, according to Ministry of Finance data. This follows an 8.2% drop in August. Imports fell 1.5% in the same period. The trade balance turned into a deficit of 123.0 billion yen, lower than the forecasted surplus of 54.0 billion yen.

site_title: Pound dips as Brexit saga drags but hopes for deal lend support
summary: Sterling fell 0.6% against the dollar and euro on Monday after the UK House of Commons voted to delay passing Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal, forcing him to request another delay from the EU. Despite the setback, the pound has proven resilient, with analysts citing hopes for a deal and minimal losses. A deal before October 31 is still expected, but uncertainty remains, including the possibility of a confirmatory vote or second Brexit referendum.

images.alt_text: Sterling fell on Monday after MPs voted to delay passing British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit deal, though losses were limited by hopes the country can eventually avoid crashing out of the EU without a divorce agreement in place.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.25% and the Topix index up 0.28%, following the latest Brexit deadlock failure by British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Investors shifted focus to Japanese corporate earnings season starting this week.

site_title: Hong Kong firms, lacking riot insurance, pick up pieces from protest damage
summary: Hong Kong businesses are expected to bear the costs of vandalism and damage caused by protests over the past four months, as few firms purchased riot insurance coverage. Smashed windows, graffiti, and fires targeting businesses perceived as supporting mainland China's increased control over Hong Kong have occurred. A small video game shop in New Territories was vandalized four times for displaying a pro-police banner. Industry insiders say businesses will likely foot the bill for the damage, with some reporting losses in the thousands of dollars.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit completes 19m euro divestment of French industrial property
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) completed the divestment of its Parc d'Osny property in France for 19 million euros (S$28.9 million) to Arc Eiffel Investissement. The sale price exceeded the property's recent valuation by 13.1%, aligning with Cromwell E-Reit's strategy of disposing non-core assets. The sale is aimed at providing regular and stable distributions to unitholders and achieving long-term growth.

site_title: Five die in fire at clothing factory looted in Chile unrest: firefighters
summary: Five people died in a fire at a garment factory in Santiago, Chile, after looters set it ablaze during unrest. The death toll in the unrest has risen to seven, with two deaths reported earlier at a supermarket. The cause of the fire and unrest is unclear.

site_title: MeGroup unit renews deal with Japanese manufacturer Hirotani
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysia-based company, announced that its subsidiary Menang Nusantara Sdn Bhd has renewed a technical-assistance agreement with Japanese automotive manufacturer Hirotani. The agreement will enable Menang Nusantara to use Hirotani's know-how and technical assistance in manufacturing noise, vibration, and harshness components for automobiles.

site_title: Trading halts: Keppel Corp, Ascott Reit, A-HTrust
summary: Keppel Corp, Ascott Residence Reit (Ascott Reit), and Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) have requested trading halts pending announcements. Keppel Corp posted a 30% fall in third-quarter net profit to S$159 million, while Ascott Reit is set to merge with A-HTrust, forming the largest hospitality trust in Asia Pacific and the eighth globally, with a combined asset value of S$7.6 billion. The merger requires unitholder approval, and trading halts are in place to allow for the announcement and voting process.

site_title: Thai central bank head warns of financial system risk from ultra-low rates
summary: Thai Bank of Thailand Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob warns that ultra-low interest rates pose a risk to emerging economies' financial systems due to increased capital flows and exchange-rate volatility. He advises emerging economies to delay normalizing monetary policies to prevent currency appreciation and maintain financial stability. With household debt at high levels and subdued inflation, central banks should prioritize financial stability in monetary policy decisions. This could exacerbate financial system instability if not addressed.

site_title: Ramping up Industry 4.0
summary: The Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) 2019 event will be held in Singapore from October 22 to 24, bringing together industry stakeholders to collaborate and deepen understanding of Industry 4.0 solutions. The event aims to debunk the myth that Industry 4.0 is expensive and time-consuming to implement, and to cultivate awareness of the various skill sets needed to adapt to industrial transformation. With over 350 exhibitors from 30 countries, ITAP will provide a platform for companies to learn how to optimise technology, processes, and people to achieve business growth, and will feature various learning platforms, technical tours, and collaboration labs.

site_title: Singapore malls offering experiential concepts to attract returning customers: Edmund Tie
summary: Singapore retail malls are evolving to attract returning customers by introducing experiential concepts, such as communal spaces and non-retail components. This shift comes as retail and F&B growth has not kept pace with GDP growth, with annual growth reaching only 2% since the 2009 global financial crisis. To boost footfall and maintain occupancy rates, malls are creating communities within their premises, aiming to shore up earnings and stay competitive in the face of e-commerce disruption.

site_title: Sakae applies for extension to hold AGM; appointing independent auditor to review disclaimer
summary: Sakae Holdings has applied for an extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) due to ongoing differences and disputes, including a disclaimer of opinion issued by its auditor Deloitte & Touche. The company has appointed an independent auditor for a review of the disclaimer and is seeking an extension to the AGM, originally scheduled for October 29. The review aims to provide more information on the company's FY2019 financial statements and clarify any questions from shareholders.

site_title: IPhone display supplier sees OLED smartphone deluge from 2021
summary: Japan Display, a supplier of mobile screens to Apple, expects to decide on whether to invest in next-generation organic light-emitting diode (OLED) displays within the next year. The company's CEO, Minoru Kikuoka, believes LCD screens will remain competitive in smartphones through 2021 due to their price advantage. However, Kikuoka anticipates a shift to OLED technology may occur in the next year, with Apple potentially adopting OLED displays in new phones. Japan Display is seeking investment to support its own OLED production, with a potential customer offering $200 million.

site_title: Trial set to open in massive US opioid lawsuit
summary: US pharmaceutical companies, including Cardinal Health, Amerisource Bergen, and McKesson Corp, face trial in a massive opioid lawsuit in Cleveland, Ohio. The case, involving 2,300 plaintiffs, claims the companies knew the dangers of highly addictive painkillers but ignored warning signs, reaping billions in profits. A proposed $48 billion settlement was rejected, and the trial could be the most costly since tobacco litigation in the 1990s. The outcome will determine compensation for long-term damage caused by the opioid crisis, including overwhelmed health systems and families affected.

images.alt_text: Leading US pharmaceutical companies go on trial Monday charged with stoking the opioid epidemic that has ravaged communities and left hundreds of thousands dead or overdosed across the country.

site_title: French train strike disrupts holiday travel
summary: French rail services were disrupted for a third day due to a strike by workers over train staffing levels, affecting holiday travelers in Paris suburbs, Champagne-Ardenne, and Occitanie regions. The strike began after a train incident in northeastern France, with unions citing understaffing and lack of ticket inspectors. SNCF's management accused workers of abusing their "right to withdraw labor" on a busy weekend. Services are expected to return to normal on Monday.

site_title: Singaporeans expect inflation to inch up to 3.2% in coming year: DBS-SMU poll
summary: Singaporeans expect inflation to rise to 3.2% over the next 12 months, according to a DBS-SMU poll. Core inflation, excluding housing and private road transport, is forecast to reach 3.3%. The poll, conducted in September, shows a slight increase in inflation expectations, despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore's recent easing of monetary policy. Experts attribute the uptick to a natural bias in survey-based measures, and caution against reading too much into the findings.

site_title: Collaboration Lab aims to help companies in their learning journey
summary: ITAP has launched The Collaboration Lab, a co-creating and demonstration area for big industry players to showcase advanced manufacturing solutions. The lab aims to help companies adopt and adapt to Industry 4.0 by providing cost-effective solutions, digital monitoring, and easy retrofitting. Industry players such as ABB, SICK Sensor Intelligence, and Igus Singapore will showcase their solutions through live demonstrations. Emerson will also share a digital transformation solution powered by Plantweb digital ecosystem, highlighting the importance of strategy and business cases in digital transformation, not just technology.

site_title: Mirach Energy says unaware of reason for Friday's 39% price surge
summary: Mirach Energy, a Mainboard-listed firm, stated it is unaware of the reason behind its 39% price surge on October 18. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) flagged the unusual price movements and sent a query to the company. Mirach Energy is set to hold an extraordinary general meeting on October 29 to vote on a proposed change in auditors. The company is in compliance with listing rules and has been granted a 15-month extension to exit the SGX's watch list. No explanation has been provided for the sudden price surge.

site_title: Online spend in S-EA to outpace growth of digital consumers
summary: Online spending in South-east Asia is projected to outpace the growth of digital consumers by a factor of three, with an average spend per digital consumer expected to increase to US$390 by 2025. Clothing and personal care are emerging as leading categories, with a projected 25% annual growth rate. The study also found that 67% of digital consumers do not know what they want to purchase before shopping online, and 75% of respondents in Singapore are open to buying from multiple brands.

images.alt_text: ONLINE spend in South-east Asia is projected to outpace the growth of digital consumers by a factor of three, with clothing and personal care emerging as two of the leading categories.

site_title: Maritime industry seeks solutions to limit pollution
summary: The maritime industry is exploring solutions to limit pollution, with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) considering alternatives to heavy fuel oil. The industry aims to reduce its impact on the environment, with some companies developing ships that can run on liquefied natural gas and energy majors supporting the technology. However, shipowners are hesitant to adopt measures such as reducing speed, citing investment costs and concerns about increased storage time and fuel consumption. The IMO has already set a 0.5% sulphur content limit in heavy fuel oil from next year, and the issue of reducing speeds will be discussed at an upcoming committee meeting.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sakae, OCBC, Hiap Seng, Mirach, HMI, Singapura Finance, Miyoshi, Acesian
summary: Key developments include Sakae Holdings' request for an extension of its annual general meeting and an independent review of its auditor's disclaimer opinion, OCBC's sustainable finance portfolio goal, and Hiap Seng Engineering's cancellation of its proposed rights issue. Mirach Energy is investigating unusual trading activity, while HMI has approved its privatization via a scheme of arrangement. Singapura Finance reported a US$295 million pre-money valuation for Matchmove, and Miyoshi expects to report a loss for fiscal 2019. Acesian Partners warned of a S$988,000 provision related to legal proceedings, and Kori Holdings secured four new contracts worth S$68.3 million.

site_title: OCBC seeks more green loans to maintain lead in South-east Asia
summary: OCBC Bank aims to expand its green loans to maintain its lead in Southeast Asia, with a target of S$10 billion by 2022. The bank has already participated in over US$500 million of green lending this year, following the adoption of standardized disclosure rules by a regional association. OCBC's expansion into sustainable financing is driven by growing awareness and pressure from investors, NGOs, consumers, and regulators. The bank's largest green loan this year was S$785 million to Frasers Property, and it has pledged to stop funding new coal-fired power plants.

images.alt_text: Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp aims to expand its lending to environmentally-friendly projects after this year building the biggest exposure to green loans among its Southeast Asian peers.

site_title: Eco-friendly drive in US sees plastic being canned in favour of aluminium
summary: The US beverage market is shifting towards eco-friendly options, with plastic being replaced by aluminium in products such as red Solo cups and water bottles. This trend is driven by environmentally conscious consumers and is expected to boost shares of aluminium can producers like Ball Corp. The shift is threatening to dislodge plastics from their entrenched position in the American drinks industry.

site_title: Facebook's Marcus says Libra won't be controlled by a single company
summary: Facebook executive David Marcus said Libra, the company's proposed digital currency, won't be controlled by a single company. Marcus stated that the Libra Association, comprising 21 companies, will "welcome competition" to benefit local access and strive for low costs. However, he cautioned that the status quo is not an option, addressing concerns from officials like France's Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire who fear a private company could undermine government control. Marcus reiterated the company's commitment to working with regulators to address concerns.

images.alt_text: Facebook executive David Marcus on Sunday tried to calm the fears of officials threatening to block its proposed digital currency, saying Libra won't be controlled by a single company.

site_title: Mindset raises S$365,000 for mental health
summary: The Mindset Challenge & Carnival 2019, a fundraiser event for mental health, raised S$365,000 for Mindset Learning Hub (MLH), a job training and placement centre for individuals with mental health conditions. The event, which featured obstacle courses and a vertical race, was won by a team from Jardine Cycle & Carriage, and marked the 8th edition of the event, which has raised over S$2.5 million since its inception in 2012. The funds will support certified job training and placement for individuals with mental health conditions, helping them reintegrate into society.

site_title: 5G licences: Will industry partners bite?
summary: Singapore regulators have announced plans for 5G licenses, providing a generous supply of spectrum for mobile network operators (MNOs). The country aims to encourage the adoption of 5G technology, with a focus on enterprise applications such as factories and ports. The government has rolled out a S$40 million fund for research and development, and industry grants for businesses to test 5G. However, concerns remain about the potential mismatch between supply and demand, with some manufacturers hesitant to roll out 5G trials due to the relative immaturity of related technologies.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Challenging times ahead for Jetstar Asia
summary: Jetstar Asia faces challenges in the competitive low-cost carrier market, with CEO Barathan Pasupathi discussing strategies to remain a leading player. The airline is adapting to the market's increasing competition, but no specific details were provided in the interview. The conversation took place on the Money FM podcast "The Breakfast Huddle".

site_title: Ultra-long Qantas passenger flight does NY-Sydney in over 19 hours
summary: Qantas has successfully completed the world's longest non-stop passenger flight, touching down in Sydney after a 19-hour journey from New York. The ultra-long-haul flight, which also includes test journeys from London to Sydney, was operated with 49 passengers and four pilots. Researchers monitored the effects of jetlag on passengers and crew, using innovative approaches to minimize its impact. The test flights aim to inform recommendations on managing pilot fatigue and passenger jetlag for future regular services on marathon routes from the US and Britain to Australia.

site_title: Brexit will happen by Oct 31 despite letter to EU: UK
summary: The UK is set to leave the EU on October 31 despite a request for a delay, according to Michael Gove. The government sent a letter to the EU requesting a delay, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson did not sign it. The UK parliament has approved an amendment that requires the government to comply with the terms of the Benn Act, which aims to eliminate a no-deal exit. EU leaders have expressed frustration with the UK's lack of clarity on its Brexit plans, with a delay requiring agreement from all 27 EU leaders.

site_title: Hundreds of shops trashed as HK police, protesters clash
summary: Hundreds of shops were trashed and Chinese banks and metro stations targeted as Hong Kong police clashed with protesters in an illegal march, drawing tens of thousands of demonstrators. The protest, which was peaceful at first, descended into chaos with tear gas, petrol bombs, and water cannons being used by police. The clashes showed that the pro-democracy campaign has not lost support, with protesters targeting government and Chinese-linked establishments. The unrest has sparked a pro-democracy movement, with protesters demanding universal suffrage, an independent inquiry into police action, and the withdrawal of the extradition bill.

site_title: Solar, wind power can alleviate water stress
summary: European Union researchers warn that traditional coal, natural gas, and nuclear power plants are major water consumers, with 30% of the water needed to produce electricity. In contrast, solar, wind, and other renewables use a "small fraction" of water. The findings highlight the need for policymakers to consider water use when promoting renewable energy sources to alleviate water stress and maintain ecosystems. Researchers urge EU leaders to formulate policies that account for the water footprint of energy sources to support the bloc's goal of decarbonizing its energy supply.

site_title: Lebanon protesters mount further pressure on govt as reform deadline nears
summary: Protesters in Lebanon returned to the streets on Sunday, increasing pressure on Prime Minister Saad al-Hariri as a self-imposed deadline to deliver economic reforms approaches. Anti-government protests, which began on Thursday, have unified Lebanese society in calling for the downfall of the political elite blamed for the country's economic crisis. The protesters' demands for reform have kept al-Hariri on edge as the deadline for delivering a package of badly needed reforms draws near. The protests are part of a broader movement demanding change in Lebanon's deeply entrenched political system.

site_title: Spanish PM under pressure over Catalan protests
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez faces criticism for handling violent Catalan separatist protests ahead of the November 10 general election. Hundreds of people protested in Barcelona, calling for order to be restored and the rights of those opposed to independence to be defended. The protests have resulted in nearly 600 injuries, with a policeman and a protester in critical condition. The ruling Socialist Party is expected to secure the most votes, but may fall short of a majority, while the opposition Popular Party is tipped to make significant gains.

site_title: Sharing insights through summits, panel discussions
summary: Industry leaders and stakeholders are gathering at ITAP to share ideas and solutions for accelerating the adoption of Industry 4.0. The event features summits, panel discussions, and exhibitions, focusing on key areas such as digital transformation, material innovation, and cybersecurity. The Future of Manufacturing CXO Summit, Global Additive Manufacturing Summit, and Standards Forum aim to facilitate high-level networking and collaboration among business leaders, while providing insights into the opportunities and challenges of Industry 4.0. The event includes masterclasses and sandbox presentations on topics such as cybersecurity and connectivity in manufacturing.

site_title: BOJ will 'certainly' cut short-term rates if easing
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to cut short-term interest rates if needed to ease monetary policy amid heightening overseas risks. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that reducing short- to medium-term interest rates would be a primary tool to combat these risks, and the BOJ may accelerate purchases of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) if markets become volatile. The BOJ aims to achieve its elusive 2% inflation target, and Kuroda emphasized that the timing of easing monetary conditions would depend on economic data.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights a relatively stable market for tankers and dry bulk vessels, with the Pacific trading in a supported manner and the Atlantic experiencing weakening turbulence. Key trends include strong fixture activity, varying rates across regions, and the impact of IMO 2020 regulations on fuel tank cleaning and bunkering. Panamax vessels saw limited activity, while Ultramax and Supramax vessels secured higher rates, particularly in the US Gulf market. Handysize vessels experienced softer market conditions, with limited activity in the Mediterranean and North Sea regions.

site_title: Thai government's stability no clearer after tight budget vote
summary: Thailand's government passed its annual budget bill with a slim majority, receiving 251 votes and 234 abstentions. The outcome has sparked debate among analysts, with some seeing it as a sign of the coalition's stability, while others question its ability to manage the fragmented legislature. The budget's delayed implementation adds to the risks facing the slowing economy, which is also buffeted by a global slowdown and a strong currency. The government's two-seat majority is subject to the whims of over a dozen parties in the coalition, and opposition blocs have already questioned its legitimacy.

site_title: Pound shrugs off Johnson's latest Brexit setback
summary: The British pound remained relatively stable after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's latest Brexit setback, dipping 0.5% to US$1.2917 following a vote in the House of Commons that forced Johnson to request a Brexit delay. Despite the uncertainty, forex markets are waiting to see how the situation unfolds, with some analysts suggesting a deal will be reached before October 31. The pound has shown minimal losses over the past week, and a potential rise in sterling is possible if the UK government can secure the necessary votes for Johnson's deal.

site_title: Commercial drone delivery takes off in the US
summary: In a milestone for the US drone industry, Wing, an offshoot of Google's parent company, successfully completed a commercial drone delivery in Christiansburg, Virginia, to a local resident. The drone delivered a FedEx package to the doorstep within 10 minutes, marking the first commercial delivery of this kind in the US. The company received clearance from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) this spring, paving the way for the operation. This achievement is seen as a significant step towards the "walk" phase of the industry's "crawl, walk, run" approach to safely integrating drones into US airspace.

site_title: Market stalemate looks set to continue
summary: US stock indexes finished mixed last week as a US-China trade-war truce and Brexit deal proved short-lived. The "Phase One" deal between the US and China was seen as a temporary ceasefire, with China resuming purchases of agricultural products but not tariffs. Brexit celebrations were brief, with the UK parliament voting to delay the Brexit deadline until January. Earnings reports were mixed, with some companies, such as banking giants, showing strong performances. Global growth concerns persist, with China's GDP growth slowing and the International Monetary Fund warning of subdued growth.

images.alt_text: Markets are likely to continue to be in flux this week, amid mixed earnings and doubts over Brexit and the trade deal.

site_title: Jokowi sworn in for second term as Indonesia's president
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo was sworn in for a second five-year term, promising to cut red tape, build infrastructure, and prioritize education to drive growth and job creation. Economic issues dominated the election, with the growing influence of conservative Islam also a factor. With a youthful population of 260 million, Widodo aims to encourage investment and create opportunities.

images.alt_text: Mr and Mrs Lee met Mr Joko and his wife on Sunday ahead of the president's swearing-in ceremony in Jakarta. The inauguration was attended by other regional leaders including Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Courts donates S$17,000 worth of appliances to promote e-learning
summary: Courts Singapore donated over S$17,000 worth of digital appliances, including laptops, tablets, and Bluetooth speakers, to four student care centres under Care Community Services Society. The donation is part of Courts' CSR programme, Courts Charity Home, and aims to promote e-learning. 26 Courts employees volunteered to conduct e-learning and cultural sharing sessions with 80 lower and upper primary school children at New Town Primary School, who will use the new digital devices. The donation was made ahead of Deepavali, a festival celebrated by the school's children.

site_title: Blenheim Commodities Fund to shut as founder Kooyker retires
summary: Blenheim Commodities Fund, once the world's largest commodities fund, is shutting down after 50 years of trading as its founder Willem Kooyker retires. Most investors have transferred their assets to a new fund, Valence Asset Management, led by Kooyker's son Terence and portfolio manager James Tatum. Valence aims to reach $800 million in assets under management and will use quantitative analysis to support fundamental trading. The closure marks the end of an era for Kooyker, who pioneered the commodities hedge fund industry, and comes as the industry faces disruption from quantitative investors.

site_title: Enhancing protection for minorities during times of corporate distress
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association Singapore (Sias) proposes two initiatives to enhance protection for minority investors during corporate distress. First, Sias should be granted official standing to act on behalf of stakeholders in court, and second, a fund or insurance policy should be set up to provide legal and financial advice for investors. This move aims to address the unequal treatment of retail investors compared to institutional counterparts, ensuring equitable treatment and representation in debt restructuring processes.

site_title: Boeing employees knew in 2016 of Max problems
summary: Boeing employees were aware of major problems with the 737 Max's automated feature, MCAS, as early as 2016. Messages between top pilots Mark Forkner and Patrik Gustavsson reveal that the system was "engaging itself like crazy" and "egregious." The company had identified safety concerns years ago, but misled the FAA. The messages, which were withheld from regulators, show a lack of candor and a safety culture prioritizing deadlines and profitability over safety. The FAA is investigating and has asked for an explanation from Boeing's CEO.

images.alt_text: Peter DeFazio, chairman of the Transportation Committee, said the message chain showed "Boeing withheld damning information from the FAA".

site_title: Sustainable investments come into their own
summary: Sustainable investments have gained significant traction, with total assets reaching $30.7 trillion globally, a 34% increase from 2016. The Global Sustainable Investment Review found that responsible investments now command a sizable share of professionally managed assets, ranging from 18% in Japan to 63% in Australia and New Zealand. A survey by Allianz Global Investors found that 71% of institutions plan to manage all portfolios in an "ESG-conscious" way by 2030. Research by Morgan Stanley found that sustainable funds offer no financial trade-off in returns compared to traditional funds, and may even provide lower market risk.

site_title: China talks up tech powers in face of US rivalry
summary: China emphasized its online presence and tech prowess, vowing to become a "great power" in cyberspace, at its annual World Internet Conference. China's tech dominance is seen as a response to US rivalry, with officials criticizing "cyber-hegemony and bullying" by the US. China's Communist Party controls the internet, and officials denied accusations of whitewashing censorship, calling it "Internet sovereignty." The US has threatened sanctions on Chinese tech firms, including Huawei, which is set to play a key role in 5G communications.

site_title: US dollar weak as Brexit deal boosts euro, sterling
summary: The US dollar fell sharply against the euro, reaching a near two-month high, as a Brexit deal between Britain and the EU boosted the euro and sterling. The euro rose 0.32% to US$1.1158, while the pound jumped 0.45% to US$1.2946. The US dollar index fell 0.31% and is down 1% for the week, with investors pricing in an 82% chance of a rate cut by the US Federal Reserve next month.

site_title: TikTok videos - US teens' latest addiction
summary: US teens are embracing TikTok, a social media app where users post short funny videos, with some schools forming clubs to create content.
