summary: Asian stocks fell on Friday after China's third-quarter GDP growth of 6.0% was weaker than expected, marking the country's weakest growth in nearly three decades. The disappointing data raised concerns about Chinese policymakers' ability to boost growth, and analysts said Beijing has limited room for significant easing measures. The UK and EU's Brexit deal boosted global sentiment, but the pound pulled back amid uncertainty over parliamentary approval.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,112.86, down 0.42% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 0.42% to 3,112.86, following downbeat third-quarter GDP data from China. The decline was part of a regional slump, with Asian stocks falling after China's economy grew 6% in the third quarter, its weakest pace in nearly three decades. Losers beat gainers 152 to 116, with key losers including Keppel Corp and Genting Singapore.

site_title: Longest non-stop flight to take off from New York to Sydney
summary: Qantas is set to operate the first direct, non-stop flight from New York to Sydney, a 19-hour journey, this weekend. Up to 40 passengers and crew will be on board a Boeing 787-9 aircraft, with researchers monitoring the effects of the long-haul flight on passengers. The flight is part of three "ultra long-haul" test flights planned by Qantas this year.

site_title: More competition with four 5G networks but investment risk should be 'contained': Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings expects 5G investment risk to be contained over the next 18 months due to localized network deployment and reasonably priced spectrum. The Singapore government's decision to award licenses to operate up to four mobile networks has increased competition, but Fitch believes this will not significantly impact investment plans. The Infocomm Media Development Authority's 5G regulatory framework, announced earlier, aims to develop the 5G ecosystem.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,490 on weak Chinese data, Brexit prospects
summary: Gold prices held above US$1,490 due to weak Chinese data and concerns over Brexit, with spot gold rising 0.1% to US$1,492.45 per ounce. The European Union backed a new Brexit deal, but doubts remain over Prime Minister Boris Johnson's ability to secure parliamentary backing. China's economic growth slowed to 6% year-on-year, fueling worries over a trade war between the US and China. Gold prices are expected to remain range-bound until Brexit and geo-political risks are clarified, with ANZ Bank predicting elevated macro and geopolitical risks supporting the metal.

site_title: Singapore keeps top spot in Asia for protection of intellectual property rights
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the top country in Asia for protection of intellectual property rights, moving up a notch to fourth place globally among 129 countries. The country's Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) has implemented various initiatives to support enterprises, including the world's first trademark registration mobile app and AI-powered image search. IPOS aims to catalyze the growth of innovative enterprises and industries through IP and intangible assets, bolstering confidence for businesses to use Singapore as a hub for managing and deploying their IP assets.

site_title: Major reforms "unlikely" with new Indonesian cabinet: analyst
summary: Indonesia's new cabinet, set to be announced after President Joko Widodo's inauguration, is unlikely to bring extensive pro-investment reforms due to coalition pressures. Analyst Achmad Sukarsono notes that intense lobbying from domestic businesses may limit market liberalization and favor local businesses. Key cabinet positions, including Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati, are likely to remain in place or receive increased powers, while some sectoral ministers may represent local players wary of foreign presence. Foreign businesses can still thrive by aligning with local players or supporting national programs.

site_title: Innopac Q4 loss widens to S$2.1m on rising costs
summary: Innopac Holdings' net loss for the fourth quarter widened to S$2.1 million, from S$446,000 a year ago, due to declining revenue and rising staff costs. Revenue from rental income fell 8.7% and administrative expenses rose 29.8%. The company's full-year net loss narrowed to S$3.8 million, from S$8.6 million a year ago. Innopac shares have been suspended since June 2018 and the company has not received any exit offer from shareholders. The board is exploring options to move the company forward, including monetising assets.

site_title: Japan won't join US coalition to protect Middle East shipping, will send own force
summary: Japan will not join the US-led coalition to protect Middle East shipping, instead sending its own separate force of ships and planes to safeguard Japanese shipping interests. Japan will cooperate closely with the US but maintain diplomatic and economic ties with Iran. Japan's military assets, including warships and aircraft, will patrol the Gulf of Oman and surrounding waters. The deployment details and timeline have not been decided.

images.alt_text: "We won't join the United States, but will cooperate closely with them," Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga told a news briefing.

site_title: Pound drops as Johnson faces battle to pass Brexit bill
summary: The British pound fell on Friday as investors questioned Boris Johnson's chances of passing his Brexit deal through parliament. Despite a brief rally to almost $1.30 on Thursday, the pound dropped after opposition MPs and some Conservative party members expressed opposition to the deal. The deal's passage is seen as crucial to avoid a potentially catastrophic exit from the EU without a divorce agreement. The economic implications of a no-deal Brexit have raised concerns among investors, contributing to the pound's decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend falls; weak China data weighs on market
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, marking the second straight session of losses, due to weak economic growth data from China and investors taking profits after a recent rally. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,649.70. Energy stocks were particularly affected, with Origin Energy down 2.5% due to weak oil prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is investigating whether policy action is needed to target buy-now-pay-later operators who prevent merchants from passing on costs to customers.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars rally on rate view and China relief
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged to four-week highs, with the Australian dollar reaching US$0.6835 and the New Zealand dollar at US$0.6376, as market expectations of a near-term interest rate cut in Australia were scaled back. The rally followed a surprise dip in unemployment and comments from RBA Governor Philip Lowe that lower rates were working to improve the economy. Meanwhile, Chinese data showed slowed economic growth but also industrial output and retail sales growth, offering hints that stimulus was supporting activity.

site_title: Singapore researchers create world's largest Asian genetic databank
summary: Singapore researchers have created the world's largest Asian genetic databank, containing the whole-genome sequencing data of around 5,000 Singaporeans. The project, which began four years ago, aims to help scientists diagnose rare diseases, understand chronic ailments, and shed light on the country's history. The databank was published in the top biomedical journal Cell and could have significant implications for healthcare in the region.

site_title: Thai Sept domestic car sales drop 14.1% y-o-y: industries federation
summary: Thai domestic car sales dropped 14.1% in September from a year earlier to 76,195 units, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline. The sales contraction was attributed to stricter lending by banks and floods in the country. Domestic car sales in 2019 are now forecast to reach 1 million units, down from 1.05 million projected earlier.

site_title: Why the protests in Hong Kong may have no end in sight
summary: Hong Kong protests may not subside as Beijing's local allies disagree on how to address the crisis. The pro-Beijing camp is divided between populists who want greater democracy and tycoons who prioritize business interests. The city's embattled chief executive, Carrie Lam, has tried to negotiate with democracy advocates, but her efforts have been met with criticism from Beijing's allies. The divisions have weakened the pro-Beijing coalition, with some parties facing potential losses in upcoming elections. A compromise on democracy remains unlikely, with both sides dug in, leaving the protests potentially ongoing for months or years.

site_title: TSMC's US$15b splurge galvanizes hope of 5G-led rebound
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) is investing up to $15 billion in 2019, a 50% increase from its original estimate, to support the rollout of 5G networks and boost chip demand. The company expects 5G to drive chip sales and revenue growth, with projected current-quarter revenue surpassing estimates. TSMC's increased spending is also driven by demand from tech giants like Apple and Huawei. Analysts have raised price targets for the company's shares, and suppliers could benefit from TSMC's expanded capacity.

site_title: Trump announces departure of Energy Secretary Rick Perry
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the departure of Energy Secretary Rick Perry, citing his three-year tenure. Perry's departure comes amid the ongoing impeachment probe, which Trump said Perry had been "standing down" from. Perry had previously communicated with Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani over alleged corruption in Ukraine, according to an interview published earlier.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump said on Thursday Energy Secretary Rick Perry, who has been caught up the impeachment probe engulfing the US president, was standing down, marking the latest departure of a senior figure from the administration.

site_title: Ex-Credit Suisse banker says secret affair helped fuel US$45m fraud
summary: A former Credit Suisse banker, Andrew Pearse, testified in a US federal jury trial that his secret affair with a subordinate fueled his decision to take millions in bribes. Pearse admitted to receiving at least $45 million for arranging $2 billion in loans to companies in Mozambique. He claimed his affair with Detelina Subeva, a Credit Suisse banker, led him to quit the bank in 2013 and collaborate with Privinvest Group salesman Jean Boustani, who is accused of defrauding US investors.

site_title: Japan finance minister signals readiness to ramp up stimulus to fight risks
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso signals readiness to deploy fiscal stimulus measures to combat risks from a slumping global economy and the US-China trade war. Despite a moderate recovery expected, Aso acknowledges the need for a coordinated monetary and fiscal response to future crises. The government has taken steps to ease consumer pain from a recent sales tax hike, but some analysts worry the higher levy may add to pains for an export-reliant economy. Aso's comments come as the IMF suggests Japan can ramp up fiscal stimulus if the economy is hit harder than expected.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher in cautious trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following a rally on Wall Street, as investors awaited a British parliament vote on a new Brexit deal. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.45%, and the Topix index increased 0.29%. The move reflects cautious optimism ahead of the Brexit vote, despite ongoing US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Apple boss Tim Cook meets Chinese regulator after HK app criticism
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook met with China's top market regulator, a week after the tech giant removed an app from the App Store amid criticism from Beijing over its alleged support for Hong Kong protesters. The app, HKmap.live, allowed protesters to track police, prompting accusations that Apple prioritized business interests over human rights. The meeting aims to address concerns and maintain business operations in China, a crucial market for Apple.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Fitch Ratings expects investment risk for 5G to be contained over the next 18 months despite increased competition from Singapore's four 5G network operators. China's GDP growth is forecast to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index. In other news, Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter's suspension as Thai Prime Minister will be cleared by the court, and the ASEAN group agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy shrank for the second month, and South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

images.alt_text: Investment risk for 5G is expected to be contained over the next 18 months, despite raised competition from the Singapore government's decision to award licences to operate up to four such mobile networks, double the two initially planned.

site_title: Zuckerberg defends Facebook's hands-off policy for politicians
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg defended the company's policy of not fact-checking politicians, citing a long tradition of free expression. He stated that private companies should not censor politicians or news in a democracy, but may remove content that leads to harm. Zuckerberg also expressed concerns about the role of Chinese firms in shaping the internet's values and warned against regulations that could compromise free expression. He emphasized the importance of open expression and the need for caution in regulating online discourse.

site_title: US$1b pulled from Hong Kong hedge funds in Q3, most since 2009
summary: Hong Kong's hedge fund industry saw a record $1 billion in net redemptions in Q3, the largest quarterly outflow since 2009. Despite this, total hedge fund assets in Hong Kong rose to $92 billion in August, driven by positive market returns. The withdrawals were primarily from small- and medium-sized hedge funds, with larger funds experiencing positive allocations. Analysts say the protests have not yet posed a significant threat to the industry, with access to Chinese onshore markets and the broader region expected to remain attractive.

site_title: China's GDP growth slows to 6% in 3rd quarter: official
summary: China's economy expanded at 6.0% in the third quarter, the slowest rate in nearly three decades, due to cooling domestic demand and the ongoing US trade war. This growth rate is within the government's target range of 6.0-6.5% for the year. Despite efforts by the government to support the economy, including tax and rate cuts, the economy remains under pressure from global economic slowdown and external uncertainties. The International Monetary Fund has lowered its 2019 growth forecast for China to 6.1%.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Friday's open; STI down 0.1% to 3,122.90
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% to 3,122.90 on Friday, following differing reactions in US and European markets to a draft Brexit agreement. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 46, with Rex International's shares up 2.3% after an oil and gas discovery. Property firm Imperium Crown traded up 12.5% and Jiutian Chemical remained unchanged. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, while European shares edged lower due to fading optimism over the Brexit deal.

site_title: Petrobras reports major rise in Q3 production
summary: Brazilian state-run oil firm Petrobras reported a 14.6% increase in Q3 production to 2.878 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, reaching a new record of 3 million boepd in August. The company is on track to meet its annual production target of 2.7 million boepd.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on global slowdown worries; New Zealand dips
summary: Australian shares dropped on Friday due to a weaker US dollar affecting healthcare firms and concerns over a global slowdown amid Brexit and Sino-US trade talks. China's economic growth slowed to 6.0% year-on-year, the weakest pace in 27.5 years, amid a trade war with the US. Global markets await progress on the US-China trade deal and Brexit.

site_title: Europe endorses Brexit deal and urges UK MPs to back it
summary: European Union leaders endorsed a Brexit deal with the UK on Thursday, approving a hard-fought accord that includes provisions to protect the rights of remaining EU citizens and the integrity of the single market. However, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces an uphill battle getting the deal through the British parliament, with opposition parties and some of his own allies expressing concerns. A rejection of the deal would force Johnson to ask EU leaders to postpone Brexit for a third time, potentially breaking his vow to lead Britain out on October 31.

site_title: Japan says trade deal with US will boost GDP by 0.8%
summary: Japan's trade deal with the US is expected to boost the country's economy by 0.8% and contribute 4 trillion yen to its GDP. The deal cuts tariffs on US farm goods, Japanese machine tools, and other products, while preventing higher US car duties. The pact is estimated to create 280,000 jobs in Japan. The agreement was signed in a limited trade deal, further staving off the threat of higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The trade deal reached between Japan and the United States is expected to boost Japan's economy by about 0.8 per cent, the Japanese government said on Friday.

site_title: Drama of disruption
summary: A Singaporean play, Merdeka, challenges the commonly taught founding story of the country, questioning who gets to shape history. The play, substantiated by historical books, reveals that Singapore was not a sleepy fishing village but a thriving trading port, and Sir Stamford Raffles was not the benign figure often portrayed. The production encourages the audience to question prevailing narratives, read widely, and consider multiple interpretations, promoting intellectual honesty and critical thinking. The play runs until November 2 at the Ngee Ann Kongsi Theatre @ W!ld Rice.

site_title: Europe: Tempered Brexit hopes drag stocks into red
summary: European shares fell 0.1% as Brexit optimism faded, despite a strong earnings report from Ericsson. The EU and Britain had clinched a deal on Brexit terms, but the Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) vowed to vote against it. Investors also focused on US-EU trade talks and a new funding round for eSIM platform Airalo, which lifted its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Juul suspends US sales of some flavoured e-cigarettes
summary: Juul Labs has suspended sales of mango, cream, fruit, and cucumber flavored e-cigarette pods in the US, as the government prepares a nationwide ban. The company will continue to sell tobacco, menthol, and mint-flavored products. The move comes amid a mysterious vaping epidemic linked to at least 33 deaths in 24 states, with THC involved in over three-quarters of cases. The US government is also planning to ban flavored e-cigarettes, with President Trump's administration backing this move.

site_title: Q&M Dental opens Singapore's first private dentistry college, launches scholarships
summary: Q&M Dental Group has opened Singapore's first private dentistry college, offering a two-year graduate diploma course in clinical dentistry. The college, located at City Square Mall, aims to revolutionize the dental landscape in Singapore and the region. The college will also provide scholarships to local bachelor of dental surgery students, with the goal of attracting top talent. Q&M aims to make Singapore a hub for dental health in the region and create a new generation of skilled dentists.

site_title: Britain, EU reach Brexit draft deal, all eyes on UK parliament vote
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has reached a draft deal with the European Union after over 1,200 days since the Brexit referendum. The deal has led to a surge in sterling, with the currency rising by almost 6% against the US dollar. Shares of companies reliant on the UK market have also seen significant gains. The UK parliament will now vote on the deal, which could determine the country's future relationship with the EU.

site_title: G-7 countries seeking common stance on Facebook's Libra
summary: Finance officials from the Group of Seven economies are meeting to discuss Facebook's Libra digital currency, which they fear undermines their control over the global financial system. The European Central Bank's Benoit Coeure is set to present a report on digital currencies, and regulators have promised close oversight and tough regulation. Despite this, Libra's launch is still uncertain, with concerns over its potential impact on the global economy and the need for clear governance. The G-7 nations are seeking a unified stance on Libra to address these concerns.

site_title: Renault warns 2019 sales drop will be steeper than expected
summary: Renault has revised its 2019 sales guidance downward, citing a less favorable economic environment and increasing costs due to regulatory requirements. The company now expects sales to drop between 3% and 4%, a steeper decline than initially anticipated. Operating margin is forecast to fall to 5% from a previous goal of 6%. Renault's operating free cash flow may not turn positive for the year, but is expected to be in the black in the second half. The company's strategic plan is being reassessed amid a broad-based slowdown in the automotive industry.

site_title: CIMB Singapore eyes US$100m of trade financing via blockchain
summary: CIMB Bank in Singapore has successfully completed its first structured trade financing transaction on a blockchain platform, iTrust, valued at US$1 million. The transaction, which involved financing dairy products imported into China, aims to reduce risks associated with commodity trade financing. iTrust provides secured real-time tracking of cargo using blockchain-based technology, allowing for more efficient and cost-effective trade financing. CIMB plans to push up to US$100 million in trade financing transactions on the platform over the next 12 months, with each trade averaging US$1 million.

site_title: Punk Pop Pioneers
summary: Green Day, a five-time Grammy-winning punk-pop trio, announced their return to Singapore in 2020 as part of their global stadium tour. The tour will support their upcoming 13th studio album, Father of All..., and includes solo dates in Asia and Europe, as well as a co-headlining jaunt with Weezer and Fall Out Boy in North America and Europe. The concert will take place at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on March 8, 2020, with tickets ranging from S$108 to S$198.

images.alt_text: Green Day plays Singapore Indoor Stadium on March 8 2020 at 8pm.

site_title: New Zealand cops trial armed patrols after mosques shooting
summary: New Zealand police have introduced armed patrols in response to the Christchurch mosque massacre, where 51 Muslim worshippers were killed. The patrols, which include Armed Offender Squads, will be constantly on patrol in specialized vehicles to increase response times. The trial, being monitored closely, does not mean police will move to routine arming. The move is part of a series of reforms introduced by the government, including tightening gun laws and launching a firearms buyback scheme. The alleged gunman, Brenton Tarrant, is set to plead not guilty to 51 counts of murder in June 2024.

site_title: International Cement Group gets 6-month extension to exit SGX watch list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted International Cement Group a six-month extension to December 4, 2020, to exit its watch list under the minimum trading price (MTP) entry criteria. The company, formerly known as Compact Metal Industries, had its mainboard listing transferred in March and meets the requirement of an average daily market capitalization of S$40 million or more over the last six months. This extension comes as SGX RegCo plans to seek public feedback on a proposal to scrap the MTP requirement for mainboard-listed companies.

site_title: Dinner With A Vue
summary: VUE, a revamped dining and lifestyle destination, has opened on the penthouse of OUE Bayfront in Collyer Quay. The restaurant, formerly known as me@OUE, now focuses on binchotan-cooked specialities and features a rooftop spritz bar and a 60-seater dining area. Chef Sam Chin's menu showcases options like wagyu and black truffle risotto. The venue boasts a dramatic walkway, cathedral-inspired high ceilings, and a dazzling waterfront view. VUE is located at OUE Bayfront, 50 Collyer Quay, and can be reached at 8879-0923.

images.alt_text: Vue is at OUE Bayfront, 50 Collyer Quay.

site_title: UAW says GM strike to continue until workers vote on deal
summary: General Motors workers will not return to work until their union membership votes on a new contract. The UAW GM National Council voted to send a tentative deal to the workforce, with ratification expected by October 25. The strike, launched on September 16, was called off after a preliminary agreement was reached between the UAW and GM. The full union membership must now vote on the deal before workers can return to work.

site_title: Coffee And Coasters
summary: Nespresso released a limited edition Singapore Marvels sleeve pack for National Day, featuring iconic architectural wonders like the Toa Payoh Dragon Playground and Supertrees of Gardens by the Bay as coasters. The pack includes five sleeves with popular blends Tribute to Milano and Tribute to Trieste, as well as Corto, Livanto, and Ristretto. The Singapore Marvels pack retails for S$38.80.

site_title: Temasek ramps up push into renewables
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investor, is ramping up its focus on renewable energy investments. The company is considering setting up a new unit to house renewable power projects, citing the increasing volatility of commodity prices and societal shift towards sustainability. Temasek's joint head, Nagi Hamiyeh, stated that the group sees natural gas as a relatively clean energy source and is prepared to invest in greenfield projects with potential single-digit returns. Two options are being explored: partnering with an operator or building a platform around a team of experts.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on Brexit progress, Netflix results
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday following the announcement of a new Brexit deal between Britain and the EU, with Netflix and Morgan Stanley gaining on solid earnings. Despite opposition from Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, analysts welcomed the agreement, which amends provisions on the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: NBA boss Silver says losses in China row 'substantial'
summary: NBA commissioner Adam Silver stated that the league has suffered "substantial" losses following its dispute with China, citing the suspension of lucrative sponsorship and telecast deals. The losses occurred after Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey tweeted support for pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, prompting the Chinese government to call for Morey's firing. Silver defended the NBA's stance, saying it supported free expression while also acknowledging the value of engaging with Chinese fans and business.

images.alt_text: NBA commissioner Adam Silver said Thursday the league has suffered "substantial" losses following its dispute with China.

site_title: Oil rises, supported by US fuel stock draws but weighed by crude build
summary: Oil prices rose about 1% on Thursday, driven by US fuel inventory draws but capped by a larger-than-expected rise in crude stockpiles. Global benchmark Brent crude rose 49 cents to $59.91 a barrel, while US WTI crude gained 57 cents to $53.93 a barrel. Refinery output fell to its lowest capacity use since Hurricane Harvey in 2017, offsetting the draws. Despite this, concerns about slowing demand and weak economic figures, including US retail sales and housing starts, weigh on the market.

site_title: Don't forget - concert to raise awareness of Alzheimer's
summary: A concert in Singapore aims to raise awareness about Alzheimer's disease, which affects one in 10 people aged 60 and above. The Alzheimer's Disease Association (ADA) is promoting awareness and reducing stigma through various avenues, including social media and the concert "Love for All Seasons" on October 26. Experts emphasize the importance of early diagnosis, treatment, and support for both patients and caregivers. The number of dementia cases worldwide is expected to rise to 152 million by 2050, highlighting the need for increased awareness and research.

site_title: Scare Tactics
summary: Pan Pacific Singapore's Edge restaurant will transform into a ghoulish graveyard for Halloween, featuring a "nightmare menu" of fright food, including Demonic Nun, Freddy Krueger's Knife Shaved Crudo, and Corpse on Stretcher. The event, Hello-ween, will take place on November 2 for dinner and November 3 for brunch, priced at S$98 and S$148 respectively for adults. Reservations can be made by calling 6826 8240 or emailing dining.ppsin@panpacific.com.

site_title: Four new industry trials rolled out for 5G
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has announced four new industry trials for 5G wireless services, including a smart port trial with PSA and M1, and a model factory 5G pilot with Singtel, JTC Corp, and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research. Other trials include smart mobility tests with CapitaLand, high-quality gaming trials with Razer, and a 5G trial with M1 and Nanyang Technological University involving shuttle buses and self-driving cars. The trials demonstrate industry interest in 5G and will be supported by a S$64 million fund for 5G development.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, SPH, SGX, Second Chance Properties, SK Jewellery
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks saw new developments on Friday. Keppel Corp reported a 30% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$159 million, while Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) cut 5% of staff and posted a 23.4% decline in net profit. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) established its first multicurrency debt issuance program. Second Chance Properties and Pollux Properties also reported lower profits, while Sarine Technologies expects a "nominal net profit" in the third quarter. Meanwhile, SK Jewellery launched a new line of lab-grown diamonds, and Soilbuild Construction Group won a contract worth S$28.8 million.

site_title: 'IPOs are not the goal, but milestones on road to profitability'
summary: Singaporean equity capital markets expert Mohamed Nasser Ismail emphasized the importance of delivering returns and maintaining risk management for startups. He stated that an initial public offering (IPO) is not the goal, but rather a milestone in a company's journey to profitability. Nasser stressed the need for robust internal control processes and risk management frameworks before going public, as companies face strict listing standards in the public market. He also highlighted the need for startups to demonstrate a path to profitability, as public market investors are not patient and expect growth and returns.

site_title: UK heading for 'fairly hard' Brexit if Johnson deal passes
summary: Britain is on track for a "fairly hard" Brexit, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's deal expected to lead to more distant economic ties with the European Union, potentially making the country poorer. The deal, which reduces regulatory alignment and trade barriers, is forecast to cause the British economy to grow more slowly than if it stayed in the EU. Analysts estimate that the deal could make Britons 6% poorer on a per capita basis, equivalent to £2,000 per year, in the medium term.

site_title: Citi promotes Peter Babej to CEO for Asia-Pacific
summary: Citi has promoted Peter Babej to CEO of its Asia-Pacific region, effective immediately. Babej, who joined Citi in 2010, brings extensive experience in the sector, including a record-breaking fund-raising round for Ant Financial. The move follows a period of transition, with interim CEO Tim Monger taking over from Francisco Aristeguieta earlier this year. The promotion is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the region's growing digital adoption and fast-growing financial services landscape. Babej will oversee a region contributing around one-fifth of Citi's revenues and close to a third of its net income.

site_title: KL orders China map cut from Abominable film as furore widens
summary: Malaysia's film censors have ordered a scene removed from the animated movie Abominable, which depicts China's "nine-dash line" in the South China Sea. The move comes amid growing anger among countries with overlapping claims in the waterway. Vietnam had already pulled the movie from cinemas, while the Philippines' foreign minister called for the scene to be cut. The film will still be released in Malaysian cinemas on November 7, with the condition that the map is removed.

site_title: Pound goes on rollercoaster ride after Brexit draft deal
summary: The British pound experienced a volatile session on October 17, 2019, after a draft Brexit deal between London and Brussels was announced. Sterling surged to within a whisker of $1.30, but then plummeted into negative territory due to concerns over parliamentary backing for the agreement. The pound ultimately stabilized, but the outcome remains uncertain, with the DUP opposing the deal and opposition lawmakers threatening to vote it down. The market awaits the outcome of the UK parliamentary vote on Saturday, with some analysts citing a chance of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: China office vacancies hit decade high
summary: China's office vacancy rate has reached a decade high of 21.5% in the third quarter, according to CBRE Group. The nation's deepening economic slowdown and supply glut are contributing factors. This is the worst spike in vacancies since the 2008 global financial crisis. Experts attribute the issue to China's economic slowdown and oversupply of office space, with the vacancy rate in 17 major cities rising significantly.

site_title: Lam escorted from legislature amid heckling again from lawmakers
summary: Hong Kong's parliament descended into chaos as about a dozen lawmakers were ejected for heckling Carrie Lam amid calls for an inquiry into a brutal attack on prominent human rights activist Jimmy Sham. The attack, which left Sham bloodied, was seen as an attempt to intimidate protesters ahead of a major rally. Lam offered no response to demands for her resignation and defended her policies, while pro-democracy lawmakers accused her of having "blood on her hands." The incident underscores the deepening rift in the city, with protests continuing for over four months.

site_title: Euro jumps to near 2-month highs on Brexit deal
summary: The euro jumped to near 2-month highs against the dollar after the European Union and Britain struck a Brexit deal, with the euro rising 0.65% to 86.85 pence. However, sterling sank into losses due to fears of parliamentary approval. The euro's surge pushed it above $1.11 for the first time in a month, boosting confidence in a low price.

site_title: Tharman receives inaugural award for leadership and service in global finance
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam received the first Distinguished Leadership and Service Award from the Institute of International Finance (IIF) for his leadership and service in global finance. Tharman, who chairs the Monetary Authority of Singapore and is deputy chairman of the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, emphasized the need for cooperative international networks and global financial reforms for inclusive and sustainable growth. The award is given to recognize his contributions to building resilient and growth-oriented financial markets.

images.alt_text: Mr Tharman is in Washington DC for the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: As public transport fares go up, so too must reliability and service standards
summary: Singapore public transport fares are set to increase by 7% on December 28, the largest percentage hike since 1998. The nine-cent increase will affect 3.2 million daily trips, with 1 in 2 commuters paying no more than four cents extra. The fare hike is part of a new fare formula, and for the first time, polytechnic students will receive student concession rates.

site_title: Asian cities risk stumbling 'zombie-like' into digital dystopia
summary: Asian cities are increasingly relying on technologies like AI and facial recognition to deliver public services, but urban experts warn that this trend risks creating a "zombie-like" digital dystopia. Governments across the region are investing in Smart Cities, but experts urge authorities to address concerns over data privacy and security, particularly for vulnerable populations. As AI continues to evolve, it is also becoming increasingly capable of lying and threatening its creators.

site_title: Singapore startups bag S$13.4b funding in first nine months
summary: Singapore startups secured S$13.4 billion in funding in the first nine months of 2019, a 36% increase from the previous year, according to Enterprise Singapore. The majority of the funding, S$6.8 billion, was allocated to digital tech startups, with deep tech sectors like agri-food, urban solutions, and healthcare seeing significant investments. The government-backed Startup SG Equity scheme also spurred deal-making activity, with S$160.5 million in private sector capital deployed.

site_title: Partial trade agreement with China being formalised, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that a partial trade agreement with China is being formally finalized, with China committing to purchasing $40-50 million worth of US agriculture products annually. The deal includes concessions on intellectual property, financial services, and currencies, but does not address tariffs imposed on hundreds of billions of dollars in trade. Markets rallied after the announcement, but officials in Beijing expressed skepticism about the agreement's significance. Trump hopes to sign the agreement with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Chile next month.

site_title: Keppel's Q3 profit falls 30% in absence of divestment gains
summary: Keppel Corp's Q3 net profit fell 30% to S$159 million due to higher net interest expenses and lower divestment gains. Revenue jumped 60% to S$2.07 billion, driven by higher recognition from offshore & marine, property, and infrastructure projects. The company's offshore & marine division posted a 52% revenue increase, while property division revenue more than doubled to S$385 million. Despite the decline in profit, Keppel's shares were down only 0.3% to S$5.96.

site_title: Blooming Good Time
summary: Gardens by the Bay's Flower Dome features an inaugural Rhododendron Radiance floral display with over 80 varieties of blooms until October 28. The display showcases vibrant flowers in red, pink, yellow, and white hues, including 'Mount Loma Prieta', 'Meadow Lemon', and 'Sierra Sunset'. Admission to the conservatories applies, offering a perfect spot for floral enthusiasts and those seeking visual inspiration.

images.alt_text: Rhododendron Radiance floral display is on till Oct 28, at Flower Dome, Gardens by the Bay.

site_title: DPM Heng on the trade war, China ties and Singapore's coming polls
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat expressed skepticism about the US and China resolving their trade dispute in a few meetings, but noted that partial agreements can be a good first step. He emphasized the need for structural policies to transform Singapore's economy, focusing on industry transformation maps and consultations with business leaders. Heng also highlighted the importance of Singapore-China cooperation, citing the country's headstart in regional development areas and its eight business councils with China. He added that Singapore's upcoming general election preparations are ongoing, with the ruling party seeking a "fairly good slate of candidates".

site_title: Russian Classic
summary: A Singaporean production of the Russian play "Dear Elena" is set to run at the Drama Centre Black Box until October 20. The play revolves around a group of students who visit their lonely schoolteacher's home to throw her a surprise birthday party, but things take a dark turn when they demand the key to her safe containing their exam papers. The play explores the moral complexities of the situation, highlighting the flaws in the system and the teacher's defense of it. Tickets are available from Sistic.

images.alt_text: Dear Elena runs at the Drama Centre Black Box from now till Oct 20.

site_title: KORE to raise US$75.6m from private placement to fund Dallas property buy
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) has successfully completed a private placement to raise US$75.6 million, exceeding four times the initial target, to fund the US$101.5 million acquisition of One Twenty Five, a Class-A office complex in Dallas, Texas. The placement, priced at 72.5 US cents per new unit, will partially finance the acquisition and improve trading liquidity. The manager will declare an advanced distribution for the period from July 1 to the day before the new units are issued, and trading of the new units is expected to commence on October 29.

site_title: Dubai Deal
summary: Emirates is offering a promotional deal to Singapore passengers, including a two-night hotel stay in Dubai, for bookings made until Oct 22. Return air fares start from S$678 for Economy and S$3158 for Business Class, valid for travel between Oct 11 and Dec 25. The hotel stays can be redeemed between Oct 22 and Dec 27 by entering the promotional code SGDUBAI when booking on emirates.com/sg.

site_title: Marlon James, Acclaimed Author
summary: Marlon James, a Jamaican author, has achieved significant literary success with his novel "Black Leopard, Red Wolf," which has been optioned for a screen adaptation and nominated for the National Book Awards. His previous novel "A Brief History of Seven Killings" earned him the Man Booker Prize in 2015, catapulting him to international recognition. James discusses his writing process, drawing inspiration from Jamaican patois and his own experiences as a black, queer author. He emphasizes the importance of empathy and distance in writing about traumatic events, and believes that books offer a unique, personal experience that cannot be replicated by digital media.

site_title: Pre-owned watch dealers go big time
summary: Pre-owned watch dealers in Singapore have seen a surge in demand for high-end models, with some boutiques selling them at up to three times the retail price of new timepieces. This trend is attributed to the growing popularity of luxury pre-owned watches. Despite initial concerns about the "grey" watch trade, the industry has evolved to cater to a more discerning clientele, offering a range of high-quality, pre-owned timepieces. The upscale nature of the pre-owned watch market has transformed the industry, with many boutiques now offering luxury pre-owned watches alongside new timepieces.

site_title: Chinese food, western-style, at Imperial Treasure
summary: The article reviews Imperial Treasure's new restaurant-in-a-restaurant concept, "Tasting Room", located in Great World City, Singapore. The reviewer criticizes the concept, stating it lacks style and substance, with counter-style, omakase-only dining that removes personal space and choice. The restaurant's phone numbers and operating hours are provided, but no overall conclusion is drawn about the restaurant's quality.

site_title: Plenty of parallels between now and the past, but lessons are less plentiful
summary: Historian Graham Allison draws parallels between ancient Greece's Peloponnesian War and the current US-China conflict, citing Thucydides' account as a model of realism. Allison argues that the Greek historian's timeless rule is that war is more likely when a rising power challenges an established power. However, the article questions the assumption that Thucydides' realism applies to international relations, instead suggesting that his work reveals the tragic implications of human nature and the inevitability of consequences. Ultimately, the article concludes that studying the past may not provide actionable lessons for navigating the present, but rather encourages modesty and lucidity.

site_title: Writing a new chapter
summary: Singapore's Writers Festival, now in its 'wokest' edition, has seen a bold and progressive lineup curated by new director Pooja Nansi. The festival, featuring hundreds of writers, showcases a distinctly personal and politically-conscious vision, with marquee names headlining the event. This marks a significant shift from previous directors, who curated strong line-ups but lacked Nansi's bold vision. The festival's programming speaks to Nansi's focus on addressing issues such as racism, sexism, and homophobia, solidifying her reputation as a progressive leader in the literary world.

site_title: Sept y-o-y NODX falls again, but improves on August showing
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 8.1% year-on-year in September, following a 9% drop in August, mainly due to lower exports to Europe, the US, and Japan. Electronics exports declined 24.8%, while non-electronics exports fell 26.7%, 10.6%, and 52% respectively. A recovery in manufacturing and exports depends on a US-China trade deal, with economists predicting a continued weak economy and GDP growth of 0.6% this year.

site_title: Singapore, US sign pact to cooperate on infrastructure finance
summary: Singapore and the US signed a pact to strengthen cooperation in infrastructure finance and debt market development, building on existing bilateral cooperation to facilitate technical exchanges and information sharing. The agreement aims to support infrastructure development in Southeast Asia and promote private sector investments. The pact will be implemented by agencies such as Singapore's Ministry of Finance and the Monetary Authority of Singapore. This move is seen as part of a broader effort to address the region's infrastructure financing needs, with the Global Infrastructure Hub estimating that developing Asia requires $51 trillion in infrastructure investment by 2040.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler faces US$79m US fine for fuel economy shortfall
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has been fined US$79 million for failing to meet 2017 fuel economy requirements. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) reported that 13 major US carmakers, including FCA, fell short of fuel economy and greenhouse gas emissions standards. The shortfall was 1.5 miles per gallon for the 2017 model year without using credits. FCA plans to spend US$10 billion to develop hybrid and electric vehicles, but the fine is not expected to significantly impact its business.

site_title: Concerns flagged on China propaganda app
summary: A widely downloaded Chinese propaganda app, "Study to make China strong," has raised concerns over data collection and potential security breaches. The app, which has 130 million users, collects location, emails, and other personal data, and contains code that could run "arbitrary commands" on certain phones. An investigation by the Open Technology Fund found that the app "maintains a level of access that no app would normally have over a user's device." The app's creators have not responded to allegations, and users' data may be further jeopardized if the code is used successfully.

site_title: Far East Hospitality to open The Clan Hotel in Q2 2020
summary: Far East Hospitality is set to open The Clan Hotel in Singapore's Telok Ayer neighbourhood in the second quarter of 2020. The luxury hotel, featuring 324 rooms, aims to redefine luxury for a new generation of travellers. With a focus on experience-driven travel, the hotel offers unique services such as immediate room check-in, a welcome tea ceremony, and turndown services. CEO Arthur Kiong stated that this new generation of travellers is willing to pay more for unique experiences, defining luxury beyond traditional expectations.

site_title: After Delta deal, Qatar Airways may raise LATAM stake
summary: Qatar Airways CEO Akbar al-Baker stated that the airline may consider increasing its stake in LATAM Airlines Group SA if the opportunity arises, after Delta Air Lines' $1.9 billion deal with the Chilean carrier. Qatar Airways currently holds a 10% stake, which could fall to 28% if Delta's tender offer is fully taken up. The airline has historically had a contentious relationship with major US carriers, but al-Baker denied prior knowledge of Delta's deal, which ended LATAM's ties with American Airlines.

site_title: Opportunities for Singapore in region despite economic challenges, says Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore remains a key player in the region despite economic challenges, according to Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Chee Hong Tat. Dyson, despite shelving electric car plant plans, will continue to expand its presence in Singapore in areas such as sensor technology and artificial intelligence. The country has attracted nearly S$8.1 billion in fixed asset investment commitments in manufacturing and services in the first six months of this year. Chee emphasized the importance of a pro-business environment and deepening economic integration in Asean to capitalize on regional business opportunities.

site_title: CDL shares jump 5.2% after Citi reiterates 'buy' call
summary: CDL shares surged 5.16% to S$10.39, surpassing the S$10 mark for the first time in over a year, following a 'buy' call reiteration by Citi. The move comes after the property developer's shares jumped as much as S$0.53 or 5.4% on Thursday.

site_title: MCT prices placement units at rich end of price range on strong demand
summary: MAPLETREE Commercial Trust (MCT) priced a S$458 million private placement of new units at S$2.28 per unit, a 2.9% discount from its VWAP, on strong demand. The deal is part of MCT's S$1.55 billion acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 2) and will raise S$918.5 million from the fundraising. A preferential offering of S$460.5 million will also be held, with units expected to trade on Nov 15.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has established its first-ever S$1.5 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, allowing for the issuance of medium-term notes or perpetual securities in any currency and amount. This programme enables the trading of retail notes on the SGX Mainboard. Analysts are optimistic about SGX's earnings, citing a defensive play benefiting from market volatility, with some raising target prices.

site_title: GM and UAW reach deal that could end strike
summary: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers (UAW) reached a tentative 4-year contract deal, ending the company's longest strike in half a century. The agreement includes a $8,000 signing bonus, 3% wage increases, and 4% lump-sum payments. The UAW achieved "major wins" and plans to present the terms to its GM locals on Thursday. The deal could provide certainty in calculating labor costs over the next four years and pave the way for permanent employment for temporary workers.

site_title: East-West Design
summary: Two exhibitions showcase French and Japanese design aesthetics. "No Taste for Bad Taste," featuring works by designers such as Philippe Starck and Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, highlights 10 French design values, including heritage and audacity. In contrast, "Into the Woods: Yoshino Wood from Nara" showcases 11 Japanese makers who represent the culture, craftsmanship, and sustainability of Japan's forestry industry. Both exhibitions run until November 16 and October 30, respectively, at the National Design Centre and LUMINE Singapore.

site_title: Hotel Compass in Geylang up for sale with S$23-25m guide price
summary: Hotel Compass in Geylang, a freehold hotel with 49 rooms, is up for sale through public tender at a guide price of S$23-25 million. Located near Aljunied and Mountbatten MRT stations, the property is within a 20-minute drive from the central business district and Changi Airport. The hotel occupies a 436.9 sq m site area with a gross plot ratio of 2.8 and is zoned "commercial/institution". The sale presents a rare opportunity for investors and end-users, with no additional buyer's stamp duty applicable. The tender closes on November 1.

images.alt_text: The eight-storey Hotel Compass, which has 49 rooms and occupies a site area of 4,703 square feet, is near both Aljunied and Mountbatten MRT Stations.

site_title: The History of Time
summary: IWC Schaffhausen has unveiled its most extensive retrospective exhibition in Southeast Asia, showcasing the evolution of its three most successful watch families: Pilot's Watches, Portugieser, and Portofino. The two-week exhibition, running from October 14 to 27, highlights the unique spirit and craftsmanship behind each family. The event is part of the brand's focus on engineering and storytelling, according to Managing Director Stanislas Rambaud.

site_title: Sakae director quits over handling of auditor's disclaimer of opinion
summary: Sakae Holdings non-executive director Foo Maw Shen has resigned over differing views on the follow-up action to the disclaimer of the independent auditor's opinion in Sakae's audited financial results for fiscal 2019. Shen resigned as chairman of the nominating committee and a member of the audit committee, effective October 16. The resignation comes after the auditor's disclaimer, which raised concerns about the company's financial reporting.

site_title: My nonna and her pasta, on YouTube?
summary: Vicky Bennison, a 60-year-old British woman, created Pasta Grannies, a YouTube channel featuring Italian nonnas, to document their traditional pasta-making techniques before they disappear. The channel unexpectedly gained popularity, turning the nonnas into minor celebrities. Bennison's intention was not to create influencers but to preserve a way of life.

site_title: The end of Pax Americana in the Middle East
summary: The US has begun a gradual disengagement from the Middle East, marking the end of the "Pax Americana" era. President Trump's decision to partly disengage from Syria was driven by the American people's opposition to entanglement in another war in the region. Despite warnings from experts, Trump prioritized public sentiment, recognizing that a small US military presence could spark a backlash. The US has never had a strategic alliance with Kurdish forces, and Turkey's concerns about the security threat posed by them are well-founded. The era of US dominance in the Middle East is over, and regional powers must adjust to this reality.

site_title: Pollux Properties guides for net loss in Q1
summary: Pollux Properties expects a net loss in Q1 due to delays in obtaining a strata title for a project, resulting in additional costs and provision for liquidated damages. The company had previously incurred costs for the project and had obtained registration for the strata title application. Pollux Properties will report its financial results on or before October 29.

site_title: Virgin Galactic unveils space suits for its passengers
summary: Virgin Galactic has unveiled space suits for its passengers, designed to resemble Star Trek-like outfits. The custom suits will be worn by the first private astronauts on the world's first commercial space flight, although the exact date has not been confirmed. Founder Richard Branson introduced the suits, which are tailored to provide comfort and safety during space travel. The suits' design is a significant step forward for commercial space tourism.

site_title: The urgent need for greener mobility solutions
summary: Climate change is being taken seriously by governments and individuals, with recent developments highlighting the urgent need for greener mobility solutions. The International Transport Forum emphasizes the sector's need to decarbonize and increase collaboration to raise collective ambitions and develop specific policy pathways. Smarter, greener mobility solutions are required, including green traction, electric-powered road vehicles, driverless trains, and data-driven rail mobility, to address the crisis and delay its effects. Governments must make radical moves to address the challenge, which requires a massive change in mindset and collective action.

site_title: Malaysia's property market shows signs of picking up as developers build less
summary: Malaysia's property market appears to be stabilizing as developers build fewer homes, contrary to the previous glut. The number of completed units fell by one-third in the first half of 2019, while new projects decreased by a fifth. The government's measures, including discounts and incentives for home buyers, have contributed to this shift. With available units down and transaction values rising, home prices remain muted, averaging RM420,345. The minimum price for foreign buyers will be lowered to RM600,000 next year, expected to help alleviate the real estate glut.

site_title: Beautiful Hunchback
summary: Raimund Hoghe, a renowned dance dramaturg, has collaborated with Japanese butoh dancer Takashi Ueno to create Pas De Deux, a unique dance piece featuring commonplace objects from Japan. The dance, which challenges traditional notions of elegance and beauty, will be performed at the Esplanade Theatre Studio in Singapore on October 18 and 19. This is Hoghe's first appearance in Singapore for Esplanade's da:ns festival.

site_title: Cloth Tales
summary: SOUTH AFRICAN textile artist Deborah Mckellar has found inspiration in Singapore's heritage homes, creating mixed media artworks that reflect the country's history and culture. Her "Talking Textiles" series features hand-drawn silk screen prints, batik, and traditional hand painting, incorporating scenes of daily life and iconic buildings. The artworks are rich in color and texture, appealing to those who love Southeast Asian style, and have been replicated on household products. Mckellar hopes her creations can bring positivity to people's everyday lives by focusing on something to enjoy and admire.

site_title: Climate change is transforming centuries old winemaking practices
summary: Climate change is transforming centuries-old winemaking practices worldwide. Producers are adapting to hotter summers, warmer winters, droughts, and extreme weather events by experimenting with new techniques and grape varieties. This shift is resulting in the expansion of wine-growing regions, such as England, and the emergence of new wine styles. To counter the effects of climate change, winemakers are focusing on five key factors: planting grapes at higher altitudes, curtailing sunlight, considering alternative grape varieties, managing unpredictable weather, and developing new viticulture strategies.

site_title: Asean stands to gain from falling PE valuations: report
summary: A report by Dechert and Mergermarket suggests that South-east Asian countries, particularly Vietnam, can benefit from falling private equity valuations in China amid ongoing trade tensions. The report notes that deal activity in the Asia-Pacific region decreased in 2019, with only 320 deals and US$62.7 billion invested. However, experts believe that Vietnam and other countries in the region could see opportunities as valuations fall, with the potential for "outsized rewards" for investors willing to take on risks. The report highlights the growing interest in frontier markets in Southeast Asia.

site_title: RBA official warns of worse to come in Australia building slump
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Deputy Governor Guy Debelle warned that Australia's construction industry slump is not yet over, with building approvals 40% lower than their peak in 2017. He forecasts a 7% decline in dwelling investment over the next year and a potential even larger decline. The RBA estimates the slump will trim around 1% off economic growth. Despite this, population growth and increasing demand will lead to higher housing prices, with some developers retaining staff through the slump. The RBA's interest-rate cuts aim to address this expected evolution of the housing cycle.

site_title: Wall Street moves higher on Brexit deal, robust earnings
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by upbeat reports from Netflix and Morgan Stanley, and a preliminary Brexit deal between Britain and the European Union. The S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite, and Dow Jones Industrial Average all increased, with the S&P 500 up 16.73 points, or 0.56%, at 3,006.42. Investors also supported the market despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Judge summons drug company CEOs to court to discuss opioid settlement
summary: US District Judge Dan Polster has summoned the CEOs of the three largest US drug distributors and a drugmaker to discuss a proposed $50 billion settlement to resolve thousands of lawsuits alleging they fueled the US opioid crisis. The companies, including McKesson, Cardinal Health, AmerisourceBergen, and Teva Pharmaceutical, have been negotiating a deal that would allow them to resolve 2,600 lawsuits nationally. The proposal would see the companies pay $18 billion over 18 years and $4 billion to Johnson & Johnson, with Teva offering to give away medications valued at $15 billion.

images.alt_text: The order by US District Judge Dan Polster in Cleveland, Ohio, came as distributors McKesson Corp, Cardinal Health Inc, AmerisourceBergen Corp and Israel-based drugmaker Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd (above) moved to reach a deal ahead of a trial before him that begins on Monday.

site_title: UBS managing director Choo Oi Yee to join digital securities startup iSTOX
summary: UBS managing director Choo Oi Yee will join digital securities startup iSTOX as its first chief commercial officer in January 2020. Choo, who is currently serving her notice period at UBS, will drive business growth by building on its network of investors and issuers. iSTOX aims to become a regulated platform for digitized securities, backed by the Singapore Exchange and Temasek's Heliconia Capital. The startup recently raised Series A funds and appointed former MAS deputy director Lim Mei Shern as its head of compliance.

site_title: Bumper Q3 would mean banner year for hospitality deals
summary: Singapore is headed for a bumper year for hotel sales, with the third quarter recording the highest level of hospitality deals on record, totaling S$2.77 billion. The quarter saw significant transactions involving major hotels such as Bay Hotel, Mandarin Orchard, and Crowne Plaza Changi Airport. Total hospitality deals for the first nine months of the year exceeded S$4.2 billion, surpassing full-year figures in Colliers International's database since 2006. However, experts predict this performance may not be repeated in the fourth quarter, with significant deals still expected to be transacted.

site_title: Sarine Technologies expects 'nominal net profit' in Q3
summary: Sarine Technologies expects to post a "nominal net profit" in the third quarter, driven by a 20% increase in revenues to approximately US$14 million. The company attributes this growth to restrained expenses and a slight increase in sales and marketing. However, revenues from inclusion-mapping services decreased by 18% sequentially due to reduced polishing activity and seasonal closures of bourses in Israel and Belgium. The group delivered a new record of 39 inclusion-mapping systems in the quarter.

site_title: IMF chief calls for reversing tariffs threatening global growth
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva urged policy makers to resolve trade tensions threatening global growth, citing precarious economic conditions. Trade conflicts, policy uncertainty, and geopolitical threats undermine confidence, investment, and growth, posing a risk to global financial stability. Georgieva emphasized the need to reverse tariff increases and find lasting solutions to trade disputes, including strengthening the multilateral trading system. The IMF projects a 1.1% decline in global trade volume growth this year, with some recovery expected next year.

site_title: Dior apologises for China map excluding Taiwan
summary: Luxury brand Dior apologized for a map of China that excluded Taiwan, a self-ruled island viewed by Beijing as part of its territory. The incident sparked widespread criticism on Chinese social media, prompting Dior to deny any representation of its position and promise to investigate. The apology came after a student posted a video showing a Dior presentation with the map, which drew criticism for omitting Taiwan. The hashtag "Dior apologises" gained over 250 million views on Weibo, highlighting China's strong reaction to perceived insults to national sovereignty.

site_title: World's fastest ant clocks nearly a metre per second
summary: The Saharan silver ant, a species of Cataglyphis, has been recorded as the fastest ant in the world, reaching speeds of nearly a metre per second (855 mm/s) and covering 108 times its own body length per second. This feat surpasses other fast creatures, including the Australian tiger beetle and the California coastal mite. The ant's speed was measured in hot desert conditions and was found to slow down significantly when temperatures dropped. Its unique ability to swing its appendages at high speeds and increase stride length contribute to its remarkable speed.

site_title: SPH posts 23% drop in earnings, to trim 5% staff from media group
summary: SPH posts a 23.4% decline in net profit to S$213.2 million for the full year ended August 31, largely due to the absence of an one-off gain from the sale of its treasury and investment portfolio. The media group will trim its workforce by 130 staff, including 71 retrenchments, as it streamlines operations amid the digital transformation of its core media business. SPH aims to deliver more effective integrated solutions across various media platforms, with a focus on sustainable recurring income and dividend payouts.

site_title: Startup headed by ex-Apple engineer aims to eliminate smartphone buttons
summary: Sentons, a startup led by ex-Apple engineer Jess Lee, has begun marketing technology to eliminate smartphone buttons. The company's sensor system uses ultrasonic sound waves to detect touches, presses, and swipes on various materials. Sentons is working with two smartphone makers and has an existing contract with Asus Computer Inc. The technology is already being used in a phone designed for gamers released in China this summer.

site_title: Investments in Singapore startups up 36% to S$13.4b in 9M2019: ESG
summary: Singapore saw a 36% increase in investments in local startups to S$13.4 billion in the first three quarters of 2019, with digital tech startups receiving 93.2% of the total capital. Deeptech investments, particularly in advanced manufacturing, urban solutions, and sustainability, grew 25% year-on-year. The government's efforts, such as the Startup SG Equity scheme, spurred dealmaking activity, with co-investors deploying S$160.5 million in investments.

site_title: Thai political feud may delay budget
summary: Thailand's parliament is debating its annual budget, which could be delayed due to the ruling coalition's slim majority. The 3.2 trillion baht budget plan includes a 469 billion baht deficit and has been criticized by opposition parties. The debate, which began on October 17, will involve a series of votes, with the final one set for January. If the budget fails to pass, Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha may have to quit or dissolve the parliament, but this is unlikely to lead to a new election. The budget outcome will remain unclear until February 2020.

site_title: Johnson's Brexit foe plans another lawsuit to allow deal review
summary: Lawyer Jolyon Maugham plans to file a lawsuit to challenge the UK's Brexit deal, citing a potential breach in taxation legislation. Maugham hopes to secure more time for Parliament to scrutinize the agreement, which lawmakers will debate on Saturday. Maugham tweeted, "What - beyond Boris Johnson's desire to meet his self-imposed deadline - is the rush." The move could further delay the Brexit process, which has already faced several challenges and controversies.

site_title: Thai king postpones royal barge procession until December
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn has postponed the royal barge procession down Bangkok's Chao Phraya river until December 12, citing concerns over water conditions and weather. The procession, originally scheduled for October 24, was part of the coronation celebrations, which took place in May. The event, a traditional part of Thai royal ceremonies, was meant to allow Thais to greet the monarch and his queen. The delay is the latest adjustment to the coronation festivities, which have already been pushed back from their original date in October.

site_title: Raising Chinese Spirits
summary: Chinese-made wines, including baijiu and sake, are gaining popularity in Singapore's drinking scene. The recent Wine Pinnacle Awards recognized Ao Yun, a Chinese red wine, as 'Best Chinese Red', highlighting China's growth in the wine industry. According to Jeannie Cho-Lee, the world's first Asian Master of Wine, China has become one of the world's top 10 wine growers in a decade, producing high-quality wines showcasing the region's uniqueness. This recognition marks a significant milestone for China's wine industry, which has been gaining international attention.

images.alt_text: HuiManNong's follow-up to the Sakura Sake, Winter White.
Farmers of Silver Heights tending to the vines.
Aging of Langjiu in ceramic pots within Tian Bao Cave.
Lucus Liu, senior sommelier of Park90.
(Left) Red Star Er Guo Tou Zhen Chang, a light aroma-style baijiu. (Right) Silver Heights Reserve Rosé.
Sake Matsuri 2019, hosted by Inter Rice Asia and Temple Cellars.
(From left) Langjiu Qinghua Lang 20-Year Vintage; Silver Heights The Summit; Grace Vineyard Deep Blue; Luzhou Laojiao National Cellar 1573.

site_title: Snap launches dynamic ads to draw more advertisers
summary: Snap Inc. is launching dynamic ads that automatically create and target ads in real-time, aiming to compete for digital ad dollars. The feature, available to advertisers, removes the need for manual ad creation. This move follows larger rivals Google and Facebook's introduction of dynamic ads, and Snap seeks to attract more advertisers with the convenience. The launch is seen as a strategic move to grow revenue and user base, despite regulatory scrutiny over market control.

site_title: US manufacturing emerges from recession in Q3: Fed
summary: US manufacturing emerged from recession in the third quarter after a decline in the first two quarters due to President Trump's trade wars. However, in September, industrial production declined 0.4% due to a nationwide General Motors strike and cutbacks in crude oil production. Despite this, the third-quarter manufacturing rebound showed output still nearly 1% below September of last year. A tentative deal between GM and the United Auto Workers may end the strike soon, and manufacturing rose 1.1% for the quarter, led by computers and electronics, autos, and appliances.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction's precast & prefab unit wins S$28.8m HDB contract
summary: SOILBUILD Construction Group has won a S$28.8 million contract to fabricate and deliver precast concrete components for a public housing development project in Tengah, Singapore. The project is expected to start in Q1 2020 and complete by Q2 2021, bringing the group's order book to S$439 million. This contract marks a significant milestone for the company, further solidifying its position in the construction industry.

site_title: Britain clinches Brexit deal, Johnson now faces parliament hurdle
summary: Britain has clinched a Brexit deal with the EU after more than three years of negotiations, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson still faces a crucial vote in parliament to secure approval. The deal, agreed upon just hours before an EU summit in Brussels, is considered fair and balanced for both the EU and the UK. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker plans to recommend approval from other EU member states, but Johnson's parliamentary approval is seen as the final hurdle. The outcome of the vote is uncertain, with many considering it a knife-edge decision.

site_title: Second Chance Properties guides for lower profit in FY19
summary: Second Chance Properties, a Mainboard-listed company, expects to report a lower profit for FY19 due to an unrealised loss on property revaluation and a loss on sale of an investment property. This contrasts with a profit on sale of an investment property in FY18. The company will announce its unaudited financial results for FY19 on or before October 24.

site_title: Questions leaders need to ask amid the roiling global economy
summary: Global trade is facing significant challenges due to trade wars, nationalism, and the decline of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The EU-Mercosur Free Trade Agreement is threatened by political strife, while the US-Japan deal is less substantial than the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement on TPP (CPTPP). The second Singapore Trade Policy Forum will discuss key facets of the emerging crisis, including the impact of economic nationalism, the role of regional and plurilateral alternatives, and the potential for sectoral initiatives to fill the gap. Experts will also examine the need for WTO reform, digital economy rules, and the integration of climate change policy into trade policy.

site_title: SGX sets up first-ever S$1.5b multicurrency debt issuance programme
summary: SGX sets up its first-ever S$1.5 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, allowing for medium term notes or perpetual securities in any currency, amount, and tenor. The programme will be used to finance investments and general working capital purposes, with net proceeds to be managed actively. The move is in line with SGX's priorities to grow its asset classes and invest strategically as the business expands, providing flexibility to capture growth opportunities. DBS Bank and Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) are the arrangers of the programme.

site_title: SPH net profit falls 23% in FY19, to axe 5% of media staff
summary: SPH, Singapore's largest media company, reported a 23.4% decline in net profit to S$213 million for FY19, due to a decline in media revenue and advertising spend. To address this, the company will cut 5% of its media staff, resulting in S$8 million in retrenchment costs. Despite this, SPH's property revenue rose 22.3% and its digital transformation strategy showed progress. The company declared a final dividend of 6.5 cents per share and plans to streamline its media operations through a new integrated sales approach.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.69% to 26,848.49, driven by hopes for another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve following weak US data. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.05%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained unchanged.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Regulators in Singapore have floated licences for local 5G networks, which could serve hot spots such as laboratories or smart factories. Meanwhile, Singapore's non-oil exports continued to fall in September with an 8.1% drop. The country's hospitality deals reached a record S$2.8 billion in Q3. Singapore was chosen to host SAP's data centre due to its geopolitical stability and data privacy. A study by NUS found that the type of housing Singaporean parents own can impact their children's future economic status.

site_title: Four-way 5G market makes it anyone's game
summary: Singapore plans to award up to four 5G wireless network licenses, double the initial number, with two nationwide licenses and two smaller-scale local licenses. Mobile network operators, including Singtel, StarHub, M1, and TPG Telecom, will compete for the licenses, which will allow them to start services from 2021. The licenses come with conditions, such as covering at least half of the island by end-2022 and leasing network wholesale to peers. Analysts predict a crowded market with potential for price competition, but also note that the industry may adopt network-sharing and smaller-scale networks to save costs.

images.alt_text: Singapore is poised to award as many as four operating licences for its upcoming 5G wireless networks - double the number mooted in a public consultation earlier this year.

site_title: Tokio Marine Life hires new chief marketing officer, chief actuary
summary: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore (TMLS) has appointed Gilbert Pak as chief marketing officer and Michael Kuek as chief actuary, aiming to strengthen its strategic focus in product development and strategy.

site_title: Oil tankers hoarding fuel are anchored off Singapore ahead of new shipping rules
summary: More than 30 oil tankers are anchored off Singapore and Malaysia in the Malacca Strait, stockpiling fuel ahead of the IMO 2020 shipping rules taking effect on January 1. The flotilla has been expanding since April, with over 4.5 million tonnes of compliant fuels floating in the strait as of October 16. Traders are hoarding fuels such as low-sulphur fuel oil, gasoil, and blending components to meet the new standards, which require ships to use cleaner-burning fuels with less than 0.5% sulphur.

site_title: European stocks slip at open
summary: European stocks slipped at the open on Thursday due to Brexit fears ahead of a Brussels summit. The FTSE 100 index dropped 0.1%, the Paris CAC 40 index fell 0.4%, and the Frankfurt DAX 30 index slid 0.1%. The decline was largely attributed to Brexit concerns, which weighed on investor sentiment.

site_title: US housing starts fall
summary: US housing starts declined 9.4% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.256 million units, but single-family home construction rose for a fourth consecutive month. The decline was largely attributed to a drop in multi-family housing construction. Despite this, the housing market remains supported by lower mortgage rates, which have pushed down rates to 3.57% on average. Economists expect a mild rebound in residential investment in the third quarter after it contracted for six straight quarters.

images.alt_text: US homebuilding tumbled from a more than a 12-year high in September, but single-family home construction rose for a fourth straight month, suggesting the housing market remains supported by lower mortgage rates even as the economy is slowing.

site_title: Property plays a bright spot in cautious session
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore ended the session at 3,126.14, down 8.57 points or 0.3% due to cautious trading amidst global growth concerns and US-China issues.
