However, property plays such as City Developments Limited and Mapletree Commercial Trust saw upside, driven by bullish equity research reports and positive sentiment. Other Asian markets also weakened, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closing at a one-month high.

site_title: Australia shares end 5-day rally; miners drag
summary: Australian shares ended a five-session rally lower, slipping 0.8% to 6,684.70, dragged down by miners as iron ore prices slid 3% to their lowest in six weeks due to Chinese demand concerns. BHP Group and Rio Tinto lost 3.3% and 3%, respectively. Soft US retail sales data also weighed on the benchmark.

site_title: Ford partners with Volkswagen, Amazon to build charging network for cars
summary: Ford Motor Co has partnered with Volkswagen AG and Amazon.com to build a charging network for its future electric cars, with 12,000 locations and 35,000 charge plugs in North America. The network aims to provide customers with charging options from highways to homes. Ford plans to invest over $11 billion in electric vehicles, targeting a majority of its sales to be electric by 2022. This partnership is part of Ford's efforts to expand its electric vehicle offerings and provide customers with a seamless charging experience.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co said on Thursday it was teaming up with Volkswagen AG and Amazon.com to give its future electric car customers a range of charging options from highways to homes.

site_title: SK Jewellery launches lab-grown diamond line of products
summary: SK Jewellery has launched a new line of lab-grown diamonds, called Star Carat, which are chemically, optically, and physically identical to natural diamonds. The new line, priced as low as half the cost of natural diamonds, aims to cater to changing consumer preferences and address the expected shortage of natural diamonds due to falling yields. The launch is seen as a sustainable alternative, with SK Group CEO Daniel Lim stating that lab-grown diamonds will "revitalise the jewellery industry".

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.3% on Brexit woes, US-China worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% on Thursday, closing at 3,126.14, amid global concerns over Brexit, US-China issues, and doubts about a Brexit deal. However, a new Brexit deal announced by UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Friday could potentially boost equities. Property plays led gains, with City Developments Limited advancing 5.2%. Trading volume and turnover were high, with 832.95 million securities traded and S$924.14 million in total turnover.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts 30% fall in Q3 net profit to S$159m
summary: Keppel Corp's Q3 net profit fell 30% to S$159m due to a 30% decline in gains from divestments and lower interest income. Revenue jumped 60% to S$2.07b, driven by higher recognition from offshore & marine projects and increased sales in the power and gas business. The company's data centre business has become a growth area, with new contracts secured and revenue from property trading projects increasing. Earnings per share fell to 8.8 cents, and no dividend was recommended for the period.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.40 point to 1,574.50. Volume was 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 413 to 393.

site_title: East Ventures, Openspace among top VC performers in S-E Asia: Preqin
summary: East Ventures, Openspace Ventures, Vickers Venture Partners, and Golden Gate Ventures have been ranked as top-performing VC funds in South-east Asia by Preqin, with East Ventures' three funds ranking in the top five. East Ventures' Fund 1 and Fund 3 led with net IRRs of 70% and 65%, respectively, while Openspace's first fund ranked third with a net IRR of 44%. The rankings are based on funds with vintage years from 2009 to 2015 and measure expected returns after factoring in fees and carried interest.

site_title: Cashless payments between Singapore, Taiwan possible with Liquid Group, E.SUN tie-up
summary: Singapore startup Liquid Group has partnered with Taiwan's E.SUN Bank to open a QR payment corridor between Singapore and Taiwan, enabling cashless payments for overseas purchases. The partnership provides real-time notifications and online transaction histories for added security. This is the third market for Liquid Group's cross-border QR payment network, following Hong Kong and Indonesia. The move aims to support growing intra-regional travel in Asia and enable seamless payments across 10 markets.

site_title: Brexit scramble looms over fraught EU summit, Merkel says deal possible
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said a Brexit deal is still possible as EU leaders gather in Brussels for a two-day summit. Merkel stated there has been significant movement in recent days, but a deal has not been reached yet. The summit comes as UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson struggles to win parliamentary backing for his Brexit plan, which includes concessions on the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. EU leaders will also discuss other challenges, including the crisis in Syria and the EU's budget for 2021-2027.

site_title: Singapore High Court grants Libra 6-month protection against creditors
summary: The Singapore High Court granted Libra Group a six-month reprieve against its creditors, including UOB and Maybank Singapore, allowing the company to submit quarterly financial reports and asset valuations. Libra shares have been suspended from trading. The company must provide detailed information on property acquisitions or disposals within 14 days. This reprieve is seen as a temporary measure to give Libra time to address its financial issues.

site_title: CIMB Singapore to pump up to US$100m in trade finance via blockchain platform in 12 months
summary: CIMB Singapore has announced plans to invest up to US$100 million in trade finance transactions on a blockchain platform over the next 12 months. The platform, backed by GIC's former head of technology and a Singapore security-tracking firm, successfully completed its first structured trade financing transaction in October 2019. On average, each trade would be around US$1 million, with a single borrower involved. This initiative aims to increase efficiency and reduce costs in trade financing.

site_title: Malaysia needs to be ready for the worst in South China Sea: foreign minister
summary: Malaysia's foreign minister, Saifuddin Abdullah, has urged the country to boost its naval capabilities to prepare for a possible conflict in the South China Sea. Tensions have escalated in the region, with China claiming most of the sea under its "nine-dash-line". Malaysia could issue protest notes if its territory is encroached upon, but its naval assets are at a disadvantage compared to China's Coast Guard. Saifuddin emphasized the need for non-militarization and a united approach among Southeast Asian nations to resolve the issue.

site_title: Gold steady as disappointing US retail sales weigh on risk appetite
summary: Gold prices held steady at US$1,490.37 per ounce as weak US retail sales data raised concerns about the US economy's weakness and potential global recession. US retail sales fell for the first time in seven months, suggesting manufacturing-led weakness could spread to the broader economy. Investors await news on the US-China trade front, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin working on a phase 1 trade deal text.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,129.36, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks closed down 0.2% at 3,129.36 on Thursday, influenced by global growth concerns and US-China headlines. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 5.35 points, while regional peers such as Australia, Malaysia, and South Korea also fell. However, Hong Kong and Japan posted gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising due to hopes of further economic stimulus.

site_title: Dubai's biggest bank plans 6.45b dirham rights share sale
summary: Dubai's Emirates NBD PJSC plans to raise 6.45 billion dirhams (S$2.4 billion) through a rights share offering, targeting expansion abroad and attracting more foreign investors. The bank will offer 758.8 million shares at 8.5 dirhams each, a 35% discount from its closing price. The issue will open on November 10 and close on November 20, with Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, and ENBD Capital managing the offering. The proceeds will be used to strengthen the bank's capital base and support growth.

site_title: Asian cities risk stumbling 'zombie-like' towards digital dystopia
summary: Asian cities are adopting facial recognition and AI to deliver social welfare and public services, but experts warn of a "digital dystopia" if authorities don't address privacy concerns and protect vulnerable populations. The United Nations under-secretary-general Armida Salsiah Alisjahbana emphasized the potential of AI to serve sustainable development needs. Governments across the region, including India and Indonesia, are backing hundreds of Smart Cities to improve waste management, energy conservation, and mitigate climate change risks. However, the focus on technology may overlook the need to protect citizens' rights and prevent potential misuse.

site_title: Northern Ireland's DUP oppose UK government's Brexit plan
summary: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) opposes the UK government's Brexit plan, citing concerns over customs and VAT issues. The DUP, which backs Prime Minister Boris Johnson, announced its opposition just hours before a crucial EU summit. The party will continue to work with the government to achieve a "sensible deal" that protects Northern Ireland's economic and constitutional integrity. This development deals a significant blow to Johnson's Brexit plans, raising concerns about the UK's ability to navigate the Brexit process.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower on Thursday, edging down 0.09% on profit-taking amid Brexit talks in Brussels. The Nikkei 225 index fell 21.06 points to 22,451.86, while the Topix index declined 7.35 points to 1,624.16. This marks a brief respite from recent gains, as investors wait for developments in the Brexit negotiations.

site_title: US, Chinese teams working on Phase 1 trade deal text: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said that US and Chinese trade negotiators are working on a Phase 1 trade deal text, with a possible signing at the November 16-17 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit. Despite no invitation from Beijing, Mnuchin is prepared to travel to China for more meetings if necessary. The proposed Phase 1 text includes chapters on intellectual property rights, technology transfers, and currency provisions, with further negotiations planned on non-financial services and structural agricultural issues.

site_title: China to scrap business curbs on foreign banks, brokerages
summary: China has announced plans to remove business restrictions on foreign banks, brokerages, and fund management firms, a move aimed at opening its financial sector amid a trade war with the US. The decision comes nearly 18 years after China joined the WTO and is expected to have limited impact on the competitive landscape dominated by state firms. China will also support foreign investment and allow more flexible borrowing, but will not allow forced technology transfers. The move aims to stabilize foreign investment and support the slowing economy.

images.alt_text: China will remove business restrictions on foreign banks, brokerages and fund management firms, a Cabinet meeting chaired by Premier Li Keqiang said on Wednesday, state television reported.

site_title: Malaysia's property market to pick up as developers build less
summary: Malaysia's property market is expected to pick up as developers build fewer homes. The government's measures to address the nation's affordable housing shortage and property glut have shown signs of success, with a 30% drop in completed units in the first half of 2019 compared to the same period last year. New projects have also decreased by 20%. With lower mortgage rates and incentives for home buyers, prices remain muted, but the market is expected to "level up" in the next two years, according to the Real Estate and Housing Developers' Association.

site_title: South Korean stocks fall on Brexit woes
summary: South Korean stocks declined on Thursday due to Brexit-related uncertainty and concerns over a global economic slowdown. The KOSPI index fell 0.23% to 2,077.94, snapping a four-day gain. Foreign investors sold US$79.82 million worth of shares, contributing to the decline. The market had risen 1.81% so far this year, but the recent downturn may signal a correction. The Brexit deal proposed by Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the EU remains uncertain, fueling market volatility.

site_title: mm2 Asia responds to SGX on differences in cash, borrowings for Q1
summary: mm2 Asia responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding differences in financial results for Q1 FY2019 and FY2020 Q1. The company reported a 36% increase in cash and cash equivalents to S$25.3 million, mainly due to financing from banks and convertible bonds. Short-term borrowings increased by 74.7% to S$27.5 million, while film products and films under production decreased by 72.1% to S$6.1 million. Shares remained unchanged at S$0.23.

site_title: Auditor gives qualified opinion on Yamada's FY19 results
summary: Independent auditor Foo Kon Tan has given Yamada Green Resources a qualified opinion on its FY19 financial results due to the impact of a disclaimer of opinion from 2017 and 2018. The auditor highlighted an unaccountable balance of 29.3 million yuan, which may be affected by unknown circumstances. The company's management has resolved the issue by representing the balance as a non-distributable reserve. The auditor also found that the group's financial statements were properly drawn up according to Singapore laws and accounting standards, except for the mentioned issues.

site_title: Powerful Pemex union boss resigns amid graft charges in Mexico
summary: Mexican oil workers union boss Carlos Romero Deschamps has resigned amid allegations of financial wrongdoing. He faces prosecution over two complaints of financial operations with funds of illegal origin, and has denied all charges. Romero Deschamps led the union since 1993 and was a former senator with the opposition Institutional Revolutionary Party. The resignation comes after President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador hinted he should step down to face the allegations, following reports of Romero Deschamps' lavish lifestyle despite his modest salary.

site_title: What Johnson's Brexit will do for the Irish border
summary: The UK's Brexit deal includes a protocol for Northern Ireland, which will be part of the UK customs union but follow the single market's rules in certain areas to avoid a hard border. No duties will be paid on goods brought into Northern Ireland from the UK, and UK residents will pay no duties on personal property. The EU's VAT rules will continue to apply, and North-South cooperation will be maintained in various areas. The Northern Ireland Assembly will vote every four years on whether to stop or continue applying EU law, with a two-year grace period if the vote is against the protocol.

images.alt_text: A lorry driver passes an anti-Brexit "No Hard Border" as he drives in Newry, Northern Ireland on October 16, 2019, on the road crossing the border between Newry and Dundalk in Ireland.

site_title: Ex-Credit Suisse banker says he hid US$45m worth of bribes
summary: A former Credit Suisse banker, Andrew Pearse, testified in Brooklyn, New York, that he and at least four other bankers hid US$45 million in illicit payments for arranging loans worth US$2 billion to companies in Mozambique. Pearse implicated Jean Boustani, a Privinvest salesman, as the "mastermind" of a scheme to defraud US investors, and described the involvement of Mozambican officials and other bankers in the scheme. The case is part of a broader investigation into corruption and bribery related to the loans.

images.alt_text: Former Credit Suisse Group banker Andrew Pearse told a jury in Brooklyn, New York, that he pocketed at least US$45 million in illicit payments for his role in the arrangement of loans worth US$2 billion to companies in Mozambique.

site_title: Singapore's APEX to launch low-sulphur fuel oil contract ahead of new shipping rules
summary: Singapore-based Asia Pacific Exchange (APEX) is launching a low-sulphur fuel oil (LSFO) futures contract to help shipping and energy firms manage price fluctuations ahead of new global marine fuel rules. The contract, set to launch on Friday, will be for 10 tonnes of fuel oil and use the Argus Bunker Index as the settlement price. The new rules, set to apply from January 1, 2020, require a 0.5% sulphur content in shipping fuel, aiming to combat air pollution. The contract aims to hedge risk in the relatively new market for 0.5% LSFO delivered marine fuels.

site_title: WeWork owner creates committee to decide on financing lifeline: sources
summary: WeWork's owner, The We Company, has formed a special board committee to consider a US$5 billion financing lifeline from SoftBank Group and JPMorgan Chase & Co. The committee, comprising two We Company board directors, aims to safeguard WeWork's interests from SoftBank's influence. The move comes after WeWork scrapped its initial public offering (IPO) plans due to investor concerns. SoftBank wants to invest up to US$5 billion, while JPMorgan is seeking US$5 billion in financing commitments. WeWork may combine the proposals in some form.

site_title: Singapore, US to cooperate on infrastructure finance and market building
summary: Singapore and the US have signed a pact to strengthen cooperation in infrastructure finance and debt market development for infrastructure financing. The agreement was signed by Singapore's Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Finance and Education, Indranee Rajah, and US Deputy Treasury Secretary Justin Muzinich. The pact aims to facilitate technical exchanges and information sharing, support infrastructure development in South-east Asia, and promote private-sector investments in the region.

site_title: Bank of England can fight a new slowdown, but fiscal policy has role too: governor
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that if the UK economy faces a downturn, the central bank would cut bank lending stimulus and consider complementing it with fiscal policy. The BoE would likely cut the countercyclical capital buffer to zero, and the UK government could increase public investment in skills and infrastructure to boost growth. Carney also emphasized the need for governments to address the global liquidity trap by implementing tax and spending policies.

site_title: Type of housing Singaporean parents own can impact children's future economic status: NUS
summary: A new study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) found that the type of housing owned by Singaporean parents significantly impacts their children's future economic status. Children from low-income families show upward mobility in housing wealth due to proximity to HDB towns and quality public schools. In contrast, middle-income families face limited mobility due to government subsidies and competition for high-quality public education. Wealthy families experience little to no mobility, as they tend to remain in core central areas. The study highlights the impact of public policies, such as the Build-to-Order and Married Child Priority Schemes, on inter-generational wealth mobility.

site_title: Teo Chee Hean discusses smart city development, urban transportation with Russian official
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean met with Russian official Sergei Ivanov in Moscow, discussing smart city development, urban transportation, and climate change. The two discussed cooperation in the Arctic and noted growing ties between Singapore and Russia. Teo expressed happiness to meet his counterpart, who was his counterpart during their previous capacities as Deputy Prime Ministers and Ministers for Defence. The meeting aims to strengthen bilateral relations and explore opportunities for cooperation.

site_title: Trump upbeat on trade talks with EU, hints at reprieve for some duties on Italian products
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about trade talks with the European Union, hinting at a possible reprieve for some duties on Italian products. Italian President Sergio Mattarella urged Trump to avoid counterproductive tariffs during their meeting at the White House. The talks come ahead of the scheduled imposition of tariffs on up to $7.5 billion of EU imports, including Italian cheeses, following a WTO ruling on Airbus subsidies. Trump's comments suggest a potential shift in the US-EU trade stance.

site_title: Protein shake seller BellRing raises US$480m in low-end IPO
summary: BellRing Brands, a spinoff of Post Holdings, raised US$480 million in its initial public offering (IPO), meeting the low end of its listing expectations. The company sold 34.3 million shares for US$14 each, down from its initial offer of 30 million shares for US$16 to US$19 each. BellRing's IPO fell short of its target, but the company reported a profit of US$96 million on net sales of US$640 million in the nine months ended June 30. The IPO is the latest in a slowing IPO market, with companies like Peloton Interactive and SmileDirectClub experiencing dismal performances.

site_title: Japan defence minister to enter race to succeed PM Shinzo Abe
summary: Japanese Defence Minister Taro Kono is running to succeed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Kono cited energy and social security policies as his top priorities. He joins a small pack of lawmakers, including Environment Minister Shinjiro Koizumi and former Defence Minister Shigeru Ishiba, in the upcoming election. Abe is set to become Japan's longest-serving premier on November 20 and is expected to lead the LDP until September 2021.

site_title: China office vacancies reach decade high on slowing economy
summary: China's office vacancy rate has reached a decade high of 21.5% in the third quarter, driven by the economic slowdown and a glut of supply. The vacancy rate is the worst since the global financial crisis in 2008. Overseas companies are hesitant to commit to new leases due to the US trade war, while cost-conscious tenants are moving to cheaper buildings. Landlords are offering incentives to attract tenants, but rents have declined in 14 of the 17 cities, including Beijing and Shanghai.

site_title: Moody's may shelve plan to control China's top rating firm: sources
summary: Moody's may abandon its plan to increase its stake in China's top credit rating firm, China Chengxin International Credit Rating, due to regulatory inaction. The US business had sought to gain a majority stake, but faced delays and hurdles, including trade tensions between the US and China. China has been opening its financial sector to global firms, but foreign entities still face hidden barriers, including slow regulatory approval. Authorities have approved a few foreign companies for control of onshore units, but Moody's application was not approved.

images.alt_text: Moody's may have to shelve a plan to take control of China Chengxin International Credit Rating, the nation's largest ratings company, amid regulatory inaction, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks tread water; all eyes on Brexit talks
summary: South Korean shares remained nearly flat on Thursday amid cautious investor sentiment due to the Brexit talks. The KOSPI fell 0.88 points, or 0.04%, to 2,081.95, with foreigners net selling 47.2 billion won worth of shares. The won rose against the US dollar, and the benchmark bond yield increased. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the KOSPI has risen 1.88% so far this year, and investors remain focused on the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: Singapore hospitality deals hit record S$2.8b in Q3: Colliers
summary: Singapore hospitality deals reached a record S$2.8 billion in Q3, according to Colliers International. This is six times the previous quarter's deals and 19 times the previous year's. Hotel deals accounted for 25% of total deals in Q3, following significant transactions such as the merger of OUE C-Reit and OUE H-Trust.

site_title: Hot stock: CDL jumps 3.5% in morning trade following Citi reiteration on 'buy'
summary: CDL shares jumped 3.5% to S$10.23 following Citi's "buy" rating reiteration with a target price of S$13.14. The developer's London-listed subsidiary Millennium & Copthorne was delisted after a takeover bid, and Citi expects management to unlock value through performance optimisation, redevelopment, and divestments. The broker expects M&C to appoint more established third-party managers, optimise yield management, and refurbish hotels. CDL plans to divest selected hotels to CDL Hospitality Trusts to fund redevelopment plans.

site_title: Insignia Ventures closes second fund at US$200m
summary: Insignia Ventures Partners has closed its second fund at US$200 million, exceeding its initial target. The Singapore-based venture capital firm has attracted prominent institutional investors, including sovereign wealth funds and family offices. The fund will focus on early-stage technology companies in South-east Asia, building on Insignia's successful track record with portfolio companies such as Payfazz and Carro. This marks the firm's second oversubscribed final close, following its first fund, which closed at US$120 million last year.

site_title: Hotel Compass in Geylang up for sale with S$23-25m guide price
summary: Hotel Compass in Geylang, a 49-room freehold hotel, is up for sale with a guide price of S$23-25 million. Located near Aljunied and Mountbatten MRT stations, the property offers easy access to the central business district and Changi International Airport. The hotel occupies a site area of 436.9 square meters and is zoned "commercial/institution" under the 2014 Master Plan. The sale presents a rare opportunity for investors and end-users, with no additional buyer's stamp duty for foreigners and companies. The tender closes on November 1.

site_title: Christian Dior apologises over China map excluding Taiwan
summary: French luxury brand Christian Dior apologized for using a map of China that excluded Taiwan in a presentation at Zhejiang Gongshang University in Hangzhou, China. The map was criticized as Beijing considers Taiwan a wayward province and part of "one China." Dior stated it supported China's territorial sovereignty, acknowledging the mistake and ensuring its commitment to respecting China's territorial integrity.

images.alt_text: French luxury brand Christian Dior apologised on Thursday and said it supported China's territorial sovereignty after it was criticised for using a map of China that excluded Taiwan in a presentation.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia's pension unit sued over fees
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia's pension unit, Colonial First State, was sued over allegedly failing to quickly move members out of high-fee default investment options to a simpler product as required by law. The class-action suit claims over 100,000 members suffered substantial losses due to the slow implementation of reforms, resulting in a missed opportunity to transfer A$3.2 billion to the lower-cost MySuper product within the statutory deadline.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia's (CBA) pension unit Colonial First State was sued on Thursday for allegedly failing to act quickly enough to move members out of high-fee default investment options to a simpler product as required by law.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat after 5-day rally as miners slump
summary: Australia's shares retreated on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index declining 0.4% due to heavy losses in mining stocks, particularly BHP Group and Rio Tinto, which fell 2.4% and 3% respectively. Iron ore prices slid 3% to their lowest in six weeks amid concerns over Chinese demand. Financial stocks also lost ground, while energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Santos gained as they posted positive third-quarter results.

site_title: Australia's Stanmore Coal says Winfield scraps takeover, shares drop
summary: Stanmore Coal said Winfield Energy has scrapped its proposed takeover, citing failure to engage with key shareholders. The Brisbane-based miner's shares dropped 6% following the announcement. Winfield had valued Stanmore at up to A$435 million and was set to be its second coal buy this year, following a 12.5% stake in Queensland's Rolleston thermal coal mine. The decision to scrap the takeover comes after Winfield's efforts to engage with Stanmore's key shareholders were unsuccessful.

site_title: Amnesty urges Hong Kong to probe bloody attack on pro-democracy leader
summary: Amnesty International urges Hong Kong authorities to investigate a bloody attack on pro-democracy leader Jimmy Sham, who was left in a pool of blood after being attacked with hammers and knives. The attack, which occurred in the Mong Kok district, is the second such incident targeting Sham since protests escalated in June. Rights group Amnesty calls for the authorities to send a clear message that targeting activists will have consequences, and for Sham's group to proceed with a planned march on Sunday. The incident is part of Hong Kong's ongoing pro-democracy protests, which have posed a significant challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Hong Kong lawmakers dragged from chamber as Carrie Lam heckled for second day
summary: Hong Kong lawmakers were dragged from the chamber by security guards after pro-democracy lawmakers heckled Chief Executive Carrie Lam for a second day. The incident occurred as Lam attempted to answer questions about her policy speech, which was met with chants and slogans from protesters. The unrest in Hong Kong has escalated into violence, with protesters and police using tear gas and rubber bullets, and vigilante attacks on Beijing critics. The city's instability is fueled by concerns over Beijing's erosion of freedoms, with activists demanding an independent inquiry into the police, amnesty for arrested protesters, and fully free elections.

site_title: BHP sets early 2021 for decision on US$17b Jansen potash project
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest miner, plans to make a final investment decision on its US$17 billion Jansen potash project in Canada by February 2021. The project, which has already seen US$2.7 billion in investment, aims to create a "high-margin, long-life" mine and mitigate the company's reliance on other sources of potash. BHP has also posted a slight dip in its September quarter iron ore production, but maintained its fiscal 2020 iron ore production forecast.

site_title: 'Panama Papers' law firm sues Netflix over film based on scandal
summary: Mossack Fonseca, a Panamanian law firm at the center of the "Panama Papers" scandal, has filed a lawsuit against Netflix over its film "The Laundromat," alleging defamation and seeking to stop the movie's release. The film, starring Gary Oldman and Antonio Banderas, portrays the firm's partners as involved in money laundering, tax evasion, and other criminal conduct. Mossack Fonseca claims the film's depiction is false and damaging, while Netflix has not responded to the lawsuit. The film is scheduled to be released on Friday.

site_title: US authorities freeze assets of China-based traders over alleged manipulation
summary: US authorities have frozen assets of 18 China-based traders over an alleged international market manipulation scheme. The scheme, which spanned six years, generated over $31 million in illicit profits by manipulating over 3,000 US-listed securities. The SEC alleges the traders used multiple accounts to create artificially high or low prices, evading detection. Two Chinese traders, Xiaosong Wang and Jiali Wang, have been charged with securities fraud, but it's unclear if they can be brought to justice due to a lack of an extradition treaty between the US and China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.08% or 18.91 points at 22,454.01. Investors are watching Brexit talks in Brussels and US-China trade relations for developments. Analysts say the market is taking a breather after recent gains, and a no-deal Brexit scenario could provide a buy-back opportunity. Individual stocks saw mixed results, with SoftBank Group rising 0.42% and Nintendo losing 2.26%. The US dollar held steady against the yen.

site_title: Singapore bosses pledge to champion employees' mental well-being
summary: Twenty Singaporean leaders, including CEOs and politicians, signed a joint pledge to champion and prioritize mental well-being within their organizations and the wider workforce. The pledge, announced by the WorkWell Leaders Workgroup, aims to create a cross-sector workplace mental well-being commitment and roadmap. The participants, from various sectors, shared insights and best practices on employee mental health, with plans for future dialogue sessions to continue the conversation.

site_title: Greece fights for its beaches and gets tough on plastic pollution
summary: Greece announces a campaign to tackle plastic pollution, aiming to stop the use of single-use plastics by June 2020, a year before the EU's ban. The country faces a significant problem, with 39 tonnes of plastic waste entering the sea daily, harming marine wildlife. Environment Minister Kostis Hatzidakis calls for cooperation between the state, private sector, NGOs, and citizens to address the issue, which Greece lags behind its EU neighbours in recycling. The government plans to work with private environmental groups to implement the changes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.54% to 26,809.04, following a weak US retail sales report that lifted hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday with gains after a weak US retail sales report lifted hopes for another Federal Reserve interest rate cut.

site_title: Looming recession to weigh on German forecasts
summary: Germany's updated growth forecasts, set to be released on Thursday, are expected to show a weaker outlook, with GDP expansion predicted at 1.1% for next year, down from 1.5% earlier. The country is already in a technical recession, with two consecutive quarters of negative growth. The massive trade surplus, a source of national pride, has turned into a weakness due to US-China trade tensions. Calls are growing for Germany to loosen its "black zero" policy and stimulate growth through fiscal measures, but the government remains cautious, highlighting the need for structural reform rather than high levels of intervention.

site_title: Sakae director quits over dispute in handling of auditor's disclaimer of opinion
summary: Sakae Holdings' non-executive independent director Foo Maw Shen has resigned after differing views on the follow-up action to the independent auditor's disclaimer of opinion in the company's audited financial results for fiscal 2019. Deloitte had issued a disclaimer due to lack of audit evidence and certain information related to associates and a Chilean company. The company had previously provided full allowance for impairment loss on its investments, but Deloitte could not confirm the carrying amounts of the investments at the year end. With two independent directors remaining, Sakae Holdings is short of a minimum requirement of three.

site_title: SAP unveils Singapore data centre to support e-commerce businesses
summary: SAP has launched a Singapore data centre for its SAP Commerce Cloud, supporting e-commerce businesses in Asia-Pacific. The centre, which will be the default data centre for customers in South-east Asia and India, aims to provide minimal latency and performance issues for online shopping experiences. This addition strengthens SAP's APAC data centre network, which includes locations in Australia, China, and Hong Kong. The move aims to help businesses master the transition to the experience economy in the region, with SAP's goal of supporting digital commerce growth.

site_title: MCT prices placement at rich end of price talk at S$2.28 on strong demand
summary: MAPLETREE Commercial Trust (MCT) raised S$918.5 million from an equity fundraising exercise, with a private placement of 406.5 million new units priced at S$2.28 per unit, a 2.9% discount from the VWAP. The issue price for the preferential offering was fixed at S$2.24 per unit, a 4.6% discount to the VWAP. The funds will be used to partially fund the acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 2) and for other expenses.

site_title: Regulators float licences for local 5G networks, on top of national systems
summary: Singapore regulators are set to award four 5G telecom licenses, including two localized networks, to enable hotspots like laboratories or smart factories. The licenses, which could serve up to two networks, are expected to be awarded by mid-2020. The move is part of the country's plan to roll out 5G mobile networks by next year and strengthen its digital value proposition. The licenses will allow all four existing mobile network operators to participate in providing 5G services, and will include a wholesale pricing system to ensure competition.

site_title: Singapore's September non-oil exports continue falling streak with 8.1% drop
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 8.1% in September, following a 9% drop in August, mainly due to lower exports to Europe, the US, and Japan. Electronics and non-electronics exports declined, with integrated circuits and personal computers contracting by 30.2% and 33.1% respectively. Non-oil re-exports rose 3% in September, while total trade decreased 4.9% year-on-year. Despite this, seasonally-adjusted total trade marginally increased by 0.2% in September.

site_title: UBS managing director Choo Oi Yee to join digital securities startup iSTOX
summary: UBS managing director Choo Oi Yee will join digital securities startup iSTOX as its first chief commercial officer in January 2020. Choo will drive business growth by building investor and issuer networks. iSTOX, backed by the Singapore Exchange and Temasek's Heliconia Capital, aims to become a regulated platform for digitized securities. The startup recently raised Series A funds and appointed Lim Mei Shern as head of compliance, and plans to graduate from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's FinTech Regulatory Sandbox in early 2020.

site_title: Trump, Pelosi clash in heated White House meeting on Syria
summary: US President Donald Trump clashed with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in a White House meeting on Syria policy, with Trump calling Pelosi a "third-rate politician" and Pelosi describing the president's behavior as a "meltdown." The meeting ended with top Democrats, including Schumer and Hoyer, walking out. The confrontation is the latest sign of deteriorating relations between Trump and Pelosi, who launched an impeachment investigation against him last month. Other lawmakers remained inside, while Trump's spokeswoman defended the president's behavior, calling it "measured and decisive."

site_title: Singapore shares edge lower on Thursday; STI slips 0.04% to 3,133.40
summary: Singapore shares slipped 0.04% to 3,133.40 on Thursday, following a disappointing US retail sales report and geopolitical tension from Brexit. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 declined 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. Advancers outnumbered decliners 50 to 33, with Mapletree Commercial Trust and Rex International being among the most traded stocks. Financials were mixed, with DBS losing 0.4% and OCBC Bank adding 0.2%.

site_title: EU-US airliner war in nobody's interests: Airbus chief
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury urged the EU and US to reach a negotiated solution to their dispute over airline subsidies and tariffs, warning that a trade war would harm both economies. The World Trade Organization has given the US permission to impose $7.5 billion in tariffs on EU imports, targeting civilian aircraft and consumer products. Airbus claims it has complied with WTO rulings, while Boeing has not. The EU is considering retaliatory tariffs on US products if it can't persuade WTO judges that Boeing has also benefited from illegal subsidies.

site_title: Qatar to end controversial migrant worker restrictions
summary: Qatar plans to scrap key aspects of its "kafala" labour rules, including employer permission for job changes and exit permits, in response to international pressure and criticism of the system. The country aims to make itself an attractive place for investors and skilled workers with new legislation, including a minimum wage of 750 riyals per month. The reforms, set to be finalized by the end of the year, are seen as a step towards liberalizing Qatar's labor market, following a series of reforms since being selected to host the 2022 World Cup.

site_title: Dealmaker Peter Babej appointed Citi's Asia-Pacific CEO
summary: Citi appointed Peter Babej as its new Asia-Pacific CEO, effective immediately. Babej, who has been with Citi since 2010, previously led the financial institutions group and has worked on significant deals, including Ant Financial's record-breaking fundraising round. His appointment follows a series of leadership changes in the banking sector, including OCBC CEO Helen Wong's retirement. The move comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Peter Babej will take over from Tim Monger, who was acting as interim CEO of the region over the past several months.

site_title: CapitaLand, Razer clinch first enterprise 5G grants by non-telcos
summary: Singapore has awarded its first enterprise 5G grants to private companies CapitaLand and Razer, partnering with telcos TPG Telecom and Singtel respectively, to test 5G mobile technology in various applications such as smart mobility and cloud gaming. The grants, worth S$40 million, aim to support the development of innovative 5G applications and services, undergirded by a secure and resilient 5G infrastructure. The move is part of the government's efforts to foster collaborations on the demand side for 5G technology and create value from specific use cases.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit placement to raise at least US$73.1m for Dallas property buy
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) is proposing a private placement to raise between US$73.1 million and US$75.6 million, primarily to fund its US$101.5 million acquisition of an office property in Dallas, Texas. The placement will issue 104.3 million new units at a discounted price, with net proceeds partially financing the acquisition. The move aims to improve trading liquidity and is expected to result in an advanced distribution for the period from July 1, 2019 to the day before the new units are issued.

site_title: Competitors look to free services to take on Netflix
summary: Video streaming upstarts, such as Tubi and Rakuten, are testing the market with free-to-viewer services featuring ads, aiming to compete with Netflix. In contrast to Disney, HBO, and Apple's subscription-based models, these services hope to attract viewers willing to tolerate ads. Tubi and Rakuten both announced plans to enter the European market, following the MIPCOM conference in Cannes, France. This shift in strategy could potentially disrupt the video streaming industry, as more companies consider alternative models to compete with Netflix.

site_title: M1, Haidilao to set up trial 5G network at hot pot chain's new Marina Square outlet
summary: M1 and hot pot chain Haidilao are partnering to set up a trial 5G network at Haidilao's new Marina Square outlet. The new store will feature self-developed smart machines, a 5G experience corner with interactive virtual and augmented reality e-gaming, and food delivery robots. The trial will begin with a 5G experience corner, followed by 5G kitchen management and robotic food servers. The partnership aims to enhance the dining experience and explore real-life applications of 5G technology in the food and beverage industry.

site_title: More US sanctions on Turkey to come if no ceasefire: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warned that additional economic sanctions will be imposed on Turkey if it does not agree to a ceasefire in northern Syria. The US has already withdrawn 1,000 troops from the area, seen as a green light for Turkish forces to drive back Syrian Kurdish militants. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has dismissed US calls for a ceasefire, saying Ankara is "not worried" about previously announced sanctions. US Vice-President Mike Pence is set to demand a ceasefire during a visit to Ankara.

site_title: ECB hawks demand revolution from new president Lagarde
summary: Two ECB governors, Austria's Robert Holzmann and the Netherlands' Klaas Knot, are questioning the bank's inflation target of 2% under new President Christine Lagarde. They argue the target may need to be modified or a range defined to give the ECB more time to achieve it. Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann also weighed in, stating the ECB should maintain its independence by focusing solely on inflation. The criticism comes ahead of Lagarde's term as ECB President, which begins on November 1.

site_title: US, France and OECD 'getting closer' to tech tax agreement: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the US, France, and the OECD are getting closer to an agreement on taxing global tech giants. Despite not having an official agreement yet, Mnuchin expressed optimism about the progress made in the talks. The goal of the agreement is to establish a framework for taxing multinational corporations, particularly those with significant global presence.

site_title: US firms say near-term outlook dimming amid slow growth: Federal Reserve
summary: US businesses have revised their outlooks due to slow growth, expecting activity to weaken, according to the Federal Reserve. The central bank's beige book report stated the US economy expanded at a slight to modest pace, with varying business activity across the country. This has led to expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Fed for the third time this year to support the sagging economy.

images.alt_text: Less than stellar US growth in recent weeks has caused many businesses to revise their outlooks and they now expect activity to weaken, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday.

site_title: US: Stocks dip amid doubts on Brexit, China trade deal
summary: US stocks declined modestly on Wednesday amid doubts over Brexit talks and the US-China trade deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.2%. A disappointing US retail sales report raised questions about the US consumer, and analysts cited growing doubts about the China trade deal and a Brexit compromise. Individual companies like Bank of America and United Airlines rose after reporting better-than-expected results, while petroleum-linked shares fell.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished modestly lower on Wednesday following a disappointing US retail sales report and amid questions over Brexit talks and the state of US-China trade relations.

site_title: UAW leaders reach tentative deal with GM to end US worker strike
summary: General Motors and the United Auto Workers (UAW) have reached a tentative labor agreement, potentially ending a month-long strike that paralyzed the auto giant. A majority of UAW members must ratify the agreement, which includes over $7 billion in investment and a $8,000 ratification bonus. The strike, which began on September 16, has affected nearly 50,000 hourly workers and 150,000 industry employees. The agreement focuses on job security, health benefits, and a quicker transition to permanent worker status for temporary workers.

site_title: AC Milan suffer record 146m euro losses: reports
summary: AC Milan, a troubled Italian football club, has reported record losses of 146 million euros (S$222 million) in the year to June 30, 2019, up 16% from the previous year. The club's debt-ridden past has led to a significant decline in revenue, with income from sponsors and ticket sales down by 6.7 million euros and 1.2 million euros respectively. The club's absence from European football has also impacted merchandising and TV rights revenue. Elliott, the US hedge fund that took over the club in 2018, has injected 325 million euros to keep the club afloat.

site_title: Europe: Shares pause as Brexit deal reports swirl
summary: European stocks paused after a strong close the previous day, closing down 0.1% due to conflicting Brexit deal reports. Despite fading expectations of a no-deal Brexit, shares in domestically focused midcaps and Irish stocks fell, while European automakers rose 1.5% due to car registration gains. The Stoxx 600 index is expected to report a 3.7% drop in third-quarter earnings, amid uncertainties around Brexit and US-China trade.

site_title: Netflix revs up growth as streaming TV war looms
summary: Netflix reported a net income of $665 million in its latest quarter, beating analyst forecasts, with revenue up 31% to $5.25 billion and 6.8 million new subscribers added to reach 158.3 million. The company expects to continue growing, despite competition from Disney and Apple's upcoming streaming services, and plans to invest $15 billion in content this year. However, eMarketer analyst Eric Haggstrom notes that the report includes signs of trouble ahead for Netflix, including disappointing growth without the new competition present, and the company trimmed its forecast for subscriber growth.

images.alt_text: Netflix shares rallied Wednesday after its latest quarterly update showed robust subscriber growth and better-than-expected profits ahead of a major escalation in the streaming television war.

site_title: JPMorgan sharpens edge on rivals in months jarred by market tumult
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has widened its edge on Wall Street rivals, posting its biggest increase in revenue from fixed-income trading in almost three years and announcing a surprise jump in fees from investment banking. The bank's shares reached an all-time high, driven by its dominance in fixed-income markets and debt underwriting units. Despite a 5% decline in equity-trading revenue, JPMorgan's overall revenue surpassed analyst estimates, and the bank attracted more deposits.

site_title: Oil rises on hopes Opec will extend supply cuts, weaker US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude gaining 68 cents to settle at $59.42 a barrel and US crude gaining 55 cents to settle at $53.36. The increase was driven by expectations that Opec and allied producers will extend supply cuts in December and a weaker US dollar. However, oil prices pared gains after industry data showed a larger-than-expected increase in US oil stocks. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies meet on December 5-6 to review output policy, with some analysts predicting deeper cuts to sustain oil market stability.

site_title: Keppel unit, Allianz in S$1.3b Beijing deal
summary: Keppel's Alpha Investment Partners and Allianz Real Estate have jointly acquired an 85% interest in the Ronsin Technology Center in Beijing for S$1.3 billion. The seller, D&J China, will retain the remaining 15%. This deal marks a significant investment in the Chinese market, with Alpha and Allianz looking to capitalize on the country's growing economy. The acquisition is expected to bolster the partnership's presence in the region and provide opportunities for growth.

site_title: Nassim Road GCB on sale for some S$175m
summary: A two-storey conservation good class bungalow (GCB) at 40 Nassim Road in Singapore is up for sale via public tender with an indicative price of S$175 million. The property, once occupied by the Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia, has a total land area of 58,784 sq ft and features an entrance hall, living room, and four en-suite bedrooms. The buyer can redevelop the land to accommodate three GCBs, with investors aware of the premium that Nassim Road commands in the GCB market. The public tender will close on November 14.

site_title: CapitaLand eyes greater presence in China post-ASB merger
summary: CapitaLand, following its merger with Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB), aims to scale up in key Chinese city clusters, including Shanghai, Beijing, and Guangzhou, with a focus on business parks and IT parks. The group has earmarked five core city clusters and plans to build scale in the medium- to long-term, citing the strong Chinese economy and technological advancements. CapitaLand also plans to expand its fund management capabilities, aiming to grow its fee-income business, and divest mature assets to redeploy funds in other opportunities.

site_title: Fearful Mexican tech startups shun the spotlight
summary: Mexican tech startups shun publicity due to concerns about attracting criminals. Unlike their Silicon Valley counterparts, many Mexican founders decline media interviews and avoid public announcements. This approach is partly driven by the fear of financial loss and cyber threats. As a result, the startup scene in Mexico remains relatively low-key, with a focus on private success rather than public recognition. This approach may provide a level of security for entrepreneurs, but it also limits their ability to gain international attention and support.

site_title: Of China wines raising a buzz and discussions on writing...
summary: China's wine industry is gaining recognition, with luxury brands investing in production and labels like Ao Yun emerging as award-winners. Despite quality, convincing Chinese alcohol of its worth remains a challenge due to preconceived notions and limited availability. Meanwhile, author Marlon James discusses his writing and the violence in his books at the Singapore Writers Festival, which also features authors Roxane Gay and Min Jin Lee. Additionally, exhibitions showcase French and Japanese design aesthetics, while theatre company Wild Rice's production Merdeka explores themes of identity and belonging.

site_title: MCT proposing placements to raise at least S$902.3m to fund acquisition
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) has proposed an equity fundraising of at least S$902.3 million to partially fund its S$1.55 billion acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 2). The trust will raise gross proceeds of at least S$450 million through a private placement of 200.9 million new units and a non-renounceable preferential offering of about 205.6 million units. Unitholders have approved the proposed acquisition, which will enlarge MCT's asset size to S$8.9 billion.

site_title: Consumer banking powers Citigroup's profit
summary: Citigroup reported higher-than-expected earnings in its consumer banking unit, driven by strong US credit card revenue and a 13% profit increase excluding currency fluctuations. The bank's consumer business, accounting for 60% of global consumer banking revenue, showed resilience despite macroeconomic uncertainty. Citi reached its key profitability target of a 12.2% return on tangible common equity, exceeding the promised 12% goal for the year. Net income rose 6% to $4.9 billion, driven by a one-time tax benefit.

site_title: European car-sales jump masks gloomy outlook for industry
summary: European car sales surged 14% in September to 1.29 million vehicles, largely due to a year-over-year comparison rather than a respite from industry woes. The increase was largely attributed to the easing of new emissions-test rules. However, the long-term outlook for the industry remains gloomy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, CapitaLand, Keppel Reit, Soilbuild Reit, Qian Hu, AA Reit
summary: Several companies had notable developments on Thursday, October 17, 2019. Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) raised S$918.5 million from an equity fundraising exercise, while CapitaLand is eyeing a greater presence in China. Keppel Reit's distribution per unit rose 2.9% due to higher rentals and a unit buyback program. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's DPU shrank 26.3% due to the cessation of revenue recognition from a tenant. Qian Hu's net profit surged 72% on improved margins from the aquaculture business. AIMS Apac Reit's units plunged to an eight-month low after a secondary placement raised S$94.9 million.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Read: The world's largest Barbie collection
summary: A man has been recognized as the world's largest Barbie collector, creating unique fashion pieces for his dolls using various materials, including toilet paper. The collection, which is valued at an undisclosed amount, features over 4,000 Barbie dolls and has been showcased in exhibitions. The collector's creative approach to fashion has garnered attention, highlighting the versatility and creativity of Barbie dolls.

site_title: US retail sales post first decline in 7 months
summary: US retail sales dropped 0.3% in September, the first decline in 7 months, as households cut back on spending on motor vehicles, building materials, and online purchases. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and other discretionary items, were also unchanged. The decline suggests a slowdown in consumer spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of the economy, and could further fuel fears of a sharper economic slowdown. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again this month to keep the economy on track.

site_title: Global economic policymakers are playing with fire
summary: Global economic policymakers are facing a synchronized slowdown, with the IMF forecasting 3% world output growth and 1.1% trade growth in 2019. Rising uncertainty, driven by trade tensions, political instability, and geopolitical risks, is a major contributor to the slowdown. The IMF warns that risks are on the downside, with potential disruptions to integrated supply chains and a worsening US-China relationship. Policymakers are urged to stop doing "stupid stuff" and instead adopt a "renewed commitment to international cooperation" to address the challenges, which are exacerbated by structurally deficient aggregate demand and a fixation on austerity.

site_title: Mental health matters at work
summary: Leaders in Singapore are urged to prioritize mental health in the workplace, as a study found 51% of firms have no plans to implement wellness programs. The WorkWell Leaders Workgroup, comprising 25 C-suite executives, aims to champion workplace mental wellness and has rallied over 60 employers to support the national "Beyond the Label" campaign. Role modeling is key, with leaders encouraged to share their own mental health struggles. Concrete initiatives include training supervisors, peer-support training, and abolishing job applicant mental health questions. Investing in workplace adjustments can yield significant returns, with NCSS finding every dollar invested yields an average of $5.65 in returns.

site_title: MAS to step up supervision of virtual assets
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is stepping up supervision of virtual assets, including digital payment tokens, to detect unlicensed activities. MAS will use real-time data gathering and experiment with technologies to review transactional information on public blockchains. The regulator aims to refine its supervisory approach ahead of the Payment Services Act, which will license digital payment token services and bring them under MAS's Anti-Money Laundering/Combating the Financing of Terrorism supervision. MAS warns consumers of the speculative nature of virtual assets and aims to guard against illicit purposes, particularly terrorism financing.

site_title: Frasers Property, Hitachi team up to drive digital transformation in Asia-Pac
summary: Frasers Property and Hitachi Asia are investing up to S$50 million each to drive digital transformation in the Asia-Pacific real estate industry over the next five years, starting with Singapore, Thailand, and Australia. The companies aim to accelerate digital transformation, co-develop new services, and explore ways to "future-proof" Frasers Property's portfolio. The partnership is driven by Hitachi's research estimating the Asia-Pacific real estate market to reach US$82 billion by 2025, and will leverage technology and digitalisation to deliver better experiences for users and improve operating effectiveness.

site_title: Embattled Hong Kong leader unveils measures to ease housing crunch
summary: Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam announced measures to ease the housing shortage, including increasing the number of housing projects and accelerating the sale of public housing schemes. She plans to bring back 700 hectares of private land into public use, with half of it taken back in the next few years. The measures aim to create home ownership opportunities for people of different income groups and address widespread discontent over sky-high property prices. The announcement followed a disrupted policy address and comes as Lam battles to restore confidence in her administration amid four months of anti-government protests.

site_title: Meeting the Mona Lisa for an intimate (virtual) rendezvous
summary: The Louvre Museum in Paris is launching a virtual reality tour of Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, allowing visitors to experience the painting in a more intimate and immersive way. The VR tour will be available in a small gallery near the main Leonardo exhibition and will offer seven-minute virtual tours, including historical information and details of the painting and its surroundings. The move is part of the museum's efforts to broaden its appeal and offer more digital alternatives, including plans to promote its art treasures with VR tours and lower-tech alternatives.

images.alt_text: A team at Emissive working on the Leonardo Da Vinci VR tour for the Louvre. The digital experiment is part of an ongoing effort to broaden the Louvre's appeal.

site_title: AA Reit plunges 7.4% after S$94.9m placement
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) plummeted 7.4% to an eight-month low after completing its sponsor's bookbuilding process and secondary placement, ending the day at S$1.37.

site_title: Pound pulls back from rally as Brexit negotiations hit hurdle
summary: The pound dropped 0.6% to $1.2707 after Brexit negotiations hit a hurdle due to opposition from the Democratic Unionist Party in Northern Ireland. Despite recent optimism, the UK government is pessimistic, and traders are snapping up options to insure against big moves in the currency. A deal could see the pound rally to $1.40, but failure could lead to a slump to $1.11, according to strategists. The pound's volatility surged to 20.07% for the week, with an emergency session of the UK Parliament set to debate a potential deal or extension.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources chairman Philip Cecil Rickard is resigning after the upcoming AGM, citing a desire to spend time with family. The company had failed to secure funding for a coal-fired power plant project in Indonesia. Andreas Rinaldi, 69, has been appointed as CEO-designate. Ellipsiz acquired a 51% stake in AXIS-TEC for S$3.6 million. LHT Holdings plans to acquire industrial land for RM2.2 million. AW Wei Been stepped down as Sabana Reit's COO, while Sunpower Group secured manufacturing and services contracts worth 71.7 million yuan. Atlantic Navigation was queried by SAC Capital over a trading activity plunge.

site_title: Getting ready for the silver avalanche in Asia
summary: The "silver avalanche" is expected to hit Asia, with countries like Singapore and China facing significant aging populations by 2030. The silver economy is estimated to be worth $26 trillion, with 32% of the Asia-Pacific population over 50 years old contributing 52% of the region's consumer expenditure. However, the silver market is highly divided, with wealthy seniors commanding a larger share of the economy than those who have embraced digital technology. Businesses must adapt their strategies to cater to the diverse needs of the silver market, requiring a concerted effort across multiple geographies and sectors.

site_title: US dollar near 4-week low as trade tensions simmer
summary: The US dollar held near a four-week low due to ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, affecting global growth outlook. The Japanese yen reached a 2½-month low, with concerns over the trade war weighing on risk appetite. This has led to increased selling pressure on the US dollar, particularly against the yen. The US dollar's decline has been attributed to the potential slowdown in China's GDP growth, which could put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Higher rents, Seoul tower contribution boost Keppel Reit's Q3 DPU by 2.9%
summary: Keppel Reit's third quarter ended Sept 30 saw a 2.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.4 Singapore cents, driven by higher rentals from Ocean Financial Centre and T Tower in Seoul, as well as its unit buyback programme. This was partially offset by lower revenue and earnings from Bugis Junction Towers, which was divested for S$547.5 million. Gross revenue rose 15.6% to S$42.4 million, while net property income (NPI) rose 17.6% to S$33.2 million.

site_title: Geneva's exclusive watch show to open to public
summary: The Geneva watch salon, known as Watches & Wonders Geneva, is opening to the public for the first time after a makeover aimed at making luxury watch brands more relevant in the digital age. The event, previously exclusive to industry professionals, will be held from April 25 to 29 and will include a main exhibition, walking tours, and open-house events at museums. The move comes as other Swiss watch fairs face declining participation due to the rise of online shopping and social media platforms. The event is expected to be priced at 300 francs per person.

site_title: Thief walks out of art gallery with US$20,000 Salvador Dalí etching
summary: A thief walked out of a San Francisco art gallery, Dennis Rae Fine Art, with a $20,000 Salvador Dalí etching, La Girafe en Feu, in less than a minute. The artwork, a limited-edition print from the 1960s, was displayed without its usual tether, allowing the thief to escape unnoticed. Surveillance footage shows a man in a blue cap and shirt entering the gallery with a second person waiting outside. The gallery had insured the piece, which could sell for up to $27,500, but its value is uncertain. The San Francisco police are investigating the theft.

site_title: Qian Hu posts 72% rise in Q3 net profit to S$301,000
summary: Qian Hu, a Singapore-based integrated fish service provider, reported a 72% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$301,000 for the third quarter ended Sept 30. Despite a 10.2% drop in revenue to S$19.2 million, the company achieved improved margins from its aquaculture business. The lower revenue was attributed to poor sales in its core fish and accessories business segments.

site_title: NTUC wants to reach 1.5m members by 2030, through innovation and digitalisation
summary: NTUC, Singapore's labour movement, has set a "bold, ambitious" target of reaching 1.5 million members by 2030, with current membership at 943,000. To stay relevant, the movement must innovate in union business, membership, and training, including exploring new union models, digital unions, and family memberships. The organization aims to partner with the government to address issues such as an ageing population and to develop an artificial intelligence engine to provide personalized training recommendations to workers.

site_title: Huawei says nine-month revenue up despite US pressure
summary: Huawei reported a 24.4% year-over-year revenue growth to 610.8 billion yuan (S$118 billion) for the first nine months of 2019, despite US pressure to isolate the company globally. Shipments of its smartphones surpassed 185 million units in the first three quarters, up 26% year-on-year, with little impact from the US blacklist on its business. Huawei attributed its performance to operational efficiency and organizational stability, and has been preparing for the potential loss of access to key hardware and software components.

site_title: Warehouse problems resolved after profit slump: ASOS
summary: ASOS reported "substantial progress" in resolving warehouse problems in the US and Germany, which contributed to a 68% slump in annual profit. The company's shares rose 16% after reporting a pretax profit of £33.1 million and revenue of £2.73 billion in the year to August 31. ASOS is working on a global warehouse and technology overhaul, aiming to improve product availability and growth opportunities. The company's shares now pare year-on-year losses to 41%.

site_title: Production date for Boeing's long-haul 777-8 up in air as Qantas weighs options
summary: Boeing's production timeline for its long-haul 777-8 airliner remains uncertain, with the company citing customer demand and alignment with its 777X program as factors. Qantas, which is considering ordering the plane for Sydney-London flights, plans a near 20-hour test flight non-stop from New York to Sydney. The airline's decision on ordering the 777-8 or Airbus A350-1000 will depend on a favorable business case and agreements with the pilot's union and aviation regulator.

site_title: Focusing on basic needs a guard against populism: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of focusing on basic needs to guard against populism in his country. By implementing policies on housing, healthcare, education, and providing opportunities for self-upgrade, Singapore aims to ensure citizens' basic needs are met and their aspirations achievable. A stable and prosperous region is crucial for Singapore's success, and the government hopes for a resolution in Hong Kong's protests, which Lee believes are driven by social issues and a desire for progressive change.

site_title: Green bonds issuance: Time for Singapore stat boards to step up
summary: Singapore is urging statutory boards to issue green bonds to fund climate change mitigation efforts, with a goal of a S$6 billion market. This move is seen as a strong catalyst for growth, as bankers believe long-tenor sovereign green bonds can effectively fund long-term infrastructure investments. The Republic's focus on mitigating climate change is expected to drive the issuance of green bonds.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit DPU falls 26% in Q3 after tenant default, rights issue
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit (SBREIT) reported a 26.3% decline in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.918 cents, due to a tenant default and rights issue. The decline was offset by a 4.5% increase in net property income. The Reit manager successfully completed renewals and secured new leases, but portfolio occupancy dipped slightly to 88.4%. The Reit's aggregate leverage stood at 36.5% as of September 30.

site_title: Singapura Finance to get 1.6% stake in MatchMove Pay for US$5m
summary: Singapura Finance agreed to pay US$5 million for a 1.6% stake in MatchMove Pay, a digital payments firm, in exchange for 587,035 Series Bc preference shares. The deal, valued at US$295 million, is expected to be completed on October 31 and is subject to regulatory approval. MatchMove Pay develops banking-as-a-service wallet solutions, and the investment is seen as an opportunity to acquire a stake in a business with possible long-term growth potential.

site_title: Wall Street opens lower on fresh China worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to concerns over China, despite positive earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.20%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.35%. Fears of more friction with China were sparked by legislation targeting the Hong Kong protests.

site_title: HK's offshore asset manager CSOP eyes family office business in Singapore
summary: CSOP, a Hong Kong-based offshore asset manager, is expanding its presence in Singapore to tap into the growing family office market. The firm aims to be a bridge between Singapore and China, offering ultra-rich families access to the Chinese capital market. CSOP will initially focus on Chinese fixed income funds for private clients and family offices, with a core focus on family offices. The firm has already launched its first Singapore-managed fund with US$150 million in assets under management.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.67 points to 1,574.90 on Wednesday, driven by a 458-426 gain-loss ratio. The market saw a significant volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion.

site_title: UK, EU make last-minute adjustments to forge Brexit deal before summit
summary: UK and EU negotiators are making last-minute adjustments to forge a Brexit deal before the EU leaders' summit. The main stumbling block is the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, with UK negotiators agreeing to concessions on customs checks and controls. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised the DUP that Northern Ireland will remain part of the UK, but the DUP is wary of EU regulations. A deal is seen as crucial to avoid the "Ben Act", which could force Johnson to seek a three-month extension from the EU and potentially lead to a Tory loss in a general election.

images.alt_text: UK and European Union (EU) negotiators are making frantic last-minute adjustments to forge a Brexit deal before this week's EU leaders' summit.

site_title: Johnson sees chance of Brexit deal, not there yet - spokesman
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told his Cabinet that there's a chance of agreeing a new Brexit deal with the European Union, but it's not yet done. Talks with the Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party are ongoing, and outstanding issues remain. Johnson emphasized that securing a good deal is possible, but it's not yet achieved.

site_title: Consumers wise up to drip pricing, pre-ticked boxes and similar tricks
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) released draft guidelines on price transparency to curb misleading practices such as drip pricing and pressure selling. The guidelines, open for public consultation until October 21, aim to protect consumers from unexpected add-on charges and false claims of limited-time discounts. The CCCS found that 80% of consumers noticed a difference between headline and final prices, and many were willing to pay higher prices despite feeling pressured. The guidelines are intended for all consumer-facing industries, including the online travel booking sector, where similar practices have been reported.

site_title: China traders in online sneaker market punish NBA after HK comment
summary: A Chinese trader noticed a significant drop in the price of cryptocurrency-backed Nike Air Jordan sneakers after Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey tweeted support for Hong Kong protests. The tweet was quickly deleted, but the damage was done, with quotes for Air Jordan 1 Retro High Satin Black Toe shoes falling 34% due to Chinese government and netizen backlash. The incident highlights the impact of global brands offending their Chinese client base, with the NBA's China market estimated to be worth over $4 billion.

site_title: Crowds making beeline for Raffles City Chongqing
summary: Raffles City Chongqing, a 1.12 million sq m integrated development in Chongqing, China, has seen 350,000-400,000 visitors daily on weekends since its soft launch on September 6, with 11-12 million renminbi in weekend sales. The mall, developed by CapitaLand at a total investment of 24 billion renminbi, features 400 shops, a serviced residence, hotel, office space, and luxury residential apartments. The development is expected to reach visitorship of 300,000 people daily on weekends and 100,000-150,000 daily on weekdays once stabilized.

site_title: PM Lee hopeful economic growth above zero in 2019
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed hope for economic growth above zero in 2019, despite the Sino-US trade war and a global downturn in the electronics industry. The city-state narrowly dodged recession in the third quarter. With full-year economic growth expected to be below 1%, Singapore's economy is seen as a bellwether for the global economy.

site_title: Private equity for retail: Just because you can do it, doesn't mean you should
summary: A private equity platform, CapBridge, has received regulatory approval to offer retail investors access to pre-listing or late-stage growth private companies with exit or liquidity plans. Retail investors will be able to participate in a private company's offering of convertible securities, but with limitations, such as capped investment amounts and indirect holding through a special-purpose vehicle, which waives voting rights. While the platform aims to manage risk, retail investors may still face greater risks, including limited exit opportunities and disenfranchisement. The feasibility of this model remains uncertain, raising questions about whether it's worth the trouble for retail investors.

images.alt_text: In the current era of ultra-low risk-free rates of return, the financial innovation challenge of the day seems to be figuring out how to give retail investors access to the sweet returns of private equity.

site_title: Ascott Reit's retail investors have big say in merger with A-HTrust
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) is set to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on October 21 to vote on a proposed merger with Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust). Retail investors hold significant power in this merger, as their approval is required for the deal to proceed. If approved, the combined entity will become the largest hospitality trust in Asia Pacific and the eighth largest globally, with increased financial flexibility and potential for higher trading liquidity. Unitholders must vote in favor of the merger, with a 50% plus one majority required for approval.

site_title: S-E Asia a 'goldmine of untapped opportunity': Grab co-founder
summary: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling describes South-east Asia as a "goldmine of untapped opportunity," calling it a region where the company knows best. Unlike other markets, solutions in South-east Asia cannot be simply copied from developed markets due to its unique blend of technology and physical aspects. The region remains a key area for growth and innovation despite global economic bleakness, and companies are finding opportunities in mobile-driven industries like travel and e-commerce.

site_title: Zico unit gets CMS licence, parent firm responds to SGX queries
summary: ZICO Trust, an indirect subsidiary of ZICO Holdings, has received a capital markets services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
