The licence allows Zico Trust to provide custodial services. Zico Holdings also responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its proposed sale of two corporate services subsidiaries, addressing questions on beneficial owners and sale prices. The SGX queries followed the announcement of the subsidiaries' sale.

site_title: European stocks mixed at open
summary: European stocks opened mixed, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2% and Paris's CAC 40 index down 0.1%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1%. The British pound dropped 0.6% against the dollar, while the euro gained 0.7% against sterling. Negotiations on a draft Brexit deal resumed after late-night talks brought the parties closer, but a breakthrough remains elusive.

site_title: BlackGold Natural Resources chairman, chief executive resigns
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources chairman and CEO Philip Cecil Rickard has resigned due to changes in the company's business strategy and direction, following the cancellation of a coal-fired power plant project in Indonesia and an Indonesian power plant graft scandal. Rickard, 50, will not seek re-election at the upcoming annual general meeting and has been replaced by CEO-designate Andreas Rinaldi, 69. Philip Soh Sai Kiang will become non-executive chairman of the board. Rickard cited a desire to spend time with his family as the reason for his resignation.

site_title: Hong Leong's Midwood condo to have preview ahead of Oct 26 launch
summary: Hong Leong Holdings' new 564-unit Midwood condominium in Hillview Rise, Singapore, is set to launch on October 26. A six-day preview begins on October 19, with early-bird prices starting from S$750,000 for a one-bedroom unit. The condominium will offer a range of units, including three- and four-bedroom options, with prices up to S$1.999 million. The launch comes ahead of a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

images.alt_text: Midwood condominium's arrival court. The condo will have a 50m rooftop infinity pool, among other amenities.

site_title: Rex International soars 15.2% on discovery of oil and gas in Norwegian Sea
summary: Rex International's shares surged 15.2% after announcing the discovery of oil and gas in the Norwegian Sea, with the company's 30% stake in the PL838 licence yielding 3-6 million standard cubic meters of recoverable oil equivalents. The discovery gives Rex the option to move towards production or farm-in to find more oil. The company's shares reached 9.1 cents, with the transfer of interests in the licences set to be completed on October 31 and take effect from January 1.

site_title: Ayondo names Dominic Morris as CTO, interim CEO
summary: Ayondo has appointed Dominic Anthony Morris, 42, as interim CEO and CTO, following the exodus of senior executives in recent months. Morris, who previously worked as Ayondo's external innovation consultant and head of innovation, will oversee the company's technology systems and infrastructure. He holds 3 million ordinary shares in Ayondo and was recommended by the nominating committee after positive reference checks. This appointment comes after the departure of previous interim CEO Richard Mark Street and CFO Sean Downey, and a series of departures within the company's leadership team.

site_title: Indonesia and S Korea move closer to signing bilateral trade deal
summary: Indonesia and South Korea are close to signing a bilateral trade deal, which aims to boost trade between the two nations by 50% by 2022. The agreement, known as the Indonesia-Korea Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, was signed by Indonesian Trade Minister Enggartiasto Lukita and South Korean Trade Minister Yoo Myung-Hee. The deal is expected to remove tariff barriers, increasing two-way trade to over $30 billion, and will benefit both countries' companies. The agreement follows years of talks that were restarted in 2018 and is seen as a significant step towards enhancing economic cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Singapore trying hard to guard itself against populism, says PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the country's efforts to combat populism by focusing on the basic needs of its people through equitable policies on housing, healthcare, and education. He stated that by meeting people's needs and aspirations, Singaporeans will be proud of their country and defend the system. This approach aims to create a sense of ownership and loyalty among citizens, thereby shielding Singapore from the negative effects of populism.

site_title: Thomas Cook Germany withdraws bridging loan application - liquidator
summary: Thomas Cook Germany has withdrawn its application for a state bridging loan due to legal reasons, according to the company's liquidator. The German unit had filed for insolvency in September to separate its brands and operations from its failed parent. The decision comes as the company is still in talks with investors about a possible rescue. Thomas Cook, the world's oldest travel firm, collapsed in September, sparking a massive repatriation effort.

site_title: Six reasons to care about climate-change investing
summary:
Investors can potentially profit from supporting a constructive response to climate change. The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) confirms that global warming is proceeding faster than previous modeling suggested, with major implications for investors. Key reasons to care about climate-change investing include:

- Responding to global economic and industrial restructuring, with companies that create the greatest economic value with the fewest carbon emissions reaping benefits.
- Maximizing risk-adjusted financial performance by integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment analysis.
- Addressing environmental and social imperatives, such as mitigating the impacts of climate change and ensuring a just transition to a low-carbon economy.
- Responding to rising client and stakeholder demand for sustainable investing, driven by millennials' growing interest in climate-conscious investments.
- Meeting regulatory and transparency requirements, including the growing need for climate risk exposures and carbon emissions management strategies to be disclosed.
- Fulfilling changing fiduciary responsibilities, as societal values and priorities shift towards addressing climate change and ESG issues.

site_title: Sunpower wins contracts worth 71.7m yuan from Wanhua Chemical Group
summary: Sunpower Group secured contracts worth 71.7 million yuan from Wanhua Chemical Group, a strategic partner, to supply energy-saving piping products. The contracts are expected to be completed in 2019 and will positively impact the group's financial results. Sunpower has a long-standing relationship with Wanhua Chemical, supplying heat exchangers to its core projects, and has established a track record in supplying high-quality equipment and environmental solutions to major petrochemical industry players.

site_title: Countries can't just wring their hands over nationalism: EDB chair
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board chairman Beh Swan Gin emphasized the need for countries to cooperate despite the global tide of nationalism and protectionism. He suggested creating alternative mechanisms for global trade, echoing Singapore's calls for a reform of global trade rules. Gin's comments come as the World Trade Organization faces challenges, but Singapore remains committed to fostering international cooperation.

site_title: Why Brexit risks breaking up Britain
summary: Scotland's National Party Leader Nicola Sturgeon plans to ask the UK government to approve another independence referendum before the end of the year, citing concerns over Brexit. The move could potentially break up Britain, but experts warn that Scottish independence would weaken the UK's international influence, economic power, and military capabilities. The UK's post-Brexit voice in international forums, including the UN, G7, and G20, would be eroded, and the country's diplomatic and trade missions would be affected. Sturgeon's plan is met with opposition from key party leaders in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, who fear the consequences of Scottish independence.

site_title: With 2 Singapore hotels in the bag, Hoi Hup aims for local portfolio
summary: Hoi Hup Realty has acquired the Andaz Singapore hotel in Singapore for S$475 million, setting a new record for the highest total price ever achieved for a standalone hotel transaction in Singapore. The 342-room luxury hotel, managed by Hyatt Hotels Corporation, is a prime location catering to both business and leisure travelers. The acquisition fits Hoi Hup's objective to balance out the cyclical nature of real estate with income-producing assets. The company has two hotels in Singapore and is not ruling out more hotel buys, but is focusing on local portfolio expansion.

images.alt_text: Mr Koon: "Hotels in Singapore don't come by often, let alone one that is a five-star hotel. Andaz is a scarce product."

site_title: UAE to launch new low-cost airline
summary: Etihad Airways and Air Arabia announced a partnership to launch a new low-cost airline, Air Arabia Abu Dhabi, in the UAE capital. The airline will supplement Etihad's services, offering a new low-cost travel option to and from Abu Dhabi. This move comes after Etihad Airways reported a loss in 2018 for the third consecutive year, blaming investment losses and market conditions. The new airline is part of Etihad's five-year restructuring process, which aims to transform the company and reduce its losses.

site_title: US earnings lift STI but growth concerns remain
summary: US earnings lifted the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) to a 0.6% gain, finishing at 3,134.71, despite concerns over growth. Other Asia-Pacific indices, including Japan and Malaysia, also rose. The Hang Seng Index initially fell but rebounded after Hong Kong's Carrie Lam pledged to relax mortgage rules, potentially easing tensions. However, the move may not end protests, and traders note that earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half.

site_title: Hong Kong protest organiser assaulted by men wielding hammers
summary: A prominent Hong Kong activist, Jimmy Sham, was assaulted by men wielding hammers while walking to a meeting in Mong Kok. Sham, convenor of the Civil Human Rights Front, suffered head injuries but was conscious. This is the second assault on Sham, who was also attacked in August. The incident occurred amid escalating unrest in Hong Kong, with protests growing increasingly violent since the government invoked a colonial-era emergency law to ban protesters from wearing face masks. The Civil Human Rights Front strongly condemns the attack and links it to a "spreading political terror" to inhibit protesters' rights.

site_title: US-China trade tensions fuels downturn risks, spillover for emerging markets
summary: US-China trade tensions are a significant source of risk for the global economy, with "real spillover effects" for emerging markets, according to the IMF. The tit-for-tat trade war has had a significant impact on financial markets over the past two years, setting up a "domino effect" for smaller economies. IMF officials urge policymakers to resolve the trade tensions to mitigate downturn risks and uncertainty, particularly for emerging markets.

site_title: Austrian Nobel winner Handke slams criticism
summary: Austrian Nobel literature prize winner Peter Handke has criticized the backlash against him, stating that journalists were more focused on his support for Serbia's late leader Slobodan Milosevic than his literary works. Organizers canceled a planned press meeting after Handke responded angrily to journalists. The controversy sparked debate in the Balkans and beyond about honoring Handke, who has been an admirer of Milosevic.

images.alt_text: Austrian Nobel literature prize winner Peter Handke has slammed criticism against him, saying journalists were more interested in the row about his support for the Serbs than in his works.

site_title: Strong quake in Philippines sends people scrambling
summary: A magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck central Mindanao in the southern Philippines, causing cracks in buildings, power outages, and panic among residents. There were no immediate reports of casualties, but the quake's epicentre was near Davao City, the hometown of President Rodrigo Duterte. The United States Geological Survey reported the quake at a depth of 14 km, with a chance of aftershocks. The Philippines is geologically active and experiences frequent earthquakes.

site_title: Oxford University probes 'sale' of ancient Bible fragments
summary: Oxford University has launched an investigation into claims that Associate Professor Dirk Obbink sold ancient Bible fragments to Hobby Lobby, a US retailer founded by a billionaire evangelical Christian. The fragments, part of the Oxyrhynchus collection, were allegedly sold in two batches in 2010. The Egypt Exploration Society (EES) had previously initiated its own probe and identified 13 texts from its collection that were taken without authorization. The university is seeking to establish the facts and clarify the sale of the fragments, which have raised concerns about academic integrity and the sale of cultural artifacts.

images.alt_text: The museum last year announced that five items it had said were fragments of the ancient manuscripts known as the Dead Sea Scrolls were in fact fake, and would no longer be displayed.

site_title: Ellipsiz buys 51% of engineering solutions firm AXIS-TEC for S$3.6m
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Ellipsiz acquired a 51% stake in engineering solutions firm AXIS-TEC for S$3.6 million. AXIS-TEC's remaining 49% stake is held by AXIS-TEC founder Vincent Ong and existing shareholder Low Chee Wee. Ellipsiz will appoint three directors and its chairman to AXIS-TEC's board. AXIS-TEC's issued and paid-up share capital is S$1.4 million, with a book value of about S$1.8 million. The acquisition was fully satisfied by Ellipsiz's internal resources.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, tracking US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a fourth straight session, tracking a positive lead on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.20% to 22,472.92, while the Topix index rose 0.70% to 1,631.51. The gains followed strong corporate earnings on Wall Street.

site_title: Jokowi advocates caution on move that may end direct elections
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged caution on a proposed constitutional amendment that could shift power from the president to party chiefs, potentially ending direct elections. The move has drawn support from main parties, but analysts warn it could entrench oligarchic power and deter investment. The parliament may take at least three years to amend the 1945 constitution, with public consultations and a potential rejection of the plan. Widodo called for in-depth studies and proposals from various figures, academics, and the public.

site_title: Asiaphos unit's ex-employees appeal to get severance pay
summary: Asiaphos unit Sichuan Mianzhu Norwest Phosphate Chemical Co's 12 ex-employees are appealing a court decision to dismiss their claims for 1.844 million yuan (S$357,347) in severance pay. The 20 former employees resigned in 2018 and filed their claims in 2019. If the appeal is accepted, Mianzhu Norwest may receive a follow-up notice of claim.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.6% on Wednesday after strong Q3 US bank earnings
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,134.71 on Wednesday, driven by a rally on Wall Street following strong Q3 earnings from major US banks. The local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, also ended higher. Despite a cut in global growth forecast to 3% by the IMF, and concerns over the US Congress's potential support for Hong Kong protesters, traders remained optimistic. Trading volume was 14% higher than the daily average, with 1.33 billion securities traded.

site_title: Qian Hu posts 72% rise in Q3 net profit to S$301,000
summary: Qian Hu, a Singapore-based fish service provider, reported a 72% year-over-year increase in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$301,000. Despite a 10.2% drop in revenue to S$19.2 million, the company attributed the growth to improved margins from its aquaculture business, which generated S$560,000 in operating profit. The company's earnings per share rose to 0.27 Singapore cent, and net asset value per share increased by 1.5%.

site_title: Keppel Reit posts Q3 DPU of 1.4 S cents on higher rents, T Tower contribution
summary: Keppel Reit posted a 3Q DPU of 1.4 S cents, driven by higher rents from Ocean Financial Centre and 275 George Street, as well as the full quarter contribution from T Tower in Seoul. The boost was partially offset by lower revenue and earnings from divested properties, including Bugis Junction Towers and Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 3. The divestment of Bugis Junction Towers will realise capital gains of about S$378.1 million.

site_title: Palm oil body to wield stick to get consumer goods giants to go green
summary: A palm oil industry watchdog, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO), will implement new rules next month that impose fines on consumer goods companies like Unilever and Nestle for not buying more green palm oil. The rules require companies to increase sustainable palm oil purchases by 15% annually or face fines. The industry blames companies for not buying enough sustainably produced oil, contributing to deforestation in South-east Asia. Currently, only a fifth of global palm oil output has RSPO sustainable certification.

site_title: Hong Kong banks to rollout support measure to small businesses - central bank
summary: Nine major Hong Kong banks have agreed to support small and medium enterprises by allowing SME customers to extend or reschedule repayments, and not changing loan terms for the real estate sector despite reduced rents. This move comes as the city faces its first recession in a decade due to anti-government protests. The banks will also not categorize loans as "non-performing" if repayment terms are revised. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority initiated the measures to ease the economic downturn affecting SMEs.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit posts 26% drop in Q3 DPU to 0.918 S cent
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 26.3% drop in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.918 Singapore cents, primarily due to the enlarged unit base after a preferential offering and the cessation of revenue from tenant NK Ingredients. Despite a 4.5% increase in net property income, gains were offset by higher income payable to perpetual holders. The Reit manager secured 87,800 sq ft of new leases and completed 76,600 sq ft of renewals, with positive rental reversion for renewals and negative reversion for new leases.

site_title: Indonesia and South Korea move closer to signing bilateral trade deal
summary: Indonesia and South Korea have taken a key step towards a bilateral trade deal, expected to boost trade by 50% by 2022. Indonesian Trade Minister Enggartiasto Lukita and his South Korean counterpart Yoo Myung-Hee signed a document concluding talks on the Indonesia-Korea Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement. The countries will proceed with "legal scrubbing" and translation before a formal signing. No timeline has been specified, but the agreement is seen as a significant step towards enhancing economic ties between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and South Korea took a key step on Wednesday towards a bilateral agreement that is expected to help boost trade between the two nations by about 50 per cent by 2022.

site_title: US retail sales post first decline in seven months
summary: US retail sales dropped 0.3% in September, the first decline in seven months, amid a slowdown in consumer spending and a moderation in hiring and services sector industry activity. The decline was attributed to a decrease in motor vehicle sales, building materials, and online purchases. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again this month to keep the expansion on track, citing a potential sharper slowdown in economic growth due to a prolonged trade war with China and a looming Brexit.

site_title: Nassim Road GCB once occupied by Saudi Arabia embassy on sale for some S$175m
summary: A two-storey conservation GCB in Singapore's Nassim Road is up for sale via public tender with an indicative price of S$175 million. The property, once occupied by the Saudi Embassy, features 13,839 sq ft of built space and 58,784 sq ft of land area. The buyer can redevelop the site into three GCBs with a 70m frontage. The sale price is expected to be competitive, given the recent sales of GCBs in the area, including a S$230 million transaction at 33 Nassim Road. The public tender closes on November 14.

site_title: MAS to step up supervision of virtual assets in 'major' undertaking
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is increasing supervision of virtual assets, including digital payment tokens, to detect unlicensed activities and money laundering risks. The regulator will use real-time data gathering and experiment with new technologies to assess risks. The move comes ahead of the Payment Services Act, which will license digital payment token services and bring them under MAS's Anti-Money Laundering/Combating the Financing of Terrorism supervision. MAS aims to refine its approach to combat financial crime and guard against illicit uses of virtual assets.

site_title: Moving factories out of China is a very slow process: IIF
summary: A study by the Institute of International Finance suggests that relocating factories from China due to the trade war is happening slowly, with no significant acceleration expected in the near future. South-east Asian countries may struggle to absorb China's processing and assembly trade, and their lack of technology and supply chains hinders their ability to handle more complex production. This could ease concerns about China's current account surplus, which has been declining rapidly, and the country's need to depreciate its currency to balance it.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian countries looking to capitalise on factories moving out of China due to the trade war could be disappointed: Any relocation is happening very slowly, and likely won't accelerate rapidly in the near future.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.61% to 26,664.28. The rally came after a brief drop when Hong Kong's leader was heckled by opposition lawmakers during a policy speech. This was in line with a rally across Asia.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index added 0.61 per cent, or 160.35 points, to 26,664.28.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on Brexit deal hopes; central bank cuts rates
summary: Seoul's stock market closed higher on Wednesday, driven by rising hopes of a Brexit divorce deal, despite concerns over Sino-US trade relations. The Bank of Korea cut interest rates, but a split vote suggested further easing may be delayed. The won weakened, while benchmark bond yields rose. Foreigners sold 46.3 billion won worth of shares, but the Kospi still rose 0.71% to 2,082.83. A Brexit deal has relieved investors, but the Hong Kong issue capped gains, with China opposing new US measures.

site_title: EDB chief repeats Singapore's call for countries to work together
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) chairman Beh Swan Gin reiterated the need for countries to work together to avoid lasting damage from the global political pendulum swinging away from right-wing nationalism. Singapore's leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, have consistently called for an update of global trade rules, citing the WTO's paralysis as a reason for reform. Gin expressed optimism that alternative mechanisms can be created to address global trade issues.

site_title: Australian shares gain for 5th day on Wall Street rally, Brexit optimism
summary: Australian shares rose for a fifth consecutive day, closing 1.3% higher at 6,736.5, driven by gains in financial and energy stocks. US corporate earnings and Brexit optimism boosted risk appetite. The financial sector, led by the country's "Big Four" banks, surged 1-1.5%, while energy stocks rose 1.3% due to global crude price gains. Gold stocks fell 2.8% to their weakest level since July 3, as investors shifted to riskier assets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Raffles City Chongqing, a 1.12 million sq m shopping mall in China, has officially launched with a $4.65 billion investment. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. In other news, Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case will be cleared, and the ASEAN region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy has shrunk for the second month, and South Korea's trade chief is seeking a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Number of significant issues to resolve in Brexit talks says EU
summary: The European Union's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier stated that "a number of significant issues" remain unresolved in talks with Britain, despite constructive discussions. The EU's executive arm was informed of this update by Barnier, who described the talks as ongoing. This development comes as the Brexit deadline looms, adding pressure on policymakers to resolve the outstanding issues.

site_title: 'People of Hong Kong' nominated for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: A Norwegian politician, Guri Melby, nominated the "people of Hong Kong" for the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize for standing up for freedom of speech and democracy, despite risking their lives and security. Melby stated that their actions have a global impact, beyond Hong Kong and the region. This move may draw China's ire, but Melby emphasized the importance of recognizing the people of Hong Kong's courageous efforts for peace and democracy.

images.alt_text: "I have nominated the people of Hong Kong, who risk their lives and security every day to stand up for freedom of speech and basic democracy, to the Nobel Peace Prize for 2020," Guri Melby, a member of Norway's parliament for the liberal party, said in a Twitter post on Tuesday.

site_title: Huawei says nine-month revenue up despite US pressure
summary: Huawei reported a 24.4% year-over-year revenue growth to 610.8 billion yuan (S$118.07 billion) for the first nine months of 2019, despite US pressure over security concerns. The company's profit margin increased by 8.7%. Despite being blacklisted from the US market and banned from buying US components, Huawei maintained its focus on ICT infrastructure and smart devices, leading to increased operational stability and solidified performance in the first three quarters of 2019. The company has repeatedly denied security concerns.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,136.32, up 0.65% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, advancing 0.65% to 3,136.32, driven by gains in Rex International and Spackman Entertainment. The Straits Times Index rose 20.15 points, with 173 gainers outnumbering 125 losers. Other Asian markets, including Tokyo and Hong Kong, also saw gains, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.9%.

site_title: First batch of 9 firms to create solutions for tourism sector under STB accelerator
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has announced its accelerator's first cohort of nine companies, chosen from over 160 applicants, to develop innovative solutions for the tourism sector. The selected companies, from Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand, India, Australia, the UK, and the Netherlands, will receive up to S$25,000 in funding to test and pilot their solutions over six months. Solutions focus on improving productivity, visitor engagement, and visitor experience, with potential to reduce food waste by 30-40%. STB plans to recruit more cohorts, with the next call for applications set to open in November 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong leader moves to ease housing woes, says city in recession
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam unveiled measures to ease housing woes and bolster the economy, amid an "unprecedented challenge" to the economy, which entered a recession in the third quarter. The policies, aimed at the 20% of Hong Kongers living below the poverty line, include compulsory land purchases, cash grants for students, and increased subsidies for low-income families. Despite announcing these measures, Lam's administration faces criticism and calls for her resignation from protesters who demand greater democracy and an investigation into police brutality.

site_title: Singapore property buyers increasingly taking 'wait-and-see' approach: poll
summary: Singapore property buyers are increasingly adopting a "wait-and-see" approach due to concerns over affordability and the overall real estate climate. A PropertyGuru survey found the property purchase intent index fell to 38, the lowest since 2018, with 51% of respondents believing the economy is not performing well. 80% of respondents think private homes are too expensive, and 58% want the government to regulate new property prices. Renters expect rents to fall, and there's a mismatch between landlord and renter expectations on home size.

site_title: Malaysia says will work diplomatically with India if palm oil imports curbed
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said the country will work diplomatically with India if India decides to restrict imports of Malaysian palm oil. The move comes after India considered curbing imports in response to Mahathir's remarks on Kashmir. Malaysia is the world's second-largest producer and exporter of palm oil, with India being its third-largest market. Malaysia has yet to receive an official statement from the Indian government on the possible restrictions. The country is also considering increasing imports of raw sugar and buffalo meat from India to quell trade tensions.

site_title: Smart data in the age of big data
summary: Big data has become a crucial tool in the ASEAN region, driven by rapid smartphone penetration and IoT growth. However, its misuse can lead to dystopian scenarios, while responsible stewardship can provide social good. Companies and governments can utilize big data to create targeted products and policies. Despite its potential, big data has been marred by failures in the West, including the Google Flu Trends project. To overcome these issues, experts advocate for "smart data" collection, which involves structured data from the outset, robust data stewardship, and comprehensive AI solutions. This approach can unlock tremendous impact from even small data sets, and ASEAN's young population and emerging middle-class are primed to take advantage of big data's benefits.

site_title: Hot stock: AA Reit tumbles 6.8% after bookbuilding exercise
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) fell 6.76% to S$1.38 after its sponsor completed a bookbuilding exercise, selling 70.3 million secondary units at S$1.35 apiece, a 6.8% discount to its closing price on October 15. The sale raised S$94.9 million and comprised 10.09% of the total units in issue. The placement units were predominantly sold to new investors across Asia-Pacific and Europe.

site_title: AA Reit sponsor raises S$94.9m from unit placement via bookbuilding
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) raised S$94.9m from a unit placement via bookbuilding, with 70.3 million units sold at S$1.35 per unit. The sale price is at the bottom end of the indicative range and represents an 8.8% discount to the units' closing price on Oct 15. The placement aims to diversify the Reit's investor base, enhance its investor profile, and improve trading liquidity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.51 points to 1,572.99. The index saw 52.66 million lots traded, worth RM20.09 million, with gains beating losses 90 to 44.

site_title: China unexpectedly injects US$28b of cash as growth slows
summary: China unexpectedly injected $28 billion into its financial system through loans to banks ahead of data showing a further slowdown in the domestic economy. The move, made via the People's Bank of China's medium-term lending facility, keeps interest rates steady and takes traders by surprise. This injection aims to ease monetary policy and support the economy, still facing growth pressure due to a prolonged trade dispute with the US. The central bank's decision comes as data shows factory deflation deepened and imports and exports fell last month.

site_title: Eastspring's Loretta Ng to head M&G Investments' Asia business
summary: Loretta Ng, current head of Eastspring's Asia business, will join M&G Investments as head of its Asian business on November 1. This move is part of M&G's strategy to invest in global markets with growth opportunities. Following Ng's appointment, M&G has grown its Asian real estate portfolio and invested in Asian equity fund management and research. The firm has also recently hired four investment professionals in Hong Kong and Singapore.

site_title: ANZ makes senior hires for corporate advisory teams in Singapore, Melbourne
summary: ANZ has appointed Ilhem Dib as its head of corporate advisory for Asia, based in Singapore. Dib joins from a technology startup in Asia, where she was responsible for capital raising, and previously worked at Nomura for 10 years. She will focus on cross-border M&A transactions in ANZ's core industry segments and private equity, as well as growing deal flow into Australia and New Zealand.

images.alt_text: ANZ has appointed Ilhem Dib as its head of corporate advisory for Asia, to be based in Singapore.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation queried by sponsor on share price plunge
summary: Atlantic Navigation, a marine services company, saw its shares plummet 44.9% to S$0.043 on Oct 11 after a trade creditor issued a letter of demand for an outstanding US$3.2 million. The company's board stated it was unaware of any material information for the price drop and is in discussions to resolve the matter amicably. The outstanding sum is recorded as a current liability in the company's H1 2019 financial results. Trading was halted on Oct 11, and the company has requested to resume trading.

site_title: South-east Asia a 'goldmine of untapped opportunity', says Grab co-founder
summary: Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling calls South-east Asia a "goldmine of untapped opportunity" and says the region's underserved nature means solutions from developed markets won't work. Despite global economic gloom, the region is a key driver of growth and innovation, according to Tan. Meanwhile, Klook's Eric Gnock Fah sees Europe as a potential opportunity, citing the mobile-driven travel industry and incremental growth in Asia. The four panellists emphasize the importance of staying focused on their specialisation while staying open-minded to new opportunities.

images.alt_text: Even though South-east Asia remains underserved, solutions that are "copy and paste" from developed markets would not work well here, ride-hailing giant Grab's co-founder Tan Hooi Ling said.

site_title: China's GDP growth slows to 6% in third quarter: AFP poll
summary: China's economy expanded at 6.0% in the third quarter, its slowest rate in nearly three decades, due to cooling domestic demand and the US trade war. The reading is within the government's target range of 6.0-6.5% for the year. Analysts predict further economic stimulus measures, including lowering interest rates, to support the economy, which has been weighed down by weak demand and tariffs. The International Monetary Fund has lowered its 2019 growth forecast for China to 6.1%.

images.alt_text: China's economy expanded at its slowest rate in nearly three decades during the third quarter, held back by cooling domestic demand and a protracted US trade war, according to an AFP survey of analysts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to US lawmakers passing a bill defending Hong Kong protesters' rights, fuelling concerns of a fresh conflict with China. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.16% to 26,461.75, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.05% to 2,992.61. The move came after a previous day's rally, as traders continued to brush off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stock market's rally.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex International oil discovery fuels 12.66% jump in share price
summary: Rex International, a Catalist-listed oilfield services firm, saw its share price surge 12.66% to 8.9 Singapore cents following an oil and gas discovery in the Norwegian Sea. The discovery, made from exploration and appraisal wells, is estimated to contain 19-38 million barrels of oil equivalents. The company's subsidiary, Lime Petroleum AS, holds a 30% stake in the PL838 licence, giving it the option to move towards production or repeat its proven business model.

site_title: New heads for SkillsFuture Singapore, National Library Board
summary: SKILLSFUTURE Singapore and the National Library Board (NLB) have announced new leadership. Changi Airport Group's Lee Seow Hiang, 49, will become NLB's new chairman from January, while SkillsFuture's CEO Lee Seow Hiang will be replaced by Ong Tze-Ch'in, 44, who will also become MOE's deputy secretary for SkillsFuture. Meanwhile, NLB's CEO Elaine Ng, 54, will be replaced by Ng Cher Pong, 47, who has been SkillsFuture's CEO since 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong leader abandons policy speech after lawmakers' heckles
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam abandoned a policy speech after being heckled by opposition lawmakers during a chaotic session at the legislature. The speech, aimed at restoring confidence, was disrupted by pro-democracy lawmakers shouting "Five demands, not one less" as they wore masks of Chinese President Xi Jinping. The move comes as the city faces immense pressure to resolve its biggest political crisis in decades, with Lam rejecting calls to stand down. The US House of Representatives has also passed legislation related to the protests, drawing a rebuke from Beijing.

site_title: Frasers Property, Hitachi team up to drive digital transformation in Asia-Pac property sector
summary: Frasers Property and Hitachi Asia have partnered to drive digital transformation in the Asia-Pacific real estate industry, investing up to S$50 million each over the next five years. The collaboration aims to accelerate digital transformation in Singapore, Thailand, and Australia, with a focus on accelerating the growth of the Asia-Pacific property market, estimated to reach US$82 billion by 2025. The partnership will explore new services, co-development opportunities, and the development of a multi-generational approach to provide technology and Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) solution for the industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend rally for 5th day cheered by Wall Street
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to 6,707.6, for a fifth consecutive day, boosted by strong US earnings and positive Brexit news. The S&P/ASX 200 index notched up gains despite global economic concerns. Wall Street also rose 1% on solid earnings reports.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Wednesday, boosted by a solid start to the US earnings season and reports that Britain still has a chance of avoiding a messy exit from the European Union.

site_title: Beijing tells US to 'stop meddling' over Hong Kong democracy bill
summary: Beijing has strongly opposed the US House of Representatives' passage of the 'Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act', calling on Washington to "stop meddling" in Hong Kong's affairs. The bill aims to defend civil rights in the semi-autonomous city. Beijing's foreign ministry spokesman, Geng Shuang, expressed firm opposition to the US move, denouncing it as an "obstruction to China's sovereignty". The move is seen as a challenge to China's authority over Hong Kong.

site_title: RBNZ's measure of core inflation at 1.7% y-o-y in Q3
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) reported its sectoral factor model of core inflation at 1.7% year-over-year in Q3, unchanged from the previous year's quarter. This measure aligns with the RBNZ's monetary policy goal of 1-3% inflation. In contrast, the official annual inflation rate dropped to 1.5% in the year to September.

site_title: Fintech soCash, JCB to offer cardless currency exchange service for tourists
summary: soCash, a fintech startup, partners with JCB Co. to offer a cardless currency exchange service for tourists, providing competitive FX rates and eliminating ATM withdrawal fees. The service aims to enhance safety and convenience for Japanese tourists in South-east Asian countries with low card penetration. The collaboration is set to launch in March 2020 and expands soCash's offerings beyond conventional foreign exchange services.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher helped by US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.20% on Wednesday, driven by US rallies and a cheap yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached 22,473.77, while the Topix index gained 1.04%. The gains followed strong corporate earnings on Wall Street.

site_title: Thief walks out of gallery with a US$20,000 Salvador Dali etching
summary: A thief walked out of a San Francisco gallery with a $20,000 Salvador Dali etching, "La Girafe en Feu," in less than a minute. The artwork, part of a limited edition, was not secured to an easel and a security camera was not turned on at the time. Surveillance footage shows a man in a blue cap and blue Nike shirt entering the gallery with a second person waiting outside. The thief is still at large, leaving questions about the theft and the potential sale of the artwork, which could fetch up to $27,500.

site_title: How taxes in Hong Kong spawned billionaires and bred inequality
summary: Hong Kong's low taxes have contributed to its status as the world's freest economy, but have also fueled widening inequality. The territory's 20 richest individuals hold a combined net worth of $210 billion, while one in five residents lives below the poverty line. The lack of inheritance and capital-gains taxes has allowed tycoons like Li Ka-shing to accumulate wealth, exacerbating income inequality. This has led to the worst unrest in Hong Kong since its return to China in 1997, with the city's Gini coefficient reaching a 45-year high in 2016.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars drift off, RBNZ dovish as inflation slows
summary: The New Zealand dollar drifted lower after dovish comments from a top central banker, while the Australian dollar also fell due to a surge in the British pound. The New Zealand dollar eased to US$0.6280, while the Australian dollar slipped to US$0.6737, following a 0.2% decline. The comments outweighed a slight upside surprise on domestic inflation, which was seen as a positive sign for the kiwi dollar. The pound's surge to its highest since mid-2016 was attributed to speculation of a Brexit deal near.

site_title: MCT launches placements to raise at least S$902.3m for acquisition
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) has proposed an equity fundraising of 406.5 million new units to raise at least S$902.3 million, partially funding its S$1.55 billion acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 2). The trust obtained unitholders' approval for the acquisition and plans to use the bulk of the funds, S$884.9 million, for the acquisition. The equity fundraising includes a private placement and a non-renounceable preferential offering, with the placement units expected to list on the Singapore Exchange on October 25.

site_title: Mizuho Bank increases risky credit in competitive market
summary: Mizuho Financial Group Inc, Japan's third-largest bank, plans to increase riskier types of corporate credit to boost profitability amid negative interest rates. The bank will offer more subordinated loans and mezzanine finance to deepen relationships with corporate customers and earn higher returns. Mizuho aims to spend 1.45 trillion yen in equity and mezzanine investments and loans for the fiscal year ending March 2020, up from 1.28 trillion yen in 2019. This move is part of the bank's strategy to free up capital and take on more risk.

site_title: US House takes hard line on China over Hong Kong, Huawei
summary: The US House of Representatives passed four pieces of legislation taking a hard line on China, focusing on pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong and the extradition of a Chinese telecom executive. The measures include a bill requiring the US secretary of state to certify Hong Kong's autonomy, a ban on military and crowd-control exports to Hong Kong, and two non-binding resolutions condemning Beijing's interference and supporting Hong Kong's residents to protest. The Senate has not yet scheduled votes, and the measures would be sent to the White House for President Trump to sign into law or veto.

site_title: Rex International makes oil and gas discovery in Norwegian Sea
summary: Rex International, a Catalist-listed oilfield services firm, announced an oil and gas discovery in the Norwegian Sea. The discovery, made from exploration and appraisal wells on the Shrek prospect, has recoverable oil equivalents of 19-38 million barrels. Rex's subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS owns a 30% stake in the licence, which is set to be transferred to Rex by October 31. The discovery could potentially be tied back to the Skarv FPSO facility, with the company planning to explore production options or repeat its proven business model in Norway.

site_title: Singapura Finance to pay US$5m for 1.6% stake in MatchMove Pay
summary: Singapura Finance has agreed to pay US$5 million for a 1.6% stake in MatchMove Pay, a digital payments firm. The deal, valued at US$295 million, will be funded by internal resources and completed on October 31, subject to regulatory approval. MatchMove Pay develops end-to-end banking-as-a-service wallet solutions with global reach. The investment represents an opportunity for Singapura Finance to acquire a stake in a business with long-term growth potential.

site_title: Keppel Capital unit, Allianz to buy stake in Beijing office complex for S$1.3b
summary: Keppel Capital's Alpha Investment Partners, in partnership with Allianz Real Estate, has acquired an 85% stake in Beijing's Ronsin Technology Center office complex for S$1.3 billion. The remaining 15% stake will be held by seller D&J China, which will manage the property with Alpha and Allianz. The complex has a 70% occupancy rate and is located near the Laiguangying subway station. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2019 and marks Alpha's first investment in Beijing.

site_title: SPH to pump up to S$50m seed equity in Japan aged care fund
summary: SPH to invest up to S$50 million in a Japan-based aged care fund, partnering with Bridge C Capital. The fund will acquire senior housing, nursing homes, and medical office buildings in Japan, focusing on the country's aging population. The partnership aims to expand SPH's recurring income base and asset management capabilities in the healthcare sector. Japan's elderly population is projected to increase from 28% to 30% by 2025, creating opportunities for growth in the aged care market.

site_title: South Korea cuts interest rates again as economic woes grow
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, cut its key interest rate for the second time this year to 1.25%, matching a previous record low, to tackle economic weakness and falling consumer prices. The decision highlights the urgency to support the economy, which has been impacted by a global slowdown and a trade war. The IMF has predicted the slowest expansion of the world economy this year since the global financial crisis, and South Korea's growth forecast was slashed to 2% from 2.6%.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank cut its policy interest rate for the second time in three months on Wednesday, as expected, to support a slowing economy and address mounting deflationary pressures.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.44% to 3,129.78
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.44% to 3,129.78 at open on Wednesday, driven by strong corporate earnings and a deal that may prevent Britain from exiting the European Union. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 33, with Rex International Holding and ESR-Reit among the top gainers. Financials also opened stronger, with OCBC Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank up 0.8%, 0.5%, and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: MGM to sell Bellagio, Circus Circus resorts for about US$5b
summary: MGM Resorts International announced the sale of its Bellagio and Circus Circus resorts in Las Vegas for approximately $5 billion. The Bellagio will be acquired by Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust for $4.25 billion, with MGM leasing it back for $245 million annually. Circus Circus Las Vegas will be sold to an affiliate of Treasure Island owner Phil Ruffin for $825 million. The deals aim to monetize MGM's real estate assets and bolster its balance sheet.

site_title: Hong Kong leader to unveil new policies after months of unrest
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam will deliver a State of the Union-style speech on Wednesday, aiming to address four months of pro-democracy protests and low approval ratings. The speech will focus on housing shortages, but major concessions to protesters are unlikely. Lam has dismissed demands for an independent inquiry into the police, amnesty for arrested protesters, and free elections. The US House of Representatives has passed a bill to defend Hong Kong's civil rights, drawing bipartisan support, and China has expressed strong indignation over the bill.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam will unveil a closely watched State of the Union-style speech Wednesday aimed at winning hearts and minds after four months of seething pro-democracy protests.

site_title: Barneys bidding starts, and it's a bet on the future of shopping
summary: Barneys New York, a luxury department store chain, is up for sale after filing for bankruptcy in August. Two potential buyers, Authentic Brands Group (ABG) and a consortium led by Sam Ben-Avraham, have made offers, each with different visions for the brand's future. ABG, which owns over 50 brands, plans to continue running the digital operation and potentially use the Barneys name for private label collections. Ben-Avraham's group aims to preserve at least two stores, including the Madison Avenue flagship, and retain some current management. The bankruptcy judge will rule on the bids on October 24.

site_title: Pound surges as Brexit deal speculation heats up
summary: The British pound surged to five-month peaks on Tuesday, reaching a level last seen in May, amid optimism over a potential breakthrough in Brexit talks. European Union's top Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier hinted at a possible divorce agreement this week, rekindling hopes that Britain might avoid a no-deal Brexit. The pound rose strongly against the euro, with analysts warning that the reports are unconfirmed and vulnerable to "headline risk."

site_title: Trump's lawyer dismisses impeachment subpoena
summary: US President Donald Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani dismissed a congressional impeachment subpoena, calling it "illegitimate" and "unconstitutional". Giuliani refused to turn over documents demanded by three Democrat-led committees, risking contempt of Congress. The move escalates tensions between the White House and Congress as Democrats build evidence of presidential abuse of office, particularly regarding Trump's dealings with Ukraine. Giuliani's actions have bolstered the case for impeachment, with several witnesses testifying about Trump's efforts to pressure Ukraine into investigating Joe Biden.

site_title: Ayondo hires TradeHero co-founder Dominic Morris as CTO, interim CEO after slew of departures
summary: Ayondo has appointed Dominic Anthony Morris as its interim CEO and CTO, following a series of departures, including previous interim CEO Richard Mark Street and CFO Sean Downey. Morris, co-founder of TradeHero, will oversee technology systems and infrastructure, as well as the company's overall business activities. The move comes after Ayondo's previous executives left in June, including the chief operating officer, chief talent officer, and general counsel. Morris holds 3 million ordinary shares in the company and was recommended by the nominating committee following reference checks.

site_title: Erdogan says Turkey 'can never declare ceasefire' in north Syria
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan stated that his country cannot declare a ceasefire in northern Syria, despite a US proposal to broker a truce. Erdogan expressed confidence that Syrian Kurdish fighters will be removed from the region, allowing Turkey to declare a ceasefire. He also downplayed concerns over US sanctions, saying they do not affect Turkey's economy. Erdogan's comments came after the Syrian army entered the city of Manbij, a flashpoint in the conflict.

site_title: Brazil aims to forge more trade accords as Bolsonaro heads to Asia
summary: Brazil aims to conclude free trade agreements with Mercosur and Singapore, as well as South Korea and other Asian countries, by next year. The country's foreign ministry has announced plans for initial trade talks with Vietnam and Indonesia, and is considering deals with India, Japan, and China. Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's upcoming trip to Japan and China is expected to lead to agreements on agriculture, renewable energy, investment, and transportation. The goal is to send a message that Brazil is open to trade, with no plans to be selective in its trade negotiations.

site_title: Oil falls on weaker economic growth forecasts and swelling US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday due to weaker economic growth forecasts and swelling US crude stocks. Global benchmark Brent futures dropped 1.0% to $58.74 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.5% to $52.81. The US-China trade war is expected to cut 2019 global growth to its slowest pace since the 2008-2009 financial crisis, but output may rebound if tariffs are removed. Optimism about a potential Brexit deal and Opec's possible supply curbs limited losses.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Cars@Expo review
summary: The Cars@Expo event saw an uptick in car purchases, resulting in a rise in COE prices across all categories. The successful event was discussed on the Money FM podcast, with hosts Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro. The increase in car sales has caused COE premiums to rise, with Category A prices exceeding S$100,000.

site_title: Shopping mall Raffles City Chongqing in China officially launched
summary: Singapore's CapitaLand officially launched its Raffles City Chongqing shopping mall in China, marking the company's ninth Raffles City development. The 1.12 million square meter development, valued at 24 billion yuan (S$4.65 billion), includes a retail podium, serviced residence, hotel, office space, and luxury residential apartments. The project is Singapore's largest single development in China, featuring 235,000 sq m of retail space, 201 serviced residences, 380 hotel rooms, 150,000 sq m of office space, and 1,400 luxury apartments.

site_title: IMF chief Georgieva tells women: Don't accept less!
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva urges women to refuse lower wages in the workplace, citing her own experience in the Soviet era. A report by the International Monetary Fund finds that women do 2 hours more unpaid work daily, with 20% more unpaid work in egalitarian countries. To address this, governments must invest in infrastructure, childcare, and education, and implement policies such as parental leave and flexible work arrangements. Quotas for hiring women in private firms are seen as a pragmatic solution, but achieving gender equity will take time.

site_title: Barneys to wrap up US$270m bankruptcy deal to reopen stores
summary: US luxury department-store chain Barneys New York Inc is nearing a US$270 million deal with Authentic Brands Group to reopen its flagship and key stores. The agreement, which includes licensing the Barneys name to Saks Fifth Avenue, could save its seven physical retail locations, including its Manhattan flagship and Beverly Hills location. Barneys filed for bankruptcy protection in August, citing rent hikes as a factor. The deal sets a floor for bids in a bankruptcy-court auction and allows Hudson's Bay to operate the Barneys website.

site_title: Fintech investments in Singapore up 69% in first 9 months of 2019
summary: Fintech investments in Singapore increased by 69% in the first 9 months of 2019, reaching US$735 million. However, the number of deals decreased by 29% to 94, indicating larger bets on fewer startups. This contrasts with the same period in 2018, where there were more but smaller deals.

images.alt_text: Fintech investments in Singapore for the nine months ended Sept 30 jumped 69 per cent, from US$435 million in the corresponding period last year to US$735 million.

site_title: Apec finance ministers express 'moderate' hope over US-China trade deal
summary: Apec finance ministers expressed "moderate optimism" that the US and China will sign a trade deal during the forum's summit in Santiago next month. The deal, covering intellectual property, financial services, and currencies, comes after US President Trump announced a partial agreement last week. Finance ministers warned that while planning is underway, actual signing of the deal is uncertain. The IMF estimated the US-China trade war would shrink the world economy by 0.8% in 2020, but a truce would reduce this impact. A joint statement supporting free trade is expected from Apec finance ministers.

site_title: Sharing economy and the future of fintech
summary: The sharing economy has undergone a re-invention, changing the global financial system and disrupting traditional banks. Fintech players are using a "push" strategy to engage consumers, sending tailored insights and offers, while banks face challenges due to their complex nature and risk management requirements. To respond, banks must refine their digital experience and engage consumers emotionally. Fintech trends are blurring industry boundaries, increasing financial inclusion, and focusing on health and wellness. Regulators must strike a balance between providing incentives and establishing risk controls. Banks are changing by partnering with other businesses, innovating, and becoming more customer-centric.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump as hopes of Brexit deal grow
summary: European stocks rose to nearly three-month highs on Tuesday after a news report suggested negotiators were on the verge of a Brexit deal, boosting shares in Irish companies and British banks. The Stoxx 600 index jumped 1.1%, with other major regional indices also gaining. The positive sentiment was also fueled by upbeat US quarterly earnings reports. However, some shares, such as Wirecard, fell after reports of accounting practices.

site_title: MCT's Q2 boosted by better portfolio contribution
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a distribution per unit of 2.32 Singapore cents for Q2, up from 2.27 cents, driven by higher contributions from its VivoCity, Mapletree Business City I, and PSA Building assets. Gross revenue rose 1.9% to S$112 million, while net property income increased 1.7%. The trust's occupancy fell to 96.1%, mainly due to Mapletree Anson, which saw a 19.2% decline. MCT's Reit manager also announced the acquisition of Mapletree Business City (Phase 2) for S$1.55 billion, expanding its asset size to S$8.9 billion.

site_title: Stock brokerages have been resilient in race to zero commissions
summary: Stock brokerages in Singapore are witnessing low commissions, with several major players cutting fees to stay competitive. Following US brokerages like Interactive Brokers, Charles Schwab, and Fidelity, Singaporean brokerages like UOB Kay Hian and OCBC Securities have also introduced zero-commission trading. The focus shifts to product and service offerings, with brokerages diversifying into banking, asset management, and market data services to retain clients and increase assets under management. The industry is adapting to lower trading costs, emphasizing client engagement and innovative services to maintain competitiveness.

site_title: Not a wasted opportunity
summary: Businesses are recognizing the economic value of recycling electronic waste (e-waste), which can be processed into raw materials for production. A study by Singapore Management University found that e-waste recycling can provide a competitive differentiator for companies, attracting environmentally conscious consumers. However, concerns about data security and negative public perceptions of waste management hinder efforts to maximize e-waste recycling. To address these issues, companies must expand collection networks, invest in R&D, and develop new technologies to increase precious metal recovery. Governments must also regulate the industry to balance economic benefits with environmental responsibilities.

site_title: US grocery space player could add to S-Reit asset classes
summary: United Hampshire US Reit is planning to raise up to $400 million through a Singapore initial public offering (IPO), making it the first US grocery-led shopping and self-storage Reit to list in the country. The firm's portfolio, valued at $586 million, comprises 18 grocery- and necessity-based shopping centers and four self-storage assets, with a weighted average lease expiry of 8.6 years. The offering is being marketed as a proxy for US consumption growth, with the asset class seen as resilient to e-commerce.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 4.3% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 4.3% rise in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.93 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from Singapore properties and lower tax expenses. Net property income fell 1.8% to S$42.3 million, while gross revenue declined 2.5% due to the absence of rental top-up income. The Reit's portfolio occupancy was 93.6% as of September 30, and its net asset value per unit increased to S$1.09. The Reit manager remains optimistic about the data centre market's growth prospects.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, SPH, BreadTalk, Keppel DC Reit, KORE, Rex, AA Reit
summary:
Key developments in Singapore's stock market include:

- Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) to raise up to S$902.3 million through a private placement and preferential offering.
- Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to invest up to S$50 million in a Japanese aged care and healthcare fund.
- BreadTalk Group to acquire Food Junction, becoming the third-largest food-court operator in Singapore.
- Keppel DC Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit rose 4.3% to 1.93 cents, while Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's DPU remained unchanged at 1.50 US cents.
- Rex International announced an oil and gas discovery in the Norwegian Sea, boosting its shares 10.1%.
- AIMS Apac Reit requested a trading halt ahead of market open on Wednesday morning.

site_title: Asia's best Reits may lose appeal as price rally trims Thai yields
summary: Thai real estate investment trusts (Reits) have outperformed their Asian peers, with a 30% gain this year, but their surging prices have reduced their appeal. The average dividend yield has fallen to about 4.7%, near its lowest level in two years, making them less attractive to yield-hungry investors. Despite this, some investors remain satisfied with the 4% dividend yield, and the sector's performance is expected to remain positive due to low interest rates and market volatility.

site_title: Japan in non-stop search for typhoon survivors; toll at 74
summary: Rescuers in Japan continue their search for survivors of the powerful typhoon Hagibis, which killed at least 74 people and caused widespread destruction. The storm made landfall on Saturday, unleashing fierce winds and unprecedented rain that triggered landslides and flooded rivers. The government has called up reserve troops and deployed 110,000 personnel for rescue operations, with over 3,000 people rescued so far. Despite the scale of the disaster, the government has no plan to delay a palace ceremony to celebrate Emperor Naruhito's enthronement on October 22.

images.alt_text: Rescuers in Japan worked around the clock Tuesday in an increasingly desperate search for survivors of a powerful weekend typhoon that killed more than 70 people and caused widespread destruction.

site_title: Pine Capital unit sues two ex-directors
summary: A subsidiary of Pine Capital Group, ADVANCE Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM), has commenced legal proceedings against two former directors, Wang Meng and Pan Ki Ro, alleging breaches of fiduciary duties and obligations owed to it. The former directors were removed at an EGM on Aug 12, with Wang also stepping down as Pine Capital's head of Greater China. ACPAM obtained an interim injunction, restraining the defendants from dealing with ACF's assets and interfering with its affairs. The case relates to possible mismanagement and the transfer of the management share of ACF to Wang, which has left ACPAM with no operating fund.

site_title: Margaret Atwood, Bernardine Evaristo joint winners of Booker Prize
summary: Margaret Atwood and Bernardine Evaristo have been jointly awarded the prestigious Booker Prize for Fiction for 2019, the first time the award has been shared. Atwood is the second female author to win the prize twice, while Evaristo is the first black woman to win. The decision was made by the five-judge panel to "break the rules" and honor both authors' works, "The Testaments" and "Girl, Woman, Other", respectively. The £50,000 prize money will be shared equally between the two winners.

site_title: US: Stocks boosted by good earnings day
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday following a batch of mostly good corporate earnings, despite a downcast IMF forecast emphasizing the drag from trade wars. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.9%, the S&P 500 gained 1.0%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.2%. Strong earnings announcements from JPMorgan Chase, Johnson & Johnson, and United Healthcare more than made up for a disappointing release from Goldman Sachs, raising hopes for the coming earnings period.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks surged on Tuesday following a batch of mostly good corporate earnings while investors shrugged off a downcast IMF forecast that emphasised the drag from trade wars.

site_title: CBRE confirms hire of JLL's Greg Hyland to capital markets team
summary: CBRE has confirmed the hire of Greg Hyland, former head of capital markets for Singapore at JLL, as managing director, capital markets (Asia-Pacific). Hyland will work with existing teams in the region, bringing over US$10 billion in real estate transactions experience. The appointment marks a significant move in CBRE's capital markets presence in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore and China ink several deals in Chongqing
summary: Singapore and China signed nine agreements at their 15th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation meeting in Chongqing, China, marking a significant milestone in their ties. The agreements include a smart-city project, a youth-internship exchange, and upgrades to their free-trade agreement, which will take effect on Wednesday. The substantial number of deals signals a new chapter in the relationship between the two countries, with Singapore transitioning to a new generation of leaders. The agreements also aim to strengthen cooperation in areas such as innovation, trade facilitation, and investment protection.

site_title: India laws a dose of reality for Big Pharma
summary: India's patent laws, which restrict the patenting of new forms, uses, and methods of administration of new medicines unless demonstrating a statistically significant increase in efficacy, have been a point of contention with the US pharmaceutical industry. The US had proposed a similar amendment to its patent law, but it was withdrawn. India's laws aim to make innovative medicines accessible to the masses, not just the wealthy, while the US sees the laws as inconsistent with its international obligations. The issue has sparked a debate over the balance between protecting intellectual property and ensuring affordable access to life-saving medicines.

site_title: Economics Nobel for research on poverty will help restore profession's relevance
summary: The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics to Abhijit Banerjee, Esther Duflo, and Michael Kremer for their research on the causes and remedies for poverty. Their work, which includes field experiments and randomized controlled trials, demonstrates that economists care about humanity's fundamental economic problem and seeks to learn how policy can relieve constraints faced by the poor. The prize highlights two healthy tendencies in economics: a strong empirical turn and methodological openness, and suggests that economics has the wherewithal to dispel public doubts about its ability to address major problems.

site_title: Keppel Electric, Geneco, iSwitch top choices in power switch by consumers
summary: In Singapore's electricity market, 40% of households have switched to a new retailer since the market opened over a year ago, with four out of 10 households choosing Keppel Electric, Geneco, or iSwitch. These households are enjoying 20-30% cheaper power bills. The move is attributed to the liberalised energy sector under the Open Electricity Market (OEM) plan, which has sparked a competitive market among over 10 players, including SP Services.

site_title: Partial US-China trade deal only a truce: analysts
summary: US and China announced a partial trade deal, but analysts say it's only a truce, with structural issues remaining unresolved. The deal includes China addressing intellectual property concerns and buying $40-$50 billion in US agricultural products, but lacks an accounting mechanism. The US will hold off on a tariff hike, but a full trade agreement remains uncertain. The deal's duration and incentives for both sides are unclear, with tensions expected to continue between the world's two superpowers, particularly in technology, finance, and human rights.

site_title: RedDoorz gunning for IPO, and making expansion a priority
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based hotel booking and management platform, aims to become Ebitda-positive by 2023 and list publicly. The company operates over 1,500 properties in Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Vietnam, with plans to expand to 15,000 hotels by 2023. RedDoorz acquires 150 new properties monthly and has a strong direct customer base, allowing it to maintain positive unit economics. The company expects to grow its annualized revenue to US$500 million by the end of 2023.

site_title: Trade talk optimism fades as investors get reality check
summary: Investors lost optimism over a potential US-China trade deal, with the STI edging down 0.27% after follow-up analyses deemed the promises "meaningless". China's September trade data showed a quickening slide in exports and continued contraction in imports, further darkening the outlook for the world's second-largest economy. Trading was thin, with key indices in China snapping a five-day winning streak and Hong Kong ending lower.

site_title: IMF's very reason for existing takes a hit
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) resource base is under threat due to US President Donald Trump's administration not supporting an IMF quota increase. The US is concerned about China's underweight position in the Fund, despite the country's significant economic influence. The US is also set to withdraw from the Fund's New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB) emergency backstop, which could leave the IMF dangerously underfunded. This decision could have severe consequences for the IMF's ability to provide financial support to countries in need.

site_title: Developers' Q3 private home sales set to be highest in six years
summary: Developers in Singapore are expected to sell the highest number of private homes in Q3 in six years, driven by a wave of condo launches. This surge in sales will test demand for prime projects priced above S$3,000 per square foot. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In other markets, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high and Goldman Sachs acquired a significant portfolio of hotel and retail assets in Seoul, South Korea. These trends indicate a fluctuating real estate market.

site_title: KORE Q3 DPU unchanged at 1.5 US cents
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.5 US cents, unchanged from the same period last year. The Reit's distributable income rose 31% to US$12.4 million, driven by contributions from new acquisitions. Gross revenue and net property income also increased, with portfolio committed occupancy at 93.8%. The Reit's aggregate leverage was 38.5% as of September 30, and it declared no distribution for the third quarter. KORE's unit price closed flat at US$0.755.

site_title: HK retail rents down sharply in Q3: CBRE
summary: Hong Kong retail rents plummeted 10.5% in Q3, the sharpest quarterly decline since 1998, amid anti-government protests. The protests have pushed shop sales to a record low, with 100 restaurants closing in the past few months. Landlords are offering rent subsidies and temporary adjustments to tenants. Overall, high street rents are expected to decline by 5-10% over the remainder of 2019. The decline is attributed to a pessimistic outlook among consumers and a lack of rental transactions.

site_title: GIC, KKR buy 42.5% stake in Philippines' biggest hospital chain for 35b pesos
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and private equity giant KKR have agreed to buy a 42.5% stake in the Philippines' largest hospital chain, Metro Pacific Hospital Holdings, for 35.3 billion pesos (US$937.6 million). The deal values the hospital chain at 83 billion pesos (US$1.61 billion), nearly tripling its 2014 value. The consortium will invest in new shares and convertible bonds, financing hospital expansions and growth, and the deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: SGX RegCo partners SISV to raise valuation standards
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) regulatory arm, SGX RegCo, has partnered with the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) to establish standards for property valuation for public companies in Singapore. Under the agreement, SISV will provide expert advice and support to review property valuation reports for compliance with applicable standards and guidelines.

site_title: Today's sharing economy and the future of fintech
summary: Traditional banks can benefit from the rise of fintech by refining their digital experience and adopting a "push" strategy to engage consumers. Fintech players have shown success by sending tailored insights and offers to customers, creating emotional connections and driving profitable interactions. Despite challenges, banks can change by narrowing customer groups, innovating digitally, and partnering with other businesses. Businesses can also leverage fintech to grow revenues and customer interactions by adopting customer-centricity and partnering with fintech platforms. The future of fintech will be shaped by regulation, industry partnerships, and interoperability, with forward-looking regulation and standards key to success.

site_title: China factory prices post steepest fall in 3 years, adding to economic gloom
summary: China's factory prices posted a 1.2% year-on-year decline in September, the steepest fall in over three years, amid weak demand and US trade pressures. This marks a grim outlook for the country's manufacturing sector and reinforces the need for further stimulus measures. Analysts expect the Chinese government to unveil additional stimulus measures at the end of the month, following a cautious approach so far, with some predicting China's overall economic growth rate may slip below the government's 6-6.5% target range this year.

site_title: Southwest Air pilots see 737 Max return in February at the earliest
summary: Southwest Airlines pilots expect the Boeing 737 Max to resume flights in February at the earliest, surpassing the carrier's initial January 6 target due to ongoing safety concerns and regulatory processes. The pilots' union has sued Boeing for lost pay and expects the FAA to certify the plane's safety before resuming flights. Boeing must complete software updates and address issues flagged in recent reports before the planes can fly passengers, with a potential 15-day public comment period and 30-day training period for pilots before resuming flights.

site_title: BreadTalk Group gets regulatory nod for Food Junction buyout
summary: BreadTalk Group has obtained regulatory approval for its buyout of Food Junction, becoming the third-largest food court operator in Singapore. The combined market share of the parties post-merger is below 20%, significantly lower than NTUC Kopitiam and Koufu. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) deemed the merger acceptable, paving the way for the deal to proceed.

site_title: London retains global finance throne despite Brexit chaos
summary: London remains the global financial hub despite Brexit uncertainty, with international banks continuing to hire and resist relocation to the EU. A US$1.2 billion bet by property developer Stuart Lipton on London's financial district is paying off, with global investors including Axa backing the move. The UK financial sector is in expansion mode, and London's status as a top financial center is expected to endure.

site_title: Upcoming results season may not be a pretty sight
summary: Singapore's upcoming earnings season is expected to be lacklustre due to the ongoing US-China trade war and the impact of Hong Kong protests on the export-oriented sector. Key sectors, including transport and logistics, and local banks, are likely to report weaker performance. However, S-Reits are expected to be a bright spot, with hospitality and retail Reits showing strong momentum. Analysts predict a decline of 2.4% in FY19 earnings growth before recovering in FY20, with some Reits, such as CDL HT and Frasers Centrepoint Trust, being top picks.

site_title: UOB to invest S$26m over 3 years in staff development programme
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will invest S$26 million over three years in a staff development program, "Better U," to enhance its 26,000 employees' skills in soft skills, digital innovation, and data. The 12-week foundation course aims to foster a growth mindset and develop problem-solving skills. By 2020, 70% of employees will have completed the course, with opportunities for specialized learning tracks and education support.
