Notable transactions include Ho Bee Holdings' acquisition of 100,700 shares in Ho Bee Land and Moneymax Financial Services' acquisition of 1,250,000 shares in Moneymax. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also increased, with notable changes in stakes held by companies such as AIMS Apac Reit, Pan Hong, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings.

site_title: China is waging war with US businesses. And it's winning
summary: China is exerting significant influence over US businesses, particularly in the wake of the NBA's decision to back Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests. The Chinese Communist Party swiftly responded, severing ties with the Houston Rockets, cancelling lucrative deals, and blacklisting NBA games. The NBA's commissioner, Adam Silver, and team owner Joe Tsai subsequently apologized for the tweet. This incident is part of China's broader strategy of corporate encirclement, as outlined by Sun Tzu's "The Art of War". US businesses must now confront China's intimidation campaign, and the US government must stem rising intellectual property theft and cyberattacks to empower American businesses to take a tougher stand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: F&N, Tuan Sing, Yoma Strategic, GKE Corp, Hatten Land, ASL Marine
summary: Singaporean stocks to watch include Fraser & Neave (F&N) after its subsidiary acquired land for integrated dairy farming and milk production in Malaysia. Tuan Sing Holdings established a S$500 million secured multicurrency MTN programme. Yoma Strategic Holdings formed a strategic partnership with AC Energy to develop renewable energy projects in Myanmar. GKE Corp posted a net profit of S$254,000 for Q1, while Hatten Land gained an extension to repay a US$20 million loan. ASL Marine Holdings' auditor raised concerns about the group's ability to continue as a going concern due to a net loss of S$145.9 million.

site_title: China's 9-month exports to US down 10.7% in dollar terms
summary: China's 9-month exports to the US fell 10.7% in dollar terms, while US imports dropped 26.4% during the same period, according to a Chinese customs spokesman. This decline is attributed to trade frictions with the US. However, recent Sino-US trade talks have yielded favorable outcomes in some areas. Despite this, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's exports to the United States fell 10.7 per cent from a year earlier in dollar terms in January-September, while US imports dropped 26.4 per cent during that period, a Chinese customs spokesman said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on partial US-China deal; STI up 0.51% to 3,129.79
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.51% to 3,129.79 on Monday, driven by a partial US-China trade deal that included a halt to tariffs. The Straits Times Index gained 15.82 points, with gains outweighing losses 105 to 47. Key stocks such as Spackman Entertainment and Rex International also saw significant gains. US stocks on Friday also rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.2%, while European shares jumped after a surprise breakthrough in Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Tuan Sing unit sets up S$500m medium-term note programme
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings, a mainboard-listed property developer, has established a S$500 million secured multicurrency medium-term note (MTN) programme. This is the group's second MTN programme, following the existing S$900 million multicurrency programme launched in 2013. DBS Bank and United Overseas Bank are appointed arrangers and dealers for the new programme.

site_title: SGX eyes smaller deals as bourse mergers implode
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is shifting its focus towards smaller deals and incremental growth, after the failure of its mega-merger attempts. The bourse is exploring acquisitions in financial technology and firms that complement its existing capabilities. SGX's equities head, Michael Syn, says the company is adopting a "softly-softly" strategy, prioritizing stability and higher yields over blockbuster deals. New initiatives include launching single-stock futures and introducing derivatives on freight capacity, with a focus on retail client trading via social media applications.

site_title: Bullish uptrend seen for DBS
summary: DBS Group's share price has shown steady growth since 2011, breaking the 30.00 mark in March 2018, a new historical high. According to the Elliot Wave Theory, a bullish uptrend is predicted for the bank's stock price, with the Grand Supercycle Wave 3 expected to consist of standard five-waves movements, potentially leading to exponential share gains. However, investors should be cautious as the current third wave movement has just completed, and a corrective Wave 4 is unlikely to converge into a pennant formation.

site_title: MAS eases monetary policy 'slightly' in October
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased monetary policy "slightly" in its October review, making the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate policy band less steep and reducing its rate of appreciation. The policy stance remains unchanged, with the MAS saying it's consistent with medium-term price stability given the current economic outlook. The central bank will closely monitor economic developments and recalibrate policy if prospects for inflation and growth weaken significantly.

site_title: US auto workers go on strike against Mack Truck
summary: US auto workers, members of the United Auto Workers union, went on strike against Mack Truck, a subsidiary of AB Volvo, on October 13, 2019. The strike, which affects over 3,600 workers, is seeking fair pay, benefits, and job protections. The union, led by Secretary-Treasurer Ray Curry, aims to stand up for the hard work of union members in designing and building Mack trucks. The strike hit plants in Pennsylvania, Maryland, and Florida, with no end date announced.

site_title: Hopes of trade war, Brexit breakthrough bring cheer
summary: US stocks rallied last week as a potential breakthrough in the US-China trade war and Brexit negotiations brought relief to investors. President Donald Trump announced a "Phase One" trade deal with China, which could result in $40 billion to $50 billion in agricultural purchases. Analysts believe this could boost business confidence and economic growth, particularly in China and the US. However, concerns about the global slowdown and potential for more tariffs remain, and some economists warn that the partial agreement may not be enough to prevent a recession.

site_title: Singapore Q3 GDP up by 0.1% in MTI flash data in close shave for recession fears
summary: Singapore's Q3 GDP grew 0.1% year-over-year, narrowly avoiding a technical recession. This is flat compared to the 0.1% expansion in Q2. The result is worse than expected, with private sector forecasts ranging from 0.2% to 0.3%. The country is now expected to experience tepid full-year growth between 0% and 1%.

images.alt_text: The Singapore economy may have narrowly avoided a technical recession in the third quarter, according to flash estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Monday.

site_title: Chinese flock to S-EA on shopping trips during Golden Week
summary: Chinese tourists flocked to Southeast Asia during Golden Week, with countries in Asean making up half of the top 10 destinations by transaction volume on Chinese payment app Alipay. New markets Cambodia and the Philippines joined Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore as leading markets, with the Philippines seeing a 26-fold increase in transactions. Despite China's economic slowdown, Alipay's merchant network grew in emerging markets, with over 300,000 merchants participating in the Golden Week campaign. Average spending per user was 85% higher in Japan than in South-east Asia.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the mixed market trends for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Capesize market showed a slight rally, with the West Australia to China C5 route lifting to $9.518, before closing at $9.227. However, the Atlantic Basin and Panamax markets experienced a decline. The BPI broke the 1900 points barrier, with rates improving in the Pacific and Atlantic Basins. Ultramax and Supramax markets saw limited fresh information, while Handysize routes lost ground. Tanker rates surged in the Middle East Gulf, with VLCCs reaching WS 205 and Suezmax rates increasing by 50%.

site_title: Online streaming giants battle for Asian audiences
summary: Streaming giants Netflix, Amazon Prime, and Disney are competing for Asian audiences, with the region seen as crucial to their growth plans. The Asia Contents Awards at the Busan International Film Festival highlighted the changing market, with local platforms like HOOQ and iwonder producing content for global audiences. Online video revenue in the region is projected to increase to $50 billion by 2024, with China accounting for 59% of the market, driven by strict regulations making it difficult for outside players.

site_title: Brexit hangs in balance amid intensifying EU talks
summary: Britain's Brexit talks with the EU are intensifying, with negotiators working through the weekend to finalize a deal that could see the UK leave the bloc on October 31. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is trying to convince the EU to accept a compromise on border arrangements for Northern Ireland, a key sticking point in the negotiations. If a deal is reached, Johnson must then convince a divided British parliament to ratify it, with a vote expected on October 19. Failure to secure a deal could lead to an uncertain future for Britain, with lawmakers considering a delay or no-deal exit.

site_title: Brexit cloud hangs over energy supplies from Dublin to Belfast
summary: Brexit uncertainty looms over Ireland's energy supplies, with the UK's impending departure from the EU potentially disrupting the single energy market that has reduced power costs for consumers. Ireland imports 88% of its energy needs, with 44% coming from renewables, and the UK's reliance on supplies from power plants in the rest of the UK could lead to increased prices for Northern Irish consumers. Trading agreements and cooperation on energy security are still unresolved, and grid companies are planning closer ties with continental Europe to mitigate potential disruptions.

site_title: CapitaLand launches S$750,000 programme with NTUC First Campus
summary: CapitaLand has launched a S$750,000 programme with NTUC First Campus' My First Skool to support 2,000 preschool children from low-income families in Singapore. The three-year programme, called CapitaLand-Bright Horizons Fund Ready-for-School, aims to help children with learning needs prepare for primary school through small group teaching and classroom co-facilitators. The programme will be expanded to 20 centres, supporting an additional 200 children.

site_title: Iraqi and Vietnamese directors scoop top prize at Busan film festival
summary: Iraqi director Mohanad Hayal's film "Haifa Street" and Vietnamese director Tran Thanh Huy's film "Rom" have won the top prize at the 24th Busan International Film Festival, each receiving a $30,000 award. The films were chosen for their maturity, confidence, and understanding of cinema language. The festival, which showcased 299 films from 85 countries, aims to expand its film funding efforts and build a Korean cinema museum. The event concluded with the world premiere of Korean director Lim Dae-hyung's drama "Moonlit Winter."

site_title: Amazon Singapore sees growth backed by logistics capacity
summary: Amazon Singapore is expanding its warehouse space at Mapletree Logistics Hub and hiring staff to support its growing retail operations. The company has added a new fulfillment centre in Singapore to meet demand, and is investing in third-party sellers to grow its sales. Amazon Singapore has seen a significant increase in sales, with shoppers chalking up S$3.6 billion in retail sales in August. The company is prioritizing investments in infrastructure and customer experience, with a focus on creating sustainable long-term growth.

site_title: Bank of England might not be able to cut rates if Brexit delayed again: Ramsden
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Dave Ramsden expressed skepticism about cutting interest rates if Brexit is delayed beyond the current October 31 deadline, citing the economy's damage from uncertainty. He noted that a prolonged delay would hinder the central bank's ability to help the economy, which has been impacted by a steady fall in investment by companies. Ramsden also highlighted concerns about productivity growth, rising company wage costs, and global trade tensions, which could drive inflationary pressure. This stance contrasts with views held by some of his colleagues, including Michael Saunders and Gertjan Vlieghe.

site_title: Protesters, police clash as metro stations, shops targeted
summary: Protesters and police clashed in Hong Kong on Sunday, with protesters targeting metro stations and shops, and police responding with tear gas and arrests. The clashes, which began peacefully, escalated into violent confrontations, with protesters trashing shops and erecting road-blocks. The protests, which have been ongoing for four months, are centered around opposition to Beijing's tightening grip on the city and social inequality. The unrest has plunged Hong Kong into its worst crisis since its handover to China in 1997, with the city facing its first recession in a decade.

site_title: Historic slump in China car market continues
summary: China's car sales continued their historic slump in September, falling 6.6% from the previous year to 1.81 million units. This marks the 15th consecutive month of decline, the worst slump in a generation. The only increase since mid-2018 occurred in June, when dealers offered discounts to clear inventory. The slump is attributed to various factors, including government efforts to support the market.

site_title: F&N Malaysia to milk upstream dairy activity from RM156m land purchase
summary: F&N Malaysia, a subsidiary of Fraser & Neave Bhd, has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 4,454 hectares of leasehold land in Malaysia for RM156 million. The land, currently a palm oil, rubber, and mango plantation, will be used for integrated dairy farming and milk production to support existing downstream production and distribution of fresh milk products. The acquisition aims to reduce dependence on imported milk and promote local agriculture.

site_title: Kurds announce deal with Damascus on Syria troop deployment near Turkish border
summary: The Kurdish administration in northern Syria announced a deal with the Damascus government, allowing Syrian troops to deploy near the Turkish border to confront Turkey's offensive. The agreement aims to prevent and confront Ankara's aggression, with the Syrian army assisting the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF). The details of the agreement were not disclosed, and it is unclear if it will compromise Kurdish self-rule in the north.

site_title: HK turmoil spells opportunity for London property owners
summary: London property owners are seeing strong demand from investors fleeing Hong Kong's uncertainty, with Oxford Properties Group selling stakes in London offices and considering a deal to sell a £700 million office complex. Oxford President Michael Turner says the firm is not leaving London, but instead looking for growth opportunities in Asia and the US. The firm's decision to sell UK properties has freed up funds for global investments, including its involvement in New York's Hudson Yards. This trend is attributed to London being the most international market in the world.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian betting on scale and depth
summary: UOB Kay Hian, a Singapore-based brokerage firm, is betting on scale and depth to stay ahead in the declining traditional retail broking business. The firm recently acquired 100 remisiers from DBS Vickers Securities, increasing its dealers and remisiers to 800 in Singapore, solidifying its position as the largest brokerage. The acquisition aims to boost scale and reduce overhead costs, while the firm also focuses on developing skill sets to offer comprehensive products and services to clients, including alternative products and corporate advisory services.

site_title: Australia to invest A$1b in dams for drought-stricken region
summary: Australia's federal and New South Wales governments will invest A$1 billion to upgrade water infrastructure in drought-stricken rural communities. The investment includes A$650 million for the Wyangala Dam and A$480 million for the Dungowan Dam. The move aims to address the ongoing drought and build drought resilience for the future. The investment is a response to the drought impacting rural and regional communities in New South Wales, which has been affected since mid-2017.

site_title: US restaurant chains eye bacon, sausage boost despite pork price inflation
summary: US restaurant chains, including Wendy's and McDonald's, are expanding their breakfast menus with pork-heavy options despite rising pork prices. The move aims to capitalize on Americans' love for sausage and bacon. The breakfast meal accounts for a significant portion of McDonald's sales, around $10 billion, and Wendy's plans a $20 million national breakfast rollout next year. This strategy is a risk, as the pork supply is at risk of crisis.

site_title: Dollar skids to 3-month low on Brexit sentiment and trade optimism
summary: The US dollar dropped to a three-month low due to easing safe-haven buying and improving risk sentiment, driven by optimism over US-China trade negotiations and a potential British exit from the EU. A partial trade deal with China was announced by President Trump, but analysts noted it may not lead to a broader deal. Meanwhile, sterling rose to a three-month high versus the dollar on Brexit optimism, and the euro advanced to a three-week peak. Other safe-haven currencies, such as the yen and Swiss franc, slid.

site_title: Investing in growth with smarter boards in family firms
summary: Family firms in Asia, where most publicly listed firms are controlled by families, can benefit from having independent directors to drive growth and mitigate weaknesses. However, a control mindset can hold back growth, and insider boards often lack diversity, hindering the firm's ability to adapt to new markets or industries. Strong, independent directors can provide new competencies and networks, strengthen internal systems, and position the firm for sustained growth and smoother succession. By viewing a strong board as an investment, family owners can harness the potential of independent directors to reach the next level.

site_title: SoftBank seeks control of WeWork through financing package: WSJ
summary: SoftBank Group Corp. has prepared a financing package to gain control over WeWork Companies Inc. The package would significantly increase SoftBank's stake, diluting Adam Neumann's influence as co-founder. WeWork is working with JPMorgan Chase to negotiate a $3 billion debt deal after canceling its initial public offering due to investor concerns. The company has burned through $2.36 billion in cash in the first half of 2020 and may run out of money in the second quarter. SoftBank's move aims to return WeWork to its core business of renting office space.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group Corp. has prepared a financing package for WeWork Companies Inc that would give it control over the shared office space company, the Wall Street Journal reported.

site_title: Japan tackles rescues, cleanup in Typhoon Hagibis aftermath
summary: Typhoon Hagibis, the largest storm to hit Japan in decades, caused widespread destruction and flooding across the country. At least 21 people died, over 160 were injured, and at least 16 were missing. Record rainfall and violent winds led to major landslides, mudflows, and river bank collapses. Japan deployed thousands of troops to assist in rescue and cleanup efforts, with 262,150 buildings losing electricity. Transportation services were restored, but the economic impact of the storm is yet to be determined.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Amazon launches Singapore website, its first in South-east Asia
summary: Amazon has launched its first website in South-east Asia, in Singapore, marking a significant expansion for the e-commerce giant. The move is part of Amazon's efforts to increase its presence in the region. The website offers various products and services to customers in Singapore, providing them with a seamless shopping experience. This launch is a key development in Amazon's regional expansion strategy.

site_title: Silver linings in the clouds
summary: Singapore's small, open economy is vulnerable to external events, and the current trade war between the US and China disproportionately affects the country. However, the job market is not yet in crisis, and the government has sufficient funds to support workers and businesses if needed. According to Victor Mills, CEO of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, calls for government intervention are premature, but a technical recession is possible.

site_title: Boeing strips CEO of chairman job over 737 Max
summary: Boeing has stripped CEO Dennis Muilenburg of his chairman role, citing the need for "active oversight" as the company navigates regulatory hurdles and safety concerns surrounding its grounded 737 Max jetliner. The move aims to focus Muilenburg on resolving the crisis, which has weighed heavily on the company since the Max's return to service. Despite the separation, the board expressed continued support for Muilenburg, indicating the pressure he faces to address the crisis.

site_title: Foreign inflows, looming rate cut belie weakness in S Korea bonds
summary: Foreign investors are pouring into South Korean bonds, despite the nation's weak returns, with yields ranking near the bottom of 46 sovereign markets. The Bank of Korea is expected to lower interest rates twice in the coming year, but economists believe it may not be enough to change the picture. The economy's vulnerability to external shocks and excess supply of bonds are also holding back Korean debt, which may catch up with Treasury yields early next year.

site_title: Impact of Fed bond-buying will depend on Treasury
summary: The Federal Reserve plans to buy $60 billion of Treasury bills per month to control the benchmark interest rate. The impact of this measure depends on the Treasury Department's response, particularly on its issuance of Treasury bills and bonds. If the Treasury increases bill issuance and cuts back on longer-dated securities, it could lead to downward pressure on long-term interest rates, potentially stimulating the economy. However, if the Treasury maintains its current plans, the Fed's buying could squeeze the bills market and push up prices. The Fed's chairman, Jerome Powell, has repeatedly stated that this is not quantitative easing.

site_title: Facebook researchers turn to maths for better translations
summary: Facebook researchers are exploring a new approach to machine translation, utilizing mathematical similarities between languages to improve translations. This method involves rendering words into figures, which could potentially lead to more accurate and efficient communication. While a universal communicator remains a distant dream, this new approach is considered a promising avenue. By leveraging mathematical patterns, the researchers aim to reduce reliance on dictionaries and enhance language understanding.

site_title: Retail, hospitality Reits get lift from tourist arrivals
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to have a stable quarter, driven by tourist arrivals boosting retail and hospitality Reits. Industrial Reits, however, face caution due to macroeconomic uncertainty and recession fears. Analysts favor steady income and longer weighted average lease expiries, with sectors like logistics, data centers, and suburban retail in vogue. Despite concerns over the co-working sector, Reits are expected to remain "in flavor" with low interest rates and the global economy not entering a significant slowdown.

site_title: Sterling investors near 'point of maximum danger'
summary: Sterling investors are optimistic about a potential Brexit deal, with the pound's rally showing its strongest bias in favor of buying contracts against the US dollar. A deal could push the pound to $1.35 and euro-sterling to 85p per euro, but failure could drive it back down to $1.22. Despite this, some investors remain cautious, with one portfolio manager labeling the situation "the point of maximum danger" if the deal fails. A Brexit deal secured before the EU summit this week could give the UK Parliament a chance to sign off on it, but lawmakers' approval would be the next hurdle.

site_title: Australia in advanced talks on developing rare earths projects
summary: Australia is in advanced talks with the US, Japan, and South Korea to develop local rare earths mining projects, aiming to diversify the supply of these critical minerals outside China. Australia's Resources Minister Matt Canavan is working with US officials to secure financing and supply deals for projects, following US President Donald Trump's order to spur production of rare-earth magnets used in military hardware. This move comes amid US-China trade tensions and concerns about the security and affordability of rare earth supply.

site_title: Warren campaign runs 'false' advertisements to challenge Facebook's ads policy
summary: US Senator Elizabeth Warren's Democratic presidential campaign challenged Facebook's ads policy by running an ad with false claims that Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg endorsed President Donald Trump's re-election bid. Warren tweeted, "Facebook changed their ads policy to allow politicians to run ads with known lies - explicitly turning the platform into a disinformation-for-profit machine." This move comes after Warren initially criticized Facebook's exemption of politicians' ads from fact-checking. The campaign's action aims to highlight the issue and challenge Facebook's policy.

site_title: ISDN powers up beyond healthcare
summary: ISDN, a Singapore-listed motion control systems specialist, is expanding its business beyond healthcare, driven by the growing demand for high-end medical equipment in Asia and China. The company is collaborating with Chinese medical device makers to supply motion control components at lower prices, targeting the mass market. ISDN is also investing in mini-hydropower plants in Indonesia, with a combined capacity of 24.2 megawatts, and plans to spin off the plants as a separate entity. Despite a 45% drop in net profit in the first half of 2019, ISDN remains bullish on China's long-term prospects and is focusing on opening up new markets and developing its software-related business.

images.alt_text: Managing director Teo Cher Koon says as living standards rise, people want higher-quality healthcare. "We're talking about high-end products like MRI, CT scans and X-ray equipment. And this market has all along been dominated by Siemens, Philips, GE. But China has a big demand, the third world has a big demand, and they can't afford that type of pricing."

site_title: Iras recovers S$175m in GST, penalties in first 9 months of 2019
summary: Iras recovers S$175 million in GST and penalties in the first 9 months of 2019, with 53 GST fraud and evasion cases investigated, 20 charged and 14 convicted. The agency uses data analytics to detect non-compliance and advises firms to register early for GST, warning that those who fail to register may face penalties. A web-based calculator was also published to help businesses determine if they need to register for GST.

site_title: Iras recovers S$175m in GST, penalties in Jan-Sept 2019 period
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) recovered S$175 million in Goods and Services Tax (GST) and penalties from audits of over 2,000 cases between January and September 2019. This includes 53 cases of GST fraud and evasion, with 14 convictions and six cases still being heard in court. Iras highlighted the funeral industry as a sector susceptible to tax offenses due to its cash-based nature and lack of proper record-keeping practices. The tax authority is urging businesses, particularly family-owned ones, to review their past records and voluntarily disclose any errors made to avoid penalties.

site_title: Acting US homeland security chief McAleenan resigns: Trump
summary: US Acting Homeland Security Chief Kevin McAleenan has resigned after serving six months, citing a desire to spend more time with his family and pursue a private sector career. President Trump praised McAleenan's accomplishments, including a reduction in border crossings, and announced plans to appoint a new acting secretary. The move comes as the Trump administration continues to crack down on immigration, with border agents arresting nearly a million undocumented migrants in the last 12 months. McAleenan's departure has been criticized by Democrats, who argue that Trump is weakening the Department of Homeland Security.

site_title: Partial trade deal, quarterly results in spotlight
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to extend its gains this week as a partial trade deal between the US and China boosts investor optimism, despite the agreement not being finalized. However, corporate earnings will also be a key focus, with expectations for a decline in earnings due to the trade war's impact. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's October monetary policy statement and preliminary Q3 GDP data will also be closely watched.

site_title: French police arrest suspected family killer in Scotland
summary: French police arrested Xavier Dupont de Ligonnes, a suspect in the 2009 murder of his wife and children, at Glasgow airport in Scotland following a tip-off. He was previously identified at Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport as he prepared to board a flight to Glasgow. The arrest marks an eight-year-long investigation into the case, which had gone cold.

site_title: GM workers struggle with daily expenses as long strike continues
summary: General Motors workers, who have been on strike since September 16, are struggling to make ends meet with a weekly strike pay of $250, with many facing daily expenses. The strike has halted production at 31 factories and led to thousands of layoffs at auto supply companies. Many workers, including those with less than eight years of seniority, make significantly lower salaries, with temporary employees earning around $33,000 per year. Community support, including credit unions and local businesses, is helping some strikers, but many are forced to make sacrifices, including selling belongings and reducing expenses.

images.alt_text: Betty Johnson, who has worked on General Motors assembly lines in Michigan and Tennessee for more than 34 years, said she knew a strike by the United Auto Workers would mean personal sacrifice.

site_title: Boeing's board separates CEO, chairman roles
summary: Boeing's board has separated the roles of CEO and chairman to allow Dennis Muilenburg to focus on running the company. This move comes as the company works to return its 737 Max jet to service after two fatal crashes. The new chairman, David Calhoun, will oversee a newly established Aerospace Safety Committee, with a new director with deep safety experience to be named in the near term. This decision aims to strengthen Boeing's governance and safety management processes amid its struggles to recover from the crashes.

site_title: Chocolate makers face ultimatum over pay for poor cocoa farmers
summary: Chocolate makers face an ultimatum to support a plan to raise the pay of impoverished cocoa farmers in West Africa, or risk suspending sustainability programs that certify their beans are not grown in protected forests or with child labor. The Ivory Coast and Ghana plan to raise the average price for cocoa to at least $2,600 per ton, with farmers receiving 70% of the revenue after costs. Analysts question whether the plan will work due to companies' inability to hedge the premium and potential overproduction, which could destabilize prices and harm the environment.

site_title: In Mali, love for Italy's vintage scooter is timeless
summary: In Bamako, Mali, a passion for Italy's vintage Vespa scooter remains strong, despite the city's flood of cheap Indonesian-made two-wheelers. Many Vespas, which date back to the 1970s, still cruise the streets, with enthusiasts like Seydou Seck, 60, proudly riding their classic scooters. The Vespa is a symbol of Malian history and a sign of social success, with its manufacturer estimating 19 million scooters sold since 1946. However, classic Vespas are disappearing due to a lack of spare parts, threatening the community's love for the iconic scooter.

site_title: Silver-haired sit-in, face mask party protests planned for Hong Kong
summary: Pro-democracy protests are planned for Hong Kong on Saturday, reflecting widespread anger at the government, with various groups organizing sit-ins, face mask parties, and street marches. The protests, sparked by opposition to a now-abandoned extradition bill, have mushroomed into a pro-democracy movement and a challenge to social inequality. Hong Kong is experiencing its worst crisis since 1997, with relative calm returning after a night of clashes between protesters and police. The protests have plunged the city into recession, with tourism and retail hardest hit, and have raised concerns about China's erosion of Hong Kong's freedoms.

images.alt_text: Several pro-democracy protests are planned for Hong Kong on Saturday reflecting the widespread anger at the government, ranging from an elderly sit-in, a face mask party, a shopping mall demonstration and an anti-emergency law street march.

site_title: US regulators block Telegram from raising funds through cryptocurrency
summary: US securities regulators blocked Telegram from raising funds through cryptocurrency, specifically unregistered digital tokens called "Grams", after the company sold over $1.7 billion to US and overseas investors. Telegram failed to register the tokens as securities and disclose risks to investors, according to the SEC. The regulator obtained an emergency court order to prevent the sale of Grams, which were planned to be delivered to consumers by the end of October and resold on the open market.

site_title: Knives are out with more cooks now in virtual kitchens
summary: A fierce battle is brewing in the world of cloud kitchens, with new and old players vying for margins and network-building opportunities created by the rising popularity of food delivery services. Cloud kitchens, also referred to as dark kitchens, ghost kitchens, or virtual kitchens, are popping up worldwide, with food delivery operators like Deliveroo, foodpanda, and GrabFood expanding their cloud kitchen networks. The growth of cloud kitchens is expected to reach US$20 billion by 2025, but concerns about anti-competitive behavior, experimentation with business models, and over-stretching have been raised.

site_title: US-China partial trade deal: the main points
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a partial trade deal with China after talks with Vice Premier Liu He. Key points include: China to increase US farm purchases to $40-50 billion/year, agreement on financial services, currency transparency, technology transfer, and intellectual property. The deal still needs to be signed, with a possible signing in Chile in mid-November. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that further work is needed before a deal can be finalized.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Friday announced a partial trade deal with China after talks in Washington with Vice Premier Liu He.

site_title: More companies back away from Facebook's Libra coin
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency alliance lost three more companies, Visa, Mastercard, and eBay, amid heavy criticism from regulators. The companies cited regulatory scrutiny and concerns about the planned digital currency. The Libra Association now has 20 founding members, with a new list to be announced on Monday. PayPal had previously quit the alliance. The departures come after US senators warned financial firms of potential regulatory scrutiny, with French finance minister Bruno Le Maire calling Libra a threat to monetary sovereignty.

site_title: US farmers cheered by apparent trade truce, hope shipments to follow
summary: US farmers welcomed a potential trade truce with China, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announcing a possible increase in agricultural sales to China, potentially reaching $40-$50 billion annually. This could more than double the $24 billion in agricultural sales in 2017. However, farmers emphasized the need for actual purchases to follow the announcement, which has been a major source of income for them during the 15-month trade conflict.

site_title: Looking beyond dividend yield when investing in REITs
summary: Investors should consider a Reit's overall return, not just dividend yield, when deciding which to invest in. Factors like income support provided by the Reit sponsor, asset diversification, and long-term stability are crucial. Income support cushions yield by providing short-term boosts, while diversification helps navigate economic cycles. A holistic assessment is necessary to ensure quality Reit investments.

site_title: Oil producers, refiners face surging global freight rates after US sanctions
summary: Oil producers and refiners face surging global freight rates amid a tanker shortage following US sanctions on Chinese giant COSCO. Charter rates for tankers from the US Gulf Coast, UK, and the Arab Gulf to Asia reached fresh highs, with Occidental Petroleum and Royal Dutch Shell paying record prices of $15.8 million and $9.2 million, respectively. The shortage is expected to continue for several months, further increasing costs for oil traders and potentially impacting global oil supplies.

site_title: One killed in Japan as typhoon approaches, over a million advised to evacuate
summary: A powerful typhoon, Hagibis, is set to make landfall in Japan, bringing heavy rain and strong winds. One man died and over a million were advised to evacuate, with four injured in Chiba prefecture. Stores, factories, and subway systems have been shut down, and flights have been cancelled. The typhoon is expected to cause floods and landslides, with storm surges continuing to hit the Pacific coast. This is the heaviest rain and winds in 60 years, a month after a powerful typhoon destroyed or damaged 30,000 houses.

site_title: US outlines 'Phase 1' trade deal with China, suspends October tariff hike
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the first phase of a trade deal with China, covering agriculture, currency, and intellectual property protections. The deal, which includes China agreeing to buy $50 billion in US agricultural products, would represent the biggest step in ending the 15-month trade war. However, officials on both sides said much work remains to be done before a full agreement can be reached, and Trump acknowledged that the deal could fall apart in the coming weeks. The deal's details will be finalized in up to five weeks, with a potential signing at a November summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation countries.

site_title: After mixed messages, US piles pressure on Turkey
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose crippling sanctions on Turkey for its military operation against Kurdish forces in Syria, following mixed messages and policy reversals. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Defence Secretary Mark Esper have also called on Turkey to halt the offensive, warning of "serious consequences." Despite this, Turkish President Recep Tayip Erdogan has dismissed the calls, saying Turkey will not step back. The operation has resulted in over 100,000 civilians fleeing and 54 SDF fighters killed, with the US seeking to curb Turkey's actions.

site_title: Buyers from China bump up Singapore luxury condo sales
summary: Mainland Chinese nationals are driving luxury condo sales in Singapore, with 97 units purchased in the first nine months of the year, accounting for about one-third of foreign buyers. This surge is attributed to the devaluation of the yuan and the perceived stability of the Singapore dollar. In contrast, Hong Kongers bought only eight units, contradicting speculation that Hong Kong turmoil would lead to a shift to Singapore. The increase in luxury home sales has pushed prices up 2.9% in prime and central regions, with 75 units sold for S$10 million or more.

site_title: Sempra nears US$3b Chile sale to China's State Grid: sources
summary: US power company Sempra Energy is near a deal to sell its Chilean business to China's State Grid Corporation of China for around $3 billion. This sale is part of Sempra's efforts to shed non-core assets and bolster its finances amid increased liabilities and pressure from investors. The deal could be announced as early as next week, following Sempra's previous sale of its Peruvian business to a Chinese unit for $3.6 billion. State Grid Corporation of China beat out other bidders, including Italian utility Enel, to secure the Chilean assets.

site_title: Values of Malay/Muslim community key to meeting today's challenges: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of the Malay/Muslim community's values in meeting today's challenges, citing character, competence, and citizenry as key factors. These values have contributed to the community's success, and Mr. Heng highlighted their significance in a speech at the Berita Harian's Anugerah Jauhari 2019 awards ceremony. The event recognized Imam Syed Hassan Mohamed Al-Attas for his contributions to interfaith work, and Mr. Heng called for the community to rally together to address societal issues.

site_title: Designing the future
summary: Autodesk president and CEO Andrew Anagnost emphasizes the importance of collaboration between humans and machines in the future of technology. He believes that the rise of cloud computing and artificial intelligence (AI) will enable the convergence of "design and make" processes, allowing for more efficient and effective design and manufacturing. Anagnost also warns that the advertising model in the tech industry is perverting the industry's purpose, creating data slavery and stifling innovation. He advocates for legislation around data ownership and privacy, and believes that the tech industry has a responsibility to educate governments on the importance of data protection.

site_title: Europe: Shares soar on rising hopes of Brexit, trade deal
summary: European shares surged on Friday, driven by a surprise breakthrough in Brexit negotiations, with the STOXX 600 index rising 2.3%. London-listed companies and the Irish index gained around 4% as UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his Irish counterpart announced a possible deal. The German index jumped 2.9%, while US shares also rose, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. Rising hopes of a US-China trade deal also boosted sentiment, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He concluding talks.

site_title: Power outages, evacuations as Typhoon Hagibis takes aim at Japan
summary: Typhoon Hagibis is forecast to hit Japan's main island of Honshu, bringing record-breaking rains and potentially severe flooding. The storm has already disrupted two Rugby World Cup matches, grounded over 1,600 flights, and forced the cancellation of a Grand Prix event. Non-compulsory evacuation orders have been issued to 600,000 people in eastern Japan, and power outages have affected 11,600 households. The storm is expected to bring "brutal winds and violent seas" and half a meter of rain to the Tokyo area, with potentially record-breaking rainfall.

images.alt_text: Powerful Typhoon Hagibis churned towards Japan on Saturday, heading straight towards the capital with potentially record-breaking rains and sparking evacuation orders, transport disruption and power outages even before making landfall.

site_title: Trump tries turning impeachment scandal into 2020 reelection fuel
summary: President Donald Trump left Washington to rally supporters, trying to turn the impeachment scandal into 2020 reelection fuel. Despite White House attempts to stop witnesses, former Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch testified, claiming she was fired due to "false claims." Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani faces troubles, including a campaign finance violation case, and Trump's previous attorney Michael Cohen was sentenced to prison. Public support for impeachment grows, with 51% of Americans backing Trump's removal from office, according to a Fox News poll.

site_title: Iranian oil tanker hit off Saudi coast, may have been missiles: reports
summary: An Iranian-owned oil tanker, the Sabiti, was struck by missiles in the Red Sea off Saudi Arabia's coast, according to Iranian media reports. The incident occurred approximately 96km from the Saudi port of Jeddah, damaging the ship but allowing it to continue to the Gulf. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on oil tankers and sites in the region since May, likely to increase tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, long-time regional foes fighting a proxy war in Yemen.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher on partial trade deal, Dow +1.2%
summary: US stocks ended higher on Friday with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.2% to 26,816.59, following a partial trade deal between the US and China that included a halt to tariffs scheduled for next week. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the Nasdaq advancing 1.3%. Analysts expressed disappointment that the agreement did not go further, but welcomed the news as "good news." Key sectors, including industrials, materials, and technology, saw significant gains, with Caterpillar and Apple among the top performers.

site_title: Govt to spend over S$1b to spruce up public, private housing estates
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong announced plans to spend over S$1 billion on upgrading public and private housing estates over the next few years. The projects will provide support for industry partners and create job opportunities for consultants and contractors. This move aims to support the industry during the current economic climate.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said the improvement projects will also help support the ministry's industry partners in these uncertain times.

site_title: At summit to mend ties, Modi, Xi see common challenge on 'terror'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi pledged cooperation against "radicalisation" during an informal summit in India, amid a backdrop of historically tense relations. The meeting came after India split Kashmir in two, prompting China's diplomatic backing for Pakistan. The two leaders agreed to work together against "terror" and other common challenges, marking a tentative step towards mending ties between the two Asian giants. The summit's focus on cooperation over Kashmir and security issues suggests a shift in their relations.

site_title: ASL Marine's independent auditor flags 'going concern' doubts
summary: ASL Marine Holdings' independent auditor, Ernst & Young, has raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a net loss of S$145.9 million for the year ended June 30, 2019. The company's current liabilities exceeded current assets by S$20.8 million. This raises doubts about the company's financial stability.

images.alt_text: The auditor, Ernst & Young, said the industry in which the group operates is still weak in terms of volume and margins, with poor demand for various classes of vessels in the chartering fleet.

site_title: Stalled escalators, empty water coolers at UN as budget crunch hits
summary: The United Nations is facing a severe budget crisis, with a $1.4 billion shortfall on its operating budget this year, largely due to late payments from 60 states, including the US, Brazil, and Venezuela. The crisis has led to measures such as stalled escalators, reduced services, and limits on hiring. Secretary General Antonio Guterres warned that the organization risks depleting its liquidity reserves and defaulting on payments. The crisis is the worst in nearly a decade, with the UN's 37,000 employees facing uncertain paychecks.

images.alt_text: Stalled escalators, the heating turned down, even the diplomats' bar closing early at 5pm: already the UN budget crunch, one of the worst in a decade, is making itself felt in a series of measures announced by the world body on Friday.

site_title: Safeguarding your eyes from the 'thief of sight'
summary: Glaucoma, a silent eye disease, affects 80 million people worldwide, with 3.2 million blind due to the condition. It is characterized by elevated eye pressure, loss of field of vision, and nerve damage. Glaucoma can be acute or chronic, with acute attacks potentially leading to irreversible blindness. The disease has various subtypes, including open angle and closed angle, with closed angle glaucoma associated with more severe symptoms. Opportunistic screening and regular monitoring are recommended for early detection and prevention of recurrence, with treatment options including topical eyedrops, laser treatments, and surgical therapies.

site_title: Beware of hidden or opportunity costs
summary: A recent event in Singapore highlighted the financial burden of caregiving for older persons, primarily borne by women. The Association of Women for Action and Research (Aware) analyzed the Labour Force Survey, revealing a 9% increase in women citing family responsibilities as the main reason for being out of the labor force from 2016 to 2018. This decision comes with severe consequences on retirement adequacy and personal savings. The concept of hidden or opportunity costs is relevant, as caregivers sacrifice potentially higher returns by not allocating funds to alternative investments. The event aimed to gather recommendations on how policymakers can help alleviate the financial cost of caregiving.

site_title: Hedging against economic uncertainties
summary: Singapore's private residential property prices have remained resilient despite global economic uncertainties, with the Core Central Region (CCR) experiencing the most significant price increase. The CCR, comprising Districts 9-11, Downtown Core, and Sentosa, saw a 2.9% price increase in Q3 2019, outpacing the 2.3% increase in the previous quarter. Areas earmarked for further growth, such as the Novena medical hub, are expected to see growing demand from medical tourists and medical professionals, potentially driving up prices and yields.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in the Novena medical hub vicinity may see growing demand from medical professionals projected to be employed, for example, at the Integrated Intermediate Care Hub and the extended National Skin Centre Building.

site_title: The plight of the office introvert
summary: Introverts dread office activities like open-plan seating, brainstorming sessions, and team-building exercises, which they view as invasive and stressful. These events can cause anxiety and make them feel like they're being forced to be social. Many introverts fear being the center of attention, leading to feelings of discomfort and dread. The author confesses to fearing the phrase "let's brainstorm" and shares that these workplace tortures can be just as painful as more obvious phrases like "you're fired."

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Chinese banks face challenges from Beijing's consumer lending push, as it may lead to increased competition and potential losses. Meanwhile, Japan's MUFG targets the US securitization market, planning to boost its headcount. The PBOC adviser urges a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services in California and Arizona. FedEx partners with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. US shoemaker remains reliant on China despite 190% tariffs.

site_title: Fast track your fitness by skipping
summary: Skipping is a low-cost, high-intensity exercise that can torch up to 200 calories in 15 minutes, improving agility, coordination, and balance. A heavy jump rope, weighing around 500g, is particularly effective for strengthening shoulders and upper body muscles. Various skipping techniques, such as the "bounce step," "the skier," "knees up," "the cross," and "power jump," target different muscle groups, including abs, glutes, and hamstrings. Regular skipping can also improve cardiovascular fitness and motivation, making it an ideal workout for boxers and athletes.

site_title: Low entry barrier makes EV field too competitive for Dyson
summary: Dyson has abandoned its £2 billion electric car project due to the low entry barrier in the EV field, making it too competitive. With only 11,000 parts needed, compared to 30,000 for combustion engines, the challenge of creating a profitable and competitive electric vehicle proved insurmountable. The move is a significant setback for the British company, which had been seen as a potential disruptor in the market. The decision highlights the difficulties faced by established companies in entering the rapidly growing electric vehicle industry.

site_title: Easier passage to India - via Bangalore - for Singapore startups
summary: Singapore's Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network has expanded into Bangalore, India, providing easier passage for Singapore startups to access the Indian innovation ecosystem. The network, a joint initiative between Enterprise Singapore and the Economic Development Board, aims to drive innovation and partnerships between local and Indian firms. Four memoranda of understanding (MOUs) were signed, including partnerships with Indian platforms Anthill Ventures, The Indus Entrepreneurs Global, and YourStory, to facilitate collaborations and provide a conducive environment for tech startups to thrive. The move is expected to benefit both economies, with India being a significant trading partner of Singapore.

site_title: Twilight of the Tech Heroes
summary: The article "Twilight of the Tech Heroes" suggests that the era of revered tech leaders is ending, as the industry faces scrutiny similar to that faced by the banking sector. Tech giants like Google, Facebook, and WeWork, once celebrated as visionary heroes, are now under fire for their monopolistic practices, data collection, and lack of regulation. The article draws parallels between the tech industry and the banking sector, highlighting the similarities in their business models and the need for increased oversight. As the public's perception of tech companies shifts, the term "Tech Hero" is being retired, and scrutiny of these companies is becoming increasingly necessary.

site_title: Renault ousts CEO in post Ghosn-era reset
summary: Renault's board voted to oust CEO Thierry Bollore, following a strained relationship with Nissan, following Carlos Ghosn's scandal-hit tenure. Bollore, who was promoted to steady Renault, had an uneasy relationship with Nissan and Renault and the French state. He was replaced by finance director Clotilde Delbos on an interim basis, as the company seeks a fresh start. The move comes after tensions between Renault and Nissan over governance reforms and a failed merger deal.

site_title: Currency, stocks perk up on hopes of Brexit deal
summary: The pound soared to 1.25 against the US dollar, its highest level in a month, following Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar's comments that Brexit talks were "positive and constructive". This optimism comes despite diplomats warning of several obstacles to a possible deal. UK and European stock markets also rose, despite recent pessimism. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier welcomed UK Brexit secretary Stephen Barclay, and European Council President Donald Tusk emphasized the need to utilize any chance for a deal before October 31. A deal will require compromises on customs declarations and border controls.

site_title: ESR-Reit nets S$50m in oversubscribed preferential offering
summary: ESR-Reit successfully completed an oversubscribed preferential offering, netting S$50 million in gross proceeds. The company had set out to raise S$40 million, and the offering was fully subscribed. The proceeds include S$4.5 million from the sponsor's acceptance of its alloted units. The success of the offering demonstrates the strong demand for ESR-Reit's shares.

site_title: The master of robots left AQR. Now he's coming for Wall Street
summary: Marcos Lopez de Prado, dubbed the world's top quant, has left AQR Capital Management and is launching his own firm, True Positive Technologies, to address the limitations of machine-learning programs in finance. He warns that most companies spending millions on machine-learning are doing it wrong, with many using the technology without a theory or rationale. Lopez de Prado advocates for a more scientific approach, combining machine learning with theory, to develop core propositions and improve investment strategies. His goal is to make finance more predictable and less reliant on human instinct, ultimately saving investors from costly mistakes.

site_title: Reits (October 12-13, 2019)
summary: US mortgage rates rise after five consecutive weeks of decline, marking a shift in the market. The Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot. Manhattan rents hit a record, with further increases expected. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won worth of hotel and retail assets in Seoul, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal, and WeWork has secured new tenants at its 21 Collyer Quay, Suntec City location.

site_title: There are some things we shouldn't adapt to
summary: Climate change poses a question of balance between adaptation and resistance to change. While adaptation can be necessary, it can also lead to undesirable consequences, such as reconciling with unacceptable changes. This can result in a loss of sense of freedom and a resignation to the status quo. The article argues that adaptation to climate change can be harmful if it involves accepting catastrophic consequences, such as permanent flooding and species extinction. The author suggests that humans and nature may be better off without adapting to climate change, and that the ultimate goal should be to halt and reverse it.

site_title: KL unveils smaller-than-expected 2020 budget
summary: Malaysia's government unveiled a smaller-than-expected 2020 budget with a 6% reduction in spending to RM297.02 billion. The budget projects a 3.2% fiscal deficit, larger than the initial target, and a wider budget deficit than earlier estimates. Despite this, the government forecast economic growth of 4.8% next year, citing a faster-than-expected growth in the first half of 2019 and a potential for stimulus measures to support growth. The government also introduced new incentives for foreign investment and tax exemptions to promote high-value added activities in the electronics industry.

site_title: About 20 people in Singapore affected by Dyson decision
summary: About 20 employees in Singapore will be affected by Dyson's closure of its automotive division, as the company ditches plans to build electric cars in the country. Dyson has committed to finding roles for as many affected employees as possible and has sufficient vacancies to absorb most of the staff into its home appliances business. The company's commitment to Singapore remains strong, with ambitious expansion plans for its research, operations, and commercial teams.

site_title: How to promote and demote employees
summary: A leader should consider the impact of their words when rewarding or demoting employees, as first impressions can be catastrophic. A new employee may view their job offer as an initiation into a hostile work environment, rather than a promising opportunity. To avoid this, leaders should focus on building a positive relationship with their employees, rather than just issuing praise or criticism. This approach can help to create a more supportive and respectful workplace culture.

images.alt_text: Every employee - male and female, young and old, educated and uneducated, bright and dim - is entitled to say "MeToo" for respect and politeness.

site_title: MAS slaps bans on four finance-industry professionals for fraud and dishonest conduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against four finance-industry professionals for fraudulent and dishonest conduct. Three insurance agents and a former bank employee, Edwin Teh Chin Hong, Joseph Michael, Aloysius Zephaniah Lim Bing Hong, and Ng Wei Ling, have been convicted and imprisoned for misappropriating client funds. The MAS has imposed nine-year, eight-year, and five-year prohibition orders against the individuals, barring them from providing financial advisory services and conducting business in the industry. The regulator emphasized that trustworthiness is essential in financial services and will take decisive action to prevent such behavior.

site_title: Global trade optimism dents safe haven appeal
summary: Global trade optimism has led to a decline in safe haven appeal, as investors shift towards interest-bearing assets. Gold prices remain supported due to shaky economic fundamentals and geopolitical uncertainties. Despite facing headwinds, gold is poised to trade positively due to accommodative monetary policies. Market analysts expect a 25bps reduction in US borrowing costs, which could boost gold prices. However, gold prices must break above key resistance levels to resume a bullish trend scenario, currently trading around $1,480.

site_title: China's hidden capital flight soars to record high
summary: China's hidden capital flight surged to a record high of $131 billion in the first half of 2019, according to the Institute of International Finance. This increase, part of "net errors & omissions" in China's balance of payments, suggests residents are using unrecorded transactions to evade capital controls. Despite recorded resident outflows of $74 billion, the true extent of capital flight appears under-reported. This surge in capital flight may weigh on China's outlook, but experts expect relatively balanced net flows in 2020.

site_title: Competition panel investigating online food delivery sector
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has launched an investigation into the online food delivery and virtual kitchens sectors, focusing on exclusive agreements and refusal of service by players to block competition. The investigation follows a complaint from Smart City Kitchens, alleging that Deliveroo and GrabFood disabled existing food delivery services for restaurants using SCK's shared kitchen in Tampines. The CCCS aims to ensure F&B businesses have access to multiple online food delivery services to reach a wider consumer base, and the investigation will examine the use of exclusive agreements and refusal of service by players.

site_title: Record S$96b long-term corporate debt issued in Singapore for 2018
summary: Singapore saw a record S$96 billion in long-term corporate debt issued in 2018, a 7.8% increase from the previous year. The surge was driven by non-SGD denominated securities as Asian issuers sought to raise global capital for regional and global growth.

site_title: How the power suit lost its power
summary: The power suit, once a symbol of power and authority, has lost its luster, becoming a uniform for the powerless. Americans are buying fewer suits, with US revenue declining to $1.9 billion in 2018 from $2.2 billion in 2013. The suit is now associated with job interviews, court appearances, and junior salespeople, rather than high-status workers. This shift has benefited women, who can now dress more freely and assert their individuality in the workplace. While some predict a recession will lead to a resurgence of suits, others argue that the suit's power is fading, and it will eventually become a relic of the past.

site_title: Non-US banks have US$1.4t at risk in the event of a shock: IMF
summary: Non-US banks face a $1.4 trillion funding gap, with 13% of their assets denominated in US dollars, making them vulnerable to a global financial crisis. A repeat of the 2008 crisis could cause markets to seize up, as seen with institutions hoarding dollars and increasing borrowing costs. The IMF recommends governments install buffers, such as larger reserve holdings and central bank swap arrangements, to protect against this situation and amplify shocks to non-US economies. This could include measures to provide access to US dollars during periods of stress.

site_title: Auditor flags lapses over Pacific Star's sale of 17 units at Puteri Cove Residences
summary: An internal auditor at RSM Risk Advisory has flagged lapses in Pacific Star's sale of 17 units at Puteri Cove Residences, including unverified loan applications and lack of delegation of authority. The units were included in the company's financial statements despite risks of non-fulfillment by buyers, resulting in a combined revenue decrease of about S$7.2 million and a deeper total comprehensive loss of about S$3 million. The auditor has made recommendations for Pacific Star to review and update its policies, implement new procedures, and ensure formal due diligence on sales recognized.

site_title: Singapore stocks rally 0.8% on Friday on trade optimism
summary: Singapore stocks rallied 0.8% on Friday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks, which lifted risk appetite. The Straits Times Index jumped 0.79% to end the week at 3,113.97, with gains more than making up for earlier losses. Gainers outnumbered losers 273 to 122, led by stocks like United Overseas Bank and Venture Corporation. However, economists warned that the developments may offer only interim relief, as tensions between the US and China continue to widen.

site_title: MOM keeps eye on companies at risk of salary defaults
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has launched a new enforcement strategy to tackle employment issues, including salary defaults. Employers at risk of defaulting on salaries will be required to report to MOM and may face penalties if they make false declarations. The strategy includes physical inspections, corrective clinics, and increased weight given to workers' claims. The number of salary claims decreased from 2.49 per 1,000 employees in 2017 to 2.42 per 1,000 employees in 2018, with 85% of claims settled within two months and 88% fully recovered.

images.alt_text: Employers who are seen to be at higher risk of defaulting on salaries will have to tell the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) whether they have been paying salaries on time.

site_title: Uber to buy Chile's Cornershop
summary: Uber is acquiring a majority stake in Chile's Cornershop, an online grocery provider operating in Mexico, Chile, Canada, and Peru. The deal will allow Cornershop to expand its delivery service into the global market. Cornershop CEO Oskar Hjertonsson stated that the acquisition will enable the company to deliver groceries in "many more countries around the world." The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: AVIC International unit bags 7.5m-euro contract for ferry project
summary: AVIC International's unit Deltamarin secured a 7.5 million-euro contract from Finnish firm Rauma Marine Constructions to provide services for an LNG-powered shuttle ferry. The contract, worth S$11.4 million, will be completed in 16-18 months. The earnings from this contract are expected to have a minimal financial impact on AVIC's current year earnings.

site_title: Wall St opens higher on trade war de-escalation bets
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by expectations of a partial trade deal between the US and China, which could delay planned tariff increases. The Dow Jones rose 0.75%, the S&P 500 gained 0.85%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.21%. Investors are optimistic about the trade talks, despite recent Trump threats to extend tariffs.

site_title: SGX queries Pine Capital on appointment of HK-based directors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Pine Capital on the appointment of two Hong Kong-based directors, David Sarkis and Chan Wai Leung, amid concerns about their plans for the company. The directors were appointed to address a board composition issue, with Sarkis initially appointed as a non-executive director and redesignated as an executive director, and Chan appointed as an independent director. Pine Capital cited Sarkis' increased involvement in his business and plans to restructure the company, reconstitute the board, and raise capital. The SGX has raised questions about the directors' backgrounds, including their involvement in other businesses and their compliance with listing rules.

site_title: To make a few more dollars, global funds take on FX risk
summary: Global bond investors are taking on more currency risk by buying dollar-denoted debt without hedging, seeking higher yields in the face of sub-zero yields at home. Funds with minimal credit risk can earn up to 1.6% on 10-year US Treasuries, but hedging costs can reduce this to a 0.3% loss. This trend is driven by a decline in hedging appetite, partly due to the US dollar's resilience and the flattening of the yield curve. Japanese investors, in particular, have increased their unhedged foreign bond holdings, and experts warn that this strategy can be reckless due to the extreme levels of dollar positioning and low-volatility backdrop.

site_title: Thai army chief decries opposition, hints at threat to monarchy
summary: Thailand's army chief, General Apirat Kongsompong, criticized opposition figures, including Future Forward Party leader Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, as threats to national security and the monarchy. The criticism came after the opposition party held a seminar discussing constitutional amendments, prompting the military to file a sedition case. The army chief portrayed the military as loyal to the nation and the royal family, warning of the dangers of "propaganda" and attempts to overthrow the monarchy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GKE Corp posted a Q1 net profit of S$254,000, reversing a year-ago loss, with revenue rising 33.7% to S$25.4 million. Libra Group received US$18.8 million in letters of demand from UOB for outstanding banking facilities and unpaid guarantees. Hatten Land secured a time extension until April 10, 2020 to repay a US$20 million loan. Pine Capital faced queries from the Singapore Exchange over the addition of two Hong Kong-based directors.

site_title: Ethiopian PM Abiy Ahmed sees meteoric rise to Nobel Peace Prize
summary: Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to reform the country's economy and heal wounds with neighboring nations. Since becoming prime minister in 2018, Abiy has made significant progress, including making peace with Eritrea, releasing dissidents, and welcoming home exiled armed groups. Despite challenges, analysts predict Abiy's personal ambition will drive him to continue pushing for reforms, but he faces daunting tasks, including holding credible elections by May and addressing security challenges, including ethnic violence and recent assassination attempts.

site_title: Swee Hong appoints Tian Yuan as new executive director
summary: Swee Hong appoints Tian Yuan as its new executive director, replacing Anil Dhanpatlal who resigned on October 7. Tian Yuan, a former CEO of CGC Group, brings experience overseeing projects in South-east Asia. The appointment comes amid trading suspension of Swee Hong shares, which closed at S$0.003 in May.

site_title: ST Engineering's marine arm sells vessel to Polish ferry operator
summary: ST Engineering's marine arm has sold a Roll-on/Roll-off Passenger Vessel (ROPAX) called MV Nova Star to Polish ferry operator Polferries. The vessel, designed and built by ST Engineering, was on a bareboat charter since September 2018. Polferries exercised a purchase option, effective immediately, to acquire the 1,215-passenger vessel. The vessel features passenger lounges, cabins, restaurants, and bars, and is designed for trailer and car carriage.

site_title: Libra Group receives letter of demand from UOB for US$18.8m
summary: Libra Group, a distressed company, received a letter of demand from UOB (United Overseas Bank) for US$18.8 million due by October 11, 2019. The demand was triggered by events of default, with Kin Xin Engineering, a unit of Libra, also receiving a similar demand. The company must repay the sum by the deadline.

site_title: HMV boss seeks rebirth of UK record store giant
summary: HMV's new CEO, Doug Putman, aims to revive the struggling UK record store giant by embracing demand for vinyl records and K-Pop, capitalizing on changing musical tastes. Despite previous bankruptcies in 2013 and 2018, Putman believes the company can overcome tough times by listening to customers and offering unique products. With 114 stores now open, HMV is seeking to differentiate itself from online retailers like Amazon and tap into nostalgic demand for vinyl records and K-Pop music.

images.alt_text: The new boss of long-troubled British music retailer HMV told AFP it can overcome "tough times" on the high street - with help from keen demand for vinyl records and K-Pop.

site_title: 'Tidal wave' of assets heading for fund management industry, says JPMorgan AM chief
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management's CEO George Gatch predicts a "tidal wave" of assets will pour into the fund management industry over the next five years, driven by increasing focus on retirement savings, sustainable investing, and technology. This shift will reverse the current tailwind, as rising markets will eventually turn into headwinds during a recession. Gatch warns that differentiation between winners and losers will become crucial, with those who adapt to the changing market landscape being the most successful.

site_title: US consumer sentiment unexpectedly rises to 3 month high
summary: US consumer sentiment unexpectedly rose to a three-month high of 96 in October, surpassing economists' expectations. The University of Michigan's preliminary sentiment index improved, driven by rising income expectations and lower inflation expectations. This boost could support a third straight interest-rate cut later this month. Despite concerns about the economy, consumers remain optimistic, with inflation-adjusted income expectations at a 20-year high and buying plans boosted. The data suggests the US economy will continue to expand into 2020, offsetting weakness in business investment spending.

site_title: Hundreds take to Hong Kong streets ahead of weekend protests
summary: Hundreds of pro-democracy protesters marched through Hong Kong's central business district, occupying major thoroughfares and disrupting traffic, ahead of another weekend of unrest. The protesters, wearing masks, chanted their core demands, including universal suffrage and an independent inquiry into police brutality. The protests have plunged the city into its worst crisis since its return to Chinese rule in 1997, with over 2,300 arrests since June and a deteriorating mental health score. Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam invoked British colonial-era emergency laws and banned face masks, further escalating tensions and divisions.

site_title: China denounces Thai politicians for show of support to Hong Kong activists
summary: China has condemned Thai politicians for showing support to Hong Kong activists, calling it "wrong and irresponsible" and potentially harming relations between the two countries. Thai politicians, including opposition leader Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, have met with Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong, sparking criticism from the Chinese embassy. China denies that Hong Kong's freedoms are being eroded and accuses Western countries of stoking anti-China sentiment. Thailand's army chief has also criticized Thanathorn's meeting with Wong, calling it "hidden agenda-driven."

site_title: Singapore PE fund locks in financing tied to sustainability in world-first for private capital
summary: Quadria Capital, a Singapore-based private equity fund, has secured a $65 million, 3-year revolving facility from ING, the first in the world to tie financing to sustainability improvements. The facility's interest rate will be pegged to Quadria's ESG performance targets, linked to metrics from B Analytics and the United Nations' Principles for Responsible Investment. This comes as private capital increasingly focuses on ESG, with ING aiming to promote socially responsible behavior in its financed funds.

images.alt_text: A singapore-based private equity (PE) fund has become the first in the world to secure financing for PEs that is tied to sustainability improvement, reflecting the rising interest from the financing sector in factoring in environmental, social and governance (ESG) in private capital.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei jumps more than 1% on hope for US-China talks
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 1.15% to close at 21,798.87, driven by growing hopes for progress in a planned US-China trade meeting. The broader Topix index also increased 0.88%. This follows a trend of Asian markets rallying despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Aviation experts blast FAA over 737 MAX redesign approval
summary: Aviation experts criticized the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for allowing design changes to Boeing's 737 MAX aircraft that contributed to two fatal crashes, resulting in over 300 deaths. A Joint Authorities Technical Review (JATR) panel found the FAA failed to follow its own rules, lacked manpower, and had inadequate awareness of the flight handling system implicated in the crashes. The FAA and Boeing were accused of deferring to the company's pressure to approve updated designs without independent testing. The FAA welcomed the scrutiny, vowing to strengthen aviation safety.

site_title: Former high-flyer tycoon brothers arrested in India
summary: Tycoon brothers Shivinder and Malvinder Singh were arrested in India, accused of siphoning off $337 million from the Religare financial group, a company they built up. The brothers, who lost a fortune worth billions over the past decade, are also wrangling with each other over the lost money. They were detained separately and charged along with three other top executives, who allegedly put the group in a "poor financial condition" by disbursing loans to unprofitable companies. The investigation could speed the fall of the Singh family's business empire.

site_title: Renault ousts CEO in post Ghosn-era reset
summary: Renault's board voted to oust CEO Thierry Bollore, citing strained relations with Nissan following the Ghosn scandal. Bollore, who had been Ghosn's right-hand man, had an uneasy relationship with Nissan and was seen as a irritant to the alliance.
