Finance director Clotilde Delbos will take over as interim CEO, and Renault shares rose 4.2% after the announcement. The move aims to repair ties with Nissan and the French state, Renault's key shareholder, and follows a failed deal to pair Renault with Fiat Chrysler.

site_title: US-China talks resume as hopes for mini-deal rise
summary: US-China trade talks resumed on Friday with optimism growing for an interim agreement, potentially pausing the damaging trade war. Investors expect a partial pact, which could see President Trump postpone tariff increases on Chinese imports. China has agreed to increase US farm exports and refrain from currency manipulation, while Washington will suspend a tariff increase. However, China has balked at Trump's demands for profound changes in Beijing's economy, which could undermine the Communist Party. The outcome remains uncertain, with the Trump administration exploring ways to exert more pressure on Beijing beyond tariffs.

site_title: Malaysia presents smaller budget for 2020, widens fiscal deficit target
summary: Malaysia's government has presented a smaller budget for 2020, with a forecasted economic growth of 4.8% and a widened fiscal deficit target of 3.2% of GDP. The budget aims to spur growth and attract foreign investment amid the US-China trade war, with incentives for the electrical and electronics industry and special investments of up to 1 billion ringgit. The government also plans to expand development spending and set aside additional funds for infrastructure projects.

site_title: EU members give go-ahead for more intense Brexit talks
summary: EU member states have given Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier the green light to intensify talks with Britain over a potential Brexit deal, with the goal of avoiding a "no-deal" Brexit in three weeks. The talks will focus on a withdrawal agreement that addresses the Irish border issue, protects the single market, and safeguards the Good Friday Agreement. The EU's position remains unchanged, with a legally operative solution needed before the October 17 European Union summit and the October 31 Brexit deadline. The outcome of the talks is still uncertain, with no clear timeline for a draft text.

site_title: Record S$96b in long-term corporate debt issued in S'pore for 2018: MAS
summary: Singapore's corporate debt market saw a record S$96 billion in long-term corporate debt issued in 2018, a 7.8% increase from the previous year. This growth was driven by non-SGD denominated long-term corporate debt securities. Total corporate debt issued fell 9% to S$236 billion, mainly due to a decline in non-SGD short-term debt issuances. MAS identified green, social, and sustainability bonds as a growth area, with these instruments helping channel capital towards sustainable investments, aiming to support Asia's low-carbon and climate-resilient model.

site_title: AHTC case: WP leaders put political interests above town council and residents, says judge
summary: A High Court judge in Singapore has ruled that Workers' Party (WP) leaders Mr Low Thia Khiang and Ms Sylvia Lim prioritized their own political interests over the Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) and residents in handling the appointment of a managing agent in 2011. The judge described their actions as "in-excusable" and "egregious," finding that they misled the public and town councillors about the reasons for waiving a tender. The ruling also found that WP secretary-general Mr Pritam Singh breached his duty of care by not questioning the waiver.

site_title: GKE posts Q1 net profit of S$254,000 on concrete plant contributions
summary: GKE Corp reported a net profit of S$254,000 for Q1 ended August, reversing a S$302,000 loss a year ago. Revenue rose 33.7% to S$25.4 million due to contributions from its concrete manufacturing plant and logistics segment. However, cost of sales increased 39.1% to S$21 million, leading to a decline in gross margin to 17.2%. The company generated S$1.1 million in net operating cash flows and has S$16.5 million in cash and S$74.1 million in debt. GKE is cautious about global trade tensions and will manage operating costs.

site_title: MAS slaps 5- to 9-year bans on 3 ex-insurance agents, 1 ex-banker for fraud
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against four former financial professionals for fraudulent conduct. Edwin Teh Chin Hong and Joseph Michael were banned for 9 and 5 years respectively for misappropriating client funds. Aloysius Zephaniah Lim Bing Hong was banned for 8 years for cheating clients, while Ng Wei Ling, a former UOB employee, was banned for 9 years for misappropriating S$215,000 from seven clients. The MAS stated that the individuals abused the trust of their customers and will not tolerate such behavior in the industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network expanded to India, allowing Singapore startups to access the country's tech ecosystem. A Singapore-based private equity fund, Quadria Capital, became the world's first to secure a sustainability improvement fund financing. Retail sales in Singapore fell for the 7th straight month in August, with a 1.3% drop from July. The Manpower Ministry introduced stricter measures to prevent salary default by employers. CapitaLand priced S$500m perpetual notes at 3.65%. Internationally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.97 points to 1,556.84 on Friday, driven by a 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 542 to 305.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks rally more than 2% on trade hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 2% on October 11, 2019, due to optimism over China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.34% to 26,308.44, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. Energy firms were boosted by a spike in oil prices following a double explosion in an Iranian tanker in the Gulf.

site_title: Competition watchdog investigates online food delivery sector, virtual kitchens
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has launched investigations into online food delivery and virtual kitchens, focusing on exclusive agreements and refusal of service that block competition. The investigation follows a complaint by Smart City Kitchens, which alleged that Deliveroo and GrabFood disabled existing services and halted new services for restaurants using its kitchen. Virtual kitchens, also known as cloud kitchens, allow F&B businesses to prepare food for consumers ordering through online delivery services, but CCCS says these facilities should not restrict access to multiple delivery services for businesses.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: MARINE services company Atlantic Navigation has requested a trade halt at 1:21pm pending an announcement, with its shares down 44.9% to S$0.043. The halt comes after the company's publicly held shares rose to 10.05% in July. Atlantic Navigation had previously suspended trading in December 2018 due to a share subscription deal. The company's shares had resumed trading on July 5.

site_title: Oil jumps above US$60 as Iran tanker attack reignites Mideast risk
summary: Oil prices surged above US$60 a barrel after a reported missile strike on an Iranian tanker near Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, rekindling fears of military escalation in the Middle East. The attack, which may have originated from Saudi Arabia, follows earlier incidents targeting ships and drones in the region. Brent futures rose 2.3% and West Texas Intermediate jumped 2.2%, with prices up 3.2% and 3.1% this week, respectively, amidst concerns over potential conflict and the ongoing US-China trade dispute.

site_title: European stock markets diverge at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% and the eurozone's DAX 30 up 0.9%. In contrast, Paris' CAC 40 rose 0.3%. The mixed performance follows US trade talks and tariff uncertainty, while also being influenced by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: HSBC hires ex-StanChart banker David Koh for key role in Singapore
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed David Koh as head of global liquidity and cash management, effective October 14. Koh joins from Standard Chartered, bringing over 25 years of experience in transaction banking across seven geographies. The appointment is part of HSBC's strategic plan to support corporate clients in South-east Asia's growing economy. Koh's role will focus on driving cross-border payment and liquidity solutions in the region.

images.alt_text: HSBC Singapore on Friday announced the appointment of David Koh as the country's head of global liquidity and cash management (GLCM), effective from Oct 14.

site_title: MOM tracking companies at risk of salary default; salary claims dipped in 2018
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry has introduced new enforcement strategies to combat salary default by employers. Employers deemed at higher risk of defaulting on salaries must declare their payment status to the ministry. Failure to do so can result in punishment. The ministry has also increased weight on workers' evidence in disputes and introduced corrective clinics for minor offences. The number of salary arrears claims has decreased, with 85% of claims resolved within two months and 88% of employees fully recovered their salaries.

site_title: Ethiopian PM Abiy Ahmed wins 2019 Nobel Peace Prize
summary: Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed won the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize for his peacemaking efforts with Eritrea, ending a 20-year border war. The prize was awarded on October 11, 2019, for his decisive initiative to resolve the conflict, which restored relations between Ethiopia and Eritrea in July 2018. Abiy, 43, is the youngest head of government in Africa, and his reforms have raised hopes for a prosperous nation, but he faces challenges, including resistance to change and high expectations from young Ethiopians.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI says AEM will outperform amid semiconductor slowdown
summary: KGI Securities predicts AEM Holdings will outperform in the semiconductor industry amid a slowdown due to overcapacity in memory markets. The company's key customer, Intel, is expected to continue spending to stay competitive, accounting for 80% of AEM's sales. AEM claims to be Intel's sole supplier of test handlers, providing a competitive edge. The analyst notes that macro headwinds and slowing sales are affecting most semiconductor players, but AEM's unique position sets it apart.

site_title: Australian shares jump on trade optimism; post best weekly gain since August
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to their best weekly gain since August, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. US President Donald Trump described talks as "very, very good" and a White House official said they had gone "better than expected." Financial stocks, commodities, and mining companies led the gains, with Fortescue Metals Group and BHP Group rising 4.1% and 2.1%, respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,606.8.

site_title: Singapore startups get access to India tech ecosystem with Global Innovation Alliance
summary: Singapore's technology startups now have access to India's innovation ecosystem through the Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network, expanding to Bangalore. The initiative aims to drive innovation and growth for both economies, with Minister-in-charge S Iswaran stating it will pave the way for partnerships and boost startup ecosystems.

site_title: China's hidden capital flight surges to record high in 2019
summary: China's hidden capital flight surged to a record high of US$131 billion in the first half of 2019, according to the Institute of International Finance. This is a significant increase from the average US$80 billion in 2015 and 2016. Despite recorded resident outflows of US$74 billion being the smallest in 10 years, the true extent of capital flight appears to be underreported. This trend is attributed to residents using unrecorded transactions to evade capital controls.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air set to list shares
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air is set to launch an initial public offering (IPO), which could raise up to $1.0 billion, making it one of the country's biggest-ever share sales. The airline, which has faced recent challenges including a customer data leak and a 2018 crash that killed 189 people, plans to use the funds to strengthen its financial structure. The IPO is Lion Air's third attempt at going public, following previous postponements.

site_title: China's CNOOC looks to replace Cosco-linked LNG tankers after US sanctions: sources
summary: China's state-owned oil company CNOOC is searching for liquefied natural gas (LNG) tankers to replace those linked to sanctioned Chinese firm Cosco Shipping Tanker. The move comes after US sanctions imposed on Cosco in September, which has driven up global crude oil tanker freight rates. CNOOC is seeking to secure ships to meet peak winter demand, causing rates for LNG tankers to nearly double to $130,000-$150,000 per day. The company has already chartered at least two tankers and is facing limited availability amid rising demand.

site_title: South Korean stocks end firmer as investors cheer signs of trade progress
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.81% on Friday, driven by hopes of a US-China trade agreement after US President Donald Trump said he would meet with China's top trade negotiator. The KOSPI index gained 16.39 points, or 0.81%, to 2,044.54, with foreigners buying US$51.42 million worth of shares. This week, the KOSPI gained 1.18% and has climbed 0.17% so far this year.

site_title: Hatten Land gains time extension to repay US$20m loan
summary: CATALIST-LISTED Hatten Land has secured a time extension until April 10, 2020, to repay a US$20 million loan that matured on Thursday. The creditor, Haitong International Financial Products (Singapore), agreed to the extension after negotiations. The terms will be finalized within a month, with a partial US$2.5 million payment due by January 10, 2020. The loan agreement was signed in 2017, and the extended loan will not have an equity conversion option.

site_title: Singapore stocks rally 0.8% on Friday amid Sino-US trade optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.79% on Friday, ending the week at 3,113.97, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The gains more than offset earlier losses, with 273 gainers outnumbering 122 losers. US President Donald Trump's comments on progress in talks lifted risk appetite, despite economists warning that a trade deal may only offer interim relief. Local lenders UOB and Venture Corp led gains, with UOB rising 1.69% and Venture Corp adding 1.38%.

site_title: How blacklisting companies became a trade war weapon
summary: US President Donald Trump has placed dozens of Chinese companies on the US Commerce Department's "entity list," restricting their ability to purchase US software and components. China is retaliating by compiling its own blacklist of foreign companies, and Japan and South Korea have also used targeted trade restrictions in their long-standing feud. The US list includes tech giants Huawei, Hikvision, and Megvii, while China's blacklist targets US companies. This escalation marks a new front in the trade war, with both sides using blacklists as a tool to gain leverage and protect national interests.

site_title: Renault board meets to turn page on Ghosn era
summary: The Renault board met to replace Thierry Bollore, who is set to step down, following the era of disgraced former CEO Carlos Ghosn. Bollore is expected to either resign or be fired, with Renault yet to begin searching for his replacement. The company will appoint an interim CEO in the meantime. This move aims to move Renault forward and distance itself from the Ghosn era.

images.alt_text: Mr Bollore (L) took over as Renault CEO in January, leading the company alongside new chairman Jean-Dominique Senard (R), with whom he has a strained relationship.

site_title: Auditor's independent review flags lapses in Pacific Star's operations, deals
summary: An independent review by RSM Risk Advisory has identified six lapses and deficiencies in Pacific Star's internal controls and sales procedures, resulting in a combined revenue decrease of S$7.2 million and a deeper combined total comprehensive loss of S$3 million for its fiscal 2019 second and third quarter. The review highlighted issues such as inadequate criteria for assessing potential buyers, lack of delegation of authority for deposit refunds, and no timeline for lenders to follow up with buyers regarding bank loan applications. Pacific Star has agreed to review and update its policies, implement new procedures, and ensure direct oversight of its finance function.

site_title: Artificial meat is now made in space, coming to a supermarket near you
summary: Artificial meat made from cells has been successfully produced in space, with a Russian cosmonaut creating beef, rabbit, and fish tissue using a 3D printer. The technology, developed by Israeli startup Aleph Farms, aims to provide a sustainable alternative to traditional factory farming. Although the products are not yet available for sale, industry players predict small-scale commercialization could occur this year, with estimates suggesting it could take 5-20 years for lab-grown meat to reach supermarket shelves at reasonable prices. Regulatory frameworks and investment are seen as major obstacles to the industry's growth.

site_title: SAP makes surprise leadership change as CEO McDermott steps down
summary: SAP has made a surprise leadership change, with CEO Bill McDermott stepping down after 10 years in the role. He will remain at the company in an advisory role until the end of the year. McDermott's successors, Jennifer Morgan and Christian Klein, will become co-CEOs effective immediately. Morgan, 48, joined SAP in 2004 and was president of the cloud business group, while Klein, 39, has been COO since 2016 and joined the executive board in 2018. The decision was made after McDermott stated he had achieved his goals and wanted to give his successors a chance to lead the company.

site_title: Indonesian police ramp up suspect search after IS-linked attack
summary: Indonesian police are searching for more suspects after two militants from an Islamic State-linked terror group, Jamaah Ansharut Daulah (JAD), stabbed Chief Security Minister Wiranto, leaving him in intensive care after emergency surgery. The attack, which also injured three others, is believed to be the first known assassination attempt by JAD on an Indonesian politician. Authorities have arrested a 31-year-old man and a 21-year-old woman, reportedly a married couple, who were linked to the extremist organization. The incident comes ahead of President Joko Widodo's second term, raising concerns about security.

site_title: SIA, Scoot flights affected as super typhoon draws near Japan
summary: Singapore Airlines and Scoot have adjusted flights due to super typhoon Hagibis expected to hit Japan on Saturday. At least 10 flights between Singapore and Japan have been retimed, with two flights cancelled between Singapore and Taipei on Sunday. Passengers on the cancelled flights will be reallocated to later flights. Airlines are preparing for the typhoon, which is expected to bring severe weather conditions.

site_title: Singapore retail sales fall for 7th straight month in August
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell for the seventh consecutive month in August, with a 4.1% decline compared to August 2018, and a 1.3% month-on-month drop from July. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales still registered a 1% year-on-year drop. The decline was attributed to poor motor vehicle sales and sustained cautious consumer behaviour due to economic slowdown and global growth concerns. Experts predict a 2.2% year-on-year contraction for retail sales in 2019, potentially marking the second consecutive year of decline.

images.alt_text: Singapore's retail sales have fallen for the seventh consecutive month in August, compared to a year ago, on the back of poor motor vehicle sales.

site_title: US sanctions hit global oil fleet as traders shun nearly 300 tankers
summary: Nearly 300 oil tankers, around 3% of the global fleet, have been removed from the market due to US sanctions against Iran and Venezuela, driving up freight rates to new highs. Companies such as Unipec, Trafigura, and Equinor are shunning tankers that have carried Venezuelan oil, while COSCO Shipping Tanker's 43 tankers are also being avoided due to US sanctions. This has led to a surge in VLCC freight rates, with rates for key routes to Asia reaching new highs, and is expected to further exacerbate tightness in the tanker market.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,112.05, up 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,112.05, up 0.7% on the day, driven by renewed optimism over US-China trade talks. The Straits Times Index rose 0.73% or 22.57 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 195 to 122, with Spackman and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding among the top gainers. Analysts attributed the market's resilience to the positive commentaries from the US-China trade talks, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore-based PE gets world's first fund financing based on sustainability performance: ING
summary: ING has introduced the world's first sustainability improvement fund financing for Singapore-based private equity fund Quadria Capital, with a $65 million three-year revolving facility. The facility's interest rate is pegged to Quadria's sustainability performance, with targets set by B Analytics and mapped to ING's internal ESG frameworks. This reflects the growing interest in factoring environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics into capital-raising activities. The move aims to incentivize Quadria's investments in the healthcare sector in developing Asia to improve sustainability.

site_title: Three dead in China bridge collapse
summary: Three people were killed and two injured in eastern China when a highway overpass collapsed and crushed cars below it on Thursday night. Videos showed the bridge swaying before falling, narrowly missing a small three-wheel car whose driver escaped. The incident occurred in Jiangsu province and is under investigation.

site_title: Daily securities turnover dips 3% in September; 3 Reits join indices: SGX
summary: Singapore's daily securities turnover declined 3% in September to S$940 million, down from S$1.2 billion in August. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% for the month, driven by utilities, banks, and real estate sectors. Three Reits joined indices in September, contributing to trading turnover. Iron ore derivatives volume surged 98% year-over-year, while commodity prices remained volatile. The benchmark derivatives for iron ore rose 98% year-over-year to 5.85 million contracts.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a slight dip in trading volume in September compared with August, amid mixed investor sentiment related to the ongoing US-China trade war, according to SGX's latest market report.

site_title: WeWork founder Adam Neumann dropped from Forbes' billionaire list
summary: Forbes has revised its estimate of WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann's net worth from $4.1 billion to $600 million, a decline of over $3 billion, due to skepticism about the company's future. This significant drop in wealth comes after earlier this year Neumann was listed as one of the richest people. The revised estimate is still substantial but marks a substantial decrease in Neumann's net worth.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares rise on hopes of partial Sino-US trade deal
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Friday as hopes for a partial Sino-US trade deal boosted investor confidence. US President Donald Trump described negotiations as "very, very good," while China expressed willingness to avoid further escalation. The ASX 200 index rose to 6,594.60, with resource stocks leading the gains, particularly mining heavyweights BHP Group and Rio Tinto. Markets await quarterly production reports from major Australian miners next week.

site_title: WeWork bailout deal may emerge soon as next week, FT says
summary: WeWork may receive a bailout package as early as next week, led by JPMorgan Chase & Co, according to the Financial Times. The US investment bank is reportedly discussing a rescue package with WeWork, which needs fresh capital by the end of November after its failed IPO attempt. WeWork's co-CEOs are weighing staff cuts and divestitures due to the company's expected cash shortfall. The bailout deal could provide a large sum of money, but the details are still being discussed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.91 points to 1,550.96 at 9am on Friday. The market saw 42.9 million lots traded worth RM14.4 million, with 93 gainers and 33 losers.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on trade optimism
summary: US stocks gained on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.6% each, amid hopes for progress in the US-China trade dispute. President Donald Trump announced a planned meeting with China's top trade envoy, Vice Premier Liu He, boosting market sentiment. The rally followed conflicting signals from Washington and Beijing, with stocks tumbling earlier in the week after new restrictions on Chinese companies were announced. The meeting aims to resolve a trade war that has been ongoing for over a year, ahead of new tariffs scheduled to take effect next week.

site_title: Tesla cars come when called, but can fray nerves
summary: A Tesla owner in California used the company's "Smart Summon" feature, which allows vehicles to be summoned remotely, but experienced a frightening incident when the car nearly collided with another vehicle. The owner, Roddie Hasan, credits the car's autopilot capabilities for stopping the vehicle, but expressed concerns about the feature's safety. Tesla has reported over 550,000 uses of the feature since its release, but critics argue that it's not ready for widespread use.

site_title: Malaysia's rubber gloves producers facing labour crunch
summary: Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers face a severe labour shortage, prompting the industry association to cut its output target by 3.6% to 188 billion pieces due to a lack of workers. The country's manpower issues, triggered by the election of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, have affected various sectors, including palm plantations and construction. The industry requires at least 25,000 foreign workers to replace those who have left and manage expanded capacities, with a shortage expected if Malaysia supplies less than 20% of global demand.

site_title: UK proposes 'pared-down' free trade agreement to end Brexit stalemate: Sky news
summary: The UK is proposing a "pared-down" free trade agreement to end the Brexit stalemate by the end of October, according to Sky News. The offer, pitched by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, focuses on a more limited free trade agreement, which was discussed with Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.08% to 25,986.82, driven by growing optimism over China-US trade talks. US President Donald Trump hailed progress in talks, boosting investor confidence. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, adding to the rally. The gains come despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split views on US Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: Hong Kong's MTR, legislature open but more protests planned for weekend
summary: Hong Kong's metro system reopened on Friday after a week, while the city's legislature began its first session since protesters stormed the building in July. Protests are planned for the weekend, with tensions heightened by a session marred by shouting between lawmakers and the wearing of black masks. The protests, which began four months ago, have been often violent, raising concerns about police brutality and the government's ability to address the crisis. The legislature's session was marked by a divide between pro-establishment and democratic lawmakers.

site_title: Thai central bank says country not in recession, plans steps to curb strong baht
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) has stated that Thailand is not in recession, but its economy is growing below potential. The central bank plans to relax rules on capital outflows and allow Thai investors to invest more abroad, while also reducing the country's large current account surplus. The baht's strength, driven by a hefty current account surplus, has affected exporters and tourism, but the BOT will monitor the currency to prevent it from rising too fast. The BOT left its policy rate unchanged at 1.50% last month and will review monetary policy on November 6.

site_title: Indonesia finds one-fifth of palm oil plantations are illegal
summary: Indonesia's government has found that approximately 19% of its palm oil plantations, or 3.1 million hectares, are operating without permits in forest areas. An investigation by the state auditor found 81% of plantations broke state regulations, including operating in conservation and peatland areas. The government is seeking to identify the owners of the unlicensed plantations and formulate regulations to rescind permits for unplanted concessions. This move aims to address climate change by turning land with good tree coverage into forest areas.

site_title: Giuliani associates charged with illegally funneling cash to pro-Trump group
summary: Two foreign-born businessmen, Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, were arrested for conspiring to funnel millions of dollars in foreign money to US political candidates, including President Donald Trump's re-election campaign. They were charged with conspiracy, false statements, and falsification of business records. Parnas and Fruman allegedly made at least $1 million in contributions from a Russian businessman to candidates in various states, and also donated $325,000 to a pro-Trump PAC. The indictment is part of a broader investigation into Trump's dealings with Ukraine and his personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani.

site_title: CapitaLand prices S$500m perpetual notes at 3.65%
summary: CapitaLand priced a S$500 million perpetual note at 3.65% on Thursday, exceeding initial guidance of 3.85%. The non-callable five-year issue, sold to over 65 accounts, received S$900 million in orders. The proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, financing investments, and general corporate purposes. The interest rate will reset in the fifth year based on the prevailing five-year swap offer rate plus an initial spread of 2.2%, with a step-up margin of 1% from year 10.

images.alt_text: Capitaland has priced a new S$500 million fixed rate perpetual issue at 3.65 per cent.

site_title: Beijing to ask US to end sanctions on Cosco Shipping's Dalian units: sources
summary: China is planning to ask the US to lift sanctions on Cosco Shipping's Dalian units, which the US accuses of violating restrictions on carrying Iranian petroleum. The sanctions, imposed last month, led to a bidding war for ships and sent costs soaring. The move comes during high-level trade negotiations in Washington, where China may also seek relief for other sanctioned companies. The US decision has affected the global shipping industry, particularly supertankers traveling from the Middle East to China, with day rates reaching an 11-year high.

images.alt_text: China plans to ask the US to lift sanctions on its biggest shipping company at high-level trade negotiations in Washington this week, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4% to 3,102.78
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,102.78 on Friday, following a strong US market open, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.6%. Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 28, with Spackman, Rex International, and financials from United Overseas Bank, OCBC Bank, and DBS contributing to the gain. The benchmark index also benefited from Asian stocks rising as high-level US-China trade talks progressed.

site_title: Typhoon-hit Japan GP qualifying moved to Sunday
summary: Typhoon Hagibis has forced the cancellation of the entire Japanese Grand Prix's Saturday track programme, including qualifying, due to predicted heavy rain and strong winds. Qualifying will be rescheduled for 10am Sunday, with the race taking place as planned at 2.10pm. This decision prioritizes safety for spectators, competitors, and staff, following a similar move in 2004 and 2010. The typhoon has already caused disruptions, including the cancellation of rugby matches in Japan.

site_title: Philippine powerhouse Ayala may look outside family for next CEO
summary: Ayala Corp, a Philippine conglomerate led by Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala II, may consider an outsider as its next CEO, according to the chairman and CEO. Zobel, 60, has led the company for 25 years, transforming it into a diversified powerhouse with significant stakes in real estate, finance, and telecommunications. The company's market value has risen almost fivefold since Zobel took the helm, but it lags behind rival SM Investments Corp. Zobel has paved the way for an outside leader, saying the company has "all kinds of options" for leadership.

images.alt_text: Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala II, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Philippines' Ayala Corp, said a CEO from outside the family is one option when the group passes power to new leaders. Part of his legacy, he said, has been paving the way to make such a move possible.

site_title: Air New Zealand entices Walmart US boss Foran home to lead airline
summary: Air New Zealand named Greg Foran, former Walmart US boss, as its new chief executive, bringing him back to his home country at a time the airline is trying to control costs. Foran, credited with turning around Walmart's US business, will join Air New Zealand in the first quarter of 2020, replacing Christopher Luxon. The move is seen as a coup for the carrier, with Foran's focus on improving existing stores to keep costs and prices low.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand named Walmart US boss Greg Foran as its new chief executive on Friday, bringing him back home at a time the airline is trying to control costs in a lower-growth environment.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore's young businesses under 10: Aquaculture Centre of Excellence (ACE)
summary: The Money FM podcast discussed Singapore's young businesses under 10 years old, focusing on the Aquaculture Centre of Excellence (ACE). ACE is a specialist centre that aims to promote sustainable aquaculture practices and reduce the cost of sustainable marine fuel. The centre is part of the research efforts of NUS, with the goal of halving the price of sustainable marine fuel.

site_title: Ex-truck driver becomes a billionaire with some help from Amazon
summary: Masaru Wasami, a 74-year-old Japanese entrepreneur, has become a billionaire after partnering with Amazon to manage same-day delivery services in the country. He started his business, Maruwa Unyu Kikan Co, at age 12, and it now handles logistics for major retailers. The partnership with Amazon, which began in 2017, has helped Maruwa's shares more than double this year, with Wasami owning nearly 60% of the company. Revenue is expected to continue growing as Amazon expands its same-day delivery services in Japan, creating opportunities for couriers like Maruwa.

site_title: Brazil's Embraer to furlough 15,000 workers ahead of Boeing deal
summary: Brazil's Embraer to furlough 15,000 workers in January ahead of a partial takeover by Boeing, which has agreed to buy 80% of Embraer's commercial plane division for $4.75 billion. The furlough, lasting Jan 6-20, will allow Embraer to implement internal business segregation. However, regulatory approval in Europe, with a deadline of Feb 20, may delay the deal's closure. Workers will return to normal functions once the deal is approved.

site_title: A million Californians without power as fire risk spreads south
summary: Over a million Californians were left without power due to pre-emptive blackouts, as Pacific Gas & Electric and Southern California Edison switched off electricity to prevent localized fires. The power cuts affected 1 million customers, with 137,000 restored by Thursday afternoon. The blackouts were sparked by high-risk "red flag" winds and dry vegetation, with several small fires reported and one large fire east of Los Angeles. The cost of 48 hours of power cuts could reach $2.6 billion.

site_title: Autumn Treats
summary: Chef Shigeru Koizumi has introduced an Autumn menu at Esora, featuring seasonal produce such as black-throat perch, persimmons, and pears. The six-course lunch menu is priced at $138++ and the eight-course dinner menu at $268++. The menu includes unique tea pairings like genmaicha and basil leaves, as well as dishes like monaka wafer stuffed with foie gras and persimmon.

site_title: Brexit deal hopes hang on British breakfast with Barnier
summary: British Brexit minister Stephen Barclay and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier are set to hold a working breakfast on Friday to test a potential Brexit deal. Despite stalled technical talks, Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar remain hopeful, citing a "pathway" to a deal. The next European Council summit is scheduled for October 17, with EU leaders expected to assess the progress. If a deal is not reached by October 19, Britain may be forced to seek a third delay to Brexit.

images.alt_text: Britain and Europe's top Brexit negotiators sit down together on Friday to test what British and Irish leaders say might be a "pathway" to a deal.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Brexit, trade deal hopes; LVMH shines
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Thursday, driven by hopes of a Brexit deal and US-China trade talks. The Stoxx 600 index closed up, with luxury goods sector stocks like LVMH and Gucci-owner Kering gaining. The US-China trade talks, which may prevent a tariff hike on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods, fueled optimism. Despite weak economic data, investors were heartened by President Trump's tweet confirming the talks.

site_title: Trump suggests US could mediate 'deal' between Turks and Kurds
summary: US President Donald Trump suggested mediating a 'deal' between Turkey and Kurdish groups, following Ankara's military offensive against Kurds. Trump tweeted that Washington could mediate a deal, citing three options: sending troops, imposing economic sanctions, or mediating a deal. This comes after Trump ordered US troops to withdraw from key positions in Syria, and earlier threatened economic sanctions against Turkey. Trump's stance has been criticized by his own party, and it remains unclear what the limits of sanctions would be.

site_title: Temasek, GIC help drive state funds' overall buys to US$24.6b in third quarter
summary: State funds increased merger and acquisition activity to $24.6 billion in the third quarter, driven by deals involving Singapore's GIC and Temasek Holdings, as well as China Investment Corp. This is the highest total since Q2 2018. GIC participated in a $8.7 billion deal to buy US freight railroad Genesee & Wyoming Inc, while Saudi Arabian sovereign wealth fund Public Investment Fund invested $550 million in Babylon Healthcare Services. Despite uncertainty over Britain's exit from the EU, several deals involved British assets, and the fourth quarter is expected to be a bumper period for deals.

site_title: ASL Marine's independent auditor flags going concern doubts
summary: ASL Marine Holdings' independent auditor Ernst & Young has raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant losses and high current liabilities. The group incurred a loss of $145.9 million in 2019, with current liabilities exceeding current assets by $20.8 million. ASL Marine's total borrowings were $363.1 million, with $46.3 million classified as current liabilities. The auditor's "material uncertainty" highlights the company's financial instability.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Opec pledges decision on supply
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by comments from Opec's Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo that the organization could take action to balance oil markets and will decide in December on supply for next year. Brent crude futures rose 1.3% to $59.10 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures increased 1.8% to $53.55 a barrel. A meeting between Opec and Russia in December could lead to sustained stability in oil prices for 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on US-China trade talks
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by anticipation of a high-level US-China trade meeting. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.69% to 21,701.19, while the Topix index increased 0.54% to 1,589.90. The market is closely watching the US-China talks, which could impact global trade and investor sentiment.

site_title: ESR-Reit nets S$50m in oversubscribed preferential offering
summary: ESR-Reit successfully completed a preferential offering, raising S$50 million with no additional units allotted. The funds will be used to finance asset enhancement works and repay existing debts. This brings the total gross proceeds from the private placement offering to S$150 million. ESR Cayman, the sponsor, accepted its allotted 8.8 million units, reducing its stake in the Reit from 8.97% to 8.78%.

site_title: Delta pilots receive record overtime while MAX crisis hits rivals: unions
summary: Delta Air Lines pilots received record overtime, with 40,554 "green slips" issued between May and August, double the same period in 2018. The surge in overtime is partly due to Delta adding flights to fill a supply gap left by the Boeing 737 MAX grounding at rival carriers. Meanwhile, Southwest Airlines pilots, who fly the MAX, sit at home on basic pay due to delayed hiring. Delta plans to add over 900 pilots in 2020 to cushion its ranks, amid a split in the fortunes of US airline workers.

site_title: To save climate, tax carbon at US$75 per ton: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund recommends that major carbon-polluting nations jointly agree to tax emissions at $75 per ton by 2030 to keep climate change at safe levels. This would prevent global average temperatures from rising more than 2°C above pre-industrial levels, while offsetting costs through targeted assistance to poor households and investments in cleaner energy. The report acknowledges the daunting costs, including coal price increases and electricity price hikes, but estimates that environmental benefits would outweigh these costs, preventing 725,000 premature air pollution deaths by 2030.

images.alt_text: The world's biggest carbon polluting nations should jointly agree to tax emissions at US$75 per ton in the next decade to keep climate change at safe levels, the International Monetary Fund said Thursday.

site_title: Ethiopia turns former palace, torture site into tourist draw
summary: Ethiopia's former palace, which served as a torture site under the communist Derg regime, is now open to the public as part of a government tourism project backed by the UAE. The "Unity Park" project, costing over $160 million, features restored rooms with historical items and a sculpture garden. Critics argue the project is a vanity for Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and may alienate ethnic Oromos who claim their ancestors were forcibly displaced. The government claims the project symbolizes unity, but many Ethiopians remain skeptical.

site_title: James Murdoch takes stake in Vice Media: report
summary: James Murdoch has taken a minority stake in Vice Media as part of a move away from the family business. The investment comes from his recently created equity group Lupa Systems. This move follows the sale of film and TV assets to Walt Disney and the publishing group News Corp, which now centers around the "new Fox". Murdoch's investment in Vice Media is seen as a strategic move to diversify his portfolio.

site_title: Double counting threatens integrity of Paris agreement
summary: The Paris climate accord faces a major hurdle as countries struggle to agree on an accounting method to count greenhouse gas reductions twice, potentially undermining the agreement's integrity. Despite progress in setting national targets, many are insufficient to meet the 1.5°C warming limit. Experts warn that poor accounting could exacerbate the issue, while the United States and other countries have yet to commit to the agreement. The lack of a solution threatens the landmark 2015 agreement signed by almost 200 countries.

site_title: Mohegan Gaming unveils plan for luxury casino resort in Greece
summary: US casino operator Mohegan Gaming & Entertainment has unveiled its plan for a luxury casino resort in Greece, dubbed Inspire Athens. The $12.15 billion project, in partnership with GEK Terna, aims to build a 1.2-hectare casino with 120 gaming tables and 1,200 slot machines, along with a luxury hotel and entertainment venues. Construction is expected to take 24-36 months and will generate over 7,000 jobs. The project has been delayed due to environmental and cultural concerns, but the new conservative government has promised to speed up the process.

site_title: Thai, Philippine firms lead revival in South-east Asia IPOs
summary: Thai and Philippine companies are leading a regional resurgence in initial public offerings (IPOs) in South-east Asia, with Asset World Corp and AllHome Corp raising $1.6 billion and $285 million, respectively. The growth is driven by investor interest in firms focused on South-east Asian consumers. Thailand's IPO market is expected to remain strong in 2020, with 11 companies raising $1.9 billion from January to October 2019, and several large IPOs preparing to list next year.

site_title: New Honda Accord review: The agreeable Accord
summary: The new Honda Accord review praises the car as a big, plush, and well-equipped take on the quintessential Japanese sedan, offering more executive features than many executive cars for its price. As a solution for office car parks with a German boss, the Accord is recommended for its comfort and value. Its 10th generation is a reminder of the appeal of big Japanese cars.

site_title: LVMH eases fears over Hong Kong hit, lifting luxury stocks
summary: LVMH, the owner of Louis Vuitton, reported stronger-than-expected sales, easing concerns about the impact of Hong Kong protests on luxury brands. The company's fashion and handbag division drove sales growth, while its watch division showed less-than-expected decline. This lifted LVMH's shares 3.9% and other luxury stocks, including Gucci and Hermes. Analysts say LVMH may be an outlier due to its investments in marketing and new designers, but the company's performance suggests it can withstand the Hong Kong protests.

site_title: Big Screen Design
summary: Asia's eighth Design Film Festival is back, featuring films on design and subcultures, including "Autonomy: The Drive for Self" and "Hi, AI." The festival will be held at the Capitol Theatre from Oct 12-13, with tickets available for $15. Other films include documentaries on British bands New Order and Suede, and the collaboration between Western and North Korean artists.

images.alt_text: A Design Film Festival 2019 will be held for over two weekends at the Capitol Theatre from Oct 12.

site_title: Temasek said to rule out investment in Saudi Aramco IPO
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investment company, has ruled out investing in Saudi Aramco's initial public offering (IPO) due to environmental concerns. The decision, driven by Temasek's focus on sustainability and reducing carbon emissions by 50% by 2030, highlights the growing pressure on fossil-fuel producers to avoid investments contributing to climate change. This move may limit funding for Saudi Aramco and other fossil-fuel producers, making it more expensive to secure capital.

site_title: China eyes broader iron ore supply sources, says Fortescue CEO
summary: China is expanding its iron ore supply sources beyond Australia, citing growing steel demand and urbanization, according to Fortescue CEO Elizabeth Gaines. China still has a way to go before reaching peak steel usage, but is expected to produce 1 billion tonnes of steel this year, driven by its "Belt and Road" infrastructure project. Fortescue is also investing in hydrogen research as a potential export market.

site_title: Family office advisers report rising interest from clients in quitting Hong Kong
summary: Family office advisers report a surge in interest from wealthy clients in quitting Hong Kong, with projects being delayed and assets moving to Singapore-based banks. The shift comes amid months of violent protests in Hong Kong, fueling concerns about Chinese authorities' intervention. Investors are seeking stability and avoiding uncertainty, driving assets to Singapore. Goldman Sachs estimates a $3-4 billion outflow of Hong Kong dollar deposits to Singapore, with many hedge funds considering relocation. The move may have significant economic implications for Hong Kong, which relies heavily on financial services.

site_title: BMW M8 review: Have a laugh with your M8
summary: BMW's M8 Competition Coupe is a technologically advanced vehicle with a wide range of features. It seamlessly transitions between comfort and high-performance capabilities. The car's complex features are accessible through the voice-activated Personal Assistant, making it easier to navigate. The M8 is a testament to BMW M's breadth of talent, offering an extraordinary driving experience.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH Reit, ESR-Reit, Q&M Dental, Cheung Woh Technologies, Capital World
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading on Friday. SPH Reit saw a 2.1% rise in distribution per unit to 1.46 Singapore cents, while ESR-Reit netted S$50 million from a preferential offering. Q&M Dental agreed to sell a 36% stake in Aidite for S$49 million, and Cheung Woh Technologies' CEO will retire due to health reasons. Capital World was queried by the Singapore Exchange about the sustainability of its loan cycle, and Transit-Mixed Concrete reported narrower losses from its continuing operations. These developments may affect the shares of these companies.

site_title: Endless wrangling over Brexit depresses UK housing market
summary: The UK housing market experienced a decline in September, with an index of homes put up for sale at its lowest since June 2016. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a decrease in buyer inquiries and vendor instructions, citing Brexit uncertainty. London and the southeast were particularly affected, with prices expected to continue falling over the next three months. However, respondents were more optimistic on a 12-month basis, suggesting that the market may stabilize. The Brexit deadline's approach has contributed to the market's depression.

site_title: Investing in growth through smarter boards in family firms
summary: Family-owned businesses in Asia, where most firms are controlled by families, drive economic growth. However, boards dominated by insiders can hinder growth due to lack of diversity and a control mindset. Insiders may not have the skills or networks to adapt to new markets or technologies, and micro-managing family leaders can lead to poor decision-making. Investing in independent directors can provide new competencies, networks, and better systems, positioning family firms for sustained growth and smoother succession. Strong, independent directors can help family owners make better decisions and avoid missed opportunities, making them a valuable resource for growth.

site_title: Best Of Both Worlds
summary: Reebok and adidas have collaborated to release a range of mash-up sneakers, the Instapump Fury Boost, fusing Reebok's iconic silhouette with adidas' Boost technology. Three packs, including Prototype, OG Meets OG, and Black & White, will be released in the coming month, with only the latter two available in Singapore. The OG Meets OG pack features colorways inspired by both brands' original sneakers, while the Black & White pack boasts monochrome uppers with metallic accents and raw gum outsoles. The sneakers will go on sale starting October 25 and December 6.

site_title: Sustainability matters, but sustainability reporting may not be the answer
summary: Sustainability reporting may not be an effective way to assess investment targets due to its limitations. ESG factors are too broad, and companies can self-curated data with little regulatory oversight. Over-reporting is common, and companies may "under-report" poor behavior. To improve sustainability reporting, harmonized global standards and more robust governance metrics are needed. Investors should consider factors like governance, which has a direct impact on financial performance, rather than lumping together environmental and social concerns. Governments should take a lead in regulating sustainability reporting to ensure its accuracy and reliability.

site_title: German shooter video stays online despite crackdown
summary: A video of a deadly shooting in Halle, Germany, where two people were killed, remained accessible online despite efforts to curb violent content. The 35-minute video was originally livestreamed on Twitch and viewed by 2,200 people before being removed, but was still available on sites like 4chan and BitChute, which promote violent and sexual content. The full video was viewed over 90,000 times, with users sharing links on 4chan and another forum. Mainstream social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube did not host the video, in contrast to the Christchurch mosque shootings.

site_title: 2019's healthy home sales mask uneven showing for different projects
summary: Singapore's developers are expected to sell over 9,000 private homes this year, surpassing last year's figure of 8,795 units, according to analysts. However, the market has seen uneven sales performance, with some projects achieving decent sales momentum due to factors like affordable pricing, niche locations, and high commissions. Developers have been launching projects with optimistic per square foot prices, often at benchmark levels, but some have managed to keep median absolute prices within the affordable range of S$1 million. The market is expected to remain resilient despite an economic slowdown.

site_title: New BMW X1 review: X-ternal changes only
summary: BMW has given the X1 a makeover, with new LED headlamps and a revised front grille, but the interior remains unchanged. The new model features a 1.5-litre turbo engine and a larger touchscreen system. However, the X1's size and interior space remain its selling points, with ample room for passengers and cargo. The facelift adds freshness to the model, but the threat from rival Audi's Q3 has grown, with the Q3's interior being more digital and luxurious.

site_title: US dollar set for biggest fall in 5 weeks
summary: The US dollar is poised for its largest daily drop in five weeks as investors anticipate a potential trade deal between China and the US, fueling demand for trade-oriented currencies like the euro and Australian dollar. A planned tariff hike next week's suspension is also seen as a positive sign. The move is driven by a rally in risky assets, despite volatile trading.

site_title: ST Telemedia eyes controlling stake in US cloud service provider 2nd Watch
summary: ST Telemedia is set to acquire a controlling stake in US cloud service provider 2nd Watch, pending regulatory approval. The investment will enhance the firm's cloud IT platform and expand its presence in the US market. ST Telemedia, a unit of Temasek Holdings, specializes in communications, media, and technology businesses. The acquisition aims to leverage 2nd Watch's capabilities and further solidify ST Telemedia's position in the cloud computing sector.

site_title: Dance Royalty
summary: International dance superstar Carlos Acosta is set to perform with his company Acosta Danza at the Esplanade's da:ns festival on October 11. Other highly-anticipated performances include Hofesh Shechter's dystopian piece Grand Finale and Raimund Hoghe's Pas De Deux. The festival features a range of dance styles and themes, including politics and ecological issues. Tickets are available from Sistic, and more information can be found on esplanade.com.

site_title: The Business Of Michelin
summary: Michelin-starred restaurants in Singapore experience significant financial gains, with a one-star increasing business by 20%, two stars by 40%, and three stars by 100%. The awards open doors to luxury brands, events, and catering opportunities, with chefs commanding higher fees. However, maintaining quality and consistency remains a challenge, as seen with Saint Pierre's Emmanuel Stroobant, who experienced an increase in enquiries but not necessarily in sales. The Michelin stars also attract foreign media coverage and international appeal, with three-star chef Sebastien Lepinoy noting a 20% increase in bookings and foreign guests.

site_title: Office of the Future
summary: Companies are redesigning workplaces to attract and retain talent, with a focus on creating a human-centric environment that optimizes employee productivity and happiness. Key features include intelligent, intuitive, and conscious design that considers current and future industry trends, technology-enabled solutions, and amenities that encourage active mobility and health and wellness. Landlords and building owners are also introducing innovative features, such as facial recognition access, luxurious members-only business clubs, and apps that integrate building services. Experts predict that the office of the future will be technology-enabled, modular, and human-centric, with a focus on agility, flexibility, and collaboration.

site_title: UK's IQE to take over Singapore JV
summary: UK-based IQE will acquire its loss-making joint venture in Singapore for a nominal fee, aiming to capitalize on supply chains in the Asian region and China's 5G market. The acquisition will allow IQE to be closer to Asian chip customers and original equipment manufacturers, despite US restrictions on China's Huawei disrupting the industry's supply chain. IQE expects a £500,000 hit to its 2019 adjusted core profit and operating profit following the acquisition, which recorded losses of S$8.9 million in 2018. The move is seen as a strategic move in the current geopolitical context.

site_title: Wardrobe Edit
summary: A sustainable capsule wardrobe is a collection of 30-40 essential, versatile pieces that can be mixed and matched for multiple occasions. This approach prioritizes quality over quantity, reducing waste and excess. Influenced by fashion icons like Susie Faux and Donna Karan, luxury brands like Saint Laurent and Louis Vuitton are adopting the capsule wardrobe concept. To build a capsule wardrobe, start with basics, versatile colors, statement pieces, and simple accessories, and update every three months to refresh the collection.

images.alt_text: COS has a range of minimalist tailored looks for a cohesive capsule work wardrobe (left). A capsule wardrobe is made up of quality pieces that are evergreen. Loro Piana's exquisite wool and cashmere pieces are certainly worth the investment (center). Brioni Fall/Winter 2019: Neutral-colour essentials will match easily to darker base colours like navy blue or black (right).

site_title: Singtel may cut dividend to maintain credit rating: DBS Research
summary: Singtel may cut its dividend payout to S$0.13-$0.15 per share for FY2021 to maintain its credit rating, according to DBS Research. The telco's balance sheet would benefit from pegging dividends to underlying earnings rather than a fixed quantum, relieving its burden. Singtel has maintained or raised its dividend every year for two decades, but DBS expects core Ebitda margins to decline due to pricing pressures and growing low-margin ICT services.

site_title: The coming alliance of populists and greens
summary: Populists and environmentalists, traditionally seen as opposing forces, are increasingly aligning in the US. This shift is attributed to the growing awareness of climate change, sparked by events such as the 1969 oil spill and river fire. The formal enacter of environmental reforms, including the Environmental Protection Agency, was Richard Nixon, who also authorized federal power growth. This alliance is seen as incongruous, but the US President Donald Trump's and Greta Thunberg's Twitter exchange highlights the acrimony between the two movements, setting the stage for a potential convergence.

site_title: Contributions from newly acquired assets boost SPH Reit's DPU
summary: SPH Reit reported a 2.1% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.46 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Aug 31, 2019, driven by contributions from two new malls, The Rail Mall in Singapore and Figtree Grove Shopping Centre in Australia. Gross revenue rose 10.2% and net property income (NPI) increased 11.8%. The Reit's full-year DPU rose 1.1% to 5.6 cents.

site_title: Starter Kit For Startups
summary: Monocle's new guide, The Entrepreneurs, focuses on startups and entrepreneurs, providing perspectives on launching, sustaining, and selling a business. However, the publication offers a mostly glossy and superficial image of entrepreneurship, lacking in-depth discussions on issues like climate crimes and human migration. The guide features stories of successful entrepreneurs who prioritize their personal values over financial gain, showcasing their unconventional approaches to business. The book's design and graphics are reminiscent of Monocle's flagship title, but its coverage of entrepreneurship is criticized for being superficial.

site_title: Goldman in talks to sell Mexican tollroad operator
summary: Goldman Sachs is in advanced talks to sell a majority stake in Mexico's largest private tollroad operator, Red de Carreteras de Occidente (RCO), to Spain's Abertis Infraestructuras SA and Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd. The potential deal values RCO at around $4.6 billion, with Abertis and GIC emerging as frontrunners. Other bidders include Blackstone Group Inc and China Merchants Bank Co. Goldman owns the stake through funds managed by its infrastructure-investing arm, and a final decision has not been made.

site_title: World's top oil traders see 2020 prices stuck in the US$50s
summary: Top oil traders predict crude prices will remain stuck in the US$50s in 2020 due to the ongoing US-China trade dispute and ample global supply. Vitol's CEO Russell Hardy and Gunvor's CEO Torbjorn Toernqvist agree that the market is currently "bearish" and that prices may be lower in the short term. Analysts at Goldman Sachs and Cornerstone Macro also see the market remaining supplied, with Brent crude expected to reach US$60 over the next two years.

site_title: WeWork Singapore expansion on track even as US parent seeks new funding
summary: WeWork Singapore is expanding its operations, opening three new locations by the end of the year, despite its US parent company facing financial struggles. WeWork Singapore will have a total of 12 locations in the country, with prices starting from S$2,690 per month for a private office. The company's new locations offer flexible workspace options, including a "mini-golf playzone" and rooftop terrace. WeWork's US parent is seeking a US$1 billion lifeline from Softbank Group to proceed with a major restructuring, amid plans for thousands of layoffs and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: This man is changing BMW's fastest cars forever
summary: BMW M's chairman, Markus Flasch, is leading the high-performance subsidiary with a focus on agility, precision, and performance. Under his leadership, BMW M sold a record 100,000 cars last year and is on track to sell 120,000 this year. Flasch aims to make BMW M's cars eco-friendly, with electric drive being a key priority. The subsidiary can access technology from BMW i, its eco-focused division, to achieve this goal, and plans to introduce electrified M cars in the future.

site_title: Before Raffles
summary: A new exhibition, "An Old New World: From the East Indies to the Founding of Singapore, 1600s-1819," explores the history of Singapore before Stamford Raffles' arrival in 1819. The show highlights the thriving trade and culture of the East Indies, including Aceh, which was already economically and culturally advanced before the arrival of Europeans. The exhibition features a multimedia show, "Meeting of the Worlds," which dramatizes the arrival of the first fleet of English and Dutch East India Companies in Aceh in the 17th century, emphasizing the region's pre-European presence.

site_title: We need a more inclusive form of capitalism
summary: The US Business Roundtable, an organization of large US company CEOs, recently issued a statement advocating for companies to prioritize the well-being of their broader stakeholder community, including workers, customers, and others, beyond maximizing shareholder value. This shift towards a more inclusive form of capitalism is part of broader efforts to reimagine the role of markets in the modern American economy. Experts argue that a balance must be struck between public and private efforts, and that the private sector typically fails to consider positive and negative externalities. Senator Elizabeth Warren's pro-reform platform aims to redesign market structures and limit the influence of money in politics to achieve better outcomes.

site_title: Peggy Chan, activist & restaurateur of Nectar Hong Kong
summary: Chef Peggy Chan, a Hong Kong-based restaurateur, advocates for a plant-based diet to reduce carbon emissions and reverse global warming. Her high-end restaurant, Nectar, offers creative, locally-sourced dishes using sustainable ingredients. Chan cites the World Health Organization's finding that livestock production causes 51% of greenhouse gas emissions, and links meat consumption to heart disease, cancer, and other chronic illnesses. She believes plant-based alternatives, such as pea protein burgers, can satisfy nutritional needs and reduce emissions. Chan's efforts have been recognized by the United Nations Development Programme and other organizations, and she will speak on the plant-based movement on October 18.

site_title: Vehicle suppliers hit as GM strike in US grinds on
summary: A strike by US-based General Motors (GM) workers, which began on September 16, continues to affect the automotive industry, with vehicle suppliers and contractors idling production. The strike, involving 1,800 GM employees, has led to the layoff of 1,200 workers from supply and trucking firms. The economic impact is significant, with the furloughs affecting 31 GM plants in the US and impacting companies that supply parts, computer systems, and raw materials. The strike's duration remains uncertain, with the United Auto Workers (UAW) Local 659 demanding a fair and equitable contract.

site_title: Employee-led ideas key to preserving the environment
summary: Employee-led ideas and initiatives are crucial in preserving the environment and driving sustainability in businesses. Research shows that 35% of consumers are willing to pay more for sustainable products, and 28% have loyalty to companies with sustainable practices. Employees, being the face of a business, can lend credibility and passion to sustainability efforts, and their insights can help identify effective practices. By empowering employees, businesses can create a shift towards sustainability, improve employee engagement, and drive long-term results.

site_title: Suspected IS terrorist stabs Indonesia's security minister
summary: Indonesia's chief security minister, Wiranto, was stabbed by a man suspected of being radicalized by Islamic State (IS) ideology while attending a university opening in Banten province. Wiranto, 72, suffered two stomach wounds and underwent surgery. Authorities arrested a suspect couple and seized sharp weapons. President Joko Widodo ordered an investigation and vowed to dismantle the network behind the attack. The incident highlights Indonesia's ongoing struggle with militancy, with hundreds detained under anti-terrorism laws since 2019.

site_title: WeWork collapse a welcome step towards sanity in venture space
summary: WeWork's collapse is a welcome step towards sanity in the venture space, as investors are forced to reevaluate their approach to valuations and fundamentals. The company's failed IPO attempt and subsequent struggles are a sign that investors are unwilling to accept promises without sound backing. This trend may also affect other tech unicorns and venture-backed businesses, which rely on investors to stay viable. The collapse highlights the need for a more rational approach to investing and growth, and may signal a shift away from the "founder's market" and towards more sustainable business models.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nico Steel reported a net loss of US$283,000 for its first half of fiscal 2020 due to uncertainties from the US-China trade war and fluctuations in commodity prices and currencies. Revenue dipped 11% to US$7.1 million, mainly due to lower demand for its proprietary metal alloys. IPS Securex Holdings secured a S$754,000 contract for a network video surveillance system solution in South-east Asia, which is expected to have minimal impact on net tangible assets but may affect earnings per share.

site_title: Living In A Grid
summary: Architect Lim Shing Hui has designed a unique 3D-like facade for a Sentosa Cove home, creating a grid-like structure from lightweight aluminum frames. The facade, which features planter boxes filled with tropical plants, adds color and shade to the home while also hiding automated watering and drainage systems. The design was chosen for its affordability, with aluminum being a relatively inexpensive material. The interior renovation included a new kitchen layout, family room, outdoor deck, and expanded bedrooms, all designed to enhance the home's functionality and aesthetic appeal.

site_title: Mind Your Peas And Q's
summary: Private kitchens, where home chefs offer restaurant-calibre cuisine in a rent-free setting, have become increasingly popular. However, guests often take advantage of the home setting, disregarding etiquette and personal space. This can lead to an uncomfortable experience for the chef, who must balance their passion for cooking with the need for respect and boundaries. As the trend continues to grow, home chefs must find ways to manage expectations and maintain a professional atmosphere in their private kitchens.

site_title: London's Ritz could be up for sale for over £800m
summary: London's iconic Ritz hotel, valued at over £800m, may be put up for sale after businessmen David and Frederick Barclay received several unsolicited offers. Despite directors stating the business was not for sale, the brothers had received bids, according to sources. The hotel, opened in 1906, has a turnover of £47m and operating profit of £15m, making it one of the most prestigious hotels in the world. The sale would be a significant move, potentially changing the hotel's ownership and future operations.

site_title: Apple pulls Hong Kong app used by protesters after China warning
summary: Apple removed the HKmap.live app from its App Store, citing China's request, amid Beijing's pressure on foreign companies supporting Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement. The app allowed protesters to track police. This move comes after other brands, including the NBA, faced similar pressure. The tech giant's decision was seen as bowing to China's demands, sparking criticism.

site_title: Dyson kills Singapore electric car project with closure of auto division
summary: Dyson, a home appliance giant, has scrapped its entire automotive division, including plans for an electric car plant in Singapore. Founder James Dyson cited a lack of commercial feasibility as the reason for the closure. The company had previously announced its plans to manufacture electric cars in Singapore, targeting a 2021 launch, but was unable to find a buyer for the project. Dyson will instead focus on expanding its core home business and developing battery technology, with Singapore remaining an important location for its growth plans.

site_title: Priorat reds imbued with newfound nuance
summary: Priorat, a Spanish wine region, has undergone significant changes over the past two decades. Initially known for its full-bodied, oaky wines, the region has evolved to showcase fresher, more elegant styles. The best examples remain expensive, but producers have focused on crafting wines with finesse, precision, and minerality. The region's traditional local grapes, such as garnacha and carinena, have regained prominence, and the international grapes planted in the past have faded. The wine's current state is characterized by diversity, with many bottles offering a perfect balance of structure and freshness, making Priorat a promising destination for wine enthusiasts.

site_title: China using economic muscle to bend Western companies to its will
summary: China has employed economic muscle to pressure Western companies, particularly the NBA, into conforming to its will after Daryl Morey's tweet supporting Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement. The country cancelled broadcasts, pulled Chinese sponsors, and barred Cathay Pacific employees from flying into China. This incident highlights China's sensitivity to Western portrayals and its growing economic influence, with US businesses facing a test of balancing profits with loyalty to open societies. The incident is part of a larger trend of China using economic might to twist corporate arms in Asia and could increase opportunities for international incidents.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar immune to protests, disappointing shorts
summary: Hong Kong's currency, the Hong Kong dollar, has remained stable despite the ongoing protests, with the last time it reached the weak end of its trading band being in May. The Libor-Hibor spread, which had previously made it profitable to short the local currency, has narrowed to less than 25 basis points, providing support. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also defended the currency, spending HK$22.1 billion in March. Experts attribute the stability to favorable market conditions, with most investors feeling the peg has been well-controlled.

site_title: Thailand to lead 4 Asean states in bid to host World Cup 2034
summary: Thailand is set to lead a joint bid to host the 2034 FIFA World Cup, with Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam as the four Asean states participating. The proposal was agreed upon at the fifth Asean Ministerial Meeting on Sports in Manila. This is the first time Singapore has been named as part of the joint bid led by Thailand. The bid faces competition from other countries, including China, Egypt, and Australia and New Zealand, which have also expressed interest in hosting the tournament.

site_title: JPMorgan Pte Bank sets up Singapore trust company
summary: JPMorgan Private Bank launched a trust company in Singapore to cater to ultra-high net worth (UHNW) clients and their families, marking its first trust company in Asia. The move aims to meet the complex needs of the super-rich in Asia and serve a wider range of clients in Singapore, a global financial centre with a sophisticated legal framework. The trust company, led by Ethan Chue, will support JPMorgan's existing clients in Asia, the US, and Europe, and is part of the bank's growing presence in the region.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Private Bank on Thursday launched a trust company in Singapore to cater for its ultra-high net worth (UHNW) clients and their families, as wealth expansion in the region continues to outpace the rest of the world. This is its first trust company in Asia, outside of its existing two in the Bahamas and Delaware, US.

site_title: Ex-billionaire Shivinder Singh arrested on charges of fraud
summary: Ex-billionaire Shivinder Singh and three others have been arrested in New Delhi on charges of siphoning nearly $337 million from a lender they controlled. The accused, who had "absolute control" over Religare Enterprises Ltd., are accused of causing a loss of $464.7 million by disbursing loans to companies with no financial standing. The arrests mark the final act in the fall of the Singh brothers' business empire, which was once one of India's most prominent. Shivinder's elder brother Malvinder Singh is still at large.

site_title: California's power outage means problems for electric cars
summary: California's power outage on October 9, 2019, left over half a million customers without power, posing a challenge for electric cars. Tesla issued a preemptive advisory to owners to charge up ahead of planned outages aimed at preventing wildfires. The company also advised on the status of its "Supercharger" stations, which were reported to be busier than usual. The outage highlights the vulnerability of electric vehicles in areas prone to power outages, with California being the country's largest electric vehicle market.

site_title: GCCP Resources inks agreement to buy palm oil grower in RTO deal
summary: GCCP Resources has entered a non-binding MoU to acquire Indonesian palm oil producer Arjuna Utama Sawit for S$220.3 million, resulting in a reverse takeover. The acquisition aims to capitalize on Indonesia's biodiesel program and Arjuna Utama's young plantation age profile, which positions it for strong production growth. The deal, conditional on due diligence and shareholder approval, will see GCCP issue 3.67 billion shares to vendors and 55 million shares to consultancy CO2 Capital as arranger fees.

site_title: Pet Painting
summary: Singaporean illustrator Carlyn Law is hosting a 2.5-hour pet painting workshop, "Imagine & Create in Watercolours," on October 12 at Pets Actually. Participants will learn to sketch and paint their pets using watercolour techniques, and create whimsical narratives to showcase their pet's personality. The workshop costs S$100, which includes materials and a S$10 shopping voucher. Suitable for beginners and those with some art experience, email eattodraw@gmail.com to book.

site_title: Samsung pours 13t won into next-gen displays
summary: Samsung plans to invest 13.1 trillion won (S$15 billion) in next-generation displays, aiming to reorganize the industry and maintain its global lead. The investment will help create 81,000 jobs and build a quantum-dot display production line in Asan, starting operations in 2021.
