Tetra Pak Thailand initiated the Green Roof project, donating over 6,000 classroom sets and 400,000 school notebooks to underprivileged students. Tetra Pak Indonesia focuses on post-consumer recycling, working with customers and consumers to create socio-economic value through recycled cartons. The company has collected and processed over 10,338 tons of used beverage cartons annually, and has also built mini-libraries using recycled cartons as roofing tiles.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as market awaits trade talks
summary: US stocks ended lower on Monday as market sentiment remained uncertain due to shifting signals on US-China trade talks. The latest round of talks, set to begin Thursday, has investors in a wait-and-see period for clarity. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.5%. Investors are awaiting key data on consumer prices and minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting, as well as third-quarter earnings season. The market's focus remains on the US-China trade talks, with analysts predicting a possible delay in a resolution.

site_title: Focus on affordability pays off
summary: PHILUSA Corporation, a 63-year-old FMCG and pharmaceutical manufacturer, has achieved market leadership in various categories while prioritizing affordability and accessibility. The company launched RHEA Generics, a brand of generic medicines developed in partnership with global pharmaceutical leaders. PHILUSA Corporation is recognized for its commitment to social responsibility, providing world-class quality products at affordable prices to citizens of the Philippines.

site_title: Ghosn whistle-blower faces pressure to leave Nissan: sources
summary: A Nissan executive, Hari Nada, is under pressure to leave the company following a pay scandal. Nada, a senior vice-president, is cooperating with Japanese prosecutors in the case against former chairman Carlos Ghosn for financial crimes. Renault supports the push to oust Nada, who is expected to be a key witness in Ghosn's trial next year. Nissan's board is set to meet on Tuesday to discuss candidates for CEO, with a deadline to announce a new leader by end-October.

site_title: US prefers a 'big deal' with China: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump prefers a comprehensive trade deal with China over a partial one, stating he wants a 'big deal'. The next round of US-China trade talks will begin on Thursday, with Beijing's top trade envoy Liu He meeting with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Despite speculation of a partial deal, Trump has expressed skepticism, citing his preference for a comprehensive agreement. The talks will focus on intellectual property rights, forced technology transfer, and agriculture, with US tariffs set to rise to 30% on $250 billion in Chinese goods on October 15.

site_title: Amazon, Walmart find success in rural India during sales season
summary: Amazon and Walmart reported record revenue from their six-day India sales festivals, marking a significant expansion into rural areas beyond the country's urban population. The sales, which included discounts and affordable credit options, attracted millions of Indian consumers and sellers, with Amazon's India chief citing 65,000 sellers from 500 cities. The e-commerce growth is driven by low-cost smartphones and wireless data rates, boosting internet businesses across the country.

site_title: 'Jim' the chatbot helps DBS hire wealth managers
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest bank, is using a chatbot named Jim to screen candidates for wealth management positions. Introduced last year, Jim has improved the quality and speed of initial screenings, with one-third of candidates passing vetting going on to get jobs. Under the previous system, only one-seventh of candidates were hired. The bank's head of talent acquisition, Susan Cheong, attributed the success to Jim's vetting process.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest bank is getting help from a chatbot named Jim in its drive to select good candidates for its fast-growing business advising customers on managing their wealth.

site_title: Europeans fear IS comeback after Trump pullback from Syria
summary: European powers warn against a threatened Turkish offensive in northern Syria, which could boost the Islamic State group and spark a new refugee crisis. The US pullout, facilitated by President Donald Trump's decision to stand aside, has raised concerns. European governments, including France, Britain, and Germany, urge Ankara to avoid any initiative that could embolden extremist groups. A Turkish operation could also allow captured foreign jihadists to escape, posing a threat to European national security.

site_title: Oxley acquires 60% stake in Pindan as settlement
summary: Oxley Holdings has acquired a 60% stake in Perth-based property firm Pindan Group for zero consideration, settling a claim related to Pindan's failure to meet agreed performance targets. Oxley now wholly owns Pindan.

site_title: Perennial JV to start claim against ex-Sakae director
summary: Perennial Real Estate has announced that its 50% joint venture, TYN Investment Group, has applied to the court to commence a claim for conspiracy against Griffin Real Estate Investment and former Sakae Holdings director Andy Ong Siew Kwee. The claim is related to TYN Group's acquisition of TYN Investment Pte Ltd, which owns the House of Tan Yeok Nee, a national monument. The claim is made in conjunction with TYN Investment's defense of a claim by Griffin, which alleges transactions relating to TYN Investment before it became an associated company of Perennial.

site_title: Leading the charge
summary: The Industry Champions award recognizes companies that lead their respective industries. Malaysia Airports Holdings Berhad (MAHB), Prasarana Malaysia Berhad, and BDO Unibank, Inc. are among the nominees. MAHB has optimized passenger service charges to remain competitive, while Prasarana Malaysia Berhad has achieved ISO certification for its management systems. BDO Unibank, Inc. attributes its market leadership to a focused strategy and customer-centric culture. The companies' efforts to enhance network connectivity, retail profiles, and public transport services have contributed to their nominations.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Breaking down gallstones
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses gallstones with Dr Liau Kui Hin, a General Surgeon at Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital and Mount Elizabeth Hospital. They break down symptoms to look out for and the risks of not seeking treatment promptly. Dr Liau emphasizes the importance of recognizing symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He also notes that gallstones can cause complications like pancreatitis if left untreated. The conversation aims to raise awareness about gallstones and encourage listeners to seek medical attention if they experience symptoms.

site_title: Shawn Mendes follows formula that rocks Singapore fans
summary: Shawn Mendes performed a sold-out concert in Singapore, sticking to a tried-and-tested formula that pleased the crowd. The 21-year-old pop idol played a stripped-down set with a four-piece rock band, switching between guitar and piano and tossing guitar picks into the crowd. Mendes showcased his musicality with guitar solos and kept fans happy with hits like "In My Blood" and "Senorita". The performance was a reminder of how far he has come, despite just turning 21, and left fans disappointed when he left without an encore.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah aims for RM5b profit after first loss in decade
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional Bhd, the country's sovereign wealth fund, aims to post a pretax profit of at least 5 billion ringgit (S$1.65 billion) for the first time in eight years. The fund, which reported its first loss in a decade in 2018, is on track to cut its debt to 47-48 billion ringgit from 50 billion ringgit. Managing Director Shahril Ridza Ridzuan attributed the stronger outlook to reduced impairments and lower dividend income. The fund's realisable asset value fell to 136 billion ringgit in 2018.

site_title: Burberry partners RealReal to give brand's old items 2nd lease of life
summary: Burberry partners with The RealReal to sell used luxury items online during the holiday season, offering customers a personal shopping session and tea in exchange for listings. The move aims to bolster appeal with environmentally conscious consumers and help the brand's sales, which have declined in the Americas since 2015. This partnership is part of Burberry's strategy to transition to a circular economy, with efforts to repair damaged garments and use recycled packaging.

site_title: Tat Hong's towering ambitions
summary: Tat Hong, a crane-owning company, is shifting its strategy to focus on branding and services as part of becoming an asset-light company. Founded over 60 years ago, the company has grown globally with operations in China, Australia, and Southeast Asia. Despite being the largest crane-owning company in the Asia-Pacific region, Tat Hong aims to capitalize on its reputation to procure cranes from other companies for its customers. The company's FY2019 revenue exceeded S$500 million, and it hires over 4,500 people globally. Tat Hong's strategic shift is driven by the need to navigate a challenging global business environment and capitalize on growing infrastructure projects in China and South-east Asia.

site_title: Volvo, Geely to merge combustion engine operations
summary: Volvo Cars and its parent company Geely are merging their combustion engine operations to create a new division, which will supply engines to in-house brands and potential rivals. The move aims to reduce development costs and increase efficiency, allowing Volvo to focus on electrified premium cars. Combining their operations will result in cost savings, particularly in development, and no job losses. The new division will combine 3,000 Volvo employees with 5,000 Geely employees, and will include research, development, procurement, and manufacturing functions.

site_title: Brandz director jailed 15 months for raising funds without prospectus
summary: A Singaporean businessman, Tay Chee Ming, has been sentenced to 15 months in jail for raising funds from investors without a prospectus, breaching the Securities and Futures Act. He, as the majority shareholder of Brandz Group, obtained S$2.825 million from 16 lenders in 2006, which was used to pay down debts. The court found that Tay had failed to provide investors with a statement of liabilities and risk factors, and that the company had made a loss of S$163,994. Tay has appealed his conviction and sentence.

site_title: Former bodyguard is now towkay of his own security firm
summary: Simon Ng, a former bodyguard to Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, has built a successful security training firm, Leacov, leveraging his experience and stint with the Workforce Development Agency.

images.alt_text: Leacov founder Simon Ng says with hindsight that he thinks he held off diversifying for too long, but that he is particularly proud of how the company pioneered digital innovation before this became a buzzword.

site_title: Bridge builder
summary: The Brigada Group of Companies, Inc, a Filipino conglomerate, was founded by Elmer Villegas Catulpos in 2005. The company pioneered a unique blend of media and product distribution businesses, creating a symbiosis of independent reportage and reliable marketing. Brigada now operates over 40 state-of-the-art radio stations and distributes 60 food supplement brands, providing journalistic independence to its media outfits. The company's growth was driven by its commitment to strengthening self-worth and fulfilling aspirations among its 1,000+ employees. Brigada's innovative approach has disrupted the local media landscape.

site_title: Deutsche Bank in strategy shift to address tech woes
summary: Deutsche Bank is shifting its strategy to address tech woes by creating a new technology division, reducing complexity and costs. The division will oversee tech security, data, and innovation functions, aiming to empower businesses to control processes while technology handles the "how." The bank plans to invest 13 billion euros in tech by 2022 and move to the cloud gradually, while reducing applications and barriers to technology functions. This move comes amid a technology arms race in banking, with competitors like JPMorgan investing heavily in tech.

site_title: The way the world moves
summary: KONE Pte Ltd, a leading elevator and escalator company, has continued to focus on innovation and sustainability, earning recognition for its commitment to employee development and environmental responsibility. For the second consecutive year, KONE was named one of the world's best employers by Forbes, and it has received an A or A- score from CDP for its sustainability efforts. The company's products, including those with Singapore Green Building Council certifications, demonstrate its commitment to creating value for customers while minimizing its environmental impact.

site_title: Young guns
summary: Young guns at ACES, a Chinese conglomerate, are leading the company's expansion. Antonio Hang Tat Chan, 25, spearheaded the King Wai Urban Oasis project, becoming the first China Environmental Label - Low Carbon Building project in 2012. The group has also expanded into Thailand's real estate and insurance sectors. Meanwhile, other news includes a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, and China urging South-east Asia to back openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a sector revival, and Reliance Jio delays its India IPO.

site_title: Homegrown nuts company aims to grow Asean markets
summary: Seng Hua Hng Foodstuff Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based homegrown nuts company, aims to expand its presence in the Asean market, particularly in China, with its Xiamen factory set to start production in mid-2020. The company, which has become Singapore's largest and only homegrown nuts manufacturer, will increase its exports to 30% of total revenue, with a focus on Asia as its key region of growth. With a commitment to keeping its products wholesome and tasty, Seng Hua Hng aims to tap into the growing demand for healthier nuts and functional foods.

site_title: DJ Dongfang Billy raises money for BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: Chinese radio DJ Dongfang Billy has raised S$19,420.50 through sold-out "afternoon tea sessions" for two charities, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. Ten percent of the funds, S$1,942, will be shared between the two charities. The sessions, which took place from Oct 3-6, also featured cooking classes and activities. Billy, a 56-year-old leukaemia survivor, plans to launch his first series of monthly cooking classes starting Nov 4-6.

site_title: The jury has decided
summary: A jury panel for the ACES Awards, an international corporate recognition, praised the increasing understanding of good corporate leadership and sustainability practices among nominees. The awards provide a platform for companies to benchmark against industry bests and share experiences, helping to build platforms for deeper dialogue on sustainability in Asia. Experts emphasize the need for companies to move quickly to harness emerging opportunities through sustainability, disclosing real progress through data and matrices benchmarked against global frameworks. The ACES Awards have helped refine corporate strategies for some companies, such as Globe Telecom.

site_title: Going for gold
summary: Globe Telecom, Inc. has been awarded the ACES Gold Trophy for the first time, marking its third consecutive win in the Top Workplaces in Asia category. Established in 1935, the Manila-based company has demonstrated a strong commitment to corporate governance, employee empowerment, and environmental sustainability. Its recognition as one of Asia's top workplaces is attributed to its investment in people, recognition and retention of talent, and fair communication practices. This achievement solidifies Globe's position as a leader in the industry.

site_title: The greening of FMCGs
summary: Denis Asia Pacific Pte Ltd and Coca Cola Philippines have made significant strides in environmental stewardship. Denis Asia Pacific aims to attain Green Mark certification for all its buildings and facilities by 2030, while reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 15%. Coca Cola Philippines has implemented water efficiency ratio improvements, retrieved and reused wastewater, and returned an estimated 108% of water used in its production processes. Both companies have also participated in community service projects, such as disaster relief operations and tree-planting campaigns, demonstrating their commitment to environmental sustainability.

site_title: Mega bourse mergers less of a threat as exchanges and markets have morphed
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) made a surprise $39 billion bid for London Stock Exchange (LSE), but the move may not have a significant impact due to the changing landscape of the financial industry. Major exchanges have diversified and adopted unique propositions, with a focus on technology and data. The US market remains a dominant force, and size is no longer the key factor in determining an exchange's value. Instead, exchanges are focusing on catering to multinational clients and developing products and services that meet their needs.

images.alt_text: No longer a boutique stock exchange bound by national boundaries, SGX has evolved to cater to multinational needs, focusing on developing the products and services that global clients want.

site_title: Vodafone tests new network tech in UK, challenging 'Big 3' suppliers
summary: Vodafone is testing OpenRAN, a new radio technology that standardizes hardware and software in mobile networks, in the UK. This innovation could enable lower-cost calls and data, challenging the dominance of Huawei, Ericsson, and Nokia in the telco equipment market. Vodafone has trialed the technology in South Africa and Turkey, and plans to launch it in 120 rural areas in Britain, with trials also set to begin in Mozambique and the Democratic Republic of Congo. This move aims to expand Vodafone's list of vendors and improve network economics.

site_title: Argentina needs sweeping reforms
summary: Argentina's chronic instability and recession are rooted in a failed political system that has failed to cement institutions for long-term development. The country's economic woes, including a history of sovereign defaults and high inflation, are the result of a combination of short-termism, weak institutions, and a lack of structural reforms. The next president, Alberto Fernández, must implement sweeping reforms, including labor, tax, and pension reforms, as well as a long-term industrial strategy and institutional reforms to bolster the peso and reduce dollarization.

site_title: SIG slumps on profit warning as UK construction weakens
summary: SIG, a UK building materials supplier, issued a profit warning due to a weakening economic outlook in Britain and Germany, resulting in a 26% drop in shares. British construction has slumped, driven by uncertainty over the UK's EU departure, while Germany's economy is slipping towards recession. SIG expects lower underlying profitability in its specialist distribution and roofing merchant businesses, taking actions to address the market weakness.

site_title: STI gains in low liquidity session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore opened 0.2% higher and closed at 3,099.48, gaining 21.12 points or 0.7% in the low-liquidity session. The gains were attributed to positive performances in regional markets, including Australia, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea. Despite worries over global growth and US-China trade tensions, investors are focusing on expected easing by the Federal Reserve. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is set to deliver its monetary policy statement on October 14, with consensus estimates suggesting a potential 50-basis-point rate cut.

site_title: M&G Prudential bets on London with £875m 'Gotham City' project
summary: M&G Prudential is investing £875 million to develop the 'Gotham City' office complex in London, solidifying its bet on the city as a future international financial hub. The project, one of the largest in the UK, will be built on a 40 Leadenhall Street site previously owned by Alberta Investment Management Corp and Nuveen Real Estate. The asset manager aims to capitalize on London's post-Brexit growth, positioning itself for success in the city's thriving business environment.

site_title: Emerging-market calm set to fray as trade and Fed worries worsen
summary: Emerging markets are poised for price swings amid trade-war tensions and central bank stimulus efforts. The US and China are set to restart trade negotiations, while Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speeches may signal a third interest rate cut. Goldman Sachs expects US tariffs on Chinese imports to increase on October 15, and is bearish on the yuan. Emerging-market currencies have strengthened, but technical indicators suggest volatility may return, with the 50-day moving average set to cross above its 200-day measure.

site_title: The rise of SMEs
summary: Four Asian SMEs were recognized at the ACES Awards, highlighting their importance to the business world. Cyclect Electrical Engineering, a B2B engineering firm, has built 10 high-efficiency power plants and reduced CO2 emissions by 16,000 tons. First Vita Plus Marketing Corporation, a multi-level marketing company, has amassed over 2 million dealers and users in its 17 years. Care Facility Services, an integrated facility services company, uses state-of-the-art thermal cameras to maintain customer retention in Brunei's saturated market. N'osairis, a Malaysian business, offers digital transformation services and IoT solutions to SMEs and blue-chip clients across South-east Asia.

site_title: Anti-GMO 'rock star' continues to challenge 'Big Six' corporations
summary: Vandana Shiva, an Indian professor-activist, continues to challenge the "Big Six" pesticide and GMO corporations, including BASF, Bayer, Dupont, Dow Chemical, Monsanto, and Syngenta. Despite restrictions in some countries and court cases in others, Shiva's fight against GMOs remains strong, with 28 European countries banning GM crops and several countries in Africa, Asia, and the Americas also restricting their use. Shiva argues that GMOs are not a solution to food security and that the industry's claims of safety are unfounded, citing the risks of antibiotic resistance and the exploitation of farmers through patent laws.

site_title: Driven by performance
summary: The article highlights three companies recognized as Best Performing Companies by the ACES Awards: Petroleum Trading Lao Public Company, Dhaya Maju Infrastructure (Asia), and GHL Systems Berhad. Petrotrade, a Lao petroleum company, has expanded its services and operations, becoming the first petroleum company listed on the Lao Securities Exchange. Dhaya Maju Infrastructure, a Malaysian construction company, operates regionally with a strong focus on delivering world-class projects. GHL Systems, a Malaysian payment solutions company, has experienced significant growth, processing over RM1 billion in transactions per month.

site_title: Sete Brasil settlement will enable Keppel, SembMarine to move on
summary: Keppel Corp and SembCorp Marine have settled with Sete Brasil, a Brazilian rig-owning unit of Petrobras, after four years of overhang due to corruption and lower oil prices. The settlement allows Keppel to take ownership of four rigs and potentially recoup costs by selling or chartering them out. This move sparks hopes of write-backs and order-book upsides for the rig builders. As a result, Keppel's shares jumped 1.7% and SembMarine's shares rose 0.9%.

site_title: Going beyond self and profit
summary: Societally conscious companies are shifting their focus from employee welfare to community care. After bundling employee perks into hiring packages, businesses are now prioritizing the communities they operate in. This marks a significant paradigm shift, where companies recognize their social responsibility beyond providing honest work and employee benefits. By caring for their communities, companies can build trust, foster goodwill, and contribute to the greater good. This new approach is a step towards creating a more positive and sustainable business environment.

site_title: Idealism needs to be grounded in reality
summary: Hong Kong protests enter their fifth month, with the initial goal of opposing the extradition bill achieved on September 4. However, violence has increased since then, including the first police shooting of a protester, and the government has invoked emergency laws and banned face masks during protests. The protests have shifted from peaceful demonstrations to a more intense and violent movement, prompting protesters to consider their future course and the likelihood of government escalation. The situation marks a turning point in the protest movement.

site_title: Labour's Jeremy Corbyn or a no-deal Brexit? UK deals with a conundrum
summary: UK opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn is seeking to rebrand himself as a safe pair of hands during the Brexit crisis, proposing a second referendum to reverse the UK's split with the EU. His Labour Party's economic plans, which include nationalizing the railways and raising taxes on the financial industry, have sparked concerns among bankers and analysts. Despite Corbyn's efforts to carve out a middle ground on Brexit, he remains unpopular with some lawmakers and the public. Analysts say that Corbyn's party is best positioned to challenge the Conservative government, but his plans may not be enough to sway voters.

site_title: High flyer
summary: Philippines-based Lufthansa Technik Philippines' CEO Elmar Lutter has been recognized as an Outstanding Leader in Asia, despite his humility about the award. Lutter leads a company that has become the world market leader in maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO) for the aviation industry, with clients including Lufthansa, Philippine Airlines, and Virgin Atlantic. He attributes his success to his leadership principles, which include drive, create spirit, lead change, foster talent, and master complexity, as well as his focus on safety and employee development.

site_title: Bugis Cube up for collective sale at S$230m reserve price
summary: Bugis Cube, a six-storey commercial building in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale via a public tender exercise at a reserve price of S$230 million. The decision follows recent sales of nearby properties, including Bugis Junction Towers, Duo, and GLS sites, as well as upcoming launches in the area. This move is expected to fuel interest in the Bugis Cube area, potentially leading to a competitive bidding process for the building.

site_title: Nikkei takes US$5m minority stake in SPH-backed AI startup DC Frontiers
summary: Singapore-based AI startup DC Frontiers has raised US$5 million from Nikkei Inc, a 14.9% stake, with Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) remaining the second-largest shareholder. The investment will help DC Frontiers expand its capabilities and accelerate sales growth. SPH will partner DC Frontiers to develop a content recommendation engine, leveraging the startup's AI technologies to enhance audience engagement. The deal is part of Nikkei's strategic diversification into Asian tech news, with plans to increase its focus on the region.

site_title: HK protesters in court after a week of bloody clashes
summary: Hong Kong protesters, arrested for defying a new face-mask ban, appeared in court after a weekend of unrest marked by bloody clashes and widespread vandalism. The ban, invoked by pro-Beijing leader Carrie Lam, failed to halt chaos, with activists calling for protests to resume. The move has sparked concerns of a slide towards authoritarianism, with demonstrators fearing more emergency orders to come. Internet curbs have also been suggested by a government Cabinet member, raising concerns for the city's online freedoms.

site_title: Cultivate trusting and long lasting relationships at home and abroad
summary: Veteran entrepreneur Roland Ng and Tat Hong successfully expanded into new Asian markets over 30 years, emphasizing the importance of localizing with strong talent and partnerships while equipping leadership with cross-border competencies. Expanding internationally is crucial for young businesses, but cultivating long-lasting relationships requires quality time invested in markets and partners, rather than solely relying on digital marketplaces. This approach allows for deeper understanding and trust to be built, ultimately driving successful internationalization.

site_title: PM Johnson warns EU he will not delay Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned the European Union that he will not delay Brexit beyond October 31, despite a law passed by British MPs requiring him to seek another delay if no agreement is reached. Johnson made the statement to French President Emmanuel Macron in a phone call, saying the EU should not expect the UK to stay in the EU after the deadline. European leaders have reacted tepidly to London's latest proposals, and EU leaders are urging the UK to revise its plans within days to conclude a deal this month.

site_title: Hmlet ties up with property developer to expand into Japan
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living company, has partnered with Mitsubishi Estate Co to expand into Japan with a combined US$25 million investment over three years. Hmlet will oversee design and community management, while MEC will manage property sourcing. The partnership aims to provide flexible, affordable, and secure accommodation in Japan, where rental costs are rising. Hmlet plans to grow to 10,000 rooms in Japan, starting with a Shibuya property set to launch in mid-October, and expand to Osaka and Nagoya.

site_title: GM laying off another 415 workers in Mexico as US strike continues
summary: General Motors is laying off 415 workers at a Mexico plant as a US strike by 48,000 hourly workers enters its fourth week. The Ramos Arizpe propulsion plant has partially idled, with some engine and transmission lines not operating. Talks between the United Auto Workers and GM resumed after a UAW official said negotiations had taken a "turn for the worse."

site_title: Beijing needs to tackle its soft power deficit
summary: China faces a soft power deficit, exacerbated by its rapid rise as a global superpower. This has led to increased scrutiny and perceptions that China is employing unfair trade practices, fueling concerns among politicians like US President Donald Trump. China's growing economic power has also led to a shift in international perceptions, with many countries viewing Beijing as the world's leading economic power. To address this deficit, Beijing must enhance international public diplomacy, showcase its capabilities in science and technology, and demonstrate a commitment to being a responsible and peaceful global stakeholder.

images.alt_text: While China celebrates the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic, it also faces several very pressing challenges, of which the demonstrations in Hong Kong are only the most visible right now.

site_title: Thai-ed for best
summary: Two Thai companies, WP Energy Public Company Limited and Worldgas, have been recognized as among Asia's Most Influential Companies. WP Energy is the second-largest LPG distributor in Thailand, serving three core sectors and providing value-added products and services to increase its slim business margins. The company's financial performance has significantly increased over the past three years, with net profits rising from US$2 million in 2016 to US$10 million in 2018.

site_title: Joker sets record on N American screens
summary: The film "Joker" has set a record for an October release, drawing an estimated $93.5 million in North American theatres over the weekend. Despite mixed reviews, the movie has survived controversy over its violent themes and has been praised for its R-rated rating. The film's success comes after concerns that it might inspire violence, with some theatres providing extra security for its opening. It ranks second at the box office, behind Universal's "Abominable".

site_title: Malaysia to present expanded Budget to ward off trade war, slow growth
summary: Malaysia's government is expected to present an expanded budget to counter the effects of the global recession, US-China trade war, and a large debt pile. The budget is likely to include a contingency plan with an estimated RM3 billion, on top of an estimated RM55 billion for development spending. The government aims to sustain domestic demand and prop up the economy, which has bucked a global cooling trend but faces growing protectionist policies. The expanded budget may slow fiscal consolidation, but analysts do not expect it to raise rating concerns due to the challenging economic outlook.

site_title: Talks between UAW and GM take 'turn for the worse': union official
summary: GM and the striking UAW union reached a roadblock in contract talks over the issue of moving production from Mexico to US plants, a major stumbling block. The union, seeking job security, had pressed GM to shift production of SUVs and pickup trucks from Mexican factories to domestic plants. However, GM's response failed to address key concerns, with UAW Vice-President Terry Dittes describing the talks as having "taken a turn for the worse."

site_title: Malaysia to boost economy in 2020 as Sino-US trade war drags on
summary: Malaysia's government plans to present an expanded budget in 2020 to boost the economy amid a weak outlook due to the US-China trade war and global recession fears. The budget is expected to include a contingency plan with a 3 billion ringgit fund to counter the effects of the trade war. The government aims to sustain development spending to prop up domestic demand and reduce its 1 trillion ringgit debt. Analysts expect a slower pace of fiscal consolidation than initially forecast.

site_title: Rabobank plans to invest 5b euros in Dutch rental homes
summary: Rabobank plans to invest €5 billion in Dutch rental homes over the next decade, aiming to add 15,000 homes to the market. The fund, BPD Woningfonds, will cooperate with Bouwfonds Property Development to build the first 1,000 homes next year. This initiative aims to address the severe shortage of rental homes for middle-income households in the Netherlands, where rents range from €650 to €1,250 per month. The move is part of efforts to combat the country's housing crisis, which has left around three million middle-income households without access to affordable housing.

site_title: Connected, optimised infrastructure will help electric vehicles take off here
summary: Singapore is positioning electric vehicles (EVs) as a key component of its mass transit system, aiming to reduce carbon emissions and transform urban mobility. The government has committed to a 10-fold increase in EVs for car-sharing and taxis by 2020 and partnered with BlueSG to deploy 500 charging stations by 2020. This move aligns with Singapore's Smart Nation blueprint and its commitment to the Paris agreement to cap CO2 emissions by 2030. EVs offer a convenient, affordable alternative to traditional cars, reducing the need for gas, insurance, and parking fees, and improving the quality of life for residents.

site_title: Fuelled by responsibility
summary: Indonesia's largest integrated petrochemical company, PT Asri Petrochemical Tbk, has been recognized for its commitment to sustainability. The company, established in 1984, aims to minimize the environmental impact of its products through its Sustainability Pillar, comprising three sub-pillars: People, Planet, and Profit. By reducing its carbon footprint, increasing conservation efforts, and promoting a circular economy, CAP has become a leader in sustainability, demonstrating its dedication to responsible growth and environmental stewardship.

site_title: About 75% of industrial emissions from refining, petrochemical sector
summary: Singapore's industries, particularly the refining and petrochemical sector, account for about 75% of the country's industrial emissions, which contribute around 60% of its total greenhouse gas emissions. In 2017, the sector emitted 52.5 million tonnes of greenhouse gases, mostly due to the combustion of fossil fuels. The government is urging industries to adopt energy-efficient technologies, with funding support increased to 50% of qualifying costs. Singapore aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 36% from 2005 levels by 2030 and has pledged to stop further increases in emissions by the same timeline.

site_title: EU to launch new impact study on Basel bank capital rules
summary: The European Union will conduct a new impact study on the Basel bank capital rules, delaying the full implementation of global capital standards. The study will gather feedback from banks and stakeholders before the European Commission decides on the final phase of Basel III. The delay aims to ensure fair implementation and avoid a collective capital shortfall of $148 billion. The move is seen as a response to concerns from banks and industry lobby groups, who argue that the rules could jeopardize dividends and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The European Union will sound out banks for a second time before implementing the final phase of global capital standards aimed at averting taxpayer bailouts in a crisis.

site_title: As Softbank's Oyo booms, some Indian hotels cry foul
summary: Softbank-backed Oyo Hotels and Homes, valued at $10 billion, is facing backlash from Indian hotel operators who claim to be blindsided by fee increases, with some accusing the company of withholding money. Oyo charges hotels a 20% franchise fee, but some operators say the startup often takes more through undisclosed fees. Discontent has grown since late last year, with over 300 hotels quitting Oyo's network this year, and hotel groups organizing protests. Oyo denies allegations, saying it operates with transparency and integrity, but hotel owners claim they were not informed of fee changes, leading to financial losses.

images.alt_text: A woman walking past a sign against Oyo, placed outside a hotel in New Delhi. An increasing number of Indian hotel operators who have partnered with it are complaining about being blindsided by fee increases.

site_title: Driving development
summary: Taiwan's Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) made a notable appearance at the ACES Awards, being nominated in two categories. As the backbone of Taiwan's petrochemical industry, CPC has been actively driving development by investing in green energy, renewable energy, and electric vehicle charging stations. The company aims to create a win-win situation between economic growth and environmental protection through sustainable operations. With plans to install 1,000 electric vehicle charging facilities and promote the market for EV charging stations and battery exchange, CPC is taking steps to support the Taiwanese government's Circular Economy policy.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: CGSI downgraded Grab to a 'hold' rating, citing slowing earnings growth in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong will retire, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal India entry with a Mumbai launch event. Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Analysts are optimistic about SGX earnings, raising target prices, citing a 'defensive play' benefiting from volatility.

site_title: Why going digital-only is not a win-win solution
summary: Singapore's push for a cashless economy may not be a win-win solution, as it could marginalize economically vulnerable people. Despite fintech investments increasing, banking penetration remains low in South-east Asia, with only 47% of the population having a bank account. An all-digital approach is seen as a recipe for failure, as the benefits of going completely cashless do not outweigh the cost of society leaving behind those without access to reliable technology. Instead, financial institutions should focus on providing flexibility and choice in managing money, and strike a balance between digital and physical transactions to cater to diverse customer needs.

site_title: US-China trade talks to resume Thursday: White House
summary: US-China trade talks are set to resume on Thursday, with Beijing's top trade envoy Liu He meeting with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. The talks focus on intellectual property rights, proprietary technologies, agriculture, and enforcement. US President Donald Trump believes a deal is likely, but warns that if not 100% in US favor, no deal will be made. The talks come as US-China tensions remain high, with ongoing tariff hikes and China's weakening economy. A deal is seen as crucial to avoid further escalation.

site_title: Thailand approves bigger 2020 budget, debates start next week
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a 3.2 trillion baht (S$145 billion) budget for the 2020 fiscal year, a 7% increase from the previous year, to bolster the country's economy, which is growing at its weakest pace in nearly five years. The budget has a projected deficit of 469 billion baht and will be submitted to parliament for approval next week, with a possible delay due to political delays.

site_title: Reading the tea leaves: When, and how hard, will the next crisis strike?
summary: The world is heading towards another global economic crisis, with multiple factors contributing to the risk, including the US-China trade war, Hong Kong turmoil, and rising tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Experts predict 2020 could be the danger year, with concerns about a severe recession and potential collapse of global financial markets. However, key fundamentals, such as stronger balance sheets and regulations, suggest the next crisis may not be as severe as the 2008 Global Financial Crisis. A balanced approach and sensible policies may help restore global economic growth by late 2021.

site_title: HSBC says Singapore recruitment plan still on track
summary: HSBC has announced plans to cut up to 10,000 staff globally, with the majority of cuts expected to occur in Europe. Despite this, the bank's Singapore recruitment plan remains on track, with plans to add over 400 retail and private banking front-end staff by 2023. Singapore is considered a key market for growth, and the bank has recently made high-profile hires in its Singapore office, including the appointment of Philip Lee as vice-chairman, South-east Asia.

site_title: Airline boss admits 'tensions' as KLM marks 100 years
summary: Air France-KLM marked its 100th anniversary with CEO Ben Smith acknowledging "tensions" over the airline's future, particularly due to the Dutch government's surprise stake increase to 14% in February. The move sparked concerns about Dutch interests being neglected, leading to flight cancellations. However, KLM CEO Pieter Elbers expressed optimism, stating that talks between the Dutch and French governments will help resolve the issue, allowing the group to move forward. The alliance's future remains uncertain, but both CEOs emphasize the need for a strong future for both companies.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at open as caution sets in ahead of trade talks
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 71.39 points, or 0.27%, to 26,502.33, amid caution ahead of US-China trade talks later in the week. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, opening 7.78 and 26.07 points lower, respectively. Investors are bracing for a potentially volatile week due to the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: German recession looms as industrial orders drop more than expected
summary: Germany's industrial orders dropped 0.6% in August, exceeding expectations, as domestic demand weakened. This data supports the notion of a manufacturing slump pushing the country into recession. Economists define a recession as two consecutive quarters of contraction, and recent data indicate continued weakness in manufacturing. The government's balanced-budget policy may face pressure to be revised, with the economy already shrinking by 0.1% in the second quarter.

site_title: Dollar breaks 4-day losing streak on trade tensions
summary: The US dollar broke a four-day losing streak due to ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, with a Bloomberg report citing reluctance from Chinese officials to agree to a broad trade deal. This kept risk appetite subdued and pressured trade-oriented currencies.

site_title: Film star Cate Blanchett decries 'heartbreaking' plight of stateless
summary: Film star Cate Blanchett urges the world to end statelessness, describing it as a "heartbreaking" waste of human talent and potential. At a Geneva meeting, she highlighted the devastating impact of statelessness, including denial of education, medical care, and basic rights. Almost every country is represented, with the UNHCR hoping the campaign will boost awareness. Blanchett, a UNHCR goodwill ambassador, met with a stateless activist and expressed her shame at not knowing about the issue until recently. She called for nations to give stateless people their basic human right to belong, stating it is a man-made problem that is solvable.

site_title: Singapore shares take lead from Wall St, add 0.7% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% on Monday, led by Wall Street's encouraging performance. The index closed at 3,099.48, driven by gains in the banking sector and conglomerate Keppel Corp. Despite US-China trade tensions and concerns over global growth, markets in Asia-Pacific countries, including Australia, Japan, and South Korea, also posted gains. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is set to deliver its monetary policy statement on October 14.

site_title: Volvo and Geely to merge engine units in electric car push
summary: Volvo Cars and Geely plan to merge their engine operations into a standalone company, cutting costs as they shift to fully electrified lineups. The combined unit will supply 2 million engines, reducing material costs and increasing scale. The move aims to free up Volvo to focus on electric powertrains and platforms in-house. No jobs will be eliminated in forming the new supplier, employing 3,000 Volvo workers and 5,000 Geely staff. The merger is part of Volvo's goal to have half of its global sales fully electric by 2025.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.33 points to 1,559.00 on Monday, driven by a 2.2 billion lots traded worth RM1.3 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 412 to 359.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.3% to 7,136.64 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.2% to 11,984.60 points. The Paris CAC 40 shed 0.4% to 5,465.58.

images.alt_text: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Monday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index down 0.3 per cent to 7,136.64 points.

site_title: Judge rejects Trump request to block New York subpoena for tax returns
summary: US President Donald Trump's request to block a New York subpoena for eight years of tax returns was rejected by a federal judge, who criticized Trump's claim of immunity from being sued. The judge abstained from resolving the dispute, dismissing Trump's lawsuit. Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance had subpoenaed tax returns and records from Trump's accounting firm, in connection with a criminal probe into the president and his family business. Trump is running for re-election and separately trying to block Deutsche Bank from handing over financial records sought by US House committees.

site_title: Social media outrage as Pakistani official buys burqas for students
summary: A district councillor in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province spent $792 on 90 burqas for students at a government-run middle school, sparking outrage on social media. The move was seen as a paternalistic attempt to protect girls from harassment, but critics argued it objectified women. An inquiry has been launched, and the provincial minister clarified that burqas are not part of the school uniform, leaving it up to individual girls to choose whether to wear them.

site_title: Hong Kong holiday protests small as stricken city cleans up
summary: Hong Kong protests remained small on Monday, with a sparse crowd gathered outside the Eastern Magistrates' courthouse where two protesters were released on bail. The city cleaned up from a chaotic weekend of clashes with police and vandalism. Activists had called for protests but failed to gain significant traction. The violence has dealt a blow to the Hong Kong economy, and the government is facing pressure to address protesters' demands for greater political freedoms. The situation remains tense, with the government considering drastic steps or a political compromise to ease tensions.

site_title: M&G Prudential bets on London with £875m 'Gotham' project
summary: M&G Prudential has invested £875 million in the construction of an office complex, dubbed Gotham City, in London. The project, which will be one of the largest in the UK, aims to capitalize on London's post-Brexit commercial property market. The 905,000 square feet complex will feature green credentials and employee well-being, and is expected to be in demand from occupiers when completed in four years. The investment is seen as a bet on London's future as an international financial hub, despite Brexit-related uncertainty.

site_title: Euro zone needs pre-emptive fiscal stimulus or may face protracted low growth - document
summary: The European Commission has warned that the euro zone economy needs pre-emptive fiscal stimulus from cash-rich countries like Germany and the Netherlands to avoid a prolonged period of low growth. The Commission's discussion paper, released ahead of a meeting of euro zone ministers, says the economy will not rebound this year and that governments should act now to stimulate growth. Germany, despite being on the brink of a recession, has resisted calls for a fiscal stimulus package, while Italy and Greece, with high public debt levels, should pursue policies to reassure markets about their debt.

site_title: UK house-price gains cool to slowest since 2013: Halifax
summary: UK house prices grew 1.1% in September from a year earlier, the slowest rate since April 2013, according to Halifax. The average price stands at £232,574. Despite political uncertainty, low interest rates and higher wage growth are preventing a sharper downturn. Halifax expects subdued activity levels and price growth to persist until economic uncertainty subsides.

site_title: Sell old Burberry online and the brand might invite you for tea
summary: Burberry is partnering with The RealReal to sell used luxury items online, offering a personal shopping session and tea to US customers who participate. The move aims to bolster appeal with environmentally conscious shoppers and capitalize on the growing online resale market. Burberry sees this as a way to raise awareness of alternative options for customers looking to refresh their wardrobe. The partnership is a rare move by a luxury brand to acknowledge the resale market, and may help the brand transition to a circular economy and boost sales during the holiday season.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down on US-China trade concerns
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.16% on Monday due to concerns over US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,375.25, while the Topix index fell 0.01%. Renewed caution about a deal between the US and China led to selling pressure, despite limited impact. The US and China are set to hold ministerial-level negotiations in Washington later this week.

site_title: Bangkok co-working spaces growing sustainably: Report
summary: Bangkok's co-working spaces are growing sustainably, with mid-sized operators posing less risk to landlords. Despite WeWork's struggles, larger players like Regus and Servcorp are thriving, while newcomer WeWork has four spaces in the city. The co-working sector accounts for 13% of annual office demand, up from 6.5% five years ago, and is expected to continue driving office demand. Central Pattana has invested in co-working spaces, while JustCo plans to expand across Asia with partnerships from conglomerates.

site_title: PropertyGuru lodges IPO prospectus to raise up to A$380m on ASX
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-East Asian real estate portal, has lodged an IPO prospectus to raise up to A$380 million on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX). The company, backed by TPG Capital and KKR, has given an indicative price range of A$3.70 to A$4.50 per share. The IPO will raise A$362.6 million, with about 30.1% to 32.2% of the company to be held by new investors and existing investors. The company aims to use the funds to pursue its growth strategy, including developing data offerings and an online mortgage marketplace.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine reached a settlement with Sete Brasil over 6 long-standing rig orders. A Keppel unit will take control of four uncompleted rigs and discuss completing two remaining rigs. Singapore's GDP is expected to increase 1.5% in Q3, narrowly avoiding a recession. The STI rose 0.7% on Monday, led by gains from Wall St. China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, a Perennial unit is seeking to start a conspiracy claim against ex-Sakae director Andy Ong.

site_title: Keppel, SembMarine settle US$10b contracts standoff with Sete Brasil
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine have settled contracts worth over US$10 billion with Sete Brasil, a Brazilian company that filed for bankruptcy amid a corruption probe. A Keppel unit will take control of four uncompleted rigs and discuss completing two remaining rigs. The settlements resolve a long-standing dispute over frozen contracts for drillships and rigs, allowing the companies to recover a significant portion of their investment.

site_title: Nikkei takes minority stake in SPH-backed AI startup DC Frontiers for US$5m
summary: Nikkei Inc has invested US$5 million in Singapore AI startup DC Frontiers, acquiring a 14.9% stake. The investment will aid DC Frontiers in expanding its capabilities, establishing offshore research centers, and accelerating sales growth. The partnership will also enable DC Frontiers to develop new applications, enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of scoutAsia, a data and news service launched by Nikkei and FT.

site_title: Parkson Retail's independent auditor raises going concern doubts
summary: Parkson Retail Asia's independent auditor has raised "going concern" doubts due to a net loss of S$34.61 million for the year ended 30 June 2019, and current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$61.33 million. The company has received a 12-month financial support commitment from its ultimate holding company, Parkson Holdings Berhad, and will issue its full annual report soon. Parkson has also reported consecutive pre-tax losses for the three most recently completed financial years.

site_title: Gold rises ahead of US-China trade negotiations
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,508.23 per ounce ahead of US-China trade negotiations, which are expected to take place in Washington on October 10-11. The uncertainty surrounding a potential trade deal has boosted gold prices, despite US President Donald Trump's optimism about a deal. The report that Chinese officials may be reluctant to agree to a broad trade deal has increased uncertainty, while ruffles in the US political front also supported gold.

site_title: Duterte's latest ailment puts new spotlight on his health
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has announced he is suffering from a chronic neuromuscular disorder, ocular myasthenia, causing one eyelid to droop. The 74-year-old leader has had the condition for a long time and has been working despite his health issues, which include back problems, migraines, and other ailments. Allies downplay concern, citing his high approval rating and super-majority in Congress, making an opposition challenge unlikely. Duterte's latest illness comes as he has been on a busy schedule, fueling rumors about his declining health.

site_title: Vodafone tests new network tech in UK in challenge to 'big three' suppliers
summary: Vodafone is testing innovative OpenRAN technology in the UK, standardizing radio access network design and potentially disrupting the market dominated by Huawei, Ericsson, and Nokia. This technology enables lower costs for customers, particularly in rural areas. Vodafone has already deployed OpenRAN in Turkey and plans to launch it in 120 rural areas in Britain. The company aims to fast-track OpenRAN into Europe, seeking to expand its list of vendors and improve network economics. This move could challenge the "big three" suppliers and potentially lower mobile costs for consumers.

site_title: Non-metro areas in South-east Asia to drive the next phase of Internet economy growth
summary: Non-metro areas in South-east Asia are poised to drive the next phase of Internet economy growth, according to a report by Google, Temasek Holdings, and Bain & Company. The region's digital payments market is expected to reach $1 trillion by 2025, with growth in non-metro areas projected to be four times faster than in metro areas. Indonesia and Vietnam are leading the charge, with their internet economies projected to reach $130 billion and $12 billion, respectively, by 2025. This shift is driven by increasing adoption of digital payments and telecom carrier billing options, enabling more consumers to access premium online services.

site_title: Australia shares follow Wall Street higher on a quiet day
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6563.60, tracking Wall Street gains after US employment data reduced recession concerns. Trading was subdued due to public holidays, with volumes at one-third of their 30-day average. Mining stocks, led by gold stocks, drove the ASX 200 index higher, while technology stocks also gained 1.4%. The recovery from a 3% weekly loss marked the end of the worst week for Australian stocks in 11 months.

site_title: Sri Lanka's Rajapakse clan steps up new bid for power
summary: Sri Lanka's election commission has allowed Gotabhaya Rajapakse, brother of former strongman Mahinda Rajapakse, to run for president despite corruption cases. Gotabhaya is seen as a front to get Mahinda back into power, who is barred from contesting due to a two-term limit. Mahinda's Sri Lanka Freedom Party will not enter a candidate, and Sajith Premadasa is his main challenger. The election is set for November 16, with 16 million people eligible to vote.

site_title: Apple supplier Japan Display says aims to seal 50b yen bailout deal this month
summary: Japan Display aims to seal a 50 billion yen (S$645 million) bailout deal by the end of the month, following a Chinese investor group's withdrawal from a plan. New CEO Minoru Kikuoka cited renewed interest in LCD screens due to solid demand for affordable smartphones. Major clients, including Apple, are expected to contribute US$350 million, easing cash shortfall risks. Japan Display has been unprofitable for five years, shifting to OLED screens that have cost it orders from Apple.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine settles with Sete Brasil over its 7 drillship contracts
summary: Sembcorp Marine settles with Sete Brasil for $5.6 billion in drillship contracts, terminating seven contracts after a corruption probe forced the Brazilian company into bankruptcy. The parties will mutually release each other from claims, with Sembcorp keeping five drillships and splitting the remaining two. The settlement ends arbitration proceedings, which began in 2016.

site_title: Offer for Star Pharmaceutical closes with enough acceptances for delisting
summary: The offer for Star Pharmaceutical, a Singapore-listed prescription drugmaker, has closed with enough acceptances to take the company private. As of October 7, about 42.68 million shares, or 93.06% of the total shares outstanding, have been accepted. Trading will be suspended, and the company is expected to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange. The offeror's executive chairman successfully bid to take the company private, marking a significant change for the pharmaceutical company.

site_title: Singapore seen narrowly dodging recession in Q3, MAS to ease: poll
summary: Singapore's economy narrowly escaped a technical recession in Q3, with a median forecast of 1.5% quarterly GDP growth, according to a Reuters poll. This follows a 3.3% drop in the second quarter, the biggest contraction in nearly seven years. Despite this, analysts expect the outlook to remain weak due to global demand faltering. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to ease monetary policy at its semiannual review on Oct 14.

site_title: SGX queries GCCP on independent director resignation and board reshuffle
summary: SGX queried GCCP Resources on the sudden resignation of independent director Teng Chang Yeow on Oct 1, despite the company announcing the news on the same day. GCCP stated Mr. Teng submitted his resignation letter on Sept 27 and the board agreed to terms on Sept 30, but waived his one-month notice period.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,101.68, up 0.76% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.76% to 3,101.68 on Monday, driven by gains from local banks and other Asian markets. The index saw 246 million securities worth S$286.1 million trade. The US unemployment rate fell to its lowest in nearly 50 years, easing concerns about the US economy.

site_title: SoftBank's Son is 'embarrassed' by record, impatient to improve
summary: SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son expresses frustration with his company's underperformance, calling himself "embarrassed" and "impatient" with the current state of his investments. Despite building a $13.8 billion personal fortune, Son cites trouble at Uber and WeWork as casting doubt on SoftBank's track record. He remains optimistic about the potential of his investments, particularly in AI, and has a 30-year plan for the company. However, SoftBank's shares have dropped by 31% since April, and Son is seeking to woo investors for an even bigger fund.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group Corp's Masayoshi Son says he is unhappy with how far short his accomplishments to date have fallen of his goals.

site_title: US to help secure Baltic energy grid against cyber attacks
summary: US Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Baltic counterparts agree to strengthen cybersecurity against cyber attacks on the Baltic energy grid, amid Lithuania's efforts to disconnect from Russia's electricity grid. The US will provide strategic and technical support, including modernizing software to prevent Russian hacker attacks. Lithuania seeks US technology firms to enhance energy system security, while the Baltic trio aims to integrate into the European energy grid by 2025. A cooperation platform for cyber security experts will be set up within six months.

site_title: Russia's deputy PM returns to idea of grain Opec creation: Interfax
summary: Russia's Deputy Prime Minister Alexei Gordeyev has proposed creating a grain organization similar to Opec, citing the need for stability on the grain market and global coordination among leading grain producers. He suggested the group could include Russia, the European Union, the US, Canada, and Argentina, and would aim to solve world hunger problems. This idea has been revived after Gordeyev's return to the government in 2018, with a meeting with German Agriculture Minister Julia Kloeckner in Cologne, where he proposed discussing global coordination among grain producers.

site_title: Oxley makes Australia property firm Pindan its wholly-owned unit
summary: Oxley Holdings has acquired the remaining 60% interest in Perth-headquartered property firm Pindan Group for zero consideration. This follows a claim by Oxley related to Pindan's failure to meet agreed performance targets. The acquisition was settled through the transfer of 45.5 million shares from three Pindan shareholders. The deal does not disclose details of the performance targets.

site_title: Businessman gets 15 months' jail for raising funds without a prospectus
summary: A Singapore court sentenced Tay Chee Ming, 54, to 15 months' imprisonment for raising S$6-8 million in funds from investors without a prospectus between 2006 and 2007. Tay, director of Brandz Group Pte Ltd, breached the Securities and Futures Act by signing a convertible loan agreement with each investor, who were promised equity in the company if it listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. The court found Tay liable for 25 charges, with 16 lenders loaning S$2.825 million.

site_title: Flying taxis in Singapore to test cleaner, quieter sky ride
summary: A British company, Skyports Ltd, is building the world's first "vertiport" for electric aircraft in Singapore, a key step towards a global network for flying taxis. The vertiport will be demonstrated during the Intelligent Transport Systems World Congress, with a test flight by Volocopter GmbH's electric aircraft. Citigroup expects the air taxi industry to reach $5 billion by 2030, with 20,000 electric passenger aircraft sold annually. The technology aims to provide cleaner, quieter transportation, with a range of 50 miles and costs comparable to limousine rides.

site_title: First Hong Kongers appear in court for defying mask ban
summary: Hong Kong democracy protesters defied a new face mask ban, leading to arrests and court appearances. The ban, invoked by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, was aimed at quelling four months of pro-democracy rallies. The first two defendants, a university student and a 38-year-old woman, were charged with unlawful assembly and defying the mask ban, carrying up to three years in jail. Protests continue, with demonstrators calling the ban unjust and fearing more emergency orders to come.

site_title: Singapore poultry industry to get first smart and green factory with S$40m UOB loan
summary: Singapore's Singapore Poultry Hub is launching the country's first smart and green factory with a S$40 million loan from UOB. The 29,384 square meter factory will improve productivity by 26% and increase capacity by 70%. The factory will utilize robotics, Industry 4.0 technologies, and industrial IoT to process 16,000 chickens per hour and reduce waste by 60 tonnes per day. The facility will also convert poultry waste into protein for livestock feed, making the hub more sustainable.

site_title: Former VP Joe Biden reassures top donors he's ready to battle Trump
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden has reassured top donors that he's ready to battle President Donald Trump, following a lackluster fundraising quarter. A summit in Philadelphia brought together 100 top donors, who received briefings and a 90-minute address from Biden. The campaign laid out its strategy, citing under four months until the Iowa caucuses. Despite eroding front-runner status, Biden acknowledged being slow to respond to Trump's attacks and expressed determination to counter them. The campaign is spending $6 million on ads portraying Trump as "unhinged."

site_title: US futures drop, yuan dips as trade talks loom
summary: US stock futures fell 0.4% as a report suggested China may be reluctant to agree to a broad trade deal with the Trump administration, causing the yen to edge up and the yuan to slip. The US-China trade talks, set to begin this week, have traders focusing on global growth, with disappointing economic data sparking fears of an economic slowdown. Oil prices also declined, and the yield on 10-year Treasuries dipped slightly.

site_title: Oil keeps falling on signs trade talks won't bring demand relief
summary: Oil prices fell for the eighth consecutive day, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) for November delivery dropping 11 US cents to $52.70 a barrel. The decline is attributed to worsening demand outlook due to the US-China trade war, with Chinese officials signaling reluctance to agree to a comprehensive trade deal. The end of the US summer driving season and reduced spare capacity are also contributing factors. Analysts believe macro headwinds outweigh supply concerns, with the global benchmark crude trading at a premium of $5.53 to WTI for the same month.

site_title: Mun Siong Engineering withdraws from proposed US joint venture
summary: Mun Siong Engineering has withdrawn from its proposed 75% joint venture in the US with businessman Gary Harvey, citing a principal financial institution's inability to provide guidance on the venture by the Sept 30 deadline. The company's board decided to allow the operating agreement to lapse, allowing Mun Siong to continue seeking business opportunities in the North America market. Mun Siong will maintain its 100% ownership of the US subsidiary, Pegasus Advance Engineering (US), and will not contribute the initial $3 million in funds.

site_title: Amazon, Walmart find success in rural India during sales season
summary: Amazon and Walmart reported record revenue from their six-day India sales festivals, as e-commerce gains traction in smaller towns and rural areas beyond urban centers. The sales, dubbed the Great Indian Festival and Big Billion Days, focused on expanding online commerce to 500 cities and 65,000 sellers. Neither company disclosed revenue figures, but both claimed record activity. This marks a significant milestone for the e-commerce giants in India, where they have been competing since Walmart acquired Flipkart Online Services last year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end little changed as investors eye trade talks
summary: South Korean stocks closed flat on Monday as investors awaited US-China trade talks, which begin on October 10-11. China signaled reluctance to agree to a broad trade deal, while Samsung Electronics is expected to report a 60% decline in July-September operating profit. Foreigners were net sellers of 21.6 billion won worth of shares, while the won was little changed against the dollar. The Kospi ended up 1.04 points, or 0.05%, at 2,021.73, with the benchmark bond yield rising.

site_title: Trade disruption: will Southeast Asia benefit?
summary: Southeast Asia, particularly Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia, is poised to benefit from the ongoing US-China trade tensions. With over 70% of respondents expecting the trade disruption to continue, companies are shifting their supply chains, leading to increased investments in the region. ASEAN countries have implemented tax incentives to attract foreign direct investments (FDIs), which have remained resilient despite global declines. The region's FTAs, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, also offer opportunities for businesses. To capitalize on these benefits, Southeast Asian governments should focus on stability, transparency, and professional support for FTA utilization.

site_title: Some US$71b of Japanese coal assets at risk from cheaper renewables
summary: US$71 billion of Japanese coal assets are at risk due to cheaper renewable energy, according to a report by the University of Tokyo, Carbon Tracker, and the Carbon Disclosure Project. The report found that low utilisation rates and cheaper onshore and offshore wind, as well as large-scale solar PV, could jeopardise Japan's planned and existing coal capacity. The report used project financial models to analyse the economics of new and existing coal plants in Japan, highlighting the growing threat of cheaper renewables to the country's coal industry.

site_title: Samsung's stock is signalling a bottom for the global chip market
summary: Samsung Electronics Co's stock has rallied 24% this year as investors anticipate the global memory-chip cycle is near a bottom. Analysts expect the company to post operating income of 6.9 trillion won in its third-quarter results, a significant improvement from last year's record. The company's shares have overcome three straight quarters of disappointing earnings, driven by concerns over the US-China trade war and South Korea's spat with Japan. Despite potential short-term corrections, analysts believe the semiconductor industry has reached a bottom and is poised for a medium-term rebound.

site_title: Knight Frank appoints new global real estate chief
summary: Knight Frank Singapore appoints Daniel Ding as its new head of investment and capital markets, effective January 1, 2020. Ding, former CEO of Soilbuild Construction, brings nearly 20 years of experience in real estate business development across Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, and the UK. He will focus on capitalizing on cross-border transactions and report to group managing director Wendy Tang.

site_title: 2 men get jail terms for spoofing index futures, giving SGX false information
summary: Two Singaporean men, Jimmy Ng Kian Bin and Erik Ng Song Hann, have been sentenced to 16 weeks and 4 weeks of imprisonment respectively for spoofing index futures and providing false information to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). They were found guilty of inducing other market participants to enter the market with fake orders, creating a false impression of supply and demand. The duo was from Joerik Financial Pte Ltd, a proprietary trading firm and SGX trading member. Their actions were deemed as "spoofing" in the Singapore derivatives market in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Disney's new sky gondola stalls midair with passengers aboard
summary: A Disney Skyliner gondola system at Walt Disney World in Florida came to a halt midair on Saturday night, stranding 300 passengers for over three hours. The problem occurred on one of the system's five stations, causing several gondolas to scrunched up together in an apparent collision. Passengers were eventually rescued by firefighters, who used special equipment to lift people out. The cause of the problem remains unknown, and the gondola system is currently shut down, with no clear reopening date.

site_title: Asia: Shares up on US jobs report, but caution seen on trade talks
summary: Asian shares rose on Monday following the US unemployment rate's drop to nearly 50 years low, easing concerns of a slowdown in the US economy. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index increased 0.18%, while US stock futures fell 0.44% after the S&P 500 surged 1.4% on Friday. However, caution remains on trade talks between the US and China, with the offshore yuan falling 0.3% and safe-haven assets like gold and the yen rising. The US-China trade negotiations are set to begin on October 10-11, with investors monitoring the outcome.

site_title: Bugis Cube launched for collective sale with S$230m reserve price
summary: Bugis Cube, a six-storey commercial building in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale via a public tender exercise with a reserve price of S$230 million. The building features 119 strata-titled retail shops and a 999-year leasehold site zoned "commercial" with a plot ratio of 4.2. Owners holding at least 80% of the property's share value and strata area have agreed to the collective sale, which closes on November 14. Prospective buyers can add value through asset enhancement initiatives, and the property's location near Bugis Junction and other popular areas is expected to attract interest.

site_title: China's CNPC quits flagship Iran gas project as sanctions bite
summary: China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) has withdrawn from Iran's flagship South Pars gas project, with Iran taking sole control of Phase 11. CNPC, the only international partner, was "dismissed" from the project due to US sanctions on Iran. Total SA of France withdrew last year, and Iran's Petropars will now develop Phase 11, which is expected to produce 500 million cubic feet of gas per day by March 2020. The move reflects the challenges faced by international energy companies in Iran since the US reimposed sanctions.

site_title: Italian opera star Marcello Giordani dies, aged 56
summary: Italian opera star Marcello Giordani, 56, died of a heart attack at his home in Sicily. He was known for his role as Calaf in Puccini's Turandot at open-air theatres in Sicily just last month. The New York Metropolitan Opera expressed condolences to his family and friends.

site_title: Malaysia seeking 1MDB funds from Najib's brother, ex-ministers
summary: Malaysia is seeking approximately RM420 million (S$138 million) from 80 individuals and entities, including Nazir Razak, former chairman of CIMB Group Holdings, and former cabinet ministers Ahmad Maslan and Shahrir Samad, in connection with 1MDB funds. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission will not pursue charges against those who voluntarily return the money. The move is part of a pragmatic approach to recouping funds lost through the troubled state fund 1MDB.

site_title: British PM Johnson warns EU he will not delay Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned the European Union on Sunday that he will not delay Brexit beyond October 31, despite British MPs passing a law requiring him to seek a delay if he fails to secure an agreement. Johnson told French President Emmanuel Macron that the UK will leave the EU on the original deadline, rejecting the possibility of an extension. This move comes as the UK and EU prepare for a make-or-break EU summit on October 17-18.

site_title: NBA executive's Hong Kong tweet starts firestorm in China
summary: NBA general manager Daryl Morey's tweet supporting Hong Kong protesters sparked a firestorm in China, prompting sponsors and media outlets to pull partnerships and threatening the league's largest international market. Morey attempted to clarify his statement, but the damage had already been done. The controversy exposed the NBA's reputation as a sports league that encourages free speech and commentary on politics. Despite walking back his comments, the league and the Rockets face potential backlash domestically and internationally, with the NBA's China market potentially at risk.

images.alt_text: The general manager of the Houston Rockets sought to quell an outcry in China on Sunday night after the support he expressed on Twitter for pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong upset sponsors, media outlets and basketball officials in a country that invests billions in the NBA.

site_title: Australian shares rise in slim trade; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by Wall Street's strength despite moderate US employment data. Trading volumes were subdued due to public holidays. Mining stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, contributed to the gains. Financial stocks and technology stocks also rose, with Afterpay Touch Group leading the way. New Zealand shares rose 0.6% amid broad-based gains, led by Fonterra's 6% rise.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
