While a slowdown in office demand is possible, landlords can mitigate losses by focusing on tenant retention and managing rents expiring in the next couple of years.

site_title: Grange Road carpark to transform into event space
summary: A 4,482 square metre carpark in Grange Road, Singapore, will be transformed into a permanent event space by March 1, 2019, as part of the government's efforts to rejuvenate Orchard Road. The carpark, operated by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, will host activities such as flea markets, pop-up attractions, and food trucks, and serve as a public space on non-event days. The transformation aims to bring more activities outside of shopping malls and make Orchard Road more pedestrian-friendly, following plans announced in 2017 to revive the shopping belt.

images.alt_text: The open-air carpark in Grange Road will be turned into a permanent event space for pop-up events and entertainment, as part of government efforts to rejuvenate Orchard Road and encourage more activities outside of its shopping malls.

site_title: JBS USA to produce pork without growth drug banned by China, seeking more exports
summary: JBS USA, a US pork producer, will remove the growth drug ractopamine from its US hog supply, citing an expected shortage in China due to African swine fever. The move aims to serve the Chinese market, which bans the drug. The company will also prohibit the drug from diets of hogs owned by farmers who sell to JBS USA. This decision follows rival Smithfield Foods, which already raises ractopamine-free hogs, and comes as demand for US pork expands. The change is expected to provide long-term benefits to the industry by ensuring US pork can compete fairly in the international market.

site_title: Tiki time
summary: Singapore's Taki Taki tiki bar celebrates the region's migrant communities with its latest menu, inspired by cuisines from Thailand, India, and others. The bar's founders aim to capture the spirit of hospitality, warmth, and "tiki time" through its decor, music, and staff. The menu features unique cocktails incorporating ingredients from local "secret little places," such as a Nyonya Daiquiri and a Hanoi-inspired drink. Taki Taki joins Rum Bellion, a day-long festival and street party, on October 13, featuring top rum brands and guest shifts from other tiki bars.

site_title: Oil settles up as US unemployment rate drops, but crude ends week down 5%
summary: US oil prices rose 1% on Friday as a drop in unemployment eased concerns about a slowing global economy, but crude fell 5% for the week, its second consecutive decline. Brent crude futures settled at $58.37 a barrel, up 66 cents, while WTI crude futures rose 36 cents to $52.81 a barrel. Despite the short-term gain, Brent futures fell 5.7% for the week and WTI lost 5.5% for the week, their largest weekly declines since July.

site_title: OCBC serves Triyards statutory demand over debts
summary: OCBC Bank served a statutory demand of US$11.6 million and 1.13 billion Vietnamese dong on Triyards Holdings for unpaid debts. The demand was issued for a deed of guarantee and indemnity granted by OCBC to Triyards' subsidiary Strategic Marine. Triyards has stated it is assessing the impact and exploring an amicable resolution. This move follows similar actions by other financial institutions, including DBS Bank and Hong Leong Finance. Triyards shares have been suspended from trading since 2017.

site_title: Reits (October 5-6, 2019)
summary: US mortgage rates rise after five weeks of declines, with no clear end to the trend. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record, with further increases predicted. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, while Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. New World is selling its China property assets following a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at its Singapore location after the company's bankruptcy.

site_title: Tech-savvy residents go nimby on self-driving cars
summary: Tech-savvy Silicon Valley residents are expressing concerns about self-driving cars being tested in their neighborhoods, citing a lack of understanding of the technology. Local experts, including a computer scientist, question how engineers can teach autonomous vehicles to make snap decisions and yield to pedestrians. Some residents are taking matters into their own hands, such as wearing shiny vests while cycling to ensure autonomous vehicles spot them. The concerns highlight a potential issue with implementing self-driving cars in densely populated areas.

site_title: Porsche Taycan Turbo S: Assault and batteries
summary: The Porsche Taycan Turbo S is a full-fledged electric vehicle that puts performance and driving pleasure at the forefront. With an 800-volt wiring system, it can be recharged at a rate of 350kilowatts, offering up to 100km of range in just five minutes. The car boasts 761 horsepower and 1,050 Newton-metres of torque, capable of shooting from 0-100km/h in 2.8 seconds. While it has minor drawbacks, including weight and width, the Taycan is a real Porsche with impressive performance, well-weighted steering, and a balanced ride. Pricing starts at S$700,000, making it a premium electric car.

site_title: Flagging market concerns
summary: South Korea and Japan are locked in a stalemate of sideways market activity due to their escalating trade spat. Japan's remilitarization under Prime Minister Abe has led to economic consequences, including the tightening of controls over crucial chemicals for Korea's semiconductor production. This has delayed exports, posing a threat to Korea's economy and the global tech supply chain. The Kospi and Nikkei indices are in a range-bound sideways market activity, with neither able to regain a decisive advantage, as investors seek better returns from more strongly trending markets.

site_title: US jobs growth rises moderately in Sept; jobless rate drops to near 50-year low
summary: US jobs growth rose moderately in September, with a 3.5% unemployment rate near a 50-year low. Non-farm payrolls increased by 136,000 jobs, despite manufacturing payrolls declining for the first time in six months. Wage growth remained unchanged, and the retail sector continued to shed jobs. The report comes amid ongoing trade tensions, which economists believe could impact the economy. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates at least once more this year due to trade uncertainty.

site_title: Green utilities are starting to outperform
summary: Renewable energy companies are outperforming the utilities sector, driven by European governments' efforts to boost spending on tackling climate change. Analysts predict a "golden age" for renewables, with investments doubling to 60 billion euros per year. Companies like Orsted, RWE, and Enel are expected to benefit from structurally growing capex pipelines and climate champions will see a 9-12% compounded annual growth rate by 2030. However, valuation concerns may deter investors, and caution is advised for German utilities due to reduced budget allocations for closing coal-fired power plants.

site_title: DBS must bulk up or lose fintech turf in S-E Asia
summary: Singapore's DBS Group Holdings, the largest lender in Southeast Asia, is struggling to maintain its fintech turf in the region. Despite its tech-savvy approach, the bank is missing out on deals, with Citigroup emerging as the top challenger. The Internet economy in Southeast Asia is expected to exceed $100 billion this year and triple by 2025, making online commerce a new battleground. DBS needs to bulk up in the region to capitalize on its digital promise, but its lack of scale outside Singapore and regulatory hurdles pose challenges.

site_title: US mortgage rates hold steady, could be primed to move lower
summary: US mortgage rates remained steady at 3.65% for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, 3.14% for 15-year fixed-rate mortgages, and 3.38% for 5-year adjustable-rate mortgages. Despite downward economic news, including cooling consumer spending and a manufacturing index at its lowest level since 2009, rates have not dropped as expected. Economists attribute the stability to investor concerns over recession fears, which have led to safer asset investments and rising US Treasury yields.

site_title: New hedge fund takes aim at badly governed companies in Japan
summary: A new hedge fund at Union Bancaire Privee (UBP) plans to launch by year-end, targeting undervalued companies with good governance while shorting richly valued businesses with weak oversight in Japan. The fund, led by ZUHAIR Khan, aims to capitalize on the poorly governed companies at risk of scandal. The long-short fund will initially focus on about 30 undervalued companies and short roughly 60 richly valued businesses. Khan, who recently left his position at Jefferies Japan, aims to capitalize on the list's recognition for poorly governed companies.

site_title: Shareholder value vs shareholder welfare
summary: Luigi Zingales, a University of Chicago Booth School of Business professor, argues that companies should prioritize shareholder welfare over maximizing profits. This shift is a response to the growing interest in sustainability and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues among investors. Zingales believes that the Friedman rule, which prioritizes profit maximization, can be adapted to include social and ethical considerations. He recommends that companies aim to maximize shareholder utility or welfare, rather than just shareholder value. This change in approach is seen as a response to the limitations of the traditional shareholder primacy model, which has been criticized for ignoring the interests of other stakeholders, such as customers and employees.

site_title: WeWork bosses tell employees job cuts may come this month
summary: WeWork's new co-CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham told employees that job cuts may occur as soon as this month, with an estimated 2,000 positions at risk, representing 16% of the company's 12,500 employees. The layoffs will be handled "humanely" and are part of cost-cutting efforts to "right-size" the business. Executives emphasized the company's core business and customer focus, and expect continued growth at a slower pace, with potential divestitures and a sale of recent acquisitions. The move comes after the company's IPO plan was derailed and the ouster of co-founder Adam Neumann.

site_title: EU to keep US islands on tax blacklist, drop UAE, Switzerland
summary: European Union finance ministers are set to remove the United Arab Emirates and Switzerland from the bloc's lists of tax havens, dropping the UAE from the blacklist and removing Switzerland from the grey list. The US territories of American Samoa, Guam, and the US Virgin Islands will remain on the blacklist, sparking ongoing friction with Washington. The move aims to reduce tax dodging and reputational damage for blacklisted states, with the EU monitoring jurisdictions' compliance with tax standards.

site_title: Britain, EU need new Brexit draft in week to avoid delay or chaos
summary: Britain and the EU must agree on a draft Brexit text by next Friday to avoid a chaotic no-deal divorce or another Brexit delay. European officials warn that a detailed deal may not be feasible by the deadline, and if not met, Prime Minister Boris Johnson may request a Brexit extension or Britain quits the bloc without a deal. Talks between British and EU negotiators are ongoing, with a focus on the Irish border and customs arrangements, but deep disagreements remain, particularly over monitoring border trade and the North Ireland provincial assembly.

site_title: Vancouver home market stabilising after slump
summary: Vancouver's home market is stabilizing after a policy-driven slump, with home sales rebounding 46% in September compared to the same period last year. This marks the third consecutive month of increased sales, indicating a possible recovery in Canada's most expensive home market.

site_title: Singapore shares extend losses on Fri, end 1.5% lower on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week at 3,078.36, 9.61 points or 0.3% lower, due to disappointing US manufacturing and employment data. The decline was exacerbated by US President Donald Trump's impeachment saga and the trade war with the European Union. Despite this, investors remain hopeful that the US Federal Reserve will lower rates this month, boosting the market. The STI fell 1.5% on the week, with trading volume reaching 1.01 billion securities.

site_title: Dismal currencies paint a bleak picture for global growth
summary: Global currencies are experiencing a bleak outlook for growth, with lesser-traded currencies like Australia's and New Zealand's dollars and Norway's and Sweden's krone reaching historic lows. This decline reflects deepening recession risks, souring economic data, and uncertainty over monetary policy's ability to boost struggling economies. Key currencies are vulnerable due to their ties to commodity exports, global trade, and monetary policy. Investors are increasingly skeptical of central banks' firepower to drive gains, leaving growth-linked currencies exposed.

site_title: Social media: What's behind those 'likes'
summary: A Facebook post by a former schoolmate boasting about buying a condo and Porsche on the same day sparked controversy, with some labeling it as "humble bragging." The post's author likely exaggerated their financial situation, as purchasing a Porsche would be financially crippling. The incident highlights the pitfalls of social media, where people often present curated, unrealistic versions of their lives.

site_title: How to deal with knee and back pain
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article provides tips on dealing with knee and back pain caused by overexertion or repetitive strain. For knee pain, exercises like single leg bridges, lateral walking, and foam rolling can help reduce soreness. Tight quadriceps can also contribute to knee pain, which can be alleviated by reducing tension and promoting blood flow. For back pain, gentle mobilization through cat-camel stretches and stability exercises targeting the transverse abdominis can help. It's essential to address back pain promptly, as poor posture and muscle strains can lead to more severe issues. Consult a physical therapist for a personalized plan.

site_title: Bond markets' tea leaves send sobering signal: trouble is ahead
summary: Global bond markets signal a sobering outlook, indicating stalled economic growth and fading inflation expectations. Benchmark yields on Treasuries and German bunds have tumbled, while inflation metrics project further declines in price pressures. Investors are piling into safety trades, with risks growing for global output in 2020, driven by headwinds such as the US impeachment inquiry, Brexit, and the trade war. Monetary policy is seen as a weak tool, and falling breakeven rates signal the Federal Reserve's stimulus efforts are failing to boost inflation.

site_title: SGX rejects two attempts by Renaissance to issue new shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Renaissance United's application to issue new shares at a revised price of S$0.0011 per share, citing concerns that the move could artificially inflate the company's market capitalization. The company had initially applied for 1.23 billion new shares at S$0.0009 each, but SGX rejected the first application due to the same concerns. The rejection follows a revised application, which also failed to address SGX's concerns. Renaissance will continue to explore fundraising options.

site_title: Hong Kong police fire tear gas hours after government imposes emergency laws
summary: Hong Kong police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in the New Territories district of Sha Tin on October 4, 2019, hours after the government imposed emergency laws to quell violent unrest. Embattled leader Carrie Lam invoked colonial-era emergency powers for the first time in over 50 years, prompting protesters to take to the streets. Masked demonstrators built barricades and held flash-mob rallies in multiple districts, continuing a four-month-long wave of protests. The move enraged protesters, who have been demanding greater autonomy and freedoms.

site_title: Indonesia online mall valued at US$2.5b after getting funding
summary: PT Bukalapak.com, an Indonesian online marketplace, has raised capital from investors, valuing it at over US$2.5 billion. The Jakarta-based startup received funding from Emtek and Shinhan Financial Group Co, following a previous valuation of US$2 billion. Bukalapak had previously announced plans to cut 10% of its workforce to focus on profitability. The funding round comes after the company's shares experienced a US$2.2 billion sell-off.

site_title: How to redefine business for today's 'New Humanity'
summary: Business leaders are seeking direction as Big Data adoption continues to rise, with 59% of enterprises using it, and 43% of business leaders reporting failed data-led projects. However, consumers are increasingly seeking personalization, with 63% expecting it from brands, despite concerns over data privacy. The key to success lies in using technology to build human connections and purpose, rather than just focusing on efficiency and profit. By prioritizing empathy and compassion, businesses can create a sense of community purpose and tailor their experiences to meet the needs of their audiences.

site_title: Greta Thunberg mocks Putin's 'kind girl' jibes on Twitter
summary: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg responded to Russian President Vladimir Putin's patronizing comments about her on Twitter, changing her biography to "A kind but poorly informed teenager" after Putin described her as a "kind girl" at a Moscow forum. Thunberg had previously sailed across the Atlantic to speak at the UN climate summit, prompting Putin's remarks. Thunberg's wit and resilience have earned her praise, with some speculating she may win the Nobel Peace Prize this year.

site_title: US jobs growth rises moderately; unemployment rate falls to 3.5%
summary: US job growth rose moderately in September, with the unemployment rate falling to 3.5%, near a 50-year low. Nonfarm payrolls increased by 136,000 jobs, while manufacturing payrolls declined for the first time in six months. Despite moderate job growth, wages were unchanged, and the Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again due to trade policy uncertainty.

site_title: Microsoft delivers a wake-up call
summary: Microsoft has announced its return to the smartphone market with the Surface Duo, a phone featuring two 5.6-inch displays held together by a 360-degree hinge. The device is expected to run a heavily skinned Android operating system and is set to be released in late 2020. Meanwhile, Lego's Imperial Star Destroyer set, the longest Star Wars set ever, is now available in Singapore for S$1,099.90, featuring intricate details and a buildable Tantive IV ship.

site_title: Trendlines: Proposed rights issue at 19.3% premium a better gauge of its value
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore startup incubator, has proposed a rights issue at a 19.3% premium to its current market price of 8.8 Singapore cents, citing its current market price "does not properly reflect the company's value." The company has received a commitment from Librae Holdings to subscribe for its entitlements and excess rights shares, representing 100% of the rights shares in the minimum subscription scenario. Trendlines plans to use the funds for working capital and investments in its portfolio companies.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on modest job growth in Sept
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday after data showed a moderate increase in job growth in September, with the unemployment rate dropping to a 50-year low. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.27% to 26,271.70, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained 0.27% and 0.46%, respectively. This eased concerns of a slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: Full steam ahead for 5G trials, but factories here still cautious
summary: Singapore is investing S$40 million in 5G enterprise trials for its SMART manufacturing cluster, aiming to encourage Industry 4.0 ambitions. However, despite the government's efforts, factories in the country are cautious about adopting the new technology, potentially hindering the country's transition to Industry 4.0. This caution may be due to the relatively new nature of 5G, which is stymying policymakers' progress in this area.

site_title: Paul Allen's estate selling Beverly Hills site for US$110m
summary: The late Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's 120-acre Beverly Hills estate, "The Enchanted Hill," is being sold for $110 million, a discount from its previous price of $150 million. The property, which offers city and mountain views, features five flat lots that could be used for a single-family home or subdivided for 15 homes. Four individuals have expressed interest in developing their own gated community, and the site's new owner could create a luxurious residential development similar to Beverly Park or Mulholland Estates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.45 points to 1,557.67. Volume was 2.0 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 413 to 400.

site_title: One Championship readies for blockbuster 100th show
summary: One Championship is set to celebrate its 100th "live" event, "One: Century", in Tokyo on October 13, featuring seven world title bouts and 28 world champions. The event will be followed by debut shows in South Korea and the US in 2020. CEO Chatri Sityodtong credits the organization's success to perseverance and hard work, despite initial rejections and doubts from broadcasters and brands. One Championship plans to expand its reach through esports and a video game, and is also exploring an IPO.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in August as exports slow
summary: The US trade deficit widened by nearly $1 billion in August, surpassing economists' expectations, as weakening foreign demand and a strong US dollar fueled imports. The trade balance rose 1.6% to $54.9 billion, with exports growing 0.2% and imports increasing 0.5%. The deficit has increased 7% in the first eight months of the year, weighing on GDP calculations for the third quarter. The decline in exports, particularly in the aircraft sector, and a deepening trade deficit with China, Mexico, and the EU are expected to continue, impacting US exports towards the end of the year.

site_title: Half of Dutch cheese exports to be hit by US trade tariffs
summary: Dutch cheese exports to the US will face a 25% tariff, affecting around 39 million euros worth of cheese, starting October 18. The US imposed the tariffs as retaliation for EU aircraft subsidies. The Netherlands, the world's second-largest agricultural exporter, exported 80 million euros worth of cheese to the US last year. This move is part of a long-running trade dispute between the US and the EU.

site_title: Johnson will ask for Brexit extension if no deal by Oct 19 - court documents
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will submit a letter to the European Union requesting a Brexit delay if no divorce deal is agreed by October 19, according to court documents. This move comes after opposition lawmakers forced through a law requiring Johnson to request an extension. Johnson has previously stated that the UK will leave the EU "do or die" on October 31, but the government has accepted that he must send a letter to the EU asking for a delay.

site_title: Kudlow says Trump team "open-minded" about US-China talks next week
summary: US White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow stated that the US team is "open-minded" about the outcome of US-China trade talks next week. The talks, scheduled for Monday to Friday, come after a "softening of the psychology on both sides" in the past month, with the US delaying some tariff increases and China making modest purchases of American farm products. No predictions were made about the talks' outcome, but Kudlow expressed optimism about the prospects for a deal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Chinese Global Investors Group, a Catalist-listed investment holding company, has been served a statutory demand for S$41,958.12 by lawyers representing former CFO Kemmy Koh Ai Ping. The demand is for unpaid remuneration from April to July 2019. If the company fails to pay within 21 days, it may be deemed unable to pay its debts and Koh may apply for a winding up order. Meanwhile, Capital World has secured a S$5.5 million convertible loan, and MeGroup has entered a definitive sale and purchase agreement to acquire an additional 25% stake in its subsidiary MJN Motors Sdn Bhd.

site_title: China investment returns to Asean amid trade war
summary: China's investments in ASEAN have rebounded to $11 billion for the first six months of 2019, doubling the amount in the prior period. The recovery was led by Indonesia, Cambodia, Singapore, and Vietnam, with Malaysia's East Coast Rail Link project set to boost Chinese investment in 2020. ASEAN projects account for 35% of all Belt & Road Initiative projects between 2014 and 2018. The US-China trade war may also benefit ASEAN, with 25% of US firms in China planning to relocate manufacturing facilities to the region.

site_title: Sri Lankan court dismisses challenge to presidential candidate Rajapaksa's citizenship
summary: A Sri Lankan court has dismissed a challenge to presidential candidate Gotabaya Rajapaksa's citizenship, allowing him to contest the upcoming election. The challenge, filed by two civil activists, claimed Rajapaksa did not properly obtain his citizenship in 2005, when he was a US citizen. The court's unanimous decision removes a major barrier for Rajapaksa, who is widely seen as the election frontrunner. Despite facing other legal battles, Rajapaksa's popularity has grown, with many Buddhist leaders and victims of the Easter attacks expressing support for his return to power.

site_title: UK car sales lag major European markets ahead of Brexit
summary: UK car sales lagged major European markets in September, with a 1.3% increase driven by fleet demand, falling short of predictions. France and Germany posted 17% and 22% growth, respectively. Year-to-date registrations in the UK fell 2.5%. The automotive industry is bracing for the impact of a no-deal Brexit, with manufacturers warning of disrupted supply chains and reduced demand. Electric vehicle sales, however, saw a boost, with battery-driven car sales more than tripling in September.

images.alt_text: UK car sales lagged other major European markets in September as consumers hold back on purchases due to uncertainty surrounding Brexit.

site_title: SkillsFuture partners IBM to train 2,500 Singaporeans on AI skills
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture and IBM have partnered to train 2,500 Singaporeans in AI skills over the next three years. The training includes five courses covering AI fundamentals, customer engagement, data analytics, blockchain, and natural language understanding. The courses are designed to help workers build AI capabilities and boost the implementation of such solutions in local enterprises. This partnership aims to enhance the training ecosystem in Singapore and build industry-led training capabilities, following the success of over 50,000 Singaporeans who have benefited from SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace since its launch in 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with losses, falling 1.11% to 25,821.03, amid government plans to ban face masks in an effort to quell months-long protests. The move has raised concerns about further unrest, prompting traders to sell. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: WeWork's co-CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham announced job cuts to employees this month, aiming to handle the layoffs "humanely". DBS, Singapore's No. 1 challenger bank, faces competition from international rivals, while SMI is suing Hyflux for a $39m deposit. The Trendlines Group proposed a rights issue at a 19.3% premium, and the SGX rejected Renaissance's revised application for a new share subscription. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure, while Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Opec is prepared to make deeper cuts if needed, Nigeria says
summary: Nigeria and Opec members are prepared to deepen production cuts if oil prices continue to drop, according to Nigeria's oil minister. The country aims to meet its new production quota of 1.774 million barrels a day, despite a pipeline outage. Opec+ is set to meet in December to discuss further production cuts, which expire in March. Nigeria will also discuss the inclusion of its new Egina field in production targets. Domestic focus is on reviving Nigeria's refining system, with plans to construct the AKK gas pipeline and potentially add a new refinery.

site_title: Chinese Global Investors served with statutory demand from former CFO
summary: Chinese Global Investors Group, a Catalist-listed investment holding group, has been served a statutory demand of S$41,958.12 by lawyers for former CFO Kemmy Koh Ai Ping. The demand is for unpaid remuneration from April to July 2019, including CPF and interest. If the company fails to pay within 21 days, it will be deemed unable to pay its debts and a winding-up order may be applied. The company is seeking legal advice and will inform shareholders of material developments. This is the second letter of demand the company has received, following a S$12,462.63 demand from landlord Ashford Investment in June.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on late bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday due to late bargain-hunting following recent declines. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.32% and the Topix index rose 0.26%. The market is looking ahead to US unemployment figures, but traders are brushing off new Trump threats. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, and the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares extend losses on Friday, end 1.5% lower on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week at 3,078.36, 1.5% lower than the previous week's close, due to disappointing US economic data and escalating trade tensions between the US and Europe. The index declined 9.61 points, with 17 of its 30 counters closing in the red. Despite this, the market expects a possible rate cut from the US Federal Reserve this month, which may provide some upside. Other markets in the Asia-Pacific, including Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan, also ended with losses.

site_title: Faced by strong baht, Thailand plans to relax rules on outflows
summary: Thailand plans to relax rules on capital outflows before the end of the year to address a strong baht that has been Asia's best performing currency this year. The Bank of Thailand's governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, stated that monetary policy is currently accommodative but ready to take action if needed. The central bank will announce more liberalization on capital outflows for Thai investors to invest abroad, including a substantial increase in ceilings for mutual funds and a limit increase for direct foreign investment.

site_title: Hong Kong teen shot by police was "rioting" - prosecutor
summary: An 18-year-old Hong Kong protester, Tsang Chi-kin, was shot in the chest by police while throwing bricks and rioting, a prosecutor said. Tsang has been charged with rioting and assaulting a police officer, carrying a maximum 10-year sentence. The incident occurred during recent rallies against the extradition law, which began after the government's announcement.

site_title: Y Ventures gets listing and quotation notice for 24.66m placement
summary: CATALIST-LISTED e-commerce firm Y Ventures has received a listing and quotation notice for its 24.66 million new ordinary shares at S$0.0812 apiece, with net proceeds to be used for business expansion, mergers and acquisitions, and working capital to accelerate its core e-commerce business. The shares must be placed within seven market days.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks tumble most in Asia before Carrie Lam's briefing at 3pm
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.1% before a briefing by Carrie Lam's officials, where emergency laws to ban mask wearing are expected to be invoked. The MSCI Hong Kong Index fell below 26,000 points, with property developers suffering the biggest losses. Traders speculate that measures beyond the mask ban will be announced, as senior ministers are attending the press briefing. The Hong Kong markets will remain closed on Monday for a holiday.

site_title: Hong Kong to introduce anti-mask law, effective midnight: media
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam is set to announce a ban on face masks at public rallies, effective from midnight, amid months of violent unrest in the Chinese-ruled city. The move is part of sweeping emergency laws aimed at easing tensions. The government plans to discuss the ban and other measures during a news conference on Friday.

site_title: Jeff Koons' controversial 'Bouquet of Tulips' unveiled in Paris
summary: Jeff Koons unveiled his massive sculpture "Bouquet of Tulips" in Paris, symbolizing US solidarity with France after the 2015 jihadist attacks. The 12-meter work, featuring a human hand grasping flowers, was initially met with controversy over its location. After four years of debate, the sculpture was finally installed in a green space near the Petit Palais museum, where it was met with applause from onlookers. Koons expressed sadness over the controversy, citing "misunderstandings and misinformation" as the cause.

site_title: Australian shares close higher but chalk up biggest weekly loss in 11 months
summary: Australian shares closed 0.4% higher on Friday, ending their biggest weekly loss in 11 months, despite weak data and trade war fears. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,517.1, boosted by CSL and Commonwealth Bank of Australia. However, the week's losses of 3% were attributed to thin trade and anticipation of a US jobs report that may signal a global slowdown.

site_title: Europe: Equities rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.3% to 7,098.40 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. The rebound comes as investors brush off new US President Trump's threats, with mining and healthcare sectors driving gains. In Asia, the STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, while a Dutch firm prepares to privatize Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: Malaysia says no talks with Goldman Sachs on recovering funds lost in 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, stated there are no talks with Goldman Sachs on recovering funds lost in the 1MDB scandal. The US Department of Justice is investigating Goldman Sachs for its role in the scandal, which allegedly involved fees higher than market rates and an estimated $4.5 billion misappropriated from 1MDB. Malaysia filed criminal charges against Goldman Sachs last year, and prosecutors have also charged 17 current and former directors at Goldman Sachs subsidiaries. The government has offered to drop charges if Goldman Sachs pays $7.5 billion in reparations.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks drop on rising tensions in Hong Kong, focus on US jobs data
summary: South Korean stocks dropped on Friday, near a four-week low, due to rising tensions in Hong Kong and anticipation of US jobs data. The benchmark KOSPI index closed down 0.55% at 2,020.69. Investors were also cautious about the Hong Kong government's plan to ban face masks at protests, affecting risk assets. This marks the second straight week of losses for the index, which fell 1.43% for the week.

site_title: Triyards says it received Sept 5 statutory demand with 21-day deadline
summary: TRIYARDS Holdings received a statutory demand from OCBC on September 5, 2019, for approximately US$11.57 million and 1.13 billion Vietnamese dong. The demand, issued in respect of a 2014 deed of guarantee, gives OCBC a 21-day deadline to present a winding-up order if the amount owed is not paid or secured. Triyards is assessing the impact and exploring an amicable resolution with OCBC.

site_title: Coworking here to stay despite WeWork concerns: Jefferies, DBS
summary: Coworking spaces are expected to remain stable despite concerns over WeWork, according to Jefferies and DBS analysts. WeWork's recent developments may lead to consolidation among operators, but traditional tenants are embracing the "core plus flexible" concept, and smaller firms are seeking lower fixed costs. Demand from entrepreneurs, freelancers, and startups will support the industry, with DBS noting that S-Reits have a limited exposure to WeWork, mainly due to long-term leases with minimal break clauses.

site_title: Hong Kong invokes rare emergency powers to ban masks at protests
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam invoked colonial-era emergency powers to ban face masks at protests, citing a rise in violence by protesters. The ban aims to deter violence and help police enforce the law, with violators facing a jail term of up to one year or a fine of HK$25,000. Protests continue, with protesters vowing to continue demonstrations despite the ban, and international leaders, including US Senator Elizabeth Warren, criticizing the move as a form of martial law.

images.alt_text: Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced the measure on Friday during a press briefing with 16 members of her Cabinet, citing a rise in violence by protesters in recent weeks.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing donates HK$1b to support local business
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing donates HK$1 billion to support local small and medium-sized businesses, amid the city's economic challenges and pro-democracy protests. The move comes after Li was criticized by China's Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission for his comments on the protests. Li's donation is seen as an attempt to alleviate housing problems and ease pressure on the government. The move also follows other property firms, such as New World Development, in donating land for social housing.

site_title: Court says SMI entitled to countersue Hyflux for S$39m in escrow; full trial required to resolve dispute
summary: A Singapore court has ruled that SM Investments (SMI) is entitled to pursue a counterclaim of S$38.9 million against Hyflux, despite a moratorium on claims. The court found that SMI's counterclaim does not go beyond a defensive stance and therefore does not require leave. The court also decided that a full trial is needed to resolve the dispute over the interpretation of a clause in the restructuring agreement between the two companies.

site_title: Apple raises iPhone 11 production by about 10%: report
summary: Apple has asked suppliers to increase production of its iPhone 11 models by up to 10% to around 8 million units, citing better-than-expected demand. This is a significant increase from last year's production levels. The surge in demand is mainly due to the cheapest iPhone 11 model and the iPhone 11 Pro model, with orders for the top-range iPhone 11 Pro Max slightly revised down. Suppliers remain cautious, concerned that the higher demand may not be sustained.

site_title: UK says will fly back 4,500 people on Friday after Thomas Cook failure
summary: Britain's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) plans to fly 26 flights on Friday to bring 4,500 more people back to the UK after Thomas Cook's collapse. The regulator has yet to repatriate the remaining 14,000 people. This is part of a programme that ends on October 6.

site_title: WeWork bosses tell employees job cuts are coming this month
summary: WeWork's new co-CEOs announced job cuts of up to 2,000 employees, equivalent to 16% of its workforce, as the company implements cost-cutting measures. The layoffs are part of efforts to "right-size" the business and focus on its core office-rental operations. Despite the uncertainty, executives assured staff that the cuts would be handled "humanely" and that clients and tenants remain interested in WeWork's offerings. The company is also canceling its upcoming Global Summit and exploring the sale of recent acquisitions as part of its restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: WeWork's leaders told staff that job cuts are coming as soon as this month.

site_title: WeWork deal in Amsterdam at risk as German landlord wavers
summary: A German asset manager, Union Investment, is considering canceling a deal to lease space to WeWork in Amsterdam's 5 Keizers complex, citing uncertainty about the company's future. This comes as WeWork faces financial difficulties after scrapping a planned IPO and cutting back on expansion plans. WeWork's parent company, We Company, has not commented on the matter, and no decision has been made. The potential cancellation of the deal could impact WeWork's plans for expansion in Europe.

site_title: Lazard Asset Management to cut workforce, shut down some funds by year-end: source
summary: Lazard Asset Management plans to cut 7% of its workforce, approximately 60 employees, by the end of the year. The cuts will affect both investment and non-investment roles, with a focus on eliminating underperforming funds. The move comes as the industry faces pressure from passive funds, and Lazard has recently ramped up its focus on quantitative and ESG strategies. The company oversees $213.6 billion in assets and had 850 employees as of June 30.

site_title: Thailand's surging baht shatters expat dreams of easy retirement
summary: Thailand's strong baht is making it difficult for foreign retirees to afford an easy retirement, with the currency appreciating over 6% against the dollar in 2019. The baht's value has dropped from 60 to 38 baht per pound, making it harder for expats to meet the financial stipulations for retirement visas. The Thai government issued 80,000 retirement visas last year, but some pensioners are voting with their feet, moving to Vietnam, Cambodia, and the Philippines. Officials continue to promote Thailand as a retirement destination, but the cost of living remains high for some, forcing retirees to cut back on spending.

site_title: Australia's retail sales rise, suggesting rate cuts buoying consumption
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.4% in August, exceeding expectations and suggesting recent interest rate cuts and tax rebates have boosted consumer spending. This positive outcome is a welcome sign for policymakers, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, which cut its benchmark rate to a record low 0.75% earlier this week. The result is seen as a positive indicator for employment growth and inflation.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,077.65, down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day at 3,077.65, down 0.3% from the previous close, as decliners outnumbered advancers 160 to 104. Key decliners included DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, while Jardine Strategic Holdings and Thai Beverage were among the gainers. Asian stocks traded mixed, with investors awaiting the release of US payrolls data, which is expected to provide insight into the US economy.

site_title: MeGroup raises stake in unit that operates its Honda dealerships
summary: MeGroup, a Catalist-listed automotive parts maker and dealer, has entered a definitive sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire an additional 25% stake in its subsidiary MJN Motors Sdn Bhd, which operates Honda dealerships in Malaysia. This deal increases MeGroup's stake from 55% to 80%. The consideration, up to RM3.75 million, will be financed through internal resources. The acquisition's completion is subject to conditions and regulatory approval. MeGroup aims to tap into strong demand for Honda cars in Malaysia.

site_title: Digital payments platform Square welcomes US marijuana businesses
summary: Square Inc. has become the first US payments platform to allow cannabis businesses to sell products on its platform, tracking payment and inventory management. This move comes as more US states legalize marijuana, with the global market estimated to increase at 24% annually by 2025. The company's program is available to US businesses selling cannabidiol (CBD) products, which are derived from hemp and remain legal at the federal level. The move is seen as an opportunity for Square to expand its services to the growing cannabis industry.

site_title: Jardine Matheson maps a road to younger Asia for its peers
summary: Jardine Matheson, a Hong Kong-based trading house, is expanding its presence in Southeast Asia, driven by strong consumer demand in Indonesia and Vietnam. The company's underlying profit in Southeast Asia grew by over 20% last year, outperforming growth in China and Hong Kong. Indonesia's disposable income has quintupled since 1997, while Vietnamese consumers have more than nine times as much cash as they did two decades ago. As the region's growth slows, Jardine is investing in e-commerce and logistics to stay competitive, and other tycoons are following suit, seeking diversification and growth opportunities abroad.

site_title: Japan PM says ready to step up economic support as risks to growth rise
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to deliver "all possible steps" to support the economy if risks intensify following the recent sales tax hike. The 10% sales tax increase is seen as critical for Japan's finances, but it may hurt consumer spending and tip the economy into recession. Abe's pledge echoes the central bank's readiness to expand stimulus, and Finance Minister Taro Aso dismissed the need for a boost in stimulus, citing solid corporate earnings and household incomes. The Bank of Japan may consider further easing measures, and Fitch Ratings expects the bank to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy settings.

site_title: US$63 billion of zombie buildings sound warning for Indian banks
summary: India's shadow banking sector is facing a crisis, with US$63 billion of stalled residential projects, leaving developers like Radius Developers struggling to fund construction due to a liquidity crunch. The sector's default of Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services has led to a credit squeeze, causing prices to fall and more loans to turn sour. This has cast a shadow on traditional banks, drying up funding to other businesses and putting pressure on the already slowing economy. The Reserve Bank of India is closely monitoring top 50 NBFCs and won't allow another systemically important NBFC to fail, amid concerns that some weak non-bank finance companies should be allowed to fail for the entire financial system to come out stronger.

site_title: Japan finance minister plays down need for stimulus after tax hike
summary: Japan's finance minister, Taro Aso, downplays the need for fiscal stimulus following the country's national sales tax hike to 10% from 8%. Despite concerns over consumer spending and recession, Aso believes corporate earnings and household incomes are solid, and the Bank of Japan is likely to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy settings. Fitch Ratings also expects the BOJ to act preemptively if growth falters, but may consider additional fiscal stimulus in a supplementary budget early next year.

site_title: Google Cloud worth US$225 billion, Deutsche Bank says
summary: Google Cloud's worth is estimated at US$225 billion, according to Deutsche Bank analysts. The unit is expected to report compound annual growth of 55% between 2018 and 2022, reaching annual sales of US$38 billion by 2025. This valuation is nearly twice that of IBM's cloud revenue in 2018. Deutsche Bank raised its price target on Alphabet, the parent company of Google, to US$1,600 a share, citing increased confidence in Google Cloud's market share growth under Thomas Kurian's leadership.

images.alt_text: Alphabet Inc's cloud business alone is now worth US$225 billion, Deutsche Bank analysts led by Lloyd Walmsley wrote in a note.

site_title: Google to join Ivanka Trump's pledge to train US workers
summary: Google's CEO Sundar Pichai announced the company's participation in Ivanka Trump's pledge to train 250,000 US workers over the next year. Google plans to provide a $3.5 million education grant and access to its IT Support Professional Certificate programme, designed to prepare individuals for entry-level tech jobs. This move aims to address criticism that Google's AI projects risk automating jobs.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher; set for worst week in 11 months
summary: Australian shares rose on Friday, pushing the S&P/ASX 200 index 0.1% higher, as investors awaited a US jobs report that could lead to further interest rate cuts. The index is set to fall 3.2% for the week, its worst drop in 11 months. CSL, the country's fourth-largest firm, jumped 3.4% after Morgan Stanley upgraded the company. Energy and mining stocks also rose, while the country's top banks fell. The non-farm payrolls report later in the day could cement expectations for US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.

site_title: Dubai seeks investment to bolster flagging economy
summary: Dubai's economy is struggling, despite its diverse economy in the Gulf region. Real estate deals plummeted 21.5% to US$60.7 billion in 2018, and tourist numbers remained stagnant at around 16 million over the past two years. The emirate is seeking investment to bolster its economy, which is also impacted by a decline in its property, tourism, and trade sectors. Dubai's efforts to attract investors come as the city-state faces challenges in maintaining its image of prosperity.

site_title: US helps Mastercard, Visa score victory in Indonesia in global lobbying effort
summary: US trade officials helped Mastercard and Visa secure a victory in Indonesia by convincing the country to loosen rules governing its domestic payment network, allowing the US companies to process credit card transactions without partnering a local company. This move represents a major lobbying victory for US payment companies in their efforts to beat back regulations in Asia and elsewhere. The decision was made in exchange for Indonesia retaining its Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) trade status, which grants the US lower tariffs on exports worth $2 billion annually.

site_title: Urgent safety alert issued for 'critical' Takata airbags in cars
summary: Australia's competition watchdog issued an urgent safety alert for "critical" Takata airbags in cars, urging consumers not to drive affected vehicles until the airbag is replaced. 20,000 vehicles under recall for defective airbags are now classified as "critical", with 425,971 vehicles still to be rectified. Car manufacturers including Honda and BMW warned of the issue, which affects vehicles worldwide.

images.alt_text: Australia's competition watchdog issued an urgent safety alert on Friday for "critical" Takata airbags following warnings from major car manufacturers including BMW and Honda Motor.

site_title: Investors 'have little choice' but to go to stocks: DBS
summary: DBS Group Holdings' chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook recommends investing in stocks due to ultra-low bond yields. He favors dividend shares, gold, and hybrid European AT1 securities, citing a "barbell strategy" to navigate uncertainty. Investors have "little choice" but to turn to equities as bond yields continue to decline, with Mr. Hou predicting a favorable environment for gold and warning of bear steepening in US Treasury yield curves.

site_title: Philippine annual inflation slows to 0.9% in September
summary: The Philippines' annual headline consumer price index in September rose 0.9% from a year earlier, lower than the forecasted 1.1% and within the central bank's 0.6-1.4% range. This marks a slowdown in inflation, providing some relief for policymakers.

images.alt_text: The Philippines' annual headline consumer price index in September rose 0.9 per cent from a year earlier, a lower increase than expected, the statistics agency said on Friday.

site_title: Indonesia to top up bond issuance by 15.3 trillion rupiah amid widening fiscal deficit: source
summary: Indonesia plans to raise its bond issuance by 15.3 trillion rupiah (S$1.49 billion) to 841 trillion rupiah in 2019, aiming to maintain economic growth amid a widening fiscal deficit. The government's current deficit outlook is 1.93% of GDP, exceeding its original target of 1.84%. The move is seen as a response to a tax shortfall and the need to maintain economic growth.

site_title: SoftBank's plans for second mega-fund hit by WeWork debacle
summary: SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son is struggling to raise money for his second mega-fund, Vision Fund 2, due to the failed WeWork IPO and sliding valuations of other investments. Despite some lieutenants urging a delay, Son remains determined to proceed, but the fund is likely to be smaller than the initially announced $108 billion. The new fund's size is expected to be at least $30 billion at the outset, significantly lower than the initial target.

site_title: E-commerce firm Etsy's decision to go free on shipping delivers the bulls
summary: Etsy, an e-commerce firm, has seen a surge in Wall Street support after announcing free shipping on orders over $35 and other initiatives. Analysts, including KeyBanc Capital and Canaccord Genuity, have praised the move as a growth catalyst, with estimates of 3-5% upside to 2020 revenue and adjusted EBITDA. The company's shares rose 2.6% and have gained 16% this year, with 13 firms recommending a buy and an average price target of $77, implying a 40% upside from current levels.

site_title: India cuts rates for 5th time amid economic slowdown, banking woes
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, cut its benchmark interest rate for the fifth time this year, lowering it to 5.15% to revive economic growth amid a slowdown. The rate cut aims to address concerns about domestic demand and the banking system, which faces new stresses. The RBI retained its accommodative policy stance and lowered its full-year growth forecast to 6.1%. The move follows recent fiscal steps by the government to spur growth and comes as central banks worldwide loosen monetary policy to offset a global slowdown.

site_title: Netflix's history says return to junk bond market is coming soon
summary: Netflix is expected to return to the junk bond market in October, following its tradition of issuing debt in the month. The company plans to spend $14.5 billion on programming this year, and its growing demand for fresh content has forced it to borrow despite its increasing sales. Analysts expect the deal to emerge after earnings, which Netflix reports on October 16. Despite concerns about competition and subscriber growth, Netflix's junk bond ratings and cheap financing costs are expected to attract investors.

site_title: Facebook says removed multiple accounts from Indonesia, UAE, Nigeria and Egypt
summary: Facebook has removed 280 Facebook accounts, 149 pages, and 43 groups, as well as 121 Instagram accounts, from the UAE, Egypt, Nigeria, and Indonesia, citing "coordinated inauthentic behavior". The removed accounts spread content on topics like UAE's activities in Yemen and criticism of Qatar, Turkey, and Iran. This is part of Facebook's efforts to prevent online abuses and spread of misinformation, particularly in political election campaigns, after facing criticism for its handling of extremist content and propaganda operations.

site_title: There's a new hedge fund for badly governed companies in Japan
summary: A new hedge fund in Japan, led by Zuhair Khan, aims to capitalize on undervalued companies with good governance, while shorting those with weak oversight. The fund, set to debut by year-end, will target 30 undervalued companies and 60 richly valued businesses with poor governance. Khan believes that Japan's corporate governance reforms have not yet been priced into the market, offering significant upside. The fund seeks a double-digit return and will operate in a volatile market with a potential 4-6% fluctuation.

site_title: Indonesia's Bukalapak gets investment from S Korea's Shinhan, says valuation US$2.5b
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak has secured a significant investment from South Korea's Shinhan Financial Group, valuing the startup at over US$2.5 billion. Shinhan's investment banking unit, Shinhan GIB, joined the latest fundraising round alongside Indonesian media conglomerate Emtek, a long-time backer. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the investment is seen as a boost to Bukalapak's growth prospects.

site_title: Thousands in bloody protests across Iraq, 31 dead
summary: Thousands of protesters in Iraq clashed with riot police, leaving 31 dead and over 1,000 wounded in the third day of mass rallies against corruption, unemployment, and poor services. Prime Minister Adel Abdel Mahdi made a televised speech, defending his government's achievements and pledging a monthly stipend for families in need, but refrained from directly responding to protesters' demands. The demonstrations, which began in Baghdad and spread across the south, have been marked by violence and internet shutdowns, with the United Nations and human rights groups calling for calm and an end to the brutality.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg defends encryption, despite child safety concerns
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg defended his decision to encrypt the company's messaging services, despite concerns about its impact on child exploitation and terrorism. The US, Britain, and Australia signed an open letter calling for Facebook to suspend its encryption plan, citing its hindrance to fighting child abuse and terrorism. Zuckerberg acknowledged the risks but expressed optimism that Facebook can identify predators using existing tools, and suggested further limiting adult-minor interactions on Facebook platforms.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia's insurance arm charged with 'hawking' offences
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) charged Commonwealth Bank of Australia's CommInsure unit with 87 breaches of an "anti-hawking" law, related to unsolicited life insurance sales via phone calls from October to December 2014. The charges could result in fines of up to A$1.8 million, with each offence carrying a penalty of up to A$21,250. This is a rare case of a major financial institution facing criminal charges for misconduct in the sector.

site_title: US panel wants Facebook's Zuckerberg to testify on Libra by January
summary: A US House committee has tentatively agreed on a date for Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify on the company's Libra digital currency, with a possible hearing in January. Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg has already agreed to testify on October 29. The committee is concerned about Libra's impact on the global financial system, citing concerns over privacy, trading, national security, and monetary policy. Chairman Maxine Waters has called for Facebook to stop implementing Libra until a legal framework is in place.

site_title: SGX rejects Renaissance's revised application for new share subscription
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Renaissance United's revised application to issue shares at S$0.0011 per share, which would have raised about S$1.4 million. The rejection was due to concerns that the low share price would artificially inflate the company's market capitalization. This is the second time SGX has rejected Renaissance's application, with the first rejection citing similar concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Friday; STI up 0.1% to 3,089.67
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% to 3,089.67 on Friday, following a strong overnight performance from US stocks. The Straits Times Index gained 1.70 points, driven by gains from Microsoft and Facebook. Asian equities opened mixed, awaiting the US jobs report and Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's remarks.

site_title: DBS must bulk up or lose fintech turf in South-east Asia
summary: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's largest lender, is facing increased competition in the digital banking space from international rivals, particularly Citigroup. The US bank has secured prime deals in the region, including a co-branded credit card with Alibaba's Lazada and a ride-hailing card partnership with Grab. DBS has less than S$24 billion in assets in South and South-east Asia, a fraction of its assets in Singapore and Hong Kong. To remain competitive, DBS needs to bulk up in the region, but the outcome is uncertain, influenced by politics and the potential for a single economic area.

site_title: China's soy-buying spree may signal prudence before US talks
summary: China has been buying large quantities of US soybeans, with at least six cargoes worth about 400,000 tons purchased, amid uncertainty over upcoming trade talks with the US. The purchases are seen as a precautionary measure, as Chinese firms want to secure supplies quickly in case talks fail and imports are halted. This comes after China received a 2 million-ton quota to import US soybeans free of tariffs, and as prices have gained 3.7% this week due to the lower prices of American soybeans.

site_title: Chinese video app TikTok bans paid political ads
summary: TikTok, a Chinese video app, has banned paid political advertisements on its platform, citing its goal of providing a non-partisan experience for its users. The ban applies to ads promoting or opposing candidates, parties, or issues at various levels, including election-related ads. This move follows a similar stance taken by its parent company, Beijing Bytedance Technology.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.23% on Friday, extending the previous day's advance, ahead of US jobs data that could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,169.51. Mainland Chinese markets were closed due to a holiday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, weighed down by a stronger yen, despite a rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.10% to 21,321.25, while the Topix index dropped 0.29% to 1,564.26. A higher yen capped the upside, according to chief strategist Yoshihiro Ito, as investors await rate cuts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares inch down at Friday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.69 points to 1,563.43 at Friday's open, with 37.1 million lots traded worth RM19.3 million. Gainers outpaced losers 117 to 38.

site_title: Delisting Chinese firms from US stock exchanges will drive business elsewhere: NYSE head
summary: The head of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), Stacey Cunningham, stated that delisting Chinese firms from US stock exchanges would not protect US investors but would prompt the firms to take their business elsewhere. This move, which has been considered by the Trump administration, would instead attract more listings to other markets, potentially excluding companies like Alibaba. The NYSE has been lobbying to solve the issue rather than simply legislating companies away.

site_title: Two women accuse actor James Franco of sexual exploitation in lawsuit
summary: Two women, Sarah Tither-Kaplan and Toni Gaal, have filed a civil lawsuit against actor James Franco, accusing him of running a bogus film school that exploited young women by requiring them to audition nude or participate in explicit sex scenes. The lawsuit claims Franco and others involved in the school engaged in sex discrimination, harassment, and fraud. Franco's attorney denies the allegations, stating the lawsuit is "ill-informed" and "publicity-seeking." The lawsuit seeks class-action status and unspecified monetary damages on behalf of other women who attended the school.

site_title: UK business morale slides, especially in manufacturing
summary: UK business morale has declined, particularly in manufacturing, according to a survey by the British Chambers of Commerce. Domestic manufacturing sales fell at the fastest pace since 2011, while growth in the services sector slowed. The survey also showed a significant drop in manufacturing export orders over the past 10 years. Weakening orders, confidence, and investment intentions suggest a weak growth trajectory for the UK economy unless action is taken to address the Brexit uncertainty. Consumer spending has helped offset the slowdown, but cash-flow issues and declining profit expectations remain concerns.

site_title: Malaysia's Maxis partners Huawei for 5G roll-out next year
summary: Malaysia's Maxis Bhd has partnered with Huawei Technologies Co Ltd to launch a 5G telecommunications network in the country when the technology becomes available in 2020. Huawei will supply 4G and 5G radio equipment and services, enabling Maxis to modernize its existing network and become 5G-ready. The partnership is part of Malaysia's plan to establish a 5G spectrum in the first quarter of 2020, with the country aiming to become one of the first in Asia to launch the technology.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Maxis Bhd said it has signed an agreement with China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd to launch a fifth-generation (5G) telecommunications network in the South-east Asian nation when the technology becomes available.

site_title: Trendlines: Proposed rights issue at 19.3% premium a better gauge of its value
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-listed startup incubator, proposes a 19.3% premium rights issue to raise funds for working capital and investments. The company believes the current market price undervalues it and that the issue price of 10.5 Singapore cents would be a better gauge of its value. Librae Holdings, an entity related to UK business tycoon Vincent Tchenguiz, has committed to subscribe for the rights issue at the same price as a recent placement, and the company has a sufficient cash reserve of US$8 million.

site_title: Weak US economic data portends Fed rate cut
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering a potential rate cut amid weak economic data, including declining manufacturing and service sector surveys, and weakening consumer confidence. Top Fed officials, including Jerome Powell, have expressed openness to cutting rates, but have also emphasized the need to sustain a low unemployment rate and stable inflation. Investors now expect a rate cut at the Fed's October meeting, with some economists warning that further economic data could lead to more aggressive rate cuts in December.

site_title: US, UK ink cross-border data access agreement
summary: The US and UK signed a cross-border data access agreement, allowing each government to demand information from tech companies in the other country for serious crimes. This agreement, joined by Australia, also urges Facebook to implement safeguards before encrypting its messaging systems. The move aims to enhance cooperation between law enforcement agencies and tech companies in investigating crimes.

site_title: Chevron aims to cut intensity of greenhouse gas emissions from production
summary: Chevron aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from its oil production by 5-10% over a seven-year period, as part of its efforts to combat global climate change. The company will also target a 2-5% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions intensity from gas production. Chevron's goals do not include reducing Scope 3 emissions or emissions from customer use of its products. The company has invested over $1 billion in carbon capture and storage projects, expected to reduce emissions by 5 million metric tons per year.

site_title: Bond markets' tea leaves send sobering signal: trouble is ahead
summary: Global bond markets are sending a sobering signal that economic growth is stalling and inflation expectations are fading. Benchmark yields on Treasuries and German bunds have tumbled, while inflation metrics project further declines in price pressures. Investors are piling into safety trades, and a weak reading on the American service industry has compounded concerns. The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates, but investors see it as a weak tool to combat a potential recession, and policymakers are urging governments to increase spending to boost growth.

site_title: Sports Illustrated staff lose jobs after magazine's transfer of control
summary: Sports Illustrated staff lost their jobs after the magazine's transfer of control to Maven, a digital platform company, on October 4, 2019. The layoffs affected 31 full-time employees belonging to the NewsGuild union and nearly 80 employees working at the Sports Illustrated website. Maven plans to "refocus" Sports Illustrated for a January relaunch, shifting coverage to a network of bloggers and reducing the role of top journalists. The move was met with concerns from staff and the NewsGuild, which questioned the impact on the magazine's quality and future.

images.alt_text: Sports Illustrated, which set a standard for sportswriting and photography during its 20th-century heyday, was transferred to a new company on Thursday. Along with the change, there were layoffs, according to three people with knowledge of the moves.

site_title: Capital World takes out S$5.5m convertible loan
summary: Capital World, a Catalist-listed property firm, has secured a S$5.5 million convertible loan from two individual investors, Chong Thim Pheng and Ong King Sin, to repay outstanding convertible bonds. The loan carries a 15% annual interest rate and is convertible into new shares representing 16.52% of the enlarged share capital at a conversion price of S$0.0151708. The loan will be disbursed after certain conditions are fulfilled, with a 17% interest rate on overdue amounts.

site_title: Brazil miner Vale mulls making low-emission iron if gas prices fall: sources
summary: Brazil's Vale SA, the world's largest iron ore miner, is considering producing low-emission "hot briquetted iron" (HBI) if natural gas prices fall below US$4 per million British thermal units (mmBtu). The company aims to produce 20 million tonnes of HBI per year, accounting for 5% of its planned iron ore production. HBI has lower emissions than traditional steel production methods, and Vale's existing iron ore advantage would enhance its environmental benefits. The company's investment plan is still under discussion, but a drastic reduction in gas prices is seen as necessary for HBI production to proceed.

site_title: US seeks advertising, sales data on e-cigarette companies
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has ordered six e-cigarette companies to turn over sales and advertising data in a possible probe of their marketing practices. The move comes amid a growing number of lung illnesses associated with vaping, with 1,080 confirmed cases and 18 deaths in the US. The affected companies include JUUL Labs, RJ Reynolds Vapor Company, and others. The FTC's action is the first sign of an investigation into e-cigarette marketing practices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up on upbeat chip industry outlook; US payrolls eyed
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.14% on Friday as chipmakers, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, gained 1.4% and 1.8% respectively due to an upbeat outlook for the industry. The won rose nearly 1% against the US dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Analysts expect earnings growth next year as chip prices turn around, despite weak US manufacturing data and a focus on the US job report.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares inched up on Friday as chipmakers rose on upbeat outlook for the industry, but caution ahead of US payrolls capped gains. Meanwhile, the won rose nearly 1 per cent against the US dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: Short interest in WeWork bonds jumps to record high
summary: WeWork's short interest in bonds jumped to a record high, with investors betting on a potential new bond issue to fund operations. The cost to borrow WeWork's high-yield debt reached a record high, and the price of its 2025 junk bond fell 18.6% in the last month. Investors expect WeWork to issue a new bond to secure alternative funding, which would likely depress the value of current outstanding bonds. This comes after WeWork withdrew its IPO due to concerns about its losses and business model.

site_title: US e-scooter startup Bird raises US$275m in latest funding round
summary: US e-scooter startup Bird has raised $275 million in a funding round led by CDPQ and Sequoia Capital, valuing the company at $2.5 billion. CEO Travis VanderZanden stated that the company has improved its financials and designed its own rugged scooters with a lifespan of 15 months. Bird aims to take a bigger share of the rapidly growing transportation sector, despite facing criticism for littering sidewalks and causing problems in cities like San Francisco.

site_title: Chasing Chinese consumers, Tiffany & Co sends top bling abroad
summary: Tiffany & Co is expanding its luxury jewellery sales to mainland China to reach consumers who are unable to purchase due to a weak currency. The company aims to avoid charging extra tariffs on imported jewellery, following its recent exhibit in Shanghai. This move is part of Tiffany's efforts to adapt to the US-China trade war, which has led to double-digit sales declines in the US and other destinations. The company is sending high-end pieces, valued at $1 million and up, to China to maintain sales and mitigate losses.

site_title: US tech giants turn to India for new apps before world release
summary: US tech giants such as Facebook, Netflix, and Amazon are turning to India as a testing ground for new apps before releasing them globally. The country's growth dynamics and fewer regulations make it an attractive market. India has already seen the success of companies like Netflix, which rolled out a mobile plan at a low price, and Amazon, which attempted to acquire Flipkart Online Services. Analyst Mark Mahaney predicts that India has the potential to become a significant contributor to the revenue of these companies, with India being less than 5% of Amazon's total revenues but having the potential to reach that level within five years.

site_title: Hong Kong to discuss emergency laws as further protests planned
summary: Hong Kong's government is set to discuss sweeping emergency laws that would ban face masks at protests, potentially entailing jail terms or fines of up to one year. The move comes as demonstrations are planned against the proposed law, following the police shooting of a teenage student on Tuesday. Activists have denounced the move, with multiple protests expected over the weekend. The laws are part of an unprecedented effort to ease months of violent unrest in the Chinese-ruled city.

site_title: Huawei CFO exposes cracks in case where only 1% succeed
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou's lawyers have exposed cracks in Canada's handling of her arrest, including an admission from border officials that they shared her device passwords with police "in error". This admission has put the prosecution on the back foot during a two-week hearing. Meng, who was detained for three hours at Vancouver's airport, was released on bail to live in one of her multimillion-dollar homes. The revelation raises questions about the integrity of the Canadian justice system and may impact the US extradition request against Meng.

site_title: Formula One plays down talk of new teams from 2021
summary: Formula One has downplayed rumors of new teams entering the sport in 2021, stating there are "no serious discussions" about admitting a new team. Despite interest from entities like Monaco-based MIM Group and Panthera Team Asia, the Liberty Media-controlled sport says the bar for entry will be set high, and any new teams would have to be competitive and add to the show. Formula One chairman Chase Carey and managing director Ross Brawn have expressed skepticism about new teams, citing the need for the sport to stabilize before seeking additional entries.

site_title: Vaping-linked lung injury kills 18, sickens 1,080 in US
summary: The US is experiencing a surge in lung injuries linked to e-cigarette use, with 1,080 cases under investigation and 18 deaths reported. The cause remains unknown, with multiple lines of investigation pursued by health authorities. A study found that patients' lungs were exposed to noxious fumes, while a report suggested the inhalation of fatty substances from aerosolized oils may be the culprit. The majority of patients, 78%, reported using tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) with or without nicotine products.

site_title: Tokio Marine buys high net worth insurer Pure for US$3.1b
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc has acquired high net worth insurer Pure for $3.1 billion, expanding its presence in the US market for wealthy Americans. The deal, which is the latest push by Japanese insurers to diversify globally, follows Tokio Marine's $7.5 billion purchase of HCC Insurance Holdings Inc in 2015. Pure, led by CEO Ross Buchmueller, will remain an independent unit within Tokio Marine, managing Privilege Underwriters Reciprocal Exchange. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to tap into the high-net-worth insurance market.

images.alt_text: Tokio Marine CEO Satoru Komiya, who took the reins earlier this year, has vowed to stick with his predecessor's strategy of expanding through overseas acquisitions. The company has spent more than $17 billion in the past 11 years on a string of large takeovers outside of Japan, data compiled by Bloomberg show.

site_title: Agri-foodtech female leaders struggle to attract investment: report
summary: A new report found that female entrepreneurs in the agri-foodtech industry received only 5% of the $16.9 billion in investments worldwide in 2018, despite making up only 16% of startups with at least one female founder. The report also showed that female-led startups deliver higher revenue per dollar invested, with more than twice as much revenue as those founded by men. The funding gap for women in the sector has increased by 37% between 2017 and 2018, with unconscious bias cited as a major obstacle.

site_title: Apple CEO sees US-China trade deal, hopes tariffs dropped
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expressed optimism over a US-China trade deal, stating he believes a trade deal will be reached and tariffs will be dropped. Cook emphasized that both countries must benefit from the agreement, as a stalemate would harm the global economy. He also declined to follow Facebook's lead in creating its own currency, citing concerns over private companies establishing competing currencies.
