images.alt_text: Apple's chief executive Tim Cook said in an interview published in a French newspaper on Thursday that he was hopeful the United States and China would reach a trade deal and it was vital for both countries to go back on their mutual tariffs.

site_title: Cheesed off European dairy producers dismayed at US tariffs
summary: European dairy producers are upset over US tariffs on their products, imposed in retaliation for EU subsidies to Airbus. The 25% tariffs will increase prices of high-quality cheeses like parmesan and stilton by $5 per kilogramme. The EU exports 133,000 tonnes of cheese to the US each year, and the tariffs will affect products such as English cheddar and emmentaler. Industry leaders say the move is "absurd" and "unacceptable," as the EU was not involved in the dispute.

site_title: Startups, tech giants face tax test as Indonesia reins in e-commerce
summary: Indonesia is drafting a tax bill to control its booming e-commerce industry, requiring local startups and digital giants like Google, Amazon, and Netflix to collect and pay value-added tax (VAT). The bill will also set a basis for income tax based on a company's economic presence in Indonesia. The move aims to encourage domestic producers and curb the flood of cheap, imported goods, with local producers accounting for less than 10% of online sales. The government expects to collect billions of dollars in taxes, with the e-commerce market projected to reach $65 billion by 2022.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, SGX, Raffles Infrastructure, Capital World
summary: Ascendas Reit acquired a Melbourne office property in Australia for A$110.9 million (S$104.4 million). The purchase, with a net property income yield of 5.7%, is the Reit's fourth suburban office property. Singapore Exchange (SGX) remains focused on its vision despite a rival takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange. Raffles Infrastructure Holdings and South Korea-listed Magic Micro Co will explore potential partnerships in infrastructure and smart city projects. Capital World secured a S$5.5 million convertible loan to repay an outstanding convertible bond subscription agreement.

site_title: US, allies urge Facebook not to encrypt messages as they fight child abuse, terrorism
summary: The US, UK, and Australia are urging Facebook to suspend its plans for end-to-end encryption across its messaging services, citing concerns it would hinder the fight against child abuse and terrorism. The US and allies plan to sign a data agreement that would fast-track requests from law enforcement for information about terrorist and child predator communications. Facebook has opposed "government efforts to build backdoors," but the company is exploring ways to prevent inappropriate behavior. The effort aims to balance regulation and user data protection, with the US Attorney-General, UK Secretary of State, and Australian Minister of Home Affairs calling for changes to Facebook's encryption plans.

site_title: Eco Beef
summary: Five Founders, an Australian beef brand, claims to be the first carbon neutral certified beef in the country. The company offsets its greenhouse gas emissions by purchasing Australian Government-approved carbon credits and allowing pastures to be renewed naturally. Their premium beef is available in Singapore and is said to taste as good as, if not better than, a ribeye. The brand's carbon neutral certification is a significant step towards reducing the environmental impact of the beef industry.

site_title: Bank of Japan ready to act as appropriate, says Wakatabe
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Masazumi Wakatabe expressed concerns over global trade tensions, stating they will persist for a while and impact economies. Japan is not exempt, but the BOJ will act as needed to boost the economy. Wakatabe warned of downside risks and uncertainty, emphasizing the central bank's preparedness to address the situation. He emphasized the BOJ's commitment to boosting the economy as needed.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters could face a year in jail for wearing masks: SCMP
summary: Hong Kong is expected to ban face masks for protesters, potentially leading to jail terms of up to a year or fines of HK$25,000, as the city struggles to quell months of violent unrest. The ban, which could be enforced by extending detention periods, is likely to trigger intense clashes this weekend. Protesters, who see masks as a symbol of resistance, fear retribution if identified. The move has sparked international condemnation, with US Senator Elizabeth Warren urging America to stand up to China and provide temporary protected status to Hong Kong residents.

site_title: Netflix cooperating with Italy tax evasion probe
summary: Netflix is cooperating with an Italian tax evasion probe, despite having no office or employees in the country. The probe focuses on whether server units provided to Italian internet service providers were sufficient to grant Netflix permanent tax status. Netflix provides the server units to reduce the pressure on networks from heavy video streaming. The company is cooperating with the investigation, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Two international consortiums bid to build Bogota's US$3.9b metro
summary: Two international consortiums, one consisting of Mexican, Spanish, and French builders, and the other of Chinese, Canadian, and Colombian companies, have submitted bids to build Bogota's US$3.9 billion metro system. The winner will be announced on October 21 and will have seven years to build and operate the project for two decades. The metro is expected to complement Bogota's existing Transmilenio bus system and alleviate traffic congestion in the city, with Colombia's capital providing 30% of the funding.

site_title: US service sector slides to 3-year low in September
summary: The US services sector, a key driver of the country's economy, fell to a three-year low in September, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey. The non-manufacturing index dropped 3.8 points to 52.6, indicating weaker general demand and a slowdown in economic growth. Economists attribute the decline to President Trump's trade wars and the global economic slowdown. The sector's contraction could lead to weaker GDP growth and potentially impact job creation, with some predicting a decline to around 50,000 monthly job creations by the end of the year.

site_title: Driving EtonHouse with 4Ps
summary: EtonHouse International Education Group, a pre-school operator, has expanded from one school in 1995 to 120 campuses worldwide under the leadership of Ng Gim Choo. Now, 24 years later, Ng Gim Choo is passing the baton to her son, Ng Yi Xian, who joined the company in 2014.

site_title: WeWork seen as startup lesson in what not to do in Silicon Valley
summary: WeWork's parent company, The We Company, withdrew its initial public offering (IPO) after ousted founder Adam Neumann and a potential valuation of $10 billion. The startup's implosion is seen as a lesson for Silicon Valley startups about the dangers of unlimited power and money. Venture capital investors criticized SoftBank Group, a major backer of WeWork, for its handling of the company. The collapse highlights the importance of effective leadership and responsible growth strategies in the tech industry. WeWork's failure serves as a cautionary tale for startups navigating the challenges of Silicon Valley.

site_title: Oil ends little changed after touching near two-month lows
summary: US crude futures ended Thursday at $52.45 a barrel, down 19 cents, after touching near two-month lows due to weak economic data. The services sector growth slowed to its most anaemic pace in three years, and job growth was the weakest in half a decade. Despite this, Brent crude rose 2 cents to $57.71 a barrel. The US-China trade dispute and reduced US oil output also provided some support. However, concerns about the worsening economic outlook overshadowed these factors, with oil prices remaining below pre-attack levels following Saudi Arabia's oil installations.

site_title: Tokyo Olympic chiefs ask for input to fight 2020 heat
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers have sent questionnaires to international sports federations seeking advice on how to combat the expected heat during the 2020 Games. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) denies the move was prompted by the devastating heat effects during the Doha world athletics championships. Despite this, Tokyo has revealed "sophisticated" heat prevention measures, including a system to drop artificial snow onto fans. The 2020 Games will run from July 24 to August 9, with temperatures expected to reach 35 degrees Celsius. The IOC chief praises Tokyo's preparation, stating it is "one of the best-prepared" cities ahead of an Olympics.

site_title: US hits China with additional duties on US$4.4 billion in cabinets
summary: The US has imposed additional duties on approximately US$4.4 billion worth of Chinese wooden cabinets and vanities, with tariffs ranging from 28.7% to 251.6%. This decision is part of a series of cases against Chinese exporters, including companies such as Dalian Meisen Woodworking and Rizhao Foremost Woodwork Manufacturing. The move aims to level the playing field and protect American industry, although funds may be returned if the decision is reversed or the US International Trade Commission finds no harm to US industry.

images.alt_text: The US trade conflict with China may not have spared the kitchen sink, or even kitchen cabinets, as Washington on Thursday announced another round of steep tariffs.

site_title: World wildlife trade affects 1 in 5 species: report
summary: A study published in Science found that over 5,500 species of animals are bought and sold on the global wildlife market, a 50% increase from earlier estimates. The trade is a multi-billion-dollar industry, with 18% of vertebrate species being traded, including 27% of mammals and 23% of birds. Threatened and endangered species are disproportionately represented, and the authors predict that up to 3,196 more species will be added to the list in the future. This highlights the severe threat of biodiversity loss due to the wildlife trade.

site_title: US: Wall Street gains as weak services data raises rate-cut expectations
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday after weak services data fueled expectations of a third interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The S&P 500 gained 0.80% to 2,910.63, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.47% to 26,201.04. Microsoft and Facebook led the gains, with bets on a rate cut surging to 90% from 40% according to CME Group's Fed Watch tool. The data also fueled concerns about a US recession, with a pivotal jobs report on Friday expected to provide further evidence.

site_title: Not resting on his laurels
summary: Kong Wan Sing, founder and CEO of Singapore-based co-working space provider JustCo, has overcome numerous challenges to establish the company, which has expanded to nearly 40 co-working centers across eight cities in Asia. JustCo was initially self-funded for four years before raising $700 million in funding. Sing credits a 'never say die' mindset, resilience, and determination as key traits that have driven his success. He plans to use the latest $500 million fundraising to capture more demand for co-working spaces from large corporations, including pharmaceutical giant Novartis and General Electric.

site_title: Singapore has not entered a recession yet; govt keeping close eye - Indranee
summary: Singapore's economy has not entered a recession, according to Minister Indranee Rajah, but the government is closely monitoring conditions and will step in with support measures if needed. The country has been affected by the US-China trade war, with a 3.3% annualized contraction in the second quarter. Despite this, Singapore remains committed to addressing massive infrastructure needs, with plans to standardize language around project financing and train government officials to attract private sector support. The government will also include further measures in next year's budget to boost productivity and innovation.

site_title: US retailers eye strong holiday season despite trade worries
summary: US retailers expect a strong holiday shopping season despite trade uncertainties, with projected sales rising 3.8-4.2% to $730.7 billion. Low unemployment, rising wages, and below-average gasoline prices contribute to the positive outlook. Despite tariffs on Chinese goods being delayed until mid-December, retailers warn of long-term costs. The National Retail Federation projects a resilient consumer market as long as job outlook remains positive and wages continue to rise.

images.alt_text: Despite the flurry of trade and political uncertainties hanging over the US economy, the National Retail Federation (NRF) on Thursday said it expects Americans to continue to spend and load up on gifts in a strong holiday shopping season.

site_title: Joy Water
summary: A musical satire, Urinetown, by Pangdemonium, explores themes of capitalism, climate change, and social activism in a futuristic city where water is scarce and controlled by the megacorporation Urine Good Company. The musical, inspired by the 2001 Broadway hit, features a mix of parodic nods and local references, including Singapore's high cost of living and government sentiments towards activists. With a talented cast and slick choreography, Urinetown raises urgent questions about corporate greed and social responsibility, but its message is occasionally undermined by inconsistent script and satire.

site_title: HK to enact rare emergency rule to ban use of masks
summary: Hong Kong's government will enact an emergency ordinance to ban face masks at public gatherings, marking the first time in over 50 years. The move comes after violent protests shook the city on October 1, as President Xi Jinping celebrated 70 years of Communist party rule in Beijing. The ban targets rallies and marches, and is aimed at restoring order. The government re-evaluated the situation after clashes on National Day, with authorities believing the law can help identify protesters. The decision is seen as a dramatic escalation by the government, which has struggled to control four-month-long demonstrations.

site_title: £9.9m chimpanzee Parliament painting smashes Banksy record
summary: A 2009 Banksy painting, "Devolved Parliament," depicting chimpanzees in the British Parliament, sold for nearly £9.9 million at Sotheby's auction house, breaking the artist's previous auction record. The 4.2-meter-long oil painting was expected to fetch £1.5 million to £2 million, but its sale comes after the UK Supreme Court deemed Prime Minister Boris Johnson's five-week suspension of Parliament unlawful. The sale reflects the tumultuous state of politics in Britain, with experts noting that the painting's simple yet powerful image reflects the "regression of the oldest Parliamentary democracy into tribalistic animalistic behaviour."

images.alt_text: A Banksy painting depicting the British Parliament populated by chimpanzees smashed the record for the mysterious British street artist on Thursday, fetching nearly £9.9 million pounds, Sotheby's auction house said.

site_title: Singapore is world's smartest city: IMD index
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's smartest city by the IMD Smart City Index, based on the perceptions of its citizens. The city scored well in areas such as public safety, lifelong learning opportunities, and green spaces. Singapore topped the ranking, followed by Zurich, Oslo, and Geneva. The index found that Singaporeans prioritized affordable housing, fulfilling employment, and public transport as the most urgent issues. The survey highlights the city's approach to building a Smart Nation, which is citizen- and business-focused, to improve the quality of life for its residents.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher on rally in Airbus, luxury stocks
summary: Europe's stocks rose on Thursday, rebounding from their worst sell-off in two months, driven by gains in Airbus and luxury stocks like LVMH. The rebound was fueled by the Trump administration's decision to exempt some products from tariffs on European-made planes and goods. The euro zone index closed 0.1% higher, while the pan-region index closed 0.02% lower, despite weak economic data and a worsening outlook for the quarterly earnings season.

site_title: A day of celebrations for children, by children
summary: A historical musical was performed by underprivileged children at Resorts World Sentosa in Singapore on Children's Day. The event, organized by the Children for Children initiative, raised S$204,786 for the Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The musical, attended by 900 children, was a day of celebrations for children, with activities at the S.E.A Aquarium and Maritime Experiential Museum. The event aims to provide arts training and financial support to disadvantaged children, with over 11,000 children benefiting from the initiative since 2008.

site_title: Unlocking the hidden joy in pawnbroking
summary: Yeah Hiang Nam, founder and CEO of ValueMax Group, prioritizes a quality customer experience to stand out in the pawnbroking industry. He finds fulfillment in helping needy individuals access essential financial assistance, believing that pawnbroking does social good and provides sustainable earnings. Nam's approach to business is driven by a desire to make a positive impact on society, making his company a unique player in the market.

site_title: Deconstructing the robot job 'threat'
summary: A study on the growing presence of robots in the service sector reveals that, despite technological advancements, robots are not yet replacing human workers. In fact, guests at a robot-staffed hotel in Japan prefer to interact with robots, such as a velociraptor, over human receptionists. The "uncanny valley" theory explains why humans find robots with human-like features unsettling, while novelty and cultural factors also play a role. However, research suggests that the fear of job loss due to automation is grounded more in perception than objective evidence, highlighting the need for businesses to understand how humans respond to robots and adapt to changes in working practices.

site_title: French teachers protest after 'exhausted' colleague's suicide
summary: Thousands of French teachers protested in solidarity with Christine Renon, a principal who took her own life due to work overload, leaving her "exhausted". Renon wrote a letter detailing her struggles, which was read aloud at the protest. Education Minister Jean-Michel Blanquer acknowledged the unsatisfactory working conditions of school principals, saying he is "ready" to discuss the issue. The protests, which included half of schools in the Seine-Saint-Denis department being closed, highlight the pressure on teachers and principals in France.

site_title: Solving F&B firms' problems since 2007
summary: The Food Innovation & Resource Centre (FIRC) at Singapore Polytechnic has helped over 700 food and beverage (F&B) players innovate since its launch in 2007. FIRC has worked on 1,500 projects, with 38% being adopted by companies. The centre, launched by Enterprise Singapore and Singapore Polytechnic, provides technical expertise in product and process development.

site_title: Scotland vote to ban smacking children
summary: Scotland's lawmakers voted 84-29 to ban parents from smacking children, making it a criminal offense. The law, expected to come into force within 12 months, is the first in the UK to outlaw physical punishment. The move is supported by Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who says it gives children the same protection as adults. The bill was opposed by the Conservatives, who argue it is "imprecise" and may lead to "good parents" being turned into criminals. Scotland follows Sweden's 1979 ban on corporal punishment, with over 50 countries now outlawing smacking in the home.

site_title: Small is Beautiful
summary: A couple in Singapore has built a 294-square-meter two-storey bungalow that is considered one of the smallest in the country. Despite its compact size, the home is designed to feel spacious and features a unique circular theme throughout, including a curved wooden door, circular skylight, and round furniture. The architect, Koh Kai Li, overcame physical challenges of the triangular land and steep slope by designing an L-shaped house with a staircase as a fulcrum. The home is cozy and comfortable, making it a successful example of small-is-beautiful design.

site_title: PM Johnson to go on whirlwind tour of EU cities to sell complex Brexit proposal
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is embarking on a whirlwind tour of EU cities to sell his complex Brexit proposal, which aims to scrap the "backstop" insurance and maintain an open Irish border. The plan would see Northern Ireland leave the EU's customs union alongside the rest of the UK, with customs checks to be decentralized and mostly electronic. The EU has expressed guarded responses, with some leaders welcoming "positive advances" while others have concerns over the proposed system of governance and customs changes. Johnson hopes to secure a deal before an EU leader summit on October 17, amid worsening business uncertainty and recession fears.

images.alt_text: Mr Johnson wants to scrap the open Irish border "backstop" insurance in former MP Theresa May's Brexit agreement.

site_title: Solid Gold
summary: Audemars Piguet has released the Millenary Frosted Gold Philosophique, a single-handed watch with a unique elliptical case design. The watch features a transparent disc with an hour indicator that follows the case's trajectory. Available in 18-carat pink or white gold, the watch is part of the Millenary collection, introduced in 1995 for men before becoming an exclusively female range in 2015. The design is inspired by the original hand-wound Philosophique watch introduced in 1982, showcasing the brand's DNA of breaking watchmaking rules.

images.alt_text: Your eyes are not playing tricks on you - Audemars Piguet's new Millenary Frosted Gold Philosophique only has one hand.

site_title: Collaboration, innovation are key to F&B companies' growth
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade & Industry Chee Hong Tat emphasized the importance of collaboration and innovation in the food and beverage (F&B) industry for growth. Companies can share knowledge on regional competition and work together to tackle common problems, such as producing healthier chocolate. Chee highlighted three promising trends: plant-based proteins, carbohydrates with lower glycaemic index, and elderly-friendly versions of traditional foods. The government is also simplifying licensing processes for local businesses, including the F&B sector, through the GoBusiness Licensing portal.

site_title: IYUNO CEO David Lee is Singapore's EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2019
summary: IYUNO CEO David Lee was named Singapore's EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2019, beating four other top entrepreneurs in their respective industry categories. Lee's company, IYUNO, was founded in 2002 as an English-to-Korean subtitling service provider and has since developed proprietary software and a cloud-based platform. He received the award for his tenacity in riding out industry disruptions through technology innovation and his commitment to fostering inclusiveness through quality localization.

images.alt_text: From left: Ernst & Young LLP's Max Loh, Ron Tan (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Media and Entertainment), David Lee (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Digital Media Supply Chain), Kong Wan Sing (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Workspace Solutions), Ng Gim Choo (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Education), Minister Ng Chee Meng, EOY 2019 judges' panel chairman Ron Sim, EY Asean managing partner Liew Nam Soon, Koh Kah Sek (EY Family Business Award of Excellence), Yeah Hiang Nam (EY Entrepreneur Of The Year - Financial Services), and Dennis A. Uy (EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence Award).

site_title: Fall/Winter 2019 - Accessories Report
summary: This Fall's fashion trends include aviator sunglasses, the "belt over blazer" look, super-long scarves in bright colors, and colorful tights. Blooms made a statement at Prada, while brooches are back in various shapes and sizes. Oversized hats, logo flap handbags, and kitten-heel soles with bows are also popular. The season's accessories include utility boots, clip-on hair accessories, and multipouches, marking a shift away from sneakers.

site_title: STI's slide presents chances to buy on dips
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.5% down at 3,087.97 after a volatile day, with decliners outpacing advancers 192 to 179. Regional benchmarks declined, except for Hong Kong, which rose 0.3% following reports of a ban on face masks at demonstrations. The decline was partly attributed to US tariffs on European imports and lacklustre US jobs data, while Asia-Pacific markets were affected by disappointing US manufacturing data.

site_title: Why foreign firms struggle to break into China
summary: Foreign firms struggle to break into China due to the dominance of domestic mega firms and tight matrix of political influence. Despite $276 billion in investments since 1990, only a few Western companies, such as Coca-Cola, General Motors, and Apple, have achieved significant success in the country. These companies have managed to build strong supply chains and go-to-market mechanisms, but others face challenges in competing with local businesses. China's growing economy, with a 18.5-fold increase since 1995, remains an attractive market for foreign entrepreneurs, but the political landscape poses significant hurdles.

site_title: A business that almost wasn't
summary: Cityneon Holdings, a Singapore-based company, was on the verge of collapse due to limited capital, experience, and trust from studio partners. However, CEO Ron Tan persevered and successfully launched the Avengers Station in New York in 2013, which has since attracted hundreds of thousands of visitors. The company was later bought over by Cityneon and is now worth S$700 million. Tan attributes his success to a "never-say-die attitude" and emphasizes the importance of learning from failures, listening to others, and focusing on fundamentals. He plans to expand the company's global reach, particularly in China and the US, and is working on developing Cityneon's own intellectual property.

site_title: Food innovation when tradition meets science
summary: Singapore Polytechnic's Food Innovation and Research Centre (FIRC) has helped small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the food and beverage industry overcome challenges while scaling up and expanding overseas. A panel discussion on F&B innovation featured FIRC director Koh Kok Sin, Irvin Gunawan, and Audrey Chew, highlighting the importance of innovation in the industry. The event aimed to share successful strategies and experiences of SMEs in the F&B sector, showcasing the key ingredient for success in this rapidly changing industry.

site_title: Crafting IYUNO's success story
summary: IYUNO Media Group, a subtitling and dubbing services provider, is poised for growth as video streaming services and content creators enter the digital media market. Founded in 2002 by David Lee, the company shifted its focus in 2010 to provide multi-language services, expanding its offerings and setting up overseas offices. Today, IYUNO employs 700 people globally and has merged with London-based BTI Studios to become the largest media localization company. The company is investing in AI-driven translation engines and exploring new markets like gaming and e-learning, driven by demand for media localization.

site_title: Lobster rolls: Clawing to success
summary: The lobster roll has become a dining phenomenon in Singapore, with several high-end and affordable options popping up across the city. The dish originated in the US in the 1920s and gained popularity in the 1970s. Today, restaurants like Burger & Lobster, Pince & Pints, and Chunky Lobsters offer lobster rolls with prices ranging from $16 to $68. The key to a good lobster roll lies in the quality of the lobster, with chefs emphasizing the importance of live seafood and proper preparation. As the market becomes more discerning, affordable options are emerging, making the lobster roll more accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on October 3, 2019, with various articles covering news from July 10-11, 2025. Notable events include US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, China urging South-east Asia to back openness amidst US tariffs, and Chinese property shares surging on unverified reports of meeting to revive the sector. Meanwhile, Reliance Jio, backed by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Health Management International (HMI) is set to hold a shareholder meeting on October 18 to vote on a privatization deal with private equity investor EQT Mid Market Asia III GP BV. The deal values HMI at approximately S$611 million, with shareholders receiving either S$0.73 in cash or one new ordinary share in PanAsia Health, indirectly controlled by EQT GP. If approved, HMI will not hold its annual general meeting or issue its annual report for fiscal 2019.

site_title: Temasek seeks sane valuations from Asean 'aspiring unicorns'
summary: Temasek Holdings is seeking "sane valuations" for Southeast Asian startups, focusing on the next tier of "aspiring unicorns" after investing in companies like Zilingo. The firm plans to announce deals in the pipeline within the next few months, following a year of investments in the space. This move comes as abundant capital chases unicorns, with Temasek looking to capitalize on the next tier of growth potential.

site_title: 2020 is coming, folks. Fashion will get dressier
summary: Nicolas Ghesquière, artistic director of Louis Vuitton women's wear, closed Paris Fashion Week with a show that marked the beginning of a new decade. The collection featured a mix of retro and contemporary elements, including belle époque prints, rainbow sequin knits, and angular hourglass silhouettes. Ghesquière emphasized the importance of embracing change and tradition, stating that fashion should grow from what it learns. The show was part of a larger trend in the fashion industry, which is shifting towards a deeper, more systemic approach to challenging received conventions and traditions.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs expected to lead Airbnb's listing
summary: Airbnb is set to hire Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs as joint lead advisers for its planned stock market flotation in 2020, opting for a direct listing over an initial public offering (IPO) due to lower fees. The company is valued at $31 billion and plans to go public around the middle of 2020, avoiding potential stock market volatility before the US presidential election. This would follow the routes taken by Spotify and Slack, which have seen their shares trade down since going public.

site_title: Hawker Fete
summary: Malaysian and Singaporean street food vendors will come together at Gardens By The Bay for "Hawker Culture," a regional culinary event organized by Maybank. The festival, taking place on October 5-6, will feature popular hawkers from the Asean region, including Michelin-starred Hawker Chan and Malaysian favorites like Kwong Wah Cendol. The event also explores the stories and traditions behind the cooking. Tickets are available at www.hapz.com/festivals/hawkerculture-2019-tickets.

site_title: Pulitzer Movie
summary: The film adaptation of Donna Tartt's Pulitzer-winning novel "The Goldfinch" received mixed reviews, with critics labeling it "dull" but a select audience giving it a 73 out of 100 score on Rottentomatoes.com. Directed by John Crowley and starring Nicole Kidman and Ansel Elgort, the film follows the story of a boy who steals a Dutch master's painting and grows up to become an expert antiques dealer. Legendary cinematographer Roger Deakins captures the many worlds of the story, despite the quiet and understated film being panned by critics.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage's share price is maintained at "hold" by UOB Kay Hian due to its successful ramp-up of Sabeco business and potential merger and acquisition opportunities. The brokerage firm suggests an entry price of S$0.76. AEM Holdings' share price is maintained at "buy" by Maybank Kim Eng, driven by increased equipment orders for extreme ultraviolet lithography equipment and potential earnings upside for FY2020-2021.

site_title: Rethink future of shipping with Tuas Port: PM
summary: Singapore's Tuas Port, set to be the world's single largest fully automated terminal, is expected to handle 65 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) of containers annually by 2040. The $20 billion project, completed in 2040, aims to improve efficiency and sustainability. It will incorporate intelligent data-driven operations, driverless automated vehicles, and autonomous drone solutions. The port will also be part of a wider Tuas Ecosystem, comprising supply chain nodes for related industries. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of innovation and sustainability in the project, calling it an opportunity to "rethink the future of shipping."

site_title: US dollar recoups losses before data release
summary: The US dollar recovered from a near one-month low against the Japanese yen, steadying at 107.12 yen, ahead of key US data releases. Investors are cautious due to weak manufacturing surveys and recession worries. The dollar has gained in recent weeks as investors expect the US economy to outperform others, but risk aversion is still present. Futures data show a three-month high in long dollar bets, while the euro and pound also experienced gains, despite mixed economic news.

site_title: Young guns fire up Singapore industries
summary: Singaporean young companies, including Emage Vision, Spark Systems, and Xjera, won the Emerging Enterprise Award for their innovative offerings in various industries. The awards, now in their 12th year, recognize businesses with annual sales turnover of up to S$20 million. The winners received prizes worth S$315,000, including consultancy services and interest-free business overdraft facilities. The government will continue to foster a pro-business environment, encouraging businesses to work together to innovate and reduce individual risk.

site_title: Ramen Stars
summary: A new ramen stall at Picnic Food Park in Wisma Atria, Singapore, has been launched in collaboration with two Michelin-starred Seizan restaurant in Tokyo. The stall offers three-noodle menu items, including Seizan Uni Ramen, made with Seizan's proprietary dashi and featuring bafun uni and cream. This marks the debut of Seizan Uni Ramen in Singapore, just before Ichiran Ramen's pop-up at this year's Japan Food Matsuri.

site_title: Fewer HDB resale flats sold in Sept as prices continue slide: SRX
summary: Fewer HDB resale flats were sold in September, with 1,875 units changing hands, a 4.9% decline from August. Prices fell 0.2% from August but rose 0.1% from the previous year. The median transaction over X-value (TOX) was negative, indicating people are underpaying for flats, with executive flats recording the largest negative TOX of S$6,000. Resale flat prices for the third quarter fell 0.1% compared to the preceding quarter, continuing the downtrend since 2019.

site_title: Realising 2025 cheque-free goal needs concerted effort by all banks
summary: Singapore aims to phase out cheques by 2025, a goal that requires concerted effort from all banks. Despite advances in electronic payments, many individuals and businesses continue to use cheques, with SMEs accounting for 80% of OCBC's business cheque volume in 2018. To encourage e-payments, banks have raised cheque charges and provided discounts for those who switch. However, the goal is ambitious and may be hindered by cash flow issues and high costs for some SMEs, which could be exacerbated by the two-to-three business day delay in cheque clearance.

site_title: Digital payments at forefront of S-E Asia's booming Internet economy
summary: South-east Asia's digital payments market has hit an inflection point, with growth projected to propel the region's Internet economy to a $300 billion market by 2025, up from $200 billion in 2016. The market has seen double-digit growth and is expected to exceed $1 trillion by 2025, with 360 million internet users still largely unbanked or uninsured. Non-bank players, including e-commerce giants like Lazada and Grab, are competing for market share, with fintech funding in the region expected to increase two to three times over the next five years.

site_title: APAC family offices outperform global peers
summary: APAC family offices outperformed global peers with a 6.2% return over the past 12 months, driven by increased equity and private equity investments. This surpassed the global average of 5.4%, which was down from 15.5% in the previous year due to weaker economic conditions.

site_title: Aspiring SEA unicorns waiting to take off, but more funding lift needed
summary: Nearly 70 startups in Southeast Asia, valued between $100 million and $1 billion, are awaiting unicorn status, according to a report by Temasek, Google, and Bain. These "aspiring unicorns" raised $1.1 billion in funding in the first half of 2019, with e-commerce and ride-hailing dominating the funding scene. However, the report suggests that more funding is needed to bridge the gap to unicorn status, particularly at the Series C and D stages. Experts predict that at least three of these startups could become unicorns by next year, with institutional investors and private equity players increasingly targeting early-stage ventures.

site_title: Point And Shoot
summary: Leica Playground, a one-day photography event, will take place on October 5 at Design Orchard. The event features workshops, art installations, and an exhibition showcasing Thomas Hoepker's work, as well as sessions on photographing luxury timepieces and whisky. Admission is free, while workshops are priced at S$15. The event aims to bring together photography enthusiasts and watch connoisseurs for a unique experience.

site_title: Soulful Seattle
summary: Seattle, a city in the Pacific Northwest, has become a popular destination for relaxation and self-discovery. With Singapore Airlines' new direct flights, travelers can easily access the city's attractions, including Pike Place Market, the Space Needle, and the Museum of Pop Culture. Seattle is known for its food scene, offering a wide variety of seafood, steakhouses, and independent shops. The city's proximity to natural parks and mountains provides ample opportunities for outdoor activities like hiking and camping. Seattle's calm and introspective vibe makes it an ideal destination for those seeking a break from the fast-paced city life.

site_title: Control Freak
summary: Ulysse Nardin's new CEO, Patrick Pruniaux, has revamped the brand's iconic Freak watch collection, expanding it into a full-fledged collection with various price points and complications. The revamped collection includes the affordable Freak Out and Freak X, and the highly technical Freak NeXt concept watch. Pruniaux aims to widen the Freak's consumer base while maintaining the product's identity, and sees the collection as a platform for innovation and reaching out to new customers. The revamped Freak collection is expected to continue to push the boundaries of watchmaking and material science.

images.alt_text: Freak NeXt introduced a new 3D flying oscillator.
Patrick Pruniaux streamlined and expanded the Freak into a fullfledged collection.
Freak X sells for a fraction of the price of the usual Freak carousell tourbillon model.

site_title: SGX aims to be the single-point access to Asia
summary: SGX aims to be a single-point access to Asia, offering 99% coverage of the region's GDP. Amidst Hong Kong Exchanges' takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange, SGX's CEO Loh Boon Chye emphasized the need for investors to diversify across multiple asset classes. The exchange has invested in platforms to scale up asset classes, including iron ore futures and commodities. SGX plans to expand its equity product range, digitize processes, and grow its fixed income, commodities, and FX trading platforms. The exchange aims to double revenues in its FICC business line and scale up its data, connectivity, and indices business over the next five years.

site_title: Are Europe's prospects brighter than they appear?
summary: The European economy is expected to experience a slowdown, with the IMF forecasting 1.3% growth this year, down 0.6 percentage points from last year. Germany's growth is expected to be 0.7%, compared to 1.9% previously. Europe's overdependence on trade and poor policy responses to economic shocks have contributed to the slowdown. However, an easing of fiscal policy and the European Central Bank's decision to resume quantitative easing may help alleviate the situation, particularly for highly indebted countries like Italy. A strong recovery for Europe as a whole is now considered more likely than previously thought.

site_title: Logistics sector tops warehouse occupancy in Singapore: Colliers
summary: Singapore's logistics sector dominates warehouse occupancy, accounting for 44% of occupied warehouse space. The sector, comprising freight forwarders and logistics companies, is expected to benefit from regional trade and e-commerce growth. Colliers forecasts a moderate increase in warehouse demand, with a stabilizing vacancy rate of 10.8% by 2020, driven by the city-state's logistics hub status and limited supply growth.

site_title: Thailand gives CP Group till Oct 15 to sign 225b baht rail deal
summary: Thailand has set a deadline of October 15 for Charoen Pokphand Group (CP) to sign a $7.36 billion investment agreement for a high-speed train project. CP Group's bid, worth $2 billion less than competitors', won the project in May. Failure to sign by the deadline could result in CP Group and other companies being blacklisted for future government projects. The project, a private-public partnership, aims to connect Thailand's main international airport to low-cost carriers in eastern Thailand.

site_title: Outsiders show what they can do
summary: Audrey Chew, a former corporate executive, transformed her father's you tiao hawker stall into a manufacturing business, despite having no F&B experience. Undeterred by industry challenges, she persevered and is now making a mark in Singapore's F&B sector. Chew's determination is a testament to her ability to adapt and succeed in a new field, proving that outsiders can make a significant impact in the industry.

site_title: Winners embody 'unstoppable' theme
summary: Five entrepreneurs have been named winners of the EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2019 Singapore awards. The recipients, representing media and entertainment, education, digital media supply chain, workspace solutions, and financial services, took home the awards for their respective sectors. The winners are Ron Tan, Ng Gim Choo, David Lee, Kong Wan Sing, and Yeah Hiang Nam. Their achievements were recognized for their impact on their industries and the region.

site_title: Neon Lights Shine Brighter
summary: The Neon Lights music and arts festival in Singapore has expanded its line-up with 13 new acts, including Nick Murphy, BadBadNotGood, and Mura Masa. Headliners Mumford & Sons, Halsey, and Honne will join the previously announced acts for the two-day event on November 23-24. The festival features a range of activities, gourmet food, and drinks, with tickets available from S$30 for children and S$128 for adults.

site_title: Banking on digital
summary: The advent of digital banking in Singapore is opening up opportunities for non-traditional finance players. Companies like Singtel and Grab, as well as peer-to-peer lender Validus, are exploring the potential to serve underserved segments, including gig economy workers, millennials, and small and medium-sized enterprises. Digital banking is expected to further disrupt the traditional banking sector, with new players potentially pitching their resources to meet the needs of these groups.

site_title: BOJ will take pre-emptive action: official
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may take pre-emptive action to address economic risks, according to a board member's remarks. Yukitoshi Funo emphasized the need for the central bank to act swiftly if hazards increase. This suggests a potential shift towards further easing at the BOJ's October meeting. Global pressures, including US tariffs and China's slowing GDP growth, are intensifying and may prompt the BOJ to take action.

site_title: Uber launches jobs app that links temp workers with businesses
summary: Uber launches Uber Works, a jobs app connecting temporary workers with businesses in Chicago, aiming to fill shifts and address high turnover. The app, available only in Chicago, shows available shifts and assists businesses with staffing. Uber Works partners with staffing agencies and connects directly with businesses, providing detailed shift information and time-tracking capabilities. This move diversifies Uber's core business and addresses regulatory scrutiny and competition in the ride-hailing market.

site_title: Spreading trade war, Dow dive spark Asia markets sell-off
summary: Asian markets experienced a sell-off on Thursday, following a bloodbath on Wall Street, amid concerns over a spreading trade war, Brexit, and the US economy's deteriorating growth prospects. The Dow Jones plunged 1.9% on Wednesday, triggering sell-offs in Asian equities, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Australia's ASX 200 falling 2% and 2.2%, respectively. However, analysts note that Asian markets' relatively low valuation may cushion the downside, and some expect a rate cut by the Federal Reserve to stabilize the global economy.

site_title: Furthering a philanthropic vision
summary: Dennis Uy, founder and chairman of Udenna Corporation, has made a significant impact on the Philippine economy and society through job creation and charity-driven ventures. Established in 2002, the company has seven business pillars, including Phoenix Petroleum, Dito Telecommunity Corporation, and PH Resorts Group Holdings. Uy's philanthropic vision is evident in the group's expansion into infrastructure development and education, with initiatives such as building libraries and running blood donation drives. He has received the EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence Award 2019 for his contributions to the economy and community in the region.

site_title: S$5m tech centre to boost energy efficiency for SMEs to be launched by end-2019
summary: A tech centre to help Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) become more energy-efficient will be launched by the end of 2019, costing S$5 million. The Energy Efficiency Technology Centre (EETC) will assist SMEs in assessing their energy efficiency and improving their performance.

site_title: Finding wine and meaning in ancient vineyards
summary: Ancient vineyards, planted decades or centuries ago, have been rediscovered for their potential in producing fine wines. These hidden gems, often on steep slopes, were previously used for local or personal needs, but now younger winemakers are preserving them to create wines that showcase their cultural heritage. Three wines from Chile's Itata Valley region, made from Cinsault grapes, demonstrate the unique characteristics of these old vines, offering a glimpse into the place and traditions behind them.

site_title: Ascendas Reit buys Aussie property for A$110.9m
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is acquiring a Melbourne office property in Australia for A$110.9 million, with 65% of space pre-committed for 10 years. The property will have a net lettable area of 17,507 square meters and is expected to receive practical completion in the second quarter of 2020. The acquisition is DPU accretive and has an annualized pro forma financial effect of 0.014 Singapore cents, improving Ascendas Reit's Australian portfolio's weighted average lease term to expiry.

site_title: Ex-Singapore banker takes on Grab in Manila with motorcycle-taxi app
summary: A former Singaporean banker, Angeline Tham, has launched Angkas, a motorcycle-taxi app in Manila, challenging ride-hailing giant Grab. With 3 million downloads and 27,000 registered drivers, Angkas has become one of the Philippines' most popular ride-hailing services, operating on a temporary license. Tham aims to secure full legality by December and is focusing on safety, with a 99.997% safety record. The app promises faster commutes starting at 50 pesos, potentially opening the door to new competitors in the region.

site_title: In praise of Putien
summary: A newly re-opened Putien branch in Singapore's ION Orchard has generated buzz for its vibrant atmosphere and over-the-top self-promotion. The Fujian eatery boasts an impressive array of dishes, including eel, claypot croaker, and braised pigs' intestines, which have received positive reviews. The restaurant's cheerful vibe and friendly staff have won over diners, despite some dishes, such as the yam paste with ginkgo nuts, falling short. Overall, Putien's food is considered "generally tasty" and worth visiting for a happy meal experience.

images.alt_text: Putien is a brightly lit, family-style Fujian eatery with a cheerful, comfort food vibe that makes you feel right at home.
Crowdpleasers include Clay Pot Yellow Croaker (above) that is simply blanched in a clear sweet broth; Salt And Pepper Crispy Oysters; and Pan-fried Live Eel on Hot Plate.
Crowdpleasers include Clay Pot Yellow Croaker that is simply blanched in a clear sweet broth; Salt And Pepper Crispy Oysters (above); and Pan-fried Live Eel on Hot Plate.
Crowdpleasers include Clay Pot Yellow Croaker that is simply blanched in a clear sweet broth; Salt And Pepper Crispy Oysters; and Pan-fried Live Eel on Hot Plate (above).

site_title: Owners of luxury Vietnam apartment project left hanging
summary: Luxury apartment project in Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City, jointly developed by Novaland Investment, is in limbo due to the government seizing the land. The project, Novahome Madison, was completed in 2018 but residents have yet to move in. The land seizure is linked to a criminal case involving a former Vietnam official. Novaland has offered buyers options, including waiting for the land's legal status to be resolved or receiving a full refund, with around 80% of buyers agreeing to wait it out.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure eyes smart city projects with new major shareholder
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has partnered with South Korea-listed Magic Micro to explore smart city projects. Magic Micro, a substantial shareholder with a 20.3% stake, will provide technological expertise and network to Raffles Infrastructure. The partnership aims to tap into the growing global smart city market, valued at $2 trillion by 2025. Raffles Infrastructure is seeking to invest in Asia's infrastructure, following a memorandum of understanding signed by the two companies.

site_title: Petal Power
summary: Australian florist Saskia Havekes shares her approach to creating unique floral arrangements. Her style involves curating blooms in a vase, with a strong structural base of foliage, and using quality flowers. Havekes provides a step-by-step guide to creating a Wild Garden Ensemble, which includes a mix of flowers and foliage. The arrangement's design allows the eye to travel around the vase, creating a visually appealing display. Havekes encourages experimentation and emphasizes the importance of using high-quality flowers to achieve a lasting arrangement.

site_title: A Grand Display
summary: Patek Philippe's grand exhibition in Singapore is a massive investment that has paid off, according to its president Thierry Stern. The 16-day event, open to the public, features over 2000 timepieces and showcases the brand's watchmaking universe. With an estimated cost of "millions" of Swiss francs, it is the largest and longest of Patek Philippe's biennial grand showcases. The exhibition aims to promote the brand's credibility and introduce the mechanical world of watchmaking to a younger audience, with Stern stating it will be beneficial for other Swiss watch brands as well.

site_title: As much as US$4b left HK for Singapore due to protests: Goldman
summary: US investment firm Goldman Sachs estimated that Hong Kong may have lost up to $4 billion in deposits to Singapore between June and August due to escalating protests. The bank's analysts noted modest net outflows from local currency deposits in Hong Kong and net inflows of foreign currency deposits in Singapore. Hong Kong's stockpile of deposits stood at $13.6 trillion in August, with US dollar savings surging and Hong Kong dollar deposits dropping the most in over a year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority attributed the fluctuations to "normal" market practices.

site_title: Beethoven Heaven
summary: The Beethoven im Garten open-air concert, held at the Singapore Botanic Gardens, celebrates German-Singaporean cultural ties. Maestro Kahchun Wong conducts 16 musicians in a performance of Beethoven's 6th Symphony. The event, a partnership between the German Embassy, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, and Nuremberg Symphony, takes place on October 5, 2019, at 6pm, with picnic grounds open from 5pm. The concert is free and marks Wong's performance with the Nuremberg Symphony since 2017.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after sharp slide
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday after a 3% decline in the past two sessions due to recession risk data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.15%, the S&P 500 opened 0.08% lower, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.02%. Investor attention focused on services data scheduled for later in the day.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.78 points to 1,564.12, as losers outnumbered gainers 495 to 303. Volume was 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion.

site_title: Scotch whisky fears bad hangover from US tariffs
summary: The Scotch whisky industry is set to face a 25% tariff on imports to the US due to a World Trade Organisation-approved retaliatory measure against the European Union over aircraft subsidies. This affects single malt Scotch and liqueurs, with the US imposing a total of $7.5 billion in import tariffs, including on British items like cheeses, French wine, and "Made in England" suits. The Scotch Whisky Association estimates the sector will be hit hard, with $460 million in US exports at risk.

site_title: Healthtech startup Biofourmis gets FDA approval for analytics engine
summary: Biofourmis, a Singapore-based healthtech startup, received FDA approval for its patient data-monitoring solution, the Biovitals Analytics Engine. The AI-powered engine enables constant monitoring of individual patients' physiology-based health data. CEO Kuldeep Singh Rajput stated that the approval will accelerate the development and commercialization of digital therapeutic solutions. The engine is the foundation of Biofourmis' set of Biovitals products, offering a medical device for patient monitoring.

site_title: 'John Soh would use bankruptcy to secure loyalty from associates'
summary: Former remisier Tai Chee Ming testified in the trial against alleged mastermind John Soh Chee Wen that Soh would make people around him stay loyal by making them bankrupt and then drip-feed them financially. Tai was part of the "inner circle" of the 2013 penny stock market-rigging scheme, which wiped out S$8 billion in market value. He claimed that Soh had "substantial funds" despite the scheme's collapse and enriched himself through a corporate deal with an Edward Lee, leaving others to suffer losses.

site_title: Notion Capital raises US$150m for its 4th fund
summary: Notion Capital, a British tech investor, has raised US$150 million for its fourth fund focused on European startups offering software as a service. The fund now has over half a billion dollars in assets under management. Notion typically invests in post-seed companies with US$1 million in annual revenues, aiming to scale them to US$1 million to US$100 million. The firm has achieved returns approaching three times on its first fund, with notable exits including a US$350 million sale of marketing firm NewVoiceMedia.

site_title: The Tiles That Bind
summary: Australian artist Jennifer Lim discovered her Singaporean identity through heritage tiles while living in Singapore. She first encountered the tiles while walking near Emerald Hill and later delved into them after attending the exhumation of her great-grandfather's grave. Lim's fascination with these colorful tiles has led her to explore her Singaporean heritage, showcasing the significance of these tiles in Singaporean culture.

site_title: Time for ST Telemedia, Singtel to inject their data centres into Reits?
summary: Temasek and ST Telemedia, subsidiaries of Singtel, are considering spinning off their data centers into real estate investment trusts (Reits) to ease capital expenditure and focus on core businesses. The move could be worth up to S$6 billion, with Singtel's data centers valued between S$400 million and S$2.2 billion. A spin-off would follow Keppel DC Reit, Asia's first data center Reit, and could provide better pricing and global coverage for enterprises. Analysts see the value in such spin-offs, given the accommodative interest rate environment and favorable demand-supply fundamentals.

site_title: New measures to develop construction industry professionals, raise building standards
summary: Singapore's SCAL announces new measures to boost construction industry professionals, including a Construction Professional Accreditation Scheme and a Young Leaders in Construction programme, aiming to raise building standards. The schemes will provide better recognition and career paths for industry professionals and nurture the next generation of leaders. The initiatives are set to be rolled out by 2020, focusing on technical and managerial skills for construction project managers and developing relationships among young leaders and industry stakeholders.

site_title: Israel's parliament sworn in without new government
summary: Israel's parliament was sworn in without a new government being formed, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to secure a coalition with his main opponent Benny Gantz's Blue and White alliance. The stalemate raises the risk of a short parliament term and another election, with Netanyahu seeking a unity government that could include Gantz. Netanyahu's lawyers are also seeking to fend off corruption charges against him, while the president calls on the rival leaders to come together. Netanyahu has 28 days to form a government, but has signaled he may inform the president he is unable to do so.

site_title: Being a boyfriend to half a million people
summary: 17-year-old YouTube personality Owen Dennis Riley creates ASMR role-play videos as a "boyfriend" to help his half-million subscribers relax and sleep better. His channel, DennisASMR, combines ASMR techniques with doting behaviors often associated with romantic partners. While Owen's content has gained popularity, some experts, including Dr. Caroline Fleck, a clinical psychologist, question the authenticity and potential impact of these role-play videos on viewers, citing concerns about unrealistic behavior and emotional manipulation. Despite this, Owen's videos have been praised for their emotional intelligence and validation, drawing from his own experiences with anxiety and loneliness.

site_title: Pepsi says consumer chugging along even with higher prices
summary: PepsiCo Inc reported strong Q3 results, beating Wall Street estimates with sales and profit growth. Higher prices on its drinks and snacks, despite economic slowdown indicators, showed US consumers are willing to pay more. The company's shares surged 3.5% as a result, marking the largest intraday gain in over five months. CEO Hugh Johnston attributed the strong performance to US consumers doing well, with the company set to meet or exceed full-year revenue growth.

site_title: Knife attack at Paris police headquarters kills at least 4 officers
summary: At least 4 police officers were killed in a knife attack at Paris police headquarters by an administrative employee who had worked there for over 20 years. The attacker, shot and killed by a police officer, started the assault in his office before moving to other areas. The motive is not yet known, but the attack raises concerns about terrorism in Paris, following previous incidents such as the Charlie Hebdo attack in 2015.

site_title: IYUNO Media Group CEO David Lee named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2019
summary: IYUNO Media Group CEO David Lee was named the overall EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2019 Singapore. He will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year competition in June 2020. Lee founded IYUNO in 2002 as an English-to-Korean subtitling service provider and has since grown the company into a global media service provider. He received the EOY award under the Digital Media Supply Chain category and dedicated it to fellow entrepreneurs who persevere in making their vision a reality.

site_title: Spokesman defends dishevelled Duterte as 'very hygienic'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte was mocked on social media for appearing disheveled in a meeting with Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. However, his spokesman, Salvador Panelo, defended the president, stating that he is "very hygienic" and has a "refreshing scent". Panelo attributed Duterte's rumpled appearance to discomfort with tight collars, not a lack of personal hygiene. The incident highlights Duterte's casual approach to fashion, which is consistent with his public statements about disliking formal wear.

site_title: UK Brexit proposals do not 'represent a basis for an agreement': MEPs
summary: UK's new Brexit proposals to the EU do not represent a basis for an agreement, according to the European Parliament's Brexit steering group. The proposals fall short in several key areas, including abolishing the backstop and threatening the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, which ended the Northern Ireland conflict. The group cited concerns over customs infrastructure, a lack of guarantee on transition period details, and a unilateral right for the Northern Ireland assembly to decide on the agreement. The MEPs deemed the proposals "grave concerns" and do not find them in their current form as a basis for agreement.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% on new trade war front, recession fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.5% on Thursday, with trading volume reaching 81% of the daily average in the first eight months of 2019. Despite a lack of fundamental changes for most locally listed entities, traders saw opportunities to buy undervalued counters such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Hongkong Land. Analysts advised clients to focus on dividend-paying defensive stocks, citing the potential for a "buy day" after two days of selling.

site_title: Trump says China's Xi should start investigating the Bidens
summary: President Donald Trump suggested that China's Xi Jinping should investigate the Bidens, calling for a probe into Joe Biden and his son Hunter. This comes after Trump reiterated his call for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to reopen an investigation into the Bidens. Trump's allegations have been discredited, and he is seeking to shift the focus to China.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said Thursday that China's Xi Jinping should consider investigating Joe Biden and his son after again calling on Ukraine's president to re-open an investigation into one of his top political rivals.

site_title: Europeans at UN seek meeting after latest North Korea missile test
summary: European powers Britain, France, and Germany have requested a closed-door UN Security Council meeting after North Korea's latest submarine-launched ballistic missile test. The test, seen as a significant step in North Korea's nuclear program, has raised concerns about the country's defence capability. The meeting comes as the US and North Korea prepare to resume nuclear talks this week. European diplomats emphasize the need to keep up pressure on North Korea, while Russia and China have called for the UN to start lifting sanctions to create momentum for denuclearization.

site_title: Climate change: global patience is running out
summary: The global community is increasingly recognizing the urgent need for climate action, with young people taking to the streets and politicians taking note. Despite decades of warnings from the scientific community, emissions continue to rise, and the world is on track for a 3°C-plus heating. The UN Climate Action Summit in New York highlighted the need for radical action, with investors and governments facing pressure to align with the Paris Agreement targets. A new study found that climate progress in the energy sector is slow, and a policy response by governments is expected by 2025, which could result in a 60% fall in emissions by 2050.

site_title: US panel to interview Boeing engineer on 737 MAX's safety issues
summary: A US panel has requested Boeing to interview an engineer involved in the development of the 737 MAX due to an ethics complaint filed by the worker. The complaint alleged that Boeing rejected a safety system to minimize costs, which could have reduced risks contributing to two fatal crashes. The engineer claims that Boeing convinced regulators to relax safety standards, including striking out four clauses that would have required a complete upgrade of the 737's flight-crew-alerting system. The committee is preparing for a hearing on October 30 to discuss the matter further.

site_title: Indian women's cricket sensation needed boy's haircut to play
summary: India's 15-year-old women's cricket sensation Shafali Verma had to get her hair cut like a boy to attend a local cricket academy, according to her father. The teenager, known for her aggressive batting, made her Twenty20 debut for the national team against South Africa last month and will soon tour the West Indies. Verma's father, Sanjeev, revealed the struggle to get her daughter accepted in games due to her long hair, which is a requirement for participating in the academy.

site_title: Singapore factory outlook falls to 3-year low in September as new orders shrink
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted in September, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.5, its lowest mark since July 2016. The sector's outlook has weakened due to new orders shrinking and employment contraction, with cost pressures also increasing. The contractionary PMI prints correspond with shrinking industrial production, fuelling recession fears. Economists warn that the sluggish momentum may lead to a softening in the labor market and a downgrade in the 2020 growth outlook if the trend persists.

site_title: Asia rice-waning demand prompts Indian, Thai exporters to lower prices
summary: Indian and Thai rice exporters lowered prices amid weak demand and currency fluctuations. Thai 5% broken rice prices fell to $396-$417 per tonne, while Indian prices dropped to $369-$373 per tonne. Vietnamese rates for 5% broken rice fell to $330-$340 per tonne, nearing a 12-year low. The decline in prices is attributed to subdued demand and high prices in Asia, with exporters waiting for the new season crop.

images.alt_text: Rice export rates in Asian hubs fell this week as weak demand and currency fluctuations prompted sellers in India and Thailand to cut prices, while expectations of lower interest from the Philippines weighed on the Vietnamese market.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes down 2% on US economy worries
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 2% on Thursday, down 2.01% or 436.87 points, to 21,341.74, amid US economy worries. Weak US jobs data and recession fears led to selloffs on Wall Street, with the dollar rising to 107.18 yen. Shares across Tokyo's board dropped, with Toyota and Honda falling 2.47% and 2.67%, respectively. The market is now focusing on US unemployment figures and US-China talks next week, with investors bracing for further economic uncertainty.

site_title: Airbnb adds getaways in tune with the animal kingdom
summary: Airbnb has launched "Animal Experiences" offering travelers interactions with animals, such as lazing with alpacas or helping dogs in the Chernobyl exclusion zone. The new nature-focused category aims to provide environmentally friendly tourism, with a focus on animal welfare. Airbnb's animal welfare policy bars direct contact with wild animals and prohibits trophy hunting, and users can opt for adventures that support conservation and animal rescue causes. The company's expansion into animal experiences comes as it prepares for its stock market debut next year.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure eyes smart city projects with new shareholder
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has partnered with Magic Micro Co, a South Korea-listed firm, to explore smart city projects and infrastructure investments. The collaboration aims to tap into Magic Micro's technological expertise and network. The global smart city market is expected to surge to $2 trillion by 2025, with Asia accounting for 40% of the market. Magic Micro has acquired a 20.3% stake in Raffles Infrastructure, becoming its second-largest shareholder.

site_title: RHB Bank's US$300 million senior notes fully redeemed
summary: RHB Bank has fully redeemed its existing US$300 million senior unsecured notes issued in 2014 under its US$5 billion euro medium term note programme. The notes will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange and Labuan International Financial Exchange.

site_title: Malaysia proposes RM86m fine on Grab for abusive practices
summary: Malaysia's competition regulator proposed a fine of over RM86 million on ride-hailing firm Grab for allegedly abusing its dominant position by imposing restrictive clauses on its drivers. The Malaysia Competition Commission (MyCC) ruled that Grab's clauses prevented drivers from promoting competitors, distorting competition and creating barriers to entry. Grab has 30 working days to address concerns before a final decision is made. The fine is Malaysia's third penalty on Grab, following similar fines in Singapore and the Philippines.

site_title: Ascendas Reit acquires Australian suburban office for A$110.9m
summary: Ascendas Reit is acquiring a suburban office property in Melbourne, Australia for A$110.9 million. The 17,507 sqm office building will have 65% of space pre-committed for 10 years. The acquisition is expected to be DPU accretive and improve the Reit's portfolio, with a weighted average lease term to expiry expected to improve to 4.5 years. The property will be developed and completed by 2020, with Nissan Motor Co starting a 10-year lease for 65.2% of the space.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher after face mask ban report
summary: Hong Kong shares ended higher on Thursday after reports that the government will ban the use of face masks at public gatherings, lifting hopes that officials could calm down increasingly violent protests in the city. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.26% to 26,110.31. The ban report was seen as a positive development for the market, which had been weighed down by protests and social unrest.

site_title: Britain's Johnson sets out defence of new Brexit plan
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson outlines a new Brexit plan, winning support from Conservative MPs, but faces skepticism from EU leaders, who express concerns about the deal's ability to preserve a free-flowing border across the island of Ireland. Johnson's plan involves creating two temporary economic borders, including one in the Irish Sea, and giving Northern Ireland the right to end its alignment with Ireland by 2025. The EU and UK must agree on the plan by the weekend to avoid a crash exit or a third Brexit delay.

site_title: Saudi Arabia fully restores oil output after attacks
summary: Saudi Arabia has fully restored its oil output after attacks on its facilities in September 2019, with a current production capacity of 11.3 million barrels per day. The kingdom is now focusing on listing its energy giant Saudi Aramco. Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman made the announcement at an energy conference in Moscow.

site_title: US labour market stable, disruptions feared from federal government layoffs
summary: The US labor market remains stable, with initial claims for state unemployment benefits rising 5,000 to 219,000 for the week ended Feb 15. Despite historically low layoffs, economists warn that federal government layoffs and spending cuts could disrupt the market, particularly in Washington DC and adjacent states. The Federal Reserve is monitoring the economic impact of the Trump administration's policies, and interest rates remain unchanged. Claims data suggests a healthy labor market, but economists expect a potential slowdown in job growth in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s decision to maintain its benchmark interest rate between 4.25 and 4.50 per cent came just days after Donald Trump took office and took place against the backdrop of a small uptick in consumer inflation.

site_title: Jokowi wants Indonesia to be more than a raw material giant
summary: Indonesia's President Jokowi aims to process more of its abundant natural resources domestically, including crude palm oil, to increase added values and reduce reliance on raw materials. The move is expected to boost prices globally and benefit the country's economy, which is projected to grow at its fastest pace in seven years in 2020. By increasing domestic processing, Indonesia aims to spur domestic investment, generate jobs, and improve the environment by reducing reliance on imported petroleum and the impact of subsidy costs.

site_title: Facebook may have to censor online hate globally, EU judges say
summary: The European Union's Court of Justice ruled that Facebook may be ordered to remove offensive and defamatory posts globally, forcing the platform to patrol its content worldwide. EU judges can also order a worldwide removal, taking international law into account. This decision comes after the bloc's highest court approved a code of conduct signed by platforms such as Facebook and Google to tackle online hate speech. The ruling aims to overhaul liability rules for platforms and impose fines on companies that fail to remove illegal content quickly enough, building on existing legislation in Germany.

site_title: As protests rack Hong Kong, China watchdog has Cathay staff 'walking on eggshells'
summary: Hong Kong's flagship airline, Cathay Pacific Airways, is facing a crisis due to China's aviation regulator, the Civil Aviation Authority of China (CAAC), after some staff members took part or expressed support for anti-government protests. The CAAC has rejected crew lists without explanation, forcing Cathay to scramble and pull pilots and flight attendants off standby. The airline has been fined, with 30 employees fired or resigned under pressure, and its CEO and top deputy resigned. The CAAC's labeling of employees as a security risk has created a climate of fear, with employees feeling their job security is uncertain and their freedom of speech is being suppressed.

site_title: European stocks diverge at open
summary: European stocks diverged on Thursday, with the London FTSE 100 index falling 0.3% and the Paris CAC 40 index rising 0.4%. The Frankfurt market remained closed due to a public holiday. Despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty, investors stayed positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks jump, reversing direction after report government to ban face masks
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged to a one-week high on October 3, 2019, after a report suggested the government could ban face masks to quell the city's four-month-long protests. The Hang Seng Index rose over 300 points, reversing losses, and reached its highest level since September 24. The potential mask ban was seen as a positive development, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Vietnam economy set to expand 6.7% in 2019
summary: Vietnam's economy is expected to expand 6.7% in 2019, driven by its transformation into a global manufacturing hub and gains from the US-China trade war. The country's manufacturing and processing industry received $22.6 billion in foreign direct investment, and exports increased 27% in the first six months of 2019. However, challenges lie ahead, including inadequate infrastructure, a relative shortage of workers, and potential accusations of a one-sided relationship with the US. Despite these risks, the report concludes that Vietnam will remain one of the fastest-growing global emerging markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,074.97, down 0.92% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon at 3,074.97, down 0.92% from the previous day, with the Straits Times Index 28.48 points lower. Losers outnumbered gainers 198 to 95, and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC declined. Asian markets fell across the board, following a below-par US jobs report and trade war fears, with Tokyo down 2%, Sydney shedding over 2%, and Hong Kong losing 0.7%.

site_title: Singapore, UK to promote IoT industry best practices for smart consumer products
summary: Singapore and the UK have signed a joint statement to promote the implementation of best practices for the Internet of Things (IoT) industry, focusing on improving the security of smart consumer products. The partnership aims to share initiatives and approaches to ensure that IoT devices have security built in by design, protecting against cyber-attacks, data theft, and physical safety risks. The two nations will adopt a multilateral approach, working with industry and consumer groups to promote the use of universal default passwords, normalise vulnerability disclosure processes, and develop software security updates to protect consumers and the technical ecosystem.

site_title: Australian shares lose A$44b in value as global risks hammer sentiment
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.2% on Thursday, losing A$44 billion in value, amid escalating global economic fears. The US imposed tariffs on European goods, while weak data from the US triggered concerns about a potential recession. Gold stocks were the only bright spot, with Newcrest Mining up 2.8%. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to its lowest close in over a month, with the Big Four banks and energy/mining stocks among the top losers.

site_title: India, Malaysia priciest share markets in Asia: Refinitiv data
summary: India and Malaysia's equities were the most expensive in Asia on October 2, according to Refinitiv data, driven by easing US-China trade tensions and rate cuts by major central banks.
