Kobe shares his views on retail and customer experience, highlighting the importance of embracing creativity and innovation.

site_title: Utico, Hyflux held talks ahead of Nov 1 deadline for rescue plan: lawyer
summary: Utico, a potential white knight, held talks with Hyflux's lawyers on Thursday night ahead of the Nov 1 deadline for a rescue plan. Utico has given Hyflux a 48-hour ultimatum to sign the definitive restructuring agreement, or it will withdraw the deal entirely. Key terms still outstanding include management oversight and a trust mechanism structure for obtaining binding consent from retail holders. If the deal falls through, Utico may withdraw its S$300 million equity injection and S$100 million shareholder loan, which would leave Hyflux with a S$200 million equity injection.

images.alt_text: The advisers of both Hyflux and Utico have held talks on Thursday night and, if required, might have further discussions on Friday afternoon, Hyflux lawyer Manoj Pillay Sandrasegara told The Business Times (BT).

site_title: Hold the vodka: Russians cut drinking 40 per cent under Putin
summary: Russia's alcohol consumption has dropped by 43% since 2003, with a 40% decrease since its peak in the early 2000s. The decline is attributed to measures introduced by President Vladimir Putin, including restrictions on alcohol sales, advertising bans, and increased minimum retail prices. This trend has contributed to increased life expectancies, reaching a historic peak of 78 years for women and 68 years for men in 2018. The changes have also led to a shift towards more "civilized" drinking habits, with people drinking less frequently and later in the night.

images.alt_text: Russians might have a reputation as a nation of hard drinkers, but a report by the World Health Organization published Tuesday showed their alcohol consumption has dropped by more than 40 per cent from its peak in the early 2000s.

site_title: Japan's Sept jobless rate edges up from near three-decade low
summary: Japan's September jobless rate rose to 2.4% from near 30-year lows, with a jobs-to-applicants ratio of 1.57. The tight labor market, driven by an aging and declining population, has hindered wage increases and fueled concerns about a fragile economic recovery. The Bank of Japan kept monetary policy steady but signaled a possible interest rate cut amid overseas risks. This follows a sales tax increase in October, which may impact domestic consumption. The sluggish economy has thwarted policymakers' hopes of creating an expansionary impulse.

site_title: Taylor Swift helps Alibaba plug world's biggest shopping spree
summary: Taylor Swift will headline Alibaba's Singles' Day event in Shanghai next month, marking the highest-profile act to feature on the online shopping extravaganza since its inception. The 29-year-old pop superstar joins celebrities like GEM and Kana Hanazawa in promoting Alibaba's signature event, which aims to take its global. The event is expected to attract 500 million participants, with over 200,000 brands offering new products. Swift's involvement underscores Alibaba's effort to expand its Singles' Day globally, following her successful Prime Day appearances for Amazon.

site_title: UOB Q3 profit up 8% to S$1.12b
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 8% increase in net profit to S$1.12 billion for the third quarter, driven by stronger client franchise income and trading and investment income. Net interest income rose 5% to S$1.69 billion, while net fee and commission income increased 14% to S$551 million. The bank's net interest margin fell to 1.77% due to declining interest rates. Total expenses rose 14% to S$1.15 billion, and allowances jumped 53% to S$145 million.

site_title: European stocks diverge at open
summary: European stocks diverged at the open on October 30, 2019, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% to 7,293.87 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 shed 0.1% to 12,932.55 points. In contrast, Paris's CAC 40 rose 0.2% to 5,750.48, driven by a 7% gain in shares of French carmaker PSA after announcing merger talks with Fiat Chrysler. The market divergence came ahead of a British general election on December 12.

site_title: Memories Of City Hall
summary: A multimedia exhibition "City Hall: If Walls Could Talk" is now on display at the National Gallery Singapore, recounting pivotal moments in Singapore's history within the walls of City Hall. The exhibition, part of the Singapore Bicentennial commemoration, features augmented interactive content and recreates defining historical events, including the fall of Singapore in 1942 and the unveiling of the national flag and anthem in 1959. The exhibition is free for Singaporeans and Permanent Residents until August 29, 2021. It aims to share important memories and connect history with art, according to the National Gallery Singapore.

site_title: Original Treats
summary: Origin+Bloom, a Michelin-starworthy takeaway cake and sandwich shop, has opened in Marina Bay Sands Hotel Tower 3. The shop, run by executive pastry chef Antonio Benites, offers elegant treats such as pound cakes and sandwiches, including the 'whole nine yards' with sourdough bread, cheese, and deli meats. Benites, formerly of Joël Robuchon Restaurant and Pierre Hermés, brings his expertise to create unique flavors like lemon pound cake with confit citrus zest. The shop is a hidden gem in the lobby of Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Boeing completes year of turmoil with promise to Indonesia on 737 MAX crash
summary: Boeing has promised to implement safety recommendations for its 737 MAX aircraft following a report by Indonesian investigators on the Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people in 2018. The company's CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, acknowledged the company's grief over the crash and outlined changes to the MCAS cockpit software, which has been linked to the accident and another Ethiopian Airlines crash. Boeing's response marks a shift in tone compared to its earlier reaction to a preliminary report. The changes aim to address safety concerns and restore confidence in the aircraft.

site_title: Japan Oct factory activity sinks to three-year low, orders fall: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity sank to a three-year low in October, with the manufacturing PMI dropping to 48.4, the lowest level since June 2016. This is the sixth-straight month of contraction, driven by shrinking new orders and output. The decline is partly due to front-loading of purchases ahead of a sales tax hike. Economists warn that weak regional growth and signs of fragility in the domestic economy indicate a fragile economic recovery, with heightened trade tensions and weaker growth worldwide posing a growing economic impact.

site_title: US moves to protect Citgo from creditors
summary: The US Treasury has moved to protect Citgo from Venezuela's creditors by altering sanctions to block transactions involving Citgo shares used to service PDVSA's debt. A $913 million payment on a 2020 bond is due on Monday, which is backed by 50% of Citgo. The new rule will remain in effect through January 22, prohibiting transactions unless specifically authorized. This move aims to prevent Citgo shares from being used to pay off debt, amid Venezuela's economic crisis and US-imposed sanctions on the government.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore aims to generate 2 GWp of solar energy by 2030. EDBI and Temasek's Pavilion Capital invested $275m in a US biotech startup's Series A round. KrisEnergy sold a 30% stake in an Andaman II production sharing contract. Temasek's ABC World Asia closed its inaugural fund at $385m. Singapore shares rose 0.4% due to sustained Brexit and trade deal hopes. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: The Experience Economy Boom
summary: The experience economy boom is driven by consumers prioritizing immersive experiences over material possessions. Brands are adapting by offering engaging experiences that compete with online diversions. Four companies are leading the trend: Andsoforth, Artbox Singapore, Shimano Cycling World, and Zedtown. Andsoforth creates immersive dinner-theatre experiences, Artbox Singapore offers a themed outdoor market with interactive art and shopping, Shimano Cycling World is an experiential cycling gallery promoting local cycling culture, and Zedtown provides a live-action gaming experience. These companies are redefining the way businesses operate, with a focus on creating memorable experiences that drive customer engagement and loyalty.

images.alt_text: Andsoforth founders Stuart Wee and Emily Png.
Scenes from Andsoforth's previous dinner-theatre productions.
Scenes from Andsoforth's previous dinner-theatre productions.

Andrew Garrick, managing director of Zedtown.
Zedtown puts participants right in the centre of a live-action game.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.21 points to 1,580.00 on Wednesday, driven by gains in the market. The index saw 2.3 billion lots traded worth RM 1.7 billion, with 469 losers outnumbering 328 gainers.

site_title: Pick a dance partner carefully in this market
summary: Myanmar's stock market is struggling, with only five listed companies and a trading value of 690 billion kyats. To boost the market, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) plans to create a second board for foreign investors, expected to launch in late 2020. Foreigners may be allowed to trade on the main board next year, and some Asian banks are interested in purchasing a stake in local banks. However, the market is too small for major Western institutional investors, and local investors are cautious due to political volatility and the lack of expertise in accounting and legal services.

site_title: LVMH-backed private equity firm closes US$1.45b Asia fund
summary: L Catterton, a US$15 billion private equity firm backed by LVMH, has closed its third Asia fund at US$1.45 billion, exceeding its target. The fund will focus on retail and healthcare companies in China, Japan, India, and other Asian countries, seeking deals above US$100 million. Managing partner Chinta Bhagat believes growing demand for improved medical and retail experiences among Asia's affluent will help offset trade war concerns and economic slowdown. The fund will run for 10 years and aims to deliver a return of 2 to 2.5 times.

site_title: MindChamps opens A$7m flagship preschool centre in Sydney
summary: MindChamps Preschool has opened a A$7 million flagship centre in Frenchs Forest, Sydney, catering to children aged six weeks to six years. The 94-place centre features six learning zones and a full industrial kitchen with farm-to-fork meals. The centre's educators undergo 200 hours of professional training to meet the MindChamps Champion Gold Standard. The centre was opened by Australia's Minister for Health and Medical Research Brad Hazzard and MindChamps founder CEO David Chiem, with plans to expand to 100 centres across Australia within three years.

site_title: The Accidental CEO
summary: Linda Jackson, the first Englishwoman and third woman to lead a global car company, has propelled Citroën to record sales under her watch. She rose through the ranks after a chance job at Jaguar and later became the finance director of Rover in France. Jackson's customer-focused approach has been key to the brand's success, prioritizing comfort and making everyday features like storage spaces a priority. Despite criticism, she has introduced innovative features like a Starbucks cupholder in the C5 Aircross. Jackson is now navigating the disruption of electric drive and driverless technology, embracing the challenge and viewing it as an opportunity for growth.

site_title: Mona Lisa graces Louvre's Leonardo show in virtual 'tete-a-tete'
summary: The Louvre's Leonardo da Vinci retrospective features 11 of the Renaissance master's paintings, excluding the Mona Lisa, which is instead showcased in a virtual reality experience. The virtual reality, created by HTC Vive Arts, allows viewers to interact with the painting's subject, Madonna Lisa del Giacondo, in a 360-degree environment. The experience reveals details of the painting's layers and sfumato technique, and includes a final sequence of Leonardo's flying machine. The virtual reality experience can be downloaded through VIVEPORT and is available until February 24.

site_title: China drawing up plan to replace Hong Kong's Carrie Lam: FT
summary: The Chinese government is drafting a plan to replace Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam with an "interim" chief executive by March, according to the Financial Times. The replacement would cover the remainder of her term, and leading candidates include Norman Chan and Henry Tang. The move comes amid ongoing protests against Beijing's tightening grip over Hong Kong, sparked by Lam's introduction of extradition legislation. Lam's resignation has been floated as a possible solution to ease tensions, with some lawmakers suggesting it could lead to a "restart" between the government and the people.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, Peugeot in merger talks to create US$50b firm: source
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot are in merger talks, potentially creating a US$50 billion firm. Carlos Tavares, PSA Group CEO, would lead the new company, while John Elkann, FCA chairman, would become chairman. Other possibilities are being considered. The deal would unite two major European automakers, Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot, and create a significant player in the global automotive market.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates coverage on Centurion with 'buy', S$0.52 target price
summary: DBS Equity Research has initiated coverage on Centurion Corporation with a "buy" call and a target price of 52 Singapore cents. The analyst cites the company's resilience and stable revenue generation, even in crisis times. Centurion's PBWA segment has maintained high occupancies, and its expansion plans are expected to boost operating income. The analyst also notes opportunities for asset divestment in the UK market, which has seen significant property valuation increases. However, downside risks include regulatory changes and economic volatility.

site_title: Oil extends gains despite weak demand outlook
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with Brent crude reaching $61.67 a barrel, up 50 cents or 0.8%, despite a weak demand outlook. A surprise drop in US crude inventories and potential market-supporting action by Opec and its allies offset concerns. West Texas Intermediate crude settled 26 cents higher at $56.23 a barrel. Analysts attribute the gains to a possible tropical depression in the US Gulf coast region and a supply pact among Opec and its allies.

site_title: Mentorship, trust and respect in succession planning
summary: Established company Soilbuild is grooming its second-generation leaders to succeed its first-generation leaders through a mentorship structure. The first-generation leaders can provide guidance by identifying areas for the second-generation to take charge of, creating a win-win in company culture. The relationship between the two generations is built on mutual trust and respect, allowing for the continuity and growth of the business in a complex and globalized environment. This approach enables the company to adapt to constant disruption and innovation, ultimately propelling it forward.

site_title: Trading halts: Perennial Real Estate, Yanlord Land, United Engineers
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings, Yanlord Land Group, and United Engineers have requested trading halts on Tuesday pending announcements. Perennial shares gained 1% before the halt, while Yanlord shares traded flat and United Engineers shares rose 2.3%. The halts come after Perennial's 50% joint venture filed a lawsuit against former Sakae Holdings director Andy Ong.

site_title: Australia: Shares propped up by miners, New Zealand flat in thin trade
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,670.40, boosted by mining stocks like BHP Group and Rio Tinto, which gained 0.4% and 1.2% respectively, driven by firmer commodity prices. Financial stocks also rose, while healthcare stocks fell 0.2%. New Zealand shares were largely flat, trading almost unchanged.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Tuesday as heavyweight mining stocks benefited from firmer commodity prices, although negative commentary from some annual general meetings weighed on the healthcare and consumer sectors.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU drops 5.1% to 2.365 S cents on enlarged unit base
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 5.1% drop in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.365 Singapore cents, primarily due to an enlarged unit base after a private placement. Despite this, distributable income from operations rose 5.7% to S$59.7 million, driven by strong performance at Suntec City, MBFC Properties, and Southgate Complex. The company's overall committed occupancy stood at 99% for its Singapore office portfolio, with Suntec City Office expected to continue performing well.

site_title: Deutsche Bank considers job cuts of at least 10% in rates unit
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering cutting at least 10% of jobs in its rates unit, a division that has struggled with low profitability. The move is part of the bank's efforts to cut costs and make the unit more profitable. Despite the potential job losses, the bank plans to maintain a significant operation in the unit, which employs hundreds of staff. A review of the unit is ongoing, with findings expected to be presented at the bank's investor day in December.

site_title: Singapore cloud market to reach US$3.6b by 2023, says report
summary: Singapore's public cloud computing market is projected to reach US$3.6 billion by 2023, with a 20% compound annual growth rate, according to a Google Cloud study. This represents a cumulative impact of US$31 billion on the country's GDP, equivalent to 1.7% annually.

site_title: Demand for HDB resale flats held firm in Q3 as prices edged up 0.1%
summary: Demand for HDB resale flats remained strong in Q3 2019, with 6,264 transactions, a 12% decrease from the previous quarter. Prices edged up 0.1% compared to the second quarter, snapping a four-quarter decline streak. The government's recent policy initiatives, including enhanced housing grants and bigger loan limits, are expected to sustain interest in HDB flats in the long term. Resale transactions are expected to reach 22,000-24,000 units this year, with prices potentially trending between -1 and 0% for the year.

site_title: Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency faces new hurdle from G-7 nations
summary: The Group of Seven nations has expressed concerns that Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency poses international risks to the monetary system and financial stability. The G-7 working group recommends that no global stablecoin project, like Libra, should begin operation until the legal, regulatory, and oversight challenges are addressed. The Libra Association has committed to working with regulators, but the project faces sharp regulatory scrutiny amid concerns about its potential to destabilize the global financial system and erode national control of monetary policy.

site_title: ECB will implement stimulus package but review welcome: French central bank chief
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will implement its September stimulus package in full despite public disagreement, according to French central bank chief Francois Villeroy de Galhau. A broader review of the bank's policy framework is welcome, with Villeroy calling for clarification on the symmetric nature of the inflation target to prevent misinterpretation. The ECB's decision follows a rare public disagreement, with several Governing Council members criticizing the move, and comes as incoming ECB president Christine Lagarde prepares to review the bank's policy framework.

site_title: Long-haul, fuel efficient jets underpin demand at Las Vegas air show
summary: The National Business Aviation Association's annual corporate aircraft show in Las Vegas highlights the demand for long-haul, fuel-efficient jets amidst slowing global economic growth and trade tensions. New models offering longer ranges and amenities are driving deliveries, with expected 7% growth in 2020. Industry analysts, however, remain cautious, citing uncertainty in Europe and the US, and predict a cyclical decline in deliveries as economic weakness manifests.

site_title: No stone left unturned: the burden of compliance in fighting money laundering
summary: Singapore has introduced stricter rules for the trading of precious gems and gold, as part of its efforts to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The new Precious Stones and Precious Metals (Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing) Act requires dealers to register with the Ministry of Law, maintain records, and carry out due diligence on customers. Politically exposed persons and high-risk customers must undergo enhanced due diligence. The law also mandates the reporting of certain trades and the screening of suppliers. Dealers and lawyers express concerns about the burden of compliance, citing costs and potential customer resistance to due diligence.

images.alt_text: Under the brand-new Precious Stones and Precious Metals (Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing) Act, dealers must keep records, carry out due diligence on customers, and report certain trades in eight precious metals and alloys, as well as six precious stones: diamonds, sapphires, rubies, emeralds, jades and pearls.

Hong Kong's Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group, which has three branches here, says the chain has not seen large cash transactions or suspicious transactions that need reporting. But, erring on the side of caution, it has appointed staff members - including one in Singapore - as anti-money laundering reporting officers.

site_title: Money FM podcast: What you can expect from Starbucks' new Mobile Order & Pay feature
summary: Starbucks has launched its Mobile Order & Pay feature at 32 Singaporean locations, aiming to connect with local customers through various touch points and innovations. The new feature allows customers to order and pay for their Starbucks items using the mobile application. Patrick Kwok, General Manager of Starbucks in Singapore, discussed the new feature, but no specific details or conclusions were mentioned in the article.

site_title: UrbanMatch aims to 'matchmake' home buyers, sellers
summary: UrbanZoom, a Singapore-based proptech startup, launched UrbanMatch, a digital "matchmaking" service for home buyers and sellers. The platform uses artificial intelligence to provide personalized, recommended homes based on buyers' criteria. Verified home sellers and exclusive listing agents will post their properties on a curated, private list, which will be sent to buyers through automated WhatsApp messages. The goal is to simplify the home-buying process and provide a more efficient, user-friendly experience.

site_title: Singapore to double down on digital growth: Iswaran
summary: Singapore will continue to invest in its digital economy despite economic uncertainty, with Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran announcing plans to support digital growth. The government aims to build skills capabilities through education and industry training, while also strengthening its value proposition in the digital space. New initiatives include launching a call for proposals for 5G operating licences and a platform to connect Chinese "deep-tech" companies to the region.

site_title: The 2020 CFO - navigating uncertainty with agility and clarity
summary: The 2020 CFO faces immense pressure to navigate uncertainty, mitigate risk, and deliver strategic value in a rapidly changing business landscape. CFOs are expected to leverage their unique position to drive analytical insights, performance, and transformation across the business. They are well-positioned to lead digital transformation efforts, adopting Big Data analytics and AI to streamline operations and promote data awareness. To create strategic value, CFOs must craft digital roadmaps, implement next-generation technologies, and prioritize talent acquisition and capacity-building, ultimately fostering a strategic partnership and ownership of organisational capabilities.

site_title: Govt will stand by workers facing difficult transition: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assured vulnerable workers facing a difficult transition to an uncertain future that the government will stand by them and ensure their well-being. He warned that if workers lose jobs, it could lead to societal divisions and a loss of confidence in the nation. Lee emphasized the symbiotic relationship between the ruling People's Action Party and NTUC, highlighting the party's commitment to advancing workers' well-being and future.

site_title: Oil short-sellers' gloom deepens with price stuck below US$55
summary: Hedge funds have become increasingly pessimistic on oil, with bets on a West Texas Intermediate crude rout rising 7.6% in the week ended Oct 15 and nearly tripling since mid-September. US stockpiles surged, and crude refining plummeted, driving prices below $55 a barrel. China's economic growth slowed, and a trade war with the US is expected to keep energy demand low, further exacerbating bearish expectations. Short-selling of WTI crude increased to 114,709 contracts, while long bets edged lower, indicating a shrinking net-long position.

site_title: Japanese emperor to proclaim his enthronement to the world in ancient ceremony
summary: Japanese Emperor Naruhito, 59, is set to proclaim his enthronement in a centuries-old ceremony, marking his official change in status to the world. The ceremony, attended by dignitaries from over 180 countries, will take place on Tuesday at the Imperial Palace's Matsu no ma, following a brief enthronement ceremony in May. Emperor Naruhito, the first Japanese emperor born after World War II, will wear traditional robes and headdress, and declare his enthronement from a pavilion with ancient treasures. The event comes after Typhoon Hagibis killed at least 80 people in Japan.

site_title: DBS to be first Singapore bank to act as settlement agent for China bonds
summary: DBS Bank has been granted a settlement agent licence by the People's Bank of China (PBOC), making it the first and only Singapore bank to hold this licence. This allows DBS to trade, settle, and provide custody for China's interbank bond market instruments on behalf of foreign investors. The move expands access to the US$13 trillion Chinese onshore-bond market, the third-largest globally. The licence also enables DBS to conduct trades and hold a Type-A licence, typically held by large global banks.

site_title: Hong Kong's AMTD may throw hat into Singapore digital banking ring
summary: Hong Kong's AMTD Group is considering applying for a digital banking licence in Singapore, following its successful digital banking launch in Hong Kong. AMTD's CEO, Calvin Choi, sees Singapore as a regional gateway to Asian markets and aims to serve more Asian customers. The move is part of AMTD's expansion plans, which also include a joint venture in Singapore's property market. Other firms, including Ping An Insurance, Standard Chartered Bank, and Singtel, are also interested in securing a digital banking licence in Singapore.

site_title: Time running out to get off Amazon's addictive cloud French minister warns
summary: French junior economy minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher warns that time is running out for Europe to wean itself off Amazon's cloud services, calling them "a soft drug" due to their global reach and affordability. The US company's dominance in the cloud computing market, with 30% market share, raises concerns over data security and access to corporate data under the US CLOUD Act. Previous attempts to build a "sovereign" cloud have failed, and Pannier-Runacher warns that Europe risks losing control over its data if alternatives are not found within 24 months.

site_title: Swiss puts A220s back in service after engine forces grounding
summary: Swiss airline has resumed flights with its Airbus A220 jets after grounding them due to a "serious" engine problem that forced a London-Geneva flight to land in Paris. The carrier cancelled about 100 flights for inspections of Pratt & Whitney engines, with full operations expected to resume on Thursday.

site_title: Brazil police target leader of Bolsonaro's party in political scandal
summary: Brazil's federal police raided the home of Luciano Bivar, head of President Jair Bolsonaro's far-right party, in a probe into a campaign financing scandal. The Social Liberal Party (PSL) has been accused of nominating fake female candidates to divert public funds, a tactic allegedly used by some parties in Brazil. The scandal has tainted Bolsonaro's presidency, with his former aide Gustavo Bebianno and tourism minister Marcelo Alvaro Antonio charged in connection with the scheme. The raid comes amid growing tensions between Bolsonaro and the PSL.

site_title: World's first major co-living fund seeks US$825m in pledges
summary: DTZ Investors and co-living developer the Collective have launched the world's first major co-living fund seeking $825m in pledges. The fund aims to invest in 6-10 projects in London, with a portfolio value of $1 billion over 10 years, offering 8-10% returns. The venture seeks to capitalize on London's high house prices and loneliness among renters, with its first investment set to be a 222-room building in Harrow due for completion in 2021.

site_title: Warning Turkey, Trump authorises sanctions and slaps steel tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump has authorised sanctions on Turkey's leaders, reimposed steel tariffs, and ended talks on a trade deal, amid Turkey's deadly offensive into Syria. Trump said he is prepared to swiftly destroy Turkey's economy if leaders continue down a "dangerous and destructive path." Sanctions and tariffs were imposed in response to Turkey's incursion, which has resulted in the release of many ISIS detainees. The US has also pulled troops out of northeastern Syria, with around 150 Americans remaining at a southern Syrian base.

site_title: EU will fight 'until last hour' to stall US Airbus tariffs
summary: The European Union will fight until the last moment to dissuade the US from imposing tariffs on EU goods, including cheese and wine, in response to illegal EU subsidies to Airbus. The US Trade Representative has given the green light to slap tariffs on $7.5 billion worth of EU imports, set to enter into force on Friday. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom said Brussels will keep pushing the Americans to freeze the tariffs, but negotiations are ongoing to avoid escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up but caution keeps traders in check
summary: Asian markets rose but investor caution prevailed as optimism over the US-China trade deal wore off. Despite a mini agreement between the two countries, details were light on, and Beijing called for further talks before signing. The pound rebounded after reports of a Brexit deal taking shape, boosting sterling. Equity traders struggled to build on the news, with analysts labeling the deal a "holding action" and warning that progress on key issues had not been made.

site_title: Should Isetan have disclosed offer for its Wisma Atria stake?
summary: Isetan Singapore faced criticism for not disclosing its potential sale of Wisma Atria to YTL's Starhill Global Reit (SGReit) after a non-binding expression of interest was received. Isetan shares surged 10% following the news, but the company's reticence sparked concerns among shareholders. The Japanese retailer is reviewing the offer, which values Wisma Atria at over S$290 million, and has not entered into a definitive decision or agreement. The delay has raised questions about Isetan's long-term strategy and its ability to unlock value in the company.

site_title: JLC Advisors' Jeffrey Ong faces more charges
summary: Jeffrey Ong, managing partner of JLC Advisors, faces 26 charges, including the most serious criminal breach of trust (CBT) offence, for allegedly misappropriating US$4.85 million from a client's account. The charges stem from a settlement involving Airtrust (Singapore) and Wrangwell Limited. Ong also faces forgery charges for making illegal copies of bank statements to deceive a lawyer into believing the funds were still intact. He is being remanded and the next court appearance is set for Nov 25.

site_title: Human guinea pigs to board world's first 20-hour non-stop flight
summary: Qantas will operate the world's first 20-hour non-stop flight from New York to Sydney, with scientists and medical researchers on board to study the effects of ultra-long-haul travel on humans. The flight will test Qantas's Project Sunrise, which aims to launch direct commercial services from cities like New York and London to Sydney. Researchers will monitor the physical and emotional toll of the journey, including jet lag, fatigue, and sleep disruption, with the goal of developing new remedies and treatments to alleviate these symptoms.

site_title: Daimler asked to recall hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles
summary: Germany's federal transport authority KBA ordered Daimler to recall hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles due to excessive emissions, a move Daimler described as a "six-digit figure" recall. The recall comes after years of controversy over the "dieselgate" scandal, with Daimler contesting involvement. This marks the latest action against the auto giant for breaking emissions rules.

site_title: Swiss Air grounds Airbus A220 jets after finding engine faults
summary: Swiss Air has grounded its Airbus A220 jets due to technical faults with the Pratt & Whitney-manufactured engines. The airline suspended flights while carrying out inspections, leading to multiple cancellations. The issue comes after an engine failure on July 25 during a flight from Geneva to London. Swiss is discussing the problem with regulators and manufacturers Airbus and Pratt. As of September 30, Swiss had 29 A220 aircraft, with 20 of the A220-300 model and nine of the smaller A220-100 variant.

site_title: China's 500 million NBA fans face loyalty test
summary: China's 500 million NBA fans are divided over backing the league amid a controversy sparked by a tweet by Houston Rockets' general manager supporting Hong Kong protests. Despite the backlash, many fans are torn between their love for the game and a desire to support China's sovereignty. The NBA has played a significant role in popularizing basketball in China, with the league having a near-universal household recognition. If the US league becomes ostracized, the Chinese Basketball Association (CBA) could potentially fill the gap, with some fans already showing interest in supporting the CBA.

site_title: Coffee Cachet
summary: Bacha Coffee, a Moroccan-themed cafe, has opened at ION Orchard in Singapore. The 30-seater cafe is styled after the 1910 Dar el Bacha Palace, with brass and silver accents, and features an extensive collection of Arabica coffee beans. Servers are dressed in traditional Moroccan attire, adding to the exotic ambiance. The cafe also serves pastries, including a recommended lemon tart. However, tea is not available. Bacha Coffee is located at #01-15/16 ION Orchard.

site_title: Mixed news flow grabs spotlight ahead of talks
summary: US-China trade talks will continue to influence investors until the end of the week. Mixed news ahead of talks, including reports of China's potential soybean purchases from the US, drove a volatile session. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) ended near flat at 3,089.48. Other market news includes Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index and Chinese banks struggling with Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Formula One team boss fined for calling steward 'stupid'
summary: Formula One team principal Guenther Steiner was fined 7,500 euros and warned about his future behavior for calling a race steward "stupid" and "idiotic" after his team's driver Kevin Magnussen received a five-second time penalty for rejoining the track incorrectly during the Russian Grand Prix. Steiner's tirade was deemed to have caused "moral injury" to FIA officials, leading to the penalty. The incident occurred two weeks ago at the Japanese Grand Prix, where Steiner was hauled in front of a hearing for his behavior.

site_title: PM Johnson to set out post-Brexit law and order drive in Queen's Speech
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will outline his post-Brexit plans in the Queen's Speech, announcing 22 new bills to reform the justice system, including tougher treatment for foreign criminals and sex offenders, and protection for victims of domestic abuse. The speech, set to be delivered by Queen Elizabeth, comes amid controversy over Johnson's handling of Brexit and allegations that he is misusing the Queen for political gain. The speech will be subject to debate and votes in Parliament, potentially destabilizing Johnson's minority government.

site_title: Ranbaxy tycoon brothers under arrest in India
summary: Indian authorities have arrested brothers Shivinder and Malvinder Singh, tycoons of the Ranbaxy generic drugs giant, over allegations of siphoning off $337 million from the Religare financial group. The brothers, who lost billions in the past decade, are accused of diverting funds to companies with no financial standing. They were detained separately and charged along with three other top executives. The detention could speed the fall of the Singh dynasty, which built up Ranbaxy into India's largest pharmaceutical group. The brothers deny wrongdoing and have launched a counter-action against the investigation.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as Trump says trade talks 'going very well'
summary: Asian markets rallied as US President Donald Trump reported that China-US trade talks were "going very well". Trump's comments, combined with optimism over Brexit talks between Britain and Ireland, boosted investor confidence and led to gains in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Shanghai. The developments eased concerns about a prolonged trade war and its impact on global markets, with investors hopeful that a trade truce could delay tariffs next week.

site_title: Number of China's ultra-wealthy slips in 2019
summary: China's number of ultra-wealthy individuals dropped to 1,819 in 2019, a first decline in 21 years, according to the Hurun Report. The decline is attributed to traditional sectors like manufacturing and real estate, which suffered due to high levels of toxic debt. However, a younger generation of entrepreneurs made their way up the rankings, with 39-year-old Colin Huang becoming the first self-made entrepreneur born in the 1980s to enter the top 10. Despite the decline, China's super-wealthy were largely unaffected by the trade war with the US.

site_title: Odds favour Greta Thunberg for Nobel Peace Prize, but experts sceptical
summary: Bookmakers favor Swedish teen climate activist Greta Thunberg for the Nobel Peace Prize, but experts are more cautious, citing a lack of consensus on whether climate change causes armed conflict. Some experts, such as Henrik Urdal and Asle Sveen, question her age and the prize's focus on peace, while others, like Dan Smith, see her efforts as extraordinary and climate change as linked to security and peace. The 2019 laureate will be announced on Friday, with other potential winners including Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and organizations focused on freedom of expression and information.

site_title: ST Telemedia eyes controlling stake in US cloud service provider 2nd Watch
summary: ST Telemedia is acquiring a controlling stake in US cloud service provider 2nd Watch, expanding its cloud IT platform and allowing participation in the US market. Founded in 2010, 2nd Watch offers managed cloud services, including strategy consulting for IT infrastructure in hybrid cloud environments. Existing shareholders, including Madrona Venture Group and Delta-v Capital, will retain significant shares following the investment, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian initiates coverage on Penguin with 'buy', S$0.85 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on Penguin International Limited with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.85, citing favourable industry trends. The company, which builds and owns high-speed aluminium craft, is also involved in passenger ferry charter services and tour travel. As of the article's publication, Penguin shares were trading up 4% at 64.5 cents per share.

site_title: Wirecard raises long-term growth targets; analysts unconvinced
summary: German payments group Wirecard raised its long-term growth targets, now expecting a transaction volume of 810 billion euros and revenue of 12 billion euros by 2025. However, analysts questioned the company's ability to give a precise forecast for its business in five years' time, citing concerns over the "take rate" and potential declines in basic processing charges. Wirecard's shares fell nearly 5% despite the raised targets, with some analysts describing the guidance as aggressive. The company's CEO attributed the expected acceleration to organic growth and a strategic alliance with Softbank.

site_title: No more laughing their way to the bank
summary: The financial sector is undergoing significant transformation, leading to job insecurity and changes in the industry. Over 60,000 jobs have been cut worldwide, with European lenders struggling due to negative interest rates and a slowing economy. Despite this, the financial services sector in Singapore remains a growth market, employing 160,000 workers and expected to add 4,000 jobs this year. The sector's transformation is driven by digital transformation, with many banking professionals concerned that their job scope will be replaced by technology. However, interest from fresh graduates remains high, with top banks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB seeing an increase in applicants. The industry is shifting towards roles that require technology skills, such as software development, robotics, and big data analytics, and front-office roles, particularly private banking.

site_title: New on the menu: Could 'dark kitchens' gobble up Britain's high street restaurants?
summary: Dark kitchens, also known as "virtual" or "ghost" kitchens, are taking over abandoned properties in Britain, potentially threatening the high street. These no-frills kitchens allow chefs to cook and serve food directly to online consumers, bypassing physical stores. Experts predict the death of bricks-and-mortar restaurants and local jobs as online deliveries become the norm. However, fans argue that dark kitchens provide a new lease of life to abandoned properties and help small catering brands compete. The trend is already seen in cities worldwide, with companies like Uber and Wagamama joining the venture.

site_title: EU weighs tighter rules against dirty money, eyes new agency
summary: The European Union is considering tighter rules to counter dirty money, following scandals at several lenders. New rules could increase controls over sectors like financial services, gaming, and real estate, and may impact intermediaries like lawyers and tax advisers. The EU may also set up a new agency or beef up existing EU-wide agencies to oversee supervision powers. A final decision is expected in December, with some member states, like Estonia and Malta, opposing changes.

site_title: Leading from the front
summary: The ACES Awards recognized outstanding leaders in the industry, including Anthony Charlemagne Yu, president of Empire East, who believes in being hands-on and understanding the needs of his laborers. Cheong Fuit Foo, general manager of Nu Skin Malaysia, emphasizes the importance of adapting leadership styles to different circumstances. John Thomas Sneed IV, vice-president of Sykes Asia, stresses the need for leaders to be supportive and approachable. The award winners also highlighted the importance of discipline, hard work, and learning by doing in achieving success.

site_title: Equinor starts production from Norway's giant Sverdrup oil field
summary: Equinor has started production from Norway's Sverdrup oil field, a mega-project that will account for around one-third of the country's oil production at peak. The field, discovered in 2010, is expected to reach 440,000 barrels a day by next summer, representing a 33% addition to Norway's production. The project is valued at $5 billion and is expected to contribute $100 billion to Norway's state coffers over 50 years, providing a lifeline to the embattled oil-service industry.

site_title: Thai energy ministry sets March target to resolve Chevron dispute
summary: Thai energy ministry sets a March target to resolve a $2 billion dispute with Chevron Corp, halting arbitration after the US oil and gas major objected to paying decommissioning costs of $2 billion for infrastructure in the Erawan gas field. The ministry will make the "utmost effort" to reach a deal, with a 180-day time frame stipulated by law. Negotiations will focus on resolving the dispute, which has implications for other energy companies operating in the Gulf of Thailand, including Total SA and Mitsui & Co.

site_title: Ex-Snapcart chief eyes seed round in 2020 for new venture Shoplinks
summary: Ex-Snapcart chief Teresa Condicion plans to raise seed funding for her new startup, Shoplinks, expected to launch in mid-2020. Shoplinks will provide secure data sharing, data matching, and AI-enabled analytics platforms to brick-and-mortar stores and brands in South-east Asia, aiming to facilitate targeted promotions for customers. Condicion aims to democratize data analytics for smaller businesses, not just large retailers, and expects to have a team of 10 employees by the end of the year.

site_title: EU likely to respond to US tariffs with own measures
summary: The European Union is expected to retaliate against US tariffs on European goods, with German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas stating that the EU will impose punitive tariffs after obtaining World Trade Organization approval. The US had announced new tariffs in response to a WTO ruling that some EU subsidies to Airbus were illegal. European finance minister Olaf Scholz urged caution, emphasizing that trade conflicts are not in anyone's interest. The EU's response is seen as a necessary measure to protect its economic interests.

site_title: Aviva Investors launches sustainable fund in Singapore
summary: Aviva Investors has launched a sustainable multi-asset fund in Singapore, targeting 5% income yield and long-term capital growth. The Aviva Investors Sustainable Income and Growth Fund aims to provide long-term sustainable income for retirement planning, utilizing a portfolio of 80-120 securities from the MSCI All Country World Index and the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Bond Index.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asiatravel.com obtained a default court ruling in China for S$7.4 million against creditor Zhonghong Holding Co, after the company failed to pay S$2.65 million on a convertible note agreement. Meanwhile, Hoe Leong Corporation is proposing to sell two vessels for US$1.7 million to Allianz Offshore Shipmanagement, amid financial pressure and a statutory demand for S$5.7 million from UOB.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Fu Yu Corp reported a 10.7% year-on-year growth in profit after tax and minority interests for the first half of FY2019. The company expects continued revenue and margin expansion in new projects and benefits from the strengthening US dollar. With a sound balance sheet and positive operating cash flow, analysts expect Fu Yu to reward shareholders with higher dividends. China Sunsine Chemical Holdings is forecasted to report a decline in revenue and net profit for Q3 FY2019 due to pricing pressure and weak downstream demand.

site_title: Pine Capital makes board changes amid search for more directors
summary: Pine Capital Group, a Catalist-listed financial services firm, announced board changes in an effort to comply with the Catalist rules and code of corporate governance. Chan Wai Leung was appointed as an independent non-executive director, chairman of the audit committee, and member of the nominating and remuneration committees. Two existing board members, David Sarkis and Tomi-Jae Wanlun Tjio, were re-designated. The firm is seeking additional non-executive or independent directors to fill vacant positions and has suspended trading of its shares since March 22.

site_title: Retailers help heat up IPO activity in South-east Asia
summary: Retailers in South-east Asia are driving initial public offerings (IPOs) activity in the region, with investors seeking to capitalize on growing domestic consumption. Recent listings include AllHome Corp's US$248 million IPO and Dohome PCL's US$113.3 million Thai IPO. Central Group's planned US$2 billion retail arm IPO and Malaysia's Mr DIY's US$500 million IPO are also pending. This trend reflects the appeal of specialty store operators, which are less susceptible to e-commerce disruption, according to Credit Suisse's Ho Cheun Hon.

site_title: Navigating choppy economic waters
summary: Global trade tensions and the US-China trade dispute have led to uncertainty, dented consumer confidence, and business sentiment. Global economic growth is expected to slow down in 4Q 2019 but may stabilize in 2020. Vietnam and Thailand are emerging as regional winners, with Vietnam attracting significant foreign investment and Thailand offering tax incentives to attract companies. However, the long-term impact of "America First" policies and currency manipulation scrutiny by the US could compromise supply chain re-routing. Analysts warn of precarious economic outcomes, with forecasting challenging due to headline and political risks.

site_title: ACES go places
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) recognizes successful companies and individuals in Asia for their leadership and corporate social responsibility. The awards, conceptualized by the MORS Group, aim to promote sustainable growth and unite businesses across the region. The ACES Awards has a transparent judging process, with a jury comprising esteemed business leaders, and is open to companies and individuals with a registered business address in Asia. The awards have various categories, including Leadership, CSR, and Individual Leadership, with winners determined based on publicly available information, research reports, and past accolades.

site_title: Singapore hasn't entered recession yet: Indranee
summary: Singapore's economy is not in recession, according to Minister Indranee Rajah, despite a 3.3% annualized contraction in the second quarter. The government is monitoring conditions closely and will provide support measures if needed. Despite the US-China trade war affecting export-reliant Singapore, the government is accelerating plans to address massive infrastructure needs. Measures to boost productivity, innovation, and worker adaptation to technology will be included in the upcoming budget. Indranee also expressed support for Hong Kong and Asia's growth, citing the need for stability and economic growth to build a nation for the future.

site_title: Banking on digital: tapping the unmet needs of SMEs, millennials, and the gig economy
summary: Singapore has opened its doors to digital banking applicants from non-banking backgrounds, with 12 new players vying for 5 digital full bank and 3 digital wholesale bank licenses. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) aims to tap unmet needs, including SMEs, gig workers, and millennials. Digital banks will be expected to show a path towards profitability, a clear value proposition, and demonstrate how they will serve underserved needs using technology. The MAS has set guidelines for digital banks, including requirements for a 20% stakeholder with a 3-year track record in operating an existing technology or e-commerce business. The MAS aims to benefit customers, especially SMEs, and retain strong local anchors in the banking system.

site_title: HC Surgical Specialists posts 38% higher Q1 net profit
summary: HC Surgical Specialists posted a 38% increase in Q1 2020 net profit to S$1.2 million, driven by revenue from acquired units and subsidiary JLES. Revenue grew 27.9% to S$4.9 million, while employee benefits rose 19.5%. The company generated S$1.38 million in net cash from operations, a 56.2% improvement. Heliconia Capital Management invested S$5 million via convertible bonds, and HC Surgical plans to expand its specialist endoscopy practice in Vietnam.

site_title: Startup Snapcart's co-founder and CEO Teresa Condicion quits to start new venture
summary: Teresa Condicion, co-founder and CEO of consumer analytics startup Snapcart, has resigned to start a new venture called Shoplinks, effective September 30. Condicion led Snapcart's focus on automation and cost reductions, aiming to scale the company. She will utilize her experience to drive data innovation in the retail and consumer packaged goods industries with Shoplinks, which aims to provide secure data sharing, data matching, and AI-enabled engagement platforms. Condicion's departure comes amid differences on the company's direction, with co-founder Reynazran Royono taking over as CEO.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after Wall Street losses
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday due to falls on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.49% to 21,778.61. The broader Topix index also fell 0.42% to 1,596.29.

site_title: Elaine Bedell, CEO, Southbank Centre, London
summary: Elaine Bedell, CEO of London's Southbank Centre, shares insights on creating hit TV shows and live entertainment that transcend the small screen. She credits her past failure with a game show to refining her strategies, focusing on inclusive and diverse audiences, and delivering popular mainstream entertainment that appeals to all backgrounds. Bedell believes art should be accessible and entertaining, not just niche and exclusive. She emphasizes the importance of original ideas, well-execution, and audience feedback in creating successful shows, and is exploring new digital and interactive strategies to engage younger audiences and revitalize classical music.

images.alt_text: I'm optimistic about the future of live entertainment, because I think at a time when everybody is hooked to their screens and devices, which are never going to go away, we are ultimately social animals and respond well to experiencing things together as a community. ~ Elaine Bedell.

site_title: US: Wall St rises at open ahead of manufacturing report
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Tuesday, driven by gains in technology companies ahead of manufacturing data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 45.71 points (0.17%) to 26,962.54, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose. Investors are watching for signs of domestic demand, which could impact the world's largest economy.

site_title: HP to cut up to 9,000 jobs amid print unit woes
summary: HP Inc will cut 7,000 to 9,000 jobs, approximately 16% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring plan to boost sales growth and cut costs. The job reductions are expected to save the company about $1 billion by the end of fiscal 2022. HP also announced plans to reorganize its printing business, raise prices for non-HP ink cartridges, and sell its microfluidics technology to other industries. The company expects to return 75% or more of its $3 billion free cash flow in fiscal 2020 to investors.

site_title: ING names Erwin Maspolim as new Singapore country manager
summary: ING Bank has appointed Erwin Maspolim as branch manager of ING Singapore and network head for South-east Asia, effective October 1. He succeeds Catherine Low, who becomes regional head of lending for Asia Pacific. Maspolim has 25 years of experience at ING, including successfully closing over $25 billion worth of deals. He will oversee Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam. Low, who has held various senior roles, will oversee lending and transaction services, including sustainable finance. The appointments are subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: ING Bank on Wednesday announced the appointment of Erwin Maspolim as branch manager of ING Singapore and network head for South-east Asia, effective Oct 1.

site_title: DFS providing laid off workers with career coaching, counselling support
summary: DFS Group, a travel retailer, is providing career coaching and counselling support to approximately 500 laid-off workers. The affected employees were retrenched due to the company's decision to exit the duty-free liquor and tobacco business at Changi Airport. DFS has partnered with the Taskforce for Responsible Retrenchment and Employment Facilitation (TRREF), Workforce Singapore, and external outplacement agencies to offer support services, including job matching, retraining, and employability skills workshops. The company aims to help staff transition over the next few months.

site_title: Wealth of opportunities
summary: Henley & Partners CEO Juerg Steffen attributes the growing interest in investment migration to the desire for security, visa-free travel, and better education opportunities. Many wealthy individuals, including those in China, prefer to have multiple citizenships to ensure their families' security and future prosperity. Steffen believes that citizenship programs serve as "insurance policies" for these individuals, offering a sense of security and freedom. With over 300 staff in 30 offices worldwide, Henley & Partners has established itself as a leader in the industry, with Singapore emerging as a key market in the past few years.

site_title: British tobacco company chief to leave in wake of vaping slowdown
summary: British tobacco company Imperial Brands Plc announced that CEO Alison Cooper is stepping down, following a week after Tesco's Dave Lewis. Cooper, who led the company for nine years, cited a drastic slowdown in revenue from smoking alternatives and weak cigarette sales. The company warned that earnings growth had ground to a halt, partly due to a US crackdown on vaping. Imperial shares rose 2.4% following the announcement, amid concerns over financial transparency and commitment to smaller brands.

site_title: Contra trading adds flexibility to share trading
summary: Contra trading, a practice of buying shares without immediate payment, is being reevaluated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Contrary to its past portrayal as irresponsible, contra trading adds flexibility to share trading, allowing investors to sell shares for profit before payment. The practice encourages market participation and is relevant to Singapore's small market survival. The review of the proposed 5% collateral requirement on share purchases is seen as a positive step, as it may create an unequal playing field for retail investors. This move aims to balance credit risk management with market flexibility.

site_title: Facilities management industry mulls over climate change challenges
summary: The facilities management industry is addressing climate change challenges at the Architecture & Building Services (ABS) 2019 conference in Singapore. Keynote speaker Tony Khoo emphasized the need for practical solutions to hot weather and heavy rainfall. Minister of State Zaqy Mohamad launched a guide to Smart FM, which integrates technology into building management processes to increase productivity and improve occupant well-being. The conference, featuring 12 sessions and exhibitions, aims to drive the adoption of Smart FM and other sustainable practices in the industry.

site_title: Air France to offset daily CO2 emissions by next year
summary: Air France plans to offset its daily CO2 emissions from internal flights by 2020, investing millions of euros in projects supporting tree planting, forest protection, and renewable energy. The move aims to counteract the airline's climate impact, following criticism over its high carbon emissions. The company will also implement measures such as banning single-use plastics and recycling waste. This initiative follows France's plan to impose new taxes on plane tickets to fund greener transport infrastructure.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit Metroline trades bus garage for industrial property plus £18m
summary: Metroline, a UK subsidiary of ComfortDelGro Corporation, has agreed to sell its Alperton Bus Garage in west London for £25 million and buy an industrial property for £7 million. The transactions, worth £18 million, are expected to be completed before October 2021 and will not have a significant impact on ComfortDelGro's financials. The sale of the bus garage will result in a £16.5 million profit, while the purchase of the industrial property will be funded by internal resources.

site_title: China's forex reserves drop more than expected in September
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell $14.8 billion in September to $3.092 trillion, exceeding expectations. The decline is attributed to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates and asset prices. Despite this, the yuan rebounded 0.14% against the US dollar, and China has maintained control over capital outflows. Economists warn that China's economic growth risks slipping below 6% due to the ongoing trade war with the US. The US dollar rose 0.47% against a basket of currencies, and top-level trade negotiators from China and the US are set to meet on October 10-11.

site_title: Co-working lab and office for biotech startups to open in November
summary: A 15,000 sq ft co-working laboratory and office for biotech startups is set to open in November in Singapore, offering a suite of facilities and equipment worth millions of dollars. Launched by NSG BioLabs, the space aims to support growing life sciences companies by providing a high-quality and efficient environment for experimentation. The facility is partnered with Nest.Bio, a US-based venture capital firm, and will house companies such as Engine Biosciences and Acumen Research Laboratory, which are developing precision medicine-based therapeutics and molecular diagnostic tests, respectively.

images.alt_text: NSG BioLabs' co-working laboratory and office will offer biotech startups a full-suite of facilities with millions of dollars' worth of equipment.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.2% to 7,421.18 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also increasing 0.3%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors. US stocks also reached fresh records, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: No force can shake China's foundation today: Xi Jinping
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping declared that no force can shake China's foundation, calling for stability in Hong Kong and unity among ethnic groups, as the country celebrates 70 years since its founding. Despite this, protests in Hong Kong continued, with demonstrators clashing with police and a protester reportedly shot in the chest. Xi emphasized the importance of the "one country, two systems" principle, but the unrest has raised concerns about his rule and China's grip on Hong Kong.

site_title: Gold extends push above US$1,500 in final hours before jobs data
summary: Gold prices surged above $1,500 an ounce as investors awaited the US employment report, which may signal a slowdown and lead to interest rate cuts. The precious metal has rallied this year due to the Fed's interest rate reductions and mounting economic weakness. Gold prices are heading for a weekly gain, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid trade tensions, the US House inquiry into President Trump, and Brexit uncertainty. Spot gold rose 0.3% to $1,509.39 an ounce, with silver also expected to gain.

images.alt_text: Gold pushed higher into the US$1,500s an ounce as investors ticked off the hours until the key monthly US employment report, which may add to mounting signs of a slowdown and stoke expectations the US Federal Reserve will be driven to reduce interest rates once again.
